name: Czesław Adam Siekierski
text: Author. – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa The question is known to everyone, so I will focus on the comment on this question, on its justification. It can be said with all responsibility that the situation on the milk market is in crisis. The milk market has always been sensitive, as even during the quota period there were also serious distortions, as evidenced by the years 2008-2009. After the elimination of milk quotas, the situation became complicated. Even before the quota was extinguished, milk producers had set out to increase production in order to have a stronger position in the freed market. In 2015, there were favourable conditions for increased production. It is understandable that each producer wants to increase its revenues, hence, under the above-mentioned favourable conditions, there has been an increase in production. Most farmers also have to finance the repayment of their loans.  The milk market is a global market and is therefore influenced by production, supply and demand in various regions and countries around the world. In 2015, production also increased in the United States, Australia. It should be taken into account that significant stocks from 2014 and earlier years were also accumulated. Imports of milk and milk products by China have also decreased. At the same time, there has been no increase in consumption, which is probably contributed by the ongoing media coverage of the harmfulness of lactose to human health. Oversupply over demand has led to a very significant fall in milk prices, they are below the cost of production.  The situation on the European market is therefore puzzling, where just over half of the 420 million earmarked for intervention on agricultural markets was used as recently as last autumn. Commissioner Hogan has given a great deal of room for manoeuvre on the use of these funds to member states in this regard. We have always proposed greater flexibility for countries, as Commissioner Hogan has done. It can be said that, despite the various positive and very important actions taken at Commission and national level, the effects are very little visible. There is now an urgent need to strike a balance between supply and demand. However, there are no proposals for instruments that would lead to a reduction in production. The notion that farmers will do so voluntarily is not confirmed in reality. Farmers are defending themselves against bankruptcy by increasing production. A form of production reduction payment should therefore be used, while ensuring that farms are able to maintain their liquidity so that they do not take up the herd earlier and on a wider scale. The efforts of Member States and Commissioner Hogan to increase sales in third countries should be positively assessed, but at the same time the consumption of milk products on national markets should be increased, especially where it is relatively low. We are also thinking here of using the distribution of free food under the programme that the European Union has adopted in this area, or of increasing the distribution of dairy products to a group of people coming to Europe. The situation described above illustrates how dependent the European milk market is on the world market, on other external conditions, often of a political nature, such as the Russian embargo, or on far-reaching concessions to the detriment of agriculture in trade agreements concluded by the Union with third countries, where agricultural matters are often sacrificed for benefit in other areas of trade. The efficiency of the milk chain from milking to the consumer must therefore be improved in the first place. Many elements need to be improved in terms of vertical integration and the functioning of cooperatives as well, because there, too, various cooperatives are owned by members, the costs are borne by farmers. It is possible to increase efficiency as part of improving vertical integration.

name: Hans Hoogeveen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, it is a great honour for me, on behalf of the Netherlands Presidency, to address the European Parliament and to answer the question. The situation in the agricultural markets in many of the Member States is very difficult and severe, especially in the dairy sector, and the Council is fully aware of this situation and shares the concerns of the farmers who have to cope with these difficult problems. Yesterday, at the hearing of the Agriculture Committee, the dairy sector clearly conveyed a clear sense of urgency, although the views on how to solve the crisis were quite different. Notwithstanding the September 2015 package, mainly directed to the dairy sector, prices are still at a low level and lower than expected. Therefore, the Council continues to work hard to properly address the concerns of farmers and of the Member States, but of course it has to be done within the framework of the Common Agriculture Policy.  It is a European crisis which needs a European answer, but at the same time, the circumstances in different Member States differ from sector to sector and from country to country. You see an average increase of milk production of about between 5% and 6%, but that is not the case in every Member State so whilst stating that we need a European answer, at the same time we need flexibility for the Member States to implement measures which are suitable for the national circumstances.  It is also clear that it should be a joint effort, a joint effort by the Council, the European Parliament, the European Commission, but also by the producers themselves. It is clear that we have to find ways to reduce milk production within the European Union. And of course we took the decision in September 2015 for the package of about EUR 420 million, and of course it was done to directly support farmers and to see how we can leverage the supply and demand. Member States – and Commissioner Hogan will probably say something about it – are still implementing those measures. The Presidency has put on the agenda of every Council meeting the market situation and discussed with the Member States how to act.  In March, we took 16 additional measures, together with the Commission and the Council, and those measures relate to intervention measures, they relate to promotion measures, to exports, as well as the possibility for Member States to give additional state aid. Also, these measures still have to be implemented and implementation is under way, and of course time will tell whether those two packages are up to the task and to see whether or not we can level supply and demand.  As stated in the Presidency conclusions of March, the Netherlands Presidency keeps the developments of the markets under close review and will discuss it of course again at the June Council. It was also stated in the March conclusions that the Council has called on the Commission to consider the availability of additional resources, including the possibility of activation of the crisis reserve as a last resort, to support market measures at the appropriate time. That will be on the agenda of the June Council to be discussed by the Council, Member States and the Commission. But also at the last Council it was clear that many Member States have stated that if we are again going to take additional measures, they have to be linked to a reduction of milk production. They cannot be standalone measures, they have to be linked to a reduction of milk in the Member States by the producers themselves.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I apologise for being slightly late this morning. I welcome the opportunity to return to this House at a time of continued crisis in the agricultural markets in several Member States, but particularly in the dairy and pigmeat sectors. The situation in the dairy sector in virtually every Member State is acute, and the most recent price information available from the Milk Market Observatory (MMO) shows that the average milk price in the European Union in April was 27.62 euro cents per kilogram. This represents a fall of 11.5% since the same time last year.  The situation is, of course, not one confined to Europe, with global supply continuing to outpace demand, which is putting pressure on dairy products in particular and indeed on their prices. Experts in the Milk Market Observatory acknowledged at their meeting on Tuesday that some improvement in market sentiment was perceptible, against a background of slowed—down milk production in the coming months, and global demand remains healthy. However, they concluded that the market fundamentals have not really changed and that an improvement in the supply—demand equation remains absolutely necessary.  Despite my commitment to identify new markets and some encouraging export data, opportunities for increased demand are limited. Accordingly, we have to focus on supply. Before looking at the extensive range of measures which the Commission has put in place, I would like to reflect further on both the supply and demand sides of the equation. Milk deliveries in the European Union increased in 2014 and 2015 by 4.4% and 2.6% respectively but in the first quarter of this year milk collection grew by 7.2%. As a result, an additional volume of 2.6 million tonnes has been collected in just three months.  At a world level, milk production increased by 3.9%, mainly due to European Union production levels, and US production was up 1.2% in April, a lower figure than was expected. Production in New Zealand is expected to be down 2% for this year and Australia down 1.2%. Within the European Union the largest increases in volume in the first two months of 2016 were reported in the Netherlands (330 000 tonnes), Germany (300 000 tonnes), Poland (140 000 tonnes) and Ireland (110 000 tonnes). In percentage terms the largest increases have been in Ireland, Cyprus, Luxembourg, Belgium and the Netherlands.  On the demand side, the view of the MMO Economic Board at its meeting on Tuesday was that world demand remains dynamic, driven by butter and cheese. European Union export data supports this view, with dairy exports having increased by some 13% in the first two months of this year. There were particularly good figures for butter, which was up 17%, and cheese, 13.4%, and double digit growth in import data from China confirms its recovery. The Union has increased cheese exports to all top ten destinations up to February 2016, principally by 9% to the United States. Significant increases of butter exports have been reported from Morocco, Canada and Turkey, while skimmed milk powder exports have also increased significantly in Algeria, Indonesia, and indeed in China it is up 71%.  As you know, the 109 000 tonne ceiling for the buying—in of skimmed milk powder at fixed price was reached on 31 March and a tender was operated on 19 April. The maximum buying—in price was fixed at the level of the intervention price and some 27 000 tonnes were additionally bought into intervention. On 20 April, buying—in at fixed price resumed under a double ceiling, up to 218 000 tonnes, which was reached yesterday. In view of this, the Commission will be proposing a further increase in the ceilings up to 350 000 tonnes. When I spoke in this House last month about the broader European agricultural sector, I outlined the extensive set of measures that I proposed last March. Today I will focus on some of the specific measures that are providing significant support to the dairy sector and without which the current situation would be considerably worse. Last year, total private storage aid and public intervention support covered 2.8 million tonnes of product, at a time when European production had increased by 3.5 million tonnes. We have now effectively deployed all of the tools available in the CAP toolkit, including the activation of Article 222 of the CMO, a measure that was never previously used. In that regard, I want to commend the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development (AGRI) of this House for the organisation of last evening’s hearing on the use of this instrument. I hope that those who participated now have a good understanding of the measure and its potential, which I believe should not be underestimated. This measure is part of a comprehensive and broad—ranging response and can play a significant role. It encourages action towards greater market balance in the dairy sector. In order to encourage use of this tool as an effective contribution to the crisis, I have met with COPA-COGECA and the European Dairy Association (EDA) and I will discuss the issue again with COPA-COGECA this week. This is a voluntary instrument and its use depends ultimately on producers. It is now genuinely in the hands of dairy farmers who may, if they so wish, join forces and collectively decide to reduce production. Before turning briefly to the question of the role of the MMO, I would like to say something about the use by Member States of the EUR 420 million targeted aid package, of which 66% was directed at the milk sector. Based on the most recent information reported to my services, just 56% of this money has been spent. The rate of spending is, of course, likely to be accelerated in the coming weeks and Member States have been reminded that they have until the end of next month to spend all of the money or to forfeit it.  Finally, I want to acknowledge the role the MMO is playing in ensuring timely and robust data to all stakeholders in the sector, including Members of this House. Transparent price information and other related data is essential for forward planning and ensures that decisions are taken on the basis of accurate information. The Milk Market Observatory provides a unique portal, where the most comprehensive possible set of market data is available. The role of the MMO is to provide such data and not to substitute for the actions of the institutions. In conclusion, let me once again acknowledge the depth of the crisis that exists in the dairy sector. While this is not a crisis exclusively of our making, we have of course been badly affected by it. But producers must take responsibility as well for the continuing increase in production which I have just outlined and which, given current market conditions, is simply not sustainable. Despite the deployment of a range of available measures, I must emphasise that I can work only within the constraints of the legislation that is available, specifically in terms of the exceptional measures available. This was the outcome of the 2013 reform, in which Parliament and the Council reaffirmed the market orientation of the CAP. I look forward to Members’ ideas about how we can go forward and how we can continue to help the dairy sector.

name: Albert Deß
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner! Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the President-in-Office of the Council for The current market situation for milk threatens the existence of hundreds of thousands of dairy farmers in the European Union. We have a situation with the lowest prices: milk prices are reported to me from the Baltic States around ten cents, there can no longer be a dairy farmer, even at 20 cents. The Commission has intervened within its capabilities with regard to butter and skimmed milk and has also adopted a number of other measures, but these measures are not sufficient in the current difficult situation. We have a completely new situation and this new situation requires new measures. Commissioner, as you know, I do not think that the current intervention price system is effective. We need an ad hoc intervention system where the Commission has the opportunity to intervene earlier before prices are totally down. In view of the market imbalance, it is necessary, even for a limited time, to withdraw milk quantities from production throughout Europe. We should consider whether it is possible for every farmer to take a certain quantity out of production for a certain period of time. I do not believe in a voluntary measure! Only the weakest areas will be phased out of production here, and production will be expanded in other areas. In my opinion, the current situation is also being brutally abused by retailers and by large corporations. I am told that it is precisely now that these groups are using the situation to dictate new requirements to the legislators to farmers, and here too it is necessary for us to take action with antitrust legal measures. I am sure Mrs McGuinness will say something about this, she is working on this problem. However, we must also ensure that sales are increased. Here, Commissioner, an immediate measure would be to reintroduce butterfat support. I believe that we could re-house a few billion kilograms of milk here and replace other fats with butterfats, which would also be in the interests of environmental policy.

name: Paolo De Castro
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the crisis that has been going on for months in the dairy sector has taken on continental, if not global, dimensions. In view of this situation, the measures implemented so far have proved not only ineffective, but even in some cases counterproductive. This is demonstrated by the worrying data on production levels in recent months which, despite the constant fall in prices, continue to rise. The latest analyses prepared by the Commission show an increase in production in the first three months of the year, on an annual basis, of 7 %. Last autumn's EUR 500 million package was followed last March by the proposal for national, or even local, measures that can be implemented on a voluntary basis in the Member States and financed by them from their own resources. Instead of exploiting the potential for coordinated use of resources to curb European production, the idea of identifying measures to be managed at member state level is proving to be unsuccessful and has the direct consequence of the risk of a progressive renationalisation of the CAP, the only policy that has always been a factor in European integration. In order to deal with a continental crisis, we therefore need instruments with a European dimension, which will make the Union regain the role that has long distinguished it. The time has therefore come for the Commission to implement an urgent procedure without further delay in order to arrive as soon as possible at the definition of a legislative act which, on the one hand, provides for emergency measures to contain supply and, on the other hand, responds with structural responses that improve crisis management instruments and mitigate the impact of price mode on our production chains. If no time had been lost, and a crisis which had been evident since the beginning of last year had been denied for a long time, but if the measures repeatedly indicated by this Parliament had been put in place, our farmers would not be in this situation, Commissioner.

name: James Nicholson
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I welcome this debate this morning but the reality is, of course, that no government, no politician and certainly no Commissioner is all powerful, that we can solve the problem all on our own.  We had a debate last night in the Parliament and in the committee, and I have to say I found it one of the most pessimistic debates I have ever sat through. I listened to the experts and I listened to the Commissioner. There was only one real truth and that was by the Deputy Director—General, Mr Korte, who said the situation was not good, and there was no need to beat about the bush. That is what your own Deputy Director—General said last night, Mr Commissioner. Now I have to say to you, we have to recognise some realities here. It has been mentioned this morning, if you have an increase this year of an extra 6% or 7% of milk, a market has to be found for that. The producers in the Member States who are producing this milk need to be aware that they are continuing to stoke the fire, and that they are continuing to make the problem worse not better, and certainly voluntary cutbacks will not work. And let us be honest, some Member States are positively going out encouraging their farmers to produce more milk regardless – they are going for market share. There is only one way that this can be resolved, which is that a lot of good farmers and family farms are going to hit the wall.  There is a big difference between producers and processors, and there are processors in serious difficulty as well. We have a situation where the retailers, Mr Commissioner, are getting away on a coach. They are laughing all the way to the bank at the cost of the producer, of the farmer and the sweat of his brow in the production of that milk. What we need is to sit down and to get some new ideas on the table. We are not going to go forward and it is not good enough, Mr Commissioner, in the depth of this crisis to blame producers; it is not good enough. I remember the reform coming forward from the old Commission. I remember Commissioner Fischer Boel and I remember we fought her hard when she talked about her soft landing and we asked her where it was going to be. Where is the soft landing today for those who the banks are going to foreclose on, Mr Commissioner? And to the Council I have to say it is time you woke up in Council. You cannot continue to do what you are doing.  (Applause)

name: Jan Huitema
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Madam President, if we in the European Parliament and from the sidelines say that we are going to improve the market situation, we are offering false hope. The most important thing is to give farmers and gardeners tools to strengthen their competitiveness, first of all through better regulation. It is precisely by giving space to innovation and entrepreneurship and regaining confidence in farmers that we reduce costs and can meet societal challenges. In addition, we need to look at how we can improve the farmer's position in the chain and focus on tools that enable farmers to absorb their risks and price fluctuations. There is an interesting initiative in Ireland. A fund has been set up from which dairy farmers get money when prices are very low and where they return when prices are high.  Let's face it: it's been a long time coming, even though there are signs of recovery. However, it is a thorn in my side that the differences between the Member States in the EU are widening because everyone is going to go about their business now that agricultural prices are low. Real action is therefore needed at both national and European level. Better regulation, a level playing field, but no empty cheques to the farmers' accounts.  For example, the Netherlands is working on structural measures. Specific elements of this plan are subject to the necessary, but that is not the point. Haste is required, but there is no point in frapping plans. Solutions must be sought from within the sector in order to improve the competitiveness of the farmer and horticultural.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President. Mr. Hogan, it's a lie that the crisis depends on the ranchers. The crisis has been caused by the European institutions, and it is they who have to put the solutions in place. Mr Hoogeveen, it is not true that the crisis will be resolved by the States, that more state aid is needed. The crisis is European and needs European responses. More state aid to resolve the crisis means condemning farmers and ranchers from southern states, impoverished European Union states on the periphery, impoverished and intervened by the troika. There are political solutions. It depends only on political will, and I will point out some proposals: reduction of compulsory production, balancing supply and demand, redistributing production among producers in the European Union, prices that cannot be below production costs, sustainable production models, looking at the internal market. This crisis responds to the abandonment of public policies, shows that the international market is a mirage and that they have used it to condemn dairy farmers and peasants and leave them totally vulnerable in the hands of industry and distribution. Be responsible for once.

name: Maria Heubuch
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner, you said that you did not cause the crisis. Yes, you may not have caused the crisis yourself, but the crisis was foreseeable and this crisis was warned, years ago. It is, of course, very sad now that this late realisation – which I think everyone now has – that there is too much milk on the market, that our farms here in Europe have to pay and have paid for at a loss of more than EUR 30 billion – money that is also lacking in rural areas. This has actually brought about a dramatic structural breach, both economically and humanly, and we have watched and have not taken the warnings seriously. It is true that ordinary decisions have now been taken at the last Council meeting in March in order to reduce the volume. But now we have the end of May, and we are no further. On the contrary, the situation has become even worse. Why? Because there is still a lack of political will to reduce production and tackle overproduction. We discuss here again and again in circles. It is then again about intervention prices, a bit of support here, a bit of support there, opening up new markets. After all, I am glad that everyone is now talking about reducing quantities, but the dairy industry and its interests are always well-considered. I wonder where the farmers who stand in the barn, milk the cows and keep the farms afloat will stay. The processors do not have the same interests as farmers. We now also have good findings and studies that show that the value added of the dairy industry is not reflected in the milk price – there is nothing to be seen. It is the eternally same concerns that hinder effective steps to reduce volumes. As has been said several times now, the reduction in quantities must be binding, it must be Europe-wide. And we can't just play the ball back to the yards and say: Now you're voluntarily producing the milk, you've caused it.

name: John Stuart Agnew
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, our House of Lords in the United Kingdom had a debate and discussion on this, and evidence presented to them suggested that sectors that have not benefited historically from direct payments are better prepared to operate in world agricultural markets, and the pig and the poultry sectors – along with a horticultural sector – were ahead of other sectors in terms of having business knowledge and recording systems to understand their production costs. They are market-focused, producing for a defined market in close collaboration with their supply chains. It is all about markets. Public policy should not aim to control prices but to help farmers develop resilience to manage the risks. The point is that government should really only be thinking in terms of helping to overcome catastrophic and extreme events on farms, such as floods or drought, and not meddling in pricing or controlling supply and demand. One—off support packages can help to counter the impact of extreme natural disasters or catastrophic events that are beyond individual farmer’s control. However, the 2015 dairy support package, for example, after endless discussion, etc., resulted in a payment of just GBP 1 500 to each UK dairy farmer. Really that is just tokenism. Farmers have always been willing and able to expand production to match increasing demand. A willingness to recognise that there is too much milk is now required.

name: Philippe Loiseau
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Madam President, as we had predicted, the end of milk quotas has plunged the sector into a deep crisis - one more, you will tell me - when everything is sacrificed on the altar of free trade. The learned predictions of incompetent technocrats, who explained that everything would be better after, proved to be false. Surprising, isn't it? You wanted an unregulated deal. Regulation, however, is the only viable policy to reduce unstable price fluctuations. Why make decisions that ultimately only benefit the industrial sector? The policy of market deregulation has inexorably led us to this crisis, as for other agricultural sectors. Yet you persevere again and again in this dead-end path. Incredible! The increase in volumes since the end of quotas causes prices to fall, and the export price is not enough to compensate for the losses. Even Germany is affected: the end of quotas has caused a drop in revenues to 27 cents per litre, with a forecast of 22 to 23 cents. In France, the price per litre is now 28 cents. A third of German dairy farms have disappeared in ten years. All professionals in the sector are asking for a regulatory policy. The "milk" package adopted last year, although insufficient, made clear observations by recognising the problems caused by the end of quotas and the serious imbalances between producers, industrialists and distributors. Do not stay at the simple stage of the observation, take courageous decisions: the decisions that are necessary, unlike those that have accelerated the disappearance of peasants and the increase of the phenomenon of concentration. What is the cost of your deregulation policy to European taxpayers? How many jobs are lost? How many rural areas are at risk? I really believe that the record of your criminal policy needs to come to light.

name: Diane Dodds (NI).
text: – Madam President, I do not think it is an understatement to say that the dairy sector in Northern Ireland is facing the worst crisis in a generation. Let us be clear, the impact of this crisis is much more than an imbalance within the supply chain and low prices. As a last resort, many family farms are turning to banks to borrow even more money, with some facing the really difficult situation of not being able to continue. This week in my local farming paper I have noticed five dispersal sales. This is the bitter reality of a prolonged crisis and a failure to act early – real families, real people, losing their homes and their livelihoods. Currently, we are sacrificing as well our long-term ability to produce milk by failing to act against unprecedented market volatility and political actions which are outside of farmers’ control. This is the third event this week that I have attended on this issue. We have rehearsed the problem. We have reviewed the actions taken so far, including that poorly—targeted aid package which many members have not even spent. Supply control and market support are two proven methods. Why are we ignoring these? Commissioner Hogan and the Council have indicated that we have used all the tools available in the CAP toolkit. Clearly the CAP is broken and farmers in Northern Ireland are demanding root and branch review or are simply just saying that Europe cannot help anymore.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, we have a great deal of pleasure in meeting again. We now see each other twice a week, but that doesn't mean we're not getting any better. Unfortunately, while we are gathered here, farms will fall. I am thinking in particular of those who have invested recently, those who have modernized and young farmers. We are in the process of seeing those who could yet be the future of European agriculture leave. The CAP was the most credible and elaborate of the Union's policies. Today we are giving the spectacle of a policy that is unraveling. We need more Europe in this crisis. We cannot afford to store milk and butter for years. So we have to limit production. Why not offer farmers over the age of 65 to stop production so that younger farmers can make way? That is a lead I am giving you, because I strongly believe that it is by reducing and limiting production that we will have the cheapest and most effective policy.  (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: "blue card" question. Madam President, dear colleague, do you not think that now is the time, when the Commission is going to launch a special programme in this area, to support producers with funds that enable them to maintain their production, despite the low prices at the moment?

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: "blue card" answer. Madam President, dear colleague, thank you for your question. Perhaps it is worth remembering that, during the reform of the CAP, I was the one who proposed a system of support for farmers who, in times of overproduction, would lower their production in an attempt to turn the market around. I'm still on that line. Parliament had adopted it, the Council and the Commission refused it: it was up to them to take responsibility today.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, it was clear that the abolition of milk quotas without a new regulatory organisation would lead to the crisis through overproduction and, therefore, mechanically, by falling prices. Today, the European Union is at the foot of the wall and you have finally decided, Commissioner, to use Article 222 of the single CMO. This is good news, but it is not enough, because the success of the implementation of this article will depend on the ability of producer organisations and cooperatives to impose themselves both in the reduction of production and also in the negotiation of prices or in the orientation of production towards humanitarian solutions. A good way, Commissioner, to facilitate their tasks, to these organisations, is to set up financial aid at European level for withdrawal. As a rural elected official, I very much hope so because, without it, we will see new waves of desertification of our countryside, and I believe that is not in anyone's interest.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. In the dramatic situation of the majority of milk producers in Poland, as buying-in prices fluctuate within 20 euro cents per litre, the government has prepared an aid scheme for them. In simple terms, it consists in the possibility of decommission of the payment of the second and third instalments of the penalty for overproduction of milk if the producer documents the difficult financial situation of his holding. Milk producers in Poland have already paid the first instalment of this penalty of around EUR 70 million, while the remaining amount to be paid is around EUR 100 million. Polish budget has fully borne the cost of milk penalties, as the European Commission has deducted EUR 170 million from current payments to our country. I hope that the European Commission will quickly agree to this form of aid to milk producers in Poland, as the economic vial of thousands of dairy farms, which have undergone profound modernisation in recent years, is under threat, using pillar II of the CAP.

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The situation on the dairy market has been extremely tense for our dairy farmers for about 15 months and there is no end in sight to the crisis! Commissioner Hogan, you have announced that no further money from the EU budget is to be expected from the European Commission. I cannot be satisfied with that! Any application of Article 222 in the Member States requires co-financing by the European Commission. There are two things we really need to tackle immediately: you have announced that we will increase the amount of intervention for skimmed-milk powder. If they go to 350 000 tonnes, that will certainly be a great relief for the market. Secondly, I call on you to start the discussion on the opening of the Crisis Fund in 2017 now. You say that we need six months. Then we should now do it, that it will be available at the beginning of 2017. If not now, when, Commissioner? Please act!

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, the crisis has been installed and with it evidence. Successive revisions of the CAP, all of which are market-oriented, all aimed at destroying all public instruments of production regulation, are the basis of an overproduction that threatens thousands of producers with pure and simple bankruptcy. Much has been said of a supported reduction in production, but how will this reduction be made? On a voluntary basis? With national or Community support? And who's going to narrow it down? Are the countries that have been the main victims of the European Union's neoliberal policies once again the poorest and most dependent countries?  Let's be serious! Let's look at reality! Let us not be afraid to acknowledge the error! Dairy quotas, whether with this or another denomination, represent the indispensable way to guarantee decent prices to those who produce and, at the same time, a food sovereignty to each national State.  Abandoning everything to the voracious markets will only benefit those who are at the basis of all these reforms, that is, the large agri-food industry that continues to accumulate profits at the expense of production.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to This has been said on several occasions: the situation is dramatic and there is hopelessness, partly because the Commission is not responding adequately. You said that the Commission is not to blame. Yes, that may be the case, but you yourself, Commissioner, have denied for a good year that there is a crisis at all. Now you have launched a helper program, which does not seem to work. Now you are betting on intervention and further export. We can see that this policy does not lead to anything! If we do not really radically change the way we do not change our milk policy now, the crisis will be prolonged! I suspect that you and the Council were playing on temporary terms: if more businesses give up now, the amount will automatically decrease. If we bet on this, then we will finally break the neck of many small businesses and many farms in the peripheral seductive slacks or in the mountains. That's why I find this playing on time and this "let's see if voluntary measures work" cynical. These voluntary measures will not work. We need to put a lid on production. Current and immediate production stop at all farms, and then we have to reduce the quantity of milk. You have again talked about success rates in exports. If we continue to play the game, we will only have success because we are bringing down prices on the world market even further with dumping prices. We are still harming our colleagues in the global south. We must not continue to play this game and we must concentrate on the European market. Hence the question: why do we not run programmes, why does the Commission still refuse to make a clear origin label, for example, so that, for example, milk from mountain regions can be particularly marketed? Why do you continue to rely on intervention when Mr Le Foll has said in the Council that there is abuse? Can you say anything about this, is there abuse of intervention? I believe that we must send out a clear signal today, not just talk about reducing quantities, but put something on the table so that we can really intervene immediately and ad hoc in the market now and not wait another six months. Then it will be too late for many colleagues. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Ulrike Müller (ALDE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Häusling, you are certainly aware of the report of the ife Institute commissioned by the Green Agriculture Ministers in Germany. You always talk about reducing milk quantities. Are you right that, if we have a reduction in quantities, there will also be a reduction in cattle numbers? It is quite clear from that opinion that even such a market adjustment premium would actually bring benefits on the market.

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her report, I do not fully understand you now, because in recent years your group in particular has always pushed for the liberalisation of the market and rejected anything that amounts to some kind of intervention and a reduction in quantities. And that you are now saying that we need these programmes to buy out – you also said yesterday that we should pay slaughter premiums. Slaughter premiums are instruments that belong in the moth box of agricultural policy. Nor do I believe that we are now buying farms out of production, but all farms are obliged to reduce the quantity of milk, and we must not force certain farms out of production. This will not be a measure that we can be responsible for.

name: Giulia Moi (EFDD).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, today we are discussing the crisis in the dairy sector in Europe. We are looking for measures to provide support, we are planning funding, but the truth is that we are killing our farmers and our farmers in particular, forcing them day after day to fall under the weight of economic measures that are strangling them. The Eu ropean Union continues to promise aid, but what farmers need is urgent regulatory action, not subsidies. While we continue to waste time, the data describe to us a reality that we can no longer ignore: 600 suicides in France, 500 in Germany, 400 in Belgium. In Italy the situation is no better: Italian farmers and breeders on my island, Sardinia, cease their activity every year because they are unable to continue. Saving our farmers, our farmers and protecting the food safety of our citizens is our task. To guarantee Europe the first place in the world for the production of excellence should, above all, be in the interests of all of us. If we do not do this, ladies and gentlemen, we will no longer be able to talk about suicides but about murders, for which the inadequate policies of this Europe will have been the only ones responsible.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Europe must choose which side it is on. The Council, the Commission and this Parliament must choose which side they are on, whether on the side of farmers or multinationals and the large-scale distribution of milk. I am with the producers and with the citizens-consumers. I say yes to compulsory labelling of origin for all dairy products, stop the sanctions on Russia which have caused enormous damage to this sector, with the consequent embargo. We need real aid to produce better, not to produce less. How can you tell Italian producers to produce less milk if 85 million tonnes of milk arrive in Italy every year from abroad? How can you say that? Our stables are closing, which means hitting the agri-food sector in the heart, it means destroying this sector: 1 500 stables closed last year. I hope that the Italian Government will be able to defend this sector and not suffer in silence the wrong choices that are being made here and have been made in the past.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE).
text: –  Madam President, I want to start by referencing remarks about suicide, because it came up in our committee last night and it has been said today and I just want us to be very sensitive to the mental health issues that cause suicide and to ask Members to be very careful of the language and the signals we give out, and indeed to ask Member States , including my own, to put in place measures to help people who are in a very bad place at the moment, and I include in that plea the banks who may be putting undue pressure on farmers. Dairy farmers are not fools. They are watching this debate even though they are milking their cows this morning. They now have heard a very stark message from the Commissioner and from this debate. The situation on the milk market is acute. The tragedy is that when they decide to cut back production it is almost after the event. So we really do need to make sure that these measures work, Commissioner, and to be ready to do more if they do not.

name: Paul Brannen (S&D).
text: – Madam President, against the backdrop of relentless problems in the dairy sector, I strongly believe that European dairy farmers need a realistic policy approach which could be based on the following four pillars. First, the power of consumers must be harnessed in support of struggling dairy farmers by making smart use of labelling, awareness raising and campaigning. Labelling can help ensure that a fair price is paid to the farmer. Second, the CAP should boost its risk management instruments designed to even out the effects of market volatility. Participation in income support tools should be encouraged and supported with contract-based supply chain relations with the retailer. Third, we need to facilitate the development of farmers’ groupings through cooperatives or producer organisations. United farmers are stronger farmers. And fourth, it is time the EU started seriously exploring viable economic alternatives to dairy production as it becomes obvious that we cannot continue with the current levels of milk output. I invite the Commission to consider these four approaches in the interests of fairness in the food supply chain and the legitimacy of the wider common agricultural policy.

name: Richard Ashworth (ECR).
text: – Madam President, the industry has been caught in the perfect storm, and there are two actions the Commission can take. Short-term we appreciate Commissioner Hogan’s efforts to help the industry through a very deep crisis, although we must acknowledge and accept their resources are limited, and would come nowhere near offsetting the losses incurred by the industry. But longer term, there is a very great deal that we can do. The likelihood is prices do not stay depressed for ever. When we look to the future we must encourage and support the industry to become more productive, more competitive, more resilient. We must help it address market balance and to build new markets. This is not something the state does to industry, it is something the industry has to do to help itself. Only by fixing the roof when the sun is shining can farmers prepare and protect themselves from future crises.

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE).
text: Madam President, milk producers are now selling at a loss. In the face of the new human tragedies that are looming, ladies and gentlemen, we have a duty to equip ourselves with intelligent protection instruments to prevent and deal with crisis situations. The angelism of the European Union cannot make commercial self-armament a dogma. I am thinking in particular of the negotiations on a free trade treaty with New Zealand. The same applies to competition law and the prohibition of cartels. So let us be pragmatic and dare to institute European mechanisms for adjusting supply-to-demand. In the logic of Article 222 of the CMO, without excessive nostalgia for quotas, it seems to me sensible to entrust producer associations - PDOs - with the task of regulating volumes delivered on the basis of regulations enacted, depending on the circumstances, at European level. An acting instrument, an insurance system conditioned on compliance with such guidelines would be likely to motivate farmers and effectively restrict their milk production, which would compensate for the momentary loss of income. The scheme would be financed by a levy in high-priced conditions. Mr President, Commissioner, there is still time to prevent the human tragedies announced. We are waiting for a European response, not a renationalisation of agricultural policy. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation))

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, I largely agree with what you said today. But I have one question: do you not think that the european Union's common policy is also intended to find solutions for the sale of dairy products and products in markets other than the internal market?

name: Jean Arthuis (ALDE)
text: "blue card" answer. "Definitely. Having said that, as far as the common agricultural policy is concerned, we must prepare for the next revision. Export markets must certainly be developed; it's an imperative. But all countries will be concerned about food self-sufficiency, and, therefore, I believe that there is a major urgent need to reconcile producers and consumers here in Europe, and to make an intelligent application of competition law and cartel law. Otherwise we risk triggering unbearable human tragedies.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, it is beyond comprehension how the Commissioner can blame the farmers – the farmers who have had a half day’s work done before he turned up late for this meeting. If he wants to blame someone, then go after the supermarkets who are making an absolute killing out of this. Go after the processors. The financial markets are making money out of this. The banks are making money out of it. As he knows, although he did say he does not read the Irish newspapers, the cooperative directors are making money out of this – nine million between nine of them over the last two years. He is making money out of this – EUR 300 000 – yet he cannot turn up on time. At the meeting the other day he claimed that there was something being done about the Russian embargo, how they are talking but they are not really listening. Was he listening or did he hear what Donald Tusk said when he could not sleep last night, and he put out on Twitter: ‘EU stays the course on Russia, including economic sanctions’. It is time to get up a bit earlier, Commissioner. It is time to talk to people like Donald Tusk. It is time for a bit of joined—up thinking and it is time that the people who get up early and do the work get the money – and not people like you.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – Thank you, President. Dear. commissioner, dear colleagues, the milk crisis is not new. It has been going on for a long time. This reveals significant delays in the development of measures to overcome it. While cabinets are discussing what to do, farmers are affected, and processors, traders often try to profit from the situation. I have said many times that only mandatory and not voluntary regulation of milk content can help to solve the milk crisis.  Another important problem is the uneven and unfair system of direct payments. After all, their purpose is to reduce the negative impact of market fluctuations on the performance of the farmer and thus stabilise their incomes. However, Lithuania is one of the countries with the lowest direct payments. This makes our farmers compete on unequal terms, and the costs are similar. I therefore call for an urgent review and harmonisation of the direct payments system.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, colleagues! Milk is indeed one of the most important agricultural sectors for the European Union. Its production accounts for about one-sixth of total agricultural production and it is natural that the milk crises at one time or another affect its producers, and the biggest problem here is milk buying prices and bankrupt farms. As Mr Turne has just said, Lithuanian dairy producers are in most small countries, three quarters of the milk market is placed on farms that keep fewer than five cows, and the buying prices dictated by processors do not fit today within the limits of common sense. Nineteen euro cents are taught per litre of milk in Lithuania. The purchase price fell by seven per cent in a month. In my meetings, people ask if it will happen that our grandchildren will see cows not without fields, but only in photos. All the more so because payments to Lithuanian farmers are significantly lower than for farmers in other countries – European countries. As a means of keeping milk buying prices, existing milk quotas have served well enough. Somehow it is strange that we are leaving when no quotas are required, but it is necessary to strictly protect the external borders of the European Union, I mean migrants, then we are introducing those quotas, and where they are needed – we are taking and eliminating, thus causing another crisis. In this situation, it is not only the financial payments that milk producers need, but also temporary tax and loan relief. It is necessary to review the legal provisions of processors and milk suppliers. Define the possible price range as low as possible in contracts with processors. Apply lower taxes to dairy cooperatives, look for ways and means, not wait.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the dairy crisis is demonstrating the extent to which the European Union nowadays has little effective measures to stabilise agricultural markets after so much futile effort at crazy liberalization. This sector faces a complex problem, where price volatility, the scarcity of instruments at European level to cope with this volatility, the drop in demand combined with increased supply and imbalances in the food chain form an explosive cocktail that has in the end plunged this sector into a major crisis that has already cost EUR 500 million to the Community budget.  The implementation of concerted production reduction measures by producer, association and inter-professional organisations, as proposed by the European Commission, would only have the expected effect if undertaken by most Member States, including the countries most responsible for overproduction. I believe that it should be a joint initiative, supported by Community funds, to achieve the expected response.  The latest package of measures announced by the Commissioner leaves the search for solutions in the hands of each country's budgetary initiative, and I do not think this is the most appropriate route. I would urge the Commission and the Council of Ministers to seek common solutions, which should go through strengthening contractual relations, without limiting them to the farmer-industry binomial, and also extending them to the commercial distribution sector, in order to end abusive practices, of which the farmer is the main victim.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, all the findings go in the same direction. For the past 18 months, we have been living with a price regime that continues to decline and is abnormally low, being lower than farmers' production costs.  So, of course, the regulation of dairy production on a voluntary basis, as proposed, is a small step in the right direction, but it is largely insufficient, because there is a need for mandatory regulation, with sanctions for Member States that do not play the game. Indeed, if it is voluntary, there will always be those who will not play the game and who, of course, will annihilate the efforts of those who will want to play it well.  Better activation of Article 222 is fundamental, with reasoned competition. But clearly, today, excessive liberalisation does not work. It may seem archaic to argue for a return to quotas, with of course adjustments for certain countries - I am thinking of Italy, in particular, which had a quota far too low compared to the high quality production it needs. However, redeveloping quotas to reflect economic reality is the only viable solution. Quotas have worked for 25 years. Since they were abandoned, it has not worked. I may be archaic, but I am archaic in arguing for the return of milk quotas.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR).
text: – The situation on the milk market is difficult and is mainly due to supply-demand imbalances. In recent years, European farmers have invested in european funds and developed milk production. Milk quotas have been abolished since April 2015 to stabilise the milk market. The difficult situation is exacerbated by the Russian embargo and the decline in demand from developing countries, particularly China. The rate of decline of the dairy cow population in Poland is one of the highest in the European Union, milk buying prices in Poland are lower than the European Union average by about 8 percent and have recently fallen to as much as 17 euro cents per liter. I call on the Commission to remission the penalties imposed on Polish producers amounting to more than EUR 161 million, and I have a question about what action the European Commission intends to take to support farmers in this dramatic crisis on the milk market.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, the end of the milk quota system, the Russian embargo and the falling demand for dairy products introduced a new scenario. Producers have, rightly, concerns since the milk and milk products market is going through a very difficult period. The European Commission remains vigilant in its response to crisis, however its short—term measures such as public intervention, private storage and temporary state aid, are insufficient. I firmly believe that ambitious revision to address long-term structural problems on the milk sector, as well as other agriculture sectors, are the only way to correct our internal market failures. Production should be based on single markets which require at the same time to be more efficient, more innovative, better organised and more competitive. In this sense, I also believe that new markets can be conquered with products with high added value.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής (
text: GUE/NGL). Madam President, Commissioner, farmers in Greece, in addition to the problems of the dairy sector throughout Europe, are also suffering the consequences of the memorial policies you impose and even the lack of protection of products of origin in the European Union's agreements with other countries. Now that we're talking about selling the feta cheese, Greece's most famous source product, in the agreement with Canada and the United States.  Through the OECD Memorandums and Toolkit, you intervened in the Greek, domestic milk market, supposedly to reduce the price of the consumer, which resulted in the introduction of questionable quality milk into Greece, while the price remained high and Greek production decreased.  Today, with the new Memorandum, you are again calling through the OECD for the use of milk to be disconnected for the formulation of another PDO product, such as yogurt. As a result, Commissioner, the livestock sector in Greece is in extinction, livestock farms are closing down and I ask you: is this the solution you are promoting to the problem we are discussing today?

name: Herbert Dorfmann (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Commissioner! I sometimes wonder what we actually want. If we continue with the policy as before, we will continue to produce milk in Europe, we will only produce it somewhere else. We will produce it where it is cheapest and where it is easiest. But there will be a battlefield. Many abandoned farms will remain, especially where milk production is more difficult, in far-flung areas and, above all, in mountainous areas. If we want to keep milk production throughout Europe – and I think that is also an objective, because milk production, especially in the mountains, also means the preservation of agriculture in and of itself – then we must change policy. Then you have to become more imaginative, then you have to support, for example, in the mountainous area those companies that produce high-quality products and are thus able to generate higher added value, which is the only chance for those companies. If, as the President-in-Office of the Council has said, a new package is being implemented, then it would be very appropriate for us to discuss this time in this House as well. Then perhaps we would be a little more imaginative than when the last 500 million were issued.

name: Michela Giuffrida (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the crisis in the dairy sector is no longer an emergency, it is becoming structural. The figures that bear witness to the danger of this dimension of the crisis are truly alarming.  In the first two months of 2016 production increased by more than 7 % and of course the production realities most affected are those of small producers who, in countries such as my own, Italy, are 50 % of farms and have no hope of surviving in this context, which is not competitive and is totally unregulated. It is precisely the survival of these products that we must think about, and it is in their interests that a series of actions must be taken as soon as possible to ensure the survival of the sector. It is necessary to manage the offer, yes, finance the actions to control prices, but it is important to act on the communication. The origin labelling of the raw material, information campaigns and promotion are fundamental measures to give the consumer the freedom to choose and enhance products that use national milk and producers to focus on the quality of their milk.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, no nostalgia for a return to quotas, but it is clear that the transition from one regime to another cannot be left to chance. No control: today thousands of businesses are close to bankruptcy. There is no capacity to conquer new markets, there is no capacity for new products, there is no capacity to recognise the areas of production, which are essential for the consumer to choose. Within the system of the 28 there has not been an important step, where those products, those minimum productions, which safeguard minimum territories, difficult territories, were recognized. In the speeches by my Italian colleagues, I heard – although a speech was made in German, but he is an Italian colleague – the recognition of those small areas where important actions are carried out that are more environmental than agricultural but which have an agricultural recognition and great environmental recognition. Here, the transition is fast: no governance capacity of this step leads us today to the loss of thousands of jobs and large companies that had history and tradition over time.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: " Madam President, Mr. Hogan, I will say very clearly, you are not to blame for this crisis. Since I've been in politics, which is more than 25 years, and even before that, the European Union has always had problems with oversupply of milk and butter and I've always read about it, and as an economist I've always wondered a little bit.  What are the solutions, because the crisis is there, what are the solutions? Certainly one of the solutions is greater production of dairy products. We should encourage higher production of dairy products, because it is evident that we have a significant increase in cheese exports to various countries outside the European Union. We need to maybe look at the Dutch model which is just interesting and gives some news and help to milk producers.  Also, what I want to emphasize is certainly the possibility to help those milk producers who want to give up production financially to repurpose production or simply stop production. And that may be one of the measures we can make.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Madam President, this is a 20 cent milk photo on a supermarket shelf in Asturias this week. Because it looks like we're either bringing you objective evidence of what's going on so that your face of shame drops directly, or you're going to keep patting yourself on the back and looking the other way. Do you know how much it costs a Spanish farmer to produce milk on average?  37 cents. This, in addition to being an absolute disgrace, is called dumping and is illegal. In Spain we produce 25% less than we consume. However, our farms and industries are forced to close. An example: this week we were gathered and reunited with workers from the Lactalis plant in Valladolid. More than 80 workers who are going to stay on the street, who are going to be fired and more than 110 farms that are going to have to close. In our country close about 65 dairy farms per month. If this is the situation now, what will happen when the ATCI monster is approved? Ladies and gentlemen, if this is the Europe you want to build, a Europe that is socially and territorially unbalanced, we will not allow it. This is a scam, and I remind you that in this Parliament we are, first and foremos say, to serve our people.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, the dairy sector is under increasing pressure because of the increase in milk, but also because there is not a large enough market that has the capacity to absorb all production. Unfortunately, farmers in Romania and beyond are put in a position to sell the litre of milk well below the production price, which will certainly lead to the bankruptcy of the whole sector. The Commission must step up its efforts to address the major differences in the price of milk that comes out of the farm gate and the one on the shelf by strengthening the farmer's position in relation to processors and retailers. It is not normal for it to come out with up to twenty eurocenters, and on the shelf to find it with more than one euro. It must also find effective mechanisms for voluntary reduction of milk production and support for farmers to shift to the meat sector or other sectors.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D).
text: – As we have seen, market liberalisation in the dairy sector has unfortunately not produced the expected results that so many of us had hoped for. There are several reasons for this, but I would like to highlight two. One is the issue of unfair commercial practices in the food chain, in the market chain, in the production chain, and the other is the issue of different VAT rates, i.e. added tax rates. I believe, and I have repeatedly tried to suggest for consideration, that a uniform reduction in VAT on foodstuffs, especially basic foodstuffs, would be a good wish in the European Union. If only because there are two consequences, they are all evidenced by embassic facts. One is that budget revenues would increase in all countries, as vat fraud would be significantly reduced. At the same time, consumers would benefit from this, given that food would be cheaper everywhere. I therefore propose, Madam President, that we think and consider that food in the European Union should be subject to vat of up to 5%.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, the situation in the dairy sector in Croatia is dramatic, as almost 2000 milk producers have failed in a year. The purchase price of milk has fallen to around 23 euro cents, self-reliance in milk production has drastically decreased, and every other litre on the market is from imports. Milk and dairy products of poorer quality come at dumped prices in Croatia and destroy domestic production.  UTPs in which retail chains lead the main role must be edied from a European level. Farmers cannot be left to the market when fair conditions do not rule the market. The Commission has put in place intervention measures, but these are insufficient. In my view, the emergency purchase price of milk should be ensured, which must not be lower than 30 euro cents, as everything else is a disaster for milk producers.  The dairy industry should be stopped from blackmailing producers and prevent them from bringing producers into a slave relationship. While some of the money was being placed in Panama, farmers were paying money into the budget. Let's save them with their money! (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure)).

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI)
text: blue-card question. – I would like to ask Mr Petir and all Christian Socialists too: why do you not want poor people to have cheap milk? The milk should be cheap. If the milk is too cheap, some producers go bankrupt and the price of the milk goes to the rational level.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear colleague, agricultural producers engaged in milk production also deserve to have a decent life, which means they have to earn the optimal price. According to some estimates, the optimal price for production is 30-40 euro cents.  In order for them to make money, and for consumers to buy this milk at an affordable price that is of excellent quality, we need to bring order to the market. So we need to put an end to the blinkers, the accumulators and the pre-cups, and that's why I'm advocating that we intervene, to stop those who destroy milk production with dumped prices, as well as those who destroy both producers and consumers through unfair trade practices.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – Madam President, there is an urgent need to invest in European mechanisms to protect the income of milk producers and to strengthen support for regions where the dairy sector is of crucial economic, social and environmental importance, coupled with a productive fabric with greater capacity to withstand price shocks, such as the Azores. The Azores produce 30% of milk in Portugal. The sector has rejuvenated and modernised and is now struggling with future prospects. Aid must go to those in need, we heard yesterday at COMM AGRE and this is what the European institutions have an obligation to guarantee. This is a European problem that requires a strong European incentive to commit all production to the supply control objective. Otherwise, there will always be those who will continue to increase production and aggravate the situation of those with the least geographically based competitive advantages. And we need measures to ensure fair prices for production in the face of shameful pressures from large areas.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE).
text: – We all agree that the Commission is not the culprit in the situation in its current composition, but the measures taken on the Commission's proposal in the European Parliament, such as the abolition of quotas, also the Russian embargo, certainly result in excessive milk production and, on the other hand, a drastic fall in prices. The Slovenian farmer lost about 600 to 800 euros in one year. The European Union's action is ... to compensate him around 30 euros. This cannot be a substitute to cover the loss of this revenue, but is necessary by more serious measures – in particular measures which will restrict production and also establish normal fair relations in the retail chain. If we do not act immediately, the following will surely happen: first, the failed farmers in the mountainous, mountainous areas will continue to perish the collapse of farmers who are not vertically linked to the dairy industry, to trade. And farmers in countries that do not have the resources to support farmers with the state budget will fail. We do not want such a Europe, and in the case of such a Europe, milk production will move into flat areas and the bushes will grow in mountainous areas. We must act now, not wait until 2020.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I speak on behalf of every milk Portuguese, from Minho to the Azores. It's people I'm talking to, not just cattle. There must be national and European measures to combat the impact of the end of some dairy quotas, against which Portugal has been. We will have to have national measures and European measures, increased de minimis support, labelling with the designation of origin of milk, the defence of a free market, but a fair market, a market without dumping practices that distort its rules.  We have to have a deal-row that ends the madness of milk promotions at forty cents a litre, and less, at the expense of producers. We must have an intervention with the distribution, which cannot abuse a dominant position to crush prices by imposing on the products values for lack of alternatives from producers.  The problem is in place and public. We will certainly have the good intervention of the European Commission as well.

name: Peter Jahr (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her We agree that prices are life-threatening. It can also be said that prices are also a naughty one, they are a general attack on the whole profession in the European Union. What is one of the causes? I would say that we – and I deliberately say 'we' – have failed to adapt contractual relations and crisis management within the supply chain to the new market economy conditions in the dairy sector. In other words, the quota is gone, but we still have the old instruments, and that simply cannot work. That is why I have a few questions for ourselves and also for the profession: why do we pay every litre of milk the same? In this sense, compliance with the contract also means that those who deliver too little usually pay a contractual penalty, and those who deliver too much can not receive the contract price, but the daily price. Why do producer groups not have a special right of termination in the event of price changes by dairies? Why do farmers actually supply milk to dairies where there is definitely no sale? On the other hand, however, what we also need is immediate action. Commissioner, we need subsidies for measures that reduce quantities. Perhaps you can quickly explain to us what is possible under Article 222. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Martin Häusling (Verts/ALE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Jahr, I remember your speeches two years ago, when you were so happy to welcome the dairy sector and farmers now have all the market-economy opportunities to finally live up to the free market economy and to make real money. In hindsight, would you see that it was a mistake to totally liberalise this market, and would you say: I was wrong, we have to go back to instruments that also allow market management?

name: Peter Jahr (PPE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I could also reply to the farmers: I never promised you a rose garden. So we have said that we want a market economy, but we have not promised paradise. Once again, we have failed to adapt crisis management to these new market conditions, and we are now talking about a crisis, but we must of course also improve contract management.  The supply relationships – farmers, dairy, market chains – are still designed as if we had the quota, and that is the huge contradiction that is now becoming very clear. We also do not get a signal to farmers about the price: please, produce a little less! We put everything in a big pot, stir three times, and everyone gets the mixed price. That cannot work. That is why we need crisis instruments, but they too need to be re-adapted. Albert Deb has already said that when it comes to interventions and also to measures that reduce quantities, it is not as a permanent measure, but as crisis management.

name: Annie Schreijer-Pierik (PPE).
text: Madam President, yesterday we heard that two thirds of the profits of the cooperatives go to business. Multinationals must therefore also be made aware of their responsibility and also contribute to solutions. The money has to go to the farmers, too.  In addition, we must move away from the idea of voluntary production restrictions for dairy farming, which was discussed at length yesterday. It simply requires non-binding agreements. Not through a quota system, but through a temporary European reduction in production of 5% for a period of, for example, three to six months, in order to regain the balance between supply and demand. Then the milk price can recover. Furthermore, farmers who want to stop their business should be given the opportunity to do so, without being left with sky-high debts. The blame is still the reason to keep going and the group has big problems. If we do this, we're going to kill two birds with one stone. Firstly, major social economic problems are being addressed. Secondly, production capacity is reduced. Finally, the marketing of butter fat will have to be supported. This generates EUR 3 billion. Mr President, finally, i am very sorry that Minister van Dam, President of the Council, is not here today. He is going to open a small business in the Netherlands today. I think this shows little respect for farmers and Parliament in this serious, sad situation. And that was the case last night.

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE).
text: Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has I would like to say thank you once again for being available to forest managers very early in the morning. We had a great discussion about sustainable forest management. Thank you again for working around the clock today. But now to the dairy sector: here too, once again, I really call for the alarm signals to be taken very seriously. Especially in the mountainous and disadvantaged areas, we have long since ceased to be able to produce to cover costs. Austria has always advocated maintaining quantity control, but was overruled in 2003. But we know, and we see – especially if we follow this discussion today – that it will not only work in liberalised markets. Our farmers have adapted, have fulfilled all these requirements of society. In Austria, for example, we now produce to a very high degree of GM- and non-GM, organic, hay milk production and much more. Action must now really be taken – origin marking. The dumping of the retail chains and much more, which really affects our farmers in production and which, of course, also leads to this crisis, must be remedied. Here really is the request for action.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the crisis is in place in the European Union, but in the Azores we face a real catastrophe, with 60 % of producers in technical bankruptcy. That is why, Commissioner, it is time to activate Article 349 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and to support the outermost regions, especially the Azores. For the Union, I propose three measures. Firstly, a mandatory and comprehensive control of supply in excess production and market collapse. Secondly, to compensate producers when the price paid to them is lower than the production costs. We cannot see this pressure on the producers. Thirdly, to set up a European campaign to stimulate consumption, since consumption in the European Union, and at a globalised level, is decreasing and this trend must be countered. Commissioner, the answers we are giving are not enough. In a crisis, we need more Europe, we need more cohesion, we need more solidarity, we need a Europe that protects the most disadvantaged.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the "blue card" procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
