text: Question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear Colleague, and I support the Commission, but not only the Commission, solving the problem of the milk crisis, but I did not understand how you proposed: how to ask the Commission to stop, to select, on what criteria, who, how much to produce? We are in a free market economy. What are the criteria that you see, which you propose to the Commission, to stop production on the basis of consumption? The proposal is absolutely inexplicable.

name: Sofia Ribeiro (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. "Dear colleague, I think I've made myself very clear.  It called, first, for the activation of a specific article supporting the outermost regions, which is enshrined in our Treaty, Article 349.  Secondly, it called for three overall strategies: a strategy of mandatory control of production in crisis situations, a second strategy of financial support to producers, which cannot be pressured in the way they are being and selling milk at prices below production costs, and a third strategy to encourage consumption at European level.  I think there are three very clear strategies.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As we debate, milk prices are falling down across Europe. In Austria, they are currently 28 cents, in Germany perhaps soon less than 20 cents, and I am surprised that Mrs Köstinger is talking about a quantitative restriction, where our Austrian Minister for Agriculture obviously does not think anything of a quota system! Ladies and gentlemen, if this continues, we will have a farmer's death throughout Europe! In Austria alone, 6000 farms are at risk! However, this is not just about milk producers, it is also about the conservation of the landscape, which preserves our cultural landscape in the alpine area with care, and that would also have disastrous consequences for the environment and tourism. What we therefore need, ladies and gentlemen, are not long discussions. It is to act quickly, otherwise we will have a farmer's death in Europe as a whole! We know quite clearly that we are taking appropriate measures here, and one of the first measures would be to temporarily suspend or reintroduce the milk quota. We do not need recipients of alms as farmers, but we need farmers who provide excellent quality, who deliver excellent quality, we need fair prices for fair milk! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Elisabeth Köstinger (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Mr Obermayr, I would like to thank Mr Obermayr for his work Can you explain the difference between a quantity control instrument and the quota, because you have now addressed this? Or do you see no differences here?

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs Köstinger, I would like to thank Mrs Köstinger for her work on this report. We have often had the discussion on milk and dairy products, overproduction. I asked you years ago if you knew what a full cost calculation means for a farmer. You dodged me. I am well aware of the differences without being a farmer. However, I expect you to make clear statements today as to whether we should consider suspending the milk quota system today. Speak and say clearly what you want.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – (The first part of the opposition was not recorded due to a technical problem.) ... it is having serious problems across Europe, with low prices putting producers in an impossible position, many of whom are thinking of leaving the sector. In some cases, the production price of milk exceeds the market price and therefore farmers operate at a loss. This situation is unsustainable and national governments are in many cases powerless. I think that the Commission's responsibility on this issue is enormous – producers, processors and consumers awaits a solution from Brussels. According to some, milk market disorders are just symptoms of a periodic crisis, the market will soon normalize. We do not know whether this will be the case, but until this happens, thousands of producers can go bust and stop farming. We have to do something.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, a few months ago the European Commission announced a battery of measures to deal with the crisis in the dairy sector. Today in my homeland, Galicia, the largest milk producer in Spain, the prices paid to farmers do not even cover the costs of producing milk. It's the realization of a failure.  In the debate on the state of the European Union, I appealed to President Juncker, and he pledged to take additional steps to tackle the crisis. We haven't heard from them. The sector languishes, and thousands of farms in my Community are at risk of closing for unworkability. It is about the survival of an economic sector, of food sovereignty, of a way of life, of the future of the European rural world.  Don't go blind and cross-armed. This is a European crisis, and it has to have a European response. Listen, Commissioner, to the cry of the sector, the cry of this Parliament. Give answers. The sector cannot wait, and you cannot remain inactive. And if you remain inactive, Commissioner, we will have to censure you.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the continuing fall in the price of milk primarily affects the viability of small producers, especially in remote and mountainous areas. Measures must therefore be taken to protect them. Designation of Origin Products are at risk of disappearing under CETA and TTIR.  In Greece, the new memorandum fully liberalized the shelf life of pasteurized milk. The result is to have pasteurized milk lasting up to eleven days, a period of time that is sufficient to transport pasteurized milk from the Netherlands to Greece.  At the same time, in the name of adaptation with the OECD toolkit, an attempt is being made to liberalise the yogurt market. So there is a risk that traditional Greek yogurt will be lost once and for all.  Mr Hogan, the greek farmers who are poor in the Memorandum cannot compete with the prices of imported low-quality products, nor do they have the funds to absorb the large price fluctuations. That is why there must be procedures for brave compensation of Greek farmers, withdrawal of their products and free provision of these dairy products to the austere Greek citizens.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, the pressure on the European dairy sector needs urgent short-term measures to save many farms. But also, a long-term plan that frees the market from price and cost fluctuations that make it very difficult to manage the sector. The final destination market for productions and the type of products are very relevant to ensure more stable prices. Likewise, a more intense participation of producers in the value chain through the creation of cooperatives or producer associations and their involvement in processing and marketing is a very useful measure to be able to deal with the crisis. The same applies to the progressive emergence of new products or modes of sale, or the value of origin, which are succeeding in the market. For these reasons, Commissioner, we would like to know how the Commission intends to support this type of bet, what reference models it works with and what it intends to do to improve the prospective studies which encouraged an end to the milk quota system and did not make it right in its forecasts on such important aspects as the growth in external demand. I'm waiting for your answer.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, the agricultural sector in the Union has been hit to a great extent by the crisis of recent years. But the crisis was only the reason for the final blow to an already weakened sector of the economy. The real cause is no other than the market disturbances caused by the wrong policies of Brussels, which for years, with the famous Agricultural Policy, has been failing one day after another. Irrelevant bureaucrats, having no idea, carry out experiments on the backs of farmers, but also of all citizens.  You have tried to regulate agricultural policy pan-European. All you have managed to do, however, is to substantially weaken the farmers. Of course, that was your goal from the outset, serving the interests of large companies. The price of milk has reached very low levels. But what is the benefit to consumers? Do they drink cheap milk? No, because cartels live and reign.  Now, after a series of failures, we are ready once again to apply another experiment with dubious, again, results. If you really want to do something in the interests of farmers, then abolish - already today - the Common Agricultural Policy. The market itself will certainly do better than you.

name: Phil Hogan
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you to all Members who have contributed to this debate. I wanted to thank MEPs Köstinger and Kumpula-Natri for their Forestry meeting at 8 a.m. this morning. I am glad that Mr Flanagan will be able to get that information. Today’s dairy crisis is not, as some would have us believe, a factor of the abolition of dairy quotas; rather it is something of a perfect storm, as Mr Selimovic said earlier on, which reflects increased production throughout the world at the same time as access to the Russian market was lost and demand in China had been reduced. But I can assure Mr Nicholson and others that I am not at all blaming producers for over-production, but I am agreeing with him that producers have to take their share of responsibility in terms of bringing about balance in the marketplace between demand and supply. And that is what Article 222 is about. It is a voluntary measure, but I have doubled the state aid ceilings in order to allow Member States to incentivise Article 222 measures if they so wish. Mr Blanco López has mentioned earlier that I have taken no measures in the last few months in order to deal with this particular crisis. In fact I have taken 23 measures since last September. And I have already told you that a significant number of Member States and regions, in respect of the targeted aid package last September, have not yet spent their money. I would remind Mr Dantin that it is very difficult to seek more money if eight Member States, including France, have not spent their allocation yet from last September. I think it is important as well that we have to be realistic about the possibility of new money, when you consider that in recent days one German minister suggested that 10% of all programme expenditure should be diverted directly to address the refugee crisis. So is this the view of the German MEPs? You can see how difficult it is to get additional money when that is the particular message being advised in the system. Mr Häusling advises me to put a cap on milk production, but he also advises me to give more support to the farmers in the ANC areas in order to produce more – slightly contradictory, and it therefore indicates how difficult it is to get solutions. I think a number of people have mentioned the possibility of the crisis reserve. Any further financial support would inevitably raise the issue of the activation of the crisis reserve, which could generate in excess of EUR 400 million. Its activation has been suggested, and I have been reluctant to propose its activation in the past because it represents nothing more than a redistribution of farmers’ payments. However, it is something that I am prepared to consider, and the ultimate decision, of course, will be yours. In relation to the MMO, your vote today and on previous occasions proposed a strengthening of the Milk Market Observatory, and I have done that. I believe that the MMO is now playing a very important role in providing up-to-date, reliable information, on the basis of which, operators and other stakeholders can make important commercial decisions. I have not been able to go into full detail today in relation to those Member States who are generating the largest increases in dairy production, but all of that information is readily available on the website of the MMO, proving that it is a credible source of transparent information. As well as turning to the Commission as a source of additional support for a sector which is clearly in crisis and for a longer time than would reasonably have been anticipated, I would invite Member States to consider if they have exhausted the full range of measures under the rural development programme. It is up to Member States to trigger these mechanisms. At a time of crisis, cash flow is important, and this is one of the reasons why I have been frustrated at the slow roll-out by a number of Member States of the targeted aid, and also the fact that I am aware of the challenge that it will be for some paying agencies to have some payments made that are outstanding by the end of June 2016. For this reason I am looking carefully at how best the Commission can help those Member States, and by extension the farmers, without the application of any penalty. Finally Mr President, while we are in the midst of this crisis, it is difficult to take time to stand back and assess the adequacy of the toolbox for which we must work, but we have to do that sooner or later. Perhaps in the context of proposing any changes to the existing CAP that will help to deal with risk management would also help to target measures better.

name: Hans Hoogeveen
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank all the Members of Parliament for their remarks but also for their suggestions, and certainly the Presidency will take them with us to our next discussion in the Council of June, because there we are going to discuss again the very severe situation in the dairy sector as well as the need for additional measures. I would like to reiterate what was said by Commissioner Hogan: that the Commission and the Council were not resting on their laurels. Many measures have been taken, not only in September but also in March, and of course we see some effects of those measures – perhaps not enough, but there are effects of those measures, and the situation could have been worse if we did not have taken those measures. And yes, I would like to reiterate that we need a European approach. But the Council also clearly stated that we have to take into account national circumstances, and the Council is very much agreeing with remarks of Mr De Castro and Mr Deß, that we at the same time have to ensure that there is a level playing field within the European Union. It is also clear that there is no ‘one size fits all’ solution. We have to be creative, but also what was said by Commissioner Hogan, we have to work within the current framework of the common agriculture policy. And it is clear that the Council also stated that we do not want to go back to a quota system. I agree with what was said by Mr Huitema, that we have to improve the situation of the farmers in the supply chain. We have to give them a fair price for their products. Therefore the work of the market taskforce installed by the European Commission is so important, and in the June Council we have the first report of this taskforce and hopefully we get some interesting and creative ideas. Also I and the Council would like to reiterate the words of Mr Ashworth as well as Mr Huitema: that we have to make sure that the farmers maintain the position as drivers of the dairy chain. They are the first responsible persons to take action. But at the same time, of course, we have to support those farmers and see how we can help them balancing supply and demand. In this respect I also would like to thank Mr Jakovčić for referring to the Dutch model. It is not the Dutch model of the Dutch Government but it is also the Dutch model of the Dutch dairy producers, and they are looking into niche markets, into improving quality, into new market concepts. But they are also now at this moment discussing possibilities of reduction of the milk production in the Netherlands on a voluntary basis, and I think it is up to the Council in June to see how we can support those initiatives of farmers’ organisations to reduce the milk production. Last but not least, I would like to reiterate and underline the words of Ms McGuinness as well as Mrs Schreijer-Pierik: that also the banks and industry have to take their responsibility. Also they have to give their support to measures to be taken by farmers and governments, and in this respect I think one of the measures which were taken in March to support the banking sector to be involved is the possibility of Member States to give some support to liquidity problems in close relation with the banks.

name: Mario Borghezio (ENF)
text: in writing. The European Union is mainly responsible for the collapse in the price of milk, which, at an average of 27cent/litre today, is bringing the livestock sector to its knees and causing thousands of farms to close. In Italy alone, more than 1,000 farms were closed in 2015. There is not only a subject for monitoring production levels, there is a problem of the 'value' of the raw material which is continually devalued by European rules which, for example, still do not provide for compulsory origin labelling for all dairy products and, in fact, give priority to the industrial and large-scale organised distribution sector over the primary sector. The Council and the Commission must therefore move quickly, by means of legislative acts, in order to offer the livestock sector a fairer market that makes greater use of the raw material, the result of the work of farmers, in the context of a chain to be reorganised and made more competitive.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. – Since the end of the milk quota regime, the EP has been alerting the European Commission to the difficulties of the sector. The situation has been aggravated by a 6% increase in the supply recorded in the first quarter of 2016, compared to the same period last year. Excess supply that adds to the continued low level of producer prices, falling global demand, effects of Russian veto and unfair practices in the supply chain, represent the "perfect storm" for milk farmers. We need European solutions to a European crisis. The allocation of 420 million to last autumn's Member States has had no effect. This is the message we have conveyed to both the Council and the Commission. However, both institutions insist on sticking to the legal framework available after the last CAP reform and giving Member States flexibility to address the problem according to their internal situation. We continue to expect a common approach and political will from the Commission and the Council to address this situation. At stake is the economic and social viability of many rural and mountain areas of the EU.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. The crisis in the dairy sector has now become structural: on the European market alone, there are 700 000 tonnes of surpluses, prices are falling and production continues to increase. However, despite the dramatic situation, it seems that the budgetary scope for action is limited. Really paradoxical! The Commission must introduce exceptional and extraordinary measures because the crisis in the sector is dramatic. The activation of Article 222 is good news, but it is not enough. In order to restore dignity to the dairy sector, we need to introduce demanding measures which you alone, Mr Hogan, unfortunately cannot take. The rules on labelling, indications of origin and traceability must be strengthened, innovative insurance systems must be introduced and measures must be taken to correct imbalances in the food supply chain. We need a joint and courageous effort from the Commission and the Council. A specific programme must be adopted to regulate and restore competitiveness to the sector with a multiannual strategy that favours its radical reorganisation and restructuring.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The Commissioner claims that he is doing everything within his power to help dairy farmers in distress. He has placed a great deal of reliance on the use of Article 222 from the Common Market Organisation (CMO) Regulation as a stress-relieving measure, so that Member States have the option of funding milk suppliers that cut their production. However the success of this measure is dependent on the Irish Government actually activating the scheme, something it has already said it does not plan on doing. In this situation, what real measures can the Commission claim to have provided directly to the farmers? Its refusal to find a way to suspend super-levy fines shows neglect towards the cash-flow problems being experienced by European farmers.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. – The milk market in Europe is experiencing a difficult period of low prices and very low profit margins. The Milk Market Observatory recently warned that the current downturn and low prices in the milk sector show no signs of a surge. Over the past few months, the price of raw milk has been 13% lower than the average price in the previous five years, with prices of whole milk powder continuing to fall – they are 5% lower, and there has also been a decrease in the average prices of skimmed-milk powder and butter. This downward trend in milk prices is an argument that existing CAP instruments and measures taken against dairy farmers are not effective in this area and cannot cope with the crisis in the dairy sector. I expect the Council and the Commission to provide details of the steps that need to be taken immediately and in the long term to ease the pressure on milk and milk producers.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. - Dear Commissioner, You are bringing up, among other things, the negligence of the Member States and the non-payment of last year's bailout as reasons for the increasing situation on the European milk market. Firstly, I would like to inform you that 99.6% of the nearly HUF 3 billion of the EUR 500 million bailout has already been paid by the Hungarian Government to farmers, who will also receive an additional HUF 11.5 billion in national aid. And the government will reduce VAT on producer milk to 5 percent from 2017. However, the crisis must be solved first and foremost here in Brussels. The steps so far have been good, but they have not pulled producer prices out of the slump. In my opinion, the only way to do this is to raise the intervention price to the cost level. Please write to me what you think of my proposal that, in return for an increase in the intervention price, dairy farmers offering intervention would undertake to withdraw an additional quantity of milk, even equal to the quantity offered, free of charge, by transferring this milk, milk powder, butter and cheese for charitable and relief purposes within the EU? By redesigning the intervention mechanism as described above, would this method work in your opinion?

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. – Since the end of the milk quota regime, the EP has been alerting the EC to the difficulties in the sector. The situation has been aggravated by a 6% increase in the supply recorded in the first quarter of 2016, compared to the same period last year. Demand is also weak and an internal war between European producers must be avoided from accusing each other of overproduction. They are all trying to survive, because in many cases they are paid less than their production costs. This is unacceptable and a solution must be found at European level. The EUR 420 million package launched by the Commission last autumn did not have the significant effect it would have wanted. This clearly shows that the measures taken have not been sufficient to deal with the crisis facing the sector. Today the livelihood of these farmers is at risk, which means that the long-term vitality of rural Europe is also at risk. This situation is unsustainable and requires strong intervention by the EU.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. – Since the end of the milk quota regime, the EP has been alerting the European Commission to the difficulties of the sector. The situation has been aggravated by a 6% increase in the supply recorded in the first quarter of 2016, compared to the same period last year. Excess supply that adds to the continued low level of producer prices, falling global demand, effects of Russian veto and unfair practices in the supply chain, represent the "perfect storm" for milk farmers. We need European solutions to a European crisis. The allocation of 420 million to last autumn's Member States has had no effect. This is the message we have conveyed to both the Council and the Commission. However, both institutions insist on sticking to the legal framework available after the last CAP reform and giving Member States flexibility to address the problem according to their internal situation. We continue to expect a common approach and political will from the Commission and the Council to address this situation. At stake is the economic and social viability of many rural and mountain areas of the EU.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The situation in the European milk sector has been difficult for a long time, and in recent months we may already be talking about drama. The price of milk is 13% lower compared to the last five years with an additional downward trend making production unprofitable and many producers are on the brink of bankruptcy. The European Commission has already implemented a number of measures to improve the situation, including mobilising more than EUR 1 billion over the last 2 years to support the milk sector, or the additional action package of March this year. These are undoubtedly very important steps towards overcoming this crisis, but the current situation shows that they are still not sufficient.  In order to compensate for the low prices, farmers produce more, leading to overproduction of milk, which does not go hand in hand with increased consumption. I believe that one of the solutions needed and urgent is to promote European dairy products and find new markets for them. This is particularly important also in the context of reduced demand from China and the Russian embargo. I appreciate the Current Action of the European Commission in this respect, but I believe that, in view of the seriousness of the situation, efforts should be stepped up as much as possible in order to achieve the desired result as soon as possible and on the largest possible scale.

name: Sandra Kalniete (PPE)
text: Writing. – The issue of the situation in the dairy sector must be seen in the context of the global market situation: the embargo in Russia and the fall in demand in China. As the European Council approaches, it is understandable that sanctions against Russia will not be lifted or revised and there is no significant increase in demand in China. The EU must therefore think about targeted support for the dairy sector. The situation across the EU is dramatic, but it is critical in Latvia. The average price of milk purchases decreased by 33 % since the embargo until April 2016. This is one of the biggest cuts between EU Member States. In April, the price fell to EUR 0,20/kg, while in May its reduction could reach as much as 37 %. The level of the purchase price of milk does not cover production costs for a long time. All temporary emergency aid granted to the EU has been paid to milk producers. In the current situation, the granting of direct financial support to milk producers is the necessary solution that would at least reduce the increasing burden of losses and prevent the producers from going into mass bankruptcy. It would be important to increase the volume of intervention procurement, to discuss financial instruments and to increase flexibility in the state aid framework. I question the effectiveness of voluntary production reductions to stabilise the market and see more risks than benefits for producers. I would also like to add that we also need to think urgently about support in the pig, fruit and vegetable sectors, where the situation is becoming increasingly worrying.

name: Karol Karski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – A few years ago, European farmers were encouraged to develop their production so as not to lose the opportunity associated with rising demand on world markets. Farmers have therefore invested and developed production. This situation was used in the EU to weaken or dismantle cap instruments to stabilise the market. It is absolutely unacceptable to additionally penal punish Polish farmers for exceeding milk quotas in a crisis situation on the milk market and after the abolition of milk quotas on 1 April 2015. The situation of milk producers in Poland and throughout the European Union is dramatic. The burden on even the most modern dairy farms with such high penalties, while the fall in milk purchase prices in Poland, leads to their bankruptcy. Some farmers receive 17 cents per liter of milk. I appeal to the Commission, in the face of an endless Russian embargo on dairy products, for the decommission of penalties imposed on Polish producers amounting to more than EUR 161 million. Once again, I call on the Commission to allocate additional financial resources to producers in the dairy, pig and other sectors affected by the crisis. The fate of milk producers depends on the Commission providing them with immediate financial assistance.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. – The liberalisation of the EU dairy market with the abolition of the milk production quota in March 2015 is the reason for the low milk prices. This liberalisation has left Austrian farmers laging behind. You don't have to be a scientist to see this connection. However, it is not only the liberalisation of the EU milk market that can be blamed for this crisis. The European Union's sanctions against Russia have also played their part. After the European Union adopted sanctions against Russia, Russia responded by banning imports of dairy products. This has led to massive overproduction in the dairy sector, which has again led to a massive fall in the price of milk. The current price of milk is a threat to the livelihoods of many farmers, and experts are already announcing further price losses for 2016. Action must be taken here, and now!

name: David McAllister (PPE)
text: Writing. – Germany is the largest milk producer among the EU's 28 member states, accounting for just over 20 percent of production. About one in four farms in Germany keeps dairy cows. The situation of dairy farmers is getting worse by the day. They are suffering from drastic price declines in their products. Since December 2013, average raw milk prices in the EU have fallen from around EUR 40 per 100 kg to just EUR 25 now in April. The fall in prices is pushing many farms to the brink of existence. Those who had actually done everything right are particularly affected. They have invested to prepare for the end of the quota. Now the markets have collapsed, the price is falling into the bottom. We need to join forces in Europe. After all, national measures have only a limited effect. The European Union should now swiftly launch another aid package – but not financed from the existing agricultural pots, but with new money.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D)
text: in writing. – News of tremors in the dairy sector is already daily. And while bureaucrats may see this as normal, thousands of dairy farms across Europe are going bankrupt. These are small and medium-sized family farms that cannot meet all the market trends that accompany the dairy sector. The Milk Market Monitoring Authority recently warned that the current downturn and low prices show no signs of a surge. Over the past few months, the price of raw milk in Europe has been 13% lower than in the previous five years. In my country - Bulgaria, the purchase price of milk in some regions has fallen to 15-16 euro cents, which producers rightly accept as a mockery of the labor and investment invested. And for some of them, this is a basic and/or single livelihood and source of income. In some regions, such as mountainous regions, this is the only possible economic activity. Europe must stop turning agriculture only into livelihoods for large producers and, on the contrary, lend a hand and provide assistance to small and medium-sized dairy producers. This aid should focus on country-specific milk products and not on those covering the needs of only some Member States.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. – During the 2014-2020 CAP reform, I have stated time and again the need to have market instruments that work. I said that full liberalisation would lead to significant problems, and I proposed to maintain supply-regulating instruments, but the majority decided to liberalise. Yes, prices have started to fluctuate significantly, farmers' incomes are increasingly uncertain and we seem to be not finding solutions to put an end to this perpetual crisis. Besides, we're going to have to think ahead. I wish that even in the case of trade agreements that the EU will sign, we will weigh well the impact they will have on farmers and their incomes. I hope that once and for all the Commission will realise that milk producers need stable incomes and this can only be achieved with market instruments that are accessible when needed.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. I could repeat many of the interventions developed by my colleagues to denounce the unbridled and disorganised liberalisation of the CAP. Denouncing the destruction of rural economic fabrics. To denounce the weakening of actors in the face of mass distribution. Denounce the loss of know-how. And, above all, to denounce the terrible human consequences, the torn families, the suicides. Yes, this deregulated CAP kills. But I only have one minute.  So I will just talk about my specialty: the EU budget. Because the CAP, contaminated with the just-return virus, is summed up in a series of national envelopes. In order to be able to measure their financial return more easily, States have sacrificed the Community dimension of the CAP. Market intervention tools are now minimal, emergency aid is paltry and market regulation is disappearing. Farmers need these tools because they want fair prices for their production and not depend on subsidies.  Until the way the Union is financed is profoundly changed, the CAP will remain sick of just-return and will continue to be ineffective. The CAP will continue to kill.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. – In addition to the financial envelope of 500 million euro, the To support European farmers, the Commission has proposed a set of measures to tackle the dairy crisis, such as the implementation of voluntary agreements on milk production and supply, a temporary increase in State aid, a doubling of intervention ceilings for skimmed-milk powder and butter, advertising campaigns and an increase in international trade, export credit, etc. However, the crisis continues to deepen, dairy farmers are piling up losses and debts and are at risk of bankruptcy. The european average price of milk is below 28 cents/litre, while production continues to rise. In the first two months of 2016, 7.4% more milk was produced compared to the same period last year. It should be clearly emphasised that the main reason for the current situation is overproduction! It is not possible to stabilise the market without limiting milk production in countries that have increased it since the quota regime was dropped. Measures to temporarily remove quantities of milk from the market are not working. The dairy farmers most affected by the crisis in mountainous and disadvantaged areas need specific support measures, such as promoting the purchase and co-financing of transport costs by European means, in order to protect themselves from bankruptcy and preserve dairy production in these areas.

name: Lara Comi
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would also like to thank and greet the Commissioner, and I would like to extend a very strong thank you to all my fellow Members who have participated in the single market strategy. You see, today with the approval of the single market strategy, we are responding to the needs of our businesses, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and to our consumers as well as our citizens.  The internal market is the real means of increasing the concept of Europe as a single economic power and not always divided by the 28 egotises represented by the Member States. Today we are going to give a strong signal not in words, but in deeds to the economic crisis. In order to overcome it, we must be close to our productive sectors, to our families, which are intended both as workers and as consumers. What the Member States have not been able to do in recent years, well, we are completing it much more quickly. I will move on, point by point, quickly, to what we are going to achieve. Firstly, compensation between public administration debts and company taxation. A state cannot demand payment of taxes when it is not solvent with companies itself, so we want an automatic change in the difference between giving and having. You see, in my country alone, more than 5 000 companies are now bankrupt because of claims not collected by the public administration; we cannot accept that the state should be the architect of this, because it is incapable of being solvent. There is also the law of the market for the public administration, as is required of companies. We do not want a suicidal state of business, but a state that supports businesses. The second chance is that if a company has gone bankrupt because of unclaimed credits or natural disasters, we have a duty to help it by financing its reconstruction. Europe, as far as we can believe, is much closer to its citizens, and we are demonstrating this through action. Thirdly, the diversity of tax systems. We in Europe have different tax regimes that complicate the lives of our businesses and our citizens. I welcome the Commission's proposals for the harmonisation of tax systems, and I welcome the proposal we have put forward, namely the possibility of introducing a single tax in the e-commerce sector. I reiterated the need for better access to European funds by small and medium-sized enterprises, facilities for translations and shorter submission times. We must make it easier for businesses, especially small ones, to receive money and to submit projects. Service passport: it will look like a miracle, today we realize it. A simple and equal way for everyone to present documents and create businesses across Europe. You see, this is less bureaucracy, the same law for everyone and the best wins: it's the law of the market. And finally, dear President, the famous made in, you as an Italian can understand me well. And here, Commissioner, we are playing our credibility: several impact studies tell us that citizens want more details about products, traceability, transparency and real protection, and I believe that traceability is the element of protection of our quality, an important and fundamental quality also for our economy. You see, allow me to be blunt, it's time for this matter to be unblocked. The European Parliament and the Commission have already given the go-ahead for market surveillance and we await the Council's approval. It is not we who have to go backwards, it is the Member States who have the courage to overcome their national self-interest and finally approve made in. People need to know who is responsible for always blocking our work; we pass laws in support of businesses and citizens, laws that reduce bureaucracy, but there is always a stop to the Council. It is time to stop, because this stop is Europe's real failure. We have seen this with immigrants, I will end, Mr President, with the late payment directive, with the data protection regulation, that is enough. Today's vote, Commissioner, will no longer give the Council any excuse for not approving made in. We trust you and Mr Juncker because, you see, we propose and approve real and useful solutions to the problems of our citizens. This means that we are popular and not populist, because we are the substance and not the appearance.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, first I want to express that the Commission strongly welcomes the report by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on the Single Market Strategy. I would like in particular to thank personally Ms Comi for all her hard work as rapporteur, and of course the shadow rapporteurs.  We know that the single market is a great asset in Europe. It is the best available instrument to improve the investment climate, business environment and productivity of the EU, the whole EU economy. The report clearly recognises that. We need to create more opportunities and dismantle unwarranted barriers. The single market must work and this is very important, both for the citizens, for the consumers, and for businesses. They must see it is an opportunity, not as a threat. We talked to citizens and businesses to understand what is really keeping the single market from reaching its full potential and, based on that, we proposed steps forward in our Single Market Strategy adopted last October. We are focusing on the real—life problems. I really want to underline this: the real—life problems. Our strategy is about targeted initiatives to tackle practical barriers and obstacles. I welcome very much the support in your report. I cannot cover all the good points that you make in your report, so let me just focus on three issues that I think and I know are of importance also to you: on geographical discrimination against consumers; the services passport and the collaborative economy.  First, geographical discrimination. Article 20 of the Services Directive is very clear about it. European consumers are not to be discriminated against based on their nationality or residence but we still, unfortunately, see this kind of discrimination all over Europe. Four out of five consumer respondents tell us that they have experienced geo—blocking in their lives, so yesterday we came forward with an ambitious but very realistic proposal about this. With your help we will address the discrimination against our citizens and companies based on their nationality or place of residence. I therefore welcome very much your support for our legislative proposal which you have voiced in your report.  Second, the services passport. It is still far too complicated for companies to offer their services cross-border. There are too many bureaucratic hurdles and too many delays so we are designing the services passport, a voluntary instrument for service providers who want to access other Member State markets. I am very much aware of the discussions you had on the services passport for the Comi report. I appreciate the compromise you have found and I really want to hear your views and the views of the citizens, and of course economic operators. That is why three weeks ago we launched a public consultation on the subject. This consultation will run until the end of July, until 26 July. Stakeholders need to be informed of this consultation and encouraged to take part in it. I would welcome also your support and your help on this. Third, the collaborative economy. This is really a fundamental transformation of our economy. This is not going back. I have always repeated that resisting it would be like resisting the printing press and steam engine in earlier times. It is also a major opportunity for Europe. We need to get it right. We need to find a way to embrace these new business models; otherwise we know exactly what will happen. Five years from now our successors will complain and regret how Europe lost the collaborative economy.  I fully understand that some people are uncertain about what this all means. We need to respond to their questions. We advocate a balance. I want to really underline this: a balanced development of the collaborative economy within the single market. That means clarity of the rules, clarity for businesses that apply and how they apply. It means avoiding market fragmentation in Europe. Next week we will provide more clarity with a communication on the application of the existing EU law in this area and we will make a number of recommendations of course to Member States.  Thank you for welcoming and supporting our approach on the collaborative economy in your report. I very much hope that you will equally support all the initiatives presented in the Single Market Strategy, because our recommendation speaks a clear language. We in the Commission are starting to roll out our proposals, but we need of course your help and your support. It is in all our interests to deliver a better-functioning single market to our citizens and businesses.

name: Ulrike Trebesius
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. Mr President, I would like to thank the The EU's Internal Market Strategy is a fundamentally useful project and can help to strengthen growth forces. The report admits that some 22 million people in the Union are without employment and the consequences of the euro crisis have not been overcome. Growth-enhancing measures are therefore very useful. In this report, I find it helpful, for example, to facilitate market access by introducing a service passport, which has already been mentioned here, or to create legal foundations for new business models in the field of e-commerce. Unfortunately, I must also point out weaknesses in the report. In my view, the recurring demand for a uniform or high level of protection for products or job security or social standards is particularly problematic. We must be aware that it is precisely in poorer countries that companies with weaker capital cannot afford every level of the more developed countries. So if we demand an evenly high level of protection, it will lead to more unemployment, more intra-EU migration and a call for more transfer payments. At the same time, we should prevent workers in developed countries from losing their wealth as a result of ever-increasing low-wage competition. The level of protection should depend on the performance of the countries. Germany, for example, must therefore impose a high level.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to begin by congratulating the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats on this successful report. I believe that we have been able to include a great many points in this report, which were also raised by the European Commission in the internal market strategy. For example, the fact that we need European insolvency law, which can make a great deal of contribution to simplifying economic structures throughout Europe, is emphasised once again here. However, Mrs Comi has also mentioned the importance of the internal market, particularly for small and medium-sized enterprises. This is also a matter of the heart in my constituency, which we pursue in the internal market legislation. I believe that if we adopt new rules in the internal market today, these rules will actually have to contribute to an improvement for small and medium-sized enterprises. Everything must be measured by this standard. The behaviour of public administration in many Member States with regard to payment obligations for public contracts is indeed appalling. The report also makes this clear. In my view, the product safety package is also about finding an undogmatic, pragmatic approach to finding solutions that will ultimately help small and medium-sized enterprises in particular. Commissioner, when you talk about real life problems, I think that is the common sense approach that we need. Commissioner, you have now also mentioned geo-blocking in your presentation. Yesterday, we discussed this sufficiently with Vice-President Ansip. That is why I would like to say something about the services passport, the legislation of which will also come to Parliament in the next few weeks. Anything that entails the simplification of the cross-border services market, Commissioner, will be welcome if we manage to ensure that legitimate safety standards in individual professions are not simply thrown overboard. When I look at the situation in my constituency between Germany and France, I believe that in many places we can find pragmatic solutions that we can achieve without having too much difficulty with the professional participants, with those involved in public. That is why I would like to expressly encourage you to make this process constructive.

name: Marlene Mizzi
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the single market is one of the most tangible results of European integration and yet, despite its significant achievements, citizens, consumers and businesses have become increasingly dissatisfied with it as it often fails to convince them that it truly represents their interests and their aspirations.  The main problem is that, in the average citizen’s eyes, the market is more concerned with vested interests than it is with their needs. We need to start working towards a fairer single market that is politically supported, economically viable and socially accepted by European citizens, a market that stimulates sustainable economic growth and job creation, but also considers citizens’ hopes, fears and expectations.  The Comi report is an important step towards achieving a strong, green, knowledge-based social market economy which by turning its focus back to its people will become a common asset of all its citizens, reduce unemployment, poverty, inequalities, social exclusion and wage dumping, promote respect of fundamental social rights, fair mobility and improvement of living and working conditions in Europe.  As a shadow rapporteur, I have striven to ensure that essential elements are added to the text aimed at improving the well—being of European citizens. Therefore, I urge MEPs to support the report, and in particular the measures aimed at endorsing a highly-competitive social market economy, providing consumers with the highest level of protection, promoting innovative start-ups, SMEs and social economy enterprises, opposing abuses in the single market, which are trying to circumvent existing rules and lower worker and consumer and environmental standards, highlighting the economic , social and environmental benefits and challenges of the sharing economy, calling for a single European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products, and supporting the ‘Made in’ labelling, which is of crucial importance to protect consumers and provide them with the information they need. Last but not least, we need to ensure that there is enough political will to ensure that a revitalized and redefined single market does happen for the benefit of all citizens.

name: Daniel Dalton
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I also want to thank the rapporteur, particularly for her work to try and keep us on board. This report shows there is a clear will to improve the single market and make it work better for everyone, both consumers and businesses, and I welcome the emphasis on cutting red tape, on reducing burdens for businesses. This should be at the heart of future efforts in this area. The report’s emphasis on opening up the service sector and addressing weaknesses in mutual recognition is also welcome, and the report is also right to focus on supporting SMEs and start-ups and cutting burdens for them. I welcome the support for a once—only principle for administrative requirements and I also agree with the importance of the sharing economy. So we will support the report and we thank the rapporteur for her efforts, but we do have some concerns in areas which we cannot support. For example, non-agricultural GIs. We do not support this. It is not workable and I personally do not agree with the premise for an extension to the system. On the ‘Made in’ label, I have not seen any evidence that a mandatory scheme is more beneficial than a voluntary scheme, nor would it contribute to product traceability. A product made in China with a slight finishing in Europe should not be packaged as European. That would be cheating consumers. So we cannot support those elements but we will support the overall package.

name: Antanas Guoga
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would also like to support and thank the rapporteur for an excellent performance so far. The single market, however, is underperforming in almost all areas and we do need some stimulation in a digital-driven market. We need to encourage start-ups, integration of global supply chains and dealing with new business models, which is a challenge to us, ensuring market facilitation and stabilisation, and licensing of professionals. Also, the draft report recognises the overall support initiatives of the single market, which is important. We need a single market for services. The service passport initiative should not only address administrative obstacles, but also tackle regulatory barriers and advance mutual recognition of priority sectors. So we really need to focus on this passport initiative.  You should also look at useless labelling of products. We tend to have this problem, so we need to fix this and we need to think about digital solutions in the labelling area. An overload of information does confuse the consumers. We also need to tackle geo—blocking. The proposal that was proposed by the Commission yesterday is definitely a step in the right direction. I personally look positively at the collaborative sharing economy. It brings competition to the market and gives us a new start in so many areas, which means better and less expensive services for all Europeans. Let us embrace it. Let us be ambitious and create a better functioning single market.

name: João Pimenta Lopes
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, more than 20 years of the Single Market have meant accelerating the process of capitalist concentration and accumulation in favour of monopolistic groups, the dismantling of instruments at the service of the Member States, sovereign regulation of economies, privatisation and liberalisation of strategic sectors and public services, harmonisation of legislation.  But it's not enough. The great monopolistic capital wants more and the objective of deepening integration in the Single Market and contributing to structural reforms is explicit, read the liquidation of the social functions of the State and labour rights.  It proposes to link with the Juncker Plan, servile to the interests of high finance and large companies and which favours Public-Private Partnerships, injecting public money into the financial system, or with the TTIP that would liquidate thousands of SMEs and deepen the attack on workers' labour and social rights. Risk capital and the creation of financial products, such as securities, which were at the root of the 2008 financial crisis, are valued, which confirm that the Single Market does not serve the sovereign development of the Member States, let alone the interests of peoples and workers.  The claim that "equal work, equal pay, in the same place" undermines the Single Market, in the argument that led to the yellow card to the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive, is revealing how it has promoted levelling under living and working conditions in Europe, increasing inequalities, exclusion and poverty.

name: Julia Reda
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner, and especially the rapporteur, for ensuring a broad political support for this report. I think we have managed to add a lot of important elements to this report, particularly so that we are not just talking about deepening the single market but also strengthening social and ecological factors and preserving limits on the free market in the public interest where necessary. We think it is very important that the single market strategy and the digital single market proceed in coherence with each other and that we need a coordinated European approach to the collaborative economy, where possible based on existing legislation. Strengthening the enforcement of consumer protection is also a very important element of this. We fully support the call for open standards that can easily be implemented by SMEs and more transparency and participation in the standard setting process. The call for greater tax coordination, particularly in the VAT sector, is also very important and would strengthen the possibility for SMEs to deal with the VAT system, as well as the strong call for greater fairness in the tax sector, fighting tax avoidance and a clear call for a country—by—country reporting obligation. Parliament also very much supports the SPC manufacturing waiver that would allow companies to produce generic medicines within Europe, which would lower healthcare costs and allow companies to keep jobs in the EU. We think it is important that the single market works for consumers and not just for companies. So actually in the text I would have liked more ambition on geoblocking, because when a company wants to segment the market, this is not always justified. We are also not completely convinced that we need geographical indication protection for non-agricultural products. But overall we can support the report.

name: Marco Zullo
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you to the rapporteur for her good work. I would like to appeal to my fellow Members to stress the importance of establishing a system of protection based on geographical indications for non-agri-food products, a system that would allow the excellence of our continent to see its peculiarities recognised. I also call on Commissioner Bieńkowska, who is here, to draw up as soon as possible a legislative proposal on indications of origin and production on the label, the famous made in. More information to the consumer can help him to make a more informed and informed choice, they are not an obstacle to the free movement of goods. The single market must certainly be developed around common rules, we must all speak the same language, but it must not be a game of downside. In my view, Europe will be strong if it is able to exploit the specific characteristics present on its territory; Europe will be strong if it is able to build a market for informed and informed citizens.

name: Mylène Troszczynski
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, your report probably outlines interesting ideas for the future, such as the collaborative economy, improving the financing of SMEs, start-ups, craftsmen or traders. Only you omit one thing: your balance sheet. You're not starting from scratch. The single market has been around for decades and the plans for the comet must give way to pragmatic balance sheets and realistic projections. And then everything falls apart! The news shows all over Europe that further European integration is not working. Worse, people no longer want it, or at least want less. However, through political autism or ideological blindness, you are proposing more Europe and calling for the eradication of the last obstacles to federalism so desired by the unelected Commissioners and technocrats in Brussels. It doesn't matter what people cry, how distressed people are, what common sense is, it's reality. Mrs Comi manages to reconcile, in a nice magic trick, the intensification of the fight against protectionism, the implementation of the "Services" directive, a real disaster for French companies, or the one on the secondment of workers, which destroys local jobs, with the protection of craftsmen and SMEs. Explain to us, other than through incantations, how these two objectives can be reconciled.

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (
text: NI). Mr President, there is no better and more successful argument than the so-called single market for all those who accuse the European Union of being addicted to big mouth and proclamations, but they are far from reality.  Where exactly have you seen the single market, when in each country we have different basic wages, different indirect and direct taxes and largely different regulations on the functioning of the market? How can you still mention the term 'single'? All the Union has created is a para-economic system, structured to benefit the largest companies in particular, especially multinationals, which have the means to overcome legal and fiscal obstacles to ensure greater profits.  In addition, you have condemned those countries that have weak economies to a permanent and lasting loss of valuable human resources for the benefit of the strongest states. So decide when you talk about a 'single market' who exactly are you kidding, yourselves or the citizens?  As for the inhuman, anti-national and unpopular mechanisms you create, the more you try to impose them, the shorter the inevitable collapse.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by congratulating rapporteur Lara Comi on the report she is proposing to us. It is an important contribution to improving the Single Market. It lists a set of vital measures for a stronger and fairer market, facing the 21st century and focusing on consumers. I would remind you, as the Commissioner has already done, that, alongside Schengen, the Single Market, which is one of the greatest achievements of the European Union, which European citizens feel in their day-to-day lives and which has completely transformed the way we trade, how we consume and how we circulate within the European area.  The potential of this market with more than five hundred million consumers is not fully exploited. Potential efficiency gains of €615 billion are estimated as the single market is deepened. However, obstacles to the free movement of goods and services remain, such as unjustified non-tariff regulatory requirements and several Member States that do not apply part of the important legislation in force. There is also a mistrust of consumers about cross-border contracts and some digital illiteracy.  All this represents unnecessary waste for the real economy and hinders greater growth and more job creation.  I therefore welcome the result achieved, in particular the emphasis on small and medium-sized enterprises, strong investment in digitisation of the market and combating geo-blocking, optimisation of the single digital portal, initiatives in the sharing economy and improvements in public procurement. To end, I underline the urgency of the Product Safety and Market Surveillance Package, which is blocked in the Council, and the urgency of Member States to ensure the proper implementation of the Services Directive.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Quite differently from what I have just heard, the citizens do not want less Europe, they want a better Europe in which a holistic, holistic approach is actually tackled! This means that we do not only see the economy, but also the workers, the consumers, the people, put people at the centre of our policy. That is what the citizens want!  I am therefore pleased that we have succeeded in adding a number of things to this report by Mrs Comi, which is very important – particularly in terms of worker protection, social protection, consumer protection and environmental protection. A very important question! I find it all the more strange, Mrs Comi, that it is precisely your group that is asking you to highlight the principle that we want equal pay for work of equal value in the same place. I simply cannot understand that, I do not understand that! Understand who wants what this approach wants, because that is exactly the opposite of what the citizens want. Commissioner, our group, the Socialist Group, is also somewhat sceptical about the European service passport. We do not yet quite see what it is meant to mean, what it should bring in terms of added value, in addition to all the instruments that already exist, such as the IMI system or the points of single contact from the Services Directive, or, for example, the European professional card that we have laid down in the Professional Recognition Directive. I do not think that, as we make more and more new instruments, we really bring relief for entrepreneurs and service providers. It would probably be a simplification and perhaps a merging of different systems more effective.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: Mr President, the report, as it is before today, provides an answer to what the European Commission previously proposed to improve internal market forces. I think that everyone today agrees that the internal market is not yet complete, and it is therefore a step in the right direction that this strategy pays a lot of attention to those sectors where there is still a lot of work to be done. I am thinking in particular of the services sector. We must make it easier for both consumers and businesses to move into that internal market: to consume, but also to do business. Get rid of the administrative, tariff and non-tariff barriers that unfortunately still keep our companies out of Europe. I am pleased that the principles of better regulation can also be found in several paragraphs in the text. On the other hand, I would like to express my concerns about the paragraphs relating to taxation, because that is still a national competence. In general, I do think that with this report we are taking a step in the right direction for a better functioning internal market. I will therefore vote in favour of the report.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, in this Chamber it is becoming quite a regular theme to discuss how the single market is faltering, and as always the so-called problems lie not with the Commission proposals but with Member States who fail to implement these laws. Blaming Member States is of course an easy answer to deflect the real issue of the single market, but we all know that the elephant in the room is the issue of over-regulation. Take, for example, manufacturers of bathroom goods. To sell toothbrushes in the single market they must abide by 31 EU laws, and to sell towels they must abide by an astonishing 454 EU laws. When you look into food regulation, it gets even more ridiculous. For bread, you need to abide by 1 200 laws, and to produce and sell milk you must abide by 12 000 EU laws. The single market is an instrument that favours big business. Endless rules and regulations which are simply too complex to comply with destroy the prospects of small-sized businesses and lead to higher prices and less choice for the consumer. British businesses have a choice, a once-in-a-generation opportunity to oppose more decades of costly regulations, endless red tape and unnecessary bureaucracy. On 23 June, many Britons can take back control and vote to leave the European Union.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I agree with the report in the meantime and, of course, the vote will be in favour of the issues presented. However, I wonder, but who is presenting the issues are not the same people who have governed this Europe for decades? So it reminds me a little bit of Renzi, who first puts taxes, then pulls them away, then puts them back and compliments himself. For example, Bolkestein is a lousy thing, which is a disaster for Italy above all, and there is still Bolkestein. We have the bathing operators, we have the peddlers who are calling for this paradoxical situation in Italy, and what are we doing? Rules on the internal market. They delocalizzano a lot of companies in Slovakia, Slovenia, Romania and here what happens? That, for example, Italian lorry drivers are persecuted compared to those who compete unfairly.  Then we have the made in and we asked and ask to vote today on the mandatory made in, because as it is written, those who are smart are always the usual Germany. We want it to be written that where things are produced, not pretend anything, because here once again Germany, which is part of the PPE, is doing what it wants, as usual, it does and does, it seems penelope. So, let's go ahead and vote on the mandatory made in.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – We have heard from Mrs Bieńkowska a lot of right words about the free market, about the single market, and immediately afterwards it is not known why you from EMPL, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs were allowed to speak, which, of course, aims to ensure that there is no single market there. There are all the socialists there: Mrs Reda and others have said that social issues are more important than some free market there. There was a discussion about milk just now. Marijana Petir was only worried about how to wean children from Croatia from cheap milk from other countries, from milk of poor quality. Well, if only an official will decide what milk is of good quality, it is known that a bribe will give a big company and big companies will get the status of good quality milk. Only a free market can protect the consumer from the dominance of big companies that bribe government officials. The free market prevailed à la Belle Époque, when there was no European Union, at the end of the 19th century, and that is why I believe that the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Speaking to the former, I am surprised that someone who considers himself a liberal is wasting public money to tell such a diversion here, and it has been around for a long time, and I am a little ashamed of it, and that he is sorry for it. Commissioner, Mrs Laro Comi, colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. We have been demanding good and honest information for the consumer for a long time, but I am wondering and I will focus today on only one point whether the information about the country of origin, this point made in fact arouses colossal emotions in all of us here. Is the country of origin information, and I mean countries within the European Union, really information about the quality of the product, who is responsible for the quality of the product: country or company? Let's take this scarf for example: the thread can come from one country, it can be laced in another country, it can be dyed elsewhere when it comes to design, then the artist can come from another country, so the company combines all the elements that I'm talking about here, a company to which the consumer should have confidence and which should provide the consumer with the right information, and I would like such a common market , where companies are competing, not European countries. This should be a market that does not burden small and medium-sized enterprises with additional bureaucracy.

name: Sergio Gaetano Cofferati (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the report we are debating is very important, the single market strategy is indeed a necessary reference for millions of European citizens. The rapporteur and the shadow have worked competently and passionately on this issue and have given us what I believe to be an important enrichment of the Commission's initial proposal, which did not have sufficient ambition. I would like to stress the fact that the social content of the internal market plays a decisive role, as has already been said. European citizens must identify with these strategies, they must see them as effective, because they improve their living conditions, their status as citizens when they work or simply when they live in their community. Then we must stress and then make the advancement of their rights and material conditions workable. That is why it is very important, for example, to recognise that, for the same work, the pay is the same. It is a fundamental right, it is the recognition of a condition of uniformity, which I do not understand why it should be called into question. Then those citizens must be guaranteed as consumers. Their fundamental rights are those of awareness through knowledge. Made in this serves, to guarantee companies fair competition, not made up of activities between them, carried out in distant places and peddled for activities instead of the neighboring territory, and to those who buy and to those who consume it is very important to let them know what they buy and what they consume. Finally, I believe that it is precisely for the benefit of the company and, at the same time, of those who work, that it is very important that in an economy there are decisive procedures for loyalty in tax behaviour, such as those that are called for. Transparency has a value in itself and has a very effective impact on general economic conditions.

name: Vicky Ford (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the single market makes it easier for businesses and consumers to trade across a marketplace of 500 million customers in 28 countries. It helps us to reduce costs and therefore increase choice. It is good to hear Members from across Europe support it. In the east of England that I represent, 50% of our exports go to customers in other parts of the single market; 300 000 jobs are directly linked to this trade, and it is 10% of our GDP. Of course there is always more we can do, especially to increase trade in services, to make the market fit for purpose in a digital age, to support innovators and to support businesses, small and large, and this report makes 100 specific recommendations. I am very pleased that in this report, Parliament will endorse the reforms negotiated by our national leaders in February to reduce red tape and set specific targets to reduce burden reductions in key sectors. Thank you also for supporting my suggestion for a more transparent and accessible appeals process on standardisations. There are a few issues I do not agree with but we can strip those out. In general this sets a clear direction of travel for improving and modernising our single market, and this will support jobs and growth, choice, and reduce costs. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: blue-card question. – Dear colleague, you are talking about standardisation, and you know, I received some letters from my country, from the small and medium-sized and micro-enterprises organisations, that are calling again and again that the Commission should have to come with a real definition on social economy enterprises. Do you not think that it is time that we should have to call again the Commission to come with this definition?

name: Vicky Ford (ECR)
text: blue-card answer. – So the standardisation process works with industry, businesses small and large, to let them set common European standards to make it easier for them to trade together, and I believe businesses small and large, from the social economy as well as traditional players, should work together and make that case to the European Commission. But this has to be industry-led, working with consumers and businesses.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE). Mr President, I consider the report on the Single Market Strategy to be a very important and comprehensive report, which I believe will be a milestone for years to come. It is a sufficiently comprehensive, very important report made by my dear colleague, Mrs Comi, in which she really deserves congratulations for this comprehensive work on such an important issue.  It is a report which is essentially aimed at the development of the economy, which will also lead to the prosperity of the peoples of the European Union. But it is much more aimed at more opportunities for citizens and for small and medium-sized enterprises. For us, since this report essentially gives particular meaning and value to both small and medium-sized enterprises and consumer support, it fulfils its objectives and mission.  For consumers in particular, it should be stressed that it is inconceivable that products marketed in the single market do not mention geographical origin. Essentially these products do not have the well-known "Made In", their identity. Products cannot be marketed and consumed and effectively marketed without their place of origin, geographical indication.  After all, this is a basic right of consumers. If we really respect consumers in practice, we must support them in practice. And practical support means recording the geographical origin, recording the data needed for consumers in order to be fully informed.  And lastly, Mr President, I would like to say that as far as geographical origin is concerned, we as Cyprus have suffered this, because products are produced in the occupied territories without identity, without procedures, without actually the provisions of the European Union and without the indication of geographical origin. There's a misdirection. With this report we are hitting deception and falsification, supporting the labelling and registration of the geographical origin of the products

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the Commission communication and the report we are debating today outline a long-term strategy, reaffirming Europe's vocation as a continent capable of offering itself and the world an efficient, sustainable and socially advanced model of development. The enhancement of quality production and its close link with the territories are one of the pillars of our economic and social model, which Europe must protect, on pain of irrelevance in the global market. The system of protection of geographical indications, currently in force for agricultural products, which has effectively protected European qualities, must also be extended to non-agricultural goods. Commissioner, we hope that the Commission will not delay further in presenting a legislative proposal that responds to the political will that this Parliament already demonstrated by a very large majority only a few months ago. Secondly, the protection of its quality products involves the recognition of the obligatory indication of the origin of products, the so-called made in, a rule already adopted by many of our trading partners. I believe that the search for a noble compromise which will allow us to introduce, at least in certain key areas, a principle that finally guarantees both consumers and our production system is a necessary act of responsibility on the part of the Council and that the Commission must effectively facilitate. Mr President, I would also like to make a final comment. However, the great achievement of the common market and its necessary strengthening risk breaking into the wall of national self-interest, in the absence of a strategic vision.
