A single market, without a political soul, will remain a mere bureaucratic construction, capable only of fuelling the anti-Europeanism of European public opinion.

name: Elisabetta Gardini (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to begin by thanking and acknowledging the great work done by the rapporteur, Mrs Lara Comi. , because, having put Amendment No 82 on compulsory origin, we are now able to give again, as a Parliament, having already voted on it on 15 April 2014 in the product safety and surveillance package, a clear message to the Commission and the Commissioner present here: unblock, make every effort to unblock that negotiation blocked in the Council because that is what consumers expect.  Guaranteeing the consumer is a key step in reviving our economy, with benefits for everyone, for businesses, but above all for all European citizens.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D).
text: – With the Internal Market in Goods and Services strategy, the Commission has openly committed itself to combating discrimination against consumers in the internal market.  It is not only consumer centres that often receive complaints from consumers concerning unjustified differences in treatment on grounds of nationality or residence. Any form of discrimination against consumers on the basis of their nationality or country of residence is absolutely unacceptable to me and against the very idea of the internal market.  I therefore very much welcome the strong rejection of the resolution on the current form of discrimination, both in and outside the electronic environment. The growing importance of the digital agenda cannot lead us to stop focusing on compliance and effective enforcement in the offline world. The resolution also, unlike the Commission, does not limit forms of discrimination to different prices, sales conditions, or the possibility of service.  I therefore call on the Commission, if it is serious about its commitment to combating discrimination, to respect this House's request and to carry out a thorough investigation into possible differences in the quality of products of the same brand and of the same packaging distributed within the single market, which is another concrete example of discrimination against consumers.

name: Pilar Ayuso (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I congratulate Mrs Comi on her report and I particularly support paragraphs 82 and 53. It would be very desirable to indicate the origin, the 'made in', for products that have to compete with imitations and counterfeits that confuse the consumer. But, of course, a European system of geographical indications is totally necessary to protect non-agricultural artisanal and industrial products, because countries' protection mechanisms vary greatly from state to state. Just as an example, in my country we have the cutlery of Albacete, the skin of Ubrique or Sales with Peña Aguilera or the lace of Almagro, which suffer very especially this problem.  These small and medium-sized enterprises based on traditional production methods that add value to local production have to constantly fight against imitation products and counterfeiting, without adequate mechanisms to protect themselves. I therefore invite the Commission to submit a legislative proposal to solve this problem.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the For me, the most important thing first is that equal pay for equal work in the same place is also a fundamental principle of the European internal market. The internal market is one of the core elements of European integration. It is based on the well-known four freedoms, which must be respected but also enforced. And that is why I repeat it: equal pay for equal work in the same place – that is part of this report. In the age of ever-increasing globalization and digitalization, Europe-wide trade in goods and services creates many new and innovative business models and opportunities. We must strategically shape the common internal market in such a way that the opportunities offered by the common market can be used as efficiently as possible and for the benefit of society as a whole. The internal market must therefore be made fair and fair. This also means that in our social market economy – as we impose ourselves in the EU Treaty – services in the general economic interest are also sufficiently respected. Finally, I would like to highlight one aspect of the Comi report, which is the subject of taxation. Taxes, aggressive tax planning, tax avoidance and tax practices are also clearly an issue for us and are to be dealt with here in the internal market report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, we Socialists and Democrats can be proud of the substantial improvements that our group has made to Mrs Comi's report, in order to breathe new life into this text, which at its core summed up the Commission's proposal very well. It was necessary to continue to ensure a high level of consumer protection, equal treatment and the creation of sustainable jobs. Beyond these aspects, I would like to pinpoint some of the priorities that are dear to me, and which are dear to our group, in the strategy for the single market, namely equal protection for the consumer shopping online or offline, the definition of the concept of a social economy enterprise, but also a legislative proposal on the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products and , finally, the promotion of handicrafts. As for the service passport, we must be vigilant, because it risks being a tool of unfair competition by promoting social dumping within the European Union. Do you want, in this context, to be the gravediggers of a Europe already sick of unfair competition within the internal market?

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, if the single market strategy is intended to create jobs and wealth in all the peoples of the European Union , as has been said, we must act to reverse the negative impact that the single market has had so far on the peoples who build the economic periphery of the Union, where our companies are already almost non-existent , our brands have been absorbed and our productions completely off-site. I don't think it's true what's said here, that allows us to choose. Now that they have the markets, they apply austerity to us. That is why I think it is essential that, before implementing or approving a new strategy, policies are ensured that prioritise the relocation of businesses and production, which prioritize the presence of local products in local and local markets. To do the opposite is to continue to impoverish the periphery, the peoples of the periphery of the European Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: - Mr. President, the report is heading in the right direction as it recognises the importance of SMEs to the European economy and highlights the biggest obstacles it encounters in the single market. The REFIT platform and a number of other programmes have finally tackled the administrative burden that is stifling business for everyone, especially smaller players in the market, so it is definitely worth supporting and further strengthening them. Simplification of rules and procedures, reduction of costs in production and trade and easier access to public procurement throughout the European Union can only be supported. However, I cannot agree with the Commission's call to combat tax mismatches in the Union, as I consider harmonisation of tax rates to be absolutely detrimental to poorer Member States. Indeed, they cannot compete in any way with more developed countries with quality infrastructure and greater legal certainty for investors and entrepreneurs other than lower tax rates, and in this way we would condemn them to a permanent lag.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, I want to clearly support this report on the single market strategy and I would like to highlight the five elements of this report. The first is to strengthen the roles of medium and small enterprises and their right of access to information, finance and funds. The second thing I want to support is the harmonisation of taxes, because I think it is very important for the functioning of the single market.  The third thing I want to support is the Digital Single Market, which we discussed more yesterday, and the Digital Single Market is a big assumption that it is the digital economy that would finally see the true light of day and be competitive on European soil. The fourth of course is the strengthening of cross-border services and fifth, perhaps even the most important in this report, I support the made in logic, because I believe that the quality and right of consumers to the country of origin and the product that is well produced and that it is known where it is produced, are extremely important for the future of the European economy.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: - Mr. President, I am in favour of introducing the Made in label, as I think it is important to establish a single European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-financial products in the Union, which Parliament has already called for. This would put an end to the inappropriate and extremely uneven situation in Europe and would have many and varied positive impacts for citizens, consumers, producers and the entire European economic and social environment.  Such an instrument would clearly highlight the added value of many local and traditional products, with obvious benefits for producers, the areas from which the products come and consumer awareness. Listing appropriate information on retail products, both handheld and industrial, in particular country of origin, is essential to protect consumers and strengthen the fight against counterfeiting.  Because it is important for consumers to know that lepoglava lace is produced in Lepoglava, Petrinjska stucka in Petrinja, Slavonian gold embroidery in Slavonia, and not elsewhere in the world. Made in protects our traditional crafts and the golden hands of our people.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR). Mr President, the objectives of the single market are supposed to be to boost competitiveness, create new jobs and strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises. However, in this period of financial crisis, the single market is far from approaching these objectives.  The single market has proved to have greatly strengthened the large enterprises and industries of the North, to the detriment of small and medium-sized enterprises in the South, increased unemployment by closing thousands of small and medium-sized enterprises and unevenly distributed the economic results produced.  This is particularly true of the impoverished Greece, where more than 250,000 small and medium-sized enterprises were closed. It is therefore necessary to immediately improve the strategy of the single market in order to strengthen employment and small and medium-sized enterprises in the South, as well as to create a social safety net for those affected by the functioning of the single market itself.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Madam Commissioner, the Digital Single Market Strategy is a necessity. I would like to congratulate the rapporteurs on the amendments made and stress that, as I have tabled in the amendments, it is urgently necessary to remove unjustified barriers in the single market. We need concrete and fast results in competitiveness, research, innovation, job creation, and for this we need, Commissioner, to propose support measures for SMEs, for those who are committed to creating jobs. We need to rethink the tax philosophy and the VAT regime in the internal market. I want to stress the need to adopt made in and extend the geographical indication to non-agricultural products. The Digital Single Market can only work if we have vocational, vocational training programmes and reach the poorest areas and the most remote and isolated areas of our sending, as well as the ability to connect online and offline. Commissioner, I believe that there is a need to support the issue of small and medium-sized enterprises and in terms of access to capital, access to finance and, as I said, a new fiscal policy. We have to support craftsmanship and crafts because they can generate jobs.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, I know that given the time I can only give you a few remarks most important for me. The first one is that we have just started the implementation phase of the single market strategy. We started yesterday with the e-commerce package with geo-blocking and anti-geographical discrimination measures put together, so as you ask, in a very coordinated way. Next week we will have communicational collaborative economy and on joint initiatives on standardisation – very important for our industry – and of course the next in line are geographical indicators for non-agricultural products, IPR, insolvency law that was mentioned by a few of you, start-ups initiative. I am very much sure about it – I believe in this – the single market is really a clear answer to many European problems, also social problems. It is not a barrier, not a threat; it is an opportunity, and it will be especially beneficial because, while preparing our single market strategy, we wanted to look at the situation with small companies’ license, with scale-ups, start-ups, they are the most important for us. So thank you very much for your support in this, as I have heard. I want to again congratulate Lara Comi for the report – a very good one – and I am looking forward for your help, your support and our cooperation.

name: Lara Comi
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank everyone for their constructive contributions and I would just like to make two points. The first concerns the case of bathers and peddlers. Firstly, it is a case that I have been following for seven years and therefore it is not an electoral spot that has always arrived in the run-up to the elections, it is a predominantly Italian problem, because Bolkestein has been accepted and transposed in Italy, so it will be the Italian Government, and I thank the Commissioner, who is awaiting the draft law, for his availability. So Europe has nothing to do with it. Secondly, I would just like to send a message. Instead of always blaming others, perhaps it is better to look at one's own home, because to win battles you have to be there in negotiations, meetings and votes and we are not in a regime, especially when last minute amendments are tabled just a few days before the vote, those who present them know very well that they will not have a result, because they are not agreed either with the rapporteur or with the rapporteur. , especially, with groups. You see, I think that, and I end with a sentence, "love always wins over hatred and envy" and maybe someone must have less envy and less hatred.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. – I consider the new Strategy for the European Union's internal market to be a very important report, because I believe that the proposals made here will help to fulfil the potential of the single market and serve as a good starting point for Europe's success on the global economic scene. Today's ambitious and pragmatic strategy focuses on results. The next step is for the EU institutions, in cooperation with the Member States, to implement these specific measures as quickly as possible. In my view, every end must be made to ensure that consumers who wish to buy services or products in another Member State, whether online or in person, do not have to face different prices, changing sales conditions or different delivery methods unless objective and verifiable arguments can be substantiated. The European Commission and the European Consumer Centre often receive complaints that customers have been wrongly treated differently on the basis of nationality or place of residence. This practice should be discontinued in the future. Continue to reduce investment restrictions and create new opportunities for consumers, professionals and companies. The single market must always keep pace with change, so it must encourage and adopt innovative new business models.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I support the own-initiative report on the Internal Market Strategy; it is an important step towards completing the European internal market and thus making Europe competitive in the future. On the basis of the Internal Market Strategy published by the European Commission in October 2015, we have managed to set further important priorities. The aim of our work was to make the internal market more innovative and modern. Important approaches are that we call for easier access to EU funds for SMEs. We also call for there to be facilitation of access to patents for SMEs, micro-enterprises and start-ups. These often very innovative companies must be able to protect their ideas and developments. The own-initiative report also deals intensively with the issue of the sharing economy. It is important that we establish equal rules for equal services in this area.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. The relaunch of the internal market can bring opportunities and resources of great benefit to Europe: the beating heart of the Community project is the productive and competitiveness capacity built up over all these years thanks to the integration of the common market. For a country like Italy, which has a value of excellence in quality manufacturing and small and medium-sized enterprises, the consolidation of the internal market network is certainly a strategic property, and I therefore welcome the strong and authoritative message that this Chamber sends to the European Commission with its report on the common market strategy. Europe is an area of citizenship that integrates with one of the largest areas in the world by commercial weight: the combination of high quality of production and modernisation of the market is the key to ensuring European competitiveness. I would therefore like to stress the important statement in favour of the principle of Made in contained in this report, a principle that this House has reiterated on several occasions and succeeded in guiding the new strategies of the European Commission.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. – As a member of the Committee on Labour and Social Affairs, I welcome the fact that the Single Market Strategy supports the removal of EU non-discrimination loopholes, in particular for persons with disabilities. I would like to point out that Directive 2000/78/EC establishing a general framework for equal treatment in employment and work must be implemented without delay. There is concern that between 40% and 47% of the EU population have insufficient digital skills, even though demand for digitally skilled workers is increasing by 4% a year. In my opinion, training and education in the fields of information and communication technologies, science, technology, engineering and mathematics should be encouraged in order to ensure that both current and future workers have the relevant digital skills. I stress the need for inclusive education, in which persons with disabilities can participate, because this also helps the integration of people with disabilities into the workplace and society. In my view, public spending on education has a key role to play in preserving the EU's medium-term competitiveness and workforce and member states should therefore be encouraged to invest in digital education and skills.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. Ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen, I invite you to vote in favour of this report because it makes important points, particularly for European consumers and workers. Firstly, the establishment at European level of a mandatory system for communicating essential information on handmade and industrial products.  This system would be a real added value for consumers and I hope that the European Commission will hear our appeal. Finally, the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place as an important tool to combat market distortions. European citizens and workers expect Europe to fight social dumping more effectively, and respect for this principle in the context of the secondment of workers would be a first step forward.  In view of all these elements, it seemed important to me that the European Parliament should support this text. I also hope that the Commission will be ambitious on both issues. Thank you for your attention.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan (PPE)
text: in writing. – The Single Market is the backbone of European economic integration. That is why the strategy for the development of the Single Market is welcome. The effort must be focused on two priorities: removing any barriers to the free movement of products, services, capital and labour; stopping corruption and abusive practices of transferring profits from one country to another, while trade in intangibles is on the rise. We must recognise that the single market is still fragmented for essential products and services such as electricity and natural gas, for which investment in the necessary connections is expected. The European Union is also adopting many regulations that diminish the competitiveness of European companies, especially small and medium-sized ones. Stopping the abusive transfer of profits from one country to another must be done as quickly as possible, so as not to further destroy citizens' confidence in the rule of law and in the state authorities.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. – We need the completion of a single market, which will be a pillar of EU integration and a driver for sustainable growth and jobs. Despite developments in recent years, we still have many reserves, particularly in removing unjustified physical, legal and technical barriers. I agree with the report, which supports the overall objectives of the Commission's Single Market strategy for goods and services and measures in key areas that will exploit the full potential of the single market for the benefit of consumers and businesses, especially start-ups. This will increase the number of sustainable jobs and strengthen SMEs.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It's about virtual currencies like Bitcoin. It is true that virtual currencies and the technology behind them can have very positive effects. Savings of billions of dollars can be expected. The so-called distributed ledgers are technological quantum leaps that enable decentralized transaction networks. But this decentralized approach makes one thing impossible: centralized control, regulation, and monitoring. And that is the problem of bureaucrats. Regulation needs the central approach. She is helpless against the blockchain. This helplessness permeates the whole report. But we need a new technology that can do without regulation and supervision and without bureaucrats – even in the future – without the supervision of the Commission and the ECB. The bureaucrats of the ECB should leave their fingers off the virtual currencies and bitcoins. That is why I voted against.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Since their inception, bitmons and other virtual currencies, as well as their underlying technology, have had a sufficiently wide impact on the global financial market and various economic sectors. It is therefore unambiguous to assess qualitatively the actual and future potential of such innovations, their performance and, where appropriate, to develop principles governing their activities. That is what I support. But virtual currencies have the potential to significantly reduce the cost of social transactions and operations for payments, especially cross-border transfers of funds. They may also have a clear positive impact on the speed of the realisation of such activities, based on the specificity of the safety architecture of the application. So – ease of use! Support!

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I supported this report, but, unlike a few of my previous sayers, I want to warn against virtual currencies being fully admitted into the financial system without some kind of initial regulation.  I think that regulating every human activity is, of course, unacceptable to me. On the other hand, the stability of the financial system and the possibility of responding to the negatives that virtual currencies bring into that system, so it is the responsibility of the legislator, i.e. our duty.  Indeed, the negatives that are described in all the same terms for the virtual currency are the legalisation of the proceeds of crime and the high volatility associated with these virtual currencies and speculative bubbles, which can only result in the fall of the financial system. I am therefore calling for regulation that will be in advance.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament, with this report, has for the first time dealt with virtual currencies based mainly on distributed ledger technology (DLT). In addition to lean and high-performance legislation, the report refers to a clear definition of virtual currencies. The report also proposes the creation of a horizontal task force, composed of the main actors and experts in the field of virtual currencies. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on virtual currencies because I believe that in order to avoid the gagging of innovation, preventive control is needed, not preventive legislative regulation

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This initiative report provides an overview of the development of virtual currencies, the main danger of which, in addition to the dematerialization of the currency which is supposed to be tangible, is the emergence of an international currency market independent of the power of central banks and therefore of states. It is also feared that one of the motivations that encourages large international banks to invest in virtual currencies is the possible establishment of an interbank market managed exclusively by themselves. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a non-legislative report that attempts to regulate virtual currencies that operate on a global basis. The tone of this report clearly demonstrates that the EU is scared of the fact people have a choice of the currency they use online, and the EU thinks the United States is in control of the internet. I voted against this report.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report is about the currently rapidly spreading virtual currencies, the best known representative of which is Bitcoin, and recommends that the Commission set up a working group to study this. Seven years after the introduction of Bitcoin, the first and most widely used virtual currency, it became clear that the underlying innovation, DSD, had a significant impact on the financial sector and beyond. In principle, this technology allows you to record any transaction decentralized, fast, reliable and relatively secure, along with the history of previous transactions in a shared ledger. They are investing more and more in DTS, and some applications can quickly become system-wide. At the same time, as the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection points out, the use of virtual currencies poses potential risks to the financial system, both in terms of regulation and market surveillance and security, and can pose a threat to financial integrity and effective financial regulation. With the spread of virtual currencies, risks to financial stability may be more pronounced. As the report merely proposes to set up a working group to study the internet currency called virtual money, I supported this.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Any attempt to regulate internet virtual currencies on a geographical basis is futile and misplaced. An EU which has created the euro as its single currency cannot hope to lend credibility and reliability to virtual currencies, in fact the EU’s record is so bad that any regulation by it would be bad for confidence. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. 7 years after the creation of bitcoins, it seemed appropriate to make an initiative report on this new kind of currency. This technology, in principle, allows a decentralization of the means, fast, flexible and fairly safe to record any kind of transaction as well as the history of previous transactions in a "distributed book".  The main possibilities of virtual currencies and DLT (distributed database) in the field of payments relate to reducing transaction costs and ease of use while ensuring resilience and privacy levels. In this context, it should be noted that transaction costs for payments remain surprisingly high. On average, more than 7% of cross-border remittances are consumed by transfer costs. In the medium term, competition could be enhanced by the introduction of a single, non-exclusive and interoperable portfolio. The important points of the report are: facilitating micro-payments for online purchases of goods; DLTs' potential at European level; difficulties related to pseudo-anonymity; Creating a commission-led task force to assess potential assessments of LTCs and virtual currencies; Transparency and consumer awareness; anti-money laundering.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies, often referred to as digital money, represent a new means of payment based largely on distributed ledger technology (DLT). Among these virtual currencies, the most relevant one is undoubtedly bitcoin that holds, despite not having reached systemic dimensions, 90% of the market. The von Weizsäcker report, which I supported with my vote, effectively highlights the opportunities and challenges associated with the use of virtual currencies and DLT. Their introduction has already led to lower transaction costs, but in the future it could prove even more important in areas where standardisation, reliability and ownership play a crucial role, such as public services, smart contracts, intellectual property transfers and supply chain management. The text also calls for the introduction of intelligent regulation that does not stifle technological growth linked to the applications of DLT and at the same time ensures that the risks of abusing these means for illegal purposes, such as money laundering and terrorist financing, are avoided. To this end, the European Commission should create a task force to regulate virtual currencies

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the recent phenomenon of virtual currencies, such as Bitcoin. These currencies have the potential to become a structural part of our financial systems. However, they contain important risks such as the ease of generating speculative bubbles, and their use for criminal activities. The report mentions these aspects and calls for greater regulation of virtual currencies.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this motion for a resolution on Virtual Currencies of the ECON committee of the European Parliament. It emphasizes that these currencies can contribute positively to the well-being of the citizen and economic development by reducing the costs of operations and operation of payments, the cost of access to financing even without a traditional bank account, increasing resilience, enabling systems that combine ease of use, systems to develop online micropayment insurance systems and allowing the possibility of merging different types of traditional and innovative payment mechanisms.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which is positive about the dematerialization of money through so-called virtual currencies. Yet they represent a great danger, a total opacity of transactions favorable to criminal activities such as money laundering, financing of terrorist activities or the activities of fraud and/or tax evasion. Moreover, if they remain marginal today - the "bitcoin" holding 90% of the market share for "only" 5 billion euros - these virtual currencies pose the risk of creating a currency market independent of the power of central banks, let alone, states. In the long run, we would end up with an interbank market exclusively managed by the major international banks and therefore the submission of all and without limit or restriction on the power of money. However, I would be less adamant about distributed registries (DLT) technology, which, when used correctly, has tremendous potential, for example in terms of crowdfunding.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Von Weizsäcker report on virtual coins is not entirely acceptable and has some passages that could lead to critical issues. That is why I did not intend to support you with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. More than 600 virtual currency systems are currently operating. As this report points out, virtual currencies and distributed registration technology can contribute positively to the well-being of citizens and economic development, including in the financial sector, reducing operating costs and payment operating costs; reducing the cost of access to finance, even without a traditional bank account, or increasing the speed of payment systems and trade in goods and services. However, they also involve risks, such as the absence of flexible and reliable governance structures, their high volatility, or the legal uncertainty surrounding them.  The report recommends increasing regulatory capacity, as well as developing a sound legal framework that is up to innovation, ensuring a timely and proportionate response if they become systemically relevant. It therefore calls for the establishment of a horizontal working group led by the Commission and composed of regulatory and technical experts to analyse these new systems in depth and to support a timely, well-founded and proportionate response to the new opportunities and challenges involved. It also calls on the Commission to improve consumer information on them.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has been advocated by Parliament on the increasing popularity of virtual currencies. In order to curb the opening of the paths for money laundering and terrorist financing by virtual currencies such as bitcoins, the European Commission should set up a working group to monitor the use of these currencies. This expert group should pool existing experience and knowledge on virtual currencies, analyse their risks and benefits and make recommendations on possible proportionate regulation that does not prevent innovation. In its resolution, Parliament supported prior supervision rather than blind regulation. Information technology is spreading very rapidly and becoming systems, and we call on the European Commission to set up a working group to oversee the development of these technologies and to be prepared to propose new rules when and if needed. Parliament welcomed the European Commission's plans to include virtual currency exchange platforms in EU anti-money laundering rules. This would eliminate the anonymity associated with such platforms and reduce the risk of money laundering and terrorist financing.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies are innovative products, an option that needs to be used, but since it is a novelty, we must take careful care as far as regulating it is concerned. I could compare the bitcoin case to Uber, both of which are a new thing, popular with our citizens, but both carry a danger. The first problem is that it is causing revulsion among its traditional peers, and the other is that member states' bodies have not yet been able to pick up the pace, as far as their regulation is concerned. These factors also weaken these products, including the largest virtual cash player, Bitcoin, which is also mentioned in the report. I am sure that virtual exchange rates can give the internal market a new opportunity for development, and that they will certainly benefit either as a basic account or as an online purchaser. Of course, it is very important to give our consumers a proper guarantee of product safety. I believe that the issue and regulation of virtual exchange rates should be manageable. It is important that we consider the possibilities for technical progress, and the reporter has done a great job on this issue, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on virtual currencies. Seven years after the introduction of bitcoin, the first and most important virtual currency, it has become clear that the innovation on which bitcoin is based, the so-called distributed ledger technology (DLT technology), will have a profound impact on the financial sector and beyond. The main opportunities for virtual currencies and DLT technology in the area of payments relate to reducing transaction costs and ease of use, while ensuring a high level of privacy protection. However, I would like to draw attention to the rather high cost of transactions for payments, which means that there is still a lot of work to be done to make full use of the potential of virtual currencies.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the face of the rapid evolution of virtual coins, this resolution asks the Commission to deepen the phenomenon and in particular the developments of the Blockchain database. Consumer awareness, transparency and trust remain important at virtual level as well, and this is why the resolution calls on the Commission to develop guidelines to ensure that current and future users are provided with correct and clear information, to enable them to make informed choices and to increase the transparency of virtual currency systems with regard to the way in which they are organised and managed and the characteristics that distinguish them , in terms of consumer protection, from regulated and supervised payment systems. It is also clear that virtual coins can also be the subject of money laundering practices or may be affected by terrorist financing channels. That is why Parliament hopes that virtual currency exchange platforms will also be covered by the anti-money laundering directive.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The issue of virtual currencies is very complex, but it is certainly a reality and regulation of the area is necessary. I congratulate my colleague Danti on his work and support his work.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Virtual currencies present two main dangers. First, they reveal an international currency market independent of the power of central banks and thus of states. Second, transactions made with these currencies allow for complete anonymity. They are used mainly on the "black market" for money laundering, terrorist financing, fraud and tax evasion and other criminal activities. These currencies have no real basis, are not subject to any regulation and are primarily used to finance criminal activities. As for distributed registries technology, it makes it possible to process large quantities of transactions reliably and very quickly. Its potential is developing beyond the financial sector. This technology also presents an opportunity for public bodies by simplifying and securing online administration services and data protection. I am still voting against this report, which presents virtual currencies as a way to contribute positively to the development of the economy and peoples.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that virtual currencies have enormous potential to make life easier for European citizens as they can speed up, decentralise, automate and standardise data-driven processes at a lower cost. These characteristics could therefore facilitate financial inclusion and the achievement of the G20 and G8 "5x5" objective.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies are an interesting new and expanding tool, capable, in particular, of favoring a significant reduction in the costs of payment transactions, while ensuring the privacy of users.  In fact, (in addition to cash) it is the only type of payment currently in existence that can allow real-time settlement, i.e. to allow the recipient to receive 100 % of the money at the time of payment. For these reasons, I support a greater development of virtual currencies, not least as they are an interesting tool that can encourage and stimulate the growth of the European single market. From this point of view, I believe that we must promote the development of shared and uniform rules at European level that promote a level playing field between the various Member States and that prevent phenomena such as money laundering and terrorist financing, regulations which, at the same time, must not penalise, by means of excessively strict preventive rules, the possible development of virtual currencies in other alternative sectors to the area of payments.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report provides an overview of the development of virtual currencies and the underlying technology that enables them to operate. Virtual currencies are presented as a way to contribute positively to the economic development of our nations. On the contrary, we consider them to be a real danger insofar as they are completely beyond the control of central banks and states.  In addition, virtual currencies offer total anonymity to those who use them to carry out transactions; they are therefore mainly used to finance criminal activities. Because we are opposed to the use of these virtual currencies which are not subject to any regulation, I voted against this report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology have a positive impact on the well-being of citizens by helping to create secure, easy-to-use and low transaction and operational costs, while ensuring respect for privacy. There will also be reductions in the cost of access to finance, even in the absence of a traditional bank account, which favours achieving the objectives of financial inclusion and reducing the cost of transferring funds by 5% in five years. Registry technology facilitates the decentralized, fast, resilient recording of any type of transaction, along with the history of previous transactions. It also offers the possibility of merging traditional and innovative payment instruments into a single application, which would contribute to the development of e-commerce, but also to the deepening of the single market. For smart regulation in this area to support innovation, it is necessary to develop the capacity of regulators in the field of technical expertise. I was in favour of this report because I believe it is an opportune report that will help to improve the level of well-being of citizens in financial terms and will also lead to the strengthening of the single market.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The theme of virtual coins based on DLT technology does not yet appear to reach dimensions of a "structural" nature such as to justify their standardization; in addition, we add our scepticism to a "virtual" instrument with regard to the currency with all the possible distortions and difficulties of application that it may entail. I am voting against.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this pioneering report on virtual currencies because it correctly identifies the opportunities and risks offered by this technology. Virtual currencies are private and decentralized in nature, reducing costs by not requiring a clearing box. At the same time, they should be adequately regulated to prevent their use by criminal and terrorist networks, as well as to inform investors in a timely manner.  In the future, consideration should also be given to the role that the European Central Bank can play in the field of virtual currencies, as it is the institution, together with the central banks of countries that have not yet adopted the euro, that have a monopoly on the issuance of coins and legal tenders. It should be noted that the report has had very broad support both in committee and in plenary.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Virtual currencies are digital representations of a value that are not issued by either a bank or a public authority. They are not necessarily linked to a fiduciary currency but are accepted as a form of payment.  There are more than 600 virtual currency systems. The best known of these is Bitcoin. Virtual currencies have advantages such as reducing transaction costs, reducing access to financing, or improving the resilience and speed of payment systems. They also carry certain risks related to the lack of governance that creates insecurity and consumer protection problems, or volatility and legal uncertainty.  The report does not call for immediate legislation in relation to virtual currencies, but first proposes a comprehensive impact assessment. The report calls for the creation of a task force on virtual currencies and distributed register technology led by the Commission and made up of regulatory and technical experts. The goal is to eventually create a proportionate regulatory framework that does not impede innovation. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reading and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on virtual currencies and I agree first of all with its cautions, in view of a fundamental reflection: the currency and financial markets are not ready for this revolution and the banking markets do not want it. One need only consider, on this point, that they are opposed by banks, as this currency makes transactions cheaper than PayPal, much better than credit cards, and by the currency markets, because of the enormous volatility of the stock, which can destabilise the markets. Preventive regulation is needed. Technological innovations can spread very quickly and become systemic. That is why we are calling on the Commission to set up a task force to actively monitor the development of technology and, if necessary, to make timely proposals for specific regulation.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which calls for an analysis of the rising use of virtual currencies (VCs) such as the bitcoin, which are stored and traded online through distributed ledger technology (DLT). The report outlines the risks associated with the use of a totally unregulated currency which has been issued privately instead of through a central bank or public authority – for example, legal uncertainty for consumers, anonymous use which contributes to tax fraud and money laundering, potential for speculative bubbles, etc. It also notes that the worldwide web and DLT are internet-based and that despite efforts to create an international governance system the internet is still governed by an agency in the US Department of Commerce.  While the report does not propose pre-emptive legislation to regulate virtual currencies at this stage, it does call for the Commission to carry out an analysis of VCs and consider revising existing relevant EU legislation on payments to include regulation of VCs if appropriate.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Any attempt to regulate internet virtual currencies on a geographical basis is futile and misplaced. An EU which has created the euro as its single currency cannot hope to lend credibility and reliability to virtual currencies, in fact the EU’s record is so bad that any regulation by it would be bad for confidence. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Virtual currencies are an interesting phenomenon and they are increasingly popular. I agree that they need to be looked at closely and the risks and opportunities associated with them need to be explored. I therefore voted in favour of this report. However, I would like to point out that when creating new legislation in future in order to protect consumers and prevent fraud, we need to remember to avoid over-regulation.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report examines the positive aspects and risks associated with the use of virtual currencies, which represent a new form of payment of increasing importance on international markets. I voted in favour of this report, which is balanced in its analysis of the possible risks and benefits for European consumers. Furthermore, the report insists precisely on the need for a regulation of this new form of payment and for a universal definition of virtual currency.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Virtual coins (bitcoins) are spreading in particular through the so-called distributed ledger technology (DLT) which forms the technological foundation of more than 600 virtual currency systems. Although virtual currencies in circulation have not yet reached systemic dimensions, they are worth more than EUR 5 billion. Reducing transaction costs and operating costs for payments could be of benefit to citizens, but for bitcoin to spread widely, they will need to be properly regulated to ensure that transactions meet high levels of security.  The volatility of virtual currencies is particularly suited to the creation of speculative bubbles but above all to transactions on the 'black market', such as money laundering or the financing of criminal activities. Virtual coins can pose a threat and for this reason, as called for in the resolution, a task force made up of technical experts and regulatory experts on the DLT must be set up within the European Commission to verify and possibly draw up a lean legal framework which does not penalise innovation but which is capable of effectively counteracting the risks posed by these new technologies. I therefore voted in favour of the resolution.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that it has become clear that the underlying innovation, distributed ledger technology (DLT), is expected to have a significant impact on the financial sector and beyond.  As investment in DLT technology soars and some applications could quickly become systemic, the significant opportunities and non-negligible risks involved make this first European Parliament report on virtual currencies and DLT technology a timely undertaking.  We believe that smart legislation on DLT technology is needed.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted today on the report on virtual currencies. It is obvious that the process of transitioning the world economy to a virtual currency regime must be seriously and carefully monitored. While online services and more and more citizens' access to a technologically developed environment favour the development of virtual currencies, we are obliged to highlight the risks that exist, as well as to look at all the data as the report points out.  That is why I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Seven years after the launch of the bitcoin, the first and most prominent virtual currency (VC), it has become clear that the underlying innovation, distributed ledger technology (DLT), is set to have a significant impact on the financial sector and beyond. This technology, in principle, enables a decentralised, rapid, resilient and rather secure means of recording any sort of transaction together with the history of previous transactions in a ‘distributed ledger’. Investment in DLT is soaring and certain applications could rapidly become systemic. While there are still some questions regarding the scope of this ongoing technological transformation, the considerable opportunities and non-negligible risks involved make this first report by Parliament on VC and DLT a timely undertaking.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Any attempt to regulate internet virtual currencies on a geographical basis is futile and misplaced. An EU which has created the euro as its single currency cannot hope to lend credibility and reliability to virtual currencies, in fact the EU’s record is so bad that any regulation by it would be bad for confidence. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – Any attempt to regulate internet virtual currencies on a geographical basis is futile and misplaced. An EU which has created the euro as its single currency cannot hope to lend credibility and reliability to virtual currencies, in fact the EU’s record is so bad that any regulation by it would be bad for confidence. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The technological transformation brought about in the financial system with the introduction of virtual currencies represents important opportunities related to the reduction of transaction costs and ease of use. At the same time, it is necessary to monitor the risks associated with the development of this technology vis-à-vis consumers, which must be protected by transparent operations and clear and complete information. Only by ensuring the proper functioning of the system and knowledge of the use of virtual currencies, can users' confidence in their use be increased. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that effective regulation should be developed that is sufficiently dynamic to adapt to technological innovation, while fully respecting consumer rights. In this regard, it is essential to set up supervisory and control bodies to monitor innovations in the application of these financial instruments.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Clearing, settlement and other post-trade management processes currently cost the global financial industry well in excess of EUR 50 billion per year. Together with bank reconciliation processes, these are areas where the use of DLT might turn out to be transformational in terms of efficiency, speed, and resilience, but would also raise new regulatory challenges. I agree that a merge into one secure and user-friendly application could advance certain aspects of e-commerce in Europe and deepen the single market. I favour the development of a level European playing field to allow the valuable potential of DLTs to be unleashed and fully developed. They can be used in numerous innovative fields and in a wide range of industries and services, such as ‘smart contracts’, crypto-equity crowdfunding and dispute mediation services, in particular in the financial and juridical sectors. I support the call to encourage public bodies to evaluate the benefits and explore the possibility of applying such innovative technologies to other fields with the aim of providing better, more rapid and more efficient services to EU citizens.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this report because even though it adequately characterizes the risks of virtual currencies, it does not require them to be regulated in a similar manner with the financial services they perform. As in the Digital Agenda, the digitization of services leaves the door ajar to their deregulation, in this case payment systems and financial deposits: something that we oppose head-on.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies can contribute positively to the well-being of citizens and economic development, including in the financial sector through, for example, a reduction in both transaction costs and the cost of access to finance and a strengthening of the speed of payment systems. However, virtual currency systems can also involve risks, such as high volatility of virtual currencies and the risk of speculative bubbles, user protection issues and criminal activities such as the possibilities of black market transactions, money laundering, terrorist financing. The European Parliament resolution, on which I voted in favour, suggests that in order to meet these risks and increase the reliability of virtual currencies, a balance must be struck between strengthening regulatory capacity and a solid legal framework that is in step with innovations and at the same time maintaining a certain flexibility and preventing early regulation , which is not adapted to an evolving reality, can send the public the wrong message about the advantages or security of virtual coins.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 At an early stage, the virtual currency industry has experienced rapid development due to the potential of distributed ledger technology to accelerate, decentralize, automate and standardize data-driven processes, reducing the costs of asset transfer and ledger management.  This technology can contribute positively to the well-being of citizens and to the economic development of Member States by promoting financial inclusion and facilitating access to finance in a wide range of industries and services in both the public and private sectors.  However, regulation and the creation of a strong legal framework have not kept pace with the rapid development of this innovative technology, increasing the risks of illicit use. Promoting operational transparency and developing effective regulatory solutions to ensure consumer protection, resilience and reliability of the system architecture are necessary to reduce uncertainty about the evolution of this area and the vulnerability of users. I voted in favour of the report on virtual currencies calling on the European Commission to develop a coherent, comprehensive strategy to identify the benefits and risks associated with this technology, as well as to strengthen regulatory capacity to monitor and ensure the security of markets and consumers.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies are innovative products, an option that needs to be used, but since it is a novelty, careful care must be taken with it in terms of regulation. It can trigger revulsion among its traditional counterparts and the competent bodies of the Member States can only react late in relation to their regulation. These factors weaken these new products, including bitcoin, the largest virtual cash player. Virtual exchange rates can give the internal market a new opportunity for development, and they can be used as a basic account or as an online purchaser. Consumers, on the other hand, should be given an adequate guarantee of the safety of the product. It is important to consider the possibilities for technical progress with regard to virtual currencies. Parliament's report adds to this.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This very balanced report discusses the opportunities and risks of virtual currencies and decentralised ledger technology in the area of payments. It addressed the use of DLT in areas other than payments and made recommendations on the approach to be taken. The report highlights the potential of virtual currencies to reduce transaction and servicing costs for cross-border transfers of funds, to reduce access to finance costs for those without a bank account, and to develop secure online micropayment systems. As regards risks, the report highlights the lack of governance structures, the limited capacity of regulators, consumer protection aspects and the potential for use for money laundering and terrorist financing.  I support the compromise reached on these issues, as the proposed extension of the anti-money laundering directive has been limited to virtual currency exchange platforms following an impact assessment and therefore does not cover the services of electronic wallets. In view of the main provisions of the report and the compromises reached, I voted in favour of it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This innovative method of payment focuses on both opportunities and risks in the technological landscape of payments. I believe that even though we need to recognise the welfare and economic contribution of virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology we need a solid framework that does not hinder innovation yet provides a basis of precautionary monitoring. The current framework needs to be closely analysed in both technological and regulatory terms, we need to ensure a resilient and consumer protected system. This is why I voted in favour of this report, as I believe that together with the other proposals, the horizontal task force DLT is an important step forward, especially when considering the growing fear that these virtual currencies could be used with criminal intent.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which supports the development of virtual currencies, which in turn have the potential to lower costs for businesses and consumers when making cross-border transfers of funds. This report could also help reduce costs to accessing finance for those without a bank account whilst it also supports monitoring, rather than harmful regulation of these new forms of currency.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has suggested the overall approach that the EU should take with regard to virtual coins and the technologies behind them, Distributed Ledger Technology. An innovative universe that arouses curiosity, given its infinite possibilities of development and use, but also some sincere perplexity, due to its possible use for un lawless purposes, such as money laundering, fraud, tax evasion or even the financing of criminal activities.  I am pleased with the final result of Von Weizsäcker's report, which proposes the creation of a specific European task force on the subject, which in the coming months will be able to analyse and monitor this ever-changing phenomenon, so as to fully explore its enormous potential and possible new uses, not only in the financial sector, but also, for example, in the e-government services sector or in the legal services sector. , which could make the lives of our citizens easier and easier.  Technologies linked to virtual currencies are one of the many faces of the ongoing digital revolution and must be addressed through the definition of a strategy at European level that addresses this issue in a coordinated, coherent and transversal way, without ever forgetting the full protection and information of our citizens.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This report addresses the challenges and opportunities of the phenomenon of cryptocurrency, decentralized electronic currency, and banking transactions governed by blockchain technologies, information storage and transmission technology. In particular, the report calls for the strengthening of the legal framework to ensure security in the use of virtual currency and the establishment of a working group dedicated to this subject. Considering that the modernisation of the financial sector must be accompanied by a clear framework, in order to support the real economy in the long term, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. This report on virtual currencies highlights the benefits and risks of virtual currencies and distributed register technology. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for smart and proportionate regulation at EU level. However, I stress that these virtual currencies must be carefully framed in order to stop their use in criminal activities such as the sale of weapons, drugs, money laundering or the financing of terrorism.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The virtual currency Bitcoin was created seven years ago. Since then, many dematerialized currencies have developed online. These virtual currencies have the advantage of reducing transaction costs. But the virtual currency has been criticized for its volatility: after exceeding $1,100 in 2013, it fell back to $150 in early 2015 before starting a rebound last month.  The lack of legal control also creates a grey area that can favour the use of virtual currencies for money laundering, fraud or terrorist financing. For this reason, the European Union must have legislation as soon as possible, including measures to ensure the monitoring of these transactions and to protect the interests of users of this type of platform.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies are innovative products, an option that needs to be used, but since it is a novelty, we must take careful care as far as regulating it is concerned. I could best compare the bitcoin case to Uber, both of which are new things, popular with our citizens, but both also carry a threat. The first problem is that it is causing revulsion among its traditional peers, and the other is that member states' bodies have not yet been able to pick up the pace, as far as their regulation is concerned. These factors also weaken these products, including the largest virtual cash player, Bitcoin, which is also mentioned in the report. I am sure that virtual exchange rates can give the internal market a new opportunity for development, and that they will certainly benefit either as a basic account or as an online purchaser. Of course, it is very important to give our consumers a proper guarantee of product safety. I believe that the issue and regulation of virtual exchange rates should be manageable. It is important to consider the possibilities for technical progress. On this issue, the reporter did a great job, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. This report calls for the creation of a working group to better understand the issue of virtual currencies, such as bitcoin, and distributed register technology. It would seem that there are some advantages: reduction of financial transaction costs and associated risks, traceability of trade, response to the financial crisis and the resulting problem with the shortage of credit to finance the economy, improved services administered online...  But the amount of darkness remains significant, particularly regarding the possibility of using these virtual currencies in the context of money laundering and terrorist financing or tax circumvention. For my part, I wonder about the links between this ICT-related innovation and the financial transaction tax I want. The ad hoc working group should shed light on the issues, opportunities and dangers to the general interest of distributed registers and, if necessary, make proposals for adequate regulation if the need arises.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Virtual currencies are innovative products, an option that needs to be used, but since it is a novelty, we must take careful care as far as regulating it is concerned. I could best compare the bitcoin case to Uber, both of which are new things, popular with our citizens, but both also carry a threat. The first problem is that it is causing revulsion among its traditional peers, and the other is that member states' bodies have not yet been able to pick up the pace, as far as their regulation is concerned. These factors also weaken these products, including the largest virtual cash player, Bitcoin, which is also mentioned in the report. I am sure that virtual exchange rates can give the internal market a new opportunity for development, and that they will certainly benefit either as a basic account or as an online purchaser. Of course, it is very important to give our consumers a proper guarantee of product safety. I believe that the issue and regulation of virtual exchange rates should be manageable. It is important to consider the possibilities for technical progress. On this issue, the reporter did a great job, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text provides an overview of the development of virtual currencies and the underlying technology of distributed registers (LTDs) for their operation. Bitcoin is a virtual currency, created in 2009, which risks serving as the basis for an international currency market, independent of the power of central banks and therefore of states. In addition, the transactions concerned are covered by anonymity and thus promote questionable movements such as money laundering, terrorist financing, fraud and tax evasion.  DLT technology enables large quantities of transactions to be processed reliably and very quickly, through new, more efficient and less costly intermediate players. It can also simplify and secure the online administration services of public bodies. It is therefore necessary to remain vigilant about this technology with great potential. It must not be exploited by large digital groups that want to get their hands on the digital security and information sector. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Virtual money, on the one hand, is easier for those using them and makes it easier to make overseas payments, and more importantly, the fees are twice as small as those of the banks. The virtual currency (V) is something innovative and we will probably find it difficult to put this payment environment into regulation, but we will have to. You will have to, because these VUs can be used to launder money from terrorist organisations and/or to organise their activities.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as I think the development of virtual currencies, which have no real impact and pose a serious and real risk to the stability of the economy, is wrong overall.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies are innovative products, an option that needs to be used, but since it is a novelty, we must take careful care as far as regulating it is concerned. I could best compare the bitcoin case to Uber, both of which are new things, popular with our citizens, but both also carry a threat. The first problem is that it is causing revulsion among its traditional peers, and the other is that member states' bodies have not yet been able to pick up the pace, as far as their regulation is concerned. These factors also weaken these products, including the largest virtual cash player, Bitcoin, which is also mentioned in the report. I am sure that virtual exchange rates can give the internal market a new opportunity for development, and that they will certainly benefit either as a basic account or as an online purchaser. Of course, it is very important to give our consumers a proper guarantee of product safety. I believe that the issue and regulation of virtual exchange rates should be manageable. It is important to consider the possibilities for technical progress. On this issue, the reporter did a great job, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this pioneering report on virtual currencies because it correctly identifies the opportunities and risks offered by this technology. Virtual currencies are private and decentralized in nature, reducing costs by not requiring a clearing box. At the same time, they should be adequately regulated to prevent their use by criminal and terrorist networks, as well as to inform investors in a timely manner.  In the future, consideration should also be given to the role that the European Central Bank can play in the field of virtual currencies, as it is the institution, together with the central banks of countries that have not yet adopted the euro, that have a monopoly on the issuance of coins and legal tenders. It should be noted that the report has had very broad support both in committee and in plenary.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: these currencies have no real basis, are not subject to any regulation and are mainly used to finance criminal activities.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Virtual currencies represent a technology with undeniable potential, but lacking in the need, yet not guaranteeing that it can be considered with a currency with all its prerogatives. The report is balanced and seeks to avoid a false message of total peace of mind to potential users of this new instrument. Since the creation of the block-chain concept, many coins have been created and many have died. Many will still be born. Others were forced to compulsorily terminate for covering illegal activities.  We are still experiencing a period of uncertainty. Doubts remain about the limited or even finite nature of the money supply, at least in the current mining format. Doubts persist about his still very volatile character. The report essentially adequately reflects these doubts and limitations of virtual currencies. It points to shortcomings and recognises the need to keep up with this phenomenon, which already arouses the appetite of large economic groups. We voted in favour.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that distributed ledger technology (DLT) is bound to have a considerable impact on the financial sector and beyond. This technology, in principle, makes it possible to register any type of operation in a "distributed register" in a decentralized, rapid and secure manner. The main opportunities offered by virtual currencies and DLT in payments are related to lower transaction costs and user-friendly use, while ensuring resilience and various levels of confidentiality.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as overall it makes sense. Virtual currencies are the future.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies bring huge payment opportunities and benefits. This is about reducing transaction costs and ease of use as a matter of priority, while ensuring resilience and different levels of privacy. However, it should be recalled that transaction costs remain at a very high level, representing up to 7% of the value of cross-border transfers. However, more competitive transaction costs can be achieved within the single market. In the medium term, competitiveness could be further strengthened by the introduction of an unoperated and interoperable single wallet.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because I am sceptical about how it works.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ My colleagues and I voted in favour of this report which importantly highlights the potential of virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology (DLT) in various areas. These include lowering costs in cross-border transfers of funds, allowing for easier access to finance for people without bank accounts and the ability to develop secure online micropayment systems. The risks of virtual currencies are also addressed. Overall, I believe this report to be well balanced and it does not advocate measures which would regulate virtual currencies and DLT out of existence.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. – I welcome and support the inclusion in the report of a Commission task force on virtual currencies, which would propose any necessary legislation to regulate the sector and to update current legislation, e.g. the Money Laundering Directive/Payment Services Directive. Also, I support the suggestion to explore the promotion of an electronic wallet. The virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology have the potential to contribute positively to citizens’ welfare and economic development, including in the financial sector.  However, virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology schemes entail risks which need to be addressed appropriately so as to enhance their trustworthiness. Addressing these risks will require enhanced regulatory capacity, including technical expertise, and the development of a sound legal framework that keeps up with innovation, ensuring a timely and proportionate response if and when the use of some distributed ledger technology applications becomes systemically relevant. I also agree with precautionary monitoring instead of pre-emptive regulation in order to avoid stifling innovation. Lastly, I support the development by the Commission, in cooperation with the Member States and the virtual currencies industry, of guidelines with the aim of guaranteeing that correct, clear and complete information is provided for existing and future virtual currency users.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
