name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament's non-legislative resolution on virtual currencies, which calls on the European Commission to have a legal framework to monitor the database called Blockchain, the infrastructure on which many servers rely, which allows transactions in virtual currency, because I strongly share the fear of using the database to promote money laundering. Seven years have passed since the launch of Bitcoin, the best-known virtual currency, destined to have an increasingly considerable impact on the financial sector and beyond. This and other virtual coins base their existence on blockchain database technology, which allows them to record any type of transaction in a decentralized, rapid, resilient and somewhat secure way. However, the European Parliament maintains serious doubts about the overall scope of the transformation taking place in terms of the risks associated with it, first of all money laundering Hence the Commission's request for a timely initiative and specifically the extension of the scope of the anti-money laundering directive to virtual currency exchange platforms as well. In addition, the European Parliament calls for government agencies to take a holistic approach to virtual currency, ensuring real-time reporting and the fight against tax evasion (VAT).

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. A general definition of virtual currencies is a very important step, considering that they have been accepted as a means of payment for several years. There are now more than 600 of them. Payments often incur high transaction costs. The regulation of this means of payment will result in more competitive transaction costs, facilitate the usability of payments and promote innovation in this emerging and important industry. For these reasons, I support the resolution.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ It has become clear that, with the growth of virtual currencies such as the bitcoin, the distributed ledger technology behind it will impact on both the financial sector and beyond. As with any new technology, there are both opportunities and risks. But this is not about stifling innovation – this report proposes that we should be smart with regulation, not heavy-handed. Instead, the rapporteur (my S&D colleague) proposes a precautionary monitoring approach and includes updating the existing Money Laundering Directive. For these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. This initiative report provides an overview of the development of virtual currencies and the underlying technology for their operation, distributed register technology (DLT).  For example, Bitcoin, created in 2009, currently accounts for 90% of the virtual currency market and currently weighs only 5 billion euros.  With these virtual currencies, we are witnessing the emergence of a market independent of the power of states and central banks. This development runs counter to one of the main attributes of state sovereignty: the right to mint money. It is also possible that the major international banks will invest specifically in virtual currencies in order to implement an interbank market managed exclusively by themselves. In addition, virtual currencies also lack transparency. They allow for the anonymity of transactions, which facilitates, for example, money laundering and the financing of terrorism. So I voted against this report.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the recent phenomenon of virtual currencies, such as Bitcoin. These currencies have the potential to become a structural part of our financial systems. However, they contain important risks such as the ease of generating speculative bubbles, and their use for criminal activities. The report mentions these aspects and calls for greater regulation of virtual currencies.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as it calls on the Commission to establish a task force to monitor the further evolution of virtual currencies, to provide technical expertise ensuring a timely reaction from regulators if and when needed, and to develop stress tests to protect us against potential systemic threats.

text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. It is important to present not only possible risks, but also opportunities which open up while using virtual currencies. It is important to positively welcome this new technology, let it evolve and then, knowing better the real situation, to apply the regulation which would fit the best.

Finally, I congratulate myself on the very broad support with which the report has been counted, both in committee and in plenary.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The issue of virtual currencies is an issue that has recently concerned Cypriot society. Despite the bad experiences of Cyprus, virtual currencies continue to grow in the European Union. We voted in favour of the report on the ground that it does not take a position for or against these currencies, but it does not want the European Commission to investigate the impact and prospects of these currencies.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this well balanced own-initiative report that responsibly addresses the emergence and growth of virtual currencies (VC) and their underlying technologies, specifically distributed ledger technology (DLT) and its new and fast developing technology. In principle, this new technology brings a lot of opportunities such as low transaction and operational costs, reducing costs of access to finance, enhancing resilience and speed of payment systems, thereby facilitating the trade in goods and services, etc. However, this report equally highlights the risks of such decentralised technology, such as its use for criminal purposes, money laundering, tax evasion and terrorist financing. There are also risks linked to the fact that there is no clear governance structure which, together with the high volatility of VCs, creates a high degree of uncertainty.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it takes a measure approach to virtual currencies, which are becoming more and more popular. The report addresses issues that could arise from their use and helps to plan for a future where the phenomenon of non-central bank governed crypto currencies and transactions via block chain technologies become part of the norm.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The report on virtual currencies was also a success for Ulrike Trebesius. It has largely been able to push its line through the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and has found broad support for a pro-technology position. ALFA aims to develop and exploit the capabilities of virtual currencies and DLT technology in Europe. In this sense, it was important to see the opportunities first and not to burden the young technologies with too many regulations. It is, of course, possible that problems may also arise, but they should only be combated when they become visible and not in advance on the basis of suspicions and fears. In this sense, ALFA puts the bidding principle before the prohibition principle. The Joint Committee (ECON) has largely adopted the IMCO Committee's line, and so I was happy to vote in favour of the final report. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst there are some concerns with regard to the increasing use of virtual currencies, it is clear that this technology has potential benefits. It is important that the EU keeps up to date on these issues and I welcome this report.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The bitcoin was launched seven years ago; however it has not yet reached a critical mass and does not have the nature of a highly liquid asset. I believe that the underlying innovation, distributed ledger technology (DLT), will have a significant impact on the financial sector. The new technologies have the potential to contribute positively to consumer welfare and economic development, as well as bringing changes to the banking sector. However, some significant risks have already become apparent, like the abuse of certain applications for criminal conduct, including money laundering and terrorist financing. It is better to have precautionary monitoring instead of pre-emptive regulation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the virtual currency report (2016/2007(INI)), because I think it is extremely important that the EU Parliament deals with this development issue. There are several important facts on this topic: today there are more than 600 virtual currency systems; technology is rapidly delivering new solutions that cannot be monitored by the legislative framework; virtual currencies can contribute to the prosperity of the economy and citizens, reduce transaction costs, access to finance, ensure transparency and reduce the risks of infringements; there are also risks such as severe currency volatility, the possibility of inflating and speculation, limited regulatory ability to act, may become a source for financial instability, potential monetary policy constraints due to increasing the volume of use of virtual currencies, the potential for a 'black market'.  I support the proposal to create a proportionate regulatory approach at EU level that will support innovation and will not impede them with redundant costs, and I support the need to prepare a comprehensive overview of the state of virtual currencies and consider a review of the relevant EU payment system in line with technological development capabilities. In all this, it is important to take into account the information and protection of EU consumers.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This initiative report provides an overview of the development of virtual currencies and the underlying technology for their operation, distributed register technology (DLT). While this technology appears to be promising, it should not be a way for a few large digital groups to take control of the digital security and information sector. Nevertheless, this report presents virtual currencies as a way to contribute positively to economic development and the development of peoples, and that is why I opposed it by voting against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support the report on virtual currencies and was particularly pleased that the approved version of the report calls for the creation of a task force within the Commission to examine the effects of the proliferation of virtual currencies and the technology underpinning them, such as blockchain. As the report highlights, it is important that legislators do not rush to regulate this industry, as we must encourage innovation and the building of new technologies. Blockchain in particular has huge potential beyond virtual currencies, such as helping to reduce fraud and being used as the basis for smart contracts. Nevertheless, there are areas where we should pay close attention with regard to the use of virtual currencies. Therefore I support the extension of the Anti-Money Laundering Directive to include virtual currencies, but as I emphasised in my amendments to the draft report, any such extension must be based on an impact assessment by the Commission which clearly demonstrates the necessity of such measures. Overall, this is a report which strongly supports innovation and I fully agree with it.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which addresses the issues and opportunities associated with the emerging phenomenon of virtual currencies such as BitCoin. These virtual currencies pose significant challenges in terms of safeguards and consumer protection, to which I am particularly vigilant.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the report of my colleague, Jakob von Weizsäcker, as it reflects the need to be ahead of evolutions and make the most out of virtual currencies and block chain in general. There is a huge potential, and if Europe capitalises it we could have a competitive advantage in a cross—cutting technology that could put Europe in the driver’s seat of a new technological revolution. This report achieves its goal in defining the key elements that need our attention with regard to virtual currencies and block chain.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. A balanced, focused technical report on virtual currencies and decentralized transaction network technology. Virtual currencies have not yet reached a systemically important dimension and there is currently no need for regulation. The report proposes that experts monitor the development of this technology in order to monitor the development of systemic relevance and, if necessary, to encourage regulatory opportunities. There is nothing to counter this. I am therefore voting in favour of this report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Virtual currencies are often in the crossfire of conflicting opinions. The EU does not have its own position, although this rapidly spreading technology allows for decentralised, reliable, fast and secure transactions, together with a record of the history of previous transactions. All the report contains is for the Commission to set up a working group to study virtual currencies, which is a small but welcome step. It is possible that more competitive transaction costs can be achieved within the single market in the near future, but the use of virtual currencies may also entail potential risks. A more detailed overview of the new technology is certainly timely.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The issue of virtual currencies attracts and needs a great deal of attention. When we talk about virtual currencies, we refer to reproductions of digital values that are managed privately, defined as private digital money, and that are mainly based on distributed ledger technology (DLT). It is the technological foundation of many virtual currency systems, the best known of which turns out to be bitcoin. The report we are voting on today notes that these are decentralised databases, capable of processing large quantities of financial transactions immediately, and that they have the capacity to transform not only the scope of virtual currencies, but also financial technology. In approving this text, we would point out that, in the use of virtual currencies, consumer awareness, transparency and trust must be the benchmarks.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on virtual currencies. This text provides a statement of place on virtual currencies and the technology that allows them to operate, distributed register technology (DLT) or Blockchain.  While highlighting the significant potential of LTDs and the fact that they can revolutionize the financial services sector, the report presents virtual currencies as a way to contribute positively to economic development and people's development. We vehemently oppose this vision on virtual currencies because they mainly allow the creation of a monetary system independent of central banks and therefore of states.  In addition, transactions made using virtual currencies, which offer total anonymity, are often made on the black market, for money laundering, terrorist financing, fraud and tax evasion, and other criminal activities.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I supported the Jakob von Weizsäcke report, in which the European Parliament calls on the European Commission to set up a working group on virtual currency. All this is aimed at developing regulatory tools and promoting virtual wallets. Virtual currencies are a very growing segment in the global market, the value of global transactions has already exceeded EUR 1 billion, so I believe that we should not remain passive towards this market segment. It is very important to introduce surveillance to avoid potential systemic risks. At the same time, I support the European Commission's initiative to extend the Anti-Money Laundering Directive to virtual currency exchange platforms to prevent money laundering and terrorist financing.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The development of virtual currencies is progressing but also carries risks. They rely on new technologies to operate, called Distributed Register Technology (LTDs), which have many advantages. In particular, they promote simpler and cheaper processing of digital data. In addition, virtual currencies simplify online administration services and data protection.  However, these advantages were denied. Indeed, the text mentions the emergence of an international currency market. This developing entity tends to sideline central banks and states, and thus to evade their control. The transactions that fuel it are done anonymously, leaving free rein to the financing of criminal and terrorist activities. Therefore, I am opposed to this situation created by virtual currencies. So I voted against it.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. After the success of the first and most important virtual currency (bitcoin), Distributed Records Technology (TRD) is generating a huge impact on the financial sector. The main advantage offered by both virtual currencies and TRD is the reduction of transaction costs and increased privacy of payments made. The report also raises the possibility of incorporating the TRD into the private sector, for example in intellectual property transfers.  We should not set aside the existence of risks arising from virtual currencies or the TRD, such as the misuse of certain applications for criminal purposes such as money laundering. To end certain bad practices and achieve an increase in efficiency, it is intended to carry out intelligent regulation of the TRD, based on analytical excellence and proportionality, thus avoiding preventive and rigid regulation.  On the basis of the importance of the subject, I support this report favourably.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The report on virtual currencies was also a success for Ulrike Trebesius. It has largely been able to push its line through the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and has found broad support for a pro-technology position. ALFA aims to develop and exploit the capabilities of virtual currencies and DLT technology in Europe. name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The popularity and use of virtual currencies has been growing in recent years, but there is currently no definition with which to universally define what virtual or digital currencies are. The European Banking Authority (EBA) has expressed the view that it considers virtual currencies to be digitally expressed values that do not have to be linked to fluctuating real currencies.  The EBA also found that virtual currencies can only be traded if legal and natural persons accept it as a means of payment and exchange between them. Bitcoin as the most famous virtual currency after seven years in circulation has gained considerable influence over the financial sector using decentralized transaction record keeping (DLT) technology. The technology enabled decentralised, relatively safe, resilient and fast record keeping of various transactions. The advantages and opportunities that open up thanks to virtual currencies and DLT mainly relate to lowering transaction costs and ensuring easier use with the ability to ensure a different level of privacy.  The risks associated with virtual currencies and DLT are still unknown and such a thing will only be defined through the wider use of them. I supported the European Parliament's report on virtual currencies because virtual currencies and DLT can have a positive impact on economic development and contribute to prosperity.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies are changing financial systems around the world and contributing to their economic development. They facilitate and make cross-border financing operations cheaper, many firms trust them more than institutionalised currencies. Despite all the advantages, I consider it important to create conditions and a regular environment so as not to abuse these systems for money laundering, illegal and criminal activity and to prevent their misuse to possibly support terrorism.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained when voting on the report on virtual currencies because this report is not complete. In addition, it initiates procedures of a scoundrel society to which I am vertically opposed, as I have expressed publicly within and outside the European Parliament and the Greek Parliament.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. This report focuses on the development of virtual currencies and their underlying technology: distributed register technology. Distributed registry technology facilitates financial transactions. It can be applied to other areas and uses: crowdfunding, digital signing of legal documents, and online public administration services. We are therefore in favour of the use of this technology. On the other hand, we are vehemently opposed to the rise of virtual currencies.  For the time being, it remains in the hypothesis state: evidenced by the mediocre success of Bitcoin created in 2009: although it accounts for 90% of the virtual currency market, it weighs only five billion euros. The development of virtual currencies would primarily serve the interests of banks by enabling the creation of an interbank market of which they would have exclusive rights. In addition, complete anonymity would promote fraud and criminal and terrorist activities.  In general, we reject the complete dematerialization of payments. Indeed, the tangibility of the currency is a guarantee of independence of citizens from the banks' grip.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on virtual coins. I have worked on this report as shadow rapporteur. We have agreed to support regulatory action on the use of virtual coins which will follow the rapidly expanding development of this type of reality. The tendency will be to have a lower cost of transactions and a rapid effectiveness of the same. This is a new issue, which is still little known, but it is certainly a very growing one and of great benefit to the consumer, to whom great attention will still be paid to its protection.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Bitcoin brings a fairly large number of new approaches that raise discussions and questions about the future of the currency. Personally, I agree with the need to promote new and modern trends that we cannot avoid in the development of society. At the same time, however, I have a number of doubts concerning, for example, the misuse of the currency for crime – the currency is suitable for crime due to its demanding traceability and impossibility of control, and i think that the limited amount of money will lead to permanent deflation. Moreover, the value of the currency is only speculative, the currency itself is not covered by anything. Another problem, I think, is the need to generate addresses, for each payment – if it is to be identifiable – you need to create an additional address. I abstained in the vote.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. In recent years we are getting used to living with so-called virtual currencies, a breakthrough that can contribute positively to the well-being of citizens and economic development, including in the financial sector. However, virtual currency systems involve risks that need to be adequately addressed in order to increase consumer reliability and confidence. For this reason, I agree with the proposal that we approve today in this regard, calling for a regulatory approach provided at Union level so as not to stifle innovation or add superfluous costs at this early stage, but taking seriously the challenges that the generalisation of the use of virtual currencies can pose in terms of regulation.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 The financial sector has been heavily affected in recent years following the entry of the first electronic currency (Bitcoin). Such technology, namely Distributed Ledger (DLT) technology, provides the means to securely record transactions of all kinds. Nevertheless, I believe that there is much more to be studied in order to have a controlled development of DLT technology, which makes the matter topical for the European Parliament.  The aim of this report is to adopt smart European legislation on virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology, which has flexibility to promote growth and development in this area. In order to be innovative, however, there must also be the right foundations with the help of 'technical expertise', as the report itself typically states. Therefore, in order to acquire the regulatory capacities needed to create the legislation, the report proposes the establishment of a horizontal DLT task force.  I would like to vote in favour of the above proposals because I believe that virtual currencies and DLT technology can make a positive contribution to the economic prosperity of the Union by reducing both transaction costs and user access costs.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is where virtual currency and decentralized transaction network technology are reported. Virtual currency is not systemically important at the moment, so I am abstaining.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that virtual currencies create a great deal of opportunities for businesses and consumers, contribute to economic development, but it is necessary to strengthen supervision and regulation in this area in order to prevent a new type of abuse and illegal operations.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report that examines the potential challenges of a non-bank regulated currency and the impact that this could have on consumers and exchange rates.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The report in question provides an update on virtual currencies and the technologies that allow them to be priced. The report supports the spread of virtual currencies, arguing that they are the vectors of our economic developments. Among other things, they offer total anonymity that opens up tax evasion or money laundering without pressure. We oppose the system of central banks, beyond the control of states, that underlies the vision developed on these currencies. These have no real basis, are not subject to any regulations and first benefit the scammers. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology can contribute positively to the well-being of citizens and economic development, particularly in the financial sector. It is therefore necessary to strengthen regulatory capacity, including technical capacity, and develop a sound legal framework that keeps pace with innovation, ensuring a timely and proportionate response if and when the use of some applications of distributed ledger technology takes on systemic importance. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that underlines the benefits that virtual currencies, such as the bitcoin, have for SMEs. This report ensures the safety of virtual currencies without overburdening SMEs.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The development of new technologies is a source of innovation and profound transformation in our society. The development of virtual currencies is an example of which we do not yet fully know its long-term potential.  There are currently more than 600 virtual currency systems in the world. As we know, this technology could reduce transaction costs or the costs of accessing financing. However, risks can also be highlighted due in part to the unreliability associated with the lack of governance structures or the risk of financial instability linked to the risk of high volatility in virtual currencies and the creation of new speculative bubbles. In addition, virtual currencies could become a means of promoting the black market and money laundering.  We must therefore regulate in an adequate way to avoid breaking the innovative potential of this new technology. I am therefore pleased that this report calls on the Commission to set up a cross-sectional study group to better understand this phenomenon, to analyse the risks and benefits and to design stress tests to ensure its stability.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Bitcoin is one of the most important virtual currencies (VMs) and it is more than obvious that the relevant innovation, distributed ledger (DLT) technology, will have a significant impact on the financial sector and beyond. In principle, this technology is a fast, flexible and relatively secure way of recording any transaction, together with the history of previous transactions in the so-called distribution inventory. Investments in DLT are soaring and some uses can spread rapidly throughout the system. VMs and DLT in payments help reduce transaction costs and contribute to ease of use while ensuring resilience and different levels of privacy protection. However, transaction costs for payments remain surprisingly high. Much of DLT's potential is likely to be reflected outside the payment sector. As a model example of the use of DLT in the private sector is management after the completion of a business transaction. More broadly, however, they can be used for smart contracts, transfers of intellectual property rights, supply chain management and some government services. However, they also entail risks in the form of the misuse of certain criminal applications, including money laundering and terrorist financing. Therefore, the proper functioning and resilience of these systems is essential, which will require a well-functioning administration and supervisory structures. The proposal in question has my support.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on Virtual currencies, which calls on the Commission to set up a task force to monitor virtual currencies like the bitcoin. In my opinion, this task force will help prevent virtual currencies being used to launder money or finance terrorism and will better protect consumers.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs points out in its report that the transaction costs of payments remain surprisingly high, but virtual currencies and DOM technology provide an opportunity to reduce these transaction costs, provide easy use and reliable and variable levels of confidentiality. At the same time, there are already some risks associated with this, such as the use of certain applications to commit criminal offences, including money laundering or terrorist financing, and the wider spread may reveal additional risks. The report therefore calls for smart regulation to address risks, where appropriate, before they become systemic. The report therefore proposes the creation of a horizontal working group on DST, led by the Commission. I supported the adoption of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Virtual currency technology is growing rapidly. I recognise the hypothetical advantages of virtual currencies for the economy, which include faster and more efficient and less cost-effective payments and transfers, in particular at international level, and their potential to promote financial inclusion and promote access for the business sector and SMEs to finance and financial resources. However, virtual currencies may carry risks related to criminal activities such as terrorist financing, money laundering and tax fraud and evasion, among others. It is important to note that virtual currency holders are vulnerable to illegal activities and challenges such as scams, virtual currency theft, cybercrime, computer piracy, software/hardware malfunctions, fraud and fraudulent systems, false claims or misrepresenting, and it is vital to ensure an adequate level of protection and remedies for consumers who may face some risks associated with the use of virtual currencies. I am voting in favour of this report advocating the establishment of a working group to study the advantages, disadvantages and vulnerabilities of virtual currencies in order to ensure consumer protection, transparency and confidence in their use, as well as that of the financial system.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Virtual currencies are a system beyond the control of central banks and states, so I vote against this report, which presents them as a simple tool that can promote economic development.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which highlights the benefits, including the reduction of transaction costs, and the disadvantages of virtual currencies, including the lack of governance that can guarantee user protection. In particular, I support the european Commission's request to create a Task Force composed of regulatory experts but also technical experts to establish a regulatory framework for these new currencies.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on virtual currencies. The European Parliament is once again demonstrating its ability to keep up with the times by addressing a new issue, which still marginally affects our lives, but which could potentially change our daily lives in a profound way. Virtual currencies, as defined by the Bank of Italy, are digital representations of value, used as a means of exchange or held for investment purposes, which can be transferred, stored and negotiated electronically. At this time, virtual currencies are not legal tender but can be used by users to purchase goods or services, if the seller is willing to accept them. The most famous example is that of Bitcoin, which today represents the largest share of the virtual currency market. Although it is not yet equated with money, virtual currency is certainly an innovative, fast, inexpensive and effective payment system. It is therefore necessary for the institutions to continue to monitor the phenomenon, trying to introduce a lean and effective system of rules, which will hit and resolve the critical issues identified in this report.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the proposal on virtual currencies, as we must follow the development of technology in today's accelerated world. Virtual currencies and technologies in this new field have many potential. The report also mentions simplification and cost reduction of cross-border money transfers, which can reduce the overall global transaction cost by a significant amount. It is necessary to take advantage of this new opportunity, the new technology, to monitor the development of the system, but also to know that there may be risks that have not yet been mapped.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The definition of virtual currency (VC) appeared in 2012 drafted by the European Central Bank as ‘a type of unregulated, digital money, which is issued and usually controlled by its developers, and used and accepted among the members of a specific virtual community’. Distributed ledger technology (DLT) will enable a decentralised, resilient, rapid and secure means of recording transactions of any sort together with the history of previous transactions. I voted for this report that will introduce smart regulation of the DLT.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology have the potential to contribute positively to citizens' well-being and economic development, including in the financial sector. To date, a universally applicable definition has not yet been formulated, but virtual currencies are sometimes referred to as 'electronic money', and the European Banking Authority (EBA) considers them a digital representation of a value that is not issued by a central bank or public authority, are not necessarily linked to a fiduciary currency, but are accepted by natural or legal persons as a means of payment and can be transferred stored or traded electronically. I stress the importance of consumer awareness, transparency and confidence in the use of virtual currencies. The Commission should develop, in cooperation with the Member States and the virtual currency industry, guidelines to ensure that accurate, clear and complete information is provided to existing and future virtual currency users in order to enable them to make an informed choice, thereby increasing the transparency of virtual currency systems in terms of how they are organised and used and how they differ from regulated and supervised payment systems in from the point of view of consumer protection.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report. The report notes the rise of the use of virtual currencies such as the bitcoin which are stored and traded online through distributed ledger technology (DLT).  In principle, virtual currencies could provide a much more democratically regulated currency, regulated by the community. Moreover, the tech – blockchain – could also provide a more transparent transaction system which could counter illicit capital flows and money laundering if it is paired with the right form of regulation such as anti-money laundering regulations. However, the report further outlines the risks associated with the use of a totally unregulated currency which has been issued privately instead of through a central bank or public authority – i.e., legal uncertainty for consumers, anonymous use which contributes to tax fraud and money laundering, potential for speculative bubbles, etc. However, as stated above this can be countered by the right form of regulation such as anti-money laundering regulations. The most significant aspect of the report is the call for the Commission to carry out an analysis of virtual currencies and consider (if appropriate) revising existing relevant EU legislation on payments to include regulation of virtual currencies.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the resolution on virtual currencies because I see them as an opportunity in terms of reducing transaction costs and ease of use. In this context, attention should be drawn to the high transaction costs of payments. G8 data show that, on average, more than 7% of cross-border transfers of funds are swallowed up by transfer costs. The Commission should therefore carry out a comprehensive analysis on the topic of virtual currencies and, on the basis of this assessment, consider a possible revision of relevant EU legislation on payments, including the Payment Accounts Directive, the Payment Services Directive and the Electronic Money Directive, taking into account the new possibilities that are being opened up through new technologies, including virtual currencies. The aim should be to promote competition and reduce transaction costs.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The report covers virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology. Virtual currencies such as Bitcoin have not yet reached a systemically important dimension, so there is no need for regulation yet. The report proposes that experts monitor the development of this technology. Furthermore, the motion contains positive approaches, but it is too vague in elementary areas.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. In order to monitor developments in virtual currencies and their technologies and to analyse the benefits and risks involved, it is reasonable to convene a working group of experts to recommend measures to regulate and mitigate risks in this area if necessary.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report.  There is an urgent need to adapt to changing markets and consumer needs, as information technology is spreading very rapidly and becoming systems. It should be noted that in a crisis case, a virtual currency can be a solution to the problems of depreciation or settlement. In addition, virtual money schemes integrate much faster in countries facing economic or political turmoil. It is therefore essential to strengthen the control of the use of virtual currencies. In order to curb the opening-up of these currencies for money laundering and terrorist financing, it is appropriate to set up a special group to propose their regulation. I support the proposal that anti-money laundering rules include virtual currency exchange platforms.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Any attempt to regulate internet virtual currencies on a geographical basis is futile and misplaced. An EU which has created the euro as its single currency cannot hope to lend credibility and reliability to virtual currencies, in fact the EU’s record is so bad that any regulation by it would be bad for confidence. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Virtual currencies are a big step towards a digital single market, nevertheless we need to be cautious in underestimating the dangers they could bring due to their exclusivity. I support the draft report, which aims for additional legislation and the establishment of a dedicated task force with budget and staff to address the challenges of virtual currencies, in particular the lack of guarantees and safeguards for consumers, and the volatility of exchange rates. I am a strong supporter of innovation and believe that we should not hinder the development of an innovative digital single market; however I also understand the dangers associated with a virtual currency and want to be certain of its secure and legitimate use for all citizens of the EU.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Virtual currencies allow money transfers without bank intermediation. DLT, the virtual basis of technology currencies, can have a significant impact on the financial sector and beyond. In principle, this technology enables decentralised, fast, resilient and relatively secure record keeping of any types of transactions. Today's investments in DLT are growing strongly and some of its applications could quickly become systemic.  The application of DLT is likely to occur primarily in areas where reliability, proof of identity and ownership are important. Already known, a number of risks associated with virtual currencies and DLT will become clearer only when their application becomes more widespread. These are all data that are warned about in the cover report. I welcome the European Commission's recommendation on the need for a comprehensive review of the state of virtual currencies and the possibility of revising the relevant legislation and have supported this resolution.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The first and best known virtual currency, bitcoin, has been introduced for seven years now and it is clear that the technological innovation behind it, distributed ledger technology (DLT), is bound to have a considerable impact on the financial sector and beyond. This technology allows you to record any type of operation in a decentralized, fast, resilient and somewhat secure way. Investment in DLT technology is increasing dramatically, and some applications may soon become systemic.  The most obvious opportunities offered by these new technologies relate primarily to the payments sector, allowing a reduction in costs while ensuring security and confidentiality. On the other hand, the potential of DLT is also relevant in other areas such as smart contracts, intellectual property transfers, supply chain management and a range of public services. The most obvious risks (but probably others will emerge over time) include money laundering and the financing of criminal and terrorist activities. In this context of rapid development, it is right to call, as this report calls for, for intelligent regulation that favours the free development of new technologies, but at the same time addresses the risks before they become systemic.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament pointed out that virtual currencies and DLT have the capacity to contribute positively to the prosperity and economic development of citizens, among other things, the financial sector, by lowering transaction costs for payments and, in particular, cross-border transfers of funds, very possibly below 1% compared to current costs of 2%-4% in traditional online payment systems, and more than 7% on average for cross-border transfers of remittances , which could reduce the total global cost of remittances by up to EUR 20 billion. He noted that virtual currencies and DLT imply risks that need to be adequately addressed under existing conditions in order to improve the credibility of this technology. One of these risks is the legal uncertainty associated with the new applications of DLT. Finding a solution to these problems will require improving regulatory capacity and technical know-how and developing a robust legal framework that develops to keep up with innovation, ensuring a timely and proportionate response if and when any of the DLT applications become systemically relevant. I support the proposal for a Resolution of the European Parliament and underline the importance of consumer information, transparency and trust in the use of virtual currencies.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Virtual currencies represent a technology with undeniable potential, but lacking in the need, yet not guaranteeing that it can be considered as a currency with all its prerogatives. The report is balanced and seeks to avoid a false message of total peace of mind to potential users of this new instrument. Since the creation of the block-chain concept, many coins have been created and many have died. Many will still be born. Others were forced to compulsorily terminate for covering illegal activities.  We are still experiencing a period of uncertainty. Doubts remain about the limited or even finite nature of the money supply, at least in the current mining format. Doubts persist about his still very volatile character. The report essentially adequately reflects these doubts and limitations of virtual currencies. It points to shortcomings and recognises the need to keep up with this phenomenon, which already arouses the appetite of large economic groups.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Together with electronic tools aimed at faciliting the movement of people, goods and services, extremely rapid technological changes are also occurring in the area of capital management and transfer and money. Virtual currencies are taking up an increasingly wide area as a means of financial exchange, to which we need to respond with appropriate market security measures.  Accordingly, this report intends to encourage the elasticity of those capacities in charge of the operability of the electronic payment method in order to facilitate and accelerate the process. Taking into account the risk to the safety of citizens when carrying out such operations, the report underlines the need to agree on the existing legal framework set out in the implementation of technical expertise in the Member States so that these measures are not adopted without confirming their correctness and functionality in the first place. I supported MeP von Weizsäcker's report and emphasise in particular how valid measures can be found in existing regulations such as the EMIR regulation and CSDR, as well as existing directives so that the creation of further electronic benefits would be a convenience for citizens rather than a new reason to worry about the level of privacy and security they enjoy.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Digital cash became part of the fintech currently used several years ago by significantly reducing the cost of transferring funds and increasing their availability. However, as this type of currency is still linked to significant risks, I supported the report, which deals precisely with the solution of risks, such as their high volatility, the formation of speculative bubbles or the absence of management structures. I believe that technological documentation on the functioning of virtual currencies must become more transparent and that a proper legal framework should be drawn up, which is currently lacking. I therefore supported the recommendation that the European Commission carry out a comprehensive analysis of digital cash and the new possibilities offered in this context. At the same time, I would like to point out that the consumer and its protection play a very important role in this area. I therefore voted in favour of establishing cooperation between the Commission, the Member States and representatives from this innovative financial sector, which must guarantee the provision of the right information. It is a necessity for any consumer to be allowed to make optimal decisions in the European internal market based on clear and erre up-to-the-art information. I also supported the provision asking the European Commission to amend the legislation so that these new technologies cannot be misused for the purposes of money laundering or other activities of the black economy, including terrorist financing.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is the first drawn up by the European Parliament on virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology (DLT). The main opportunities offered by virtual currencies and DLT in payments are related to lower transaction costs and ease of use. In addition, much of DLT's potential is likely to develop far beyond the payments sector, for example in areas where reliability and the ability to demonstrate ownership identity, i.e. so-called 'smart contracts', play a central role. For all this, I voted in favour and I hope that we will soon be able to arrive at clear and effective regulation of this payment system.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The report discusses the opportunities and risks of virtual currencies and DLT decentralised ledger technology in the area of payments, addresses the use of DLT in areas other than payments and makes recommendations on the approach to be taken.  The report highlights the potential of virtual currencies and LT to reduce transaction and servicing costs for cross-border transfers of funds, reduce access to finance costs for those without a bank account, and develop secure online micropayment systems. As regards risks, the report highlights the lack of governance structures, the limited capacity of regulators, consumer protection aspects and the potential for use for money laundering and terrorist financing.  The most controversial points of the report concerned the regulatory approach to be adopted and the proposal to set up a Task Force chaired by the Commission.  In the compromise reached, the proposed extension of the anti-money laundering directive was limited to virtual currency exchange platforms following an impact assessment and therefore does not cover e-wallet services. The report recommends that an analysis of virtual currencies be carried out and that, where appropriate, the relevant payment legislation be amended. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which encourages the European Commission to develop a necessary expertise on virtual currency technologies and recommends the preparation of legislation in this regard. Nevertheless, it is not a question of stifling innovation and excessively regulating technology. Coaching and monitoring must be the watchwords in terms of accompanying technological changes.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The use of virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology today has a significant impact on the financial sector. These instruments contribute to the well-being of citizens and economic development, in particular by reducing transaction costs and protecting users' privacy. However, virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology present risks, such as legal uncertainty and high volatility associated with their use, propensity to form speculative bubbles and the potential stimulus to the parallel economy and criminal activities. The use of book technology—reason distributed outside the domain of payments and the financial sector also exposes these contingencies. In my view, the report on virtual currencies provides an adequate response to these risks, advocating for the strengthening of smart regulation and the development of a sound and proportionate legal framework, and promoting the creation of a working group, with a budget, a staff and competences aimed at increasing benefits and preventing the risks inherent in the use of distributed ledger technology.  For the above, I vote in favour of the adoption of the report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Any attempt to regulate internet virtual currencies on a geographical basis is futile and misplaced. An EU which has created the euro as its single currency cannot hope to lend credibility and reliability to virtual currencies, in fact the EU’s record is so bad that any regulation by it would be bad for confidence. Accordingly UKIP voted against.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted for this resolution on virtual currencies. Virtual currencies are considered to be digital cash accepted as a means of payment by individuals or corporations that can be transferred, stored or exchanged electronically. These are mainly based on distributed register technology, which has the potential to process large amounts of transactions quickly and the ability to revolutionize the virtual currency sector but also, more generally, that of financial technologies.  Virtual currencies and distributed register technology have many advantages but also risks that need to be carefully considered: the high volatility of virtual currencies, the absence of traditional forms of regulatory surveillance, guarantees and protection, or the possibility of transactions on the "black market", money laundering, terrorist financing, etc.  We therefore recommend a proportionate regulatory approach at EU level, without hindering innovation. It would also make sense to create a cross-cutting study group of technical and regulatory experts. Finally, we stress the importance of consumer awareness, transparency and confidence in the use of virtual currencies.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The main opportunities of virtual currencies concern reduced transaction costs and ease of use, while providing resilience and varying levels of privacy protection. Many of the potential of this technology are likely to extend beyond the payments sector. However, the virtual currencies and the underlying ledger technology carry risks that will only become clearer as their use becomes more widespread. Some of these risks have already become visible, for example, the abuse of certain applications for criminal activities, such as money laundering and terrorist financing. Their proper functioning and resilience of these systems must be ensured on the basis of sound governance and supervisory structures.  In addition, consumer protection issues are likely to be relevant in a number of applications. Hence the need to ensure regulatory capabilities, advocating the creation of a horizontal working group under the direction of the Commission.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. More than 600 virtual currency systems are currently operating. As this report points out, virtual currencies and distributed registration technology can contribute positively to the well-being of citizens and economic development, including in the financial sector, reducing operating costs and payment operating costs; reducing the cost of access to finance even without a traditional bank account or increasing the speed of payment systems and trade in goods and services. However, they also involve risks, such as the absence of flexible and reliable governance structures, their high volatility, or the legal uncertainty surrounding them.  The report recommends increasing regulatory capacity, as well as developing a sound legal framework that is up to innovation, ensuring a timely and proportionate response if they become systemically relevant. It therefore calls for the establishment of a horizontal working group led by the Commission and composed of regulatory and technical experts to analyse these new systems in depth and to support a timely, well-founded and proportionate response to the new opportunities and challenges involved. It also calls on the Commission to improve consumer information on them.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which states that the European framework for virtual currencies, such as Bitcoin, and the Blockchain technologies that underpin them is not necessary at this stage. On the other hand, I believe it is more necessary to follow these technologies by creating a task force at the level of the European Commission. Such a working group could indeed be called upon to monitor the evolution of these innovative technologies without restricting their ability to significantly reduce the cost of financial transactions, while ensuring that they are not diverted for criminal purposes. (Blockchain technology is a decentralized database stored on multiple servers that allows for the timely and safe checking and documenting of financial transactions despite the absence of a central clearing authority.)

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies are still a new financial instrument and a technological phenomenon and already, in addition to their potential impact on the global economy, deserve separate attention.  They reduce the payment costs associated with the conclusion of transactions and transactions by a quarter or even a seventh and may result in payments of up to EUR 20 billion. The economic impact of the euro on a global scale, it increases the resilience and speed of payment systems and trade in goods and services, increases security while opening up space for a new type of abuse and illegal operations.  I am therefore convinced that the area of virtual currencies deserves careful supervision, but one that promotes the development of this highly competitive area, rather than hampering this opportunity to increase Europe's global competitiveness. In this respect, the technologies of the diffused book of operations, although developed by non-state actors, remain an area that must be carefully monitored by the responsible authorities, discussed in political control bodies such as the European Parliament, and successfully integrated into everyday life and used to increase competitiveness.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This Initiative Report on virtual currency and "distributed ledger" technology - a technique for organizing digital records in blocks, together in a cryptographic and chronological way in a chain, through the use of complex mathematical algorithms, in which all transactions are recorded - on all nodes of the network.  This new technique will allow you to register any banking operation in a decentralized manner, maintaining the privacy /security of the data and avoiding its alteration or tampering. It also has the advantage of being able to be done by anyone, anywhere in the world, without minimum/maximum value limit, nor recourse to intermediaries. Nevertheless, there are some risks associated with virtual currencies and "distributed ledger" technology, such as phishing, as well as the possibility of money laundering or terrorist financing. Hence the importance of ensuring functional and efficient regulatory structures, as well as effective monitoring/supervision mechanisms. Overall, I believe that this is a first good report on this subject, the implementation of which could benefit consumers, businesses and the economy in general, contributing to the improvement of money transfers, thus contributing positively to the development of the digital single market, and I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on virtual currencies. These are digital representations of a value that are not issued by either a bank or a public authority. They are not necessarily linked to a fiduciary currency but are accepted as a form of payment. There are more than 600 virtual currency systems.  Given the new and innovative nature of virtual currencies and their lack of regulation, the aim of this report is to be able to give Parliament's position on virtual currencies.  In the end, the text calls for a thorough impact assessment before establishing legislation and also calls for the creation of a task force on virtual currencies and distributed register technology, led by the Commission and composed of regulatory experts and technical experts.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The growing phenomenon of virtual currencies poses new problems, in particular with regard to the economic and legal regime of their statutes and transactions related to these sui generis monetary instruments. This report is the result of a compromise for which I voted in favour in unity with the GROUP of the European People's Party: the need to set up an operational unit for a prior and in-depth assessment of the subject has been put before the call for immediate legislative action.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the recent phenomenon of virtual currencies, such as Bitcoin. These currencies have the potential to become a structural part of our financial systems. However, they contain important risks such as the ease of generating speculative bubbles, and their use for criminal activities. The report mentions these aspects and calls for greater regulation of virtual currencies.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ A Commission task force should be set up to monitor developments in virtual currencies and inform any necessary legislative proposals in this area. Virtual currencies have implications for money laundering and other important issues related to monetary regulation, and this calls for a dedicated task force to provide the necessary analysis and advice.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The report calls on the European Commission to set up a task force to monitor virtual currencies so that they cannot be used to launder money or finance terrorism. It is important that we follow developments so that we can take action with legislation if virtual currencies are misused.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report. We are right to call for a precise impact assessment in order to better understand the risks and opportunities of such a currency. I also see some legislative need for legislation on consumer protection before such a currency could be introduced.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Consumer confidence in financial service providers, as well as a high level of consumer protection when that trust is not met, are essential factors for a well-functioning and stable financial system. Virtual currencies are a rapidly evolving technology that, like other innovations in the digital environment, is currently not subject to and supervised by fixed and enforceable rules. This, of course, entails a number of risks that need to be addressed appropriately. I therefore welcome the fact that this resolution not only highlights the potential benefits of virtual currencies, but in particular clearly names the areas to be addressed so that virtual currencies are not an instrument of fraud, theft, cybercrime or deceptive behaviour towards consumers. I am glad that the resolution underlines the importance of consumer information, transparency and trust in the use of virtual currencies and calls on the Commission to develop specific guidelines to ensure that users of the virtual currency are provided with correct, clear and complete information.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I abstained in this report because even though it adequately characterizes the risks of virtual currencies, it does not require them to be regulated in a similar manner with the financial services they perform. As in the Digital Agenda, the digitization of services leaves the door ajar to their deregulation, in this case payment systems and financial deposits: something that we oppose head-on.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the last period the phenomenon of virtual currencies has developed that are becoming more and more popular, including Bitcoins. With this resolution, Parliament has called on the Commission to set up a task force to regulate the use and spread of virtual currencies, without holding back their innovation and development. The task of this task force would be to monitor their development and, if necessary, to act in a timely manner. I hope that this task force will be set up in a short time so that it can combat the illegal use of virtual currencies as a means of laundering dirty money or financing terrorist activities. I have therefore chosen to vote in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Attempting to regulate a virtual currency that operates on a global basis is futile.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which recognises that the key to smart regulation of virtual currencies is for the regulators to develop a sufficient capacity to address the highly technical challenges that such dynamic innovations bring with it. Pre-emptive and heavy-handed regulation would stifle growth and should be avoided. And, indeed, as this report outlines, this can be avoided.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 In today's modern age, based on rapid technological progress, it is clear that standard forms of banking and financial operations as we know them are changing significantly. One of the changes is the introduction of virtual currencies such as bitcoin. I therefore voted in favour of adopting this resolution, which appropriately assesses the positive attributes of these systems, such as reducing transaction costs or decentralised, fast, flexible and relatively secure way of recording transfers, but at the same time points to the not inconsiderable risks that these systems entail and calls for the establishment of a working group to actively monitor how these technologies are being developed, thus enabling them to respond well in advance to the preparation of the legislative framework. , the creation of which will be necessary for this area.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 There are currently around six hundred virtual currencies (VMs), 90% of which are covered by bitcoin, according to Reuters. The sector is about $7 billion, which is not much globally, as transactions on global exchanges amount to about $5 trillion a day. I recognise that VMs are of some benefit to consumers, businesses, charities and the economy, but it should also be borne in mind that VMs in many cases pose a threat to the consumer related to crime, e.g. terrorist financing, money laundering, tax fraud and tax evasion, as well as other potential illegal activities and problems. Although there is currently little evidence that VMs are being used as a means of payment for crime, I believe that, in the interests of the consumer, it is necessary to ensure the proper functioning and resilience of these systems from an EU level. From the point of view of the present report, I appreciate and support the fact that the EU has a natural interest in understanding the functioning and impact of VMs on the economy, thus ensuring consumer protection, especially with regard to cybersecurity, the algorithms used, contact persons and contact details.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Seven years after the introduction of bitcoin, the first virtual currency, it has become clear that the innovation on which bitcoin is based will have a profound impact on the financial sector and beyond. This technology, in principle, enables a decentralised, fast, resilient and rather secure recording of any transaction, together with the history of past transactions in the so-called distributed ledger of transactions. Although there are still some questions concerning the scale of these technological changes, this is the European Parliament's first report on virtual currencies and DLT technology due to significant opportunities and not incenentible risks at the right time. The report also takes into account the Greens' opinion on the energy consumption of Bitcoin, as well as our opinion on the definition of virtual currency. The report is well balanced and represents a sensible way forward with regard to virtual currencies, which is why I also supported it and voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The report on virtual currencies was also a success for Ulrike Trebesius. It has largely been able to push its line through the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and has found broad support for a pro-technology position. ALFA aims to develop and exploit the capabilities of virtual currencies and DLT technology in Europe. In this sense, it was important to see the opportunities first and not to burden the young technologies with too many regulations. It is, of course, possible that problems may also arise, but they should only be combated when they become visible and not in advance on the basis of suspicions and fears. In this sense, ALFA puts the bidding principle before the prohibition principle. The Joint Committee (ECON) has largely adopted the IMCO Committee's line, and so I was happy to vote in favour of the final report.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Since the universally applicable definition has not yet been introduced, Virtual currencies are sometimes referred to as digital cash, and the European Banking Authority (EBA) considers them to be digitally expressed values that are not issued by the central bank or public authority, nor is this value necessarily linked to the fiduciary currency, but accepted by natural or legal persons as a means of payment that can be electronically transmitted, stored and traded electronically.  Virtual currencies and DLT have the ability to contribute positively to the prosperity and economic development of citizens, including the financial sector. Virtual currencies would reduce transaction costs of payments, in particular cross-border transfers of funds, but would generally reduce the cost of access to finance, even if the beneficiary does not have a conventive bank account, the potentially contributing to financial inclusion and the achievement of the G20 and G8 '5X5 target'.  At the moment, it is important to have a proportionate regulatory approach at EU level that will not hamper innovation and add redundant costs at this early stage, taking seriously the regulatory challenges posed by the widespread use of virtual currencies and DLT. Therefore, I call for the establishment of a horizontal task force for DLT led by the Commission with staff composed of technical experts and regulators, and I support the report.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒there is still no universal definition of virtual currency, but it is sometimes referred to as digital cash. Natural or legal persons accept it as a means of payment that can be electronically transmitted, stored and can be traded electronically. There are currently over 600 virtual currencies, the most famous of which is bitcoin.  Virtual currencies have the capacity to contribute positively to the economic development of citizens, but also to the financial sector in such a way that they can reduce transaction costs for payments and cross-border transfers of funds. Also, virtual currencies have the potential to improve the resilience and speed of payment systems and trade in products and services. Virtual currencies can create systems that combine ease of use, low transactional and operating costs, and a high degree of privacy, but not complete anonymity, so that transactions in the event of an infringement can be tracked somewhat.  I support this resolution proposal, as I think virtual currencies will allow you to pair different types of traditional and innovative payment methods into one secure, easy-to-use app. In my view, this could improve certain aspects of e-commerce in Europe and further deepen the single market.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on virtual currencies. The virtual currency emerged 7 years ago, so we can assess in real time its impact and its contribution. By reducing transaction and operational costs for payment, reducing the cost of access to finance even without a traditional bank account, increasing the resilience and speed of payment systems and trade in goods and services, we can see that virtual currencies make a positive contribution to citizens' well-being and economic development. I therefore support the Commission's recommendation to carry out a comprehensive analysis of virtual currencies and, on the basis of this assessment, to consider amending the current EU payment legislation if necessary.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The issue of virtual currencies is an issue that has recently concerned Cypriot society. Despite the bad experiences of Cyprus, virtual currencies continue to grow in the European Union. We voted in favour of the report on the ground that it does not take a position for or against these currencies, but it does not want the European Commission to investigate the impact and prospects of these currencies.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of virtual currencies is wrong overall, because they have no real impact and pose a serious and real risk to the stability of the economy.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on virtual currencies, which provides a balanced picture of virtual currencies used as an alternative to currencies in circulation. I think it is right that the reporter draws attention to the potential risks inherent in virtual currencies and DST, such as terrorist financing, money laundering, tax evasion and circumvention, and the risks that virtual currency holders may face, such as the theft of virtual currencies, hacking or software/hardware malfunctions. At the same time, the report also highlights the benefits of this relatively new currency and its potential.  I agree with the extending of the anti-money laundering directive to virtual currency trading platforms and I support the proposal for the Commission to carry out a comprehensive analysis of virtual currencies and, on the basis of this analysis, to consider, if necessary, a review of EU payment legislation, thereby helping to strengthen competition and reduce transaction costs. I also support the creation of a coherent and comprehensive strategy for virtual currencies and technologies at EU level that protects against these threats, but does not hinder innovation or distort the market. Finally, I particularly welcome the fact that the report has highlighted the importance of raising consumer awareness.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Virtual currency, i.e. unregulated digital money, issued and usually controlled by its creators, used and accepted among users of a particular virtual community, has become increasingly popular in recent years. Seven years after the introduction of Bitcoin, the first and most popular virtual currency with a venture investment value of more than one billion euros, it is clear that this technology has great potential. Although it is not yet of systemic importance, its innovative nature and pace of development can be amazed. In its report, the European Parliament calls on the Commission to set up a task force on virtual currencies and to increase supervision of virtual currencies in order to prevent the potential negative effects of their use for money laundering or the financing of criminal and terrorist activities. The report also rightly emphasises that the scope of the Directive on the prevention of the use of the financial system for money laundering or terrorist financing should be extended to include virtual currency exchange platforms. For these reasons, I have chosen to vote in favour of the report on virtual currency.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour because it is important for the European Parliament to react to changes in modern society at an early stage.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 For the first time in the European Parliament, reports on virtual currencies based mainly on distributed ledger technology were discussed and voted on. The report addresses this issue from different perspectives, attempting to analyse the cost-opportunities of virtual currencies and calling for appropriate regulation. The positives are analyzed, generating a reduction in costs, and the possible new applications for consumers based on distributed ledger technology. The main risks are mainly related to the lack of clear regulation and the high volatility of these instruments. That is why we voted in favour of the call for a regulatory framework at EU level, taking into account existing legislation to avoid excessive costs. Like 5 Stars, we have called for the creation of a Commission-led expert task force to ensure expertise in virtual currencies. Another past request of ours was to use the resources already available within the Commission and to assist them with those of national experts.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Information technologies have made remarkable progress in recent years, essentially changing our daily lives. Such progress is also the emergence of virtual currencies which allow transactions to be carried out in information networks, without the need for the use of national or regional currencies. The advantages of this procedure are to facilitate financial transactions, in particular by reducing additional costs, but also to monitor financial flows, increase consumption and combat tax evasion. At present, however, these transactions are being charged at an exaggerated level, affecting the development and expansion of the virtual currency sector. At the same time, there are also risks that such operations will be used by organised crime or terrorist groups for money laundering activities.
