All these problems could be solved much more effectively, however, by more carefulregulation of the new field, using appropriate technologies (distributed ledger technology) proportionately and avoiding red tape. This report recommends the creation of a horizontal task force on distributed ledger technology to develop smart regulation to encourage innovation and guarantee integrity. It is a commendable initiative, so I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this well-balanced text. We recognize the potential benefits associated with virtual currencies and clean technologies for consumers, businesses, charities and the economy as a whole, which include increased speed and efficiency and reduced costs for payments and transfers, including cross-border payments and transfers, and potentially promoting financial inclusion and easier access to financing and financial resources for the business sector and SMEs.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on virtual currencies, as I believe that this is a much needed step to address the emergence and growth of virtual currencies (VC) and their underlying technologies. Virtual currencies offer both great opportunities by contributing positively to citizens’ welfare and economic development, including in the financial sector, but can also entail non-negligible risks such as their use for criminal purposes. I believe that this report has managed to present a responsible and balanced way of addressing virtual currencies, by avoiding over-regulation, allowing this new and still developing technology to reach its full potential, while at the same time taking precautionary measures to be able to regulate when necessary and deal with potential risks before they become systemic.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported a report recognising the potential of virtual currencies and decentralised transaction record keeping technologies to reduce transaction and operational costs for cross-border transfers. In my view, virtual currencies can reduce the cost of accessing finance to people without bank accounts and make it easier to buy goods online.  I would like to stress that it is very important to inform consumers, i.e. to provide accurate, clear and complete information to existing and future users of virtual currencies in order to ensure transparency of these systems and consumer protection.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. - I supported the motion for a European Parliament resolution on virtual currencies. Virtual currencies will gain more influence over the financial sector in the future by enabling fast and secure transactions. The main advantages of virtual currencies relate to reducing transaction costs and easy use. However, the risks associated with the use of virtual currencies are already visible today, as they are also used for money laundering and the financing of criminal and terrorist activities. However, it will only be possible to assess what the other risks are when the virtual currency is used more. For the control of virtual currencies, it is necessary to have sufficient capacities developed, which include, in particular, technical knowledge. It is necessary to avoid obedience regulations to regulate the area, as these could suppress growth. However, this area needs to be regulated by immediate and reliable control measures to address risks before they become systemic.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the recent phenomenon of virtual currencies, such as Bitcoin. These currencies have the potential to become a structural part of our financial systems. However, they contain important risks such as the ease of generating speculative bubbles, and their use for criminal activities. The report mentions these aspects and calls for greater regulation of virtual currencies.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The virtual currency report was a success. I was able to broadly enforce my line in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and found broad support for a pro-technology position. We want to ensure that the possibilities of virtual currencies and DLT technology are developed and exploited in Europe. In this sense, it was important to see the opportunities first and not to burden the young technologies with too many regulations. It is, of course, possible that problems may also arise, but they should only be combated when they become visible and not in advance on the basis of suspicions and fears. In this sense, I have taken the idea of putting the principle of prohibition before the principle of bidding. The Main Committee (ECON) has largely adopted the line of my committee, and so I was happy to vote in favour of the final report.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This initiative report provides an overview of the development of virtual currencies and the underlying technology for their operation, distributed register technology (DLT). For the time being, the virtual currency market remains very marginal and very recent. The main danger they represent, in addition to the dematerialization of the currency that is supposed to be tangible, is the emergence of an international currency market independent of the power of central banks and therefore of states. In addition, transactions made using virtual currencies, which offer total anonymity, are made almost entirely on the "black market" for money laundering, terrorist financing, tax evasion and evasion, and other criminal activities. While this report highlights the important potential of LTDs and the fact that they can revolutionize the financial services sector, this report presents virtual currencies only as a means of making a positive contribution to economic development and peoples' development.  I therefore vote against this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Seven years after the introduction of Bitcoin, the first and most widely used virtual currency, it became clear that the underlying innovation, DSD, has a significant impact on the financial sector and beyond. They are investing more and more in DTS, and some applications can quickly become system-wide. Although there are still some questions regarding the extent of the current technological transformation, the European Parliament's first report on virtual currencies and DST is timely due to the huge potential and the not insignificant risks. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report on the recent phenomenon of virtual currencies, such as Bitcoin. These currencies have the potential to become a structural part of our financial systems. However, they contain important risks such as the ease of generating speculative bubbles, and their use for criminal activities. The report mentions these aspects and calls for greater regulation of virtual currencies.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. While we may have doubts about the use of virtual currencies (VC) like Bitcoin for criminal and speculative purposes, the ‘Blockchain’/’distributed ledger’ technology underlying virtual currencies could be used to increase access to finance, e-government initiatives and tax transparency and in other useful ways. The report sets out a number of the risks and benefits of VCs and DLT (including the fact we raised, that Bitcoin is hugely energy intensive), which we agree need exploring. The report calls for the creation of a horizontal Task Force DLT (TF DLT) led by the Commission, consisting of technical and regulatory experts to explore technological benefits and associated regulatory issues. Overall the report is balanced and represents a sensible way forward on the issue of VC/DLT.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I stress that virtual currency and diffuse transaction book technology can make a significant contribution to citizens' well-being and economic development (including in the financial sector) as they: (a) reduce the costs of payments related to transaction and transaction (in particular cross-border transfers of funds) (b) reduces the cost of access to finance more widely, even without a normal bank account, and can therefore increase financial inclusion (c) increase the resilience of payment systems and trade in goods and services; depending on the architecture of the scheme concerned, as a fundamentally decentralised structure of diffuse ledger technology is used, which can function reliably (d) provides easy-to-use systems that ensure low transaction and transaction costs and a high level of privacy.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on virtual currencies. I believe that this new technology can offer significant opportunities for the consumer and economic development. However, we have to approach this issue carefully. IT innovations can spread very rapidly and become systemic and therefore it is essential that the Commission establishes a task force to actively monitor how the technology evolves and to make timely proposals for specific regulation if the need arises.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. The non-legislative report addresses the main opportunities and risks of virtual currencies and distributed registration technology (TRD) in a rapidly evolving payment environment, the use of TRD for non-payment purposes or smart regulation with a view to fostering innovation and ensuring integrity. We are talking in short about a matter of great importance in the current digital environment and on which Parliament expresses its position through this report. In view of the consensus reached among political forces in the text, I think it is appropriate to vote in favour of this report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because virtual currencies can make a positive contribution to citizens' well-being and economic development, including the financial sector. For example, it may reduce operating and transaction costs for payments. According to an optimistic estimate, the total cost of transfers could be reduced by up to EUR 20 billion.  We must ensure that this currency is not misused by criminal environments.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. The "Bitcoin" is an encrypted and virtual currency.  It is electronic money that has the distinction of developing independently of any authority including state, banking or even entrepreneurial.  The "Bitcoin" is the most widespread and most widely used virtual currency in the world since its launch in 2011. This type of currency has many advantages: no cost between transactions, no intermediary, quick payment... But it is not free of risks for users because of its lack of regulation, its volatility and its dependence on algorithms that can make it a significant speculative tool. The unprotected user can therefore be hacked and lose his money without compensation. This currency can even be used for money laundering and thus finance criminal networks or the black market. That is why it has been banned in some countries. The report submitted to the European Parliament is a balanced report which I thought presented the necessary risks and improvements, urging caution while taking into account the small impact of this type of currency on the current economy, particularly in Europe.  Taking these elements into account, I voted for it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Virtual currencies represent a promising technology, no doubt, but it still does not guarantee that it can be considered with a currency with all its prerogatives. In this sense, we believe that the report is balanced and seeks to avoid a false message of total peace of mind to the potential users of this new instrument. Since the creation of the block-chain concept, many coins have been created and many have died and many have yet to be born. Others were forced to compulsorily terminate for covering illegal activities.  We are still experiencing a period of uncertainty. Doubts persist about the limited or even finite nature of the money supply, at least in the current mining format. Doubts persist about his still very volatile character. We therefore follow the report which points out these shortcomings, but it recognises the need to keep up with this phenomenon which already arouses the appetite of large economic groups.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The report covers virtual currencies and distributed ledger technology. Virtual currencies have not yet reached a systemically important dimension, so there is currently no need for regulation. The report proposes that experts monitor the development of this technology so that regulations can be reconsidered in the event of increased relevance. The motion contains very good approaches, but it is too vague in elementary areas.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. – I am in favour of this report, as I believe that, in many aspects of our daily lives, digitisation is a reality: proof of this is the launch, more than seven years ago, of bitcoin, the first and most important virtual currency. Virtual currencies are destined to have a significant impact on the financial sector, as in many other markets, as they offer a decentralized, fast, resilient and fairly secure means of recording trades of any kind along with the history of previous operations. In 2015, the European institutions taken further steps towards advancing a more digitized payment market, reaching an agreement for the payment package, composed of the Payment Services Directive (PSDII) and the Multilateral Exchange Fees Regulation (MIF). We must continue our efforts to encourage electronic payments and continue to work to create a true digital single market for European consumers.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this report, for the first time, the European Parliament has been concerned with virtual currencies based mainly on distributed ledger technology (DLT), given the growing importance that this new form of payment is having in international markets. The report deals with this issue from different perspectives. First, it requires a clear and unambiguous definition of "virtual currencies" that is universally applicable. It then analyses the positive aspects that this new form of payment and possible new DLT-based applications generate for consumers, mainly through cost reduction. The report also examines the risks associated with virtual currencies often due to the lack of appropriate regulation and the volatility of these instruments. For this reason, a regulatory framework is required at EU level, taking into account existing legislation to avoid excessive burdens. Finally, it is proposed to set up a horizontal task force led by the Commission and composed of the main actors and experts at national level to ensure the necessary expertise in the field of virtual currencies. For all these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report on virtual currencies. Virtual currencies and DLT technology can make a positive contribution to citizens' well-being and economic development, including in the financial sector. This requires the creation of a robust legal framework that goes ahead with innovation and which can respond to all risks in the use of virtual currencies in a timely and appropriate manner.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the instrument that can intervene directly to plug serious employment crises. The Jäätteenmäki report proposes to allocate around EUR 5 million to relocate 2,132 transport and logistics workers to France. In the absence of viable alternatives, this fund is certainly an instrument that can best help redundant workers. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim of this text is to mobilise the sum of 5.1 million euros in order to reintegrate 2,132 workers made redundant by the French road transport company Mory-Global. Even if this text tries to conceal the unfair competition exerted by the secondment of foreign workers in France and by the road coasting which represents 10% of the transfers of goods made in France, I position myself as a defender of these workers. Indeed, since the latter are the first victims of the proliferation of free trade agreements, I strongly support the granting of this aid.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This application relates to 2132 workers who were made redundant in the transport sector - MoryGlobal SAS - in France. It is also a crisis-based application based on the decline in freight transport in Europe by 13% (and by 21% in France) since the crisis. There were some issues with this application as the company had sought state funds in recent years and then relocated anyway. However, the French trade unions while critical of the company’s action still supported the use of the fund for the workers. Therefore, I voted in favour of this application.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (request from France – EGF/2015/010 FR/MoryGlobal), because I believe that the forthcoming funding will make a significant contribution to the reintegration of many redundant people into the labour market.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the redundancies following the liquidation of the French road transport company Mory-Global, France has requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (5.1 million euros) with a view to reintegrating 2,132 laid-off workers into the labour market. The French government argues that since the 2008 crisis, the road transport sector has shrunk by 14% in the European Union and by 21% in France. It also argues that a price-cutting race has been waged in the European Union. This fund therefore acts as a disempowering mechanism both for business leaders who can more easily relocate, but also for national governments that do not dare to face the real problem of unfair competition imposed by free trade. However, this is still a substantial amount of assistance needed to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case, at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of France, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this budgetary vote as it would approve €5,146,800 of taxpayer's money to be given to 2,132 workers made redundant in France. UKIP is totally opposed to the EU spending British taxpayers money as dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Just as I approved in April 2015 the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to the former MoryGlobal SAS-France entity, Mory-Ducros, I voted for this contribution of EUR 5,146,800 to help the 2,093 people made redundant from MoryGlobal. The road transport sector is still struggling to recover from the 2008 crisis, with its activity still more than 10% lower than before the crisis.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Funds provide timely assistance to laid-off workers due to major structural changes in world trade. These aids are of paramount importance as they provide the opportunity to recycle to workers from a wide range of sectors. There is no doubt that the European institutions must also be urged to take the necessary measures and measures to stop business movements which, without conforming to legality, harm the present and future industrial of the Union.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument designed to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. The Jäätteenmäki report, which I supported in Parliament today, supports the Commission's proposal to mobilise the EGF in favour of France to support the 2 132 workers made redundant by MoryGlobal SAS following the bankruptcy and closure of the company. My vote in favour of the text presented is based on the conviction that the mobilisation of the EGF, with EUR 5 146 800, will be crucial in providing a coordinated package of instruments dedicated to training, job search and the creation of a personalised career path.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and help young people without education or employment. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for France to support the return to the labour market of workers laid off at MoryGlobal SAS operating in land and pipeline transport, storage and transport activities in departments of mainland France. The transfer request is a total amount of EUR 5,146,800 of the EGF reserve. Given the importance of this fund I have supported the same as I always do.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which concerns the assistance provided by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which will provide a meagre compensation to the 2,132 laid-off workers of the French road transport company Mory-Global. The very existence of this fund is further proof, if any, of the devastating effects of this so-called "happy globalisation": since 2008, the road transport sector has fallen by 14% throughout the European Union and by 21% in France. However, the report does not dare to mention the ravages of unfair competition: probably because Brussels itself is responsible for the Directive on the Detachment of Workers, which murdered our employees through social dumping. The Commission is keen to reform this directive by providing for the minimum wage for seconded workers: it will always be much lower than the average wage of French truck drivers and the differential in social security contributions can still account for up to 30% of the cost of labour.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported, with my vote, the mobilisation of the EGF worth EUR 5 146 800 in favour of 2,132 workers operating in the ground transport and logistics sector after the bankruptcy of the company French MoryGlobal. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a key instrument for supporting citizens at this time of crisis, but I am firm in my belief that the EU must focus on resolving the malfunctions underlying the internal market as a whole, rather than just providing economic support to try to support its victims.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of EUR 5.1 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the 2 132 workers of the Transport company Mory Global in France laid off as a result of the economic and financial crisis in the road transport sector in the EU.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it has given Parliament the choice to support the provision of support from the European Globalisation Fund to support France in order to help 2 132 workers made redundant from MoryGlobal SAS, which is active in the inland transport and transport by pipeline sector. According to the French authorities, the redundancies were caused by the bankruptcy and closure of the company. The Bank of France estimates that the annual number of bankruptcies in the road haulage sector increased by 35 % compared to 2007 and 2013. The global financial and economic crisis is estimated to have resulted in a 13.7% reduction in road freight transport by vehicles more than 3.5 t in the EU between 2007 and 2012 and 21 % in France (Eurostat). This decrease is due to a decline in the overall physical output indicators in Europe. As the volume of goods transported decreased, the sector has been hit by a price war and the situation has been aggravated by the trend towards various other costs (fuel, wages, materials) and, as a result, since 2007. In France, the operating margins of this sector decreased and losses increased.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. France has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/010 FR/MoryGlobal'. The request complies with the requirements of the relevant Regulation, according to the Commission's investigation, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I also supported the european Parliament's motion for a resolution on the use of european globalisation adjustment funds, an application submitted by the French Government to alleviate the difficulties of redundancies at MoryGlobal. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to provide support to redundant workers who have been left out of work as a result of the major structural changes in world trade flows resulting from globalisation. Workers will have mentoring measures, employment and business services, training, wage subsidies, travel allowances, accommodation and relocation costs. I am also pleased that funds will also be used to help start a business and promote entrepreneurship. However, I hope that in future similar cases will be as few as possible.  For those measures, we have approved the EGF of EUR 5 146 800 in the European Parliament and I believe that they will help alleviate the social problems of the workers affected.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 5.1 million euros in aid for the reintegration of 2,132 laid-off workers into the labour market. Although the fund acts as a mechanism to disempower business leaders who can more easily relocate and national governments that do not dare to face the problem of unfair competition imposed by free trade, this fund serves as the main aid to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers. I therefore voted for it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that it is up to the European Union to support workers in difficulty due to the effects of globalisation and that the redundant workers of Moryglobal must be supported at this difficult time.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is useful for providing support to redundant workers and self-employed workers whose activities have ceased as a result of major changes in the structure of world trade due to globalisation, either because of the continuing global financial and economic crisis or because of new economic and financial crises of a supra-regional nature.  The Fund must be used to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market, updating their training and giving them financial support at the same time. It is therefore appropriate to mobilise the EGF in order to make a financial contribution to moryglobal workers who have suffered serious problems as a result of these phenomena.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal aims to give France a financial contribution of 5.1 million euros, from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in order to reintegrate 2,132 employees who have been made redundant as a result of the liquidation of the road transport company, Mory Global, into the labour market.  While this fund has the merit of responding to the urgency of the situation, it does not, on the other hand, address the roots of the deindustrialization that Western countries have faced since the 1980s. It would be essential to combat the unfair international competition that our companies are experiencing and to regain our monetary sovereignty in order to correct existing differences in competitiveness within the euro area. As a good arsonist, the European Union delivers our economies to savage globalisation by removing almost all tariff and non-tariff barriers that protect us from the social and environmental dumping of emerging countries and then comes to the bedside of our sacked employees as a result of the closure of their businesses.  I did, however, vote in favour of this proposal, which provides an immediate response to the urgency of the situation.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the context of the collective dismissal of 2,132 workers from MoryGlobal, France submitted an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The events leading up to these redundancies occurred against the backdrop of the global financial and economic crisis. As a result of the reduction in the volumes of goods to be transported, a price war broke out in this sector, as a result Of MoryGlobal went bankrupt and had to lay off more than 2,000 employees. Dismissed workers will benefit from a range of counselling and retraining services, as well as job-seeking allowances. I have expressed myself in favour of the request from France because I believe that in such situations, where collective dismissal is required, measures are necessary to support employees in order to support vocational training and reintegration into the labour market.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 EUR 5 146 800 for 2 132 workers in the land transport and logistics sector after the bankruptcy of the company French MoryGlobal. Between 2007 and 2012 Eurostat recorded a 13 % reduction in transport volumes in Europe and 21 % in France. This phenomenon, combined with falling tariffs and rising costs, has led to a gradual deterioration in profit margins to net loss. I am voting in favour.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund requested by France for sacked employees of Mory Global. The contribution amounts to 5,146,800 euros for 2,132 workers in 54 sites in France. These workers will be able to benefit from training to help them in their career reorientation.  The Fund's mobilization in the case of Mory Global was justified. Indeed, the too often unfair global competition in the field of transport penalises European companies. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund demonstrates the Union's solidarity with some of the negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade. The application in question was submitted by France in relation to 2,132 redundancies at MoryGlobal, a transport company. I believe that the redundancies at MoryGlobal are due to the general decline in production in the EU, which has led to a reduction in the volumes to be transported and a price war in the road freight sector, leading since 2007 to a continuous deterioration in operating margins and a series of losses for the sector in france in particular. I regret, and I will reiterate this in every explanation of vote, that Italian companies are not able to benefit more from this fund because of the lack of support from local and national institutions. Between 2007 and 2015, Italy submitted only 15 applications to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, 3 of which in 2007, only one in 2008, zero between 2009 and 2010, 7 in 2011, 2 in 2012, zero in 2013, one in 2014 and one in 2015.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This report was an approval of an application by the French government for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) of €5.1 million to support 2,132 former drivers from road haulage firm MoryGlobalSAS. The EGF funds are used to provide re-training and personalised job search supports to workers made redundant as a result of globalisation and major changes in global trade patterns. In recent years changes to the rules of the EGF has meant that workers made redundant as a result of the financial crisis can also be covered by the EGF programmes. This application was based on the crisis-related criteria, relating to the decline in freight transport in Europe by 13% (and by 21% in France) since the crisis began. While there were some criticisms raised by French workers of the company’s behaviour in previously seeking and receiving public aid, and then shutting down anyway, I vote in favour of the report to approve the mobilisation of the fund. The aid directly benefits only the workers and not the company.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary vote as it would approve €5 146 800 of taxpayer’s money to be given to 2,132 workers made redundant in France. UKIP is totally opposed to the EU spending British taxpayers money as dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report because the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be mobilised in order to help over two thousand workers of Mory Global who were made redundant reintegrate into the labour market. Among others, they will be provided with career counselling, training workshops and job offers which should make their return to the labour market easier.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report concerns the request to mobilise around EUR 5 million from the EGF fund to help relocate 2,132 workers previously employed in the transport and logistics sectors in France. Although the EGF is not the instrument that best can help redundant workers, in the absence of viable alternatives I voted in favour of the mobilisation proposal.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, as we consider that the EGF/2015/010 FR/MoryGlobal application for a financial contribution from the EGF following redundancies at MoryGlobal SAS in France meets the requirements applicable to the definition of a financial contribution by the EGF. The redundancies are due to the constant major structural changes in the shape of world trade due to globalisation.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The vote on the proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was, once again, supported by socially sensitive strata, since it concerns the risks faced by thousands of workers in France. As the purpose of this fund is precisely to support workers in organisations and companies that are unable to cope with burdens arising from reclassifications in the world economy, I voted in favour in the interests of citizens.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The application relates to 2 132 workers made redundant in MoryGlobal SAS. This enterprise operated primarily in the economic sector classified under the NACE Revision 2 Division 49 (Land transport and transport via pipelines) and also in the NACE Revision 2 Division 52 (Warehousing and support activities for transportation). The redundancies made by MoryGlobal SAS are located throughout mainland France.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary vote as it would approve €5 146 800 of taxpayer’s money to be given to 2,132 workers made redundant in France. UKIP is totally opposed to the EU spending British taxpayers money as dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Support the Jäätteenmäki Report which allows the use of EUR 58 146,800 from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to reintegrate 2 132 workers made redundant by MoryGlobal SAS into the labour market. These redundancies are linked to the general decline in physical production in Europe, which has resulted in a decrease in transport volumes and a price war in the road transport sector, causing a steady reduction in operating margins and a series of losses for the sector in France since 2007, followed by a wave of bankruptcies. Through the use of this Fund, created to provide additional support to workers for major structural changes in world trade, it will be possible to support these workers through measures ranging from guidance/interpretation and facilitating job search to support for business creation or personalised professional requalification.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this budgetary vote as it would approve €5 146 800 of taxpayer’s money to be given to 2,132 workers made redundant in France. UKIP is totally opposed to the EU spending British taxpayers money as dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a useful tool to provide support to those workers affected by structural changes in the global market. I voted in favour of the procedure for activating the Fund after seeing the positive conclusion of the Committee on Budgets, which attests that the application submitted by France fulfils the conditions for a European financial contribution.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 5 146 800 following the dismissal of 2 132 workers from MoryGlobal in France. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these workers in this country, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 7 April 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the EGF for France to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from MoryGlobal. The application concerns 2132 redundant workers. According to the French authorities, the redundancies led to the bankruptcy and liquidation of the company. The Banque de France estimates that between 2007 and 2013, the number of bankruptcies in the road transport sector increased by 35% per year. This is due to the global financial and economic crisis, which led to a 13.7% fall in road haulage of vehicles over 3.5 tonnes between 2007 and 2012 in the EU and 21% in France. Personalised services for redundant workers include advice and guidance from a team of experts – training workshops on general knowledge, training on the use of the Internet, job fairs and meetings with staff from educational institutions. The French authorities have provided all the necessary safeguards for the following and have therefore agreed today by the European Parliament that France is entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 5,1 million under that Regulation.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EGF helps workers find new jobs and acquire new skills when they lose their jobs as a result of changes in the structure of world trade, e.g. in the event of the closure of a large company, the relocation of a factory outside the EU or the global financial and economic crisis. France requested a total financial contribution from the EGF of EUR 5,1 million to cover the costs of personalised services (training, CV writing, interview preparation, job search and establishment skills) and expenditure on preparatory actions, management, provision and dissemination of information and control and reporting. I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for implementing these strategies and an effective and cost-effective tool for restoring redundant workers to the labour market. In view of the above, I voted yes.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a general rule, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund can be used only where over 500 workers are made redundant by a single company, or if a large number of workers are laid off in a particular sector in one or more neighbouring regions. I voted in favour of this report as the eligibility for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment fund is met.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as in my view we need to reduce EU spending wherever possible and also provide stronger budget scrutiny to reduce waste and inefficiency of taxpayers’ money. I support less spending at the EU level, not more.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes the mobilization of 5,146,800 euros from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for the 2,132 licensees of the road transport and delivery services company MoryGlobal SAS in France, following the closure of the company.  The WEF helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalization or the global economic and financial crisis. This European instrument has a maximum annual budget of 150 million euros for the period 2014-2020 and aims in particular to provide career guidance services.  Considering that the European Union must promote the transition from losing sectors to a competitive economic model, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Commission's proposal to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) aims to enable France to receive financial contributions from the EGF in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of laid-off workers. Having complied with the conditions for granting the financial contributions of the EGF and the redundancies being due to the repercussions, in the road transport sector of goods, of the global financial and economic crisis, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. The global economic and financial crisis has hit many sectors of European industry hard. According to the Bank of France, since 2007, bankruptcies in the road freight sector have increased by 35% per year. In this context, 2,132 HGV drivers recently lost their jobs as a result of the closure of the MoryGlobal truck and delivery services company. It is therefore natural for the European Union to help these laid-off workers through the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Five million euros have been allocated to finance an employment training and skills upgrading programme or entrepreneurship support programmes. But beyond the one-off and specific assistance that the Fund can provide, it is urgent that the European Union put in place a real strategy to better anticipate economic changes, preserve SMEs, implement a forward-looking investment policy, and develop genuine trade defence instruments.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalisation. It has a maximum annual budget of 150 million euros for the period 2014-2020 and can finance up to 60% of the cost of projects designed to help people who have lost their jobs to find work or start their own businesses.  Thus, I voted in favour of mobilizing the EGF at the request of France following the layoffs at MoryGlobal. After the crisis in the road transport sector in 2015, the company went bankrupt and 2,132 employees were laid off. Nine sites were forced to close in the Central Region, with 383 redundancies. Thanks to this vote, the EGF will release 5,146,800 euros to provide support to sacked employees. This sum will finance, among other things, the collective and individual information sessions of employees, the professional transition (membership, skills assessment, professional project), support and reclassification to new jobs.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I was the shadow rapporteur on this dossier of support for the Mory-Global company (which had taken over 2,107 former workers from Mory-Ducros) following the various bankruptcies affecting the road freight transport sector. I took the opportunity to convey the main messages of my report on the EGF's balance sheet since 2007. It is a useful tool of solidarity with workers.  I believe that it should continue to operate outside the PSC during the next programming period while enriching itselfed with a number of improvements in budget execution, speed of procedures, its more forward-looking role for forward-looking sector financing, coordination with structural funds and allocation criteria to account for SMEs and collateral damage in the immediate environment of the target business (trade). , crafts, social life).  I also call for a more comprehensive reflection on the impact of globalisation sector by sector and I call on the European Commission to formulate proposals to introduce real social and fiscal harmonisation, particularly in the area of transport.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Following the redundancies at MoryGlobal SAS, the French authorities submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGA under reference number EGF/2015/010 FR/MoryGlobal. After assessing the request, the Commission concluded, on the basis of all the relevant provisions of the EGF Regulation, that the conditions for granting the financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled. The application concerns 2 132 workers made redundant from MoryGlobal SAS: EUR 5 146 800. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the redundancies following the liquidation of the French road transport company Mory-Global, France requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (5.1 million euros) to reintegrate 2,132 workers into the labour market. It should be noted that the French government makes no reference to unfair competition by the posting of foreign workers in France.  Unfortunately, this fund risks disempowering business leaders who are more likely to relocate, but also national governments that do not dare to question the dogma of ever-increasing free trade.  Nevertheless, this is substantial assistance needed to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers. For pragmatic reasons, however, I voted for this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EQF Group and I personally fully support measures and policies that create growth and jobs. We know that in today's times of crisis they are completely necessary. However, we do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right instrument for the implementation of such policies, nor do we believe that it is an effective tool that justifies investment in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market. We're talking about 6.4 million euros for 200 workers. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 This is a financial contribution of EUR 5,146,800 for MoryGlobal's dismissed persons in France. The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining programmes. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We have previously accepted that the Fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, particularly in the light of the Swedish National Audit Office's analysis, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: this is substantial assistance needed to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mory-Ducros was the second largest operator in the land transport and transport sector by pipelines or pipelines in France, mobilizing about 4 to 500 vehicles per day. Since 2008, road transport in vehicles weighing more than 3.5 tonnes has been reduced in the EU and France. Bankruptcies in the sector increased by 35%/year between 2007 and 2013, according to estimates by the Bank of France.  Mory-Ducros' bankruptcy was declared in November 2013. Settlement procedures have been initiated. Arcole Industries, the main shareholder, an investment company specialising in companies in difficulty, has submitted an offer for the acquisition of Mory-Ducros, presenting a 'Social Plan' for its workers. Mory-Global was created a new company, which took over part of the Mory-Ducros business, rehiring only half of the workers, despite many talks with the unions and the French Government. The unions continued their struggle and 200 workers were reinstated. Mory-Global's liquidation was declared in early 2015. However, the Court noted that the 'shareholder seemed to have lost interest in the restructuring project of Mory-Global and its sustainability'. The unions accuse Arcole Industries of intentional underinvestment.  Shame on you. Capitalism, in all its splendor.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I do not consider this measure to be a useful tool for the development of policies that promote growth and the creation of new jobs, nor able to give a comprehensive answer with regard to redundant workers.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this support to the dismissed workers, especially considering it concerns an SME close down, following the deep Greek crisis since 2008.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. This is the third application in this case, concerning the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 5 146 800 from the EGF in favour of France. It concerns 2 132 redundancies. MoryGlobal has paid for a slowdown in freight development and growth in France.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour of concrete aid to 2,132 French workers.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The application relates to 2 132 redundancies in MoryGlobal SAS in France, operating in the economic sector, classified under NACE Revision 2 Division 49 (Land transport and transport via pipelines) and also under NACE Revision 2 Division 52 (Warehousing and support activities for transportation) during the reference period from 27 April 2015 to 27 August 2015. The EGAF funding of EUR 5 146 800 is to contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for the reintegration of 2 132 redundant workers into employment. The redundancies are linked to the general decline in physical output in Europe, caused by major structural changes in world trade patterns. This has led to a reduction in volumes to be transported and a price war in the road haulage sector, followed by a wave of bankruptcies. I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in France.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the request for the use of the EGF by France. The Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in world trade or made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, and to support their reintegration into the labour market. In the interests of European workers, workers in difficulty as a result of the crisis must be able to take corrective steps to reposition them on the labour market. In agreement with the rapporteur, I believe that France's request is legitimate, since the situation of the workers concerned has led to the bankruptcy and liquidation of the undertaking. France has launched a social plan in which MoryGlobal will participate financially before receiving additional EGF support. The redundancies at MoryGlobal are linked to a general decline in production in Europe, which has led to a reduction in the quantities to be transported and a price war in the road transport sector.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the EP's motion for a resolution on the EP and Council decision mobilising a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund contribution of EUR 5 146 800 in connection with the redundancies of MoryGlobal, because the redundancy of 2 123 workers has seriously affected several locations in mainland France in the transport sector and the storage sector. Of these, 17 % are over 55 years of age and face a higher risk of long-term unemployment and social exclusion. The Moryglobal affair, linked to the bankruptcy of Mory-Ducros, is the result of what can be described as a price war in the freight sector, with a drastic reduction in physical production in Europe and the consequent compression of the volumes to be transported and the operating margins of companies. Once again, it is up to the workers to pay the price of the crisis.  The financing of the EGF of tailored services for job search and retraining, combined with an initial application of the "social contract", will therefore make it possible to implement individual and collective actions to protect redundant workers, with particular attention to workers over 55, who account for 19 % of redundancies.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been set up for workers suffering the consequences of far-reaching structural changes in world trade patterns. This also applies to the insolvency and closure of the large company Mory Global in 22 departments in France. The many workers must be helped financially to reintegrate into working life.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. France has requested 5.1 million euros in aid from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the conversion of 2,132 employees laid off by Mory-Global.  This company, which specializes in road transport, was hit hard by the 2008 crisis. In France, volumes transported decreased by 21% between 2007 and 2012. French carriers are also subject to unfair competition from the posting of foreign workers and road coasting.  As such, the application of the minimum wage to seconded workers will not solve the problem, since the average wage of French road hauliers is higher. In addition, there is a social security contribution differential that accounts for up to 30% of the cost of labour! Although the aid requested by France does not solve this problem of unfair competition, it will give the European Union the opportunity to repair a small part of the damage it has caused.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and help young people without education or employment. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns, due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the outflow of funds from the EU Globalisation Fund to be given to redundant workers in order to support their retraining. The company in question, which was discussed, fired more than 2000 workers and closed 54 factories in France, at the same time as the French State tried at all costs to prevent its closure.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this application to mobilise EUR 5 146 800 of the EGF for 2 132 workers in France made redundant following the closure due to bankruptcy of MoryGlobal SAS across 54 different sites throughout mainland France. MoryGlobal was active in the fields of courier services, freight transport and delivery, warehousing and rental of related materials, providing these services in France and abroad. As a result of the global financial and economic crisis, road haulage in vehicles weighing more than 3.5 tones declined by 13.7% in the EU and by 21% in France between 2007 and 2012. In 2014 the activity of the road freight transport remained more than 10% lower than the pre-crisis activity and due to the reduction in volumes to be transported a price war broke within the sector, leading to a steady deterioration of operating margins followed by a wave of bankruptcies in the road haulage sector. I was very pleased to see that the application will support co-funded personalised services to be provided to the redundant workers consisting of advice and guidance provided by a team of expert consultants, which comes on top of the social plan and the Contrat de Sécurisation Profesionelle funded by France in order to support the workers on the labour market.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this motion as it supports the reintegration in the labour market of workers who have been made redundant and works to decrease unemployment within the affected area and social grouping.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was formed to support people who lose their jobs as a result of major structural changes in the structure of world trade as a result of globalisation. The request from France for the mobilisation of the EGF to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant under MoryGlobal SAS comprising 2,132 workers was approved by the European Commission for EUR 5 146 800. , which are reflected in training workshops for general skills, training and training on internet use, job fairs and meetings with employers or representatives of the sector; all contributing to the increase of the real chances of reintegration into the labour market.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which provides financial support to laid-off French workers of MoryGlobal, as this allows them to remain in the labour market and actively contributes to addressing the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows.  In this context, it should be noted that there has been a decline in the production of tangible goods in Europe, and accordingly the volume of goods for transport has decreased and the price of road transport has increased. Therefore, I support the provision of financial assistance to the redundast workers of this French company in as quick and efficient a way as possible.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This fund acts as a disempowering mechanism both for business leaders who can more easily relocate, but also for national governments that do not dare to face the real problem of unfair competition imposed by free trade. However, this is still substantial assistance needed to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers. Hence my vote in favour of the text.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides assistance to workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in global trade related to globalisation. In this case, it was a mobilisation for the French company MoryGlobal dealing with courier services, freight transport and the supply of goods. The resources made available should provide redundant workers with consultation with career professionals, training seminars and training, and further support leading to a better position in the labour market. Since the French authorities have provided the necessary assurances regarding the absorption of funds, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to mobilise, at the request of France, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of 5,146,800 euros to help sacked employees of the MoryGlobal group in France.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague's report, as it is necessary in cases such as those of the road transport company MoryGlobal SAS in France. 2,132 truck drivers employed by the road transport company MoryGlobal SAS in France lost their jobs due to the bankruptcy of MoryGlobal as a result of the prolonged global economic and financial crisis. It is important to show that the EU stands by the citizen.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this report as the application submitted for the mobilisation of the EGF meets the conditions for a financial contribution to be made available. It is my personal concern to reintegrate workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation into the labour market in the best possible way and to give them the opportunity to adapt their qualifications to the new challenges.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns, due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. Over the years, it has provided effective support to many workers in difficulty as a result of the crisis.  Today we are dealing with a request to mobilise the EGF in favour of France, to support the professional reintegration of workers made redundant by Mory Global SaS, which deals with the economic sector of land transport and transport by pipelines, but also with storage and transport support activities.  Among the actions financed are personalised services to be offered to redundant workers, consisting of advice and guidance provided by a group of expert consultants, able to identify a personalised career path, and a sufficient number of job vacancies. This is an appropriation totaling EUR 5 146 800, which I support with my vote.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Mory-Global's licensees. Following the redundancies following the liquidation of this French road transport company, France has requested assistance (5.1 million euros) for the reinstatement of 2,132 workers made redundant in the labour market.  The French government argues that since 2008, the road transport sector has shrunk by 14% in the European Union and by 21% in France. But at no time is there any reference to unfair competition by the posting of foreign workers and by road coasting, which accounts for 10% of the transfers of goods made in France. And the application of the minimum wage to seconded workers does not solve anything since the average wage of French road hauliers is much higher. The social security contribution differential can account for up to 30% of the cost of labour. This fund therefore acts as a disempowering mechanism for business leaders, but also for national governments that do not face the real problem of unfair competition imposed by free trade.  However, this is still substantial assistance to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a European aid that can be mobilised to support employees laid off by their struggling companies. In this case, it is requested for the 2,132 debauched of the French road transport company Mory—Global, to the tune of 5.1 million euros.  The 2008 crisis is the main cause of the failure of the road sector and the liquidation of this company. However, foreign workers posted to France are another unfair competition, born of globalization and free trade.  Although the European Fund is a means of clearing national authorities of any responsibility, it is necessary to rehabilitate Mory—Global workers, who do not have to pay the price for the dishonest policies of their leaders. That is why I voted FOR this aid.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour because it is the mobilisation of EGF to help 2132 workers from the MoryGlobal transport company in France, laid off as a result of the economic and financial crisis in the road transport sector in the EU.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) provides assistance to workers suffering the consequences of structural changes in global trade patterns.  According to the Bank of France's estimates, bankruptcy in the road transport sector increased by 35% in 2013 compared to 2007. In this case, we find a request from the French State due to the dismissal of MoryGlobal SAS workers.  This report aims to ensure that laid-off workers are advised and guided by expert consultants to provide them with a personalized career plan as well as a number of job offers.  It should be noted that the French authorities have provided all the necessary guarantees regarding the principles of equal treatment and non-discrimination in access to the proposed actions. Similarly, all the requirements required at the national level in the field of collective redundancies have been met. I believe that this report should be adopted, provided that there is no disagreement in the transfer request, so that the EGF can provide the aid deemed necessary to those workers who have been the victims of the above-mentioned structural changes.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The EGF was set up to provide additional support to workers facing the consequences of major structural changes in world trade flows. Requests shall be made to this fund to support workers, and in the event of a positive assessment of the application, it shall be submitted to the budgetary body for the mobilisation of the Fund and at the same time an appropriate transfer request. In the event of a disagreement, a trilogue procedure shall be initiated. In such a procedure, on 7 April the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to mobilise the EGF in favour of France in order to support the reinsubposition into the labour market of a total of 2,132 redundant workers at MoryGlobal SAS. This procedure concerns the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 5 146 800 from the EGF for France, and the Commission has concluded in accordance with all the applicable provisions of the EGF Regulation that the application is eligible for a financial contribution.  The cause of the layoffs is bankruptcy and business closures, and according to the Estimate of the French Central Bank, the number of bankruptcies in the road transport sector of goods increased by 35%, which is considered a consequence of the economic crisis. Redundante workers will be provided with active measures to help in the labour market and no financial support from other Union funds or financial instruments will be received for the proposed measures, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund concerns a total amount of EUR 5 146 800 to be used for the reintegration of 2 132 French workers into the national labour market. They were employed in the field of land transport and pipeline transport in 22 French departments on the mainland. The need for the aid to be provided has arisen as a result of the bankruptcy and subsequent closure of the company. It can be noted that between 2007 and 2013 the frequency of bankruptcy in the road transport sector increased by a healthy 35 %, largely due to the financial crisis and its consequences. Given the number of people affected, as well as the importance of the sector for the EU and, in particular, for the French economy, it was logical to support the mobilisation of the requested funds from the EGF.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The mobilisation of EUR 5 146 800 concerns a French road transport company where, as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, the volume of road freight transport has fallen, leading to price wars and, consequently, bankruptcy and the closure of the company. The amount set aside will be used for the benefit of 2 132 redundancies for personalised services aimed at reintegration of these people into the labour market. The application fulfils the approved mobilisation conditions of the EFG, which is why I support it.

name: Louis-Joseph Manscour (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) comes when more than 500 people are out of work due to globalisation or the global economic and financial crisis. In this context, on 7 April 2016, the European Commission submitted a proposal for financial support, following a request by France to provide assistance to 2,132 laid-off workers of the Company Mory—Global. The latter having been driven to closure due to persistent difficulties (falling volumes to be transported, price war ...) since the financial crisis of 2008. This allocation of funds proposed by the Commission will allow training or reintegration plans to be deployed for these employees. In order to reaffirm Europe's support for employment, I am voting in favour of this FEM dossier.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. The aim is to provide financial assistance amounting to 5.1 million euros to the 2,132 employees of the French road transport company MoryGlobal. The latter was liquidated in 2015.  This report does not in any way call into question the harms of the free movement of workers and the Detachment Directive.  The Detachment of Workers Directive allows an employer to pay payroll taxes in the country of origin of an employee from another Member State. In France, this differential in social security contributions is in the order of 30%.  The road transport sector employs the bulk of seconded workers in France. In addition, road coasting, which consists of the possibility for a European carrier to deliver goods between two cities in a Member State in which it is not established, aggravates this social dumping.  These considerations aside, we support this report. Indeed, we hope that these former employees will be able to benefit from this welcome material support.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of France.  France submitted the FR/MoryGlobal EGF/2015/010 application for financial assistance from the EGF to support the reintegration into employment of some 2 132 workers made redundant at MoryGlobal SAS, an economic company operating in the economic sector "Land transport and pipeline transport", for a total amount of EUR 5 146 800 for France.  The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) provides support to redundant workers and the self-employed who are affected by the effects and consequences of the economic and financial crisis by supporting them in finding solutions to remain in the labour market and find new jobs through services such as collective and individual information sessions, professional transition and accompaniment to new jobs. The European Union must be an example and a guide in development aid.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, one of the instruments created by the EU to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of significant structural changes in world trade structure or the consequences of the global financial and economic crisis, and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. France has submitted an application for assistance from this fund for employees of MoryGlobal, which has been forced to lay off more than 2 500 workers as a result of globalisation, many of whom have already reached retirement or pre-retirement age. I agree with the need for financial assistance, which is why I voted in favour of mobilisation of the european globalisation adjustment fund.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Here, funds from the Globalisation Fund are to be distributed to French workers. The amount of approximately EUR 5 million will be made available for reintegration into the labour market. I can only support that.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support redundant workers and self-employed workers who have ceased their work as a result of major structural changes in world trade patterns due to globalisation and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.  November 19, 2015 France submitted an application to EGF/2015/010 FR/ MoryGlobal for financial support from the EGF as 2132 redundancies were made in France from MoryGlobal SAS. The EP welcomes the fact that the application submitted by France is not a payment of benefits, but rather a measure with real added value in ensuring the future return of redundant workers to the labour market.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of releasing funds to help workers adjust to changes in their work situation.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. It is proposed that the Globalization Adjustment Fund should help the 2,132 laid-off employees of the French company Mory-Global.  In principle I disapprove of the existence of this fund, because it makes companies irresponsible for their relocations. I am aware of this phenomenon that raises questions about the usefulness of this fund. It also prevents states from being concerned about the unfair competition that free trade allows.  However, it is right to help these workers to allow their reintegration. As a result I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices that are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights.  The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to France to give this aid to the EFG/2015/010 FR/MoryGlobal application for a financial contribution from the EGF, following redundancies across metropolitan France in the economic sector classified in DIVISION 49 of NACE Revision 2 (Land transport and transport by pipelines or pipelines) and Division 52 (Storage and ancillary transport activities), where 2 132 workers are expected to be made redundant and eligible for the EGF contribution to participate in the measures. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
