text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the tools at the Union’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted upon by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions for mobilising EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 2 132 French lorry drivers.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 5,146,800 for France to support the reintegration into the labour market of 2,132 workers laid off at MoryGlobal SAS. The economic and financial crisis has hit the road freight sector hard. Through this contribution, workers will be provided with personalized services to support them in their professional transition. It is all about helping them develop the skills they need to stay in the workforce.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. This fund may not exceed a maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million. The amounts concerned shall be entered in the general budget of the Union as a reserve. The European Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of France in order to promote the reintegration of workers into the labour market made redundant from MoryGlobal SAS "Land transport by pipeline" and the division "Storage and auxiliary transport activities" in the 22 departments of France. In accordance with all the applicable provisions of the EGF Regulation, the Commission concludes that the application qualifies for a financial contribution from the EGF. The French authorities have notified the Commission that the EGF measures are being pre-financed and co-financed by the Ministry of Labour, Employment, Training and Social Dialogue via the budget line for accompanying economic change and employment development. I agree with this proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving a green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in France. The EGAF funding of EUR 5 146 800 is to contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for the reintegration of 2 132 redundant workers into employment. The redundancies are linked to the general decline in physical output in Europe, caused by major structural changes in world trade patterns. This has led to a reduction in volumes to be transported and a price war in the road haulage sector, followed by a wave of bankruptcies.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. At France's request, the Commission has now proposed to use EUR 5 146 800 from the Fund, which would contribute to the settlement of the situation of the 2 132 workers made redundant after the judicial liquidation of MoryGlobal, a company which carries out activities complementary to land and pipeline transport, as well as warehousing and transport. The report notes that the conditions laid down in Article 4(1)(a) of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council are fulfilled and that France is therefore entitled to that financial contribution. It therefore proposes that Parliament contribute to the use of EUR 5 146 800 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund within the framework of the General Budget of the European Union for 2016, in the form of commitment and payment appropriations. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation No 1927/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 December 2006 established the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in the context of the global economy.  France's application to the EGF refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of € 6 052 200 of the EGF's financial contribution, following redundancies across metropolitan France in the economic sector classified in NACE Rev. 2 Division 49 (Land transport and transport by pipelines or pipelines) and Division 52 (Storage and ancillary transport activities), where 2132 workers are expected to be redundant and eligible for the EGF contribution to participate in the measures. I support the mobilisation of this financial budget in order to cover the bankruptcies in the road haulage sector. Among other cases, this is also the result of the global economic and financial crisis which caused the road transport of goods to decrease European economic activity by 13.7 % and in the particular case of France by 21 % between 2007 and 2012 (Eurostat).

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This is substantial assistance needed to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers; I'm voting for.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of employees of the French transport company Mory Global, who were made redundant due to a drop in French production that affected demand for road transport. 2,132 sacked employees will benefit from a contribution of 5.1 million euros from Europe to help them quickly find a job or training. This is in addition to the 6 million euros paid in 2015 for the reclassification of 2,513 former employees of Mory-Ducros. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund intervenes to support sacked employees due to major changes in the structure of world trade resulting from globalisation, due to the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis, or due to a new global financial and economic crisis.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to help. It supports workers who have lost their jobs as a result of the economic or financial crisis and helps them to re-enter the labour market. Unemployment poses a particular threat to the older age group, especially those aged between 55 and 64, who, if they lose their jobs, find it very difficult to re-enter the labour market, which could lead to long-term social exclusion, so I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund can be accessed by any Member State of the European Union and aims to implement policy measures on the labour market and support the search for jobs, training and starting a business. It covers 60% of the costs for implementation of the desired measures, the rest being covered by the state, region, local authority, private funds. It may have an implementation period of maximum 24 months from filing the application. I have voted for this report that will bring aid to 2 132 workers made redundant at MoryGlobal SAS in France.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 France has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), as a result of redundancies in the land transport and pipeline sector, as well as in the field of storage and ancillary activities for transport. The application follows the judicial liquidation of MoryGlobal and 2,132 workers are eligible for EGF contributions. MoryGlobal's redundancies are linked to the general trend of decline in physical production in Europe, which has led to a reduction in the volumes of goods to be transported and triggered a price war in the road freight transport sector. The consequence was the steady deterioration of operating margins and a number of losses for this sector in France since 2007, followed by a wave of bankruptcies, including that of Mory-Ducros and subsequently MoryGlobal. France indicated that the coordinated package of personalised services was developed in consultation with the representatives of the beneficiaries concerned and the social partners. EGF assistance is complementary to national measures and does not replace actions under the responsibility of Member States or undertakings.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This application relates to 2 132 workers who were made redundant in the transport sector – MoryGlobal SAS – in France. It is also a crisis-based application based on the decline in freight transport in Europe by 13% (and by 21% in France) since the crisis. There were some issues with this application as the company had sought state funds in recent years and then relocated anyway. However, the French trade unions, while critical of the company’s action, still supported the use of the fund for the workers. Therefore, I voted in favour of this application.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 7 April 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of France in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by MoryGlobal SAS in France. French authorities say the event that led to the redundancies was the bankruptcy and the closure of the company. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of significant structural changes in global trade patterns. I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. It concerns a possible mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for France. Approximately EUR 5 million will be made available for reintegration into the labour market. The application concerns 2 132 redundant workers from the 'land transport and transport in pipelines' sector. An industry that has suffered particularly badly in France as a result of the financial crisis. I see that the conditions for mobilisation within the meaning of the EGF are clearly met.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The bankruptcy of the French company MoryGlobal led to redundancies and the fund helps redundant workers to re-enter the labour market.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. I support the mobilisation of the Fund for a French company to reduce social consequences. The financial support provided will make it easier for redundant workers not to lose competitiveness in the labour market and to increase their employment opportunities. In particular, job search assistance, vocational training and retraining will be provided. It should be noted that support is directed towards measures adapted to individual needs and have real added value in ensuring the return of future redundancies to the labour market.  I believe that every country where redundancies have had a significant impact not only on the local labour market but also has severe social consequences should be encouraged to make greater use of all the opportunities offered by the fund to reduce unemployment.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary vote as it would approve EUR 5 146 800 of taxpayers’ money to be given to 2 132 workers made redundant in France. UKIP is totally opposed to the EU spending British taxpayers’ money as dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support workers made redundant by major structural changes in world trade flows and to assist in their reintegration into the labour market. Major structural changes in world trade flows have once again led to significant losses for some companies, this time MoryGlobal in France.  As many as 2,093 of the company's workers were made redundant. Aware of the difficult situation these workers are in, I support the French authorities' request to be awarded a financial contribution from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund of €5 146 800, which applies to 2,132 workers. This monetary assistance is necessary to alleviate the disadvantage of redundant workers and to allow their reintegration on the labour market.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒The purpose of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to support redundancy workers and the self-employed who have ceased their activity due to major structural changes in world trade flows due to globalisation, due to global financial and economic crises to help them re-enter the labour market.  The EGF must not exceed the maximum annual amount of EUR 150 million (in 2011 prices), as set out in Article 12 of the EEA. Council Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 2013/2013 1311/2013. I agree with the acceptance of an application concerning 2,132 workers dismissed by MoryGlobal SAS. This company mainly operateed in the economic sector - land transport and pipeline transport, and in storage and accompanying transport activities. The redundancies at MoryGlobal SAS took place across mainland France.  According to Eurostat, as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, road transport of goods by vehicles weighing more than 3.5 tonnes decreased by 13.7% in the EU and by 21% in France from 2007 to 2012. This decline was in line with the overall decline in material goods production in Europe and the road transport sector in Europe has not yet recovered from the large decline in activity it suffered in 2009 due to the economic crisis.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 After the 2008 crisis, road transport in heavy vehicles fell by 13.7 % in the EU and 21 % in France between 2007 and 2012. Bankruptcies in the sector increased by 35%/year between 2007 and 2013, according to estimates by the Bank of France.  Mory-Ducros was the second largest operator in the land transport and transport sector by oil or gas pipelines in France. It went bankrupt in November 2013, and settlement procedures began. It was acquired by Arcole Industries, presenting a 'Social Plan' for its workers. The company was created by Mory-Global, which took over part of the Mory-Ducros business, recontracted only half of its workers, and 200 workers were reinstated later.  Mory-Global's liquidation was declared in early 2015. The Trade Court noted that the 'shareholder seemed to have lost interest in the restructuring project of Mory-Global and its sustainability' and that Arcole Industries 'put itself in difficulty', having withdrawn EUR 7.5 million from Mory-Global to finance Mory-Ducros' so-called Social Plan. She received €17 million in state support and the unions accuse her of intentional underinvestment. An example of how capital serves its own interests by compromising the interests of workers and countries. We voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ A request to activate €5.1 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EFG) was requested by France to help laid-off mory global SAS workers who went bankrupt amid major structural changes in global trade flows in the transport sector. The EGF, as an important EU instrument to support companies affected by the negative effects of globalisation, will provide further support to the 2,132 redundance workers across France to find new jobs.  The measures planned to be taken to assist redundance workers, co-financed by the EGF, consist of advising and directing redundance workers and investing in start-ups and workers' takeover of companies. It is important to increase overall awareness and recognition of the EGF and to strengthen the communication of all parties involved in the application for mobilisation of the EGF, in particular social partners and stakeholders at regional and local level, with a view to attaining as many synergistic effects as possible. Consequently, I supported my colleague Anneli Jäätteenmäki's report on the proposal for an EP-Council decision to mobilise the EGF.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of collective redundancies at MoryGlobal in France. As Europe faces a decline in physical production, which is relocating to other continents due to globalisation, the need for truck transport is also logically decreasing. This is precisely what more than 2,000 workers have paid, who should rightly be granted aid of EUR 5 million. These, in combination with appropriate national measures, can help them to reintegrate into the labour market. I supported the assistance of workers in the form of advice on finding a new job, setting up new businesses or creating new training courses. It is important to note that this case of collective redundancies has largely affected workers in the problematic 55 to 64 age group. It is therefore necessary to start personalised assistance as soon as possible in order to prevent the social exclusion of these citizens. I am glad that the European Parliament has been able to agree to grant support in a relatively fast time. Finally, I would like to add that, in my opinion, all Europeans, regardless of their member country, should be looking forward to supporting mass redundancies, as the positive and negative effects of globalisation are felt throughout the European Union.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in relation to the EGF/2015/010 FR/Mory Global application, presented by France to provide a financial contribution to the "Land transport and pipeline transport" sector.  This application was submitted following 2 132 redundancies. According to reports by the French authorities, the events that caused the redundancies are the bankruptcy and closure of the company. Bankruptcies in the road freight sector increased annually by 35 % on the basis of a comparison between 2013 and 2007 data. This is believed to be due to the global financial and economic crisis. I hope that the mobilisation of the EGF, amounting to EUR 5 146 800, will prove to be a decisive instrument for supporting these workers, as well as valuable help for their families.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EGF helps workers find new jobs and acquire new skills when they lose their jobs as a result of changes in the structure of world trade, e.g. in the event of the closure of a large company, the relocation of a factory outside the EU or the global financial and economic crisis. France requested a total financial contribution from the EGF of EUR 5,1 million to cover the costs of personalised services (training, CV writing, interview preparation, job search and establishment skills) and expenditure on preparatory actions, management, provision and dissemination of information and control and reporting. The application concerns 2132 employees made redundant from MoryGlobal SAS.  I support measures to promote the growth of new jobs and to bring redundant workers back into the labour market. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), established in 2006, helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of structural changes in international trade, such as relocations or business closures. Here, more than 2,000 former employees of the French carrier Mory Global (formerly Mory Ducros) will benefit from European Union support for enhanced support in their job search.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As a mechanism set up to support workers affected by the effects of structural changes in world trade patterns, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is geared towards cases such as moryglobal SAS. Indeed, the transport sector was one of the most suffered in the context of the successive global economic and financial crises of the 21st century. In France, the sector has a very significant economic weight, as a result of the privileged geographical location of the Gauls in the European economic area. The dismissal of 2 132 employees of MoryGlobal SAS - a serious social consequence of the above-mentioned crisis - therefore justifies the mobilisation of the EGF. In order to support the 2132 European citizens in this precarious situation, and to benefit from such relevant measures as access to consultancy services and training aimed at re-entering the labour market, I am voting in favour of the adoption of the report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary vote as it would approve EUR 5 146 800 of taxpayers’ money to be given to 2 132 workers made redundant in France. UKIP is totally opposed to the EU spending British taxpayers’ money as dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. The land transport sector has suffered greatly from the crisis, and is particularly weakened in France, which has seen much of its physical production relocated in recent years. When the liquidation of the moryGlobal transport company was pronounced, more than 2,100 workers were unemployed in April 2015. It is to help all these former employees to return to work that France has asked the European Union for a contribution from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), which I voted on 26 May 2016.  Thanks to the agreement of the European Parliament, 5 million euros will be paid for career guidance and re-qualification, which will complement the professional security contract financed by the French state. Nearly 20% of the workers in the 55-64 age group are also considered particularly vulnerable to the risk of long-term unemployment and exclusion from the labour market. That's why they will be able to benefit from personalized services as part of the WEF. The Europe that protects is the one for which I am committed. It is essential that it continues to play this role.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilisation of EUR 5.1 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the 2,132 workers of the Transport Company MoryGlobal in France, dismissed as a result of the economic and financial crisis in the road transport sector in the EU.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Fund in favour of France.  As a reminder, France had filed the EGF/2015/010 FR/MoryGlobal application to obtain a financial contribution from the Fund following the redundancies in the economic sector under Division 49 (Land Transport and Pipeline Transport) and Division 52 (Storage and Auxiliary Transport Services) of NACE Revision 2 across metropolitan France. 2,132 workers had been dismissed as a result of MoryGlobal's judicial liquidation. These same layoffs were linked to the general trend of decreased physical production in Europe, which resulted in a reduction in transport volumes and a price war in the road freight sector, which in turn led to a steady deterioration in operating margins and a series of losses for the sector in France since 2007. France and its workers are entitled, under this regulation, to a financial contribution of EUR 5,146,800. I recall that the Fund's assistance to 2,513 former Mory-Ducros workers, which was approved in April 2015, amounts to EUR 6,052,200.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The economic downturn has also had a serious impact on the European road haulage sector. The application in question therefore comes from a sector whose workers, in this case, have already received European support. I therefore vote in favour and I call on my colleagues to support this proposal.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns a proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EFAG) in favour of France, following 2 132 redundancies across the country in the land transport and transport sector by oil and gas pipelines, as well as in the storage and auxiliary transport activities sector , arising from the liquidation of Mory Global. From the analysis carried out, it was possible to conclude that the application meets the assumptions of allocation of the fund provided for in the EEAG Regulation, and I therefore voted in favour of allocating a financial contribution of EUR 5 146 800 to France - which corresponds to 60 % of the estimated total cost of the proposed measures, with the aim of channeling this support to measures with effective added value , with a view to the future, but which is intended soon, the reintegration of workers made redundant into the labour market.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which approves EUR 5.1 million in EU aid for 2,132 workers in the road transport sectors in France. As a result of the bankruptcy and closure of the road transport and delivery services company, Mory Global, 2,132 employees lost their jobs. This European aid under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) will enable former employees to be supported in their search for a new job by co-financing an employment training programme. Appropriate training will enable former Mory Global employees to improve their employability. It is crucial that the European Union has instruments and financial resources such as the EGF to respond quickly and effectively to such large-scale economic situations.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. With the vote on this report, Parliament is in favour of mobilising a fund made available to Member States to deal with critical situations due to the impact of changes in world trade. This measure, which Italy has also benefited from, is now being used by France because of the need to cope with a company bankruptcy followed by more than 2 000 redundancies. The mobilisation of the Fund will benefit employment policies that will assist redundant workers and help them find solutions to stay in the labour market and find new jobs through personalised services such as collective and individual training sessions, professional transition and accompaniment to a new listing. Together with the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and the majority of this House, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and help young people without education or employment. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will assist workers who were made redundant as a result of the impact of the economic crisis on the road haulage sector. The use of funds to reintegrate workers into employment helps not only those who were made redundant, but also society at large in terms of social security savings. However, only a relatively small amount of the available funds has been mobilised so far this year, and I would urge the uptake of all the available resources to provide similar support for other victims of the financial crisis wherever possible.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of profound structural changes in world trade patterns. In France, 2,132 lorry drivers lost their jobs because of the protracted global financial and economic crisis. I believe that it is important to support workers affected by the negative consequences of globalisation, which is also the purpose of the Fund. That is why I support the proposal.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 5 146 800 following the dismissal of 2 132 workers from MoryGlobal in France. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these workers in this country, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is not for the EU to make redundancy payments.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave the green light for this mobilisation of the EGAF because it is a greatly needed tool in allowing our society to receive the biggest benefits from Globalisation while providing a safety net where unforeseen excesses and competition arise. This represents the fourth mobilisation of this fund, which have hitherto represented 8.4 million euros, leaving 157.2 million euros remaining. This fact reveals that this fund is not abused and completely not misspent and I encourage the UK Government to change its position on this fund.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support the measures that are implementing policies to create growth and jobs. Nevertheless, I voted against this resolution. In fact, I do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right instrument for implementing such policies, nor do I think that it is an effective instrument that offers the right value (by reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market) for money.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The French authorities have submitted an application for a contribution from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund due to the downturn affecting MoryGlobal. As, according to the available data, the application meets the criteria set, I agreed with this proposal. The purpose of the Fund is to address unforeseen market circumstances resulting from globalisation processes. The situation in which 2 132 redundancies of MoryGlobal are found is linked to the global financial and economic crisis. Since 2007, there has been a decrease in road transport of goods due to an overall decrease in physical production in Europe. Road transport is a major economic sector in France, which is estimated by the National Bank of France to have seen a 35 % year-on-year increase in the number of bankruptcies between 2007 and 2013. This was linked to the price war that broke out in the industry due to decreasing transport volumes, and there were also increasing costs of gasoline, wages or materials. I supported the release of around EUR 5 million from this fund for the benefit of France, as this is intended to help retrain staff and their early entry into working life. In particular, the funds will be used for individualised services such as advice and guidance from experts. Of the total number of redundancies, up to a fifth are over the age of 55 at risk of long-term unemployment. The risks associated with the loss of their employment should also be compensated in this way.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE
text: ), written. In line with the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission, the Union's financial assistance to redundant workers should be dynamic and accessible, but also faster and more efficient. I support this report because I believe that workers facing the consequences of major structural changes in world trade and the global financial and economic crisis should be provided with additional support, as well as assistance to re-enter the labour market, using legislative and budgetary instruments established by the European Union.  The adoption of the EGF Regulation reflects the agreement between Parliament and the Council on efficiency gains in processing EGF mobilisation applications in the Commission, Parliament and Council by shortening the time, further extending the rules of acceptable actions and beneficiaries by involving the self-employed and young people, on the reintroduction of criteria for mobilising the fund in the event of a crisis. Furthermore, the requirement that at least 500 workers in a company in a Member State be made redundant within the four-month reference period has been met and I therefore support the report.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of european globalisation adjustment funds (role of France — EGF/2015/010 FR/MoryGlobal). The French company MoryGlobal SAS faced bankruptcy and closure of the company as a result of major structural changes in world trade flows, specifically in the on-land and pipeline transport sectors, and therefore had to lay off 2,132 redundancies. As the application is complete and qualifies, I supported the allocation of EUR 5 146 800 from the EGF for France.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The company discussed, fired more than 2000 workers and closed 54 factories in France, at the same time as the French State tried at all costs to prevent its closure. Although this tactic was a scandal, we could not vote against the outflow of funds from the EU Globalisation Fund to be given to laid-off workers. Since these funds will be given for retraining and support for redundant workers, we voted in favour.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 This is a financial contribution of EUR 5,146,800 for MoryGlobal's dismissed persons in France. The money from the Adjustment Fund should basically be given to the dismissed and not to reintegration or retraining programmes. We don't need skilled unemployed people.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because the matter has been dealt with and examined in detail at committee stage. I would like to emphasise that the cities of Salo and Oulu in Finland have also benefited in recent years from the mobilisation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund as a result of the global restructuring of the travel phone sector.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Union’s financial assistance to workers made redundant should be dynamic and made available as quickly and efficiently as possible. France submitted the application EGF/2015/010 FR/MoryGlobal for a financial contribution from the EGF, which will support 2 513 former Mory-Ducros workers and amounts to EUR 6 052 200. Redundancies in MoryGlobal are linked to the general decline in physical output in Europe, caused by major structural changes in world trade patterns. This has led to a reduction in volumes to be transported and a price war in the road haulage sector, followed by a wave of bankruptcies. It is important to take into account the sensitivity of the specific labour market since France has the highest share of EU-28 value added within the land transport services sector. Moreover, considering that workers in the 55-64 age group are at a higher risk of long-term unemployment and exclusion from the labour market with the possible effect of social exclusion, the specific needs when it comes to providing them with a personalised approach need to be kept in mind. I therefore support assisting the redundant workers and helping them find solutions to remain in the labour market and find new jobs.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have spoken out in favour of this mobilization of the European fund. The EU has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade or the global economic and financial crisis, and to support them in their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers in France who lost their jobs at a company working in road haulage, MoryGlobal SAS, due to the company’s bankruptcy. Bankruptcies in the road haulage sector have increased by 35% annually when comparing 2013 with 2007, as a result of the global financial and economic crisis and the general decline of physical output in Europe. The fund will thus provide these workers with additional assistance such as advice and guidance, training for new skills, and will facilitate meetings with possible new employers.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is a lever to help workers who are victims of the effects of the globalised economy. The economic and financial crisis of 2008 had a profound impact on the European economy. Road freight transport fell by 13.7% in the European Union and by 21% in France between 2007 and 2012 (Eurostat).  This economic downturn led to the bankruptcy and closure of MoryGlobal SAS and the dismissal of its 2,132 employees. France has therefore applied to the Commission for EU assistance. We voted in favour of allocating EUR 5,146,800 to laid-off workers. This money should be used to provide supports such as group and individual information sessions, assistance with the professional transition and support for new jobs. That's the least moryglobal workers can do. In the absence of a desire to protect the European economy and jobs from the disastrous aspects of global competition and to be able to combat relocation, aid for vocational reintegration remains the last bulwark for workers.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I voted against a request submitted by France to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which should help laid-off MoryGlobal workers return to the labour market. While I agree that this company's string of losses was caused by a decline in the production of tangible goods in Europe that led to a decrease in the volume of goods for transport and price rises in the road transport sector, I consider that such measures are not sufficient for the recovery of this sector.  In fact, short-term measures such as advising and retraining the redundant will not help the European economy recover and will not prevent more redundancies in the sector. The recovery of this sector and at the same time the reduction of unemployment can be achieved by reducing the tax burdens and administrative barriers faced by companies.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (role of France — EGF/2015/010 FR/MoryGlobal) as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 7 April, a proposal for a decision was adopted to mobilise the EGF in favour of France in order to support the reintegration of 2132 workers made redundant by MoryGlobal SAS in 22 departments in mainland France. The global financial and economic crisis has been blamed on the increased number of bankruptcies of the road haulage sector.  Tailored services, advice and guidance for redundant workers will be provided by a team of expert advisers from three executive agencies. The Agencies are obliged to provide each participant with a tailored career, a sufficient number of job offers and to consult general experts and/or experts specialised in setting up companies with excellent knowledge of the labour market in the region and available and responsive.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and help young people without education or employment. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the redundancies following the liquidation of the French road transport company Mory-Global, France has requested assistance from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund (5.1 million euros) with a view to reintegrating 2,132 laid-off workers into the labour market. The French government argues that since the 2008 crisis, the road transport sector has shrunk by 14% in the European Union and by 21% in France. At no time is there any reference to unfair competition by the posting of foreign workers in France, and by road coasting, which accounts for 10% of the transfers of goods made in France. The application of the minimum wage to seconded workers does not solve anything since the average wage of French road hauliers is much higher. In addition, the social security contribution differential can account for up to 30% of the cost of labour. This fund therefore acts as a disempowering mechanism both for the leaders of companies who can more easily relocate, but also for national governments that do not dare to face the real problem of unfair competition. However, this is necessary assistance to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers. I'm voting for this report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. In this case, we are talking about more than 2,000 jobs, and I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and help young people without education or employment. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the use of this fund, which helps persons affected by company closures resulting from relocations, in the case of the French company MoryGlobal.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that the measures for which egf support is requested do not include the measures referred to in Article 7(1)(b) of the EGF Regulation, i.e. benefits, and that support is directed towards measures with real added value in ensuring the future return of redundant workers to the labour market.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application EGF/2015/010 FR/MoryGlobal). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to provide, under specific conditions, support for workers who have lost their jobs as a result of mass redundancies caused by major changes in global trade. The measures, co-financed by the EGF and French government, would help the workers to find new jobs by providing them with occupational guidance and other assistance schemes such as collective and individual information sessions, job transition and accompaniment towards new jobs.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a fund that is dedicated to processing transfers of funds to pay compensation for maximum redundancies for the cessation of different business activities of the Member States. In this case we are talking about a transfer that has been dampening the situation of serious economic deterioration that Mory-Ducros has been suffering and subsequently MoryGlobal since 2007. It is therefore appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because France is entitled to a European financial contribution amounting to EUR 5 146 800, representing 60 % of the total cost of EUR 8 528 000, in order to cope with the bankruptcy of Moryglobal and the dismissal of 2150 employees.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 7 April 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a Decision on mobilising the EGF in favour of France to support the professional reintegration of workers made redundant from MoryGlobal SAS, in the sector classified in NACE Rev. 2 Division 49 (Land transport and transport by pipelines or pipelines) and in Division 52 (Storage and transport ancillary activities) , in 22 departments (départements) of metropolitan France. This is the fourth application to be assessed under the 2016 budget and the third on the land transport and transport sector by oil or gas pipelines, and concerns the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 5 146 800 for France. The application covers the dismissal of 2 132 workers. We continue to have doubts about this instrument. We are sensitive to the drama of workers, but we believe that the fundamental issues of the economy should be attacked and not just pouring funds into these companies.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. – The application deals with a possible mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for France. An amount of approximately EUR 5 million will be made available for reintegration into the labour market. The application concerns 2 132 redundant workers from the 'land transport and transport in pipelines' sector, an industry which has suffered particularly badly in France as a result of the financial crisis. The circumstances described clearly justify a claim within the meaning of the EGF.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I rejected the European Parliament's report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (Request from France – EGF/2015/010 FR/MoryGlobal). I fundamentally reject this fund as a waste of taxpayers' money. It will save uncompetitive companies. It also means overstepping the EU's powers by violating the principle of subsidiarity. I do not want more EU, but less – that is, not more funds and more money for the EU, but less.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for France in the case of MoryGlobal. Under the EGF Implementing Regulation, France is entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 5146800, which represents 60 % of the total cost of 8528000, money needed for the future reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from MoryGlobal. The redundancies at MoryGlobal, a company specialising in land and pipeline transport, were linked to the general decline in physical production in Europe, which led to a reduction in the volume to be transported and a price war in the road freight transport sector, resulting in a steady deterioration in operational margins and a series of losses for the French sector. , since 2007, followed by a wave of bankruptcies, including that of Mory-Ducros and later MoryGlobal.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today voted on the request to mobilise the EGF for a situation concerning France. The Jäätteenmäki report provides for the mobilisation of around EUR 5 million to help relocate 2 132 workers previously employed in the transport and logistics sectors in France. I am generally in favour of mobilising this fund, although I am aware that this is probably not the instrument that best can help redundant workers, but in the absence of viable alternatives I nevertheless believe that it should be supported.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which estimates that France is eligible for a financial contribution of EUR 5 146 800 under the EGF Regulation. Union financial assistance is intended for workers made redundant with a lower level of education in order to facilitate their reintegration into the labour market and employment.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today we voted on financial contributions from the so-called Globalisation Fund to people who have become unemployed after the closure of European companies. I consistently vote against these unemployment benefits for two reasons: firstly, labour market policies and financial support for the unemployed should be decided on, and financed, at national level – not at European level. Secondly, the basic idea of the Fund is based on the fact that globalisation is something negative – which is not true. Globalisation and free trade lead to growth and peace.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provides support for those who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world trade due to globalisation. The Ní Riada report proposes to allocate almost EUR 6.5 million to relocate some 500 food distribution workers to Greece. In the absence of viable alternatives, this fund is certainly an instrument that can best help redundant workers. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. The aim of this text is to mobilise the sum of 6.5 million euros in order to reintegrate 557 workers made redundant by the Greek company Supermarket Larissa in order to help 543 "NEETs" (young people without a diploma, training or employment).  Greece argues that its economy has experienced a severe recession since 2008 and that consumption has fallen by 21 points. Moreover, the austerity imposed on the Greek people has drastically reduced domestic demand, thus affecting the sales sector. While this aid is a bad thing, it should not encourage the deflationary external adjustment policies required by the very existence of the euro.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an application from Greece under the crisis criteria (as opposed to globalisation) for 557 workers and 543 NEETs from the same region. The redundant workers are from a cooperative of grocery stores, Supermarket Larissa, which closed last year. The application cites a 30% drop in food/beverage consumption and purchasing power as a result of the crisis. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this application.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (request from Greece – EGF/2015/011 GR/Supermarket Larissa), because I believe that forthcoming funding is an important tool for the reintegration of many redundant people into the labour market given the deep economic crisis in Greece.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 557 workers following the liquidation of "Supermarket Larissa", a Greek company, the Greek authorities requested 6.5 million euros in aid for their reintegration into the labour market, but also to help 543 "NEETs" (young people without a diploma, training or employment). The company in question was in the retail sector. Greece argues that its economy has experienced a severe recession since 2008 and that consumption has fallen by 21 points. Moreover, the austerity imposed on the Greek people has drastically reduced domestic demand, thus affecting the sales sector.  While this aid is a bad thing, it should not encourage the deflationary external adjustment policies required by the very existence of the euro.  However, it appears to be necessary for laid-off workers, so I voted in favour of this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ The principle of subsidiarity dictates that decisions should be taken at the closest possible level to the citizen – in this case, at regional or national level. Therefore, these projects should not be funded by the European Union. It is absurd that the arbiters of whether this funding should, or should not, be given are Members of the European Parliament with no detailed knowledge of the situation. This project may well be of benefit to the people of Greece, but I am not best placed to judge. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund should be scrapped, which would give money back to the Member States to decide for themselves about the appropriateness of such funding. Consequently, I had no option but to vote against – even though this may be a worthwhile project.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this budgetary vote as it would approve EUR 6 468 000 of taxpayers’ money to be given to 557 workers made redundant in Greece. UKIP is totally opposed to the EU spending British taxpayers’ money as dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Greece, economically weakened, had to take drastic and unpopular measures to meet its external debt. Thousands of businesses have closed their doors and contributed to the rise in unemployment and thus to the decline in consumption, especially of basic foodstuffs, a sector of the company Supermarket Larissa. With the conditions of the regulation met, I naturally voted for this contribution of EUR 6,468,000, which will help the reintegration of 557 workers.

name: Beatriz Becerra Basterrechea (ALDE)
text: in writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Funds provide timely assistance to laid-off workers due to major structural changes in world trade. These aids are of paramount importance as they provide the opportunity to recycle to workers from a wide range of sectors. There is no doubt that the European institutions must also be urged to take the necessary measures and measures to stop business movements which, without conforming to legality, harm the present and future industrial of the Union.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is an instrument designed to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade.  The outbreak of the international economic crisis, and the subsequent Greek debt crisis, has led to a collapse in the purchasing power of Greek households and a drastic reduction in credit to businesses and individuals. Among the many consequences, these processes have also led to the bankruptcy and closure of the shops of the Supermarket Larissa cooperative, active in Central Macedonia and Thessaly.  My vote in favour of the Ní Riada report stems from the need to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide assistance to the 557 workers made redundant and to the 543 young people in these regions who do not work, do not participate in any education and are not in training. This measure will provide a coordinated package of instruments including training and mobility allowances as well as business start-up grants and training, retraining and vocational training programmes.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and help young people without education or employment. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I supported this report on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Greece to support the return to the labour market of laid-off workers at Supermarket Larissa ABEE, which operates in the retail division, excluding motor vehicles and motorcycles, in the Nuts 2 level regions of Central Macedonia and Thessaly. The transfer request is a total amount of EUR 6,468,000 from the EGF reserve. Given the importance of this fund I have supported the same as I always do.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the allocation of aid provided by the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the 577 workers of "Supermarket Larissa". We know what the Greeks have been going through for several years now: the enslavement by the Troika of the Greek people, forced to sell their country to meet the austerity demands, makes this aid of 6.5 million euros seem a poor compensation; at least they will help reintegrate 543 young people, currently without a degree or job. Unfortunately, Greece is the model of what the European Union and its euro is in store for us. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is just the arsonist's fire hose.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I wanted to support the mobilisation of the EGF worth € 6 468 000 in favour of 557 redundant workers and 534 young people under 30 after the bankruptcy of the Greek cooperative Larissa, operating in the retail sector, caused by the collapse in the purchasing power of Greek families and the drastic reduction in credit to businesses and individuals. The Globalisation Adjustment Fund remains a key instrument for supporting citizens in this time of crisis, but I believe that the EU should do even more to improve its efficiency.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilising EUR 6.4 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the 557 workers laid off by the bankruptcy and subsequent closure of the Larissa cooperative, due to the fall in purchasing power in Greece and the drastic reduction in loans to businesses and individuals. Greece has also decided to include 543 young people in this dossier without employment, education or training, so the total number of beneficiaries amounts to 1 100.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has given Parliament the power to support Greece in support of the European Globalisation Fund in order to help 557 workers made redundant from the supermarket larissa small food shopping cooperative. This financial support will also aim to help 543 targeted young people not in employment, education or training (NEETs). According to the Greek authorities, the redundancies are due to the bankruptcy and closure of supermarket larissa's shops, which has been caused by a reduction in the purchasing power of Greek households and a drastic reduction in the provision of loans to businesses and individuals. The personalised services intended to be provided to redundant workers and NEETs include five types of measures: vocational guidance, training, retraining and vocational training, business support, participation benefits and training allowances, mobility allowances. One of the guidance measures consists of information campaigns specifically aimed at NEETs to identify a group of beneficiaries.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers and self-employed persons made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade, as a result of globalisation, or as a result of the protracted global financial and economic crisis or another global financial and economic crisis. Greece has submitted an application for a financial contribution from the EGF under reference number 'EGF/2015/011 GR/Supermarket Larissa'. The request complies with the requirements of the relevant Regulation, according to the Commission's investigation, and I therefore voted in favour of the adoption of the proposal.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. My vote also went to support the European Parliament resolution on the use of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund funds, an application submitted by the Greek Government for supermarket Larissa. The contribution of EUR 6 468 000 will thus help to reintegrate into the labour market for workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade flows - in this case former workers of Supermarket Larissa.  Those funds will thus be used for mentoring measures, the possibility of employment and business services, training, wage subsidies, travel allowances, accommodation and relocation costs. I am also pleased that funds will also be used to help start a business and promote entrepreneurship.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This is the mobilization of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for 6.5 million euros in aid for the reintegration of 557 laid-off workers into the labour market but also to help 543 "NEETs" (young people without a diploma, training or employment). This aid, which appears to be necessary for laid-off workers, should not, however, encourage the deflationary external adjustment policies demanded by the very existence of the euro.  I therefore voted for it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that it is up to the European Union to support workers in difficulty due to the effects of globalisation and that redundant workers at Supermarket Larissa should be supported at this difficult time.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since the demand in question is relevant to the legal and social areas relating to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), it is appropriate to proceed with the technical assistance of the companies involved, hoping for a rapid resumption of their productive activities and full protection of the employment and incomes of workers and their families.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This proposal aims to give Greece a financial contribution of 6.5 million euros, from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, in order to reintegrate 557 employees, who were laid off following the liquidation of the Greek retail company Supermarket Larissa, into the labour market.  While this fund has the merit of responding to the urgency of the situation, it does not, on the other hand, address the roots of the deindustrialization that Western countries have faced since the 1980s. It would indeed be essential to combat the unfair international competition that our companies are experiencing and to recover our monetary sovereignty in order to correct existing differences in competitiveness within the euro area.  As a good arsonist, the European Union delivers our economies to savage globalisation by removing almost all tariff and non-tariff barriers that protect us from the social and environmental dumping of emerging countries and then comes to the bedside of our employees, who were made redundant following the closure of their businesses. I did, however, vote in favour of this proposal, which provides an immediate response to the urgency of the situation.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Vote in favour. EUR 6 468 000 for 557 redundant workers and 534 young people under 30, following the bankruptcy of the Greek cooperative Larissa operating in the retail sector, as a result of the collapse in the purchasing power of Greek families and the drastic reduction in credit to businesses and individuals.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of sacked employees of Supermarket Larissa in Greece. The amount of aid amounts to 6,468,000 euros. 577 laid-off employees will receive training aimed at reintegrating into the labour market and finding a job. I voted in favour of this report, which shows the Union's solidarity with some of the negative consequences of globalisation on employment.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the report on the proposal on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major changes in the structure of world trade.  The application in question was submitted by Greece in connection with 557 redundancies at Supermarket Larissa, a company operating in the retail sector. Due to the deep recession in the Greek economy, followed by a decline in household consumption and purchasing power, volumes in the food and beverage retail trade fell by more than 30 % compared to volumes at the start of the 2008 crisis. Supermarket Larissa sales followed the same trend. I regret that Italian companies are not able to benefit more from this fund because of the lack of support from local and national institutions. Between 2007 and 2015, Italy submitted only 15 applications to the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, 3 of which in 2007, only one in 2008, zero between 2009 and 2010, 7 in 2011, 2 in 2012, zero in 2013, one in 2014 and one in 2015.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which was an approval of an application by Greece to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). My colleague Liadh Ni Riada was rapporteur on the report. The report approved aid of EUR 6.4 million for 557 redundant workers from the Larissa supermarket chain in Greece, which closed last year. It also approves support for 543 young people not in employment or education (NEETs) in the same area. The EGF funds are used to provide re-training and personalised job search supports to workers made redundant as a result of globalisation and major changes in global trade patterns. In recent years changes to the rules of the EGF have meant that workers made redundant as a result of the financial crisis can also be covered by the EGF programmes. In this case, the Greek application relied on the ‘crisis-related’ criteria for mobilisation of the EGF. The application cites a 30% drop in food/beverage consumption and purchasing power as a result of the crisis. Naturally I support the proposal to provide assistance to workers made redundant as a result of the crisis to find new employment.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary vote as it would approve EUR 6 468 000 of taxpayers’ money to be given to 557 workers made redundant in Greece. UKIP is totally opposed to the EU spending British taxpayers’ money as dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund so that appropriate aid can be provided to former workers of the Greek Supermarket Larissa in who were made redundant as a result of bankruptcies and closure of the cooperative shops. The funds should finance guidance and training in order to help workers return to the labour market. I particularly welcome the fact that the funds will also be used to finance start-ups.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report is concerned with the request to mobilise around EUR 6.5 million from the EGF Fund to help relocate some 500 workers previously employed in a small food shop cooperative operating in the Greek regions of Central Macedonia and Thessaly. Although the EGF is not the instrument that best can help redundant workers, in the absence of viable alternatives I voted in favour of the mobilisation proposal.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report as we believe that in accordance with all the applicable provisions of the EGF Regulation, the conditions for granting a financial contribution from the EGF are met. Greece's application concerns 557 employees made redundant by Larissa Supermarket S.A.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The vote on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund concerned in this respect the avoidance of the dismissal of hundreds of workers due to the problems a resulting from the economic crisis and the unbearable austerity measures in Greece. As this company has faced total collapse, I believe that support from the Fund is a sensible and legitimate solution, for the benefit of workers. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The application relates to 557 workers made redundant in Supermarket Larissa ABEE. This enterprise operates in the economic sector classified under the NACE Revision 2 Division 47 (Retail trade, except of motor vehicles and motorcycles). The redundancies made by Supermarket Larissa are located in the NUTS level 2 regions of Central Macedonia (EL12) and Thessalia (EL14).

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary vote as it would approve EUR 6 468 000 of taxpayers’ money to be given to 557 workers made redundant in Greece. UKIP is totally opposed to the EU spending British taxpayers’ money as dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Support the Ní Riada Report, which allows the use of EUR 6 468,000 from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to reintegrate into the labour market of 557 workers made redundant from Supermarket Larissa and 543 young people who do not work, study or train. At the origin of the redundancies were the bankruptcy and closure of the supermarket larissa stores, due to the fall in the purchasing power of Greek households and the drastic reduction of loans to companies and individuals. Through the use of this Fund, created to provide additional support to workers for major structural changes in world trade, it will be possible to support these workers through measures ranging from guidance/interpretation and facilitating job search to support for business creation or personalised professional requalification.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this budgetary vote as it would approve EUR 6 468 000 of taxpayers’ money to be given to 557 workers made redundant in Greece. UKIP is totally opposed to the EU spending British taxpayers’ money as dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The situation presented by the Greek authorities shows that the collapse of production and the drastic reduction in purchasing power have had extremely negative consequences for companies, which need financial aid to promote vocational training, retraining or starting up a business.  Having taken note of the compliance of the Committee on Budgets with the application submitted by Greece for the Globalisation Adjustment Fund with the requirements for obtaining a European financial contribution, I decided to vote in favour of the procedure for activating the EGF.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 6 468 000 following the dismissal of 557 workers from Supermarket Larissa ABEE, as well as 543 young people under the age of 30 who neither work nor follow studies or training (ninis) in Greece. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these workers in this country, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 14 April 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision to use the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for Greece to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from Supermarket Larissa ABEE in the central Macedonia and Thessaloniki regions, thus benefiting Greece with a total of EUR 6.4 million from the EGF. The application concerns 557 redundant workers and approximately 543 non-employed young people without education. The Greek authorities claim that the bankruptcy and closure of supermarket larissa cooperative shops caused the redundancies following a decline in the purchasing power of Greek households and a drastic reduction in lending to businesses and individuals. One of the measures covered by career guidance is the launch of information campaigns specifically for young people. Greece has notified the Commission that the national public investment programme is a source of pre-financing or co-financing by the Member States. According to today's decision of the European Parliament, as Greece fulfils the necessary criteria for the use of the Fund, it is therefore entitled to use it.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EGF helps workers find new jobs and acquire new skills when they lose their jobs as a result of changes in the structure of world trade, e.g. in the event of the closure of a large company, the relocation of a factory outside the EU or the global financial and economic crisis. Greece has requested a total financial contribution from the EGF of EUR 6,4 million to cover the costs of active labour market instruments such as training, setting up, allowances, including training and mobility allowances. I personally support actions implementing strategies for growth and jobs. I believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right tool for implementing these strategies and an effective and cost-effective tool for restoring redundant workers to the labour market. I therefore voted yes.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a general rule, the EGF can be used only where over 500 workers are made redundant by a single company, or if a large number of workers are laid off in a particular sector in one or more neighbouring regions. I voted in favour of this report as the eligibility for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment fund is met.

name: Daniel Dalton (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as in my view we need to reduce EU spending wherever possible and also provide stronger budget scrutiny to reduce waste and inefficiency of taxpayers’ money. I support less spending at the EU level, not more.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This legislative report proposes the mobilization of 6,468,000 euros from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) for the benefit of the 557 licensees of the "Larissa" supermarket in Greece. The WEF helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in international trade as a result of globalization or the global economic and financial crisis.  This European instrument has a maximum annual budget of 150 million euros for the period 2014-2020 and aims in particular to provide career guidance services. Considering that the European Union must promote the transition from losing sectors to a competitive economic model, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF) to enable laid-off workers to re-enter the labour market. As redundancies are due, in particular, to the decline in the purchasing power of Greek households, the EGF must be mobilised for the benefit of Greece.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – Supermarket Larissa ABEE in Greece received redundancies following which the Greek authorities submitted an application for a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) under the reference number 'EGF/2015/011 GR/Supermarket Larissa' on 26 November 2015. After assessing the request, the Commission concluded, on the basis of all the relevant provisions of the EGF Regulation, that the conditions for granting the financial contribution from the EGF were fulfilled. The application concerns 557 workers made redundant from Supermarket Larissa ABEE, amounting to EUR 6 468 000. The Fidesz-KDNP delegation supports the motion in the spirit of solidarity. It is important that redundant workers are adequately supported to re-enter the labour market.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. After the dismissal of 557 workers following the liquidation of "Supermarket Larissa", a Greek company, the Greek authorities requested 6.5 million euros in aid for their reintegration into the labour market, but also to help 543 "NEETs" (young people without a diploma, training or employment).  Such aid should not have the result of encouraging the deflationary external adjustment policies required by the very existence of the euro. Indeed, Greece argues that its economy has experienced a severe recession since 2008, due to a 21-point drop in consumption. However, for pragmatic reasons, I voted for this text which comes to the aid of laid-off workers.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EKR Group and I personally fully support measures and policies that create growth and jobs. We know that in today's times of crisis they are completely necessary.
