However, we do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right instrument for the implementation of such policies, nor do we believe that it is an efficient instrument that justifies investment in terms of reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market. That is why I voted against this report.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour because it is a financial contribution of EUR 6,468,000, concerning 557 dismissed Greeks.  Our disagreement is that the funds should be given to employment programmes for the unemployed and/or laid off and not to some companies that will be paid to train them.  In Greece the problem is unemployment and not lack of knowledge and skills.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. "Our belief is that prosperity is created through free trade and fair competition. That is why we are opposed in principle to the European Globalisation Fund, which we believe is an expression of protectionism. We have previously accepted that the Fund has been used as a mere emergency measure at a time of deep economic crisis, as a means of confronting people's sense of hopelessness and the alienation that follows in the wake of the crisis and which risks further reinforcing the wave of nationalism and xenophobia that is spreading in Europe. However, particularly in the light of the Swedish National Audit Office's analysis, which states that the Fund even has a negative effect on the return to work, we believe that the Fund has lost its legitimacy and should not be used any more.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: necessary for laid-off workers.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Larissa Supermarkets is a small grocery cooperative (retail sector) formed in 1986, which had 42 stores and about 600 workers in Greece. It states that 'the successful development of the cooperative has been disrupted by the economic and financial crisis'. Little by little, they had to close stores in 2014, followed by the company's closure and subsequent layoffs in 2015, when the court ruled on filing for bankruptcy.  This mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), of EUR 6 468 000, proposes to support the 557 workers made redundant, as well as 543 young people without a job, who are not in training or studying programmes (NEETs).  Brutal decrease in family income, drastic reduction in loans to businesses and individuals, colossal decline in GDP since 2008, decrease in public consumption and private consumption, increased unemployment, wage cuts (- 30 %): here are some of the causes close to this tragedy. This report goes a little further than usual, asking the European Commission to provide more details in future proposals on the sectors in which workers are most likely to find a job and to collect comprehensive data, including data on the quality of jobs found and the rate of reintegration achieved through the EGF.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against because I do not consider this measure to be a useful tool for the development of policies that promote growth and the creation of new jobs, nor able to give a comprehensive answer with regard to redundant workers.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was created to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. This is the fifth application in this case, concerning the mobilisation of a total of EUR 6 468 000 from the EGF in favour of Greece. It concerns 557 redundancies and 543 young people who are neither in employment nor in education or training. Larissa has paid the price for the decline in the purchase of Greek households following the outbreak of the economic and financial crisis.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of concrete aid to more than 1 000 workers after the bankruptcy of the Greek cooperative Larissa.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe that the EGF offers value for money when it comes to attempting to reintegrate redundant workers back into the labour market. I want to see proper budget discipline by the EU that gives British taxpayers good value for money and the inefficient EGF does not do this. As a result, my Conservative colleagues and I voted against this report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The application relates to 557 redundancies in Supermarket Larissa in Greece, operating in the economic sector, classified under NACE Revision 2 Division 47 (Retail trade except of motor vehicles and motorcycles) during the reference period from 3 May 2015 to 3 September 2015. The EGAF funding of EUR 6 468 000 is to contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for the reintegration of 557 redundant workers into employment. The redundancies were caused by a deep economic recession, the decrease of private consumption and purchasing power, due to the financial and economic crisis. I voted in favour of the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Greece.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I approved the request for the use of the EGF by Greece. The Union has set up legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes in world trade or made redundant as a result of the global financial and economic crisis, and to support their reintegration into the labour market. In the interests of European workers, workers in difficulty as a result of the crisis must be able to take corrective steps to reposition them on the labour market. The redundancies in the retail sector in larissa, Greece, are expected to affect 557 workers and 543 unemployed young people under the age of 30 who are unemployed, not in training or education in these regions. It should be noted that a drastic reduction in corporate lending has also contributed to this situation in an environment where quantitative easing by the ECB has not been able to kick-start lending. This case is the dramatic result of continued pressure from creditors on Greece and European austerity policy.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in relation to the EGF/2015/011 GR/Supermarket Larissa application, presented by Greece, because I believe it is important for the EU to give a strong signal of support to Greek workers affected by a very serious social crisis. This EGF contribution of EUR 6 468 000 is really important because it is aimed at supporting 557 redundant workers, including as many as 543 young people who do not work or study and who are a sign of the mistrust in the future that the younger generation is experiencing in southern Europe. The case of the supermarket cooperative Larissa shows once again that simple austerity is not enough: redundancies, wage cuts and renegotiation of deadlines cannot save economic activities in the face of a recession and a consumption crisis as serious as the Greek one. The measures financed by the EGF, in particular vocational guidance, retraining and vocational training, business start-up grants, participation allowances and mobility allowances, are therefore a breath of fresh air in a region, Thessaly, with a record 73 % unemployment.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been set up for workers suffering the consequences of far-term structural changes in world trade patterns. This also applies to the insolvency and closure of branches of the Supermarket Larissa cooperative in Greece due to the decline in purchasing power and lending. The many workers must be helped financially to reintegrate into working life.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and help young people without education or employment. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns, due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the release of funds from the European Globalisation Fund in order to support laid-off workers. Unfortunately, this case is yet another tragic case of the closure of a cooperative in Greece because of the harsh neoliberal austerity policies imposed through the memorandums.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this application to mobilise EUR 6 468 000 of the EGF for 557 workers made redundant following the bankruptcy and closure of the Supermarket Larissa ABEE in Greece. The Greek economy was in deep recession for six consecutive years from 2008 to 2013. Since 2008, Greek GDP has decreased by 25.7%, public consumption by 21% while unemployment increased by about 19%. In order to deal with foreign debt repayments, the Greek Government has increased tax rates, streamlined public expenditure and decreased public employees’ salaries and wages in the private sector have decreased. This all resulted in an immediate effect of reduced income leading to a decrease in consumption that strongly affected the retail sector, in which Supermarket Larissa operates. I was very pleased to see that in addition to the 557 workers dismissed, 543 young people not in employment, education or training (NEETs) under the age of 30 from the same regions are expected to participate in the measures and receive personalised services co-financed by EGF.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this application as it aides workers who were made redundant, due to the Greek economic crisis. In particular it aids young people who are unemployed and not in education or training to up skill and find work.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide real support to redundant workers who have suffered as a result of the global financial crisis. Greece's request for access to EUR 6 468 000 from the EGF for the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant from the Larisa supermarket was adopted by the European Commission. I welcome the Commission's decision in this regard on the services to be offered to redundant workers consisting of guidance and training measures, retraining and vocational training, contributions to the establishment of an undertaking, participation and training allowances and mobility allowances.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a Resolution from the European Parliament on the proposal for a decision by Parliament and the Council to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the event of the redundancies of workers of the Greek supermarket larissa cooperative, as financial assistance would cover 557 redundancy workers and 543 young people not in employment.  The financial crisis that hit Greece deeply touched the Greek economy, and was therefore followed by a major decline in purchasing power and consumption. In such cases, I believe it is necessary that eu financial assistance is dynamic and accessible as quickly as possible in order to prevent prolonged exclusion from the labour market and further weaken European economies. Therefore, I support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. If the aid mentioned in the text is a bad thing, it should not encourage the deflationary external adjustment policies required by the very existence of the euro.  However, it appears to be necessary for laid-off workers.  So I voted for the text.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help workers who have lost their jobs in Supermarket Larissa stores in Greece. These subsidies are intended to enable them to integrate more easily into the labour market. The Fund will provide staff with professional advice, training, retraining and training, as well as mobility allowances.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to mobilise, at the request of Greece, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of 6,468,000 euros to help the Greek employees made redundant from the company Supermarket Larissa.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of my colleague's report, as it is necessary in cases such as those of supermarkets in Larissa for the EU to show that it understands its social obligation.  The 422 employees and 135 employees-owners were dismissed from Larissa Supermarkets after the bankruptcy of the cooperative company.  These measures, co-financed by the EGF and the Greek State, will help these people find new jobs by providing them with professional guidance and other assistance programmes.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I agree with this report as the application submitted for the mobilisation of the EGF meets the conditions for a financial contribution to be made available. It is my personal concern to reintegrate workers who lose their jobs as a result of globalisation into the labour market in the best possible way and to give them the opportunity to adapt their qualifications to the new challenges.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of mobilisation of the fund, as I support giving assistance to reintegrate workers in the labour market made redundant due to major structural changes in world trade patterns, due to globalisation and the economic crisis.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 As a result of the overall European austerity policies, the retail sector and the activities of small and medium-sized enterprises are suffering a major blow. Unable to cope with the deep economic recession in which Greece has fallen and thus the decline in the purchasing power of households, the small grocery cooperative "Supermarket Larissa" was forced to close its stores.  The mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund can make an active contribution, through personalised services, to the reintegration of redundant persons into work. I would like to stress, however, that the provision of a financial contribution, although an important breather for those affected, is not sufficient. The Union must take preventive actions, focusing its trade policy on the ways in which jobs, production and know-how can be safeguarded.  I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – I have repeatedly complained that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund funds are being used to help companies in rich central countries, often their multinational large companies. In this case, however, the aid will be placed in the right place, because it will help the out-of-work employees of a local company in the outskirts.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. As in the previous proposal, I voted in favour of the proposal to mobilise the EGF in favour of Greece in order to provide for the reintegration into the world of work of workers made redundant at the Supermarket Larissa EEA, a company operating in the economic sector of retail trade, in the regions of Central Macedonia and Thessaly.  This application, totalling EUR 6 468 000, concerns 557 workers made redundant and 543 young people who do not work and do not participate in any education or training cycle (NEET), due to the bankruptcy and closure of the shops of the Supermarket Larissa cooperative. They are the result, as described by the Greek authorities, of the collapse in household purchasing power and the drastic reduction in credit to businesses and individuals. I am therefore voting in favour of mobilising the Fund for These Families.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the licensees of the "Supermarket Larissa". Following the dismissal of 557 workers after the liquidation of this Greek company, the authorities of that country requested 6.5 million euros in assistance for their reintegration into the labour market, but also to help 543 "NEETs" (young people without a diploma, training or employment). The company in question was in the retail sector.  Greece argues that its economy has experienced a severe recession since 2008 and that consumption has fallen by 21 points. Moreover, the austerity imposed on the Greek people has drastically reduced domestic demand, thus affecting the sales sector.  While this aid is a bad thing, it should not encourage the deflationary external adjustment policies required by the very existence of the euro. However, it appears to be necessary for laid-off workers.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I spoke out in favour of this text.  It proposes to release 6.5 million euros under the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, to help the 557 workers of Supermarket Larissa (Greek company) reintegrate into the labour market. The aid paid would also extend to the 543 NEETs (young people without a degree, training or employment). Indeed, specialized in retail, the company in question went bankrupt, victim of the recession of 2008, which caused consumption in Greece to fall by 21 points.  Although the aid requested increases deflationary policies of external adjustment, I believe that employees do not suffer the consequences.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour, because it is the mobilization of the fund for the 557 workers laid off in Greece due to the bankruptcy and consequent closure of the Larissa cooperative due to the fall in household purchasing power in Greece and the drastic reduction of loans to businesses and individuals.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. As mentioned above, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) provides assistance to workers suffering the consequences of structural changes in global trade patterns.  In the wake of falling purchasing power in Greek households and a large reduction in lending to both businesses and individuals, Larissa supermarkets were forced to carry out numerous redundancies. What is intended by this report is that these employees are provided with a number of experts who offer them professional guidance, training and compensation for participation, among other measures.  Like the French authorities, the Greek authorities have also provided all the necessary guarantees in relation to equal treatment and non-discrimination in access to these proposals.  Finally, I support this report as it will help those affected by these structural changes to emerge from the precarious situation in which they are located.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) specialises in assisting and supporting people who have lost their jobs due to structural change and the dynamism of the business environment.  The EGF for 2014-2020 has an annual budget of €150 million with up to 60% of the costs directly from the fund. The EGF specialisation is to help workers who have become technologically redundant in order to find a new job or become entrepreneurs themselves.   The EGF can only be used in cases where over 500 workers of one company lose their jobs or a large number of workers are technologically redundant in a particular sector in one or more regions. Greece has applied to use the EGF on behalf of Larissa Supermarket.  The application concerns 557 workers dismissed from Supermarket Larissa ABBE operating in a sector that falls under 'retail trade, excluding motor vehicles and motorcycles'. The regions affected by the layoffs are Central Macedonia and Thessaly (NUTS 2). I supported the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund Mobilisation Report: EGF/2015/011 GR/Supermarket Larissa, as I believe that adequate use of the EGF can deliver new jobs for workers who have lost their jobs.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This financial allocation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund concerns a total amount of EUR 6,468 million, which is planned to be used to support and reintegrate 557 former Greek workers and 543 targeted young people into the labour market. The sector affected is retail trade, while the main reason for the closure of the company was identified as the rapid decline in purchasing power of the Greek people, as well as a reduction in lending to both companies and individuals. In view of the situation of recent years, this is unfortunately perfectly understandable. Since it is clearly worth supporting the Greek Government's efforts to gradually revive the national economy and raise the level of Greek prosperity, it was logical to support the issuance of these funds.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The amount of EUR 6 468 000 that has been allocated from the EGF reserve for Greece is intended to support the reintegration of workers made redundant at Supermarket Larissa in the Central Macedonia and Tesla regions. It concerns 557 redundancies and 543 young people who are not in employment, education or training either. This is due to the bankruptcy and closure of the company as a result of a decrease in the purchasing capacity of the population and a reduction in credit support for businesses and individuals. The application qualifies for EFG assistance.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 On Monday 23 May the European Parliament's Budget Committee gave the green light for the granting of aid amounting to EUR 6,468,000 to the 557 redundant supermarkets "Larisa". The application for financial assistance from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was submitted by the Greek authorities on 26 November 2015 following the bankruptcy of the cooperative company and the European Commission completed its assessment on 14 April 2016. Given that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by major structural changes or the global financial crisis, I support the decision of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide assistance to the redundant people of the Larissa supermarket, as well as to 543 additional unemployed people who will benefit from the programme. In view of the above, I am voting in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. The report aims to unlock eur 6.5 million in financial support from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund.  This envelope would be allocated to the 557 former unemployed employees following the judicial liquidation of "Supermarket Larissa" in Greece. 543 NEETs (young people without a degree, training or employment) would also benefit from these subsidies. We see that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is limited to dealing with the consequences, not the causes of massive job destruction in Europe. In this case, the unyielding austerity policy imposed on Greece has led to an economic recession and a 21% contraction in consumption since 2008.  Despite these considerations, we are in favour of providing material assistance to these people.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Greece. Greece has in fact applied for a financial contribution totalling EUR 6 468 000 as a result of 557 workers made redundant by the Supermarket Larissa EEA cooperative, a company operating in the retail sector, excluding motor vehicles and motorcycles. Citizens. The activation of the Fund will only finance measures which will contribute to the reintegration of redundancies into the labour market, thus creating conditions enabling workers to find temporary or permanent jobs, participate in vocational training programmes and acquire the necessary skills. I believe that special assistance is extremely important for the workers made redundant and for those affected by the current global economic climate.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, one of the instruments created by the EU to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of significant structural changes in world trade structure or the consequences of the global financial and economic crisis, and to assist them in their reintegration into the labour market. Greece has submitted an application for assistance from this fund for larissa supermarket employees. The company was forced to lay off more than 500 employees as a result of globalization. I agree with the need for financial assistance, which is why I voted in favour of mobilisation of the european globalisation adjustment fund.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Here, funds from the Globalisation Fund are to be distributed to Greek workers. The amount of approximately EUR 6.5 million will be made available for reintegration into the labour market. These are 557 workers made redundant and 543 young people from the retail sector. I am concerned about supporting these workers. I therefore support this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report by which the EP supported the proposal to grant financial assistance to Greece from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Support is granted to the central Macedonian and Thessaly regions following the bankruptcy of Supermarket Larissa ABEE.  The aim of the support is to retrain workers according to their needs and the needs of the business environment.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to release funds to help workers facing unexpected moments of difficulty.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. It is proposed that the Globalization Adjustment Fund should help the 557 employees laid off following the bankruptcy of Supermarket Larissa.  As a matter of principle, I disapprove of the existence of this fund, which only solves problems in the very short term in Greece.  However, I think it is appropriate to help these workers. As a result I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The EU is an area of solidarity and includes the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund. This support is essential to help the unemployed and the victims of relocations in a globalised context. More and more companies are relocating, taking advantage of the low labour prices that are practised in several countries, notably China and India, with harmful effects on countries that respect workers' rights.  The EGF is intended to help workers who are victims of business relocation and is key to facilitating access to new employment. The EGF has already been used in the past by other EU countries, and it is now up to Greece to give this aid to the EGF/2015/011 GR/Supermarket Larissa application for a financial contribution from the EGF, following redundancies in the economic sector classified in NACE Rev. 2 division 47 ('Retail markets, except for motor vehicles and motorcycles') in the NUTS Level 2 regions of Central Macedonia and Thessaly, and 557 redundant workers and 543 young people under the age of 30 who do not work, study and do not train are expected to participate in the measures.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is one of the tools at the Union’s disposal to provide additional assistance to workers negatively impacted upon by major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission approved this specific application as it met the conditions for mobilising the EGF to support the local economy. I therefore voted in favour of this report to alleviate the situation of 422 employees and 135 worker-owners were made redundant in Greece.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I am in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to the tune of EUR 6,468,000 for Greece to support the reintegration into the labour market of 557 laid-off workers, 543 of whom are unemployed, without education or training. This situation is due to the crisis in Greece, thus reducing the purchasing power of Greek households and making Supermarket Larissa unable to keep its staff. These young people, through the Fund, would have the opportunity to benefit from personalized services such as career counselling measures as part of the Youth Employment Initiative. More broadly, workers and young people without training could receive a sum of 15,000 euros to help them start their own businesses.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The European Commission has adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Greece to promote the reintegration of workers made redundant at Supermarket Larissa ABEE, which is active in the 'Retail, excluding motor vehicles and motorcycles' division in the Central Macedonia and Carnia regions. This is the fifth application to be examined under the 2016 budget. It concerns the mobilisation of a total of EUR 6 468 000 from the European Fund in favour of Greece. The Greek authorities argue that the event that led to the redundancies was the bankruptcy and closure of the collective stores of Supermarket Larissa following the decline in the purchasing power of Greek households and the radical restrictions on loans to businesses and individuals. After examination, the Commission concludes that the application qualifies for a financial contribution from the European Fund. The personalised services to be provided to redundant workers consist of five types of measures (for redundant workers and young people not in employment or education or training) covered by this application: 1) professional advice, 2) training, retraining and vocational training, 3) start-up allowance, 4) participation and training allowance , 5) mobility allowance. I agree with the proposal that has been tabled.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of giving a green light for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGAF) in Greece, mainly Central Macedonia and Thessalia. The EGAF funding of EUR 6 468 000 is to contribute to the costs of a coordinated package of eligible personalised services, providing assistance for the reintegration of 557 redundant workers into employment. The redundancies were caused by a deep economic recession, the decrease of private consumption and purchasing power, due to the financial and economic crisis.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund aims to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. At greece's request, the Commission has now proposed to use the Fund 6 468 000, which would contribute to the settlement of the situation of 557 workers in central Macedonia and Thessaloniki, as well as 543 unemployed young people under the age of 30 who are not in education and training, due to the bankruptcy of Supermarket Larissa, which specialised in the retail trade in motor vehicles and motorbikes. The report notes that the conditions laid down in Article 4(1)(a) of Regulation (EU) No 1309/2013 of the European Parliament and of the Council are fulfilled and that Greece is therefore entitled to that financial contribution. It therefore proposes that Parliament contribute to the use of EUR 6 468 000 from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund within the framework of the General Budget of the European Union for 2016, in the form of commitment and payment appropriations. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Regulation No 1927/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council of 20 December 2006 established the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with the aim of supporting workers who have lost their jobs due to structural changes in the context of the global economy.  Greece's application to the EGF relates to the mobilisation of a total amount of € 6 468 000 of the EGF's financial contribution, following the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Supermarket Larissa operating in the economic sector classified in DIVISION 47 of NACE Rev. 2 (Retail markets, other than motor vehicles and motorcycles), in the regions of Central Macedonia (Κεντρική Μακεδονία) (EL12) and Thessaly (Θεσσαλία) (EL14), nut level 2 of nut. I am voting in favour of this report, which is measures to support 557 redundant workers, of whom 194 are men and 363 are women. In addition, another 543 young people under the age of 30 who are out of work, education or training in the same area can receive personalised services, such as vocational guidance under the Youth Employment Initiative.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a substantial amount of assistance needed to facilitate the reintegration of laid-off workers, I am voting for.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted to mobilise the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of the employees of the small Greek grocery cooperative Supermarket Larissa, who were made redundant because of the Greek crisis, which drastically reduced the demand for food and drink from households. 557 sacked employees as well as 543 young people without work and without education or training will benefit from 6.5 million euros of support to accompany them to employment. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund intervenes to support sacked employees due to major changes in the structure of world trade resulting from globalisation, due to the persistence of the global financial and economic crisis, or due to a new global financial and economic crisis.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) supports and helps victims of the economic or financial crisis to find work again. In addition to the financial contribution, it supports young workers through career guidance counselling, training and retraining. It is important that young people receive not necessarily financial support that allows them to successfully find work or set up new businesses, so I voted in favour of adopting this report.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund can be accessed by any Member State of the European Union and aims to implement policy measures on the labour market and support the search for jobs, training and starting a business. It covers 60% of the costs for implementation of the desired measures, the rest being covered by the state, region, local authority and private funds. It may have an implementation period of maximum 24 months from filing the application. As shadow rapporteur I have voted for this report that will mobilise a total amount of EUR 6 468 000 from the EGF to Greece in aid to 557 workers made redundant and 543 targeted young persons not in employment, education or training.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Greece requested a financial contribution from the EGF as a result of the redundancies in retail trade following the bankruptcy and closure of Supermarket Larissa ABEE. Supermarket Larissa is a small grocery store cooperative founded in 1986, with 42 stores and 600 employees, which could not cover its losses and had to close its stores in the second quarter of 2014.  The financial contribution from the EGF shall be provided that, during a reference period of four months, at least 500 workers from an undertaking in a Member State are dismissed, including workers made redundant by suppliers and downstream producers and/or self-employed persons who have ceased their activity. 557 laid-off workers, as well as 543 young people under the age of 30 who are not in employment and do not follow any educational or training programmes, will benefit from personalised services co-financed by the EGF.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The first is an application from Greece under the crisis criteria (as opposed to globalisation) for 557 workers and 543 NEETs from the same region. The redundant workers are from a cooperative of grocery stores, Supermarket Larissa, which closed last year. The application cites a 30% drop in food/beverage consumption and purchasing power as a result of the crisis. It was for these reasons that I voted in favour of this application.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 14 April 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Greece in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Supermarket Larissa ABEE. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the effects of significant structural changes in global trade patterns. I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The application deals with a possible mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for Greece. Approximately EUR 6.5 million will be made available for reintegration into the labour market. The application concerns 557 redundant workers and 543 young people from the 'retail trade without trade in motor vehicles' industry. I see that the conditions for mobilisation within the meaning of the EGF are clearly met.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Support from the Fund is essential to encourage the successful return to the labour market of workers made redundant from Supermarket Larissa in Greece.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary vote as it would approve EUR 6 468 000 of taxpayers’ money to be given to 557 workers made redundant in Greece. UKIP is totally opposed to the EU spending British taxpayers’ money as dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Over the last year, we have voted for a number of decisions on the use of the European Fund to help workers who find themselves in an unenviable position. Major structural changes in the flows of world trade caused by globalisation and the continuation of the global financial and economic crisis have led to significant losses for some companies. As many as 557 larissa supermarket workers in Greece were made redundant.  Aware of the difficult situation of laid-off workers, I support the Greek government's request for assistance and the allocation of a financial contribution from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund of €6 468 000. It should be noted that workers who have been made redundant are likely to encounter difficulties in finding a job. This monetary assistance is necessary to enable their reintegration in the labour market.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒The purpose of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to support redundancy workers and the self-employed who have ceased their activity due to major structural changes in world trade flows due to globalisation, due to global financial and economic crises to help them re-enter the labour market. I agree with the request concerning the 557 workers laid off from Supermarket Larissa ABEE.  The company operates in the economic sector "Retail trade, except for the trade in motor vehicles and motorcycles". In order to establish a link between the redundancies and the global financial and economic crisis discussed in Regulation (EC) No 546/2009, Greece claims that the Greek economy has been in deep recession for six consecutive years (from 2008 to 2013). According to ELSTAT, greece's statistics body, Greece's GDP has shrunk by 25.7 percentage points since 2008, public spending by 21 percentage points and private consumption by 32.3 percentage points, while unemployment has increased by 19 percentage points.  In addition, the gdp decline widened the gap between Greece's GDP per capita and GDP per capita in the EU, undoing progress towards economic convergence established by Greece between 1995 and 2007.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Larissa Supermarkets is a small grocery cooperative (retail sector) formed in 1986, which in Greece had 42 stores and about 600 workers in Greece. As underlined by the Commission itself, 'the successful development of the cooperative has been disrupted by the economic and financial crisis'. Little by little, they had to close stores in 2014, followed by the company's closure and subsequent layoffs in 2015, when the court ruled on filing for bankruptcy.  This mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF), of EUR 6 468 000, proposes to support the 557 workers made redundant, as well as 543 young people without a job, who are not in training or studying programmes (NEETs) who will participate in the measures put in place.  Austerity measures, such as wage cuts (-30%), have not prevented the closure of companies such as Larissa, yet another dramatic result of continued pressure from creditors on Greece and European austerity policy.   We voted in favour.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 A request to activate 6.4m euros from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EFG) was requested by Greece to help laid-off workers from Supermarket Larissa, which went bankrupt as a result of the decline in purchasing power of Greek households, as a result of the greek economy's downturn as a result of major structural changes in global trade flows.  The application concerns 557 redundate workers and 543 young people who are not in employment, school or training and are under 30 years of age. Given the situation in Greece that has been hit by the financial crisis and the fact that the Greek economy has been in a deep recession for six consecutive years, the link between the redundancies and the global financial and economic crisis discussed in Regulation (EC) No 2013/2013 is clearly visible. 546/2009 It is important to increase overall awareness of the EGF and its recognition, as well as to strengthen the communication of all parties involved in the submission of applications for mobilisation of the EGF, in particular social partners and stakeholders at regional and local level, with a view to attaining as many synergistic effects as possible. Consequently, I supported my colleague Liadh Ní Riad's report on the proposal for a decision by the EP and the Council on the mobilisation of the EGF.

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of the mass redundancies of almost 600 workers from a cooperative of small Greek food shops. Greece's economy was deeply hit by a recession in 2015, with household consumption also down as much as 30 percent from pre-crisis levels. Unfortunately, the cooperative was unable to save the situation with internal austerity measures, which were not helped by the subsequent external pressure of austerity regulations by Greek and European actors. I therefore voted in favour of granting more than EUR 6 million, which should complement the Participation of the Greek Government in resolving this particular case. I supported that the support amount should be used not only by the redundancies, but also by another 500 young unemployed people under the age of 30 from the same region of Thesalia. I did so because of the lack of jobs in this area, where long-term unemployment is marked by a hard-to-believe three quarters of job seekers. I am therefore glad that European funds will be used for activities that include the provision of professional advice, training, retraining and vocational training, support for start-ups or mobility allowances. Although the media world is not currently putting the problems of European unemployment first, this mobilisation of the Globalisation Fund is another evidence that Europe's economic problems are far from being resolved.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 14 April 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision mobilising the EGF in favour of Greece to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant at the Larissa ABEE Supermarket. This application relates to the mobilisation of the EGF totalling EUR 6 468 000. It covers 557 redundant workers and 543 young people who do not work and do not participate in any education or training (NEET).  The European Parliament has repeatedly stressed the need to improve the added value and efficiency of the EGF as a support tool for redundant workers. For this reason, I welcome the fact that the Commission intends to invest additional resources in this area. For all this, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The EGF helps workers find new jobs and acquire new skills when they lose their jobs as a result of changes in the structure of world trade, e.g. in the event of the closure of a large company, the relocation of a factory outside the EU or the global financial and economic crisis.  Greece has requested a total financial contribution from the EGF of EUR 6,4 million to cover the costs of active labour market instruments such as training, setting up, allowances, including training and mobility allowances. The application concerns 557 employees made redundant from supermarket Larissa ABEE. I support measures to promote the growth of new jobs and to bring redundant workers back into the labour market. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EMF), established in 2006, helps people who have lost their jobs as a result of structural changes in international trade, such as relocations or business closures. Here, more than 500 employees of the bankrupt Greek company Supermarket Larissa will receive assistance from the European Union.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 As a mechanism created to provide support to workers affected by the effects of structural changes in world trade patterns, the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is dedicated to cases such as that of Supermarket Larissa ABEE. In the context of the successive global economic and financial crises of the 21st century, Greek households experienced a sharp drop in purchasing power and a drastic reduction in access to credit. The impact of the crisis has, of course, extended to the Hellenic business fabric, and in particular to the retail sector.  This report focuses on a proposal for a decision to support, through the mobilisation of the EGF, 557 workers made redundant by Supermarket Larissa ABEE, of whom 543 are in the so-called NEET situation, i.e. they are under 30 years old, do not work, do not study and do not follow any training.  Underlining the need to comply with the rules of the EGF Regulation, in particular the provision contained in Article 7 thereof, in view of the fact that this is, in casu, a situation of manifest eligibility, and considering the relevance of the re-entry of these citizens into the labour market, I am voting in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this budgetary vote as it would approve EUR 6 468 000 of taxpayers’ money to be given to 557 workers made redundant in Greece. UKIP is totally opposed to the EU spending British taxpayers’ money as dole money for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of mobilising EUR 6.4 million from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for the 557 workers laid off by the bankruptcy and subsequent closure of the Larissa cooperative, due to the fall in purchasing power in Greece and the drastic reduction in loans to businesses and individuals. Greece has also decided to include 543 young people without employment, studies or training (ninis) in this dossier, bringing the total number of beneficiaries to 1100.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I have of course voted in favour of this report of raising funds for Greece.  As a reminder, Greece had filed its application "EGF/2015/011 GR/Supermarket Larissa" with a view to obtaining a financial contribution from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund following the redundancies in the economic sector under Division 47 (retail trade) of NACE Revision 2, in the NUTS 2 regions of Central Macedonia and Thessaly. In fact, 557 workers were laid off and 543 young people were unemployed, not educated or trained (NEET) and under the age of 30. Under the settlement of this special fund, Greece is entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 6,468,000, which represents 60% of the total cost of EUR 10,780,000.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I must admit that it looks strange when a supermarket chain asks for support from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. As we know, large traders are quite well able to survive even in the event of economic downturns, shifting their costs to the shoulders of suppliers and buyers. In a specific case, it is quite possible that Supermarket Larissa is also shifting part of its costs to the shoulders of the redundant workers and the European Union, asking them for support. If this case were not from the Thessaly region, which has extremely high unemployment rates and long-term unemployment, I would be inclined to insist on re-examining in detail how justified this application is. In this case, in accordance with the principle of European solidarity and in view of the still difficult situation in Greece, I am inclined to support the proposal.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Bearing in mind the objective of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EFaG) of providing additional support to workers affected by the effects of structural changes in world trade patterns, an application has been submitted by Greece - the fifth examined under the 2016 budget - with a view to obtaining a financial contribution of EUR 6 468 000 , to deal with the dismissal of 557 workers at Supermarket Larissa, operating in the retail market sector in the regions of Central Macedonia and Thessaly. Having gathered the necessary assumptions for the allocation of the EFAG's financial contribution and taking into account that this application is intended for the guidance, training, retraining and vocational training of redundant workers, as well as contributing to the creation of enterprises and to grant participation, training and mobility subsidies - all of which are active measures within the labour market , as provided for in the EFaG, I have given my vote in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. 2012 This report, on which Parliament is called upon to give its opinion, concerns the mobilisation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund in favour of Greece in the face of the closure of a small shop cooperative which, despite the measures taken to deal with the losses, has been forced into restructuring which has led to numerous redundancies of staff of young people under 30.  In view of the restrictions on access to credit for businesses and the difficulties in in terms of the integration of young people, the report welcomes, on behalf of Parliament, the request made and the support given by the Commission for workers who start their own businesses, will enter a training or retraining course, or will need a mobility allowance. Together with the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats and a very large majority in Parliament, I voted in favour.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and help young people without education or employment. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund will assist workers affected by the difficulties in the retail sector. This solidarity mechanism is one way to reduce the impact of the financial crisis and reintegrate unemployed people back into the labour market. The potential of this fund should be fully realised.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of profound structural changes in world trade patterns. In Greece, 557 employees lost their jobs when a supermarket was declared bankrupt as a result of the financial crisis. It is important to support workers affected by the negative effects of globalisation, which is also the purpose of the Fund. That is why I support the proposal.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report, as it allows the mobilisation of EUR 6 468 000 following the dismissal of 557 workers from Supermarket Larissa ABEE in Greece. This mobilization of funds aims to mitigate the disastrous social consequences of the economic crisis of the capitalist system.  While these funds are unable to solve the problems of these workers in this country, they at least give the possibility of alleviating a small part of human drama. That is why I have decided to vote in favour of this report.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ It is not for the EU to make redundancy payments.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I gave the green light for this mobilisation of the EGAF because it is a greatly needed tool in allowing our society to receive the biggest benefits from Globalisation while providing a safety net where unforeseen excesses and competition arise. This represents the fifth mobilisation of this fund, which have hitherto represented 14.8 million Euro, leaving 150.7 million Euro remaining. This fact reveals that this fund is not abused and completely not misspent and I encourage the UK Government to change its position on this fund.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I fully support the measures that are implementing policies to create growth and jobs. Nevertheless, I voted against this resolution. In fact, I do not believe that the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund is the right instrument for implementing such policies, nor do I think that it is an effective instrument that offers the right value (by reintegrating redundant workers back into the labour market) for money.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Greek authorities have submitted an application for a contribution from the Globalisation Adjustment Fund due to the downturn that has hit the Supermarket Larissa store association. I agreed with the proposal as, according to the available data, the application meets the criteria set. The purpose of the Globalisation Fund is to address precisely such unforeseen circumstances caused by structural changes in world trade resulting from globalisation processes. The situation in which 557 redundancies at Supermarket Larissa found itself was due to a decrease in the purchasing power of Greek households and a drastic reduction in lending to firms and individuals. I supported the release of almost EUR 6.5 million from this fund for the benefit of France, as this is intended to help retrain staff and their early inclusion in working life. In particular, the funds will be used for individualised services such as advice and guidance from experts. In addition to the workers made redundant, 543 young people who do not have a job, do not study or are not trained in any training will also be supported from these funds. Given the current situation of the Greek economy, I believe that this will also compensate for the cuts to which Greek society is subject.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I support the Report for mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund in the case of Greece, as the measures are expected to cover 557 redundate workers, as well as 543 young people aged up to 30 from the same regions who are not in employment, school or training. Union financial assistance to workers in need should be dynamic and accessible as quickly and efficiently as possible, in line with the Joint Declaration of the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission.  I also believe that the European Union has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of global changes in global trade flows, as well as to help them re-enter the labour market. Egf funds help redundantic workers of small and medium-sized enterprises, which is also the case for this example from Greece.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Union has set up legislation and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes caused by the global financial or economic crisis, and their reintegration into the labour market. The conditions to be met for these measures to be applied require that a minimum of 500 workers in one company must become excessive for a period of 4 months in a Member State.  The Hellenic Republic has submitted an application titled EGF/2015/011 GR/Supermarket Larissa for financial contributions from the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) with regard to the 557 workers eligible to attend these measures. Of these, most of the workers, 363 of them, are women. Parliament notes that an additional 543 people under the age of 30 from the same region as affected workers, who are unable to work, education or train, will also be included in these measures and receive personalised EGF-funded assistance.   I support this report because I think it is a financial remuneration that will help workers, who have become excessive in their companies as a result of globalisation, to reintegrate into the labour market.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (role of Greece — EGF/2015/011 GR/Supermarket Larissa). As a result of major structural changes in global trade flows, the Greek company Supermarket Larissa ABEE has been in difficulties in the retail sector, resulting in 557 redundancies and 543 young people not in employment, education or training. For these reasons and the fulfilment of all the conditions, I support the allocation of EUR 6 468 000 from the EGF to Greece.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The case of Larissa supermarkets is unfortunately yet another tragic case of the closure of a cooperative in Greece due to the harsh neoliberal austerity policies imposed through the memorandums. We voted in favour of the liberalisation of funds from the European Globalisation Fund, in order to support laid-off workers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 We agree because this is a financial contribution of EUR 6,468,000, concerning 557 dismissed Greeks.  Our disagreement is that the funds should be given to employment programmes for the unemployed and/or laid off and not to some companies that will be paid to train them. In Greece the problem is unemployment and not lack of knowledge and skills.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report because the matter has been dealt with and examined in detail at committee stage. I would like to emphasise that the cities of Salo and Oulu in Finland have also benefited in recent years from the mobilisation of the Globalisation Adjustment Fund as a result of the global restructuring of the travel phone sector.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union has put in place special legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional support to workers affected by economic change at international level and to support them in their reintegration into the labour market.  I believe that EU trade policy should continue to focus on how jobs can be maintained in the Member States and, respectively, on stimulating the social economy sector. In the case of the Larissa supermarket, where workers were made redundant following the bankruptcy and closure of the company, financial assistance should be efficient and rapid. For this reason, I am voting in support of the measures presented.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have spoken out in favour of this mobilization of the European fund. The EU has put in place legislative and budgetary instruments to provide additional assistance to workers suffering the consequences of major changes in the structure of world trade or the global economic and financial crisis, and to support them in their reintegration into the labour market.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of mobilising the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help workers who lost their jobs at the Supermarket Larissa cooperative shops in Greece to reintegrate the job market more easily. The Supermarket’s bankruptcy followed the drop of the purchasing power of Greek households and the drastic reduction of loans to companies and individuals. The fund will provide the workers with occupational guidance, training, retraining and vocational training, as well as participation, training and mobility allowances.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Greece has applied for the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund due to the bankruptcy and closure of larissa supermarkets to introduce measures for redundanst workers. This mobilisation, in addition to the 557 redundant workers, would also cover 543 young people up to the age of 30, and the measures Greece plans to introduce are career guidance, training, retraining and vocational training, incentives to start a business, participation fees and training allowances and mobility allowances. Since the start of the economic and financial crisis in Greece, thousands of businesses have closed and household consumption and purchasing power have been reduced. The retail sector in Greece is in an unenviable position, but these short-term measures will not help its recovery. I agree that further attention should be paid to maintaining jobs, production and expertise in the Union, which can be achieved by reducing bureaucratic barriers and tax burdens. Since no such solutions were offered by this report, I voted against it.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of european globalisation adjustment funds (the role of Greece — EGF/2015/011 GR/Supermarket Larissa) as the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was established to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. On 14 April, a proposal was adopted by the European Commission to mobilise the EGF in favour of Greece in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of those workers made redundant at Supermarket Larissa. There are a total of 557 such workers, plus 543 young people who are not in employment or education. The fall in purchasing power has led to the closure and bankruptcy of supermarket Larissa's cooperative stores. There will be five types of measures available to redundant workers: vocational guidance, training, retraining and vocational training, contribution to setting up a business, participation and training allowance, and mobility allowance.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and help young people without education or employment. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Following the dismissal of 557 workers following the liquidation of "Supermarket Larissa", a Greek company, the Greek authorities requested 6.5 million euros in aid for their reintegration into the labour market, but also to help 543 "NEETs" (young people without a diploma, training or employment). The company in question was in the retail sector. Greece argues that its economy has experienced a severe recession since 2008 and that consumption has fallen by 21 points. Moreover, the austerity imposed on the Greek people has drastically reduced domestic demand, thus affecting the sales sector. While this aid is a bad thing, it should not encourage the deflationary external adjustment policies demanded by the very existence of the euro. However, it appears to be necessary for laid-off workers. I'm voting for.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional support to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade. In this case, there are just over 500 jobs, the majority of which are filled by women. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report, as it promotes funds to compensate for and establish compensation measures in cases of relocation or closure of companies for structural changes in markets due to globalisation. They will serve to address the situation of laid-off workers, and help young people without education or employment. These are measures which, if they do not exist, would leave the workers concerned worse off. Such measures take effect only in the short term, but do not solve the problem in the long term, since the issue of employment and relocations should have another approach to action. On the one hand, Europe needs an investment plan, of a very different cut from Juncker's, and another employment policy, to act on labour matters. Second, this alternative should be to invest in future activities, especially a change in the productive model.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the use of this fund, which helps people affected by company closures resulting from relocations, in the case of Larissa supermarkets in Greece.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the fact that the Greek authorities have started to provide personalised services to the workers affected.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application from Greece – EGF/2015/011 GR/Supermarket Larissa). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) aims to provide support for workers, under specific conditions, who have lost their jobs as a result of mass redundancies caused by major changes in global trade. The measures, co-financed by the EGF and Greek government, would help the workers to find new jobs by providing them with occupational guidance and other assistance schemes such as collective and individual information sessions, job transition and accompaniment towards new jobs.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a fund that is dedicated to processing transfers of funds to pay compensation for maximum redundancies for the cessation of different business activities of the Member States. In this case, we are talking about a transfer that comes to alleviate the closure of Larissa supermarkets in Greece. It is therefore appropriate to vote in favour of that report.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because Greece applied for a financial contribution as a result of the bankruptcy and the redundancies of 557 employees of Supermarket Larissa ABEE. 543 young people under the age of 30 from the same regions are neither in employment nor in education or training and are expected to take part in the measures taken with this money, such as training, job application skills, etc.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 On 14 April 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a Decision on mobilising the EGF in favour of Greece in order to support the reintegration into the labour market of workers made redundant by Supermarket Larissa. This is the fifth application examined under the 2016 budget and refers to the mobilisation of a total amount of EUR 6 468 000 for Greece. It concerns 557 redundant workers and 543 young people who do not work, study and do not follow any training (NEET). The Greek authorities claim that the fall in the form of the redundancies was the bankruptcy and closure of the supermarket larissa's shops due to the fall in the purchasing power of Greek households and the drastic reduction in loans to businesses and individuals. The Commission concluded, in accordance with the applicable provisions of the EGF Regulation, that the application meets the conditions for a financial contribution from the EGF.  We continue to have doubts about this instrument. We are sensitive to the drama of workers, but we believe that the fundamental issues of the economy should be attacked and not just pouring funds into these companies.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The application deals with a possible mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for Greece. An amount of approximately EUR 6.5 million will be made available for reintegration into the labour market. The application concerns 557 workers made redundant and 543 young people in the 'retail without trade in motor vehicle' sector – an industry which in Greece suffers particularly badly from the weakened purchasing power of Greek households, due to the sharp decline in lending to companies and individuals. The circumstances described clearly justify a claim within the meaning of the EGF.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I rejected the European Parliament's report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (Greece's request – EGF/2015/011 GR/Supermarket Larissa). I fundamentally reject this fund as a waste of taxpayers' money. It will save uncompetitive companies. It also means overstepping the EU's powers by violating the principle of subsidiarity. I do not want more EU, but less – that is, not more funds and more money for the EU, but less.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) for Supermarket Larissa, Greece, a small grocery store cooperative founded in 1986, with 42 stores and 600 workers, who could not overcome losses and had to close its stores in the second quarter of 2014. According to the EGF Regulation, Greece will receive from the EU 6 468 000 euros out of a total of 10 780 000, money that will be used for retraining and training, start-up business support, mobility allowances, etc.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We have today voted on the request to mobilise the EGF for a situation concerning Greece. The Ní Riada report is linked to the crisis in Supermarket Larissa, a cooperative of small food shops that operated mainly in the Greek regions of Central Macedonia and Thessaly; the contribution requested in this case amounts to almost 6.5 million euros, to help relocate about 500 redundant workers of the Supermarket Larissa, as well as another 500 young people from the area under 30 years of age, who do not work and do not participate in some education or training cycle, the so-called NEETs.  I am generally in favour of mobilising this fund, although I am aware that this is probably not the instrument that best can help redundant workers, but in the absence of viable alternatives I nevertheless believe that it should be supported.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund, which estimates that Greece is eligible for a financial contribution of EUR 6 468 000 under the EGF Regulation.  The Purpose of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF) is to provide support to workers made redundant as a result of major structural changes in world trade flows as a result of globalisation and the global financial and economic crisis, and to help them reintegrate into the labour market.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Court of Vercelli transmitted, on November 20, 2015, the request for authorization to acquire some data about the telephone records of a number in the name of Deputy Buonanno. The required data control is essential for the conduct of criminal proceedings, established by virtue of alleged telephone threats suffered by the Member.  In order to shed light on the matter, I voted in favour.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of gianluca Buonanno's request to waive his parliamentary immunity. The MP, who was allegedly the victim of telephone threats received from an anonymous correspondent on his mobile phone number, has brought criminal proceedings before the Vercelli court. Gianluca Buonanno's immunity must be waived for the purposes of the investigation (access to telephone records) and for the sake of legal security. I approved that request.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The case concerns the waiver of the immunity of Gianluca Buonanno from the ENF. In this case, he has not committed a crime but was rather the subject of threatening phone calls. According to Italian Constitutional law however, the waiver of his immunity is needed before the police can access his phone records or acquire data concerning his telephone traffic. Therefore, I voted in favour of this waiver.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. On 14 April 2015, Gianluca Buonanno was reportedly the victim of telephone threats received from an anonymous correspondent on his mobile phone number. Mr Buonanno then brought criminal proceedings before the Vercelli court. For the purposes of the investigation, the Vercelli court prosecutor submitted an application for authorisation to obtain data from telephone companies on recordings for a number used by an MEP. It is necessary to take into account the immunities of MEPs, as well as the Constitution of the Italian Republic which, in Article 68, subjects any wiretap of a Member to the authorisation of the chamber to which it belongs. Access to telephone records, as in this case, is equated with wiretapping.  As a precaution, the prosecutor of the Vercelli court preferred to extend parliamentary privilege also to cases where the Member is the alleged victim of a crime. This request for the lifting of immunity will allow the perpetrator of the threats against Mr. Buonanno to be unmasked and tried. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ As this was a secret ballot, for reasons of transparency and democracy I wish to place on record that I abstained on this waiver. My reasoning is that, although the waiver is fair and reasonable, it probably is not in fact necessary. I do not want to tacitly accept that we have jurisdiction if we do not have it.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting immunity so that all the light could be shed in this case.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs, I voted in favour of waiving the immunity of Mr Gianluca Buonanno. This is a request concerning access by the investigating authority to the communications records of the honourable Member's mobile number for the date of 14 April 2015 alone. The proceedings relate to alleged telephone threats reported, as a victim, by the Member himself.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this request to waive my colleague ENL Buonanno's parliamentary immunity because it will shed light on the author of the telephone threats that the Italian Member has suffered.
