In order to find out who was threatening him, Mr. Buonanno initiated criminal proceedings at the Vercelli court; however, the prosecutor's office, in order to carry out his investigation, must be able to obtain data relating to the recordings of the number used by the MEP. It is therefore in his interest and that of justice that immunity is waived. This request is also in accordance with Article 68 of the Italian Constitution.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote Mr Buonanno's request to waive his parliamentary immunity, in order to allow the Italian authorities to investigate the serious threats against him by unknown persons.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. As the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which I supported, the Vercelli Ordinary Court Prosecutor's Office has requested authorisation from the European Parliament to obtain data from telephone companies relating to telephone records of a number used by Mr Gianluca Buonanno in connection with criminal proceedings brought before the Vercelli Ordinary Court on behalf of that Member and relating to the telephone threats he claims to have received from an anonymous communicator on his mobile phone on April 14, 2015. Although the Commission considers that it was not necessary for the Public Prosecutor's Office to seek authorisation to order the collection of data relating to the telephone traffic of Gianluca Buonanno, in the interests of legal certainty, it has recommended suspending Gianluca Buonanno's parliamentary immunity.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report because it has led Parliament to waive the immunity of Gianlucos Buonanno. The Deputy Prosecutor of the Court of Verchel sent a request for authorisation to apply to telephone service companies for information relating to telephone conversations used by Gianlucos Buonanno, a Member of the European Parliament elected in Italy, concerning criminal proceedings initiated on behalf of that member in the Vergel court for phone threats which he claimed to have received from anonymous on his mobile phone on 14 April 2015. in order to obtain, where appropriate, data relating to telephone conversations of a member of parliament, the competent authority should request authorisation from the houses of parliament of which that person is a member. Parliament's decision notes that, in his request for waiver of immunity, the Deputy Prosecutor of the Court of Verhel acknowledges that it is not clear whether this parliamentary privilege also applies in cases where a member of parliament is an alleged victim of a crime. However, it concludes that, nevertheless, the best interpretation of national legislation is that this privilege should apply to Members of Parliament regardless of their procedural situation.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. Gianluca Buonanno, an Italian member of the European Parliament, has launched criminal proceedings in the Vercelli court after being verbally threatened by an anonymous correspondent on his mobile phone. For the purposes of the investigation, the Crown prosecutor submitted an application for authorisation to obtain from the telephone companies the data relating to recordings for a number used by a European parliamentarian.  Although the lifting of his parliamentary immunity is not necessary to obtain this data, the rapporteur considers it appropriate to access it as a preventive measure in order to unmask and try the perpetrator of these threats.  I therefore voted in favour of lifting Gianluca Buonanno's parliamentary immunity.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Following telephone threats received from unknown persons, in order to acquire telephone records and identify the author of such telephone calls, we must vote in favour of waiving immunity. Vote.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this file, which concerns the waiver of immunity of an Italian MEP from the Lega Nord party. The MEP in question has not committed a crime in this case, but has been the subject of threatening phone calls. Under Italian Constitutional Law, the European Parliament must grant the waiver of his immunity before police can access his phone records, or acquire data concerning telephone traffic. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported with my vote mr Buonanno's request to waive his parliamentary immunity, in order to allow the Italian authorities to investigate the alleged threats against him by unknown persons.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (
text: PPE), in writing. \u2012 We support the report on the waiver of my colleague's immunity, bearing in mind that vercelli's Deputy Prosecutor of First Instance has submitted an application for authorisation in order to obtain data from telephone companies on conversations recorded by a telephone number used by Gianluca Buonanno.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 The request for waiver of immunity by Mr Gianluca Buonanno is the result of the investigation procedure carried out at his request, on the basis of his personal affairs and is aimed at the freedom of access to his personal data. As this procedure is not related to his parliamentary duties or his freedom of expression, I voted in favour.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ It should be noted that it is not for the European Parliament to interpret the domestic rules on the privileges and immunities of Members of Parliament; whereas it seems appropriate, however, to recall that the objective of Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union is primarily to safeguard the independence of Members by ensuring that pressure, in the form of threats of arrest or legal proceedings, is not brought to bear on them during the sessions of the European Parliament.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of waiving this immunity because it is procedural and not preliminary and is necessary in order to carry out the appropriate checks, requested by the same Member, to carry out checks by the national authorities on telephone threats received.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the lifting of Mr Buonanno's parliamentary immunity since it is necessary, under Italian law, for the Italian authorities to investigate his phone in order to clarify the threats he has received.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 After examining the proposal, I voted IN FAVOUR.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This report requests the removal of the parliamentary immunity for an MEP. As I have always done in these cases, I agree to the removal of immunity so that an MEP can prove his innocence or otherwise according to the judicial system of the relevant Member States.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. On 14 April 2015, Gianluca Buonanno, an Italian member of the European Parliament, was reportedly the victim of telephone threats received from an anonymous correspondent on his mobile phone number. Mr Buonanno then brought criminal proceedings before the Vercelli court. For the purposes of the investigation, the Crown prosecutor submitted an application for authorisation to obtain data from telephone operators on recordings for a number used by the MEP.  Although this request for waiver of immunity is not necessary, the report considers it appropriate, for reasons of legal certainty, to grant preventive access to Mr Buonanno's request to waive his immunity. So I voted for it.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I agree with the waiver of Mr. Buonanno so that the authorities could identify the criminals who were threatening his life by telephone.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote for: this request for the lifting of immunity will allow the perpetrator of the threats against Mr Buonanno to be unmasked and tried.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In this particular case, as provided in the report, Gianluca Bonano is not responsible for any type of criminal conduct or illegal act. He was the target of phone threats. He is a Member of the ENF Group. Italian Law No 140 of 20 June 2003, in Article 4 on immunities in Italy, states that, where records of calls and phone calls are to be obtained, the competent authority shall seek authorisation from the body in which the Member is elected. As such, the waiver of immunity is requested so that it is possible to investigate who is the perpetrator of the telephone threats.  We are dealing with a simple case in which there is no idea why they are obscing to the waiver of immunity.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The request to waive the immunity was submitted by the Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court of Vercelli. It seemed appropriate for the sake of legal certainty to accede ad cautelam to the request for authorisation forwarded by the Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court of Vercelli. I therefore supported the request to waive the immunity of Gianluca Buonanno.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 My fellow Member Gianluca Buonanno has opened criminal proceedings in Italy for allegedly receiving threatening calls to his mobile phone number from an unknown caller on 14 April 2015. The Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Vercell Court forwarded to the European Parliament a request for the investigating authority to have access to the traffic data of his mobile phone number for that day. I have adopted the decision to waive the immunity of my fellow Member in the interests of legal certainty.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. In order to find the perpetrator of the telephone threats made against my Italian parliamentary colleague Gianluca Buonnano, Vercelli's deputy prosecutor has requested the lifting of his parliamentary immunity, in order to obtain telephone records from the operators concerned. In accordance with the wishes of my colleague Gianluca Buonnano, I have therefore voted in favour of this request, which, I recall, is being brought in with the aim of finding the perpetrator of the threats and is not directed against Mr Buonnano.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons for the proposal to waive the immunity.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report on the waiver of the immunity of MEP Gianluca Buonanno.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the request to waive the right of immunity of Gianluca Buonanno MEP. For the sake of legal certainty and to ensure that the Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court of Vercelli investigates any manner of wrong-doing, I believe that a waiver of parliamentary immunity in this instance is justified.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this wavier due to its effects on the investigation.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a proposal for a decision by the European Parliament on a request to lift Gianluca Buonann's immunity because of telephone threats that Mr Buonanno himself received from an unknown caller. At issue is the investigative body's access to the records of telephone calls made by that Member, and the role of the European Parliament is not to interpret national rules on the privileges and immunies of Members of Parliament. Therefore, I support the waiver of immunity.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. This request for the lifting of immunity will allow the perpetrator of the threats against Mr. Buonanno to be unmasked and tried. I naturally voted in favour of the text.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The draft decision concerned the waiver of the immunity of Gianluca Buonanna MEP in order to facilitate the investigation of telephone threats reported by Buonanno himself to the police in the past. Parliament's recommendation is based on a request from Italian investigators, who are prohibited from examining a MEMBER's telephone records if he is protected by immunity. In view of the recommendations of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which did not find that this request was intended to prevent Members from doing so, I had no problem supporting the proposal, despite the fact that this is a rather unusual situation in which the alleged victim, not the defendant, is depriving himself of immunity.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report concerns the waiver of Mr Buonanno's parliamentary immunity. The waiver of immunity is in the interest of the member to give the investigating authority access to recordings from telephone conversations, since he received drohan calls. I agree with this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the request as I agree with the reasons for the proposal to waive the immunity.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the report on the lifting of Gianluca Buonanno's parliamentary immunity. On 14 April 2015, he was the victim of telephone threats received from an anonymous correspondent on his mobile phone number. Mr. Buonanno then initiated criminal proceedings. For the purposes of the investigation, the Vercelli court prosecutor submitted an application for authorisation to obtain data from telephone companies on recordings for a number used by an MEP. Access to telephone records, as in this case, is equated with wiretapping. As a precaution, the prosecutor of the Vercelli court preferred to extend parliamentary privilege also to cases where the Member is the alleged victim of a crime. The report considers that this request for waiver of immunity is not necessary to obtain access to data relating to Gianluca Buonanno's telephone communications, but in the interests of legal certainty, the report considers it appropriate to access Mr Buonanno's immunity as a preventive measure.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. This report is due to the request by the Vercelli Ordinary Court to obtain data from telephone companies relating to the Italian MEP Gianluca Buonanno, for a series of telephone threats that the latter has received anonymously.  Any Member of the European Parliament enjoys the immunities and privileges granted to him in his country of origin and, in the Constitution of the Italian Republic, they are granted immunity from personal registration.  However, a problem of interpretation arises in Italian law as there is no national case-law specifying whether this guarantee should apply to the alleged victim of a crime (as is the case in which we are) or to the perpetrator thereof.  In any event, the report calls for the suspension of Gianluca Buonanno's parliamentary immunity, since only in this way will his telephone register be accessible which will allow progress in the litigation process to progress and resolve this particular situation. For the same reason, I vote in favour of this report.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This report speaks of a request to lift the immunity of MEP Gianluca Buonann. Gianluca Buonannu's request for waiver of immunity refers to the investigative body's access to the mp's mobile phone number records for the date on which he claims to have received threatening phone calls.  It is not the duty of the European Parliament to interpret the national rules on the privileges and immunies of Members of Parliament, and in that case it appears that this Member is not under any pressure to influence him or her, as the procedure relates to alleged threats reported by the Member himself as a victim of telephone threats. For reasons of legal certainty, Parliament complied with the request for authorisation sent by the Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court in Vercelli ad cautelam and decided to lift Gianluca Buonann's immunity, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Last April, a Member of the European Parliament from Italy, Gianluca Buonanno, received a personal threat. Given that, according to the Deputy Prosecutor of the General Court of the City of Vercelli in Italy, it is partly possible for a qualitative criminal offence to be investigated only after the member's immunity has been waived in order to gain access to his telephone data (although this is not absolutely necessary), and the European Parliament today voted in favour of such a decision on the basis of the ad cautelam principle, I join my colleagues and also voted positively. It is all the long time that this case will be investigated as soon as possible and the perpetrators will receive appropriate punishment.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Parliament has agreed to waive the immunity of Italian MEP Gianluca Buonanna in connection with an investigation into phone threats received by this Member from an unknown person. Although there are certainly doubts as to whether it is necessary to waive parliamentary immunity even if a Member is a possible victim of a crime, in the interests of legal certainty and the removal of doubts, I agree that immunity should be waived.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on Gianluca Buonanno's request for waiver of parliamentary immunity, following the positive recommendation of the European Parliament's Committee on Legal Affairs.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted for this report. Gianluca Buonanno was allegedly the victim of anonymous telephone threats on 14 April 2015.  The Vercelli Court Prosecutor wishes to process the telephone recordings for the purposes of the investigation.  Access to these statements would be like wiretapping. However, the status of MEPs and Article 68 of the Italian constitution condition any wiretap of an MEP to obtain prior authorisation from the relevant parliamentary chamber. The report therefore calls for the lifting of Gianluca Buonanno's parliamentary immunity. This procedure is probably an excessive legal rigorism since Gianluca Buonanno is the complainant in this case. This reservation will not prevent us from granting this request necessary for the progress of the investigation.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I expressed my opinion against the request for the waiver of the immunity of Mr Gianluca Buonanno because I believe that parliamentary immunity is not a personal privilege of a Member but a guarantee of the independence of Parliament and its Members as a super partes institution. I remain convinced that a guarantee line must be followed in these cases, so I will continue to vote against this type of report in defence of the institutional role conferred by this Parliament.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about waiving the immunity of MEP Gianluca Buonanno. He did not commit a crime. This is simply a matter of clarifying the drohan calls made to him. That is why I support this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In order to enable Italian law enforcement to investigate possible criminal activity, it is necessary to waive the legal immunity of a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The request to waive immunity follows threats made by telephone against Gianluca Buonanno. This procedure should enable the anonymous perpetrator of these acts to be identified by using wiretaps. The rapporteur considered it unnecessary to give rise to the removal of the parliamentarian's immunity, but as a legal precaution, he proposed to follow up on the request. As a result, I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The defence of the independence of the Mandate of the European Parliament is the responsibility of the European Parliament and that independence cannot be called into question. In accordance with Article 8 of the Protocol on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union, members of the European Parliament may not be sought, detained or persecuted for the opinions or votes cast in the performance of their duties.  In this case, the Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court of Vercelli submitted an application for authorisation for the acquisition of data from telephone companies relating to telephone call records to the number used by a Member of the European Parliament elected by Italy, namely Gianluca Buonanno, in criminal proceedings brought before the Vercelli Common Court on behalf of that Member in relation to telephone threats which he allegedly received on 14 April 2015 from an unknown to your mobile phone number.  Since this type of request would not be necessary in this case, I would vote in favour of the waiver of parliamentary immunity.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the request for waiver of immunity of Gianluca Buonanno, for the sake of bringing legal certainty to the request for authorisation forwarded by the Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court of Vercelli;

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court of Vercell requested permission to obtain traffic data from telephone companies of one of the telephone numbers used by Gianluca Buonanno, an MEP elected in Italy. The MP claims that on April 14, 2015, he received threatening calls to his mobile phone number from an unknown caller, and that the data needed to be obtained for the criminal proceedings brought as a result. According to the Deputy Public Prosecutor, it is also not clear whether the parliamentary privilege of obtaining a Member's telephone registration data requires Parliament's permission also applies to cases where a Member of Parliament is a suspected victim of a criminal offence, but nevertheless considers that, according to the most appropriate interpretation of the legislation, that privilege is granted to members of Parliament irrespective of their procedural status. In its report, the Committee on Legal Affairs takes the position that, for the sake of legal certainty, it seems appropriate to accept this interpretation as a precaution and to comply with the request of the Deputy Public Prosecutor, and therefore proposes that Parliament suspend the immunity of Gianluca Buonanno in the case in question. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Whereas Gianluca Buonanno's request for waiver of immunity concerns access by the responsible authority to the recording of telephone calls received by that Member's mobile telephone number on the date on which he claims to have received telephone calls on which threats were made, I am voting in favour of this report which raises Mr. Deputy's immunity, and the authorities responsible may therefore investigate any existing infringements.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This request for the lifting of immunity will allow the perpetrator of the threats against Mr Buonanno to be unmasked and tried, so there is no reason to object.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this request to waive immunity. This request was made by the Member concerned himself so that he could act in a judicial proceeding. It was also supported by the competent committee of the European Parliament, whose recommendation I followed.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the request for the waivey of gianluca buonanno's immunity. The MEP was threatened via his mobile phone in April 2015, and the court in Vercell, Italy, asked for the immunity of the MEP to be waived in connection with the criminal proceedings, since the request for the necessary traffic data from the telephone company is possible only with the waive of immunity.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report according to the evaluation made by the JURI Committee.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The case concerns the waiver of the immunity of Gianluca Buonanno from the ENF. In this case though, he has not committed a crime though but was subject of threatening phone calls. According to Italian Constitutional law however, the waiver of his immunity is needed before the police can access his phone records or acquire data concerning his telephone traffic. Therefore, I voted in favour of this waiver.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The topic is the waiver of the immunity of MEP Gianluca Buonanno for the clarification of drohan calls made to him, mainly in April 2015. The aim is to obtain the data requested by the Deputy Prosecutor of the Vercelli Court concerning telephone connections from telephone companies via a telephone number used by the member. This is a waiver of immunity that is necessary for clarification.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 On Mrs Regner's proposal, I thought it appropriate to vote in favour. In view of the provisions of Article 9 of Protocol 7 on the privileges and immunities of the European Union and as laid down in the Italian Constitution in Article 68, the request for authorisation by the Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court of Vercelli to acquire Mr Buonanno's telephone records goes in the direction of preserving the independence of a Member of the European Parliament and preventing him from being the victim of any kind of pressure or threat.  I therefore voted in favour.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ Since Gianluca Buonannu's request for waiver of immunity relates to the investigative body's access to the records of telephone calls to that Representative's mobile phone number for the date on which he claims to have received threatening phone calls; whereas, in its request for the waiver of the immunity of the Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court of Vercelli, he acknowledges that it is not clear whether this parliamentary privilege should also apply to cases where a Member of Parliament is an alleged victim of a crime; whereas it concludes that despite the best interpretation of national legislation, this privilege should apply to Members of Parliament regardless of their procedural role; whereas, however, it does not list any cases of national case law to support its conclusion; whereas, notwithstanding this for the sake of legal certainty, it seems appropriate to comply with the request for authorisation submitted by the Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court in Vercelli ad cautelam, I agree with the recommendation of the Committee for the Waiver of immunity to my colleague Buonann.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The elements make it possible to determine Gianluca Buonanno is not responsible for any type of criminal conduct or illegal act. He's been the target of phone threats and wants his investigation to be carried out. Italian Law No 140 of 20 June 2003, article 4 on immunities in Italy, states that, where records of calls and phone calls are to be obtained, the competent authority shall seek authorisation from the body in which the Member of Parliament is elected. As such, the waiver of immunity is requested so that it is possible to investigate who is the perpetrator of the telephone threats.  We voted for it.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. We were called upon to vote on the lifting of Gianluca Buonanno's parliamentary immunity. Following the advice of the European Parliament's Legal Affairs Committee, and Mr Buonanno himself in favour of lifting this immunity so that the Italian authorities could investigate it in his favour, I agreed to this waiver of immunity.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Gianluca Buonanno. The request was made in the context of a court case, in which a magistrate of the Italian public prosecutor's office requested, from a telephone company, the record of calls to the number used by that Member of the European Parliament, who had allegedly been the victim of telephone threats.   Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union provides that Members of the European Parliament enjoy the immunities granted to Members of their national parliaments. At the same time, Article 68 of the Italian Constitution stresses that no Member may be subject to a personal inspection. According to the report, Article 9 of Protocol No 7 is inapplicable to the present case, since this standard is intended only to ensure the independence of Members by preventing pressure from being exerted on them during parliamentary sessions. The report stresses, however, that it is not for the European Parliament to interpret national rules on the privileges and immunities of Members.  Thus, considering that the precautionary response in the report is appropriate to the protection of the status of Members of the European Parliament, without obstructing the action of the Italian judicial system, I am voting in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The judicial procedure does not concern opinions or actions in the performance of the duties of Gianlucca Buonanno as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. As the report of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which I supported, the Vercelli Ordinary Court Prosecutor's Office has requested authorisation from the European Parliament to obtain data from telephone companies relating to telephone records of a number used by Mr Gianluca Buonanno in connection with criminal proceedings brought before the Vercelli Ordinary Court on behalf of that Member and relating to the telephone threats he claims to have received from an anonymous communicator on his mobile phone on April 14, 2015. Although the Commission considers that it was not necessary for the Public Prosecutor's Office to seek authorisation to order the collection of data relating to the telephone traffic of Gianluca Buonanno, in the interests of legal certainty, it has recommended suspending Gianluca Buonanno's parliamentary immunity.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the lifting of Mr Gianluca Buonanno's immunity, so that the Italian justice system could have all the necessary documents to carry out its work, with strict respect for the rights of the defence, on the understanding that the investigation has no direct link with Mr Buonanno's office as an MEP, and is not motivated by any desire to harm.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 This issue does not in principle merit a debate – colleague Gianluca Buonanno, according to him, has received phone threats. In order to investigate these threats, it is necessary to ensure that the investigating authority has access to the mobile phone conversation tile of the member on the day on which he claims to have received threatening calls. The best we can do, therefore, is to give Italian law enforcement the opportunity to carry out an investigation, revoking the legal immunity of our colleague.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report concerns the request for the waiver of the parliamentary immunity of Mr Buonanno. This is a request made by the Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Vercelli Ordinary Court concerning the records of telephone calls to the mobile phone number used by Gianluca Buonanno concerning criminal proceedings brought before the Vercelli Common Court, in which the MEP states that he received telephone threats from an unknown person to that telephone number on 14 April 2015. As described in the report, in accordance with Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union - which consists of ensuring the independence of MEPs by preventing pressure stemming from threats of detention or prosecution stemming from them during the sessions of the European Parliament - I consider that in this case there is no doubt that the colleague in question is not the subject of the pressure described above - I consider that in this case there is no doubt that the colleague in question is not the subject of the pressure described above , in so far as the case concerns alleged threats reported by the MEP himself as a victim of these telephone threats. That is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. In order to be a member of the European Union, you have to have a rule of law. That is why we must trust that the rule of law can assess when a Member of the European Parliament has violated national law and thus must have his immunity waived. That is why I support the repeal.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for the lifting of Mr Buonanno's parliamentary immunity, since it is necessary, under Italian law, for the Italian authorities to be able to investigate his phone in order to clarify the threats he has received.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ Abstain on this as it is within the sovereign authority of Italy to resolve this issue.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the motion for a resolution on the waiver of Gianluca Buonanna's parliamentary immunity, as it is necessary to examine the context of the appointee in criminal proceedings. Pursuant to Article 68 of the Constitution of the Italian Republic, it is provided that, without the consent of the competent Chamber of Parliament, no Member of Parliament may be subjected to personal or house searches, be detained or otherwise deprived of liberty or taken into custody. Consent is also required for the purpose of monitoring a Member's calls and communication or for withholding his correspondence. The request to waive the immunity of MEP Gianluca Buonanna relates to the access of investigative bodies to the recordings of phone calls from the MEMBER's mobile number from the day during which he claimed to have received threatening phone calls. It was necessary to waive his immunity so that italy's investigative authorities would confirm or refute suspicions as to whether the MEMBER was the victim of phone threats.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court in Vercelli has applied for authorisation to obtain telephone company data on the telephone documentation for the number used by Gianluca Buonanno, A Member of the European Parliament elected in Italy, in connection with a criminal procedure brought before the Vercelli Ordinary Court on behest, relating to telephone threats he claims to have received from an unknown caller on his mobile phone number on 14 April 2015.  Since the case in question does not appear to be pressured to influence the Member concerned, as the procedure relates to alleged threats reported by the MEP himself as a victim of telephone threats, I supported the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We agree with the waiver of Mr. Buonanno so that the authorities could identify the criminals who were threatening his life by telephone.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of lifting this individual's immunity so that he could explain himself to these multiple misdeeds, of which he is once again the perpetrator, before the courts of his country.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of requesting a waiver of immunity for the Member of Parliament Gianluca Buonanno, to facilitate the inquiry in connection with criminal proceedings initiated before the Ordinary Court of Vercelli on behalf of Mr Buonanno himself, in relation to telephone threats he claims to have received from an unknown caller on his mobile telephone number in April 2015. A waiver will thus grant the access by the investigating authority to the phone call records of the Member’s mobile telephone number on the date on which he claims to have received threatening telephone calls.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒The request to lift representative Gianluca Buonanno's immunity refers to the investigative body's access to the mp's mobile phone number records for the date on which he claims to have received threatening calls. It is undeniable that no pressure is being put in this case to influence it, as the proceedings relate to alleged threats reported by the MP himself as a victim of telephone threats. Therefore, for the sake of legal certainty, I consider it appropriate to comply with the application for authorisation submitted by the Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court in Vercelli, and I voted to lift the immunity of Italian Representative Gianluca Buonanno.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal for a European Parliament decision on the request for waiver of gianluca Buonan's immunity. From the circumstances of the case, it appears that the offence or acts committed by the MEP is unrelated to his position as a Member of the European Parliament.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. On 14 April 2015, Gianluca Buonanno was reportedly the victim of telephone threats received from an anonymous correspondent on his mobile phone number. Mr Buonanno then brought criminal proceedings before the Vercelli court. For the purposes of the investigation, the Vercelli court prosecutor submitted an application for authorisation to obtain data from telephone companies on recordings for a number used by an MEP. This request for the lifting of immunity will allow the perpetrator of the threats against Mr. Buonanno to be unmasked and tried. I'm voting for.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Deputy Public Prosecutor of the Ordinary Court of Vercell forwarded a request to authorise the purchase of traffic data from telephone companies from telephone companies in connection with a criminal proceedings by a Gianluca Buonanno MEP elected in Italy because he claimed to have received threatening calls to his mobile phone number from an unknown caller. The request for waived immunity is in order to gain access to the traffic data of the member's mobile phone number on the day the member allegedly received threatening calls. I supported him.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the pleading for the suspension of immunity as proposed by the JURI Commission. We understand that there is no possibility of using suspension to initiate political prosecution.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the suspension of Gianluca Buonanno's parliamentary immunity.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the request for waiver of the immunity of Gianluca Buonanno in connection with criminal proceedings initiated before the Ordinary Court of Vercelli on behalf of Gianluca Buonanno in relation to telephone threats he claims to have received from an unknown caller on his mobile telephone number on 14 April 2015. Although it is not for the European Parliament to interpret the domestic rules on the privileges and immunities of Members of Parliament, it seems appropriate to recall that the objective of Article 9 of Protocol No 7 on the Privileges and Immunities of the European Union is primarily to safeguard the independence of Members by ensuring that pressure is not brought to bear on them during the sessions of the European Parliament. Nevertheless, in this case it unquestionably appears that no pressure has been brought to bear on the Member concerned, since the proceedings relate to alleged threats reported by the Member himself as the victim.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of the removal of my colleagues' immunity in order to assist him in the criminal case he brought against an anonymous caller.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 Apparently Gianluca Buonanno is not responsible for any kind of criminal conduct or illegal act. He was the target of phone threats. He is an ENF Member. Italian Law No 140 of 20 June 2003, in Article 4 on immunities in Italy, states that, where records of calls and phone calls are to be obtained, the competent authority shall seek authorisation from the body in which the Member of Parliament is elected. As such, the waiver of immunity is requested so that it is possible to investigate who is the perpetrator of the telephone threats.  In this case, this is a simple case in which immunity should be lifted, we are voting in favour.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This is the waiver of MEP Gianluca Buonanno's immunity in April 2015 to investigate drohan calls made to him. The purpose of the repeal is to obtain the requested data from telephone companies regarding telephone connections via a telephone number used by the member. This is a waiver of immunity that is necessary for clarification.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the report on the waiver of Gianluci Buonan's parliamentary immunity. There are reasonable grounds for granting immunity with a view to certain investigative acts relating to criminal proceedings brought on behalf of the Member before the Ordinary Court of Vercelli in connection with telephone threats allegedly received on his mobile phone by a Member on 14 April 2015 from an unknown caller .

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur A couple of years ago, at the on time of the migrant crisis, Sweden received more than 170 000 applications from migrants or refugees arriving in the country. And last year, this meant that in Sweden, there were already 11,503 applicants for the status in question. Highest score in the world! Not only in Scandinavia, not only in the European Union, but in the world. And, in accordance with the rules submitted under the European Union, through Council decisions, etc., Sweden should receive 1369 and 4358 persons from Italy and Greece. And today's proposal would remove this need for only one calendar year. There's that misfortune. But given how many migrants, refugees have already arrived in Sweden, quite in fact, this country has fully realised its responsibilities.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, I too support Sweden's request, made last December, to suspend, for twelve months, the obligation to receive refugee quotas, as agreed by the Council. Sweden took in more than 160,000 refugees in 2015 alone and this situation has put colossal pressure on the Swedish asylum system, obviously with negative consequences on the ability to process the demands of those seeking international protection. Moreover, all Member States must be able to trigger defence mechanisms when faced with emergencies, as it is in this case, when there are a very large number of asylum seekers and the authorities cannot cope.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I am very pleased that Parliament has voted, by a large majority, to support Sweden in its reception of refugees by providing a temporary one-year break for relocation programmes from Greece and Italy. As head of the PPE Group, I have fought to show that Sweden too is under disproportionate pressure and has become the first host country and also the end destination country. What our municipalities and our migration agency are showing and saying is that it is an emergency, and then you just have to give a temporary pause in order to be able to provide a functional, long-term and sustainable opportunity to continue to receive refugees in a dignified way, in a humane way. Sweden will continue to be a country that receives people on the run. Sweden should continue to be a safe haven for people who need support, but it is time that other countries also take part in the responsibility. It is time for other countries to fully implement the relocation programme. All 28 countries.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Given the worrying humanitarian emergency that has long affected Europe, last September the relocation of 160 thousand refugees was ordered, to be allocated among the Member States, thus trying to reduce the pressure exerted on strategic countries such as Italy and Greece. In view of this act of solidarity, Sweden has, after a few months, called for its obligations to be suspended, on the grounds of the emergency situation that such a number of citizens would have unleashed in sweden. In view of the importance of a collective commitment, I voted against.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I objected to this report on the Council's proposed decision establishing interim measures on international protection for Sweden. This text introduces provisional measures for international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece.  After taking in more than 170,000 asylum seekers in the space of a month, Sweden has formally called for the suspension of its obligations to distribute migrants within the European Union, while the Swedish government has systematically encouraged and facilitated mass immigration.  While I am obviously opposed to the distribution of migrants in the European Union, a system that does not work and seriously undermines the sovereignty of the Member States, I am opposed to other states such as France taking care of migrants that Sweden is no longer able to take in.  The only way to find a lasting solution to this crisis is to let the nations manage their migration policy and establish humanitarian camps with the Gulf monarchies in the areas from which these migrants leave.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ This proposal would see Sweden negate its obligations in relation to the refugee relocation programme. In the initial report Sweden was essentially requesting to be treated like Italy and Greece and to have refugees relocated out of Sweden. This report however seeks to simply suspend Sweden’s obligations to the relocation agreement. Given the worsening situation in the Mediterranean, the deterioration of conditions in detention/reception centres across Europe and the onset of summer, now is not the time for any nation to shirk its responsibilities to address the refugee crisis. The rapporteur and GUE/NGL have tabled a rejection amendment on that basis. We have consistently called for everyone to play their part in this crisis, and therefore I tabled a negative vote.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The Council has introduced interim measures on international protection for Sweden, as it has formally requested the suspension of its obligations because of the dual challenge it faces, that of first-arrival and final destination countries; whereas in March 2016, Sweden took in a total of 170,104 asylum seekers, including 73,331 children, including 36,181 unaccompanied minors, who have special needs and require additional resources for access to health care, dignified housing and education, in accordance with EU asylum rules. We have always opposed the EU's policy of distributing migrants. It does not work, and it is contrary to the principle of the sovereignty of nations. There is no point in introducing temporary measures to address the problems of the common asylum and immigration policy. Member States must be empowered to develop their own policies in this area. I obviously voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This is a legislative report that highlights the economic and social problems Sweden is facing as a result of the migrant crisis. Sweden wants to suspend its obligation as part of the EU to accept migrants for a period of one year. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This report recognises that Sweden has had a higher number of refugees per capita than any other EU nation. This vote allows Sweden to suspend its right to take refugees in for a year. UKIP voted for this proposal to give Sweden the opportunity to adjust to this demand. We also do not believe it should be in the EU’s remit to decide over Member States how many migrants should be repatriated to specific Member States.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported the one-year exemption that the European Commission is proposing to grant Sweden in the area of relocating asylum seekers. It should be noted that Sweden has the most asylum seekers per capita in the EU. As of March 2016, it housed more than 170,000 applicants, including 36,000 unaccompanied minors. It is therefore legitimate to grant this exemption at a time when some Member States remain extremely wary of taking in migrants and implementing the relocation process.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The latest data confirm that in 2015 Sweden was the EU country with the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita, with an increase in applications of 60 % compared to 2014. In March there were more than 170 000 applicants for protection.  I have decided to support the Keller report on temporary measures in the field of international protection for Sweden, because I believe it is important to support the Scandinavian country. At this time of extraordinary influx of third-country nationals into its territory, Sweden finds itself not only the country of first arrival but also the final destination. The text voted specifically endorses the Council's position allowing the activation of Article 9 of Council Decision (EU) 2015/1523, thus allowing for the suspension for one year of the reallocation obligations provided for in Council Decisions (EU) 2015/1523 and (EU) 2015/1601.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Report on provisional measures at the international level for the benefit of Sweden. This is a proposal for an amendment to a Council decision adopted in 2015, which lays down provisional measures for the benefit of Member States in an emergency situation characterised by a massive influx of third-country nationals in one or more Member States, also known as "temporary scheme relocation". This amendment to the relocation scheme was submitted by the Commission in December, following the Swedish Government's requirement to benefit from this relocation scheme. The original request of the Swedish Government in November was to benefit from this mechanism such as Greece and Italy. However, this request was rejected by the Commission, which, on the contrary, agreed with the one-year suspension for the "obligation" to relocate those applying to Sweden (1369 people).

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work and effort to carry out this report. I voted in favour of the Greens' amendment, which called for the European Commission's proposal to exempt Sweden one year from its obligation to take in refugees from Greece and Italy under the relocation programme of 160,00 people approved last year, of whom 3,766 were to go to Sweden. I therefore voted against the European Parliament's report in the final vote. Sweden has made great efforts, but I do not agree with the precautionary suspensions of measures adopted among all in relation to the distribution of refugees.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I rejected not only the Commission's proposal, the LIBE report, but also the amendments tabled on this report and the rejection amendment. The latter was also part of an infamous attempt by the left to force all Member States, regardless of their particular situation, to respect the eu's migrant quotas without the possibility of interim measures. However, Sweden has already taken in a total of 170,104 asylum seekers, including 73,331 children, including 36,181 unaccompanied minors, who obviously require special measures and require additional resources, such as access to health care. The motion of rejection of the left proves once again that, behind its so-called "humanism", hide a cold logic and a desire for mass immigration outside of any principle of reality. That said, the Commission's proposal is also unsatisfactory as it would only "move" the problem, since it plans to "relocate" these migrants to another Member State. This is further proof that the EU's handling of the migration crisis is disastrous and has the most serious consequences, both for the migrants themselves and for the Member States.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report we are voting on has some unclear passages which I do not entirely agree with. I have therefore chosen to abstain.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament discusses in Sweden the emergency situation caused by the sudden influx of third-country nationals into its territory. The significant increase in the number of irregular border crossings to the European Union and secondary movement in Europe have led to a significant increase in the number of applicants for international protection in Sweden. Sweden recorded the highest per capita number of applicants for international protection in the EU in 2015 (11 503 applicants per million population); by March 2016. a total of 170,104 applicants arrived in Sweden, of which 73,331 are children, including 36,181 unsleaved minors. Thus, in Sweden, the situation has become difficult, even as a result of the recent significant increase in the number of unaccompanied minors (one in four applicants claim to be an unaccompanied minor). The situation described has made the Swedish asylum system very difficult and has had serious practical consequences with regard to reception conditions and the possibilities of the asylum system to examine applications. The current migration situation in Sweden is therefore special in the European Union and, given the pressure on its ability to examine applications for international protection and to provide appropriate reception conditions for persons in clear need of international protection, it is necessary to suspend sweden's obligations under the resettlement mechanism and, where appropriate, to provide operational assistance.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As a member of the Hungarian Delegation to the People's Party, I supported sweden's exemption in accordance with Article 9 of the Decision on transitional measures in the field of international protection for Italy and Greece, because this exemption proves that the transitional measures adopted in the original decision, the mandatory distribution of quotas to migrants, are not suitable for dealing with the problem. The system established in the decision is inoperable, migrants reach countries that pay higher social care fees, e.g. sweden, irrespective of the allocation by quota. To date, it has not been possible to distribute more than a few hundred migrants instead of the tens of thousands targeted because of the shortcomings of the system, so these transitional measures should be suspended as soon as possible and all Member States should be exempted from the mandatory allocation mechanism according to quotas.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the introduction of temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Sweden and Italy and Greece. These are the urgent measures needed to deal with the current refugee-migrant crisis and to protect European citizens. Sweden is facing an emergency situation due to the sudden increase in the number of third-country nationals entering its territory. In 2015, sweden had by far the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita in the EU (11,503 applicants per million inhabitants). By March 2016, Sweden had taken a total of 170,104 asylum seekers, of which 73,331 children.  Even for an open society such as Sweden, such figures are far too high, so the adoption of temporary measures in the field of international protection is necessary.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. I am opposed to the EU's policy of distributing migrants. It does not work, and it is contrary to the principle of the sovereignty of nations. There is no point in introducing temporary measures to address the problems of the common asylum and immigration policy. Member States must be empowered to develop their own policies in this area. I voted against the motion to reject it because the signatories are in fact demanding that all Member States comply with EU-imposed migrant quotas, without provisional measures. I also voted against the motion for a resolution which supports the Commission's motion.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that Sweden, as the country most affected by the migration crisis, should be supported by the EU institutions and other Member States as evidence of the solidarity that should be felt between the members of this Union.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We believe that sweden, as well as any European country, needs to act fairly and cohesively in the protection of refugees and in the management of migrant flows. Each state must play its part: the challenge facing us today is difficult for a single country, but it is easily tackled by the Union as a whole. The citizens of Europe have the capacity and the resources to overcome the difficulties that the historic moment presents us with.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. After taking in more than 170,000 asylum seekers in the space of a month, Sweden has formally requested the suspension of its obligations to distribute migrants within the European Union. The Swedish government is literally overwhelmed by the massive influx of migrants and is suffering the consequences of its lax migration policy. Since the beginning of the war in Syria, Sweden has always encouraged and facilitated the arrival of these illegal migrants. I objected to this request insofar as the other Member States of the European Union, such as France, will have to take care of migrants that Sweden can no longer take in. It is time to find a lasting solution to this migration crisis by co-financing with the Gulf monarchies the construction of humanitarian camps in the countries from which these migrants originate. So I voted against it.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Against the background of the migrant crisis, Sweden faces a high influx of third-country nationals into its territory, thus calling for the suspension of its obligations under Council Decisions (EU) 2015/1523 and (EU) 2015/1601. In 2015, Sweden had the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita in the EU (11,503 applicants per million inhabitants), and in March 2016 it received a total of 170,104 applicants, including 73,331 children and 36,181 unaccompanied minors. Also, one in four applicants are unaccompanied minors with special needs, which requires a greater amount of financial resources to ensure their access to healthcare, decent housing and education, in line with EU asylum rules. This difficult situation facing Sweden, both the country of initial arrival and the final destination, justifies taking provisional measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Sweden, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of this report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Abstention vote. Sweden, after years of prior class (by EU standards) in the field of immigrant reception, has changed its policy (thanks to the success at home of the parties opposing this policy) deciding to completely reverse the course of the past and thus complaining about the massive influx of third-country nationals into its territory due to the sharp shift in migratory flows (remember the announcement of the plan to repatriate 80 000 asylum seekers). On 8 December 2015, the Swedish Government formally requested the suspension of its obligations under Council Decisions (EU) 2015/1523 and (EU) 2015/1601, as it faces the dual challenge of being both a country of first arrival and a final destination. Sweden has therefore requested measures for relocations and resettlements similar to those adopted for Italy and Greece (although in fact they have proved to be completely useless). There is, however, a fundamental difference, namely the geographical difference, between the two Mediterranean countries and the Scandinavian country. We therefore recommend a vote of abstention because we understand, given the numbers, Sweden's demands, but we cannot fully support them because these numbers are the result of a myopic policy implemented to date in the field of immigration.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe it is right to support Sweden in dealing with the difficult emergency situation caused by the sudden flow of third-country nationals. Sweden in 2015 was certainly the EU country with the largest number of applicants for international protection per capita. The situation in Sweden has also become even more complicated as a result of the significant increase in the number of unaccompanied minors. In March 2016, Sweden accepted 170 104 applicants, including 36 181 unaccompanied minors. The latter, as you know, have very special needs, so additional resources are needed to ensure that they have access to health care, decent housing and education. The peculiarity of the Swedish case is the dual nature of the challenge: the country in question is both the choice for the first arrival and the final destination. The issue of refugees or migrants should not, however, be addressed solely as a purely humanitarian issue: it is a global issue and must be addressed with appropriate means and policies if we are to continue to ensure international stability. There are major threats, risks and fragility, so we must remain vigilant and tackle these issues in practice.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this proposal which sought to relieve Sweden of its obligations in relation to the refugee relocation programme adopted in 2015. Although I recognise that Sweden has already done a lot to give refuge to those feeling danger, given the worsening situation in the Mediterranean, the worsening of conditions in detention/reception centres across Europe and the onset of summer, now is not the time for any nation to shirk its responsibilities to address the refugee crisis. Sinn Féin calls on all countries, including Ireland, to play their part in this crisis. For these reasons, I voted against the proposal.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report recognises that Sweden has had a higher number of refugees per capita than any other EU nation. This vote allows Sweden to suspend its right to take refugees in for a year. UKIP voted for this proposal to give Sweden the opportunity to adjust to this demand. We also do not believe it should be in the EU’s remit to decide over Member States how many migrants should be repatriated to specific Member States.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I believe that Sweden should be allowed to suspend its obligation of relocation for one year. Sweden has already accepted an enormous number of asylum seekers and the situation is already very difficult for the country and its asylum system. I would like to take this opportunity to praise Sweden for its efforts in alleviating the current refugee crisis.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against Sweden's request to suspend its obligations under the Council decisions of last September on the relocation of 160 000 refugees from Italy and Greece. The adoption of this proposal would in fact set a dangerous precedent for the functioning of the refugee relocation mechanism for the benefit of Italy and Greece, which is already experiencing considerable delays due to the lack of political will on the part of some Member States to comply with the obligations taken in the Council.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Swedish Government's request to the European Commission to temporarily suspend the reception of migrants stems from the country's need to reorganise itself in order to develop measures to deal with the growing and continuous request for asylum.  In 2015, Sweden was the EU country with the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita (11 503 applicants per million inhabitants). In the first quarter of this year alone, it accepted 170 104 applicants, of whom 73 331 were minors, including 36 181 unaccompanied minors.  The request is essentially based on the real and concrete need to find suitable solutions for refugees and to provide facilities and services to offer those arriving in Sweden living conditions equal to those enjoyed by the citizens of the same country. The high number of children, especially unaccompanied children, has led to the need to strengthen health care, access to education and the creation of decent housing that can accommodate particularly vulnerable people. I voted in favour of the Swedish request to give a country that has never shirked its responsibilities in the face of migration time to plan reception systems for immigrants and thus guarantee them the best possible living conditions.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. Europe faces a huge humanitarian challenge with the current refugee crisis. Common European solutions are part of the solution to the crisis. Part of the concrete European solutions that are in place right now are the so-called 'temporary relocation scheme'. The scheme means that Italy and Greece will have to relieve some 160,000 refugees. The refugees are distributed to the other Member States according to a quota allocation. Sweden is one of the countries to take in more refugees. However, Sweden is also one of the countries that have already taken the most refugees per capita. That is why we understand that Sweden will be suspended from temporary relocation for one year. Member States must be able to keep up.  Denmark has and will continue to have a clear exception in the area of refugee and asylum policy. The Danish exception is also clear in the adopted text. That is why we support the report. At the same time, with our support, we are showing that we will not stand in the way of the wishes of the other Member States for common European solutions to concrete problems. Just as we note with satisfaction that the other Member States , with the explicit reference to the Danish exception, fully respect Denmark's position.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the draft legislative resolution, as the emergency situation in Sweden needs to be addressed due to a sudden influx of third-country nationals into its territory due to the marked shift in migration flows.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on the proposal for a Council Decision establishing provisional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Sweden is a request for support to the country concerned, given the burden it has had to bear on the refugee issue.  I believe that although certain countries in Europe have accepted a large number of refugees, there are several more steps to be taken and that individual favourable treatment is not an appropriate way of resolving the issues.  I therefore voted against it.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because it represents the right political message in the face of the increasingly important phenomenon of immigration. In particular, this document attempts to help Sweden, which, according to the data, has been faced with an emergency situation characterised by a sudden flow of third-country nationals into its territory (Sweden had by far the largest number of applicants for international protection per capita in 2015).  With my vote, I wanted to support the Commission's proposal for greater operational and economic support. Furthermore, I hope that this vote will also lead to a more cooperative attitude towards the border countries, primarily my own, which are at the forefront of tackling immigration and supporting its costs.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Sweden faces an emergency situation characterised by a sudden inflow of nationals of third countries in its territory. The considerable increase of irregular border crossing into the EU and of secondary movements across Europe has led to a sharp increase in Sweden of the number of applicants for international protection.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report recognises that Sweden has had a higher number of refugees per capita than any other EU nation. This vote allows Sweden to suspend its right to take refugees in for a year. UKIP voted for this proposal to give Sweden the opportunity to adjust to this demand. We also do not believe it should be in the EU’s remit to decide over Member States how many migrants should be repatriated to specific Member States.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – This report recognises that Sweden has had a higher number of refugees per capita than any other EU nation. This vote allows Sweden to suspend its right to take refugees in for a year. UKIP voted for this proposal to give Sweden the opportunity to adjust to this demand. We also do not believe it should be in the EU’s remit to decide over Member States how many migrants should be repatriated to specific Member States.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of temporary international protection measures, as Sweden is among the European countries that have made a major contribution to the reception of refugees from third countries. Sweden should be given the conditions to ensure a decent and humane reception of refugees, giving it a time to efficiently reorganise the management of migrants. I also believe that all European countries should offer their practical help in the reception and management of refugees, while respecting relocation policies.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Sweden has in 2015 by far the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita and the large sudden inflow of migrants has put a significant strain on country’s asylum system. I support the Commission proposal as amended by the vote in committee, since I believe a provisional suspension will help Sweden ease the pressure now and be better coping with such emergency situation in future.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2015, a number of measures were adopted for countries in difficult situations, osrising in the number of migrants and asylum seekers, known as the relocation mechanism. Greece and Italy have so far been welcomed to this mechanism. Sweden is the country with the highest number of asylum seekers per capita, and has so far been an example of good practice in this field. However, the current social democratic government wanted to take these measures, an exercise in insolidarity given its economic situation. The proposal that the Commission has sent to Parliament is not the original relocation but of halicking Sweden's obligations in the relocation system. We voted against this proposal, because there is now a situation of enormous gravity in the main points of arrival in the EU, where migrants and asylum seekers are surviving in conditions of extreme precariousness. To alleviate this situation, the solidarity of all the Member States is necessary, and we cannot allow such exceptions.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sweden has long been confronted with the arrival of large flows of migrants that often make this country not only a destination of first arrival, but also their final destination. In 2015, Sweden was the Member State with the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita (11 503 applicants per million inhabitants).  I therefore voted in favour of this resolution to include in the proposal for a Council decision a number of amendments that take account of the specific situation in Sweden, in particular with regard to the large number of unaccompanied minors, which provides for specific and essential needs with regard to access to education, healthy housing and health care.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As part of the Common Asylum Policy, the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union provides a concrete legal basis for dealing with emergencies. The transitional measures envisaged by the TMS are of an exceptional nature. They may only be applied if the urgency and seriousness of the problems caused by the sudden influx of third-country nationals in the asylum system of a Member State or Member State reaches a certain degree. By letter dated 8 December 2015, Sweden formally requested the suspension of its obligations. Eurostat data confirmed that the number of asylum seekers in Sweden has increased sharply, from 1 January to 31 October 2015 by more than 60 % compared to 2014 to 112 040. Moreover, the monthly number of applicants for international protection has increased even further recently. This exemption demonstrates that the transitional measures adopted in the original decision, the mandatory distribution of quotas to migrants, are not suitable for dealing with the problem. The system established in the Decision is inoperable, with migrants reaching countries paying higher social care charges, such as Sweden, regardless of the allocation by quota. This shows that transitional measures should be suspended as soon as possible and that all Member States should be exempted from the mandatory allocation mechanism under quotas.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In its proposal, the Commission recommends suspending the allocation of refugees granted to Sweden under the EU relocation programme for 12 months. The Council also adopted two decisions establishing provisional measures in the area of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece. According to the Council Decision, 40 000 applicants for international protection are to be transferred from Italy and Greece to other Member States. Of all these, 1369 persons were allocated to Sweden by Council Decision 2015/1523 and 4358 persons by Council Decision 2015/1601.  In the event of an emergency situation in a Member State characterised by a sudden influx of third-country nationals, the Council may, on a proposal from the Commission and after consulting the European Parliament, adopt provisional measures in favour of the country concerned in accordance with Article 78(3) of the Treaty. By letter dated 5 November 2015 Sweden has informed the Commission and the Council that it is in the situation referred to in Article 4(3) of Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 of 22 September 2015 laying down provisional measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. Sweden gave due reasons and requested that the relocation mechanism be adapted in its favour. I agree with the arguments put forward by the Swedish side on the relocation of refugees, which is why I voted in favour of this proposal.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of granting Sweden a temporary derogation of one year from the EU’s relocation schemes for the benefit of Italy and Greece following unprecedented and high inflows of asylum seekers because I believe it is essential to show solidarity to those who have always been on the forefront of the solidarity debate. In 2015 alone, Sweden received the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita in the EU before Malta for the first time in ten years. Although through this measure Sweden will be temporarily exempted from the relocation scheme, Sweden has still committed to receiving those asylum seekers that arrive at Sweden’s borders asking for asylum. The humanitarian crisis that Europe faces is volatile, and the situation is ever changing. Since migration policy must be based on the movement of persons, it must be flexible to understand the different realities that different Member States face. This is why I believe that we should show solidarity to Sweden in this regard, which has been on the forefront of a debate with regards to a clear EU-wide distribution policy.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament has voted in favour of the Council's decision to suspend Sweden's obligations to relocate migrants for one year. The aim is to help Sweden cope better with the emergency situation characterized by a large influx of third-country nationals into its territory. In 2015, Sweden received the largest number of international protection claimants per capita.  The initiative report calls for the withdrawal of the European Commission's proposal, noting that the situation of asylum seekers has deteriorated more sharply in Italy and Greece than in Sweden. Considering that this situation has created unprecedented difficulties for the Swedish asylum system, I voted in favour of this report, and I supported the Council's decision.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. By voting on this report, I wished to express my solidarity with Sweden, which in 2015 welcomed the largest number of applicants for international protection per capita to Europe. In order to help Sweden manage this situation, which puts a lot of pressure on its reception capacity in particular, the report allows for the suspension for one year of the country's obligations to relocate refugees within the EU, as well as the establishment of operational support by specialist agencies if necessary.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hungarian Delegation of the People's Party supported sweden's exemption in accordance with Article 9 of the Decision on transitional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece, because this exemption proves that the transitional measures adopted in the original decision, the mandatory distribution of quotas to migrants, are not suitable for dealing with the problem.
