The system established in the decision is inoperable, migrants reach countries that pay higher social care fees, e.g. sweden, irrespective of the allocation by quota. To date, it has not been possible to distribute more than a few hundred migrants instead of the tens of thousands targeted because of the shortcomings of the system, so these transitional measures should be suspended as soon as possible and all Member States should be exempted from the mandatory allocation mechanism according to quotas.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The Hungarian Delegation to the People's Party supported sweden's exemption in accordance with Article 9 of the decision on transitional measures in the field of international protection adopted in favour of Italy and Greece, because this exemption proves that the transitional measures adopted in the original decision, the mandatory distribution of quotas to migrants, are not suitable for dealing with the problem. The system established in the decision is inoperable, migrants reach countries that pay higher social care fees, e.g. sweden, irrespective of the allocation by quota. To date, it has not been possible to distribute more than a few hundred migrants instead of the tens of thousands targeted because of the shortcomings of the system, so these transitional measures should be suspended as soon as possible and all Member States should be exempted from the mandatory allocation mechanism according to quotas.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Sweden has formally requested the suspension of its obligations under decisions (EU) No. 2015/1523 and (EU) No. 2015/1601 of the Council, due to the dual migration challenge it faces: Sweden is a country of first arrival but also of final destination. As of March 2016, the country claims to have taken in 170,104 asylum seekers, including 73,331 children, including 36,181 unaccompanied minors. With or without interim measures, we are opposed to the EU's policy of distributing migrants. It is irresponsible and violates the principle of the sovereignty of nations. Finally, the Swedish position is hypocritical in the sense that successive governments in that country have systematically encouraged and facilitated mass immigration. Also, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from the Commission proposal to introduce provisional measures in the field of international protection for sweden' benefit, freezing the application of Council Decision (EU) 2015/1523 and Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 establishing temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece, through which the EU imposed a mechanism for the reallocation of 160 000 refugees from Italy and Greece to other Member States. As I have repeatedly stated, I am against the quota distribution of illegal immigrants and refugees from the outset. A year after the adoption of the mechanism in question, we all saw that the proposed measures by the Commission did not work. I abstained because I believe sweden has every right to stop accepting refugees, but I do not think it is the Commission's job to decide this.

name: Linnéa Engström (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 In today's vote, we decided whether Sweden should be granted an exemption from receiving its share of the refugees to be redistributed to Sweden from Italy and Greece. We chose to vote against for two main reasons. Sweden has been one of the EU countries that has been pushing for a binding, solidarity-based and fair distribution system and for the temporary redistribution mechanism of 160,000 refugees. The principle itself is based on the fact that the mechanism is binding and that everyone receives their share. Member States have two years to implement this redistribution. The fact that Sweden is asking for a one-year derogation in this situation reduces our credibility in the further efforts to agree on a genuine asylum policy of solidarity. Since the ID checks were introduced, the number of refugees coming to Sweden has decreased drastically, which gives better conditions to receive refugees now. In the light of the deteriorating situation of asylum seekers in Greece, we do not believe that there is any reason to grant derogations to any Member State now. Instead, the focus must be on getting all Member States to fulfil their obligation to participate in the relocation scheme. We hope that Sweden will continue to show the way towards a fair asylum policy.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is oxymoron and tragic when a Member State invokes the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity in order to suspend its obligations under international treaties, in particular the Union Code.  The illegal immigration issue was addressed on the basis of the wrong decisions of the three institutions: the Council of Europe, the Commission and the EC, where Sweden is actively involved, so that it could correct the gaps in political decisions, particularly on the question of quota.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hungarian Delegation of the People's Party supported sweden's exemption in accordance with Article 9 of the Decision on transitional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece, because this exemption proves that the transitional measures adopted in the original decision, the mandatory distribution of quotas to migrants, are not suitable for dealing with the problem. To date, it has not been possible to distribute more than a few hundred migrants instead of the tens of thousands targeted because of the shortcomings of the system, so these transitional measures should be suspended as soon as possible and all Member States should be exempted from the mandatory allocation mechanism according to quotas.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. The refugee crisis we have seen is partly a consequence of not taking joint responsibility in Europe. For me and the Center Party, it is important to have a more even distribution of asylum seekers in Europe and for all countries to take a proportionate responsibility. In 2015, Sweden took 163,000 asylum seekers, while other countries avoided taking responsibility. Therefore, given that we see the need for a balanced distribution in Europe, we chose to support the Commission's proposal and to vote against the amendments that were in the same way.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: we are opposed to the EU's policy of distributing migrants.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission proposes interim measures in favour of Sweden - read: measures to suspend asylum obligations - in the context of the refugee crisis, because it considers that the country is "doubly penalised" for the reception of refugees and for being a destination for relocation. It therefore proposes that Sweden be exempt from participation in the relocation scheme. The rapporteur proposes to reject this proposal. A fair position, which we share, but which unfortunately did not take revenge in the final vote, and has avenged the European Commission's proposal. For this reason, we voted against it. We note that the Swedish delegation of our group does not follow up on the Arguments of the European Commission and has voted against its proposal. The European Commission says that Sweden has done more than most other Member States to protect refugees and that no other Member State has more asylum applications per capita than Sweden.  In this respect, Sweden has been one of the main examples for the other Member States. However, given the deteriorating situation of asylum seekers in Greece, all Member States must fulfil their commitment to solidarity and sharing of responsibilities and therefore no Member State should be suspended from its relocation obligation.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted against the report because I believe that the 12-month suspension of Sweden's share of refugees would lead to an unjustified increase in the migratory burden in countries such as Italy and Greece, which are already facing a strong migration situation on a daily basis.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Sweden is facing an emergency situation due to the sudden influx of third-country nationals into its territory due to significant changes in migration flows, as a result of which Sweden formally requested the suspension of its duties on 8 December 2015. Sweden had by far the highest number of applications for international protection per capita in the European Union in 2015.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining in the vote on the report because these choices made today by Sweden are the result of wrong migration policies of the past.

name: Anna Elżbieta Fotyga (ECR)
text: in writing. – I abstained in voting both, the Commission proposal for a Council decision establishing provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Sweden in accordance with Article 9 of Council Decision (EU) 2015/1523 and Article 9 of Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 establishing provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece, and in voting a legislative resolution of the European Parliament in this respect. I consider an obligatory relocation mechanism established by the Council a mistake and the difficult situation of Sweden supports my position.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hungarian Delegation of the People's Party supported sweden's exemption in accordance with Article 9 of the Decision on transitional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece, because this exemption proves that the transitional measures adopted in the original decision, the mandatory distribution of quotas to migrants, are not suitable for dealing with the problem. The system established in the decision is inoperable, migrants reach countries that pay higher social care fees, e.g. sweden, irrespective of the allocation by quota. To date, it has not been possible to distribute more than a few hundred migrants instead of the target tens of thousands because of the shortcomings of the system, and therefore these transitional measures should be suspended as soon as possible, exempting all Member States from the mandatory allocation mechanism under quotas.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the suspension of Sweden's obligations in relation to the management of the migrant crisis. Recently, like my country, Hungary, Sweden has faced an emergency situation that is growing as a result of the influx of migrants and is becoming less and less able to meet its EU obligations. In March 2016, it received a total of 107,104 applicants, including 73,331 children.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Sweden had the highest number of people applying for international protection per capita in the EU in 2015. In order to ensure these people access to the health system, accommodation and other steps that are necessary under asylum law, we must support the country in tackling this task. It is precisely through the experience of my constituency with regard to the integration of refugees that I consider provisional measures to be effective and important.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. In the context of the migration crisis, Sweden has asked not to honour its "refugee relocation" obligations. The relocation involves 160,000 migrants who have arrived in Greece and Italy and is forcing member states to distribute them.  This scheme therefore applies to only a small proportion of those who have arrived in Europe, while the vast majority are already travelling freely in search of the most welcoming countries.  For example, Sweden argued that it had already opened its doors to many migrants (more than 170,000) outside the scheme and could not follow through on its relocation obligation.  This request must be the subject of a decision by the Union, which therefore proposes provisional measures to postpone sweden's relocation by one year. Parliament's report proposes to validate this decision.  The relocation process is irresponsible because it encourages migrants to cross the Mediterranean to reach Europe. It is also ineffective because Schengen allows them to move freely once settled. I have, of course, objected to this report because the decision to postpone still facilitates the wave of migration we are facing.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Report on provisional measures at the international level for the benefit of Sweden. This is a proposal for an amendment to a Council decision adopted in 2015 which lays down provisional measures for the benefit of Member States in an emergency situation characterised by a massive influx of third-country nationals in one or more Member States, also known as "temporary scheme relocation". This amendment to the relocation scheme was submitted by the Commission in December, following the Swedish Government's requirement to benefit from this relocation scheme.  The original request of the Swedish Government in November was to benefit from this mechanism such as Greece and Italy. However, this request was rejected by the Commission, which, on the contrary, agreed with the one-year suspension for the "obligation" to relocate those applying to Sweden (1369 people).

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. I support the relocation proposals which are based on a fair distribution to provide increased solidarity and responsibility sharing between Member States. This proposal would suspend Sweden’s participation in the relocation scheme.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report proposes specific measures in favour of Sweden because of its stance on refugees. We fully recognise that Sweden has played a key role in tackling the refugee crisis, and has accepted a large number of refugees on its territory, which we welcome. We are even clear in our positions when we demand that all EU Member States do the same and assume their responsibilities for support and solidarity with both refugees and the Member States which have accepted the greatest burden of the refugee waves.  However, our position is that responsibilities should be shared among everyone according to their capabilities and in the Member States. We believe that it is appropriate to put pressure on states that do not do what is necessary to do so, and not to take specific measures to do what they have to do. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Given the recent sudden inflow of nationals of third countries in its territory, Sweden is faced with an unprecedented situation. Sweden has received a total of 170 104 applicants, of whom 73 331 were children, including 36 181 unaccompanied minors who have special needs and who require additional resource. The Swedes would have to provide access to health care, dignified accommodation and education according to Union asylum rules. It has formally requested the suspension of its obligations under Council Decisions (EU) 2015/1523 and (EU) 2015/1601, having to face both challenges of being a country of first arrival and final destination. As a result, I acknowledge it is a difficult situation and support the request from Sweden to suspend its obligations under the above decisions.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I approved this provision as it benefits both migrants and Sweden in coping better with the refugee crisis. The country will be more able to support the sudden inflow of nationals from third countries, once they receive the support granted by this motion.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. On the basis of Article 78 TFEU, which seeks a common EU asylum policy, special measures will also be applied to Sweden, as in the same way as Greece and Italy, in order to compensate for Sweden's burden of migratory flows. To this end, on 15 December 2015, the Commission drew up a proposal for provisional measures in favour of Sweden in the field of international protection, following sweden's request on 5 November 2015. As Sweden is in distress due to a sudden influx of third-country nationals, Sweden and the Commission believe that appropriate support is needed.  Specifically, Sweden will be exempted from the relocation mechanism of 160,000 third-country nationals from Italy and Greece, adopted in mid-September 2015, for at least one year. However, there is still a formal obligation to take in a total of around 4700 third-country nationals from Italy and Greece. In principle, I support this project by the European Commission.  However, the plenary subsequently included in the report the false claim that Sweden is not only the target country, but also the first country of arrival for asylum seekers. This claim call into question the validity of the current Dublin Regulation with regard to the initial reception of third-country nationals or stateless people, and thus fundamentally the rule of law, which further undermines citizens' confidence in the EU. That is why I am abstaining.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hungarian Delegation of the People's Party supported sweden's exemption in accordance with Article 9 of the Decision on transitional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece, because this exemption proves that the transitional measures adopted in the original decision, the mandatory distribution of quotas to migrants, are not suitable for dealing with the problem. The system established in the decision is inoperable, migrants reach countries that pay higher social care fees, e.g. sweden, irrespective of the allocation by quota. name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted AGAINST the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council decision to introduce interim measures in the area of international protection for Sweden's benefit in accordance with Article 9. Council Decisions (EU) 2015/1523 and Article 9 Council (EU) Decisions 2015/1601 on the imposition of interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece, as I support transfers on the basis of fair and objective redistribution.  I believe it is necessary to increase solidarity and sharing of responsibilities between Member States. I therefore support the alde group's position calling on Member States to adequately provide assistance to persons in need of international protection. It should definitely take into account the great efforts sweden has shown in receiving asylum seekers, however rejecting the resettlement scheme is not the best way to provide assistance to Sweden.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. We have always opposed the EU's policy of distributing migrants. It does not work, and it is contrary to the principle of the sovereignty of nations. There is no point in introducing temporary measures to address the problems of the common asylum and immigration policy. Member States must be empowered to develop their own policies in this area. My vote was therefore against the text.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In 2015, Sweden had the highest number of applicants for international protection per population of the entire EU (11 503 applicants per million inhabitants), leading to a serious burden on the Swedish asylum system. Sweden has therefore requested a temporary suspension of its obligation under the Council Decision on the redistribution of asylum seekers from Greece and Italy. In view of the change in the situation in recent months, parliament's report recommended not granting an exemption from the reallocation. On the one hand, it is true that the number of applications in Sweden has decreased significantly and the exemption may no longer be up to date. On the other hand, we should recognise that Sweden has done a greater part of the work than many other EU countries. Unfortunately, today we see that the relocation scheme in general is proving to be a not very functional mechanism, which is why I abstained when voting on this issue.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which proposes to grant Sweden a one-year suspension of its obligations under the European Union's relocation programme. This choice, which is an exceptional interim measure, is due to the emergency situation in Sweden, which is experiencing the largest increase in the number of international protection claimants per capita in the whole of the Union.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This report provides, inter alia, for additional resources to be made available to unaccompanied minors, to increase access to national health and education systems and, in general, to allocate more money to address the migration crisis. Since this only combats symptoms, but does not take the true reasons for crisis management, I am voting against the report.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. Europe faces a huge humanitarian challenge with the current refugee crisis. Common European solutions are part of the solution to the crisis. Part of the concrete European solutions that exist right now are the so-called 'temporary relocation scheme'. The scheme means that Italy and Greece will have to relieve some 160,000 refugees. The refugees are distributed to the other Member States according to a quota allocation. Sweden is one of the countries to take in more refugees. However, Sweden is also one of the countries that have already taken the most refugees per capita. That is why we understand that Sweden will be suspended from temporary relocation for one year. Member States must be able to keep up. Denmark has and will continue to have a clear exception in the area of refugee and asylum policy. The Danish exception is also clear in the adopted text. That is why we support the report. At the same time, with our support, we are showing that we will not stand in the way of the wishes of the other Member States for common European solutions to concrete problems. Just as we note with satisfaction that the other Member States , with the explicit reference to the Danish exception, fully respect Denmark's position.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. On the basis of Article 78 TFEU, which seeks a common EU asylum policy, special measures will also be applied to Sweden, as in the same way as Greece and Italy, in order to compensate for Sweden's burden of migratory flows. To this end, on 15 December 2015, the Commission drew up a proposal for provisional measures in favour of Sweden in the field of international protection, following sweden's request on 5 November 2015. As Sweden is in distress due to a sudden influx of third-country nationals, Sweden and the Commission believe that appropriate support is needed.  Specifically, Sweden will be exempted from the relocation mechanism of 160,000 third-country nationals from Italy and Greece, adopted in mid-September 2015, for at least one year. However, there is still a formal obligation to take in a total of around 4700 third-country nationals from Italy and Greece. In principle, I support this project by the European Commission.  However, the plenary subsequently included in the report the false claim that Sweden is not only the target country, but also the first country of arrival for asylum seekers. This claim call into question the validity of the current Dublin Regulation with regard to the initial reception of third-country nationals or stateless people, and thus fundamentally the rule of law, which further undermines citizens' confidence in the EU. That is why I am abstaining.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hungarian Delegation of the People's Party supported sweden's exemption in accordance with Article 9 of the Decision on transitional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece, because this exemption proves that the transitional measures adopted in the original decision, the mandatory distribution of quotas to migrants, are not suitable for dealing with the problem. name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report on interim measures for international protection for Sweden. The Swedish government's position is hypocritical, as successive governments in that country have systematically encouraged and facilitated mass immigration. Now he is calling for interim measures on his migrant quota.  If Sweden does not meet its quota of migrants, they will be relocated elsewhere in the European Union. I have always been opposed to the EU's policy of distributing migrants. It does not work, and it is contrary to the principle of the sovereignty of nations. There is no point in introducing temporary measures to address the problems of the common asylum and immigration policy. Member States must be empowered to develop their own policies in this area.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The text proposes to temporarily suspend the obligation to relocate migrants to Sweden, which is the responsibility of each member state. Thus, in the form of provisional measures for international protection, the country would be exempt from taking in asylum seekers. Drawing on the difficulties caused by mass immigration, he develops a hypocritical argument since successive Swedish governments have always encouraged her. It is therefore unacceptable to vote in favour of this text and to clear Sweden of the consequences of its immigration policies. In addition, states must be able to control their territories and set their own immigration policies in the name of their sovereignty. I have therefore spoken AGAINST this text.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. On the basis of Article 78 TFEU, which seeks a common EU asylum policy, special measures will also be applied to Sweden, as in the same way as Greece and Italy, in order to compensate for Sweden's burden of migratory flows. To this end, on 15 December 2015, the Commission drew up a proposal for provisional measures in favour of Sweden in the field of international protection, following sweden's request on 5 November 2015. As Sweden is in distress due to a sudden influx of third-country nationals, Sweden and the Commission believe that appropriate support is needed.  Specifically, Sweden will be exempted from the relocation mechanism of 160,000 third-country nationals from Italy and Greece, adopted in mid-September 2015, for at least one year. However, there is still a formal obligation to take in a total of around 4700 third-country nationals from Italy and Greece. In principle, I support this project by the European Commission.  However, the plenary subsequently included in the report the false claim that Sweden is not only the target country, but also the first country of arrival for asylum seekers. This claim call into question the validity of the current Dublin Regulation with regard to the initial reception of third-country nationals or stateless people, and thus fundamentally the rule of law, which further undermines citizens' confidence in the EU. That is why I am abstaining.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour. From the beginning, I do not agree with the perverse idea of redistribution of people, and in the past I have tabled an amendment on behalf of the EFDD Group so that Member States do not have to participate in this redistribution if they do not want to. That is why, in this case, I voted in favour of Sweden not having to accept the redistributed quota at least temporarily. This proposal is not at the expense of the Czech Republic.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Sweden is in a crisis situation due to the sudden influx of third-country nationals and a significant increase in the number of unaccompanied minors to its territory due to sudden changes in migration. In 2015 it had the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita in the EU (11 503 applicants per million inhabitants) and in March 2016 it had the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita in the EU. In 2014, it received a total of 170,104 applicants, including 73,331 children, including 36,181 unaccompanied minors, who have special needs and need additional resources to provide them with access to healthcare, decent housing and education under EU asylum rules. Having had to deal with the dual challenge simultaneously, being a first entry country and final destination, on 8 December Sweden formally requested the suspension of its commitments under Council (EU) 2015/1523 and (EU) decisions in 2015/1601. This report accepts the Commission's proposal with proposed amendments to the imposition of interim measures in the area of international protection for Sweden's benefit, so I supported this report.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the proposal for a Council Decision establishing provisional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Sweden in accordance with Article 9 of Decision (EU) 2015/1523 and Article 9 of Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 establishing provisional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece, because it is not complete and substantiated.  With the exception granted to Sweden by the relocation process, the process of relocating refugees from Greece and Italy to other EU countries is once again being undermined. Already, while 66,400 refugees have had to be relocated from Greece to other EU countries to date, there are fewer than 1000 relocations.  The announcement of the Commissioner responsible for 6,000 relocations per month from Greece to other EU countries should be implemented immediately.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the legislative resolution, the committee's proposal, the amendments and the motion to reject it. The report looks at the 2015/1523 and 2015/1601 decisions that introduce interim measures for Italy and Greece in the face of the influx of migrants.  Sweden took in a total of 170,104 asylum seekers in March 2016. It would therefore like to benefit from interim measures suspending its childcare obligations. We cannot support the Swedish government. He has always advocated for the reception of migrants by Member States through the introduction of quotas. This U-turn is therefore inappropriate. In addition, Sweden's return of migrants will lead to their relocation to other Member States. Nor do we support the motion to reject the Swedish request by forty MEPs. This motion calls for strict application of migrant quotas to Member States. Clearly, the European Union's migration policy is deadlocked. There is an urgent need to give states back their prerogatives over immigration control.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on temporary measures in the field of international protection for Sweden. The issue is what is happening in the area of migration, where Sweden is facing an intense challenge due to the number of people trying to enter. One of the related problems concerns the high rate of minors who declare that they are not accompanied and the consequent necessary measures to be taken in such cases: additional costs and special attention to be paid to those in need of special care.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about amending an original application. Additional funds will be made available for the integration of refugees. I therefore reject this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the Commission's proposal to suspend the resettlement mechanism for Sweden, as it has recently faced an unusually large influx of migrants, with Sweden registering the highest per capita number of applicants for international protection in the EU in 2015.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Commission’s proposal which highlights the current migrant situation in Sweden and provides for operational support.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This is a text wishing the distribution of immigrants in Europe, to alleviate Sweden, which has taken in these populations (170,000 last March). More than forty MEPs came forward to force Member States to accept quotas. I am opposed to this text, firstly because the Commission has nothing to impose on the Member States, and secondly because this allocation does not work. Finally, Sweden has supported highly unreasonable migration policies and these steps are only self-involved. As a result, I voted against these texts.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sweden faces an emergency situation, characterized by a sudden influx of third-country nationals into its territory. Therefore, the current migration situation in Sweden is unique in the EU and the pressure on its ability to deal with applications for international protection and to ensure adequate reception conditions for people in clear need of international protection requires the temporary suspension of Sweden's obligations under the relocation mechanism and the provision, where appropriate, of operational support. In order to help Sweden better cope with an emergency situation characterised by a sudden influx of third-country nationals to its territory, the proposal for a Decision suspends Sweden's obligations as a Member State for relocation under Council Decisions (EU) 2015/1523 and (EU) 2015/1601 for a period of one year. Sweden remains obliged to replace 1 369 persons under Council Decision (EU) 2015/1523 and 4 358 persons under Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 from Italy and Greece after this Decision expires. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it is important that Sweden is able to efficiently process and assist applicants for international protection, especially minors, which this report addresses.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. In the context of the migration flows facing the Union at the moment, I would like to underline Sweden's historic role in welcoming asylum seekers. However, I regret the European Parliament's approval today of Sweden's one-year suspension of the relocation mechanism for asylum seekers in Greece and Italy.  While this mechanism, a symbol of solidarity between Member States on asylum, is not yet functioning as it should, the time is not right to weaken it even further. I am of the opinion that by endorsing this exemption, we are sending the wrong political signal at a time when the proposed solutions to ensure the coherence and effectiveness of our asylum policy must absolutely show their effects.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Sweden is facing an emergency situation due to the sudden influx of third-country nationals into its territory due to significant changes in migration flows. On 8 December 2015, Sweden formally requested the suspension of its obligations under Council decisions. The aim is to introduce a temporary measure suspending, for a period of one year, Sweden's commitment to relocation in view of the seriousness of the situation caused by the influx of third-country nationals. Sweden had the largest number of applicants for international protection per capita in 2015, putting considerable pressure on the country's asylum system. Sweden is also facing a difficult situation in view of the recent significant increase in the number of unaccompanied minors – one in four applicants claim to be unaccompanied minors. I support the European Commission's proposal in its original version and do not agree with the rapporteur's amendment.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Sweden had by far the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita in the EU during 2015 and it has had a significant increase in the number of unaccompanied minors among the applicants. The recent data from Eurostat shows that the number of applicants for international protection in Sweden has increased by 60% between the years 2015 and 2016 and that Sweden had 39 055 applicants in October 2015 alone. Therefore, I supported the legislative resolution for provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Sweden.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Commission has proposed to the Council a decision laying down transitional measures in the field of international protection in the interest of Sweden. Under the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the Commission must consult the Council before taking a decision. In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament approve the proposal put forward by the Commission with three amendments. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sweden formally requested, on 8 December, the suspension of its obligations under Council Decisions (EU) 2015/1523 and (EU) 2015/1601, as it is facing an emergency situation characterised by a sudden influx of third-country nationals into its territory following a sharp change in migration flows. The considerable increase in irregular border crossings in the European Union, and secondary movements across Europe, has led to a sharp increase in the number of applicants for international protection in Sweden, most of which have entered the EU through Italy and Greece. Sweden recorded the highest number of international protection claimants per capita in the EU in 2015 (11,503 applications per million inhabitants). This situation has put the Swedish asylum system under pressure, with serious practical consequences on the ground, with regard to the reception conditions and capacity of the asylum system to deal with these applications. This report deserves my vote in favour, for the foregoing and to guarantee Sweden the necessary support for its asylum system to deal with this emergency situation.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. The EU-imposed principle of quotas for the distribution of migrants is abhorrent. It does not work, and is contrary to the principle of the sovereignty of nations. There is no point in introducing temporary measures to address the problems of the common asylum and immigration policy. Member States must be empowered to develop their own policies in this area.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which aims to allow Sweden, overwhelmed by the influx of migrants, to be able to temporarily evade its migration policy obligations. Last year, Sweden had the highest number of asylum seekers per capita. In March 2016, it received a total of 170,104 applicants, including 73,331 children, including 36,181 unaccompanied minors. I objected to an amendment by the Greens that proposed not to grant these emergency measures to Sweden.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Why did I vote in favour of Sweden yesterday so that it does not have to take in any resettled migrants for 12 months? In this way, the European Commission has recognised that the social tolerance of individual Member States must also be taken into account. Despite being a rich and sparsely populated country, even Sweden has a finite capacity. Because technocratic statistics do not work, only the resettlement target based on a similarity between the financial situation, population density and the number of migrants so far. While sweden has seen an increase in the number of illegally settled people from 60 to 110 000, the resources of the new Member States are similarly tied up in addition to Roma integration, in addition to resolving internal social tensions, supporting families living in poverty and those with small pension benefits.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Sweden faces an emergency situation due to the sudden inflow of nationals of third countries in its territory due to the sharp shift in migratory flows. I have voted for this report that will establish provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Sweden. The country is also facing a difficult situation because of the significant recent increase in the number of unaccompanied minors, who have special needs and require additional resources in order to provide them with access to healthcare, accommodation and education according to the European Union’s Asylum Rules.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the proposal by the Council to recognise the request of the Member State Sweden to suspend its obligation, for a period of one year, to relocation of third country nationals, taking into consideration the enormous migratory pressure that the country has faced particularly within the last year. Indeed, as of 2015 Sweden was the Member State of the EU with the highest number of applicants for international protection per EU capita, causing such strain on the Swedish authorities’ ability to process asylum claims and provide asylum seekers with appropriate conditions upon their arrival that it is justifiable to characterise this situation as one of emergency.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported granting a temporary exemption to Sweden from participating in the emergency relocation mechanism due to the exceptionally high influx of refugees in 2015 and in the first months of 2016, which made Sweden the state with the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita. I therefore believe that this concession to Sweden is justified and I was somewhat surprised by the relatively close result of the vote on the LIBE Committee responsible in this regard. Sweden is making a huge effort in the refugee crisis, which deserves to be supported in this way as well.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This proposal would see Sweden negate its obligations in relation to the refugee relocation programme. In the initial report Sweden was essentially requesting to be treated like Italy and Greece and to have refugees relocated out of Sweden. This report however seeks to simply suspend Sweden’s obligations to the relocation agreement. Given the worsening situation in the Med, the deterioration of conditions in detention/reception centres across Europe and the onset of summer, now is not the time for any nation to shirk its responsibilities to address the refugee crisis. The rapporteur and GUE have tabled a rejection amendment on that basis. We have consistently called for everyone to play their part in this crisis, and therefore I tabled a negative vote.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. The application concerns amendments to the original application, which calls for additional resources to be made possible for the care of unaccompanied minors in terms of health care, accommodation and education. Although Keller rejects the original application, it is only for Sweden to fulfil its "obligations" as a "positive example of an asylum country".

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Not supported because it does not consider such exceptions to be reasonable. The number of people moving to Sweden has decreased, and the granting of such an exception will also reduce the incentive for other countries to relocate refugees.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. – I support the report tabled. In view of the current situation and the problems facing Sweden, temporary measures in the field of international protection should be established for Italy and Greece. It should be noted that Sweden is facing one of the worst migrant crises and cannot solve the problems associated with high immigration. The refugee crisis has extremely negative consequences for the state's social welfare system and the whole welfare model. In 2015, the country recorded the highest per capita number of applicants for international protection in the EU. It is therefore essential that Sweden is entitled to suspend its obligations under the resettlement mechanism and should be granted operational assistance.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against suspending Sweden's participation in the obligations arising from the Council's decisions on the 'relocation of refugees'. It is confirmed that after the capitalist states choose those who need their domestic monopolies, then they inhumanely "close" the borders. Those who for so long in the European Parliament have been indulging in over-hypocritical statements about so-called 'solidarity' in favour of refugees are now putting their stamp on a decision that brutally violates their rights.  These decisions by the EU and the civil governments intensify the entrapment of thousands of refugees and migrants in the first host countries - if they escape the long-dead enclaves - in camps where even the minimum living conditions are not respected, without drinking water, without or with inappropriate food, in mud and garbage dumps.  The Communist Party of Greece takes aim at the real cause of the refugee crisis, which is imperialist interventions and capitalist barbarism, and supports in every way the refugees' demands for: safe movement to the countries of final destination, recognition of refugee status to all peoples who have been attacked imperialist, human treatment, open and humane, state-organized, places of hospitality.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report recognises that Sweden has had a higher number of refugees per capita than any other EU nation. This vote allows Sweden to suspend its right to take refugees in for a year. UKIP voted for this proposal to give Sweden the opportunity to adjust to this demand. We also do not believe it should be in the EU’s remit to decide over Member States how many migrants should be repatriated to specific Member States.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Keller's proposal. In the current migration crisis that the European Union is facing, Sweden is, together with other countries, among the most affected, having to face the arrival of a large number of migrants and unaccompanied minors who require international protection.  On the basis of these considerations, I believe that Sweden should be recognising temporary measures in the field of international protection. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ In March this year Sweden received over 170,000 asylum applications. Of the total number of applications, more than 73 000 were submitted by children, of which 36 000 were minors with special needs. In 2015, the country had by far the highest number of applicants for international protection, over 10,000 per million inhabitants.  The sudden influx of immigrants, via Italy and Greece, has created a situation that has put intense pressure on the Swedish asylum system with serious practical consequences on the ground, in terms of the inability to ensure adequate conditions for the admission of these people and the ability of the asylum system to cope with the requirements. Therefore, Sweden decided to formally request the suspension of its obligation to deploy immigrants for a period of one year. As an MP coming from a country that itself has cared for a million refugees in an imposed war, I understand the pressure put on the Swedish asylum system, and on the material and humanitarian resources due to migration movements. In this crisis, as well as during the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Sweden has shown itself to be a country that helps in humanitarian crises and I consider that the request of that state to be reasonable.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I disagree with the rapporteur, Ms Keller, that the Commission's proposal to temporarily suspend Sweden from the realisation system should be rejected. I agree that certain Member States can and should do more to accept a refugee. However, Sweden is in a crisis situation due to the sudden influx of third-country nationals due to sharp changes in migratory flows. Sweden requested the suspension of its obligations under Council (EU) decisions 2015/1523 and (EU) 2015/1601, as it had to deal with a dual challenge, i.e. at the same time it was both a first entry country and a final destination. Sweden had by far the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita in the EU in 2015 (11,503 applicants per million inhabitants), and in March 2016 received a total of 170,104 applicants, including 73,331 children, including 36,181 unaccompanied minors.  Sweden is also in a difficult situation due to a significant increase in the number of unaccompanied minors; 25% of applicants claim to be an unaccompanied minor and have special needs and need additional resources to give them access to health care, decent housing and education under EU asylum rules. Therefore, I agree with the Commission's proposal to temporarily suspend Sweden from the refugee realisation system.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission proposes interim measures in favour of Sweden - read: suspension of asylum obligations - in the context of the refugee crisis, because it considers that the country is "doubly penalised" for the reception of refugees and for being a destination for relocation. It therefore proposes that Sweden be exempt from participation in the relocation scheme. The rapporteur believes that Sweden has set an example in welcoming refugees and that it must continue in this direction. At a time when the conditions of hundreds of thousands of refugees arriving on European soil are deteriorating, and the humanitarian crisis is worsening as a direct consequence of European Union policies, we follow the concern expressed in the rejection amendment, which considers it unacceptable that Member States should give up responsibility for taking in the thousands of refugees and migrants fleeing hunger with dignity. , misery, war, conflicts resulting from the policy of aggression and interference on countries, notably North Africa and the Middle East, with direct responsibilities of the EU and its Member States. For the above, we voted in favour of the amendment of rejection and against the Commission's proposal.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒As part of the common asylum policy, Article 78(3) of the EIA the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU provides for a specific legal basis for resolving crisis situations and the provisional measures envisaged are extraordinary. They can only be activated if, due to the sudden influx of third-country nationals within the Member States' asylum system, a certain threshold of urgency and severity of the problem is reached.  Under Article 78(3) of the TFEU, the Council adopted two decisions on the imposition of interim measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. I supported The Keller Report, as the current migration situation in Sweden is unique in the EU and, as pressure on the capacity to process applications for international protection and ensure adequate reception conditions for people in need of international protection, requires a temporary suspension of Sweden's obligations under the relocation mechanism and the provision of operational support to Sweden.  This situation weighs heavily on the Swedish asylum system, which has serious practical implications for the reception conditions and the ability of the asylum system to process applications. In order to help Sweden cope with extreme pressure on asylum and migration systems, it should be provided with specific support through relevant activities coordinated by EASO and other relevant agencies.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sweden is one of the Member States that has done the most to protect refugees, as well as being a country that receives a large number of asylum applications. The continuous flow of migrants has led Sweden to an emergency situation, requiring temporary measures to deal with the thousands of asylum applications. Sweden has therefore applied for the possibility of being suspended for only one year from its obligations under the EU relocation programme.  I voted in favour of this report, but I believe that, in view of the deteriorating situation of asylum seekers in Italy and Greece, and above all by noting that the relocation system is functioning smoothly, all Member States must respect their commitment to solidarity and shared responsibility.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 In its proposal, the Commission recommends suspending the allocation of refugees granted to Sweden under the EU relocation programme for 12 months. Of those to be transferred from Italy and Greece, Sweden was allocated 1369 persons under Council Decision (EU) 2015/1523 and 4358 persons by Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601. In accordance with the second paragraph of Article 4(3) of Decision 2015/1601, a Member State may, on du grounds, notify the Commission and the Council that it is in an emergency situation characterised by a sudden influx of third-country nationals due to a sharp change in the direction of migration flows. The Commission shall evaluate the reasons given and, where appropriate, submit proposals to the Council. By letter dated 5 November 2015 Sweden has informed the Commission and the Council that it is in the situation referred to in Article 4(3) of Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 of 22 September 2015 laying down provisional measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. Sweden gave due reasons and requested that the relocation mechanism be adapted in its favour. By letter dated 8 December 2015 Sweden has formally requested the suspension of its obligations under Council Decisions (EU) 2015/1523 and (EU) 2015/1601. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Like many European Union states, Sweden has faced a massive influx of migrants into its territory. In one year, the number of asylum seekers in the country has increased by 60%, resulting in a deterioration in reception conditions and, in fact, a deterioration in the functioning of the asylum application system in Sweden. It is for these reasons that I voted in favour of interim measures on international protection for Sweden to adapt to the reality of the situation in the country. To deal with this migrant crisis, it is a matter of being pragmatic and not dogmatic.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The current migration crisis affects the various Member States with different intensity. In this context, Sweden is now facing an emergency situation, characterised by a sudden influx of nationals from other countries. Sweden is by far the Member State with the most asylum applications per capita, and at the same time there has been an increase in asylum applications from unaccompanied minors and therefore in need of special aid.  The Commission has therefore decided to submit a proposal for a decision to the Council to establish interim measures in the field of international protection for Sweden, suspending its obligations as a Member State of relocation and determining the granting of operational support to sweden in accordance with Article 78(3) TFEU, in accordance with the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality , and in compliance with the provisions of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Whereas it is only through quality integration that it will be possible to deal with the above-mentioned increase in migration flows, without compromising the stability of the European asylum system, I am voting in favour of approving the Commission's proposal to the Council, with the amendments made to parliament.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report recognises that Sweden has had a higher number of refugees per capita than any other EU nation. This vote allows Sweden to suspend its right to take refugees in for a year. UKIP voted for this proposal to give Sweden the opportunity to adjust to this demand. We also do not believe it should be in the EU’s remit to decide over Member States how many migrants should be repatriated to specific Member States.

name: Christine Revault D'Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D)
text: In writing. Sweden is the country in the European Union that receives the most asylum seekers and refugees in proportion to its population. This Member State has asked the Commission for a temporary exemption in order not to implement its relocation obligations for one year. The challenge of this interim measure is to enable the Swedish authorities to rebuild their reception capacities (particularly in the areas of education, health and housing), in order to be able to fully meet their European commitments. The country has no intention of no longer receiving people in need of international protection on its soil, especially since asylum seekers and many unaccompanied minors arrive in Sweden every day outside the framework of relocation measures.  I have decided to vote in favour of the Commission's proposal to grant this temporary exemption. It would be incomprehensible to sanction one of the few countries in the Union which already hosts a large number of refugees and wishes to receive more, but under better conditions, even though other Member States continue shamefully to refuse to fulfil their reception obligations and to trample on calls for solidarity.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Commission's proposal to establish interim measures for Sweden in the field of international protection. Sweden bases its claim on the argument that it is facing an emergency situation characterised by a sudden influx of third-country nationals into its territory due to a sharp shift in migration flows. The rapporteur is of the opinion that Sweden has not achieved this emergency. The European Parliament supported the Commission's proposal.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In view of the Commission's proposal to the Council (COM (2015)0677), in view of Article 78, paragraph 3 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, under which it was consulted by the Council (C8-0017/2016) and on the basis of the report of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (A8-0170/2016), the European Parliament approved the Commission's proposal as amended and called on the Commission to amend its proposal accordingly.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 As we know, Sweden recorded the highest per capita number of applicants for international protection in the EU in 2015 (11 503 applicants per million population). Total by March 2016 170,104 applicants arrived in Sweden, of which 73,331 are children, including 36,181 unsubscrived minors. In this context, Sweden's request for certain protective measures appears to be extremely well founded and reasoned.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Sweden registered the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita in 2015. It is therefore necessary to support this Member State in order not to overpressure the Swedish asylum system, as this could of course have serious practical consequences on the ground, particularly as regards the reception conditions and the capacity of the asylum system to cope with the complications caused by this unforeseen influx. The aim of the Council's decision is to suspend Sweden's obligations as a Member State with regard to the relocation of refugee citizens for a period of one year in order to help Sweden cope with the emergency situation it has been experiencing, with regard to the sudden flow of third-country nationals who have reached its territory massively. In addition, operational support coordinated by the European Asylum Support Office (EAsA) and, if necessary, other relevant European agencies is also provided for. I voted in favour of this report because, since this is a very sensitive matter, with very complex contours and obvious cross-border implications, I think it deserves the solidarity and monitoring of the other Member States and, of course, the European Parliament.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report acknowledges Sweden's efforts in 2015 in terms of the redistribution of people from third countries on its territory. The committee responsible has therefore given its favourable opinion to the Council's proposal, which is to suspend sweden's compulsory participation in the redistribution of asylum seekers.  In accordance with the direction resulting from the committee's work, I voted in support of the Council's proposal.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Report on provisional measures at the international level for the benefit of Sweden. This is a proposal for an amendment to a Council decision adopted in 2015, which lays down provisional measures for the benefit of Member States in an emergency situation characterised by a massive influx of third-country nationals in one or more Member States, also known as "temporary scheme relocation". This amendment to the relocation scheme was submitted by the Commission in December, following the Swedish Government's requirement to benefit from this relocation scheme. The original request of the Swedish Government in November was to benefit from this mechanism such as Greece and Italy. However, this request was rejected by the Commission, which, on the contrary, agreed with the one-year suspension for the "obligation" to relocate those applying to Sweden (1369 people).

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. Europe faces a huge humanitarian challenge with the current refugee crisis. Common European solutions are part of the solution to the crisis.  Part of the concrete European solutions that are in place right now are the so-called 'temporary relocation scheme'. The scheme means that Italy and Greece will have to relieve some 160,000 refugees. The refugees are distributed to the other Member States under a compulsory allocation of quotas. Sweden is one of the countries to take in more refugees. However, Sweden is also one of the countries that have already taken the most refugees per capita. That is why we understand that Sweden will be suspended from temporary relocation for one year. Member States must be able to keep up.  Denmark has and will continue to have a clear exception in the area of refugee and asylum policy. That is the way it is today and that will be the future. Moreover, the Danish derogation is clearly stated in the adopted text. Since I do not want the EU to decide on the policy of refugees in Denmark, and since I fundamentally disagree with a coercive quota solution, I have chosen to abstain. I could have chosen to vote against, but I also do not want to hold the other countries to do what they think is right.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the Commission's proposal, because Sweden has already taken in a large number of refugees, so I believe that a suspension for taking in more refugees for one year is legitimate.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. In 2015, a number of measures were adopted for countries in difficult situations because of the increasing number of arrivals by migrants and asylum seekers, known as the relocation mechanism. Greece and Italy have so far been welcomed to this mechanism. Sweden is the country with the highest number of asylum seekers per capita, and has so far been an example of good practice in this field. However, the current social democratic government wanted to take these measures, an exercise in insolidarity given its economic situation. The proposal that the Commission has sent to Parliament is not the original one of relocation, but of halicking Sweden's obligations in the relocation system. We voted against this proposal, because there is now a situation of enormous gravity in the main points of arrival in the EU, where migrants and asylum seekers are surviving in conditions of extreme precariousness. In order to alleviate this situation, the solidarity of all member states is necessary and we cannot allow such exceptions.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I follow the Commission’s view that Sweden’s emergency situation is such that the Swedish asylum system is under so much strain that Sweden’s participation in the relocation scheme warrants suspension for a year. Sweden had, by far, the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita in the EU during 2015 and I am concerned that the services in Sweden won’t be able to cope and that’s before one considers, as the Commission has, the number of unaccompanied minors among the applicants.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the Commission’s proposal because I believe Sweden’s sovereign right to take a pause from receiving migrants should be permitted. It is clear that there are significant problems with the relocation mechanism, and I know some of the abstention votes were a reflection of this.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Council Decision on temporary measures in the field of international protection in favour of Sweden concerns the recently approved relocation mechanism for 160 000 asylum seekers from Italy and Greece. Under the scheme, Sweden is expected to take in nearly 6,000 refugees from the two countries. However, the Commission has come up with a proposal that Sweden should be temporarily removed from the scheme. In the Commission's view, Sweden is facing an emergency situation due to the increased number of applicants for international protection, which puts unmanageable pressure on the Swedish asylum system. Today's number of asylum seekers in Sweden is causing practical problems, as refugees cannot be given adequate conditions for life and their applications are processed late. Sweden received a total of more than 170,000 applicants in March 2016, of which more than 70,000 were children, according to the latest figures. In view of this information, I believe that Sweden has shown a sufficient degree of solidarity over the last period. We must approach the refugee crisis holisticly, as some countries, such as Slovakia, also contribute to its resolution through other instruments (such as the provision of security forces or material equipment). For these reasons, I supported the Commission's proposal to exempt Sweden from participation in the relocation mechanism for a year.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. On the basis of Article 78 TFEU, which seeks a common EU asylum policy, special measures will also be applied to Sweden, as in the same way as Greece and Italy, in order to compensate for Sweden's burden of migratory flows. To this end, on 15 December 2015, the Commission drew up a proposal for provisional measures in favour of Sweden in the field of international protection, following sweden's request on 5 November 2015. As Sweden is in distress due to a sudden influx of third-country nationals, Sweden and the Commission believe that appropriate support is needed.  Specifically, Sweden will be exempted from the relocation mechanism of 160,000 third-country nationals from Italy and Greece, adopted in mid-September 2015, for at least one year. However, there is still a formal obligation to take in a total of around 4700 third-country nationals from Italy and Greece. In principle, I support this project by the European Commission.  However, the plenary subsequently included in the report the false claim that Sweden is not only the target country, but also the first country of arrival for asylum seekers. This claim call into question the validity of the current Dublin Regulation with regard to the initial reception of third-country nationals or stateless people, and thus fundamentally the rule of law, which further undermines citizens' confidence in the EU. That is why I am abstaining.

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the EP resolution approving Sweden's request for a temporary one-year suspension of the relocation obligation. I would like to draw attention to the fact that this is only a suspension of relocation decisions in favour of Sweden, so that the relocation obligation does not lapse for Sweden, it is merely suspended, in full compliance with the relocation decisions adopted. In 2015, Sweden registered by far the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita in the EU (11 503 per million inhabitants), which is currently facing a significant increase in the number of unaccompanied minors. Sweden has always been and continues to be a country that has approached asylum policy very responsibly and with a huge degree of both human and financial solidarity. Sweden has made a long-term and significant contribution to European and global funds to help refugees. Sweden is now in an emergency situation, facing a sudden influx of huge numbers of migrants on its territory. Naturally, all these factors place a significant burden on the Swedish asylum system. Sweden wants to continue to provide applicants for international protection with decent treatment and the necessary assistance, so it is asking its EU partners for the necessary solidarity and time to better manage the emergency situation they face.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament has adopted the Commission's proposal with proposed amendments to the Council's decision to introduce interim measures in the area of international protection for Sweden's benefit in accordance with Article 9. Council (EU) Decisions 2015/1523 Parliament has also asked the Council to consult it if it intends to substantially amend the Commission's proposal. I support the Commission's proposal with the proposed amendments, as I believe it is a technical change that will result in a more clearly worded decision whose content will essentially remain the same.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament accepts the Commission's proposal with proposed amendments to the Council's decision to introduce interim measures in the area of international protection for Sweden's benefit in accordance with Article 9. Council (EU) Decisions 2015/1523 Parliament also asks the Council to consult Parliament if it intends to substantially amend the Commission's proposal. I support this Commission proposal with the proposed amendments, as I consider this to be a quality change aimed at a more clearly worded decision. The content of the decision essentially remains the same.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision imposing temporary measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Sweden. Sweden is facing a state of emergency as a result of the refugee and migrant crisis, with large numbers of third-country nationals arriving in its country. I support the proposed amendment, which defines Sweden as a first arrival country and destination, while also clearly defining the number of applicants for international protection per capita in the EU by March 2016.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 When voting on temporary measures in the field of international protection in favour of Sweden, I supported the intention to suspend Sweden's participation in the relocation programme for a period of 1 year, as this is not about removing Sweden from this mechanism, but merely temporarily suspending its participation in order to give Sweden, which has already taken in the largest number of migrants per population, time and space to cope.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. On the one hand, we fully recognise that Sweden has played a key role in tackling the refugee crisis, and has accepted a large number of refugees on its territory, which we welcome. We are even clear in our positions when we demand that all EU Member States do the same and assume their responsibilities for support and solidarity with both refugees and the Member States that have accepted the greatest burden of the refugee waves.  However, as a group we voted against Sweden's special treatment of refugees. Responsibilities must be shared with everyone according to their capabilities and Member States must show solidarity with each other. If some states do not behave in this way, they should be pressured to do so, and not to start giving special arrangements to the states that do so.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 It is oxymoron and tragic when a Member State invokes the principles of proportionality and subsidiarity in order to suspend its obligations under international treaties, in particular the Union Code.  The illegal immigration issue was addressed on the basis of the wrong decisions of the three institutions: the Council of Europe, the Commission and the EC, where Sweden is actively involved, so that it could correct the gaps in political decisions, particularly on the question of quota.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Hungarian Delegation of the People's Party supported sweden's exemption in accordance with Article 9 of the Decision on transitional measures in the field of international protection in favour of Italy and Greece, because this exemption proves that the transitional measures adopted in the original decision, the mandatory distribution of quotas to migrants, are not suitable for dealing with the problem. The system established in the decision is inoperable, migrants reach countries that pay higher social care fees, e.g. sweden, irrespective of the allocation by quota. To date, it has not been possible to distribute more than a few hundred migrants instead of the tens of thousands targeted because of the shortcomings of the system, so these transitional measures should be suspended as soon as possible and all Member States should be exempted from the mandatory allocation mechanism according to quotas.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the Keller report, given that it does not propose granting Sweden a one-year transitional exception under the Commission's proposal of December 2015 from the relocation quota system for refugees arriving in Europe. I have considered the fact that Sweden has undoubtedly assumed a significant burden in terms of accepting refugees compared to many other Member States, but other Member States, especially in the south, have been facing an even more serious situation for a long time, while sweden's burdens are not actually reaching crisis levels, taking into account the country's financial capacity. Furthermore, as a Hungarian opposition MEMBER, I had to be particularly careful in this decision that such a benefit should not set a precedent for breaking the EU solidarity requirement, as it could serve as a concrete reference for the Hungarian Government's ongoing anti-refugee and anti-EU campaign. Such an exception for Swedes could also subsequently make a similar claim on the part of other Member States questioning the relocation system, which could fundamentally de-believe joint EU efforts to manage the refugee wave effectively and sustained.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The refugee crisis affecting the European Union over the past year has had significant effects on certain states, which have had to take in more refugees than usual. One of these countries is Sweden, where the number of refugees has increased exponentially in recent times, being one of the favourite targets of asylum seekers. Specifically, between 2015 and 2016, the number of refugees arriving in Sweden increased by 60%, with 39,055 asylum applications registered in October 2015 alone. Furthermore, in March 2016, the number of applications increased to 170,104, of which 73,331 were children, with 36,181 being unaccompanied minors. Faced with this influx, Sweden has requested the Commission's support to be exempted from the proposed EU resettlement scheme for at least one year. The Commission agreed to this temporary measure to allow Sweden to provide asylum seekers with adequate access to healthcare, decent housing and education, in line with EU rules in this area. However, in view of the difficult situation currently facing Greece and Italy, the exemption of Sweden from the resettlement scheme constitutes discrimination between Member States. For this reason, I agree with the rejection of the Commission's decision.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported Mr Skeller's report on the Council's proposal for a decision establishing interim measures on international protection for Sweden, article 9 of the Council's 2015/1523 decision (EU) and Article 9 of the Council's Decision (EU) 2015/1601 establishing interim measures on international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstain on the Commission decision to suspend Sweden from its obligation under the relocation scheme from Italy or Greece to Sweden for one year. Indeed, although I am not in favour of the scheme, I am against suspending obligations under it. In December 2015, Sweden notified the Commission of an emergency situation based on an influx of third country nationals and asked for a suspension of its obligations under the relocation decisions.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒As part of the common asylum policy, Article 78(3) of the EIA The Treaty on the Functioning of the EU (TFEU) provides for a specific legal basis for dealing with crisis situations. Accordingly, on the basis of a proposal from the European Commission and after consulting the European Parliament, the Council may adopt interim measures for the benefit of or several Member States facing a crisis situation due to the sudden influx of third-country nationals into one or more Member States.  Given that Sweden has formally requested the suspension of its obligations as it is in a crisis situation due to the sudden influx of third-country nationals into its territory, I have supported interim measures in the area of international protection for Sweden's benefit. Namely, Sweden faces a double challenge and a problem, as it is also a country of first entry but also a final destination. I therefore consider it correct the Commission's recommendation that the swedish quota be suspended for one year.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Proposal for a Council Decision imposing interim measures in the field of international protection in favour of Sweden in accordance with Article 9 of Council Decision (EU) 2015/1523 and Article 9 of Council Decision (EU) 2015/1601 imposing interim measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Italy and Greece. Sweden is facing an emergency situation resulting from the sudden arrival of third-country nationals on its territory.
