Sweden had by far the highest number of applicants for international protection per capita in the EU in 2015 (11,503 applicants per million inhabitants), and by March 2016 a total of 170,104 applications had been accepted. Sweden is also facing a difficult situation due to the recent increase in the number of unaccompanied minors who have special needs and need additional resources to ensure their access to medical care, decent accommodation and education in accordance with Union asylum rules.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Report on provisional measures at the international level for the benefit of Sweden. This is a proposal for an amendment to a Council decision adopted in 2015, which lays down provisional measures for the benefit of Member States in an emergency situation characterised by a massive influx of third-country nationals in one or more Member States, also known as "temporary scheme relocation". This amendment to the relocation scheme was submitted by the Commission in December, following the Swedish Government's requirement to benefit from this relocation scheme. The original request of the Swedish Government in November was to benefit from this mechanism such as Greece and Italy. However, this request was rejected by the Commission, which, on the contrary, agreed with the one-year suspension for the "obligation" to relocate those applying to Sweden (1369 people).

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The LIBE Committee adopted a report on the Council's proposed decision establishing interim measures on international protection for Sweden. MePs stated in the recitals that Sweden has formally requested the suspension of its obligations because of the dual challenge it faces, that of first-arrival and final destination; whereas in March 2016, Sweden took in a total of 170,104 asylum seekers, including 73,331 children, including 36,181 unaccompanied minors, who have special needs and require additional resources for access to health care, dignified housing and education, in accordance with EU asylum rules. The Swedish government's position is hypocritical, as successive governments in that country have systematically encouraged and facilitated mass immigration. If Sweden does not meet its quota of migrants, they will be relocated elsewhere in the European Union. I have always been opposed to the EU's policy of distributing migrants. I therefore vote against this report.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 As early as last year, when decisions were taken that are now being challenged by successive countries as impossible to fulfil, I pointed out to the European Parliament that the relocation mechanism would be inefficient because it is too arbitrary in its assumptions and does not take into account the social context. Today, too, I find no serious reason to defend a decision that was already wrong at the time. Sweden's request to suspend last year's decisions is justified in the country's asylum situation, which is why I support the European Commission's request on this matter, which is in favour of Sweden's request.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Sweden is also facing an emergency in recent times, characterised by a sudden influx of third-country nationals into the country due to a significant change in migratory flows. I supported the relevant document in accordance with S&D's position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Report on provisional measures at the international level for the benefit of Sweden. This is a proposal for an amendment to a Council decision adopted in 2015, which lays down provisional measures for the benefit of Member States in an emergency situation characterised by a massive influx of third-country nationals in one or more Member States, also known as "temporary scheme relocation". This amendment to the relocation scheme was submitted by the Commission in December, following the Swedish Government's requirement to benefit from this relocation scheme. The original request of the Swedish Government in November was to benefit from this mechanism such as Greece and Italy. However, this request was rejected by the Commission, which, on the contrary, agreed with the one-year suspension for the "obligation" to relocate those applying to Sweden (1369 people).

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. In a context of a significant deterioration of the situation, conditions and erosion of rights for asylum seekers in Greece and more generally in Europe, coupled with the extremely slow progress of relocations in practice, with only 1 500 people relocated across Europe since the launch of the scheme (state of play as at 13 May 2016), Member States’ commitment to solidarity and responsibility needs to be renewed and urgently strengthened. Supporting the Commission proposal to exempt Sweden from the obligation to accept people to be relocated from Greece and Italy would further undermine Member States’ commitment to solidarity and responsibility sharing.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – Sweden has been in a state of emergency due to the sudden influx of third-country nationals as a result of the sudden change in migration flows. Sweden faces problems both as a country of first entry and as a country of final destination.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the report on the proposal for a Council decision establishing provisional measures in the area of international protection for the benefit of Sweden. Sweden faces an emergency situation characterised by a sudden inflow of nationals of third countries in its territory due to a sharp shift of migratory flows, and furthermore faces both challenges of being a country of first arrival and final destination. In March 2016 Sweden received a total of 170 104 applicants, of whom 73 331 were children, including 36 181 unaccompanied minors, who have special needs and require additional resources in order to provide access to health care, dignified accommodation and education according to Union asylum rules. Nevertheless, I believe that the situation that Sweden faces does not require special provisional measures, such as the ones envisioned in the case of Greece and Italy, and that is why I voted against this report.

name: Bodil Valero (Verts/ALE)
text: Written. \u2012 In today's vote, we decided whether Sweden should be granted an exemption from receiving its share of the refugees to be redistributed to Sweden from Italy and Greece. We chose to vote against for two main reasons. Sweden has been one of the EU countries that has been pushing for a binding, solidarity-based and fair distribution system and for the temporary redistribution mechanism of 160,000 refugees. The principle itself is based on the fact that the mechanism is binding and that everyone receives their share. Member States have two years to implement this redistribution. The fact that Sweden is asking for a one-year derogation in this situation reduces our credibility in the further efforts to agree on a genuine asylum policy of solidarity. Since the ID checks were introduced, the number of refugees coming to Sweden has decreased drastically, which gives better conditions to receive refugees now. In the light of the deteriorating situation of asylum seekers in Greece, we do not believe that there is any reason to grant derogations to any Member State now. Instead, the focus must be on getting all Member States to fulfil their obligation to participate in the relocation scheme. We hope that Sweden will continue to show the way towards a fair asylum policy.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The Council of the European Union has decided on the distribution of asylum seekers and refugees who have entered the EU among EU Member States, to which Sweden has contributed to the temporary suspension of implementation. By suspending its obligations, Sweden is advocating an investigation into the situation in its own country, as during 2015 more than 160,000 asylum seekers and refugees arrived and received in Sweden. Sweden considers itself to be in an emergency caused by the sudden mass arrival of third-country nationals on its territory as a result of a sharp change in migratory flows. I supported the temporary suspension of implementation of the Council decision requested by Sweden. I believe that Europe has failed to deal with the refugee crisis and that the Dublin Agreement should be respected with all the greater precision.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Sweden has taken in the most refugees in recent months in proportion to its population, and this is what the Swedish government is now using to demand that it suspend its participation in the mechanism for relocating asylum seekers from Greece and Italy to other states. The Commission rejected this request and returned with a compromise: that of suspending this mechanism for one year. The rapporteur, Ska Keller, initially proposed an outright rejection of this temporary exemption, but this was not adopted in the LIBE committee vote. Since the beginning of this humanitarian 'crisis', I maintain that Member States must show solidarity as demanded by European citizens. They must stop focusing on national interests and take responsibility for the urgency of the situation and this should continue to concern Sweden. Granting it an exemption regime leads to sending the wrong signal to other Member States that refuses any solidarity effort. The GUE/NGL tabled an amendment to reject this exemption, which was not adopted. I therefore voted against this resolution, which echoes the Commission's compromise proposal.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The draft report takes into account that Sweden has done more than most other Member States to protect refugees and that no other Member State has more asylum applications per capita than Sweden. In this respect, Sweden has been one of the main examples for the other Member States. However, given the deteriorating situation of asylum seekers in Greece, all Member States must fulfil their commitment to solidarity and sharing of responsibilities and therefore no Member State should be suspended from its relocation obligation. At the same time, it should be considered that Sweden should not be obliged to re-place unaccompanied minors due to the exceptionally high number of unaccompanied minors already in Sweden. It is also regrettable that Decision (EU) 2015/1601 provides for the possibility for the Council to take decisions on the implementation of relocations without consulting the European Parliament and that the Council has therefore unilaterally decided to suspend Austria from its relocation obligation.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. The application concerns amendments to the original application, which calls for additional resources to be made possible for the care of unaccompanied minors in terms of health care, accommodation and education. Although Keller rejects the original application, it is only for Sweden to fulfil its "obligations" as a "positive example of an asylum country".

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. The vote on this resolution is a double-edged sword. Those who agree are conceding that the EU dictates Sweden's domestic policy: Commission officials and EU parliamentarians from 27 other Member States in Brussels decide on Sweden, but not the national government and the Reichstag in Stockholm. That is why I voted against the resolution. Sweden– like all other EU Member States, should be able to take on its own the domestic policies that Parliament and government consider necessary to protect the state and citizens from uncontrolled mass immigration and the consequences that are now incalculable. Finally, Sweden can still (temporarily) withdraw from the Schengen compromise. But this is the decision that the Swedes, not the Eurocrats, make.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The European Parliamentary Group of the Communist Party of Greece voted against suspending Sweden's participation in the obligations arising from the Council's decisions on the 'relocation of refugees'.  It is confirmed that after the capitalist states choose those who need their domestic monopolies, then they inhumanely "close" the borders. Those who for so long in the European Parliament have been indulging in over-hypocritical statements about so-called 'solidarity' in favour of refugees are now putting their stamp on a decision that brutally violates their rights. These decisions by the EU and the civil governments intensify the entrapment of thousands of refugees and migrants in the first host countries - if they escape the long-dead enclaves - in camps where even the minimum living conditions are not respected, without drinking water, without or with inappropriate food, in mud and garbage dumps.  The Communist Party of Greece takes aim at the real cause of the refugee crisis, which is imperialist interventions and capitalist barbarism, and supports in every way the refugees' demands for: safe movement to the countries of final destination, recognition of refugee status to all peoples who have been attacked imperialist, human treatment, open and humane, state-organized, places of hospitality.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The mechanism for the forced relocation of so-called 'refugees' is a harmful utopia which, in addition to deepening the political crisis facing the European Union, will not solve the uncontrolled influx of migrants into Europe. It is contrary to common sense to force Member States to accept predetermined amounts of immigrants without taking into account their economic or social situation. This system cannot work in practice. The government's request in Stockholm is justified, albeit for completely different reasons than the Swedes themselves think. Indeed, it is difficult not to get the impression that the huge number of immigrants currently in Sweden is the fault of the bad policy pursued by the Swedish government.  However, I believe that, despite this context, this proposal should be supported and thus the policy of forced relocation should be opposed as an idea pushed by the European Commission. In any similar case where a Member State wishs to call into question the meaning of the existence of such a mechanism, such a request should be supported. We must send a clear signal discouraging potential immigrants from attempting to cross the EU border illegally. The first step to solved the current crisis is to effectively stem new waves of refugees. Consent to forced relocation will prevent this purpose. Of course, we must help our partners to deal with the problem that has affected them, but only in a way that does not mean an increase in the level of danger to the citizens of the other Member States.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a Council decision imposing interim measures in the field of international protection for the benefit of Sweden in accordance with Article 9 of Council Decision (EU) 2015/1523. The Purpose of the Council Decision is to suspend Sweden's obligations as a Member State in relation to the relocation of asylum seekers to its territory for a period of one year, as Sweden is facing an emergency situation due to the sudden influx of third-country nationals into its territory as a result of drastic changes in migratory flows.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Transatlantic relations, or relations between the European Union and the US, as well as the EU and Canada, are the world's busiest, and it must be said that the most financial, economically-voluminous relationship is also the case. For example, the flow of data between the EU and the US amounts to about 15 terabits per second, such a connection exceeding the flow between any other region in the world. As part of the motion for a resolution, it would be worth noting that in 2014 US imports of digitally provided services from the European Union accounted for 54% of total bilateral trade in services. In other words, the security of transatlantic data flows must be one of the most important places in EU-US relations, which is also particularly relevant to the TTIP negotiations. But, of course, I support this document and I believe that it is very much needed by the European Union.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cross-border data flows between the EU and the US are the most intense in the world, representing, among other things, an essential component in trade relations. In this regard, in a judgment of October 2015, the European Court of Justice ruled that THE EU-US negotiations must take into account privacy guarantees, thus fulfilling the requirements of legal certainty. The protection of personal data is, in fact, a fundamental right, formally recognised in the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the TFEI. In view of the fact that the new agreement is clearly at odds with the Court's rulings, I voted against the motion for a resolution, considering it of the utmost importance to ensure respect for the privacy and inviolability of personal data.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. In the context of the transatlantic treaty negotiations between the European Union and the United States, the issue of protecting the personal data of Europeans is more than ever at the centre of the debate. However, in its judgment of 6 October 2015, the European Court of Justice invalidated the Commission's decision on the relevance of the levels of protection provided by the Safe Harbor principles, published by the Us American Ministry of Commerce. While the Commission and the US government have referred to a "privacy shield", the joint resolution which tends to support this idea seems very optimistic about the possibility of moving the Americans on this point. I therefore supported the first resolution, which criticises the lack of provisions on private protection. On the other hand, I voted against the final motion for a resolution, which only very generally refers to principles and considerations without requiring sufficient guarantees. The protection of the personal data of our citizens is paramount.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the motion for a resolution which concerned the new EU-US Privacy Shield. This is an agreement which is a Commission proposal to create a new framework for exchange of data. It follows from the invalidation of the Safe Harbour agreement last year. This Privacy Shield agreement will not effectively shield citizens’ privacy rights. Privacy Shield does still allow US intelligence to collect massive and indiscriminate data, however, and it is expected that new challenges could be brought to the Court. Obama Policy Directive 28/2014 indicates the following six instances in which collection of large quantities of signals intelligence data is authorised: (1) Espionage and other threats and activities directed by foreign powers or their intelligence services against the United States and its interests; (2) Threats to the United States and its interests from terrorism; (3) Threats to the United States and its interests from the development, possession, proliferation, or use of weapons of mass destruction; (4) Cybersecurity threats; (5) Threats to U.S. or allied Armed Forces or other U.S or allied personnel; and (6) Transnational criminal threats, including illicit finance and sanctions evasion related to the other purposes named in this section.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This joint resolution was tabled by the EPP, the Socialists, the Liberals and the ECR and EFDD groups. In its judgment of 6 October 2015, the European Court of Justice invalidated the Commission's decision on the appropriateness of the levels of protection provided by the Safe Harbor principles published by the Us American Ministry of Commerce. The Commission and the US government must make substantial improvements in the "privacy shield". The joint resolution starts from this principle, and supports the process. There are many positives, but it seems optimistic about the possibility of getting Americans moving. The Greens' resolution is critical and concerned that the "privacy shield" scheme cannot fully meet the obligations of the Charter, the Directive, the General Data Protection Regulation and the rulings on the matter by the European Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights. We are in favour of a maximum level of data protection and the privacy of our citizens, so we support the Greens' text. Since the Greens' resolution was rejected, I voted against the joint resolution.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for the Commissioner to get involved in legislating for any data exchanged between the United States and the EU. The United States lacks a comprehensive Data Protection Act compared to the UK. I believe blanket permission clauses are negative to data protection rights. I abstained on this resolution as a whole.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Court of Justice set aside the EU-US Data Protection Convention (Safe Harbour) in a judgment of 6 October 2015. According to the Court of Justice, the Convention does not provide adequate protection of the data of EU citizens, does not prevent mass surveillance and does not provide adequate judicial redress against them. The European Commission and the US authorities have worked together on a new so-called Privacy Shield agreement. Behind this agreement is the intention to prevent national authorities from setting rules to prevent the transfer of private data of people living in the EU to the US following the abolition of Safe Harbour. We must see this intention as a restriction on national self-determination. A fundamental objection is that, in the draft treaty, the US-appointed Ombudsman is not an appropriate institution to provide, without bias, redress in the event of a conflict between US authorities and EU citizens. NGO analysis shows that the new treaty could also contribute to the bulk collection of data by the U.S. Secret Service. The concerns listed in the joint motion for a resolution are mentioned only on a mention basis, not as a definite requirement. Support for the decision thus sends a message that Parliament agrees with the conclusion of the agreement in question. Accordingly, I voted against the motion.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP are principally against the EU taking charge of transatlantic data exchange above Member State co-operation. This particular motion for a resolution we loosely support in the sense that it does empower citizens against the very ‘flexible’ data protection laws of the US. Therefore we voted against the original Green motion for a resolution based on the principle that this should be done by Member States and not the EU. But we abstained on certain amendments that were tabled because it does protect citizens from very loose data protection standards from the US.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Since the cancellation of Safe Harbour, there has been a legal vacuum regarding the exploitation of personal data of European citizens by the United States. The Privacy Shields agreement negotiated between the Commission and the United States provides some sort of redress to this situation. It sets up a redress mechanism for European citizens and establishes an American mediator to which the European side can resort in the event of a challenge. Nevertheless, the European Parliament will have to remain extremely vigilant to ensure that the personal data of European citizens is effectively protected.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union recognises among its fundamental rights that of data protection, a right enshrined in Article 8 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and reiterated in a judgment of the Court of Justice which defined as an adequate level of protection, in the exchange of data with third countries, a level essentially equivalent to that guaranteed by the EU.  The joint resolution on the flow of transatlantic data, which I supported in Parliament today, addresses this issue by emphasising the need to conclude negotiations on the EU-US Privacy Shield, primarily ensuring legal certainty on how to transfer personal data from the EU to the US. This is essential to promote not only increased consumer confidence but also transatlantic business development and international cooperation.  The Commission must continue its dialogue with the US administration in order to further improve the Privacy Shield Agreement, overcoming its shortcomings, which have been precisely highlighted by the national data protection institutions. In this way, it will be possible to strengthen even more an economic link which, in terms of the size of trade, is the first in the world, while maintaining a high level of protection for citizens.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Motion for a Resolution on transatlantic data flows, because we understand that it focuses on the legal certainty of the transfer of personal data between the Union and the US and, the right to information is not balanced, with the right to consumer privacy. Our group tabled an amendment to introduce improvements in the field of privacy and consumer rights, related to the protection of personal data. The amendment did not go ahead, so we did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's Resolution on Transatlantic Data Flows, which points to the shortcomings in the data protection agreement that the European Union negotiates with the United States, the so-called "Privacy Shield". It values the efforts made by the Commission and considers substantial improvements compared to "Safe Harbor", but there are still shortcomings, including the us authorities' access to the information transferred and the possibility of collecting data in bulk in some cases, which does not meet the criteria of necessity and proportionality set out in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the resolution tabled by the Green Group and against the joint resolution of the other political groups on the transatlantic data flow. The Greens' resolution has the merit of being more demanding in terms of the protection of personal data. It requires the Commission to ensure compliance with the ECJ's 6 October 2015 ruling, which stipulates that an adequate level of data protection is a level "substantially equivalent" to that of the European Union, which, in this case, is not the case for the United States. The Court therefore struck down the Commission's decision on the adequacy of the levels of protection provided by the Safe Harbor principles published by the U.S. Department of Commerce. The joint resolution tabled by the other political groups seems to me to be very optimistic about the ability of the Americans to improve this level of protection.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the resolution on transatlantic data transfers appears well structured and without any critical issues, which is why I wanted to support it with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. In the wake of Max Schrems' complaint, the EU Court of Justice ruled last October that the agreement regulating the transmission of data from European citizens to the US has not provided sufficient protection since 2000.  Last February, the Commission introduced the new agreement with the US, known as privacy shield, to regulate transatlantic data flows, a new framework that makes significant progress on the previous scheme, as it includes strict obligations for businesses, clearer safeguards and transparency obligations in terms of access by the US administration, greater protection of the rights of EU citizens (the US has approved the Judicial Redress Act , which extends access to European citizens to the courts of that country) and an annual joint review mechanism. However, as established by the Parliamentary Resolution, which I supported, the Article 29 Working Group has expressed its deep concern about the trade aspects and public authorities' access to data transferred under the Privacy Shield, and the Commission is therefore requested to fully implement the recommendations of this Group in order to avoid future further annulment.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament stresses the importance of transatlantic relations, which are essential for both partners. Stresses, furthermore, that a comprehensive decision between the US and the EU should respect the right to data protection and the right to privacy. One of the EU's main objectives is the protection of personal data, including when transferred to its main international trading partner, and Parliament insists that the 'security shield' procedure is in line with EU primary and secondary law, as well as the relevant judgments of the Court of Justice of the European Union and the European Court of Human Rights. The European Parliament recognises that the Privacy Shield is part of a broader dialogue between the EU and third countries, including the United States, on data privacy, trade, security and related rights and related rights and shared interests, and therefore calls on all parties to work together to develop and sustainably improve effective and common international frameworks and national legislation to achieve those objectives. Furthermore, insists that legal certainty regarding the transfer of personal data between the EU and the US is essential to ensure consumer confidence, transatlantic business development and law enforcement cooperation, and therefore, in order for data to be transmitted efficiently and over a long period of time, measures involving this transfer must be consistent with EU primary and secondary law.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ I also supported the resolution on the transatlantic data flow, by which the European Parliament welcomes the efforts of the Commission and the competent authorities in the US to significantly improve the protection of privacy in the exchange of data between Europe and the US. Both sides must strive for respect for the right to data protection and the right to privacy. The EU must maintain the highest level of protection of personal data even after it has been transposed to the other side of the Atlantic, regardless of the purpose of its use.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Personal data entered on the network must be properly protected and in any case their use for commercial purposes must be regulated. Of particular importance is the management of this data when it is transferred from the European Union to the United States, where there is a different privacy and personal data regulation. In this resolution, Parliament welcomes the progress that the new Privacy Shield agreement would present in relation to the old 'Safe Harbour'. However, it is highlighted that some gaps still present in certain sensitive areas, such as access by public authorities to transferred data, or the possibility of collecting a quantity of data that may not meet the criteria laid down in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, should be filled.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the EU-US agreements on transatlantic data flows represent a good step forward compared to the discipline of the past but that they need greater protection with regard to the protection of the confidentiality of European citizens' data.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. In the context of the transatlantic negotiations between the European Union and the United States, the issue around the levels of data protection of our compatriots has never been more topical.  However, in a judgment dated 6 October 2015, the European Court of Justice invalidated the European Commission's decision to recognise the relevance of levels of protection provided by the US Secretary of State for Trade. The Court asked the Commission to make substantial improvements in the "privacy shield".  If we supported the first motion for a resolution to criticise very harshly the inadequacy of the data protection provisions, we can only approve the following which merely list overly general considerations without requiring sufficient safeguards, particularly on the sunset clause. I voted against the final motion for a resolution.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The development of the information society and e-commerce, as well as the development of intelligence agencies' interception capabilities, have led, worldwide, to an exponential increase in data transfers, but at the same time to an increase in the risks associated with the misuse of such data. This type of abusive communication not only serves to curb the development of e-commerce because it undermines consumer confidence, but sometimes constitutes a violation of citizens' rights and freedoms and, in particular, constitutes a violation of the right to privacy. Thus, it is pointed out that both the Privacy Shield Mechanism and the situation in the USA do not make sufficient improvements compared to the safe harbor.  I voted in favour of the resolution on transatlantic data flows because I believe it is very beneficial for EU states, and it is essential to develop e-commerce for better cooperation between states and, last but not least, for the development of the EU.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The wide-ranging debate on data protection includes the issue of the EU-US Privacy Shield agreement, to protect the privacy of European citizens whose personal data is transferred to the United States for commercial purposes.  We find this joint resolution a good compromise between the ultra-guarantor approach to the right to privacy for EU citizens and the approach that emphasises the need to reach an agreement in an increasingly fundamental area such as data protection.  Following the annulment by the Court of Justice of the European Union, in its judgment of 6 October 2015 in Case C-362/14 Maximillian Schrems/Data Protection Commissioner, it was stated that an adequate level of protection in a third country must be interpreted as "substantially equivalent" to the protection provided in the Union. This makes it necessary for the shield (now being negotiated between the EU-US) to ensure legal certainty as to how personal data is transferred from the EU to the US. Abstention vote.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The US-US/European Union data protection shield will protect the fundamental data and rights of European citizens while providing legal certainty for businesses. The latter is essential for SMEs, which, because of their size, are often more vulnerable. This shield should replace the Safe Harbour decision that was invalidated in 2015 by the European Court of Justice because it did not allow for optimal protection of the data of European citizens.  The resolution welcomes the efforts of the European and American authorities to significantly improve the protection of the fundamental rights of European citizens in the decision. The text recognises the need for a legal framework for the protection of personal data between the United States and the European Union.  However, we must ensure that the agreement does not compromise the interests of European businesses and SMEs and protects European citizens. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reflection and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on transatlantic data flows, Statements by the Council and the Commission, in view of the following assessments: - the new body of legislation for transatlantic data flows seems to have taken up the challenge of ensuring over-atlantic protection of personal data and development of business activities; - the strict obligations imposed on companies on the personal data of European citizens and the monitoring of compliance with these obligations must therefore be respected, but first of all the transparency obligations on the United States must be highlighted by means of truly effective redress procedures; - there is, in fact, the impossibility of effective national 'domestic' control and, in the event of a possible infringement, the role of the Commission remains emphasised, which I hope will not again await the Court of Justice.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this resolution, which sought to set out the European Parliament’s position in relation to a new framework for transatlantic exchanges of personal data. This new framework comes up for discussion again after the Safe Harbour agreement was invalidated next year. I was prepared to vote in favour of the resolution, however two vitally important amendments were lost, so I withdrew my support for the final vote. The amendments concerned had called for a sunset clause to be included, and for negotiations on an improved basis to take place on the basis of the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation – the very Regulation that the Safe Harbour agreement had contravened. As I did not find the joint resolution to be nearly critical enough of the mass collection of large quantities of data, and as these amendments were not included, I voted against.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP are principally against the EU taking charge of transatlantic data exchange above Member State co-operation. This particular motion for a resolution we loosely support in the sense that it does empower citizens against the very ‘flexible’ data protection laws of the US. Therefore we voted against the original Green motion for a resolution based on the principle that this should be done by Member States and not the EU. But we abstained on certain amendments that were tabled because it does protect citizens from very loose data protection standards from the US.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution in order to show my support for the agreement between the European Commission and the Government of the United States on transfers of data between the EU and the US, the Privacy Shield. This is a significant improvement on our previous agreement, the Safe Harbour, and is bound to be of great benefit for consumers and businesses, most importantly small and medium-sized enterprises. I am also content that the protection of personal data of EU citizens will be better protected than before.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cross-border data flows between the EU and the US are an essential component of trade relations.  A ruling by the Court of Justice of the European Union in October 2015 ruled that EU-US negotiations must take into account privacy guarantees, thus fulfilling the requirements of legal certainty. The protection of personal data is, in fact, a fundamental right, formally recognised in the Charter of Fundamental Rights and the TFEI.  In view of the fact that this agreement is clearly contrary to the Court's rulings, I voted against the motion for a resolution, considering it essential to ensure respect for the privacy and inviolability of personal data.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it is, in my view, absolutely necessary to enhance safe data flows between the EU and the US. The mutual exchange is by far largest in the world and is essential for businesses, mainly for SMEs, with regards to their activities overseas. We have to keep our level of personal data protection while, at the same time, not blocking trade opportunities on both sides of the Atlantic. It is legal certainty, clear and uniform rules we call for which should be key benefits of the proposed privacy shield.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support efforts for a new US-EU agreement on the transfer of European data to the US. We stress, however, that the new agreement that has been proposed, known as 'Privacy Shield', should guarantee effective protection of the privacy rights of European citizens.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The motion for a resolution on transatlantic data flows is an issue of the utmost importance to the citizens of both Europe and the UNITED States.  While we recognise the need for both sides to cope with the dizzying speeds at which modern technology is developing, as well as the need to deal effectively with illegal actions, I do not think that the protection of citizens' personal data and freedoms, which is a fundamental stone of Europe, is not at the forefront.  I therefore voted against it.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution because I believe that two principles must be taken into account in relations with the United States: the first is that it is the market that is most homogeneous to ours, as well as the largest (in macroeconomic terms, i.e. total income) and therefore increasing trade allows us to expand the market for our products; the second is that the money we earn from increased trade must not buy our values and dignity. In the face of the explosion in data traffic that has taken place in recent years, we cannot fail to be concerned that both stakes mentioned are very firm: therefore, conditions are welcome that allow us to trade, but that these are also conditions compatible with our standards.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The Privacy Shield is part of a broader dialogue between the EU and third countries, including the United States, in relation to data privacy, trade, security and related rights and objectives of shared interests. We need to call on all parties therefore to work together towards the creation and sustained improvement of workable, common international frameworks and domestic legislation that achieve those objectives.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP are principally against the EU taking charge of transatlantic data exchange above Member State cooperation. This particular motion for a resolution we loosely support in the sense that it does empower citizens against the very ‘flexible’ data protection laws of the US. Therefore we voted against the original Green motion for a resolution based on the principle that this should be done by Member States and not the EU. But we abstained on certain amendments that were tabled because it does protect citizens from very loose data protection standards from the US.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP are principally against the EU taking charge of transatlantic data exchange above Member State cooperation. This particular motion for a resolution we loosely support in the sense that it does empower citizens against the very ‘flexible’ data protection laws of the US. Therefore we voted against the original Green motion for a resolution based on the principle that this should be done by Member States and not the EU. But we abstained on certain amendments that were tabled because it does protect citizens from very loose data protection standards from the US.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the growth of international network trade, the free movement of data across borders is crucial for trade and investment by the European Union and the United States.  However, it is necessary to ensure the protection of users' privacy by adopting a regulation protecting personal data, ensuring that the fundamental rights of EU data subjects are protected in the transfer of data for the purposes of international trade. I also believe that legal certainty and the existence of clear and uniform rules are essential for the development and growth of businesses, especially SMEs.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that the Privacy Shield will help ensure that the fundamental rights of EU data subjects are protected during data transfer. This is crucial in bridging the gap between European and American approaches to privacy which is essential for rebuilding transatlantic trust. It is only through this confidence that an established framework for compliance can be reached. Business-to-business transatlantic transactions and services are a reality, with free flow of data for intracompany purposes becoming a daily occurrence, and investment in data centres that provide access to the cloud in the US and the EU relying on cross-border data flows. The digitisation of the US and EU economies renders the cross-border flow of data a key element in the competitiveness of businesses domestically and globally, in particular for those engaging in e-commerce. I therefore support an adequate level of protection of EU personal data. There is a degree of information which would be invalid, hence through the Privacy Shield we can obtain legal certainty on how personal data should be transferred from the EU to the US.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against the resolution because none of the measures necessary to safeguard adequate levels of personal data protection are proposed therein. In the face of the numerous scandals of mass espionage of European citizens by the US authorities in the face of the passivity of EU governments, a strong position of rejection is urgent. In addition, the resolution has been a missed opportunity to defend European data protection standards, which will be significantly reduced if TTIP is adopted.  We are also concerned about the insufficient content about espionage carried out by private companies, and the transfer of personal data to or between them. The purchase and sale of personal data is an increasingly strong economic sector that must be strictly regulated and limited or we run the risk of losing the right to privacy.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Protecting data means protecting people, their right to privacy, security, the freedom to exercise professional activities freely. Similarly, legal certainty and clear rules in data transfer are crucial for the development and growth of businesses, particularly SMEs. In this context, transatlantic data flows, which are among the most intense in the world and the exchange of personal data, are an essential component of the union's links with the United States.  It is extremely important, in a digital age, which is not just a digital economy, to strengthen confidence and security in data exchange and to ensure legal certainty for businesses, consumers and citizens, on the basis of a sound legal framework, based on data protection regimes equivalent and less vulnerable than criminal use. In this respect, the Commission has done an important job.  It is in the interests of authorities, businesses and citizens, both European and American, to create a legal, coherent and stable regime. There are still points to be clarified and procedures to be simplified, and that is why we call on the Commission not to interrupt the dialogue with the overseas authorities on the Privacy Shield by removing the remaining shortcomings as well.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Data flows are an essential element of the EU's security, economic and trade relations. SMEs accounted for 60% of companies relying on a secure data transfer agreement that allowed them to benefit from targeted and cost-effective compliance requirements. There are already agreements on the exchange of information in certain policy areas, including the terrorist finance tracking programme and the EU-US Agreement on Passenger Name Record data. Following the ECJ ruling in the Schrems case and in response to allegations of mass surveillance, since 2013, Congress and the U.S. administration have made more than twenty changes to surveillance laws and programs. The reforms include the US Freedom Act, which prohibits bulk data collection, the President's Regulation (PPD-28), which states that the protection of the privacy and civil liberties of non-EU citizens is an integral part of US surveillance policy, and the Judicial Remedies Act, which extends data protections to EU citizens.  I personally support the implementation and adoption of the new privacy shield and wish to adopt and implement the EU-US General Umbrella Agreement on Data Protection as soon as possible. I believe that these two agreements guarantee a high level of protection and legal certainty for businesses and consumers, a level that has not yet been achieved.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this Joint Motion for a Resolution on the draft commission decision on the adequacy of the protection in the US provided by the Privacy Shield Principles as I believe that the right to protect ones data from disproportionate use is a fundamental right, in today’s digital-age. The Resolution calls for a balance between security and privacy, and seeks to ensure that citizen’s data is used in a manner which adheres to Europe’s high data-protection standards when it comes to cross-border data flows between the EU and the US. In the past years various issues have been highlighted in various court decisions and conclusions by high level working parties such as the one enshrined within Article 29 of Data Protection Directive. The resolution calls for United States data controllers to comply with the Data Protection Regulation with regards to services offered on the EU market or with regards to the monitoring of persons within the European Union.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. In this resolution, the European Parliament votes in favour of the 'privacy shield', a new agreement on the exchange of data between the United States and the European Union.  Following the Court of Justice's ruling of 6 October 2015, deeming the Level of Data Protection of the European Commission insufficient, a new agreement was proposed to better protect the privacy of European citizens whose data is transferred to the United States for commercial purposes.  This resolution stresses the importance of transatlantic relations and respect for the right to data protection, including personal data.  In support of these objectives, I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution because it met the expectations of my political group. The data flows between the United States and the European Union are the largest in the world. While stressing the importance of providing strong guarantees for the protection of personal data, it is essential to ensure legal certainty for companies, particularly SMEs, which are operating in the transfer of data from the European Union to the United States. However, we call on the European Commission to continue to discuss with the US authorities to make the necessary improvements to ensure that this agreement fully meets all our expectations.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. In a new agreement, the Commission and the US government must make substantial improvements to the "privacy shield". It replaces the "safe harbor" agreement between the European Union and the United States that aimed to protect the data of European citizens, even when they are managed by American companies outside Europe. Both parties must also take into account existing provisions such as the Charter, the Directive, the General Data Protection Regulation and the decisions made in this regard by the European Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights.  For these reasons, I have supported this text which goes in the direction of a maximum level of data protection and the privacy of our citizens.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution as a whole because I am convinced that this is an important recognition of the fact that progress has indeed been made on certain aspects. The fact is that data flows between the EU and the US are strong and very intertwined, which can lead to reduced protection, as we have seen in recent months. I therefore strongly support the adoption of the new privacy shield, which I consider an imperative safeguard in the light of increased transatlantic data exchange, and I welcome the initiatives taken in this regard.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 In providing data protection to transatlantic flows between the US and the EU, a proper basis has so far not been established which is combined with the corresponding protection in all third countries and effectively protects the fundamental rights of people.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. These motions for resolutions follow the decision of the Court of Justice of the EU of 6 October 2015, which found the European Commission's decision 2000/520/EC, known as the Safe Harbor agreement, invalid because it considered that it had obvious implications for amending the rules on the transfer of personal data from the EU to the US. In a context where negotiations on transatlantic free trade agreements are ongoing (for example - TTIP and TiSA), the issue of data transfer is as important as rights such as citizens' privacy, but also the commercialisation of citizens and the internal security of states. These motions for resolutions place the treatment of this issue on a supranational level between the European Commission and the United States of America, underaltering the Member States and, therefore, the imperative need to deal with this issue sovereignly and democratically in each country, in accordance with their legitimate interests. The resolutions do not address a broad range of concerns regarding the protection of personal data. The amendments tabled by our group were partly aimed at addressing these shortcomings. Unfortunately, they were rejected. Hence our vote against.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution as I consider established relations between the EU and the UNITED States to be fundamental and essential. The resolution has the merit of encouraging the Commission to continue negotiations with the US in order to fill the gaps in the Privacy Shield. The existence of clear and uniform rules, together with the introduction of an appeal mechanism under the Privacy Shield, are crucial both for citizens and for the development and growth of businesses, in particular SMEs. The EU Commission and the US administration must commit themselves to making this as simple and effective as possible.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report to protect the privacy of European citizens.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I believe it is fundamental to have clear and detailed information concerning the looming adoption by the Commission of the adequacy decision concerning personal data transfers to the United States, called the Privacy Shield. However, as the text is now, it does not fulfil the criteria laid down for adequacy decisions in the EU data protection law, the Court jurisprudence and the Fundamental Rights Charter. The redress mechanism for individuals under the Privacy Shield is too complex and difficult to use and would therefore render itself ineffective. Moreover, neither the US Federal Trade Commission nor the US Department of Commerce nor the providers of alternative dispute resolution have investigatory powers essentially equivalent to those of European data protection supervisory authorities. I welcome such a regime with the US, but I believe it needs to respect the new Data Protection acquis of the EU, Court jurisprudence, the Fundamental Rights Charter and be completely legally watertight.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution initiated by my fellow members. The protection of personal data, respect for privacy and communication for private purposes, the right to security, the right to know and communicate information and the right to a business are all fundamental rights which, under the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, the EU must protect and balance within the Community. Transatlantic data flows provide an opportunity for the US and the EU to expand trade and investment in the developing world. Thanks to the global growth of internet access, we need to focus on the opportunities for international online trade and on the need for free data flows. Furthermore, the flow of data creates a new opportunity for SMEs to properly participate in international trade and to have better access to new markets on other continents. SMEs can gain the most from the new Privacy Shield and the Commission should therefore be made aware of the need to work closely with data protection authorities to ensure greater clarity, accuracy and accessibility for the companies concerned in the implementation and operation of the Privacy Shield.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the EP's non-legislative resolution on the transfer of data flows because I shared the need for the Commission to continue negotiations with the UNITED States to remedy the shortcomings expressed as a result of the 'Privacy Shield' agreement on the protection of commercial data of EU citizens transferred to the US. The EP resolution, stressing the importance of transatlantic relations, which are essential for partners, also highlights the importance of respecting the right to data protection and confidentiality, as one of the EU's fundamental objectives is the protection of personal data, even when it is transferred to its main trading partner. I strongly supported the need to respect the EU's primary and secondary law and the relevant judgments of the European Court of Justice. Nevertheless, I shared the EP's concern about some important shortcomings in the new agreement proposed by the Commission, in particular with regard to public access to the transferred data, the possibility of collecting a quantity of data that does not meet the criteria of necessity and proportionality and, finally, the complexity of the appeal mechanism. I hope that this mechanism will be made easier to access, effective and, above all, transparent.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution calling on the European Commission to continue negotiations with the US on better protection of citizens' data transferred to the US. The Commission and the US administration are making efforts to improve existing safeguards to protect the privacy of EU citizens whose personal data is disclosed, e.g. when shopping online, across the Atlantic. As the number of transactions increases, the risk that they will be used without the citizen's knowledge, to his detriment, e.g. by intelligence agencies, increases. In order to prevent this, the data protection guaranteed by EU law should be maintained even when the data leave the EU. The sealing of the system is intended to replace the previous transatlantic data transfer system ("Safe Haven") with a new, more effective mechanism (the "Privacy Shield"). Unfortunately, there is no significant improvement. Americans do not guarantee protection at the level required by EU law. They propose the appointment of an ombudsman to the State Department on the redress of Europeans. I doubt that a spokesperson, dependent on us executive power and with too little power, can effectively carry out his duties. The Commission and the US administration should create a more effective and more friendly redress mechanism for European citizens. The Commission should periodically assess the compliance of its privacy decision with EU rules in order to strengthen data protection in the EU.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Transatlantic data exchange between the EU and the US is the largest in the world. Since the ECJ annulled the Save Harbour Agreement, there has been legal uncertainty about how personal data should be transferred from the EU to the US. The Privacy Shield is an important step in protecting our citizens and businesses from randomly transferring their data to the United States. I believe that this monitoring mechanism is an effective way of continuing to ensure important data exchange by introducing certain rules.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Motion for a Resolution on transatlantic data flows, because we understand that it focuses on the legal certainty of the transfer of personal data between the Union and the US and, the right to information is not balanced, with the right to consumer privacy. Our group tabled an amendment to introduce improvements in the field of privacy and consumer rights, related to the protection of personal data. The amendment did not go ahead, so we did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which calls for recommendations in the retail energy market to bring energy prices down, enhance transparency, empower consumers, democratise the energy system and protect the most vulnerable. Energy should be considered as a social right: currently, over 50 million are living in energy poverty in the EU – around 2.3 million in the UK. We need to take action at the EU level so that people do not have to choose between heating, eating or cooling and do not pay more for energy because they are unable to insulate their homes.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The free cross-border data flows between the US and the EU are of paramount importance for US and EU trade and investment, as consumers from the two sides of the Atlantic are increasingly using the internet to purchase goods and services from each other’s marketplaces. Free flow of data for intracompany purposes has become a daily occurrence, and investment in data centres that provide access to the cloud in the US and the EU relies on cross-border data flows.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 We voted in favour since the report notes the need for effective protection of the fundamental rights and personal data of European citizens.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the motions for resolutions regarding transatlantic data flows. Given the huge economic data trade between the EU and the US and given the fact that a huge amount of the data flow is relied on by SMEs, it is necessary that they are regulated in such a way as to ensure the protection of personal data and to ensure that the principles of the European Union are upheld. The legal certainty for the transfer of personal data between the two parties is an essential element for consumer trust, international business development and law enforcement cooperation and therefore it is imperative that any data transfer is in harmony with EU primary and secondary law.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on transatlantic data transfer provides for the launch of a new legal framework that makes the flow of data between the EU and the US binding. This was made necessary by the so-called Schrems ruling of the European Court of Justice.  The renegotiated so-called 'Privacy Shield', which is the basis of the motion for a resolution, takes into account in a very balanced way the interests of data protection of EU citizens, the interests of companies in the use of electronic data and the interests of security services to ensure public security, for example in the fight against terrorism. This will achieve a high level of legal certainty for all sides. I therefore agree with the motion.  Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Privacy Shield Decision, adopted by the Commission, is an improvement to the Safe Habour Decision. However, many changes are necessary to since the text, as it is, does not fulfil the criteria laid down for adequacy decisions in the EU data protection law, the Court jurisprudence and the Fundamental Rights Charter.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒I voted for a joint proposal for a resolution on transatlantic data flow, because the protection of persons' data is one of the fundamental rights of the Union and that it is of utmost importance to take into account the content of the rules applicable in a third country when it comes to the level of protection provided by such a country.  It is necessary to highlight the importance of transatlantic relations and the fact that the cross-border flow of data between Europe and the US is the largest in the world. In this context, legal uncertainty should be prevented and clear and uniform rules should be put in place to improve business development and growth. The EU-Third Country Privacy Shield, and in particular with the US, is essential for the development of transatlantic relations, consumer trust and law enforcement cooperation, and I therefore support this proposal for a resolution.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The Greens' resolution is concerned that the "privacy shield" scheme cannot fully meet the obligations of the charter, the directive, the general data protection regulation and the rulings in this area by the European Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights. From this point of view, it seemed perfectly normal for me to be in favour of it. I voted for the text.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Data sharing is undoubtedly important for the European economy, security and trade. However, the European Union needs to ensure that maximum standards for the protection of personal data are ensured on the PART of the US when sharing such data, and that the rules of the game are clear and uniform. This time it is necessary to have an agreement that, unlike the previous proposal (Safe Harbour), would stand up to litigation. I therefore supported the joint resolution, which asks the Commission, inter alia, to clarify the legal status of the so-called written guarantees by the US and to negotiate further improvements to this agreement.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this joint resolution dealing with the Privacy Shield agreement allowing the transfer of personal data from Europe to the United States. The Privacy Shield was negotiated after the previous safe harbor agreement was invalidated in 2015 by the European Court of Justice. It is particularly urgent to reach a new agreement to guarantee legal certainty for our companies, while strengthening safeguards for respect for the protection of personal data.

name: Εva Kaili (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the motion for a resolution on the Transatlantic flows as it raises the issues of data protection with regards to data flows. Though innovation will be incremental for the EU’s future, we need a solid legal framework protecting our data from being abused. This motion for a resolution raises the concerns of our people. We should always have in mind that if a true Digital Single Market is to be achieved, the trust of the citizens will be the cornerstone.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. This resolution calls for a regular review of the appropriate application of the agreement and its compliance with EU primary and secondary law. However, economic interests are mixed with data protection, without ensuring that this is also appropriate. I am abstaining on this resolution.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on transatlantic data transfer provides for the launch of a new legal framework that makes the flow of data between the EU and the US binding. This was made necessary by the so-called Schrems ruling of the European Court of Justice.  The renegotiated so-called 'Privacy Shield', which is the basis of the motion for a resolution, takes into account in a very balanced way the interests of data protection of EU citizens, the interests of companies in the use of electronic data and the interests of security services to ensure public security, for example in the fight against terrorism. This will achieve a high level of legal certainty for all sides. I therefore agree with the motion.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Cross-border data flows between the US and Europe are the most intense in the world and that is why the European Parliament is closely following the issue of their protection and protection.  With this joint resolution, we have reiterated that data protection is one of the fundamental rights recognised by the Union and we welcome the improvements made by the 'Privacy Shield' in relation to the Safe Harbour decision.  Specifically, we are in favour of the inclusion of key definitions, such as 'personal data', 'processing' and 'controller', of the mechanisms set up to ensure control of the privacy shield list and of internal and external compliance checks, which have now become mandatory.  However, there is no shortage of shortcomings in this new agreement, particularly with regard to public authorities' access to the transferred data, the complexity of the redress mechanism and the possibility of collecting a disproportionate amount of data. As a further guarantee, we have asked the Commission to carry out appropriate assessments of the 'Privacy Shield' in particular with a view to the new EU data protection rules that will come into force in two years' time.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Strong data protection principles are in place in the EU in order to protect citizens’ rights and privacy. In the EU data protection is considered both a fundamental right and a key component of a digital single market. Cross-border data flows between the EU and the USA are the highest in the world. Personal data exchanges across the Atlantic not only boost economic growth but also represent a crucial element of EU-US cooperation in the law enforcement field, and in particular the cooperation between the EU and the US in the field of ‘national security’. Nevertheless, large-scale US intelligence collection programmes affect transatlantic data flows and specifically the fundamental rights of Europeans, their right to privacy and protection of personal data. We should work in close cooperation with the US administration in order to implement the EU-US Privacy Shield framework as soon as possible. This framework ensures legal certainty on how personal data should be transferred from the EU to the US. However, in order for the Privacy Shield agreement to enter in force, the EU should encourage the United States to commit to legislative reform of surveillance laws within a reasonable time. These reforms should be in synchronisation with the protection of personal data under the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I would like to welcome Parliament's motion for a resolution on transatlantic data flows. The issue of the protection of personal data is a very important and constantly developing subject, given the speed with which the electronic market grows and changes.  This constant growth has led to an increase in the circulation of personal data on the network, and consequently of the potential risks of misuse of such information. For the most part, this exchange of data is not only carried out within the territorial limits of the European Union, but also sees third countries as protagonists. It is therefore necessary, for the protection of citizens' and consumers' rights and freedoms, to create a system of cooperation for the protection of privacy.  I am therefore voting in favour of improving the privacy shield agreement for the protection of our consumers' personal data.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. This resolution deals with the Privacy Shield agreement allowing the transfer of personal data from Europe to the United States, which was negotiated after the Safe Harbor agreement was invalidated by the European Court of Justice in its judgment of 6 October 2015. I voted in favour of this resolution because I think it is very important to find a new agreement quickly to ensure legal certainty for our companies, while strengthening safeguards for the protection of personal data.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the joint resolution on transatlantic data flows.  Even if it sets out fair principles and considerations, it does not seem convincing enough to me as to the willingness of the United States to comply with European rules on the protection of the personal data of French and European citizens.  I would like to point out that the European Court of Justice has invalidated the Commission's decision on the relevance of the levels of protection provided by the Safe Harbor principles, published by the US Department of Commerce. The Court stated in its judgment that an adequate level of protection in a third country is understood as "substantially equivalent" to the protection offered in the EU, which is not the case in the United States. The Commission and the US government must therefore make substantial improvements in the "privacy shield" in relation to the Safe Harbor decision.  I do not share the optimism that is constant in the joint resolution. That is why I supported the Greens' resolution.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. I spoke out against this text. I believe that the privacy data of our citizens must be given a maximum level of protection. I am therefore fundamentally opposed to the vote on the transatlantic data flow. But in 2015, the European Commission accepted the level of privacy data protection provided by the U.S. Department of Commerce. It turns out that it is not enough, which is why the European Court of Justice disagreed with a judgment on 6 October 2015. The text reacts by following the position of the legal body but calls on the Commission and the US Department to find a sufficient level of protection for private data. As a result, it encourages the global sharing of our citizens' data.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Resolution, because I believe it is imperative that the agreement on the transatlantic flow of data with the United States which is reached be transparent and take into account the recently adopted data protection rules so that further annulment by the Court can be avoided.  Especially in the area of business obligations and the rigorous application of rules, the clearest safeguarding of transparency obligations on access by the US administration, the effective protection of the rights of EU citizens with various recourse possibilities and finally the inclusion of a joint annual review mechanism.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. The protection of personal data is one of the fundamental rights that the European Union has an obligation to guarantee, but always taking into account that it may be limited for the achievement of the objectives of general interest recognised in our treaties.  I support this report because data flows between the United States and the European Union are of fundamental importance for trade and investment between the two. Citizens and businesses benefit, directly and on a daily basis, from the free movement of data by creating new opportunities for them to participate in international trade and improving access to new markets on other continents.  Considering, moreover, the digitisation of our economy and that cross-border data flow is a key element for the competitiveness of businesses at national and global level, I give my positive vote for approval.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on transatlantic data transfer provides for the launch of a new legal framework that makes the flow of data between the EU and the US binding. This was made necessary by the so-called Schrems ruling of the European Court of Justice.  The renegotiated so-called 'Privacy Shield', which is the basis of the motion for a resolution, takes into account in a very balanced way the interests of data protection of EU citizens, the interests of companies in the use of electronic data and the interests of security services to ensure public security, for example in the fight against terrorism. This will achieve a high level of legal certainty for all sides. I therefore agree with the motion.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained. I do not agree with the principle of sending citizens' data between the EU and the US Government. This resolution is a saying but harmless call for greater protection of personal data when it is exchanged between governments.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the joint motion for a resolution on transatlantic data flows for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 25/5/2015, and because this joint motion for a resolution is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the joint resolution, but for the resolution and the amendments of the Greens.  The joint resolution was tabled by the EPP, the Socialists, the Liberals and the ECR and EFDD groups.  It follows the decision of the European Court of Justice on 6 October 2015. It invalidated the Commission's decision on the adequacy of the levels of personal data protection put in place by the United States Department of Commerce.  The Commission and the US government must therefore amend the "privacy shield" in line with this court decision. The resolution is part of that. She is very optimistic about the possibility of quickly reaching common ground with the United States. We support the resolution and the amendments of the Greens: they are concerned about the discrepancies between the "privacy shield" and the obligations of the charter, the directive and the general regulation on the protection of personal data.  Our position in favour of maximum protection of personal data is therefore in tune with that defended by the Greens.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The insensitive handling of personal data is criticised here. However, these directives fall far short. That is why I am abstaining.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
