text: Writing. \u2012 I support the European Parliament resolution on transatlantic data flows as it calls for an adequate level of protection of the personal data of EU citizens, for preventing mass data surveillance and for guaranteeing an effective mechanism to protect the rights of EU citizens to privacy.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as the transfer of data is essential for business development and law enforcement on both sides of the Atlantic Ocean, while ensuring high levels of data protection.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The European Court of Justice ruled against the Commission's decision on the levels of protection provided as defined by the Safe Harbor Principles published by the United States Department of Commerce. Indeed, the level of the United States is not the same as that of the European Union. However, we would have to be housed in the same way if the agreement were to be timely. The Greens' motion for a resolution on this issue is more circumspect, in the face of the prevailing optimism about American engagement. They are seeking to impose more guarantees in the agreement. As a result I voted for it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Protecting data means protecting the persons to which the information processed relates and such protection is one of the fundamental rights recognised by the Union (Article 8 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and Article 16 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union). The protection of personal data, respect for privacy and communications, the right to security, the right to receive and transmit information and the freedom to set up and manage businesses are fundamental rights that must be respected and counterbalanced. The EU-US agreement on the privacy shield must be in line with EU primary and secondary law and the relevant judgments of the European Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this cross-party resolution as it enshrines greater protection of EU citizens’ data. The resolution expresses Parliament’s commitment to coming to an agreement that respects EU law as well as the relevant judgements of the Union’s legal bodies.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption by the European Parliament of this resolution on transatlantic data flows. While the Privacy Shield, which is supposed to regulate transatlantic data flows for commercial purposes, is about to be closed, it was essential that Parliament decide on this issue. This is an extremely important theme that is an integral part of our relationship with the United States. Successor of the Safe Harbour invalidated by the Court in 2015, the Privacy Shield must provide the best possible guarantees for the protection of personal data transferred to the United States. While improvements have undeniably been made to the safe harbour system, some deficiencies remain. The Commission should therefore continue the dialogue with the US authorities in order to best close the loopholes highlighted here by Parliament, in particular those relating to the mass collection of data.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Protecting personal data means protecting individuals affected by the information being processed, and this protection is one of the fundamental rights recognised by the European Union. The Commission is required to assess the content of the rules applicable in a given country and arising from national law or international obligations, as well as the procedures to ensure compliance with those rules, as it must take into account all the circumstances of the transfer of personal data to a third country. This assessment should not only cover legislation and procedures relating to the protection of personal data for commercial and private purposes, but must also cover all aspects of the framework applicable to that country or sector and, above all but not limited to, law enforcement, national security and respect for fundamental rights. I insist that legal certainty as regards the transfer of personal data between the Union and the US is a prerequisite for consumer confidence, the development of transatlantic trade and law enforcement cooperation, making it essential for their effectiveness and the long-term implementation of instruments enabling such transfers to comply with primary and secondary Union law. The privacy agreement must comply with primary and secondary EU law, as well as with the relevant judgments of the Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights. I therefore agree with the proposal in question.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Resolution on Transatlantic Data Flows, in response to the Commission’s decision concerning personal data transfers to the United States, called the Privacy Shield. Although, the content of the Privacy Shield is a step in the right direction, it is still extremely problematic, as noted by Working Party 29 (consisting of the National Data Protection Authorities of the Member States) and the EDPS. In my opinion such a regime with the US needs to respect the new data protection acquis of the EU, Court jurisprudence, the Fundamental Rights Charter and be completely legally watertight.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ This Joint Motion for a Resolution on Transatlantic Data Flows is an excellent example of the political parties of this House working together. While we recognise and welcome the Commission and the US administration’s efforts to reach an agreement, some concerns remain especially in relation to bulk data collection, access to data by the US authorities, a very complex redress mechanism and the role of the Ombudsman. Through this resolution we urge the Commission to deal with these issues as soon as possible because it hinders commercial exchanges with one of our largest trade and investment partners. Additionally, it is necessary to submit the agreement on transatlantic data flows to periodical reviews particularly in light of the new General Data Protection Regulation, which will apply as of 2018. I endorsed this resolution that sent a clear but also reasonable and constructive message to the Commission, to our US Partners and to all Member States.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 On the subject indicated, the Verts/ALE, PPE, EFDD, S&D, GUE/NGL, ECR and ALDE political groups tabled a motion for a resolution of the European Parliament. Five of them, PPE, EFDD, S&D, ECR and ALDE, reached agreement and adopted a compromise proposal. I abstained from voting because I agree with the agreement reached by the European Commission and the Us Government, which does not require any further changes.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Taking into account the development of the information society and e-commerce, there has been an exponential increase in the circulation of electronic data and communications, as well as the risks related to the misuse of such data and the interception of such communications. These abuses not only hinder the development of e-commerce, undermining consumer confidence, but also constitute a violation of people's fundamental rights and freedoms. I am voting in favour of this report because I endorse the positions expressed in relation to the efforts made by the Commission and the US Administration to achieve substantial improvements in the privacy shield compared to the Safe Harbor Decision. However, I cannot but express concern that the agreement on the privacy shield does not fully comply with the requirements of the Charter, the Directive, the General Data Protection Regulation and the judgments of the Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights in this matter. Despite the importance of transatlantic trade and cooperation, legal certainty for data subjects and data subjects, I believe that safeguarding fundamental rights, including data protection and privacy rights, is essential.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is in the direction of better privacy protection, so I am voting for it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the "Privacy Shield" agreement, which allows the transfer of personal data from Europe to the United States, an agreement negotiated after the "Safe Harbor" agreement was invalidated by the European Court of Justice in 2015. The "Privacy Shield" agreement was necessary to provide greater legal certainty for European companies, while strengthening safeguards for privacy.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The importance of the protection of personal data is not to be forgett by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. It stresses that it is the UNION's responsibility to ensure and balance the protection of these rights. There are particularly strict rules in cases where the possibility of sharing data with third countries arises. In many ways, we see the United States of America as one of the most important partners of the European Union, which also means a high level of data flow every day. That is why I believe that it is high time to adopt a new, effective directive. The so-called "Privacy Shield" is a much more thoughtful tool that will finally allow us to provide what was not possible with its predecessor, known as safe ports.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The European Commission and the United States have agreed on a new framework for transatlantic data flows: the EU-US Privacy Shield. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that highlights the importance of the Privacy Shield Framework enabling Member States to examine and investigate claims related to the protection of the rights to privacy and family life under the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the right of confidentiality over our personal data is a hard-earned good, a living guarantee of our status as European citizens, inhabitants of democratic states. In a delicate security context, where the issue of terrorist threats is eating away at our day-to-day existence, the transfer of relevant data between states is crucial. In this respect, the clearest regulation of this exchange of information through the adopted report is of particular importance, all the more so as we consider a data flow that ensures close commercial and legal link with a view to ensuring economic development and the safety of citizens. I also appreciate that the report takes into account the 'privacy shield' mechanism that must meet international human rights standards.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the European Parliament resolution on the transatlantic data flow, which supports the efforts of the Commission and the US Government to substantially improve the privacy system compared to the safe harbour decision. In this context, I welcome the introduction of a corrective mechanism for individuals, but the Commission and the US Government should still work to make the procedure as simple and effective as possible. It is important that the transfer of personal data between the EU and the US is based on legal certainty, which is a prerequisite for the trust of both consumers and business partners. The Commission should therefore continue its dialogue with the US Government to negotiate further improvements to the privacy system arrangements.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against the motion for resolution which concerned the new EU-US Privacy Shield. This is an agreement which is a Commission proposal to create a new framework for exchange of data. It follows from the invalidation of the Safe Harbour agreement last year. This Privacy Shield agreement will not effectively shield citizen’s privacy rights. Privacy Shield does still allow US intelligence to collect massive and indiscriminate data, and it is expected that new challenges could be brought to the Court.  Obama Policy Directive 28/2014 indicates the following six instances in which collection of large quantities of signals intelligence data is authorized: (1) Espionage and other threats and activities directed by foreign powers or their intelligence services against the United States and its interests; (2) Threats to the United States and its interests from terrorism; (3) Threats to the United States and its interests from the development, possession, proliferation, or use of weapons of mass destruction; (4) Cybersecurity threats; (5) Threats to U.S. or allied Armed Forces or other U.S or allied personnel; and (6) Transnational criminal threats, including illicit finance and sanctions evasion related to the other purposes named in this section.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. It is about data exchange with the USA. Despite justified and well-explained criticism of the handling of sensitive data, the motion as a whole falls short. EU citizens are not adequately protected for their data.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Cross-border data flows between the US and Europe are the largest in the world and the transfer and exchange of personal data are important components in the area of business and law enforcement. Due to the October 2015 judgment (on safe harbour), it was necessary to increase the protection of personal data between the US and the EU. The new Privacy Shield improves the protection of personal data, but it also needs periodic review and some shortcomings to be rectified.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the resolution tabled.  The transfer and exchange of personal data is an essential element of a close RELATIONSHIP between the EU and the US. The extent of cross-border data flows between the United States and Europe is the largest in the world. There is therefore a need to ensure a high level of data protection and appropriate safeguards and to promote and develop international standards for privacy and the protection of personal data. Clear and uniform rules are a key element in business development and growth. The 'Security Shield' procedure should be in line with EU primary and secondary law, as well as the relevant judgments of the Court of Justice of the European Union and the European Court of Human Rights. It is essential to promote a mutually strong culture of respect for privacy and the protection of the rights of natural persons, which will help restore and maintain trust.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP are principally against the EU taking charge of transatlantic data exchange above Member State cooperation. This particular motion for a resolution we loosely support in the sense that it does empower citizens against the very ‘flexible’ data protection laws of the US. Therefore we voted against the original Green motion for a resolution based on the principle that this should be done by Member States and not the EU. But we abstained on certain amendments that were tabled because it does protect citizens from very loose data protection standards from the US.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union protects and strengthens the protection of personal data, respect for privacy and communications, the right to security, the right to receive and disseminate information and the right to engage in a commercial activity given the importance of these rights in the light of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Limits can therefore only be imposed if there are requirements which cannot be met in any other way. Noting that the flow of information between the US and the EU is of considerable scope, I believe that the EU-US Privacy Shield meets the needs that this sector requires. In the hope that there will be a continuous dialogue between the institutions and the United States aimed at implementing the agreement, I would like to support the position of my political group.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The development of information society and electronic commerce globally has led to an increase in data movements, thereby risking misuse of data and interception of communication flows. Such abuse acts as a brake on the development of e-commerce, in the sense that it undermines consumer confidence, and often constitutes an invasion of the right to privacy.  The right to privacy is a fundamental right in the EU and it is the Duty of the European Commission to ensure an adequate level of protection of this right for European citizens in third countries as well. After two years of negotiations, the European Commission and the US have negotiated a transatlantic data exchange agreement called 'Security Shield' to protect their fundamental rights guaranteed by European legislation when transferring european citizens' personal data to the US.  I consider that the agreement reached has not achieved its purpose, as I consider that it calls into question the legal security of citizens and poses a risk of loss of personal data protection. Therefore, I support the title resolution and call on the Commission to start negotiations with the US on improving the legal data protection framework.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Privacy Shield is certainly an improvement on the Safe Harbour agreement, as regards the protection of personal data, recognised as one of the fundamental rights of European citizens by the Charter of Fundamental Rights. Cross-border data flows between the US and Europe are the most intense in the world and a key factor in business and judicial cooperation. A clear legal framework, simple and efficient compliance procedures are essential for SMEs, among the most dynamic and fast-growing players in the European economy, increasingly dependent on the free movement of data. The new agreement introduces several improvements, in particular the definition of key concepts and the establishment of mandatory and more effective mechanisms and controls. Many doubts remain, however, about the adequacy of the Privacy Shield to solve all the problems highlighted by the RULING of the Court of Justice of the EU which rejected the Safe Harbour Agreement. The collection of mass data and personal communications of non-US citizens is still in too many cases authorised by US law and, therefore, the rights of European citizens are not yet sufficiently protected. I therefore agree with the call for the Commission to continue its dialogue with the US administration in order to achieve further improvements to the agreement.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ In Case C-362/14 Maximilian Schrems v. Data Protection Commissioner, the Court of Justice of the European Union concluded that the Commission's claim that the US provides an adequate level of protection of EU personal data under safe harbour is invalid, resulting in the need for an urgent conclusion of negotiations on the EU-US Privacy Shield Agreement( 'Privacy Shield') to ensure legal certainty regarding how personal data is transferred from the EU to the US. As privacy and data protection in the US are embedded in a comprehensive data regulation and privacy system, in particular with regard to the most sensitive categories of personal data such as health, finance, electronic communication and minors, I welcome the conclusion of negotiations between the EU and the US on the Privacy Shield after more than two years of negotiations between the European Commission and the US Department of Commerce.  I welcome the fact that the EU-US Privacy Shield is significantly different from the Safe Harbour Framework, as it provides for much more detailed documentation imposing more specific obligations on companies willing to join the framework, and includes a new control system that ensures that EU citizens have their rights respected when processing their data in the US. In addition, I hope that the agreed independence of the U.S. Attorney will be guaranteed. Otherwise, the whole concept needs to be reviewed.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. These motions for a resolution follow the Decision of the Court of Justice of 6 October 2015, which found the European Commission's decision 2000/520/EC, known as the Safe Harbour agreement, invalid because it considers it to have obvious implications for amending the rules on the transfer of personal data from the EU to the US. In a context where negotiations on transatlantic free trade agreements are ongoing (for example - TTIP and TiSA), the issue of data transfer is so much more important because rights such as citizens' privacy are at stake, but also the commercialisation of them and the internal security of states. These motions for resolutions place the treatment of this issue on a supranational level between the European Commission and the United States of America, subalternising the Member States and thereby the imperative need to address this issue, sovereignly and democratically, in each country in accordance with its legitimate interests and national defence. From the foregoing, we voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 The protection of data of our citizens must always be at the top of the priorities when concluding international agreements. This obligation must also be aimed at further policies extending the EU data protection directive to encourage our partners to share the same interest in data protection. What defines the new agreement is the existence of a protective net so that the documents exchanged cannot be misused, ensuring that differences in DATA protection laws between the US and the EU do not harm our citizens. I supported the European Parliament's resolution, as it underlines the importance of clear transparency between both sides in the EU-US partnership, while ensuring a greater and faster flow of information relevant to the issue of national security.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Data flows are essential components of the EU's relations in the areas of security, economy and trade. There are already agreements on the exchange of information in certain policy areas, including the terrorist finance tracking programme, the EU-US Passenger Name Record Agreement and Safe Harbor, a recent agreement known as the Privacy Shield. The recently adopted General Data Protection Regulation and the Data Protection Directive for law enforcement purposes also deal with data protection in relation to third countries. Since 2013 Congress and the U.S. administration have made more than twenty changes to surveillance laws and programs. Reforms include the US Freedom Act, the President's Regulation (PPD-28), which states that the protection of the privacy and civil liberties of non-EU citizens is an integral part of US surveillance policy, and the Judicial Remedies Act, which extends data protection measures to EU citizens.  The ECR Group supports the implementation and adoption of the new Privacy Shield and wishes to adopt and implement the EU-US General Umbrella Agreement on Data Protection as soon as possible. These two agreements guarantee a high level of protection and legal certainty for businesses and consumers, a level that has not yet been achieved. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution, which calls on the European Commission to continue its negotiations with the United States to improve the legal framework for transatlantic flows of personal data for commercial purposes.  Indeed, this "privacy shield" still has flaws, as some provisions do not meet the criteria of "necessity" and "proportionality" of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  It should be remembered here that the Member States of the European Union have the option of suspending all data transfers in the event of citizens' complaints.  With two years to go before the implementation of the new European Data Protection Regulation, it is important to remember that the European Parliament's action is primarily aimed at protecting the citizens of each country.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The increase in the volume of data transfer and electronic communications, a logical corollary of today's information society, underlines the relevance of transatlantic relations established between the US and the EU. The report on the transatlantic transfer of data provides that, in the context of the above mentioned relationships, it is important to safeguard the right of consumers to the protection of their data, enshrined in the jusfundamental order recognised by the Union in Articles 8 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and 16 TFEU.  I am thus of the understanding that the protection of citizens' data must be guaranteed not only within the European economic area but also in the third countries to which the data are transferred in accordance with Directive 95/46/EC. In this context, relations between the US and the Union generate the largest flow of data in the world, so that legal certainty in the transfer of such data is very essential to ensuring consumer confidence, the development of transatlantic businesses and cooperation between the judicial forces of these two Western powers.  Precisely because it is a report which underlines the need to improve the shield of protection of privacy between the US and the Union, without prejudice to the pressing promotion of transatlantic relations, I am voting in favour of its adoption.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP are principally against the EU taking charge of transatlantic data exchange above Member State cooperation. This particular motion for a resolution we loosely support in the sense that it does empower citizens against the very ‘flexible’ data protection laws of the US. Therefore we voted against the original Green motion for a resolution based on the principle that this should be done by Member States and not the EU. But we abstained on certain amendments that were tabled because it does protect citizens from very loose data protection standards from the US.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 This resolution highlights the importance of transatlantic cooperation in the context of data transfer, but also underlines the need to safeguard fundamental rights, including the right to data protection and privacy. There remains some apprehension with regard to: the complexity of the appeal mechanism for individuals under the Privacy Shield; insufficient penalty measures for possible infringements; the non-change of the legal situation with regard to mass surveillance by US agencies outside the US and foreigners within the country; the lack of an assessment by the Commission of the rights of EU citizens when their data is transferred by an AMERICAN data controller to eu law enforcement agencies.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. In the wake of Max Schrems' complaint, the EU Court of Justice ruled last October that the agreement regulating the transmission of data from European citizens to the US has not provided sufficient protection since 2000.  Last February, the Commission introduced the new agreement with the US, known as privacy shield, to regulate transatlantic data flows, a new framework that makes significant progress on the previous scheme, as it includes strict obligations for businesses, clearer safeguards, and transparency obligations in terms of access by the US administration, greater protection of the rights of EU citizens (the US has approved the Judicial ReDress Act. European citizens access to the courts of that country) and an annual joint review mechanism However, as established by the Parliamentary Resolution, which I supported, the Article 29 Working Group, has expressed its deep concern about the commercial aspects and public authorities' access to data transferred under the Privacy Shield , and the Commission is therefore requested to fully implement the recommendations of this Group in order to avoid further annulment.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted in favour of this resolution, in particular in view of the European Parliament and Council Directive 95/46/EC of 24 October 1995 on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and the free movement of such data, in view of the Council's 27 November 2008 Framework Decision on the Protection of Personal Data Processed in the Context of Police and Judicial Cooperation in Criminal Cases, in view of the Directive (EU) 2 016/680 of the European Parliament and the Council of 27 April 2016 on the protection of individuals in relation to the handling of personal data by the competent authorities for the purpose of preventing and detecting criminal offences , investigations and prosecutions of criminal sanctions, and the free flow of such data, and repealing the Council's 2008/977/JAI Framework Decision, in view of the Commission's decision 2000/520/EC of 26 July 2000 (safe harbor decision) and given the Commission's communication to the European Parliament and the Council of 27 November 2013 entitled 'Restore confidence in the data flows between the European Union and the United States of America'.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Figuratively suggesting that the Atlantic is the inner sea of the Western world and therefore everything that concerns the exchange – no matter what – goods, services, information, human contacts or anything else in this region deserves our particular attention. The issue of transatlantic data exchange discussed today is also important in the fact that data exchange is also a driving force for the modern information society. We must make every effort to maximise the flow of data, both on our continent and with our strategic partners.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This joint resolution proposed by 5 political groups, including the EPP, deals generally on the protection of personal data, particularly in the transatlantic relationship- European Union/United States of America and, in particular, the recent Privacy Shield Agreement. In fact, transatlantic relations remain vital for both partners on both sides of the Atlantic - especially business/economic relations - so the need for a comprehensive, appropriate and existing solution to data protection and privacy is urgent ly needed to deliver on what is one of the EU's fundamental objectives: the protection of personal data. The legislative package called "Privacy Shield" recently announced by the European Commission, replacing the previous data protection regime between the EU and the US "Safe Harbor", invalidated in 2015 by the Court of Justice of the European Union, resulted from a broad dialogue between (and within) the EU and the United States. For making substantial improvements over the previous regime, but because the resolution considers it 'a process under construction' jointly and permanently - an idea with which I agree, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this resolution on the Privacy Shield agreement, which allows the transfer of personal data from Europe to the United States and which was negotiated after the Safe Harbor agreement was invalidated by the European Court of Justice on 6 October 2015. It is important that the European Commission continue its negotiations with the United States to remedy the loopholes in the Privacy Shield scheme for the transfer of the personal data of European citizens to the United States for commercial purposes. Concrete and effective answers must be made to ensure legal certainty for our companies, while strengthening safeguards for respect for the protection of personal data.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 With this resolution, Parliament is intervening on the agreement reached between the European Commission and the United States on security, exchange of commercial information, and protection of privacy. This framework agreement was necessary because of the judgment of the European Court of Justice declaring the previous agreement invalid.  The first point of interest of the new agreement concerns the obligation to process personal data properly, since it enforces the requirements laid down by the European Court of Justice for both contractors. Secondly, this exchange is of particular benefit to the sector with the greatest prospects for the expansion of the European economy, namely SMEs, which make up 60% of the Union's economy. At the same time, therefore, the new agreement is even closer to consumers, because companies that will benefit from the possibility offered by this agreement will have to submit to the highest standards of protection of personal data. The resolution expresses Parliament's support for the agreement. Together with the GROUP of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, which sponsored the resolution adopted together with 4 other groups, I voted in favour.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Motion for a Resolution on transatlantic data flows, because we understand that it focuses on the legal certainty of the transfer of personal data between the Union and the US. and, the right to information is not balanced, with the right to consumer privacy. Our group tabled an amendment to introduce improvements in the field of privacy and consumer rights, related to the protection of personal data. The amendment did not go ahead, so we did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The so-called Privacy Shield has been called into question in the same ways its predecessor, the Safe Harbour decision was. Serious issues about fundamental rights and data protection law are at stake here. Any agreement made with third countries must fully respect, and not undermine, the provisions of existing EU law.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 With the Privacy Shield, we achieve significant improvements to the data protection shield in conjunction with our previous safe harbour protection system. In this way, we ensure that we can transfer data to the United States, even though we have different data protection standards. The "Privacy Shield" thus guarantees the protection of Europeans' data in the United States, which is important for consumers.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against the Resolution because none of the necessary measures are proposed therein to safeguard adequate levels of protection of personal data. In the face of the numerous scandals of mass espionage of European citizens by the US authorities in the face of the passivity of EU governments, a strong position of rejection is urgent. In addition, the Resolution has been a missed opportunity to uphold European data protection standards, which will be significantly reduced if the TTIP is approved.  We are also concerned about the insufficient content about espionage carried out by private companies, and the transfer of personal data to or between them. The purchase and sale of personal data is an increasingly strong economic sector that must be strictly regulated and limited or we run the risk of losing the right to privacy.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Parliament asked the Commission to continue negotiations with the United States to remedy some of the shortcomings of the Privacy Shield. The Privacy Shield gives personal data protection agencies in EU Member States a leading role in examining data protection requests and in suspending data transfers.  This resolution highlights shortcomings in the Privacy Shield, especially with regard to the amount of data that can be collected and public authorities' access to the transferred data. In addition, the Commission has been asked to carry out regular appropriate assessments of the Privacy Shield, also in view of the new rules that will enter into force in two years' time.  Considering this resolution to be very important for European citizens and their privacy, I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as Ukip are principally against the EU taking charge of transatlantic Data exchange above member state co-operation. This particular Motion for Resolution we loosely support in the sense that it does empower citizens against the very ‘flexible’ data protection laws of the US. Therefore we voted against the original Green Motion for Resolution based on the principal that this should be done by Member States and not the EU. But, we abstained on certain amendments that were tabled because it does protect citizens from very loose data protection standards from the US.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which was expertly put together by my Socialist colleague Birgit Sippel. I am happy to have such a regime with the US, however it needs to respect the new Data Protection acquis of the EU and be completely legally watertight.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ The fight against international terrorism has to be waged through smart intelligence sharing between nations, in order to prevent attacks like those we have seen on mainland Europe. I was glad to support my colleague Timothy Kirkhope’s hard work in this area and to see problematic amendments voted out.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In October 2015, the European Court of Justice annulled the decision on the so-called safe harbour with its judgment in a case initiated by the Austrian citizen Maximilian Schrems. Safe Harbor was an agreement that allowed companies such as Facebook, Google or Microsoft to transfer sensitive personal data from the EU to the US. The Court has recognised that the personal data of European citizens are not sufficiently protected in this way and has established that an adequate level of protection in a third country is to be understood as 'substantially equivalent' to the level of protection guaranteed within the Union. According to the EU Founding Treaties, the protection of personal data is one of the fundamental rights, as protecting data means protecting the people affected by the information being processed. Following the abolition of the safe harbour, the Commission came up with a bilateral agreement between the US and the EU called the 'Privacy shield', which is intended to be a corrective measure in response to the reservations of the Court of Justice. It must be acknowledged that key definitions such as 'personal data', 'processing' or 'controller' have been incorporated into this agreement, but privacy must continue to form part of a wider dialogue between the EU and third countries, including the US. It will therefore be necessary to incorporate the recently adopted new measures on the protection of personal data, which were approved by the EP in April. I also agreed with the resolution because we call on all stakeholders to respect the principles based on EU legislation.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on transatlantic data transfer provides for the launch of a new legal framework that makes the flow of data between the EU and the US binding. This was made necessary by the so-called Schrems ruling of the European Court of Justice.  The renegotiated so-called 'Privacy Shield', which is the basis of the motion for a resolution, takes into account in a very balanced way the interests of data protection of EU citizens, the interests of companies in the use of electronic data and the interests of security services to ensure public security, for example in the fight against terrorism. This will achieve a high level of legal certainty for all sides. I therefore agree with the motion.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the conclusion of negotiations between the EU and the US on the Privacy Shield after more than two years of negotiations between the European Commission and the US Department of Commerce. The flow of data between the United States and the European Union is about 15 thyrabites per second, representing by far the largest data flow in the world. The free flow of data between the EU and the US is of significant importance for trade and investment growth as transatlantic and business-to-business transactions and services have become increasingly common.  According to the latest trends, consumers on both sides of the Atlantic are increasingly using the Internet to buy goods and services. I believe that the transatlantic flow of data, as well as the fact that internet access has spread to the whole world, opens the possibility for the EU to expand trade relations and investment and exports. Therefore, I believe that there will be a growth in online international trade, as well as the need for free flow of data.  In doing so, the protection of personal data, respect for privacy and communication, as well as the right to security and business, are fundamental rights that must be guaranteed by the European Union as required by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The protection of personal data, respect for privacy and communication, as well as the right to security and business, are fundamental rights that the European Union is tasked with respecting as required by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The flow of data between the United States and the European Union is about 15 thyrabites per second, representing by far the largest data flow in the world.  The free flow of data between the EU and the US is essential for trade and investment growth, as transatlantic transactions and services between companies have become a reality and consumers on both sides of the Atlantic are increasingly using the internet to buy goods and services.  I support this proposal for a resolution, as I believe that the transatlantic flow of data, as well as the fact that internet access has spread to the whole world, opens the possibility for the European Union to expand trade and invest in developing countries. That is why I believe that there will be a growth in online international trade as well as the need for the free flow of data, and I see this resolution as a step forward in this direction.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on transatlantic data flows. Transatlantic data flows between Europe and the US are very important for our economy. As society continues to digitise, this sector is very important for our future. We must conclude the negotiations on the Privacy Shield as soon as possible, which will achieve two things: on the one hand, we will protect the data of our citizens, and on the other hand, on the other hand, which is also very important, we will give legal certainty to our businesses, especially the small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the backbone of our economy. The Commission has done a great job and I hope that it will complete its work as soon as possible.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's agreement to a new AGREEMENT between the EU and the US on the handling of personal data of EU citizens. The new Privacy Shield replaces the original Safe Harbour Agreement, which has been described by the Court of Justice of the EU as inadequately protecting the personal data of European citizens. I believe that the new agreement negotiated by the European Commission meets the requirements of European legislation on the protection of personal data and its early conclusion is in the interest not only of European citizens, but also of European entrepreneurs, because in the digital economy the handling of personal data is an essential part of trade relations. The negotiation of this agreement demonstrates that, if the Union acts in a uniform way, its position is very strong.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The provision of protection of transatlantic data flows between the US and the EU has so far not established a proper basis, combined with the corresponding protection in all third countries, that effectively protects the fundamental rights of people.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the joint motion for a resolution on the transatlantic flow of data. Like the motion, I welcome the Commission's work on the Privacy Shield, which provides a new framework for transatlantic data flows. I agree with the statement that transatlantic relations remain a priority for the parties, but that citizens' rights to the protection of personal data in the European Union are unquestionable and that their right should not be infringed when transferring their data to third parties. I endorse the motion's call for the Commission to fully implement the recommendations of the Working Party established under Article 29 on the Privacy Shield decision. In agreement with the motion, I believe that it is also the basis for legal certainty, consumer confidence, transatlantic business developments and law enforcement cooperation on the protection of personal data moving between the EU and the United States. It is therefore absolutely necessary to ensure that the means enabling such movements comply with the requirements of primary and secondary Community law.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Personal data of EU residents that are collected for commercial purposes, e.g. when shopping online or registering on social media, and goes to the US, must be properly protected. The existing 2000 Safe Harbour agreement did not provide sufficient protection. Consequently, in October 2015, the European Court of Justice annulled the agreement. The new privacy shield agreement proposed by the Commission aims to seal the system and improve safeguards to protect the privacy of Citizens of the European Union. In the new agreement, the Americans have pledged that access to eu citizens' data will be supervised and subject to clear restrictions. In addition, the US government has assured that there will be no surveillance of people whose data will go across the Atlantic. U.S. data transfer companies will need to guarantee protection in their processing. Parliament's resolution appreciates the proposed agreement, which rightly imposes specific obligations on companies to protect the data of EU citizens processed in the US. The Privacy Shield can bring a lot of benefits to European consumers and businesses, especially SMEs. Enabling the free flow of data between the EU and the US is crucial for both economies, trade and investment. That is why I decided to vote in favour of the resolution in favour of the new agreement.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Information has become a vital component of today's society, especially in the context where most of our decisions are based on how well we are informed. The decisive role of information is also highlighted by the importance of intelligence structures in ensuring global security. The rise of global terrorism has raised the issue of collaboration between relevant actors in the information field. The most relevant case in this respect is the collaboration between the European Union and the United States in the field of personal data transfers. The initial agreement between the two parties in this sensitive area, also known as the 'safe harbor', was rejected by the Court of Justice of the European Union as it does not comply with European standards for the protection of personal data and privacy. The adoption of a new agreement, called the 'privacy shield', has somewhat changed the focus, but there are still issues concerning compliance with the standards of the European Data Protection Supervisor. In these circumstances, the agreement must be amended to comply with European law, the case-law of the Court of Justice of the EU and the Charter of Fundamental Rights. For this reason, I support the rejection of this resolution, with a view to clarifying the outstanding issues concerning the legitimate rights of European citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the resolution. Data protection means the protection of the people to whom the information is being processed belongs, and this protection is one of the fundamental rights recognised by the Union.  The protection of personal data, respect for privacy and communications, the right to security, the right to receive and communicate information and freedom of enterprise are all fundamental rights that must be respected and balanced among themselves.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the EU-US Privacy shield. This is a framework of rules (administered by the US authorities) aiming to achieve a level of protection of personal data equivalent to the one in the EU. It is an arrangement for managing the transfer of data in the commercial sphere from the EU to the United States, replacing the Safe Harbour arrangement that was invalidated by the European Court of Justice. American companies can sign up to the Privacy Shield programme and, if they meet the requirements of this arrangement (which are more stringent than those normally prescribed by US law), are allowed to receive personal data from the EU.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 The development of the information society and e-commerce and the improvement of the ability to intercept intelligence agencies at global level have increased the flow of data and electronic communications and the risks associated with misuse of such data. I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on transatlantic data flows because such protection would be useless if it were limited to the territory of the Union and if it was not adequately guaranteed under the directive in the third countries to which the data are transferred. The EU-US Privacy Shield (EU-US Privacy Shield) reflects the requirements of the EU Court of Justice judgment of 6 October 2015, which repealed the previous Safe Harbour framework. The new regime will impose greater obligations on US companies on the protection of Europeans' personal data and ensure stricter monitoring and enforcement by the US Department of Commerce and the Us Federal Trade Commission, inter alia through enhanced cooperation with European data protection authorities. The new deal imposes an obligation on the US to subject public authorities' access to personal data transferred under the new regime, under US law, to subject clear conditions, restrictions and controls to prevent universal access. Europeans will be able to lodge any enquiries or complaints in this regard with a special new Ombudsman.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Motion for a Resolution on transatlantic data flows, because we understand that it focuses on the legal certainty of the transfer of personal data between the Union and the US and, the right to information is not balanced, with the right to consumer privacy. Our group tabled an amendment to introduce improvements in the field of privacy and consumer rights, related to the protection of personal data. The amendment did not go ahead, so we did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on transatlantic data transfer provides for the launch of a new legal framework that makes the flow of data between the EU and the US binding. This was made necessary by the so-called Schrems ruling of the European Court of Justice.  The renegotiated so-called 'Privacy Shield', which is the basis of the motion for a resolution, takes into account in a very balanced way the interests of data protection of EU citizens, the interests of companies in the use of electronic data and the interests of security services to ensure public security, for example in the fight against terrorism. This will achieve a high level of legal certainty for all sides. I therefore agree with the motion.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. In its judgment of 6 October 2015, the European Court of Justice overturned the Commission's decision on the appropriateness of the levels of protection provided by the Safe Harbor Principles, published by the US Department of Commerce. The Court stated in its judgment that an adequate level of protection in a third country is understood as "substantially equivalent" to the protection offered in the EU, which is not the case in the United States. The Commission and the US government must therefore make substantial improvements in the "privacy shield" in relation to the Safe Harbor decision. The joint resolution starts from this principle, and supports the process. There are a lot of positives, but it seems too optimistic about the possibility of getting Americans moving. I am in favour of a maximum level of data protection and the privacy of our citizens. I therefore voted against this text because important amendments were not adopted.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The good points of the resolution we voted on are the right institutional ideas and proposed redress mechanisms. On the flow of data between Europe and North America, a maximum level of protection of personal data should be ensured, while being guided by the principle of rationality. When collecting data to combat the worst crimes, the right to privacy must not be abused at the expense of citizens' security. The EP motion for a resolution put to the vote today met these criteria, which is why I voted in favour of it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The development of the information society and e-commerce and the development of the eavesdropping capabilities of intelligence agencies at global level have resulted in an exponential increase in data movement and electronic communication, as well as the risk of misuse and interception of such data. I voted in favour of S&D's position in the related vote.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. U2012 We voted against this Motion for a Resolution on transatlantic data flows, because we understand that it focuses on the legal certainty of the transfer of personal data between the Union and the US and, the right to information is not balanced, with the right to consumer privacy. Our group tabled an amendment to introduce improvements in the field of privacy and consumer rights, related to the protection of personal data. The amendment did not go ahead, so we did not vote in favour of this report.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. Following the invalidation of the Safe Harbour agreement by the Court of Justice, the Commission has proposed a new regime for the flow of data between the USA and the EU. Nicknamed ‘Privacy Shield’, this agreement is very much criticised for the lack of data protection safeguards in the USA.  The Greens/EFA are very concerned about the new Privacy Shield: we understand the need to provide legal certainty for business to continue between the USA and the EU, but not at the cost of fundamental rights. Parliament’s resolution on the Privacy Shield, however, does not reflect those concerns. Our key Greens/EFA demand – a sunset clause – was rejected and therefore I voted against the resolution as a whole.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I am concerned that the Privacy Shield system may not fully comply with the requirements of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights, the Data Protection Directive, the General Data Protection Regulation and the relevant judgments of the Court of Justice of the EU and the European Court of Human Rights.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on the non-legislative resolution on transatlantic data flows. The resolution suggests that the Commission and the US administration need to make data flow more user-friendly and effective. It equally stresses that the Privacy Shield framework gives EU Member States’ data protection agencies a prominent role in examining data protection claims and notes their power to suspend data transfers. It also notes the obligation placed upon the US Department of Commerce to resolve such complaints.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution because it welcomes the efforts made by the Commission and the US Administration to achieve substantial improvements in the Privacy Shield compared to the Safe Harbour decision, in particular the insertion of key definitions such as ‘personal data’, ‘processing’ and ‘controller’, the mechanisms set up to ensure oversight of the Privacy Shield list, and the now mandatory external and internal reviews of compliance. I also welcome from this resolution the appointment of an Ombudsperson in the US Department of State, who will work together with independent authorities to provide a response to the EU supervisory authorities, channelling individual requests in relation to government surveillance. I consider, however, that this new institution is not sufficiently independent and is not vested with adequate powers to effectively exercise and enforce its duty.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because I am satisfied with the efforts of the Commission and the US Government to achieve significant improvements in the Privacy Shield. Because transatlantic relations are so important, we need to use the right and the same definitions in the context of privacy; there needs to be a global solution between the EU and the US that ups and downs the right to data protection and the right to privacy. This resolution emphasises this once again.  The Privacy Shield regime must certainly be in line with EU primary and secondary legislation and with the relevant rulings of both the European Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. With the "Schrems" case, the European Court of Justice invalidated in 2015 the so-called "Safe Harbor" agreement between the European Union and the United States on data exchanges between the United States and the European Union, saying that it was not protective enough for European citizens. The European Commission has therefore presented a new agreement known as the "privacy shield" which is supposed to fill the legislative void. The new European data protection regulation that has just been adopted to replace the 1995 data protection directive is even stricter than the previous one. The U.S. legislative framework is therefore still far enough away from providing equivalent protection... Unsurprisingly, this joint resolution welcomes the negotiations with the United States. However, we are far from taking into account all the requirements of the Court of Justice: the United States has not made legally binding commitments, mass surveillance is still possible... This agreement therefore falls well short of data protection expectations, and shows little progress compared to Safe Harbor and the majority of the European Parliament refuses to lobby to try to improve it.  We are facing a real game of dupes that I refuse to validate. So I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 In a framework where negotiations on transatlantic free trade agreements are ongoing (for example - TTIP and TiSA), the issue of data transfer is all the more important because rights such as citizens' privacy are at stake, but also the marketing of them and the internal security of states. These motions for resolutions follow the Decision of the Court of Justice of 6 October 2015, which found invalid the European Commission decision 2000/520/EC, known as the Safe Harbour agreement, because it considers it to have obvious implications for amending the rules on the transfer of personal data from the EU to the US. These motions for resolutions place the treatment of this issue on a supranational level between the European Commission and the United States of America, underaltering the Member States and thereby the imperative need to address this issue, sovereignly and democratically, in each country, in accordance with their legitimate interests and national defence. By the foregoing, vote against.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. These requests relate to the exchange of data with the United States. While on the one hand the insensitive handling of personal data is rightly criticised, on the other hand it is overlooked that the directives sought are far too short and thus do not provide EU citizens with adequate protection of their data.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I agreed with this resolution, I negotiated it on behalf of my EFDD Group. The AfD demands on data protection: "Contrary to other efforts, data protection is to be given a high priority and its scope extended to all personal characteristics. Freedom of expression and the free development of personality need strong data protection." In its judgment of 6.10.2015 in Case C-362/14 (Maximilian Schrems v Data Protection Commissioner), the ECJ annulled the Commission's "safe harbour decision": the US is "not a safe third country" for the adequate protection of personal data of the citizens of the Member States. A new agreement must now be reached, but it will once again only be negotiated by Commission officials.  Legal certainty in the transfer of personal data between the EU and the US is crucial for citizens' confidence and the future shape of transatlantic relations. The instruments for the transfer of personal data must be compatible with EU primary and secondary law – on both sides of the Atlantic. This "equivalence" was demanded by the ECJ. However, the CDU/CSU, SPD and FDP refuse to regularly check, by means of a "sunset clause", whether the US actually protects the personal data of Europeans in the same way as the ECJ has requested in order to guarantee the necessary legal certainty for Europeans. If necessary, "Schrems 2" must reaffirm the data protection rights of Europeans.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I have decided to support the report submitted, and I also welcome the efforts of the Commission and the US Government to improve the protection of personal data. However, I am aware of the fact that the Privacy Shield measures and the situation in the US do not provide sufficient improvements. Personally, I believe that the proposal for an ad- protection decision will very likely be challenged again in court once it is adopted, creating a situation of legal uncertainty for businesses and individuals. Together with data protection experts and economic associations, I encourage companies to use other means of transferring personal data to the US.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The exchange of digital information between the United States and Europe is a necessity which, in the age of the data economy, is the basis for the functioning of many businesses. However, this need must not mean disregarding security and privacy principles. The development of clear and effective rules for the exchange of data is the best guarantee of their security and thus gives us confidence that the information we leave behind on the web will not be used by unauthorized persons. The United States is a demanding negotiating partner that takes a very liberal approach to many privacy issues.  Of course, the EU's negotiations should provide the best possible safeguard for our interests, but this must not lead to disagreement. The current state of these discussions is encouraging and shows that even on such a sensitive issue, it is worth seeking a compromise. I believe that the proposals to improve the Privacy Shield mechanism, which aims to better define key information on data exchange and to combat abuse by administrators, meet the expectations of EU citizens. It is also pleased to develop a redress procedure for individuals who will be able to assert their rights in court at the time of discovery of the abuse. Of course, while protecting our privacy, we must not forget that digital data analysis is an important tool in the fight against terrorism. In this area, we must be ready to make concessions.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution on the transatlantic transfer of data because I believe that, under the data transfer agreement to the US, the EU will respect the protection of the personal data of European citizens. I would stress that the European Socialist Group has successfully fought to make the agreement on the privacy shield in conformity with eu primary and secondary law and the relevant judgments of the European Court of Justice and the European Court of Human Rights.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. The cross-border flow of data between the US and Europe is essential for innovation, job creation and economic growth of the EU and the US. Legal certainty, and in particular clear and uniform rules, are among the key elements of business development and growth. That is why I supported the European Parliament resolution on the transatlantic data flow, which calls on the Commission to continue the dialogue with the US administration and to conclude the NEGOTIATIONS on the EU-US Privacy Shield in order to ensure legal certainty as to how personal data should be supplied from the EU to the US.

name: Jude Kirton-Darling (S&D).
text: – Mr President, energy poverty is a blight on the lives of over 50 million Europeans. Across our continent people are struggling with the cost of heating their homes and this is unacceptable. In my constituency this has an impact on one in ten households. No one should have to turn off their heating during the depths of winter and no one should have to choose between heating and eating. I welcome the report from my fellow Labour MEP, Theresa Griffin. This report is an important step forward in our efforts to solve some of these issues and, if implemented, will provide a range of measures to tackle the root causes of energy poverty. I welcome the empowerment of consumers, providing opportunities for consumers to find the most appropriate deal for them and move away from unsuitable tariffs. I am appalled today that Tory and UKIP MEPs voted against a ban on unfair commercial practices and concrete actions for the most vulnerable consumers. This is not the way to deal with energy poverty. Theresa’s report sets out a clear plan.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur The current reform of the energy system at Union level is generally focused on making it the most de-centralised, energy-efficient, flexible and, for the most part, based on renewable energy sources. And one of the primary objectives would therefore also be to provide citizens with stable, affordable, efficient, sustainable energy. That's number one. Realisable changes also mean the possibility for people to produce their own energy as needed, this is particularly important in sparsely populated areas, as well as freely selecting the respective service providers. Finally, in my view, it must actually lead to the elimination of energy monopolies, which in some Member States are still a long way from real implementation. And, of course, I support this direction.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, the centralised classical energy system is a thing of the past. We are evolving towards a decentralised, flexible, efficient and renewable energy-based system. The Commission Communication on the new energy consumer agreement builds on three pillars: better information for consumers to consume as little as possible, both energy and money; also the second pillar : more possibilities for consumers to choose between heating variants, for example, and the third pillar: maintaining the highest level of consumer protection. I support this report. We need to see how we define energy poverty at Union level when each state has different energy needs, when the minimum per capita income is different from one state to another or states define the idea of reasonable costs differently.  I hope that we will find a resolution, as I said, on energy poverty at Union level that will bring us to implement this agreement.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – I strongly support the Energy Union project, I also support the issue of the creation of a single energy market, but in this area it is necessary to weigh in this area the so-called 'pharmacy weights', which measures will be centralised or unified and which measures will remain fully within the remit of the Member States. This distinction is primarily a task for the European Commission. With regard to this particular report, I appreciate the fact that it seeks to strengthen the competitiveness of European businesses entering the energy market, clearly reinforces the demand for transparency and aims to create a good functioning system for energy markets. For me, it is important that the social right of individual consumers, which is directed against energy poverty, is also enshrined here. I think that this is also important for us who subscribe to the middle and the right.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The energy 'new deal' strategy provides for an active role for citizens in the European energy market. The new deal is based on consumer protection, better information on energy and efficiency of the energy market. In addition, we have pushed for a clear definition of "prosumers" (an English neologism that indicates a person who is both producer and consumer). For the substantial benefits that the proposal will bring to the energy market, I have decided to vote in favour of

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the new agreement on energy consumers, which refers to the Energy Union, which citizens should have at their core and contribute to the design of energy policy and the protection of consumers from uncompetitive and unfair practices by suppliers.  At the same time, the report proposes measures for the proper functioning of the energy market and presents proposals to save consumers money from energy bills.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. Privatisation, competition and deregulation, which does not exclude a very restrictive bureaucratic over-regulation, in the energy sector are likely to lead individuals and businesses alike to pay for increasingly expensive energy, ensuring that multinational oligopolies have comfortable margins made on the backs of the most precarious and at the expense of investments in the network and production capacity. So I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I object to any EU legislation in this field. I believe that in order to alleviate energy poverty, the UK should make its own energy policy and invest in low-cost reliable energy sources such as nuclear.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We are against the report because we object new EU legislation in this field. We in UKIP believe that the UK should make its own energy policy and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. I approved this report on the Commission's communication entitled 'A new deal for energy consumers'. MEPs stress that the energy transition must lead to a more decentralised, more energy-efficient, more flexible and largely renewable energy-based system. In this context, this includes ensuring that citizens are provided with stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy, as well as energy-efficient products, services and buildings. The energy union must also help to eradicate energy insecurity, protect consumers from abusive or unfair practices and promote energy-saving measures.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted today in favour of the Griffin report on a 'new deal' for energy consumers. It is a text that effectively highlights how the current phase of energy transition is leading to an overshoot of the centralised energy production system, which has so far prevailed.  The evolution towards decentralisation, however, brings with it many challenges, which require an adequate response built around two key elements: on the one hand, the principle of energy efficiency, on the other hand that of building a genuine Energy Union, which protects consumers from abusive practices and at the same time allows citizens to produce, consume, store or exchange their renewable energy. Investment in new technologies must be a priority combined with stronger support from the Commission for initiatives such as the Covenant of Mayors, Smart Cities and Communities and 100 % RES communities. Only with a global approach will it be possible to build a more efficient, sustainable and inclusive energy system.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Griffin report, because it represents a good opportunity to promote energy self-consumption (stable legal framework, rejection of retroactive measures, removal of administrative and financial barriers), while aiming to provide tools to combat energy poverty and recognize access to energy as a basic social right.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I would like to thank the rapporteur for her work. I supported this report, which mentions, inter alia, that the Energy Union must focus on the interests of current and future generations of citizens, empowering them to produce, consume, store or market their own renewable energy. It is requested that efforts should be made to eradicate energy poverty with better coordination at Union level, through the sharing of best practices among Member States and the development of a broad definition of it.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report, which has the sole purpose of privatizing energy. While encouraging alternative models of energy production can be a good idea, especially through self-production or cooperative production, it is regrettable that the millefeuille of standards on this subject decided by Brussels is actually aimed at taking away their energy sovereignty from states. In particular, the report stresses the change of supplier, which is clearly aimed at putting an end to the state monopoly, even in cases where they would benefit consumers, particularly in terms of investments in infrastructure. What is politely referred to as "liberalisation" of the energy sector actually risks leading individuals and businesses alike to pay more for energy, to the benefit of multinationals with comfortable margins.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although I am partly acceptable, there are still some highly critical passages that convinced me to vote against.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Griffin report on the establishment of a new agreement for energy consumers, prior to the legislative initiatives that form part of the Energy Union strategy. I support the rapporteur's approach, which places citizens at the heart of the Energy Union, with measures to save on the energy bill.  The fight against energy poverty, which affects more than 50 million people in Europe, must be a vital objective and affordable energy must be a basic social right. No one should have to choose between eating or paying for heating/cooling.  I regret that the EPP voted against prioritizing energy poverty alleviation measures in forthcoming legislative proposals. The same will be removed from the final report proposed in favour of self-generation and self-consumption of energy. Citizens who produce their own energy should not be penalized with taxes or abusive charges, as has been the case in my country with the sun tax. If we do not place citizens at the base of energy market efficiency, the climate targets agreed in Paris cannot be achieved.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report, in which the European Parliament examines a package of new options for energy consumers. Although some progress has been made, the objective of the third energy package, which is to create a truly competitive, transparent and consumer-friendly retail energy market, has not yet been fully achieved in all EU Member States, as evidenced by the still high market concentration indicators, the fact that the fall in wholesale prices is not reflected in the retail prices of certain Member States, the sluggish shift of consumers to other suppliers and the low satisfaction. The European Parliament therefore considers that the Commission needs to establish or develop additional indicators for well-functioning and user-friendly energy markets. Stresses, furthermore, that account should be taken of the economic impact on consumers switching suppliers, technical barriers to switching suppliers or plan and the level of consumer awareness. Parliament believes that open, transparent and competitive properly regulated markets are important in order to reduce prices, stimulate innovation, improve customer service and remove barriers to innovative new business models that can offer citizens great value, enabling them and helping to avoid energy poverty.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the european Parliament's motion for a resolution on a new arrangement for energy consumers, or the so-called third energy package. It aims to ensure a truly competitive, transparent and customer-friendly retail energy market. Unfortunately, despite some progress, this is not yet achieved in all EU Member States, as evidenced by the constantly high levels of market concentration and also by the fact that the ever-lower wholesale costs are not reflected in retail prices. I believe that open, transparent and competitive well-regulated markets are the most important for maintaining low prices, encouraging innovation and improving services for consumers. We can also improve the price-to-service ratio and contribute to the prevention of energy poverty by removing the barriers currently facing innovative energy business models.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Within the framework of the Energy Union strategy, consumers will have a role of sure centrality. We must establish a legislative framework that enhances its contribution and stimulates its active role. This resolution, which I supported, shows that in many European countries consumers still face charges for switching suppliers; as well as the late spread of the smart meter tool, on which Italy has been a pioneer. One area on which we certainly need to make progress is that of the legibility of bills.
