With a clear understanding of their consumption and understandable information on tariff bands and plans, consumers will increasingly be able to play an active role in the market. The legislative framework relating to self-handling from renewable sources and network connection dynamics also needs to be developed and harmonised. The legislative proposals that the European Commission will present in the coming months will be an opportunity to take action in all these areas.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Commission has published an estimate that the average household would save 10 to 30 percent on heating and cooling only when they could know how much they were spending at any given time. In much of the EU, bills come quarterly, or even year-on-year, so the consumer cannot know until January next year how much it will cost to direct. In some EU countries, savings are already a reality. In Estonia and scandinavian countries, consumers can access real-time online spending calculations and save the projected 30 percent. On behalf of the Socialists and Democrats Club, I believe that no one should choose between electricity, heating, water or health services or education. It should be borne in mind that most energy-vulnerable citizens are not active in the energy market, and therefore social tariffs should not only be enabled, but also promoted.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. Privatisation, competition and deregulation of the energy sector advocated by this report are likely to lead individuals and businesses alike to pay for increasingly expensive energy, ensuring comfortable margins for multinational oligopolies made on the backs of the most insecure and at the expense of investments in the grid and production capacity. I therefore voted against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the Commission's proposal for a 'new deal' for energy consumers contains some extremely positive elements that will enable citizens to obtain more sustainable energy at lower prices.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The citizens of the European Union have been waiting for this piece of legislation for a long time.  The European electricity system is undergoing a period of profound change. The share of electricity produced from renewable energy sources will increase from the current 25 to 50 % in 2030. But even in the absence of sun and wind, electricity must still be produced in sufficient quantities to cover consumers' needs and keep the electricity grid stable. The electricity market is constantly evolving and today's market differs profoundly from that of ten years ago.  We must support all available means of energy efficiency: new network technologies, measuring systems and smart homes, self-handling and storage equipment, which give citizens the opportunity to take an active role in the energy transition, using them to reduce their bills and actively participate in the market. We must allow consumers to make a conscious choice and to be able to move easily in the supply of the market, which is why transparency of operators and a clear political will on the part of the Union to democratise the European energy system are important.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This draft report aims to aggravate the separation between energy producers and distributors in order to complete the liberalisation of the energy market: privatization, competition and price deregulation. If the mentions relating to self-production, i.e. the energy autonomy of households and the distribution of smart meters that better manage electricity consumption, the fundamental objective of this text is to permanently break the last monopolies in energy production and distribution, which risks leading to a sharp rise in consumer prices, which is very detrimental to the purchasing power of taxpayers. I voted against this draft report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses exclusively on household energy consumers, and industrial consumers should be treated in a completely different context. The ongoing energy transition leads to a shift from an energy system based on traditional centralised generation, to a more decentralised, energy-efficient, but also more flexible and largely based on renewable energy sources. As regards the costs of switching to a new market structure in certain Member States, the report draws the attention of the European Commission and calls on it to take these costs into account in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, the ultimate objective being an economy based 100% on renewable energy sources. I voted in favour of the report on 'New benefits for energy consumers' because I believe that it is necessary to support new types of energy, especially renewable ones for much better economic development at both Member States and the EU.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report, although it contains some ideas that we can support on combating energy poverty and promoting renewables, is fully functional to the Energy Union. I am voting against, in line with what the delegation has said in this parliamentary term.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of all the technological developments that have gained momentum in recent years and the objective of having a 100% renewable energy economy that Europe is proposing, I support this report which highlights the need for a new organisation of the energy market. The European Union must be a model for the whole world in terms of making the internal energy market more efficient and carry forward a forward-looking climate change policy. The main beneficiaries of this new energy policy must be citizens, who, through access to new technologies, will be able to reduce their bills and have active market participation through efficient management of energy consumption. The installation of heating control devices and thermostats can have a significant impact on energy consumption, but only by corroborating it with a serious housing rehabilitation project that many European cities need. People will not only save money, but they will make a significant contribution to reducing energy consumption.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Griffin Report on the establishment of a new agreement for energy consumers, prior to legislative initiatives based on the Energy Union strategy. I support the rapporteur's approach to the central core of the Energy Union, with measures to save on the energy bill.  The fight against energy poverty, which affects more than 50 million people in Europe, must be a vital objective and affordable energy must be a basic social right. No one should have to choose between eating or paying for heating/cooling.  I regret that the EPP voted against prioritizing energy poverty alleviation measures in future legislative proposals. The same thing that proposals for self-generation and self-consumption of energy were removed from the final report. Citizens who produce their own energy should not be penalized with taxes or abusive charges as has been the case in my country with the sun tax. If we do not place citizens at the base of energy market efficiency, the climate targets agreed in Paris cannot be achieved.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. Rethinking the way we consume energy is a necessity in our time. To do this we need to inform European citizens of their energy opportunities and put in place incentives to enable them to consume both economically and ecologically. We need a more decentralised, flexible energy system that is as focused as possible on renewable energy.  However, let us not forget that the energy transition requires a period of adaptation so that all stakeholders can adjust to the new recommendations. We must combine the preservation of the environment with the economic competitiveness of European companies. Consumers are at the centre of this energy transition and we must also help them adapt to these new standards. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today because I believe that, although some progress has been made, the objective of the third energy package to establish a truly competitive, transparent and consumer-friendly retail energy market has not yet been fully achieved. This is demonstrated by the persistence of high levels of market concentration, the fact that the reduction in wholesale costs does not result in a reduction in retail prices, the small number of supplier changes and the low level of consumer satisfaction.  Emphasis must be placed on the importance of properly regulated, open, transparent and competitive energy markets in order to keep prices low and improve customer service, giving European citizens more decision-making power and helping them to avoid energy poverty. I would remind you that the customer has limited choice with regard to distribution networks because of the nature of their natural monopolies. This means that customers cannot change their distribution system manager. There is therefore a need for adequate monitoring of the distribution network operators' market to protect customers from sudden increases in distribution bills, for example by setting a legal maximum percentage for each increase.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which sets out a series of guidelines on energy transition in favour of consumers who have started to generate their own energy through, for instance, private wind turbines on farms or solar panels on houses. The report calls for transparent and fairer pricing and says that the transition should result in a more efficient, sustainable, stable, decentralised and inclusive energy system so that citizens, local actors and communities can be empowered to produce and distribute energy from renewable sources. I was also happy to support this report as it calls for energy poverty to be addressed so that affordable energy becomes a basic social right. In light of the vast number of houses in Ireland currently struggling to pay various household-related taxes and charges, this was an important point. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We are against the report because we object new EU legislation in this field. We in UKIP believe that the UK should make its own energy policy and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the Commission’s communication on the ‘New Deal for Energy Consumers’ and I therefore voted in favour of this report. The report outlines some very good proposals to increase the competitiveness of the energy market, which I hope will soon be realised, and these seem to create many benefits for the consumers. I am particularly satisfied with the measures which are to help bring energy poverty to an end.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report expresses the European Parliament's position on the strategy to be adopted to deal with the consumer/citizen dimension in energy legislation coming this autumn. Solutions are proposed to improve the functioning of the energy market so that its citizens benefit directly, who, moreover, want to encourage the active role in the energy transition in the production of renewables and energy efficiency. A number of requests submitted by the Delegation of the 5-Star Movement have been accepted, such as, for example, the call for a shared EU definition of the term "prosumers" and for measures to stimulate behavioural change for the energy transition. In light of the positive aspects of the report and the inclusion of the requests presented by the 5 Star Movement, I voted in favour with great conviction.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and believe that the ultimate objective should be an economy based entirely on renewable energy sources. In this context, the Energy Union should focus on the interests of current and future generations of citizens.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on a new agreement for energy consumers focuses exclusively on domestic energy consumers and aims to move to an economy based entirely on renewable energy sources, the provision of stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy and the eradication of energy poverty.  I believe that these objectives are very important and achieving them will be a benefit to the citizens. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 From the documentation presented to me I was able to verify how important this report is really important in the field of energy, energy sustainability and renewable energy sources. I think it is necessary to protect the enormous resources that our world offers us and this always bearing in mind as its final objective the realization of an economy based 100% on renewable energies. An economy that prioritises energy saving in order to guarantee energy security, competitiveness and, above all, the reduction of consumer bills.  That is why I voted in favour of this report: to put individual citizens in a position to play an active role in the energy transition, to produce their own renewable energy and to increase its efficiency. With this vote, I have therefore voted for better development throughout the Union with specific responses to the individual causes of energy poverty.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ The ultimate goal here should be an economy based on 100% renewables, which can only be achieved through reducing our energy consumption, making full use of the ‘energy efficiency first/first fuel’ principle and prioritising energy savings and demand side measures over the supply side in order to meet our climate goals in line with the Paris Agreement 1.5° scenario, energy security, competitiveness and especially lower consumer bills.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We are against the report because we object new EU legislation in this field. We in UKIP believe that the UK should make its own energy policy and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: in writing. The ongoing energy transition must be translated into a more efficient, transparent, sustainable, competitive, stable energy system that favours society as a whole and contributes to increased participation of citizens and communities at local and regional level. Despite progress, the objective of the third energy package to establish a truly competitive, transparent and consumer-friendly energy retail market has not yet been fully realised in all Member States of the Union. To this end, I would like to point out the need for the implementation of the third energy package, in particular as regards the right to switch from energy suppliers free of charge and the better provision of information to consumers on their rights, and independent and up-to-date price comparison tools should exist. On the other hand, it is essential that all websites and billing systems are fully accessible to people with disabilities. At the same time, I warn that the processing and storage of citizens' energy data should be managed by entities that comply with the EU's existing regulatory framework on privacy and data protection. I have for the foregoing supported this report.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – We are against the report because we object new EU legislation in this field. We in UKIP believe that the UK should make its own energy policy and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of adopting a new energy resource management system that will benefit consumers in terms of efficiency and accessibility. The energy transition to new renewable energy sources should provide citizens with stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy, as well as high-quality and energy-efficient products, services and buildings. It is necessary to develop conditions conducive to the creation of an efficient and competitive internal energy market that offers consumers choice as well as clear and transparent access to information. I also express the need to adopt energy measures to enhance the competitiveness of European companies operating or entering the energy market by establishing an effective system for the marketing of energy.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I agree with the scope of the report to build a more decentralised, flexible and renewable-based energy system for EU countries. I agree that by empowering citizens to take ownership of the energy transition, produce their own renewable energy and become energy efficient it will be beneficial to both our consumers and tackle the problem of energy poverty. A transparent and consumer-friendly retail energy market has not yet been fully realised in all EU Member States, as evidenced by persistent high levels of market concentration. I agree that the failure to reflect falling wholesale costs in retail prices will be a disservice to consumers. We should recognise that energy is a common good at the service of the community in order to facilitate the energy transition and deliver its maximum value. For this reason, I agree with the report in that it recommends developing guidelines for price-comparison tools to ensure that consumers can access independent, up-to-date and understandable comparison tools for greater control over their consumption and efficient energy use.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the report because it is a real step forward in setting up electricity markets at European level in the context of the transition to a sustainable economy. The report focuses on the role that consumers can play in the context of this energy transition and, although the report does not refer to the fundamental role that the public sector must play in this transition, as well as the importance of involving the social partners, it launches interesting proposals for the functioning of an energy sector that can combat energy poverty. While energy poverty cannot only be considered and fought from the demand side, the measures contained in the report are a good compendium in undertaking the fight against this growing phenomenon. The report introduces key aspects of the energy debate, such as the participation of local and regional authorities in the design of energy markets, seeks to promote information transparency in the functioning of energy markets, as well as calls for the definition of the term "prosumer" in view of the new laws to implement energy union.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution focuses on domestic energy consumers in the context of the energy transition and supports the Commission's work to ensure greater affordability. The energy transition is resulting in a move away from the energy system based on traditional centralised production in order to move towards a more decentralised, energy-efficient, flexible and renewable energy-based system.  I voted in favour, because I believe that the interests of present and future generations must be placed at the heart of the Energy Union. In particular, I believe that we need a well-functioning, inclusive and beneficial energy market for citizens, who must be put in a position to play an active role in the transition, produce their own renewable energy and become energy efficient.  I agree with the idea of establishing a one-stop shop in each state that provides the information to put consumers in a position to make decisions, or that EU funds for energy efficiency and support for self-handling are primarily intended for low-income or energy-poor consumers. Only through a truly competitive, transparent and consumer-friendly energy market will it be possible to establish a genuine Energy Union.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Since energy cost volatility can have major repercussions on consumers, it is important that the European Union and the Member States have a firm policy to decentralise energy systems and increase efficiency and flexibility through resource diversification. Together with these, improving and strengthening connections with Member States and partners should be a priority for the development of two-way flows at each cross-border interconnection. Reducing the monopoly and encouraging citizens' participation, individually or collectively, in the energy market can contribute to eradicating energy poverty and protecting consumers by providing stable, sustainable, affordable energy and energy-efficient products, services and buildings.  I voted in favour of this report because I believe that the effects of the instability of energy policies are felt at the level of the well-being of European citizens. Thus, we expressed the need to put the citizen at the heart of European energy policies by developing functional energy systems based on collaboration between local, communal and citizens.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report "A new direction for energy consumers" is an important stage in achieving the objectives of the Energy Union. Ensuring stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy is in the national interest. The development of consumer-friendly, competitive and well-functioning energy markets is key, and full implementation of the third energy package is essential to achieve these objectives. Adequate information to consumers is a prerequisite for energy-conscious behaviour. As a result, improving the transparency of accounts and ensuring comparability of service provider accounts is in the common interest – these measures may even lead to lower overhead costs. It is particularly practical for consumers to create up-to-date and easy-to-understand comparison tools and interfaces and to provide information on these options. Ensuring switching is an essential condition for competition.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report was prepared in response to the Commission Communication on the implementation of a new contract for energy consumers, which is based on three pillars: saving money and consumer energy through better information; increasing consumer choice; maintaining the highest level of consumer protection. I believe that it is very important to create an energy system that is fair to consumers and contributes to the protection of poor energy consumers. However, I am concerned that many of the amendments adopted in the draft report violate the principles of subsidiarity and are unworkable in practice. For example, I am a supporter of the idea of a broad and non-binding definition of energy poverty, because any attempt to establish a central definition would be useless, because nations define energy needs differently or the low-income threshold. It should also be borne in mind that a large number of the provisions referred to in the report already exist under the Third Energy Package and therefore require better implementation instead of new rules. However, these are not very negative provisions and, in my opinion, the report is appropriate and raises important issues. In view of the above, I voted in favour of it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The role of consumers in the energy market is fundamental in order to ensure an inclusive and fair energy system. We need to have an energy union which truly safeguards consumer interests of both present and future generations. I voted in favour of this report as I agree with the rapporteur that more needs to be done in order to empower our citizens in the energy market. We need to protect consumers from unfair practices from suppliers and also make available the tools they need to be empowered, which are highlighted in the report, such tools consist of treating them fairly when they produce their own energy in terms of Taxes and charges. I strongly agree with the need to address the causes of energy poverty and with the principle that access to affordable energy is a basic social right.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report welcomes the European Commission's communication and stresses the need to move from a centralised and rigid energy system to a decentralised, flexible and renewable energy-based system. Considering that the energy market must be reformed to promote sustainable and renewable energy in order to meet economic and environmental issues, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on a 'new deal for energy consumers'. It is necessary to move from a centralised energy system to a more decentralised system based on renewable energies. This transition would lead to an economy that is primarily based on renewable energy. To achieve this goal, it is important to change our energy consumption habits.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. I believe it is necessary to move from a centralised and rigid energy system to a more decentralised, flexible and renewable energy-based system. That's why I voted in favour of the Griffin report entitled "A New Deal for Energy Consumers." I am convinced of the need to help consumers take ownership of the energy transition, produce their own energy and become more energy efficient.  Finally, by voting in favour of this text, we have committed ourselves to preventing energy insecurity, in particular with the "primacy of energy efficiency" which gives priority to energy savings and measures acting on demand rather than on supply.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. With a view to contributing to the progressive direction of the Energy Union legislation being overhauled, I supported my colleague Theresa Griffin's report. This resolution makes progress on three points. On management arrangements, it defends collective purchasing systems (particularly at the apartment building level) and encourages self-production and self-consumption by calling for reducing administrative barriers affecting them.  On price transparency, it provides easy and fast access to consumption and related cost data and measures that allow consumers to compare different offers and switch suppliers without having to pay extravagant termination fees.  On the prioritization of EU funds for energy efficiency, social tariffs are needed to adapt to situations of energy insecurity and that aid for self-production benefits the poorest, which is far from the case.  Finally, on this report, I supported an amendment to recognise, in the context, the status of the 'common good' on the question of energy, so that it would never be confiscated for the benefit of a few.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE)
text: Writing. – The 'New direction for energy consumers' report is an important stage in achieving the objectives of the Energy Union. Ensuring stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy is in the national interest. The development of consumer-friendly, competitive and well-functioning energy markets is key, and full implementation of the third energy package is essential to achieve these objectives. As the report emphasises, adequate consumer information is a prerequisite for energy-conscious behaviour. As a result, improving the transparency of invoices and ensuring comparability of service provider accounts is in our common interest – as this can lead to lower overhead costs. It is particularly practical for consumers to create up-to-date and easy-to-understand comparison tools and interfaces and to provide information on these options. After all, ensuring switching is an essential condition for competition. Although I do not fully agree with all the points in the report, the direction is good and should be supported.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is part of the 3rd energy package which aims, in particular since 2009, to liberalise the energy market: privatization, competition and price deregulation. The fundamental objective is to put an end to state monopolies. However, it is not clear that price deregulation necessarily benefits the consumer in the long run.  Moreover, this policy does not exclude a very restrictive bureaucratic over-regulation in this sector, which risks leading to an increasingly expensive energy, to the benefit of multinational oligopolies. Finally, it is up to each Member State to define its energy policy and ensure the investments necessary for the development or maintenance of infrastructure, especially when it has made the choice of nuclear power. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Although many of the things in this report are in the Third Energy Package, I supported it because it is aimed at the end user and in particular to be able to inform himself more easily and thus be able to receive lower electricity prices. Also, awareness of what exactly pays is also important because many people in my country do not understand many of the things that are included in their payment documents. Of course, huge attention should be paid to the energy poor, and there are many in Bulgaria, while at the same time doing so in an established order so that there are no abuses.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as the energy needs and energy adequacy of the Member States differ substantially from each other and therefore cannot be placed under the full control of the EU without significant losses, especially for the "energy" wealthy states.

name: Norbert Erdős (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The "New Direction for Energy Consumers" report is an important stage in achieving the objectives of the Energy Union. Ensuring stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy is in the national interest. The development of consumer-friendly, competitive and well-functioning energy markets is key, and full implementation of the third energy package is essential to achieve these objectives. As the report emphasises, adequate consumer information is a prerequisite for energy-conscious behaviour. As a result, improving the transparency of invoices and ensuring comparability of service provider accounts is in our common interest – as this can lead to lower overhead costs. It is particularly practical for consumers to create up-to-date and easy-to-understand comparison tools and interfaces and to provide information on these options. After all, ensuring switching is an essential condition for competition. Although I do not fully agree with all the points in the report, the direction is good, so I voted in favour of the report.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. The ongoing energy transition is diverting from an energy system based on traditional centralised power generation to a more decentralised, energy-efficient and flexible energy system largely based on renewable energy. In this transition, it is becoming increasingly important to strengthen the power of energy consumers and I welcome the report in these parts as the European Union has an important role to play here. On the other hand, the report unfortunately contains a great deal about energy poverty, which does not belong at European level, because this is social policy that the EU should not engage in, and that is why I voted against these elements.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: privatization, competition and deregulation of the energy sector are likely to lead individuals and businesses alike to pay for increasingly expensive energy.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is part of a vision of privatisation and liberalisation of the energy sector. Vision that the report assumes, without contesting.  It therefore ignores the whole process of dismantling and privatising companies that traditionally vertically and under a state monopoly, the production activities (in the case of electricity), transport, distribution and marketing of energy. The centralization of national or regional energy systems, public and universal access to energy, can be classified as a civilizational achievement of the European peoples. It was a situation that made it possible to optimise planning and operationalisation to meet the needs of consumers, including renewable energy. With many advantages, for example, because it would not lead to the multiplication of production and transport structures, it avoided the enormous difficulties of managing the system that today arises, ensuring the correct and rational use of resources and the adoption of the best energy efficiency measures. It is technically and economically indefensible that the spraying of small production and the geographical distance of production from consumption contribute to the efficiency of energy systems, in particular in electricity. Electricity produced locally as a small business will never be able to compete economically with centralised production systems, so it will only be viable when subsidized by consumers or taxpayers.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I believe that it is very necessary to create a fairer energy system for all consumers, never losing sight of protection from energy poverty. In this respect, it seems appropriate to establish a new agreement that guarantees the consumer a reduction in costs through better and more extensive information.

name: Luke Ming Flanagan (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against as it does not support the democratisation of energy.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report which, although it contains some ideas that we can support on combating energy poverty and promoting renewables, is fully functional to the Energy Union.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report focuses on the consumer perspective of the energy union and the rapporteur has chosen to focus her report on the issues of ensuring the energy market benefits citizens, ensuring an inclusive energy system by empowering consumers to produce their own energy, promoting the development of demand-side management and addressing the causes of energy poverty. I support the inclusion, in the report, of a call for a definition of energy poverty at EU level, focusing on the idea that access to affordable energy is a basic social right; the request for the Commission to prioritise measures to alleviate energy poverty in upcoming legislative proposals and present a dedicated action plan by mid-2017; and the call for a ban on doorstep-selling by energy suppliers/retailers. Considering the urgent need to tackle energy poverty and to challenge big energy suppliers, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported my fellow Member Griffin's report, as the Energy Union must focus primarily on the interests of current and future generations of citizens and, to this end, provide affordable and efficient energy and high-quality energy-efficient products, services and buildings to consumers. However, in many Member States market concentration is still high and the reduction in wholesale costs is often not reflected in retail prices. The Commission should define or develop additional indicators for well-functioning, consumer-friendly energy markets, taking into account the economic impact on energy consumers switching providers, technical barriers to switching or treaty change or levels of consumer awareness. I believe that the prices set by the market benefit consumers and that network charges should therefore be designed in such a way as to allow for a reasonable collection of costs and not to hinder energy efficiency measures. Full implementation of the third energy package is necessary, including the right to switch providers free of charge and improving consumer information on their rights.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Griffin Report on the establishment of a new agreement for energy consumers, prior to legislative initiatives based on the Energy Union strategy. I support the rapporteur's approach to the central core of the Energy Union, with measures to save on the energy bill.  The fight against energy poverty, which affects more than 50 million people in Europe, must be a vital objective and affordable energy must be a basic social right. No one should have to choose between eating or paying for heating.  I regret that the EPP voted against prioritizing energy poverty alleviation measures in forthcoming legislative proposals, as well as removing proposals for self-generation and self-consumption of energy from the final report. Citizens who produce their own energy should not be penalized with taxes, as has happened in Spain with the sun tax. If we do not place citizens at the base of energy market efficiency, the climate targets agreed in Paris cannot be achieved.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Griffin Report on the establishment of a new agreement for energy consumers, prior to legislative initiatives based on the Energy Union strategy. I support the rapporteur's approach to the central core of the Energy Union, with measures to save on the energy bill.  The fight against energy poverty, which affects more than 50 million people in Europe, must be a vital objective and affordable energy must be a basic social right. No one should have to choose between eating or paying for heating/cooling.  I regret that the EPP voted against prioritizing energy poverty alleviation measures in forthcoming legislative proposals and against the removal of proposals for self-generation and self-consumption of energy from the final report. Citizens who produce their own energy should not be penalized with taxes or abusive charges as has been the case in my country with the sun tax. If we do not place citizens at the base of energy market efficiency, the climate change targets agreed in Paris cannot be achieved.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. I welcome Mrs Griffin's report: I share the positive assessment of the energy strategy recently presented by the European Commission, it is an ambitious plan that can lay the conditions for a framework of great efficiency and innovation in domestic energy consumption. We are in a real phase of energy transition, which is translating into a move away from an energy system based on traditional centralised production, and instead moving towards a more decentralised, efficient, flexible and largely based system based on renewable energies.  Against this background, Europe will be able to take a major step forward not only towards the internationally signed environmental protection objectives, but also to make a major leap forward in modernisation, innovation and research.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the non-legislative resolution 'a new deal' for energy consumers, as I believe that consumers should have more power in the energy market and I share the challenge of energy efficiency, self-generation and other measures aimed at vulnerable citizens in energy poverty. At present, 50 million European citizens live in energy poverty. Many of whom are forced into contracts that often require them to pay a hen penalty when switching to a cheaper supplier. The elimination of these penalties is just one of the most significant requests to the Commission, in view of the legislative proposals that will be presented in September.  The additional demands are aimed at introducing new business models, such as collective purchasing systems and innovative financial instruments that promote self-handling, self-consumption and energy efficiency measures; the promotion of Community/cooperative energy systems; clear prices and comparable tariffs.  The fight against energy poverty – cases where people are unable to have heating or use electricity in their affordable homes – must be tackled at its root, through the introduction of 'Social Tariffs' for low-income and vulnerable citizens.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. As a member of the ENVI Committee on the Environment, the question of a functioning energy market is important to me. European energy policy is closely linked to environmental policy. In these important areas, EU directives must be properly implemented in order to reduce CO2 emissions and achieve the 20% target by 2020. In addition, red tape must be cut in order to make it easier for consumers to save energy.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Griffin report because it represents a good opportunity to promote energy self-consumption (stable legal framework, rejection of retroactive measures, removal of administrative and financial barriers), while aiming to provide tools to combat energy poverty and recognize access to energy as a basic social right.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for this report and I would like to congratulate the rapporteur. I believe that there is a need for an energy market that works to the benefit of citizens. This has not yet been achieved because in many Member States the retail energy market has not led to lower retail prices. Captive consumers – citizens have a low level of supplier change. I am pleased that the report underlines the need to analyse aggressive tax planning. I believe that a joint effort by the Commission and the Member States is needed to interconnect all consumers regardless of which area they live in: urban, rural, mountainous. I support the provision in the report on the transparency and clarity of contracts and consumer invoices. The energy system in the single market must be socially inclusive. The Commission should take into account the recommendations in the report on reducing obstacles to the opening of new production capacities from its own sources – simplifying and shortening depreciation procedures.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The main goal is to make energy consumers just as well informed and empowered as buyers and sellers operating on wholesale energy markets. This can be achieved through clearer billing and advertising rules, trustworthy price comparison tools and by leveraging schemes such as collective switching and energy cooperatives.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. We Social Democrats have voted in favour of the report on a new deal for energy consumers. We have abstained on a ban on home sales, as we believe that horizontal measures rather than individual bans are needed to address the consumer problems of home sales.  We have also abstained on a wording on working for targeted discounts on electricity for certain groups. We are convinced that active measures will be needed to combat energy poverty. Discounts to different groups can be one way, and where energy companies choose to give such a discount, we are obviously not against this. However, we believe that there are more long-term sustainable measures than discounts on electricity, such as an active distribution policy and targeted investments in energy efficiency, etc., in order to reduce the energy costs of vulnerable groups. We therefore do not want to lock ourselves in to this individual measure.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Griffin Report on the establishment of a new agreement for energy consumers, prior to legislative initiatives based on the Energy Union strategy. I support the rapporteur's approach to the central core of the Energy Union, with measures to save on the energy bill.  The fight against energy poverty, which affects more than 50 million people in Europe, must be a vital objective and affordable energy must be a basic social right. No one should have to choose between eating or paying for heating/cooling.  I regret that the EPP voted against prioritizing energy poverty alleviation measures in future legislative proposals. The same thing that proposals for self-generation and self-consumption of energy were removed from the final report. Citizens who produce their own energy should not be penalized with taxes or abusive charges as has been the case in my country with the sun tax. If we do not place citizens at the base of energy market efficiency, the climate targets agreed in Paris cannot be achieved.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Both positive and negative reports are included in the report. The position of decentralisation in energy management is problematic, with the responsibility of shifting from the state to SMEs, consumers and local communities. Negative, too, is the call on states to implement immediately the third energy package, for which we have expressed disagreement as it does not meet the needs of society. The proposals that are being developed promote the privatisation of energy, with negative consequences, of course, primarily on citizens but also on the state and society.  On the positive side, the objective of combating energy poverty is recorded with a specific relationship plan and a focus on the fact that access to affordable energy is a basic social right. Protecting consumers from unfair market practices as well as the proposal to ensure states have a strong legal framework that puts an end to the charging of unpaid bills are positive elements. For these reasons, we consider this abstention to be an appropriate attitude.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I was happy to support the report pressing for a new deal for energy consumers across the EU, to improve consumer choice, information and transparency, and to increase the EU-wide deployment of ICT, which can reduce energy use and household bills. There should be an implementation of market liberalisation measures to tackle persistently high levels of market concentration, improve low levels of consumer switching, and for retail prices to better reflect falling wholesale costs. Enhanced coordination at EU level to combat energy poverty through the sharing of best practices among Member States and the development of a broad, common but non-quantitative definition of energy poverty is important. This should focus on the idea that access to affordable energy is a basic social right, providing a coherent and cohesive policy for consumers.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I had no problems with its final outcome and welcome the aim of bringing the energy union together.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report "On Improved Opportunities for Energy Consumers" ("Griffin Report") does not have a legal binding effect as such, but can be understood as a political signal. The ALFA agrees with the core content of this report and supports a wide range of objectives set out in the report. All that should be mentioned here is fair access to energy and full access for consumers to all the information they need to meet their energy needs. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report. However, if the European Commission were to launch a draft law on this matter, I will have to weigh much more critically whether this is not an attempt to impose common definitions on the Member States and on joint action, which is ultimately dysfunctional. The Griffin report's call for energy poverty to be combated at supranational level may serve as a cautionary example. However, this cannot be achieved because no consensus can be reached at EU level on key concepts such as 'energy need' and 'low income'. Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Gunnar Hökmark (PPE)
text: Written. With regard to the report on a new deal for energy consumers, we voted against calls for energy poverty to be tackled at European level. Energy poverty needs to be addressed, but it should be done within the social safety net of each Member State and is the responsibility of each Member State. In order for consumers to be given better prices and conditions, the market needs to be opened up, subsidies phased out and there is a balance between supply and demand. It should be the focus of the construction of the European Energy Union.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls for Europe’s citizens to have access to affordable and sustainable energy and I welcome that call. In this regard, Scotland is an energy pioneer with almost 60% of electricity consumed in 2015 coming from renewable sources. Last year the Scottish government invested UKP 2.5 million in Our Power Energy, an independent energy supply company operating on a non-profit distributing basis – and I commend initiatives such as this to the House.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report since I strongly believe that the emphasis in the Energy Union should fall on European citizens. Europe’s main concern should be on tackling energy poverty and challenging the big energy suppliers.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on the delivery of new benefits for energy consumers, on the basis that it is necessary to enable consumers to become active players in the energy market as investors, producers and stakeholders. In addition, in addition to ensuring an energy system that works efficiently and efficiently, it is necessary to ensure greater transparency and consumer protection and better availability of information related to energy flows.  In this context, it is necessary to encourage faster development of information and communication technologies, such as mobile applications and online platforms, so that consumers have easier access, credible information and real-time data on their energy consumption. This achieves significant cost reduction, higher energy efficiency and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Are good ideas being undermined by utopias that are dangerous to consumers, especially the big consumers of our industries, who will be the first to suffer from the end of long-term energy policy and regulated tariffs? Privatization, competition and deregulation, which does not exclude a very restrictive bureaucratic over-regulation, of the energy sector are likely to lead individuals and businesses alike to pay for increasingly expensive energy, ensuring that multinational oligopolies have comfortable margins on the backs of the most insecure and at the expense of investments in the network and production capacity. That is why I voted against the text.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In this report, Parliament calls for a new agreement for energy consumers in the EU. It calls for better consumer choice, greater information, transparency and increased use of information and communication technologies to help reduce energy consumption and electricity costs in households. I believe that we need to implement liberalisation measures and ensure a truly transparent and competitive energy market for European consumers. I was therefore happy to support the report, which aims to strengthen consumers and help them to be active market participants.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which calls for further efforts to transition energy towards a more decentralised, energy-efficient, more flexible and largely renewable energy-based system. In addition, this text provides concrete recommendations for the development of a truly competitive and consumer-friendly retail energy market.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report calls for the issue of energy poverty to be communitised. Such a complex issue, which depends primarily on specific circumstances in the Member States, can be better dealt with by social policy measures at country level, rather than communitarisation of social policies at European level. In addition, the report is anti-market, which could damage the dynamism of the European energy landscape. I am therefore voting against this report.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Energy policy must, like all EU policies, take social aspects into account and contribute to fighting poverty and social exclusion. I therefore supported the report as it calls for the end of termination fees so that consumers can switch to a cheaper supplier at no cost. We want straightforward bills that contain consumer-empowering information. We want energy regulators to work with energy suppliers and price-comparison organisations to deliver information directly to consumers.

name: Jaromír Kohlíček (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Under the title of the implementation of the new policy for energy consumers lies a rather extensive report, which on 9 pages brings some interesting ideas. They mistakenly claim that there can be an ideal free market without being influenced by natural monopolies. Sympathetic is the shy statement of the need to eliminate energy poverty. Translated, the author would like to propose a "right to supply electricity". However, the Directive does not deal with this right. The author has an obvious effort to allow everyone to produce electricity. Even in this case, it is not an exact technical specification, but rather an appeal to national governments. Similarly, the declaratory call for reasonable prices remains in place, including the recognition that another price should be at peak times and beyond, the author goes on to talk about the price advantage of operators who have the possibility of providing energy storage to the system. There is talk of the benefits of low prices for consumers, and the expansion of the number of municipalities with full coverage of self-consumption is considered to be a positive. It is recommended to examine the increase of fixed components in invoices, a classic case of a jump in the fixed component of the energy price is the effort of large suppliers to significantly increase the price of connection to the electricity network, or to derive the price of the connection from the size of the circuit breaker. Given that, although tentatively, the report clearly calls for a number of positive changes, the GUE/NGL Group supports it.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report "On Improved Opportunities for Energy Consumers" ("Griffin Report") does not have a legal binding effect as such, but can be understood as a political signal. The ALFA agrees with the core content of this report and supports a wide range of objectives set out in the report. All that should be mentioned here is fair access to energy and full access for consumers to all the information they need to meet their energy needs. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report. However, if the European Commission were to launch a draft law on this matter, I will have to weigh much more critically whether this is not an attempt to impose common definitions on the Member States and on joint action, which is ultimately dysfunctional. The Griffin report's call for energy poverty to be combated at supranational level may serve as a cautionary example. However, this cannot be achieved because no consensus can be reached at EU level on key concepts such as 'energy need' and 'low income'.

name: Στέλιος Κούλογλου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which focuses on domestic energy consumers because of the important role they can play in the ongoing energy transition. On the occasion of the Commission communication entitled 'New Agreement for Energy Consumers', it is stressed that measures taken to achieve the Energy Union should promote consumer protection, provide them with better information on their rights and ways of managing energy sources more efficiently and strengthen coordination at EU level to combat energy poverty.

name: Béla Kovács (NI)
text: Writing. – Nowadays, renewable energy production is beginning to outgrown children's diseases, and technologies are already available that are viable at the level of small communities or even in family investment. The report will help to create and harmonise the legal and economic regulatory background that has so far hampered technical developments and should therefore be supported. The modernisation and replacement of basic power plants should not be neglected or postponed any longer, but as an additional factor increasing security of supply, it is necessary to encourage local electricity production. However, from a network regulatory point of perspective, small producers will be challenging due to the limited storage capacities.

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the introduction of a new trade mechanism for energy consumers, as I believe that enhanced coordination at European Union level is needed to combat energy poverty, focusing on the idea that access to energy at affordable prices is a fundamental social right. Synergies need to be promoted in the area of supporting energy-poor citizens by drawing up a set of good practices to protect the most vulnerable low-income citizens.  Efforts to reduce energy consumption and the principle of 'energy efficiency – most important fuel' must not be left to the background, creating mechanisms to reduce the number of energy-inefficient homes by 2030.  I welcome the possibility for citizens to produce and sell their own energy from renewable sources, which has been established as a fundamental right, and in this regard to minimise administrative obstacles, shortened and simplified authorisation procedures, of course while ensuring compliance with all rules and requirements.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – There is no doubt that consumers should play a more active role on the EU single energy market and benefit more from renewable energies and new technologies. The retail energy market will become truly competitive and transparent if we manage to make it more consumer friendly. To do so, consumers should be in meaningful control of their consumption. We should deliver a new energy deal which empowers consumers in a way that they will have clear information on energy bills (prices, consumption and taxes) and protection from unfair commercial practices. Empowerment of energy consumers is also related to the notion of self-generation and consumption. Citizens should benefit in full from the advancement of green/renewable energy technologies for the home (wind turbines, solar and thermal panels) and the integration of smart home energy management systems. In this regard, we should conduct training and information campaigns in order to fully empower consumers and change their behaviour.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. This project is based on the creation of a 'new deal' for energy consumers. With this report, we want to create a new structure of the electricity market, capable of consolidating the role of energy consumers, but above all in order to move towards a flexible system based on renewable sources. The objective of the third energy package, which is aimed at a competitive retail and consumer market, has not yet been achieved, and that is precisely why we are making a number of concrete recommendations.  These include directing consumers to take into account the ownership of the energy transition, according to which producing their own energy would bring enormous benefits, including a reduction in energy consumption. I believe that the solution offered is beneficial both for consumers, who will be able to manage their consumption also from an economic point of view, and to contribute to the overall reduction of energy consumption. I therefore support Mrs Griffin's report.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the report entitled "A New Deal for Energy Consumers." The fundamental objective of European policy remains to break what is left of state monopolies. Apart from the fact that there is no evidence that price deregulation necessarily benefits the consumer in the long run, it is up to each Member State to define its energy policy and ensure the investments necessary for the development or maintenance of infrastructure, especially when nuclear has been chosen.  Privatisation, competition and deregulation, which does not exclude a very restrictive bureaucratic over-regulation, of the energy sector are likely to lead individuals and businesses alike to pay for increasingly expensive energy, ensuring that multinational oligopolies have comfortable margins on the backs of the most insecure and at the expense of investments in the grid and production capacity.

name: Bogusław Liberadzki (S&D)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I support Theresa Griffin's report. It emphasised the need for better protection for CONSUMERS in the EU, especially energy consumers, who have to pay heavy penalties for switching energy suppliers. We should seek to abolish such practices. Cooperation between Member States is necessary to do so– good practices should be identified and information exchange should be encouraged. One way would be to develop a database of measures applied by different Member States to prevent unfair practices by energy suppliers. Local authorities, national regulators and energy companies can play a key role in tackling this problem. A common European approach is needed to find long-term solutions that benefit consumers and ensure that our industry has access to affordable energy.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is part of the process of liberalising the energy market, and in particular in the third package of energy measures. Essentially, it separates producers and distributors. To do so, it relies on three fundamental measures: privatization, competition and price deregulation.  Some measures are relevant, such as the decentralization of energy production, which would make it easier for individuals or local authorities to install solar panels or other energy producers. In addition, it stresses the importance of transparency and energy efficiency, which are essential principles for the functioning of this market. However, these mementorative aspects are tarnished by the overall liberalizing will of the text, which carries many risks. The state monopoly remains fundamental in this sector, in particular to ensure the stability of nuclear energy. I opposed this text by a vote against it.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Griffin Report on the establishment of a new agreement for energy consumers, prior to legislative initiatives based on the Energy Union strategy. I support the rapporteur's approach to the central core of the Energy Union, with measures to save on the energy bill.  The fight against energy poverty, which affects more than 50 million people in Europe, must be a vital objective and affordable energy must be a basic social right. No one should have to choose between eating or paying for heating/cooling.  I regret that the EPP voted against prioritizing energy poverty alleviation measures in future legislative proposals. The same thing that proposals for self-generation and self-consumption of energy were removed from the final report. Citizens who produce their own energy should not be penalized with taxes or abusive charges as has been the case in my country with the sun tax. If we do not place citizens at the base of energy market efficiency, the climate targets agreed in Paris cannot be achieved.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Griffin Report on the establishment of a new agreement for energy consumers, prior to legislative initiatives based on the Energy Union strategy. I support the rapporteur's approach to the central core of the Energy Union, with measures to save on the energy bill.  The fight against energy poverty, which affects more than 50 million people in Europe, must be a vital objective and affordable energy must be a basic social right. No one should have to choose between eating or paying for heating/cooling.  I regret that the EPP voted against prioritizing energy poverty alleviation measures in future legislative proposals. The same thing that proposals for self-generation and self-consumption of energy were removed from the final report. Citizens who produce their own energy should not be penalized with taxes or abusive charges as has been the case in my country with the sun tax. If we do not place citizens at the base of energy market efficiency, the climate targets agreed in Paris cannot be achieved.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report "On Improved Opportunities for Energy Consumers" ("Griffin Report") does not have a legal binding effect as such, but can be understood as a political signal. The ALFA agrees with the core content of this report and supports a wide range of objectives set out in the report. All that should be mentioned here is fair access to energy and full access for consumers to all the information they need to meet their energy needs. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report. However, if the European Commission were to launch a draft law on this matter, I will have to weigh much more critically whether this is not an attempt to impose common definitions on the Member States and on joint action, which is ultimately dysfunctional. The Griffin report's call for energy poverty to be combated at supranational level may serve as a cautionary example. However, this cannot be achieved because no consensus can be reached at EU level on key concepts such as 'energy need' and 'low income'.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this proposal because I do not agree with the European Union accepting further legislation and further regulation in the energy sector. I do not agree with the idea that 'social tariffs' of electricity for the poor should be introduced. On the contrary, I think it is the EU policy that makes electricity and gas tax and high VAT unaffordable, especially for poor energy, in the form of surcharges on 'renewables'.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ As part of the third energy package, one of the key objectives is to ensure transparency and competitiveness of the retail energy market that will be suitable for all consumers. The target has not yet been fully achieved in all Member States, resulting in uneven consumer satisfaction across the Union.  For this reason, the European Union is making increasing efforts to capture the interests of current and future generations of citizens through an established Energy Union. With the help of the Energy Union, the Union aims to provide citizens with stable, efficient and sustainable energy and to define better price flexibilisation for different Member States, which would ultimately result in new and better benefits for energy consumers. Another objective advocated by the Union through the Energy Union is to train citizens in collective or individual energy production and storage with the principle of energy savings and non-waste. I supported the Report on delivering new benefits for energy consumers in order to make greater progress in rational energy use, the development of new energy and technological innovations and better energy management of all consumers.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting in favour of the report on a new agreement on energy consumers, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 25/5/2015, and because this report is complete and documented.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted for the report on new benefits for energy consumers because the liberalisation and integration of the energy market can only be implemented by taking into account the level of real competition in the market and consumer access, in particular household access to more suppliers.  I believe that the phasing out of regulated energy prices for consumers should take into account the real level of competition in the market in the context of the European Union strategy, which should ensure that consumers have access to safe energy prices. In addition, consumers should have easy access to information on their consumption patterns, together with recommendations from the supplier on the most advantageous tariff.  I call on the Commission, in the legislative proposal to follow, to take the necessary measures to ensure that the benefits of increasing the level of interconnection of national networks are not transferred to distribution system operators, but are directly transformed into benefits for final consumers. Improving the level of interconnection of networks must have a positive effect on energy prices for consumers and therefore the transfer of benefits only to distribution system operators should be avoided.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report.  Despite several interesting proposals, notably on proactive consumers, self-consumption, decentralisation, and the introduction of 'smart meters', the substance of the report clearly aims to deprive Member States of a little more sovereignty over energy policies, which we oppose.  It is essential that the state be able to maintain some control over the measures to be taken in two areas often neglected by the private sector: long-term investment and maintenance. These two areas are of particular importance in highly nuclear-armed states, such as France Moreover, privatization but also competition and deregulation can lead to higher prices.

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on a new deal for energy consumers.  The aim of this report is to achieve an economy based on 100 % renewable energy, which can be achieved by prioritising energy saving and ensuring energy security, competitiveness and the reduction of consumer bills. It is a priority to introduce measures to provide citizens with affordable and sustainable energy, as well as high-quality and energy-efficient services, creating favourable conditions for the creation of an efficient internal energy market that offers consumers choice as well as transparent access to information. Ensuring the full implementation of the third energy package is a priority for the European institutions.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcomed the fact that today's report is aimed exclusively at household energy consumers in the context of the energy transition, as I believe that industrial consumers should fall within a specific framework. In the report, we set ambitious targets such as eradicating energy poverty, we want to better protect consumers and guarantee them full right to information and free choice of energy supplier, as well as to keep retail prices at an affordable level. I also agree that unfair commercial practices must be combated and energy consumers in particular protected. I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marisa Matias (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report because I argue that energy is an essential good that must be in the public domain. This report aims, within the energy market, to create a new framework that defends its consumers. Calling for citizens' access to a stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy supply; the protection of consumers from abusive, anti-competitive and unfair practices of market participants; access to energy bill information in a clear and transparent manner, enabling operator change whenever necessary. The report also promotes citizens' participation in the production, consumption, storage or sale of their own energy from renewable sources, becoming active participants in this sector.  Finally, this own-initiative document presents a set of measures that will contribute to the eradication of energy poverty, based on the idea that access to affordable energy is a basic social right.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 This report concerns only domestic energy consumers and not industrial consumers, who should be subject to a separate legislative regime because of their substantial differences.  By developing the traditional central energy production system, we are moving towards a more decentralised and efficient system based on renewable energy sources, since this is our ultimate goal, the full exploitation of renewable energy sources. At the same time, the main objective of the Energy Union must be to provide energy to citizens at affordable prices, but at the same time at good quality. Protecting citizens must be a priority in the face of unfair competition and energy poverty. I therefore believe that despite the progress that has been made, more effort is needed to achieve a balanced energy Union that combines a competitive environment with friendly prices for the consumer. Improved practical and innovative initiatives will make a significant contribution to achieving this objective, so I am voting in favour of the resolution because I think it contains valuable points.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. Strengthening consumer rights is worth supporting. However, attempts are being made here to take advantage of consumer law. That is why I do not support this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I believe that the liberalisation of the energy sector and real competition between service providers in this area will ensure not only greater consumer choice, but also lower energy prices.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report which outlines the need for more flexibility in energy sources.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report deals with the third energy package that separates producers and distributors in order to make the market more liberal. The text has some good proposals; it insists on self-production and cooperative production. This opens up interesting opportunities for individuals to find autonomy. On the other hand, the report aims to disintegrate the last monopolistic prerogatives of the state. I think it is up to the state to decide its energy policy, especially in nuclear matters. Moreover, it is not certain that liberalisation, desired as a substitute, benefits the consumer. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report focuses exclusively on the new framework for domestic energy consumers in the context of the energy transition. Industrial consumers should be subject to a different picture. The ultimate objective should be to achieve an economy based in full on the principle of 'energy efficiency priority/first fuel' and to focus on energy saving and demand-side measures, rather than supply-side measures, in order to achieve our climate targets, including the 1.5° C target set in the Paris Agreement and the objectives of energy security, competitiveness and, in particular, reduction of consumer bills. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it highlights the need to move towards a more consumer-oriented and fair energy market, beneficial to all citizens.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – The energy market in Europe is in full swing. In order to achieve our energy and climate goals, we will eventually have to move towards an economy based entirely on the use of clean and renewable energy. This report calls for consumers to be made a privileged player in the energy market. The energy market in Europe has since been freed up, but now it is mainly a matter of achieving a transparent and competitive retail market tailored to the consumer. Customers should be given the right to access their energy consumption and the tariffs charged to them on the bill even faster and more clearly - not once a year at the final bill. After all, it has been shown that 'real-time information' motivates consumers to save up to 8% on their consumption and therefore also on their bill. Supplier choice also implies that consumers should be able to switch to competing suppliers quickly and free of charge. It is also a good thing to give consumers who produce renewable energy at home better access to the energy market. Because the more producers supply energy, the more competition there is and the more interesting the invoice becomes for the end user.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – The aim of the third energy package is to ensure a truly competitive, consumer-friendly retail energy market. However, this objective has not yet been met in all Member States. This is evidenced in particular by persistently high levels of concentration in the market, the non-reflection of falling wholesale prices at retail prices, the low numbers of consumers switching to another offer and the low level of satisfaction of consumers. I believe that open, transparent and competitive, well-regulated markets are important for maintaining low prices, stimulating innovation, improving customer service and removing obstacles to new innovative business models that can benefit citizens. Measures should be taken to ensure that the benefits of increasing the level of connectivity of national networks are not pass on to distribution system operators, but are directly translated into benefits for end-users. Furthermore, I believe that improving the interconnection rate of national networks must have a positive impact on the price of energy for consumers, and it must therefore be avoided that the benefits are limited to distribution system operators. In view of the above, I support the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Energy Union should have citizens at its core and contribute to eradicating energy policy and protecting consumers from uncompetitive and unfair practices from suppliers. Therefore, I voted in favour of the report on delivering a new deal for energy consumers, that proposes measures to allow consumers to save money on energy bills by asking suppliers to work with energy regulators, and for price comparison tools to be able to proactively notify consumers of how much they can save by switching supplier.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The report on ‘Delivering a New Deal for Energy Consumers’ brought to our attention the scale of the problem of poor access to modern energy services by our most vulnerable category of citizens, in particular those having two jobs, single parents and elderly people.
