These alarming findings determine us as policymakers to frame affordable energy as a basic social right, asking for simplified bills that should mention clearly tariffs and offers on the market, banning door-step selling and demanding the end of termination fees when switching to cheaper suppliers. I voted in favour of this report, which carries on our group’s diligent struggle conveyed in the S&D Manifesto - Fighting Energy Poverty.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its report, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy recommends that Parliament welcome the Commission's communication of 15 July 2015 entitled 'A new direction for energy consumers'. The report recalls that the ultimate goal should be to achieve an economy based on 100% renewable energies. To this end, the Energy Union must provide citizens with stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy, as well as high-quality energy-efficient products, services and buildings; enable citizens, individually or collectively, to production, consume, store and sell their own renewable energy; contribute to the eradication of energy poverty; protect consumers from abusive, anti-competitive and unfair practices by market participants; create favourable conditions to ensure a well-functioning and competitive internal energy market. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report deals with the new framework for domestic energy consumers in the context of the energy transition, which translates into a move away from a traditional centralised energy system towards a more decentralised, energy-efficient, flexible and largely renewable energy-based system. I believe that citizens should have access to stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy and ensure that products, services and buildings are of high quality and energy efficient.  Thus, as I believe it is essential to strengthen coordination at EU level to combat energy poverty by sharing best practices between Member States and ensuring access to affordable energy as a basic social right. I am voting in favour of this report but I would like to stress that this new configuration of the electricity market should provide consumers with more choice and better control of their participation in a fully functional and efficient energy market.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Privatisation, competition and deregulation of the energy sector will lead individuals and businesses alike to pay more and more energy, ensuring that multinational oligopolies have comfortable margins on the backs of the most insecure and at the expense of investments in the network and production capacity, I therefore vote for this text.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this text, which calls for a more efficient and consumer-friendly European energy market. The report proposes a set of concrete measures to achieve this objective: more frequent and transparent invoices, one-stop energy, implementation of price comparison tools, facilities to switch suppliers, etc.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 We welcome the report on a "new deal" for energy consumers. Within the framework of the energy union, a vast and ambitious project aimed at creating a single energy market within the European Union, thus promoting free competition and discouraging the creation of oligopolies, this report, which provides a new angle to the debate on the energy market, that is to say that of consumers, who should be the first beneficiaries of the benefits provided for in the project, is included.  The creation of an inclusive energy system, in which consumers can contribute to the market by producing energy at home and public actors are able to improve energy poverty situations, must be one of the priorities of this Commission. The energy union must put consumers and their needs at the centre. In this respect, we need to work on eliminating unfair practices by energy suppliers, which contribute to the maintenance of position rents and artificially high prices.  Finally, the report calls for the European Commission's action to be focused on creating a fairer and more competitive market, where it is easy to compare prices and have access to state-of-the-art services for quality and tariffs.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I welcome the new directive on household energy consumers. We are talking about a very important subject that has a direct impact on the citizens of the European Union, as well as on the future generation. The primary objective of the Directive is to set up a stable, affordable and efficient system, which at the same time allows for the introduction of various energy saving measures, the emergence of a competitive energy market and the eradication of energy poverty. I would like to highlight energy poverty, as this poses a particular threat to Central and Eastern Europe, including my country, Slovakia. The winter season is a problem for many families, who are often unable to heat their homes enough or fall behind by paying bills, which leads to serious health problems. I am very confident that with the help of the new directive we can make great progress not only from an economic and social point of view, but also from an environmental point of view. I also see the need to develop a directive that includes questions about the situation of industrial consumers.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ One of the most important goals of the European Union is to achieve an economy based on 100% renewables, which can be achieved only by reducing energy consumption, making full use of the ‘energy efficiency first/first fuel’ principle and prioritising energy savings and demand side measures over the supply in order to achieve our climate goals in line with the Paris Agreement, energy security, competitiveness and lower consumer bills. I have voted for this report that should ensure an inclusive energy by empowering citizens to take ownership of the energy transition, produce their own renewable energy and become energy-efficient.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Energy Union should primarily target the interests of current and future generations of citizens and provide citizens with stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy, as well as energy-efficient products, buildings and services. It should also contribute to the elimination of energy poverty, protect consumers from abusive, uncompetitive and unfair practices by market players and enable them to fully exercise their rights. As S&D ITRE coordinator, I stress that we need to create favourable conditions to ensure a functioning and competitive internal energy market, providing consumers with options and clear and transparent access to information.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it has the interest of the consumer as its focal point. Empowering consumers and enabling them to become actively involved in the energy market by providing them with comprehensive, clear and transparent information about energy prices, suppliers etc. is key to creating an Energy Union, which is affordable, fair and inclusive. Implementing the energy transition, that is, the shift towards energy based on efficiency, flexibility and renewables is vital if we want to cut energy consumption. In this context, I welcome the idea of encouraging, through policy, a behavioural change among citizens, giving them the tools to become ‘prosumers’ who either individually or collectively participate directly in the energy market for example by generating, storing or trading their own renewable energy.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the implementation of the new policy for energy consumers and I agree with its appeal to increase the share of renewable energy sources, achieve energy savings and improve energy efficiency. I am of the opinion that the Member States should fully implement the switching provisions set out in the third energy package and that national legislation must guarantee consumers the right to change supplier quickly, easily and free of charge, without the possibility of switching suppliers being hindered by termination fees or fines. Last but not least, it is important to ensure the enforcement of this right through market surveillance and effective, proportionate and dissuasive sanctions. In the context of the social dimension of energy consumption, the report rightly points out that in some Member States there have been an increase in complaints about door-to-door sales. This is a phenomenon that needs to be strictly controlled.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Measures to strengthen consumer rights are always positive. However, this is an inefficient and inflexible 'one fits all' policy at European level. This must be rejected.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to inform energy consumers about the potential of the energy market and thus help them to save money. Consumers must be able to obtain adequate information on the cheapest energy prices, the possibility of better comparing different offers and certainly the right to exchange suppliers quickly, easily and free of charge. It is also necessary to address the causes of energy poverty by using EU funds and self-production subsidies for low-income and vulnerable citizens.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The EU needs to step up its efforts to eliminate energy poverty and protect vulnerable consumers.  Better coordination at EU level must be ensured in order to combat energy poverty. Common guidelines must be laid down to combat this social phenomenon. In addition, it is essential that a common definition of energy poverty is established. In order to better assess the state of energy poverty in Europe, existing statistics need to be harmonised.  It should be noted that access to affordable energy is a social right and therefore social tariffs should be applied to vulnerable citizens on low incomes. They must also have access to innovative technologies that optimise energy consumption. Greater attention must be paid to improving energy efficiency in the field of construction. For low-income people, Member States should apply certain aid measures to overcome existing difficulties.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We are against the report because we object new EU legislation in this field. We in UKIP believe that the UK should make its own energy policy and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Union is committed to achieving, by reducing energy consumption, an economy based on 100% renewable energy in line with the text adopted in Paris, which places a limit on temperature rise of 1.5°C. In order to achieve these objectives, there needs to be an efficient internal market that allows citizens to benefit from affordable, transparent and sustainable energy. I therefore believe that the proposals presented in the document under discussion are an excellent starting point for building a productive energy market. I am therefore voting in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – Making our world a better place for next generations to come is something that concerns all of us. In this regard there is one issue which cannot stay unaddressed. The fact that we need to move away from energy creation from non-renewable resources is key considering a long-term perspective for both the wellbeing of humanity and our planet. I therefore support the European Commission’s communication on ‘New Deal for Energy Consumers’, which is part of the ‘Summer Energy Package’ launched in July 2015 aiming at bringing the Energy Union together. There is a need to move away from a centralized, inflexible energy system to one which is more decentralized, flexible and renewables-based and it is in our interest to be able to offer the citizens of the EU a new alternative.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ I welcome the Report on delivering new benefits for energy consumers. The Common European Energy Policy is an important component of the Croatian economy. In fact, the EU imports 53% of the energy needed annually and pays more than €1 billion a day for energy imports. In addition, energy infrastructure is outdated, national policies are out of line, and the market is uninterested.  In many Member States, regulated tariffs continue to limit the development of effective competition. It is precisely the objective of the Energy Union, an ambitious European project, to provide EU consumers with sustainable, competitive and affordable energy. Achieving this goal requires a fundamental transformation of the energy system in Europe.  That's why we need to move away from a fossil fuel economy that relies on outdated technologies and make smart use of the renewable energy and resources we have. In my view, consumers must have a choice between multiple energy suppliers and control over their energy costs, and that socially vulnerable consumer groups must be protected from energy poverty.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 More than fifty million European citizens live in a state of energy poverty. The EU, with its strategy for an Eu ropean Energy Union, must address this problem, promoting a transition to a sustainable model that puts people at the centre. Consumers, particularly the most vulnerable, should benefit most from this transition. All this can be done by making invoices more transparent, allowing consumers to know and control the actual use of energy, as well as by developing micro-production by the users themselves. Public funds must be invested in innovative projects for the construction of quality homes, with better energy efficiency, lowering energy costs and improving living conditions. Innovative companies developing technologies and materials with increasing energy efficiency should also be supported. Energy policy must take social aspects into account and contribute to the fight against poverty and social exclusion. Millions of citizens are being held hostage by outdated contracts, without adequate information about cheaper tariffs, forced to pay heavy penalties when they decide to switch to another supplier. That is unacceptable. The report calls for an end to this situation and I am therefore voting in favour of it.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament stressed that this report focuses solely on domestic energy consumers in the context of the energy transition, and stressed that the issue of industrial consumers should be considered in a separate framework.  He recalled that the ultimate goal should be an economy based entirely on renewable sources, which can only be achieved by reducing our energy consumption, fully respecting the principle that energy efficiency comes first, namely, primary fuel and prioritising energy savings and spending measures under supply-related measures to meet our climate objectives in line with the agreed 1.5° of the Paris Agreement , energy security, competitiveness and in particular lower costs for consumers. He pointed out that open, transparent and competitive well-regulated markets are important for keeping prices low, fostering innovation, improving consumer services and removing barriers to innovative new business models that can offer services to citizens for a good price, putting them in a better position and contributing to preventing energy poverty. I support this motion for a resolution and I think it is of utmost importance to establish and define the basic right to self-generation and self-consumption under the revised renewable energy directive.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 This report is part of a vision of privatisation and liberalisation of the energy sector. Vision that the report assumes, without contesting. It therefore ignores the whole process of dismantling and privatising companies that traditionally vertically and under a state monopoly, the production activities (in the case of electricity), transport, distribution and marketing of energy. The centralisation of national or regional energy systems and public and universal access to energy can be classified as a civilizational achievement of the European peoples. It was a situation that made it possible to optimise planning and operationalisation to meet the needs of consumers, including renewable energy. With many advantages, for example, because it would not lead to the multiplication of production and transport structures, avoided the enormous difficulties of managing the system that arise today, would ensure the correct and rational use of resources and the adoption of the best energy efficiency measures. It is technically and economically indefensible that the spraying of small production and the geographical distance of production from consumption contribute to the efficiency of energy systems, in particular in electricity. Electricity produced locally as a small business will never be able to compete economically with centralised production systems, so it will only be viable when subsidized by consumers or taxpayers.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Despite changes in europe's energy sector over the past decade, retail channels in the energy market have not implemented the necessary changes. Due to numerous barriers, consumers cannot fully benefit from the ongoing energy transition, manage their consumption efficiently and reduce bills. In its vision on a new electricity market model, the Commission aims to provide new benefits for energy consumers, including by better connecting wholesale and retail markets.  Using new technologies, new and innovative energy service companies should enable all energy consumers to participate fully in the energy transition, managing their own consumption through energy-efficient solutions that will save money and contribute to the overall reduction of energy consumption. I welcome three key points for achieving new benefits for consumers: strengthening the role of consumers, smart homes and networks, and managing and protecting data. I supported The Griffin Report, as well as the proposed steps needed to achieve the EU's objective, as delivering new benefits from the Union's energy strategy means putting consumers at the heart of a thriving and functioning energy system.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Currently 50 million European citizens live in energy poverty. This means that, in some cases, some people are not even able to have heating or use electricity in their affordable homes. For this reason, this resolution on the "new deal" for energy consumers supports collective purchasing systems, energy production among households, better pricing tools and the possibility for consumers to change supplier more easily and choose the cheapest tariffs. I am convinced that the targeted use of EU funds could promote efficiency and combat energy poverty. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report was prepared in response to the Commission Communication on the implementation of a new contract for energy consumers, which is based on three pillars: saving consumers money and energy through better information; increasing consumer choice; maintaining the highest level of consumer protection. The creation of an energy system that is fair to consumers and contributes to the protection of poor energy consumers should be encouraged. However, many of the amendments adopted in the draft report violate the principles of subsidiarity. For example, the idea of a broad and non-binding definition of energy poverty is good, but any attempt to create a central definition would be useless, as different nations define energy needs or the low-income threshold. It should also be noted that many of the provisions mentioned in the report already exist under the Third Energy Package. They therefore require better implementation and perhaps the establishment of new, necessary rules. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. In the context of the preparation of the energy union legislation to be presented by the European Commission, I have supported this text which calls for strengthening the power of consumers in the energy market in Europe. Bearing in mind the central objective of the fight against energy poverty, it will be important in the coming years to promote the collective purchase of energy, the emergence of new price comparison tools for consumers or the possibility of being able to change energy suppliers more easily and thus tariffs.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. In order to achieve the goals set out in the Paris Agreement, the New Deal for Energy Consumers presented by the Commission has made it possible for a renewable energy system based on renewable sources, more decentralised and flexible.  In this context, the report on the creation of a new framework for energy consumers underlines the importance of a retail energy system that provides consumers with sustainable energy and affordable costs. By the way, it will not be too much to list the recommendation for the creation of a one-stop shop and price comparison platforms. At the same time, the report advocates an inclusive energy system that respects the multiple intergenerational interests, enabling consumers to produce, drink, store and sell their own energy, with a view to becoming energy-efficient.  Finally, and what is more, the document stresses the essentiality of a properly regulated energy system, characterised by transparency and fair competition.  Thus, because I believe that only in an energy system adapted to today's social market economy will it be possible to lower energy prices, foster innovation and promote sustainable development, my vote is in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ We are against the report because we object new EU legislation in this field. We in UKIP believe that the UK should make its own energy policy and exploit and invest in lower-cost, reliable energy sources like coal, gas and nuclear.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. As part of the EU's energy transition objective, this report aims to strengthen the position of energy consumers in Europe. Specifically, it is about improving transparency, information and consumer protection against abusive, anti-competitive and unfair practices (clearer invoices and contracts, tools for comparing offers and prices, smart meters, etc.). In this, the report stresses the central place and role played by consumers (both households and industrialists), under the formulation of "consumers" or "consumers".  In the end, the benefits for citizens would be numerous: greater transparency in the choice of energy offers with increased competition between them, financial gains due to the optimization of their energy consumption, greater energy efficiency in general, and much more environmentally friendly consumption. Finally, the need for the Union to strengthen its policies to combat energy insecurity was reiterated, and finally to establish a common legal framework for energy self-production and self-consumption.  In line with these political lines, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution. Citizens and consumers remain at the heart of the energy transition and must be supported in this regard. The Commission and the Member States must fully implement the third package of energy measures while including our various proposals on domestic consumers. Among other things, we call for improved clarity in energy bills and transparency in invoices and contracts. Consumers also need to be better informed about the offers available. There needs to be a better comparison of the offers offered to consumers through independent, up-to-date and understandable price comparison tools. In addition, national legislation must guarantee consumers the right to switch suppliers quickly, easily and at no cost.  Finally, the fight against energy insecurity is also a major issue. Affordable access to energy must be seen as a fundamental social right on which a common definition of energy insecurity will be based. At the other end of the day, we stress the importance of well-adjusted social tariffs to protect low-income and vulnerable citizens.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The current energy transition should be a departure from an energy system based on traditional centralised production towards a more decentralised, energy-efficient, flexible and largely renewable energy-based system. The Energy Union should be centrally concerned with the interests of current and future generations of citizens, and should also: - provide citizens with a stable, cost-accessible, efficient, sustainable and quality energy supply; - enable citizens to produce, consume, store or sell their own energy from renewable sources, individually or collectively, to adopt energy saving measures and to become active participants in the energy market through consumer freedom of choice;  - contribute to eradicating the causes of energy poverty; - protect consumers from the abusive, anti-competitive and unfair practices of market participants so that they can fully exercise their rights; - create conditions that favour the smooth functioning and competitiveness of an internal energy market that offers consumers choice and allows them to access information in a clear and transparent manner.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Griffin Report on the establishment of a new agreement for energy consumers, prior to legislative initiatives based on the Energy Union strategy. I support the rapporteur's approach to the central core of the Energy Union, with measures to save on the energy bill.  The fight against energy poverty, which affects more than 50 million people in Europe, must be a vital objective and affordable energy must be a basic social right. No one should have to choose between eating or paying for heating/cooling.  I regret that the EPP voted against prioritizing energy poverty alleviation measures in future legislative proposals. The same will be removed from the final report proposed in favour of self-generation and self-consumption of energy. Citizens who produce their own energy should not be penalized with taxes or abusive charges as has been the case in my country with the sun tax. If we do not place citizens at the base of energy market efficiency, the climate targets agreed in Paris cannot be achieved.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. In its recommendations on the "new deal" for consumers in the energy market, the European Parliament defended a package of measures aimed at strengthening consumer market powers in energy production and energy tariffs. To help consumers play a more active role in the energy market, we have proposed introducing new business models such as collective purchasing systems and innovative financial instruments to stimulate increased use of self-production, self-consumption and energy-efficient tools. To ensure transparency in energy prices, we have asked for more simplified invoices in terms of understanding contracts, measures to help consumers compare offers, information on the most appropriate and advantageous tariffs based on their consumption history, etc. Finally, we called for a common definition of energy poverty, based on the idea that access to affordable energy is a fundamental social right and called on the Commission to prepare an action plan by 2017 to combat energy poverty.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Competition and freedom of choice are one of the fundamental values of the European Union. In recent years, we have witnessed how competition comes and into the energy sector previously owned by state or private monopolies. The Commission's recent proposals for greater consumer choice from energy service providers are a significant step towards real competition in the area of energy. At the same time, I would like to stress that the legal regulation of freedom of choice should also lead to at least two more positive spill-over effects, on the one hand, the need to calculate indicators such as the origin of energy will give rise to an additional impetus for the development of information technology. On the other hand, the choice should encourage more conscious consumers to choose green energy, which in turn should further accelerate the development of renewable and green energy.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Commission Communication on "A new framework for energy consumers" is to achieve the Energy Union, highlighting the role of citizens at the heart of the concerns and objectives of this large internal energy market, with the ultimate aim of reducing their energy bills.  The proposed new framework is based on three pillars: capacity building for consumers, homes and smart grids and, finally, good management and data protection. This report is based on this communication and argues that the EU should move away from a centralised energy production system to move towards a more decentralised, flexible and renewable energy-based system. This third energy package aims to provide a truly competitive and consumer-friendly energy consumption market. For this reason, I endorse the ideas contained in the report on the need for consumer support in the desired energy transition and for the production of energy itself, with a view to achieving a more efficient network. I therefore supported this report, which puts the interests of consumers at the heart of the system, following the line outlined in the new framework outlined in the Strategy for an Energy Union.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 The Griffin report outlines a number of good initiatives to facilitate the exchange of energy suppliers. Clarifying invoicing and facilitating comparison are key to creating a functioning electricity market covering the EU. Information is also important. According to studies, for example, the need for heating energy decreases by 5% when the temperature drops by one degree. Information of this kind is important for consumers. Now that information has been slightly less in Mr Griffin's otherwise good report, which I voted in favour of.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the new energy agreement for consumers. This report calls for consumers to exercise more power in the energy market. This includes introducing new business models, minimizing administrative barriers to self-production capacity, and establishing favourable and incentive conditions for collective self-production for Europeans living in buildings.  On the other hand, it is crucial that energy prices are more transparent. In this sense, energy bills need to be more frequent and readable; better price comparison tools need to be available to consumers. And finally, the ability to switch energy and tariffs more easily needs to be strengthened.   I supported this resolution because it calls for tackling the root causes of energy insecurity, and thus more effectively allocating EU funds on energy efficiency and self-production aid for consumers in energy insecurity.  The aim of this resolution is to inform the legislation on the Energy Union which will be presented shortly by the European Commission.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report stresses the need to move from a rigid and highly centralised energy system to a more decentralised, flexible, renewable-based energy system that will give consumers a new role, so that they can also become producers. Although there is no doubt that the consumer must be at the heart of European energy policy, companies must nevertheless be given the opportunity to operate in the market, to offer a good service and to be able to invest in innovation. I have also contributed to the presentation of some amendments to the original text in order to avoid a proliferation of data and information in the bill that would not promote transparency for the consumer but would only increase confusion and bureaucratic costs. Although the proposed amendments were not all included in the final compromise, I voted in favour of the report as a whole.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Griffin report because it represents a good opportunity to promote energy self-consumption (stable legal framework, rejection of retroactive measures, removal of administrative and financial barriers), while aiming to provide tools to combat energy poverty and recognize access to energy as a basic social right.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Energy poverty remains a serious problem which must be addressed by effective policies. It should be possible for people to compare prices and switch supplier without incurring penalties in order to take advantage of the internal energy market. EU policies and structural funds should be more focussed on dealing with energy poverty and supporting important cost-saving measures such as energy efficiency.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. At present, 50 million EU citizens live in energy poverty. Many citizens are kept on outdated energy contracts, which often require large termination fees if they switch to a cheaper provider. I believe that energy companies should provide consumers with information about the cheapest tariffs and drop expensive charges for switching suppliers. That is why I support the proposal.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report. The report strikes a balance between consumer protection and the end-user's design options in terms of energy choice and consumption and freedom to conduct a business.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it is a real step forward in setting up electricity markets at European level for the transition to a sustainable economy. It focuses on the role that consumers can play in the context of this energy transition and, while not referencing the fundamental role that the public sector must play or the importance of engaging the social partners, launches interesting proposals for the functioning of an energy sector that can fight energy poverty. While energy poverty cannot only be fought from the demand side, the measures contained in the report are a good compendium in undertaking the fight against this growing phenomenon.  Introduces key aspects of the energy debate such as: the participation of local and regional authorities in the design of energy markets; seeks to promote the transparency of information in the functioning of energy markets or calls for the definition of the term "prosumer" in the face of the new laws to implement energy union. For all this I have decided to vote on your behalf.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, 50 million European citizens live in energy poverty: they have outdated contracts, also known as "latent" contracts, which often require them to pay a major penalty when switching to another supplier. This resolution stresses the need to define favourable conditions for the creation of an efficient and competitive internal energy market, offering consumers the opportunity to choose which company is most convenient for them and to have clear and transparent access to information about their consumption and billing of their bills. Parliament suggests making it easier for consumers to switch energy suppliers and creating a more transparent, comparable and clear pricing. It is important that there is a properly regulated, open, transparent and competitive energy market in the EU.  That is why I have chosen to vote in favour.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I believe the UK should be responsible for its own energy policy.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Hundreds of thousands of people across the West Midlands are being kept on outdated energy contracts and are made to pay large termination fees when switching to a cheaper supplier. That’s why today, I voted in the European Parliament to end of termination fees so consumers can switch to a cheaper supplier without cost. I want to see straight-forward bills that contain consumer-empowering information. Also, I want to add that this report is an example of some of the great work by my friend and fellow Labour MEP, Theresa Griffin, proving how vital UK MEPs are to the EU.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 A new approach with an emphasis on energy consumers should provide citizens with stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy and high-quality energy-efficient products and services. The new approach should also enable citizens to produce, consume and store their own renewable energy and to trade it, individually or collectively, to take energy saving measures and to become active players in the energy market through consumer choice with demand response. Energy has an irreplaceable role in production, in services, but also in the day-to-day activities of every citizen, so that he can work and live with dignity. It is therefore important to create a system for energy consumers in order to protect them from abuse, unfair practices and practices that are contrary to competition from market players and to enable them to fully exercise their rights. We need to create the right conditions for consumers to ensure a well-functioning and competitive internal energy market, which will give them a choice and transparent and clear access to information.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The report on the new agreement for energy consumers focuses exclusively on household energy consumers in the context of the transformation of the energy system and stresses the need to treat industrial consumers separately. With the current transformation of the energy system, we are away from a system based on traditional centralised production towards a system that is more decentralised and flexible. The ultimate objective of implementing the report is thus an economy that is fully based on renewable energy sources, which can only be achieved by reducing our energy consumption, by following the principle that energy efficiency comes first, and by prioritising energy savings and demand-related measures to achieve climate goals in line with the paris agreement' objective, energy security competitiveness and, in particular, the reduction of costs for consumers. The transformation of the energy system must, in principle, result in a more efficient energy system that benefits society as a whole, increase the involvement of citizens and local and regional actors and communities and enable them to own or share in the production, distribution and storage of renewable energy, while protecting the most vulnerable and ensuring that they benefit from energy efficiency and renewable energy measures. The report also proposes the adoption of price comparison guidelines. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report "On Improved Opportunities for Energy Consumers" ("Griffin Report") does not have a legal binding effect as such, but can be understood as a political signal. The ALFA agrees with the core content of this report and supports a wide range of objectives set out in the report. All that should be mentioned here is fair access to energy and full access for consumers to all the information they need to meet their energy needs. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report. However, if the European Commission were to launch a draft law on this matter, I will have to weigh much more critically whether this is not an attempt to impose common definitions on the Member States and on joint action, which is ultimately dysfunctional. The Griffin report's call for energy poverty to be combated at supranational level may serve as a cautionary example. However, this cannot be achieved because no consensus can be reached at EU level on key concepts such as 'energy need' and 'low income'.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Reducing household energy consumption and respecting the principle that energy efficiency comes first, i.e. energy savings, requires identifying an economy that will be based entirely on renewable sources. I support this report because I think it is necessary to provide citizens with stable and affordable and efficient energy, as well as to enable citizens to produce, use and trade their own energy individually or collectively and take action to save energy.  Furthermore, I share the opinion of the European Parliament's committee that the new benefits for energy consumers will also reduce energy poverty, as well as the fact that this will protect consumers from unfair practices by market players, allowing them to fully exercise their rights. It is of utmost essence that citizens become active players in the energy market, the way they are enabled to participate reliably and safely in managing consumption.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This report focuses on household energy consumers in the context of the energy transition, while the issue of industrial consumers should be considered in a specific framework. With the energy transition, we are moving from an energy system based on traditional centralised production to a more flexible, decentralised and energy efficient system based on renewable energy sources.  The ultimate goal of this system is an economy based entirely on renewables. Such an economy can be achieved by reducing energy consumption, respecting the principle that energy efficiency comes first and prioritising energy savings. This will also contribute to eradicating energy poverty. Parliament believes that the central place of the Energy Union should be occupied by the interests of citizens as well as future generations. I support this report because I believe it is the first step to provide citizens with stable, cheaper, efficient and sustainable energy, and high-quality and energy efficient products and services. I also believe that this report creates a basis to enable citizens to produce, use and store their own energy individually or collectively and become active players in the energy market.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the new agreement for energy consumers. These are household energy consumers in the context of the transformation of the energy system, as consumers in the industry must be treated separately. The Commission needs to take due account of the costs of switching to a new market design in some Member States in terms of affordability and competitiveness. I agree with the report's argument that open, transparent and competitive well-regulated markets are important for maintaining low prices, promoting innovation, improving customer service and removing barriers to innovative business models that can offer citizens a good price-to-service ratio and contribute to the prevention of energy poverty.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report includes problematic references such as the position of decentralisation in energy management with the responsibility of shifting from the state to SMEs, consumers and local communities. The aim is for citizens to produce and market energy on their own by acting as investors in order to achieve a competitive energy system in a free competitive energy market.  It is also stressed that states must implement immediately the third energy package, for which we have expressed disagreement as it does not meet the needs of society. The proposals that are being developed also promote the privatisation of the good of energy, with negative consequences for the state and society.  But there are also positive reports. We are calling for the fight against energy poverty with a specific relationship plan and a focus on access to affordable energy as a basic social right. It should be noted that consumers must be protected from unfair market practices and it is proposed that States ensure a strong legal framework that puts an end to the charging of unpaid bills. It is also stressed that well-targeted social tariffs must be promoted as they are vital for vulnerable low-income citizens. That's why we abstained.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is proposed to vote against the report as the energy needs and energy adequacy of the Member States differ substantially from each other and therefore cannot be placed under the full control of the EU without significant losses, especially for "energy" wealthy states.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The "New Direction for Energy Consumers" report is an important stage in achieving the objectives of the Energy Union. Ensuring stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy is in the national interest. The development of consumer-friendly, competitive and well-functioning energy markets is key, and full implementation of the third energy package is essential to achieve these objectives. As the report emphasises, adequate consumer information is a prerequisite for energy-conscious behaviour. As a result, improving the transparency of invoices and ensuring comparability of service provider accounts is in our common interest – as this can lead to lower overhead costs. It is particularly practical for consumers to create up-to-date and easy-to-understand comparison tools and interfaces and to provide information on these options. After all, ensuring switching is an essential condition for competition. Although I do not fully agree with all the points in the report, the direction is good and should be supported.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which contains clear findings in the fight against energy poverty. I believe that all such cases should also be looked at from the consumer side, and this is well felt in the report. The level of energy poverty is currently considered relative as it is not fully measurable. I agree with the need to define additional indicators for consumer-friendly energy markets, bearing in mind consumer protection aspects. The report was clearly about creating a well-functioning energy market that benefits consumers, which showed that the objectives of the third energy package have not yet been achieved in all countries. As we know, consumer choice is limited, which also makes it difficult to feed in from renewable energy production. I agree with the call for the European Commission to analyse the issue of aggressive tax planning and fraud in energy markets and to take regulatory action on the transparency and clarity of bills and contracts. In my opinion, energy poverty could be eradicated: decentralisation, local production units, renewable energy sources. It is clear that member states have different capacities and therefore need common (and respected) principles and incentives. Of course, the trio of research, development and innovation play an essential role in all this! Such actions would help the population much more than the fake overheads propaganda on energy bills!

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today the European Parliament voted on its recommendations to the European Commission on how the consumer/citizen dimension should be included and dealt with in the energy sector legislation to come in the autumn. With this report, Parliament is substantially improving the EU Commission's already good communication and is succeeding in enhancing the role of citizens in the wider process of energy transition towards a decentralised model of energy production based on renewables. Great attention is paid to the phenomenon of energy poverty and its possible solutions. The report reflects most of the demands and, in particular, the M5S's call for an EU-wide legal definition of the prosumers (energy-producing consumers), which is still missing, has passed by a large majority. That is why we voted in favour of this report. While the amendment (signed by all five stars and a hundred other colleagues of various nationalities) calling for renewable energy produced by the Prosumers to be regarded as a common good, did not pass by only 47 votes out of 650. We almost hoped for it. But this result can also be regarded as surprising in a Parliament such as this, which is extremely conservative and blatantly aimed at maintaining the status quo.

name: Charles Tannock (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ As a Conservative MEP, I share the fundamental aims underlying the perspective new energy deal for EU citizens – that it should be fair on consumers, protect them from energy poverty and promote competition in the sector (as such, I support the provision of clear price information which enables EU consumers to shop around for cheaper energy prices). However, I found certain draft amendments in the ITRE report problematic, specifically with the prescribed definition of ‘energy poverty’. Conservatives believe that a loose and non-binding definition could be agreed. Yet any attempts to set a binding definition would be unhelpful, as it must be up to each member state to decide what ‘energy poverty’ looks like nationally, based on their own calculation of low income and the reasonable cost of energy. A number of further provisions called for in the report have an established basis in the Third Energy Package, and are therefore unnecessary – we must focus on implementing existing legislation more efficiently, rather than duplication. Likewise, I could not support proposals in the report that are tantamount to price regulation, or an EU-wide ban on doorstep selling. As such, I voted against the Griffin report.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Achieving the Energy Union is one of the objectives of the European Union for the period ahead. However, we must not forget that the main beneficiaries of this project must be European citizens. Currently, energy suppliers are high prices at national level because the common energy market has not yet been achieved and because they still benefit from the high concentration of national markets. This keeps European consumers captive from major energy monopolies, without the possibility of switching suppliers and benefiting from such more advantageous prices. The state of affairs leads to the idea of an 'energy poverty' at European level, which must be combated by firm measures by the European institutions. A Commission action plan is needed to combat this negative phenomenon throughout the Union and to encourage the energy efficiency of buildings. Furthermore, small producers of unconventional energy should not be discriminated against in relation to large producers in the Member States. The European Union must be a consumer shield from the abuses of major energy producers and suppliers. That is why I express my support for this necessary initiative.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I said yes to this text. The ultimate goal should be an economy based entirely on renewable energy, a goal that can only be achieved by reducing our energy consumption, making full use of the principle of "energy efficiency primacy" (the "first fuel") and giving priority to energy savings and measures acting on demand rather than supply. , in order to achieve our climate targets, in line with the scenario envisaged by the Paris Agreement (1.5oC), as well as energy security, competitiveness and, in particular, lower consumption bills.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ On 15 July 2015, the European Commission adopted a Communication ‘Delivering a New Deal for Energy Consumers’ as part of the ‘Summer Energy Package’. This communication places citizens in the centre of the Energy Union strategy and focuses on: helping consumers save money and energy through better information; giving consumers a wider choice of action when choosing their participation in energy markets; and maintaining the highest level of consumer protection. The ITRE Committee own-initiative report welcomes the New Deal and highlights the ongoing transition towards a more decentralised, energy-efficient and flexible energy system. The rapporteur, Theresa Griffin, aimed at number of actions with a view to empower citizens to produce their own renewable energy and become more energy-efficient. The report proposed number of interesting ideas, it however proposed to tackle an issue of energy poverty in very specific way. I voted in favour of the report, I however decided not to support rapporteur’s proposal to develop inclusive non-quantitative definition of energy poverty as a basic social right. I believe this is very sensitive social issue which should remain in competence of Member States.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ The report on delivering new benefits for energy consumers supports a plan to increase consumer purchasing power through price comparison tools and information on energy efficiency programmes. It also calls for EU funds to promote energy efficiency, self-use and other cost-cutting measures to reduce energy bills for citizens who have poor or poor access to energy.  I believe that concrete action should be taken by the Commission to promote responsible consumer behaviour and prevent energy poverty. I also believe that Member States should develop national action plans on the basis of public participation to promote small and medium-sized renewable energy projects and energy cooperatives, and I supported the report on the delivery of new benefits for energy consumers.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the new agreement for energy consumers because the current transformation of the energy system is shifting from a system based on traditional centralised production to a system that is more decentralised and flexible and mainly based on renewable energy. The ultimate objective of the economy should be fully based on renewable energy sources, which can only be achieved by reducing our energy consumption. The Energy Union should ensure stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy-efficient products, services and high-quality housing; enable citizens to produce, spend, store or trade their own renewable energy individually or collectively, take energy-saving measures, actively participate in the energy market because they have a choice as consumers; contribute to the eradication of energy poverty; to protect consumers from unfair, uncompetitive and unfair behaviour by market players and enable them to fully exercise their rights and to create appropriate conditions to ensure a well-functioning and competitive internal energy market that provides consumers with choice and transparent and clear access to information.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Social tariffs are a good tool in addressing the causes of energy poverty. Targeting social tariffs at the most vulnerable groups can prevent situations where families have to live without hot water, electricity and heating. Every year households in Estonia suffer in cold during winter because they are not able or were not able to pay heating costs. Social tariffs can prevent such hardship.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Griffin report because it represents a good opportunity to promote energy self-consumption (stable legal framework, rejection of retroactive measures, removal of administrative and financial barriers), while aiming to provide tools to combat energy poverty and recognize access to energy as a basic social right.

name: Evžen Tošenovský (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report as a whole because the resulting text was better balanced. In the roll-call vote, I rejected, for example, a problematic passage on the common definition of energy poverty.

name: Ulrike Trebesius (ECR)
text: Writing. The own-initiative report "On Improved Opportunities for Energy Consumers" ("Griffin Report") does not have a legal binding effect as such, but can be understood as a political signal. The ALFA agrees with the core content of this report and supports a wide range of objectives set out in the report. All that should be mentioned here is fair access to energy and full access for consumers to all the information they need to meet their energy needs. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the report. However, if the European Commission were to launch a draft law on this matter, I will have to weigh much more critically whether this is not an attempt to impose common definitions on the Member States and on joint action, which is ultimately expected to be dysfunctional. The Griffin report's call for energy poverty to be combated at supranational level may serve as a cautionary example. However, this cannot be achieved because no consensus can be reached at EU level on key concepts such as 'energy need' and 'low income'.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is part of the third package of energy measures, which aims in particular to separate energy producers and distributors in order to better liberalise the market: privatization, competition and price deregulation.  Despite some positive aspects of the text, the fundamental objective remains to break what remains of state monopolies. However, it is up to each Member State to define its energy policy and ensure the necessary investments for the development or maintenance of infrastructure... especially when we made the choice of nuclear power. Thus, good ideas are undermined by utopias that are dangerous to consumers, especially the big consumers of our industries, who will be the first to suffer from the end of long-term energy policy and regulated tariffs. Privatisation, competition and deregulation, which does not exclude a very restrictive bureaucratic over-regulation, of the energy sector are likely to lead individuals and businesses alike to pay for increasingly expensive energy, ensuring that multinational oligopolies have comfortable margins on the backs of the most insecure and at the expense of investments in the grid and production capacity. I therefore vote against this text.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Energy Union must provide citizens with stable, affordable, efficient and sustainable energy, as well as high-quality, energy-efficient products, services and buildings. I voted in favour of the related document.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of the Griffin report because it represents a good opportunity to promote energy self-consumption (stable legal framework, rejection of retroactive measures, removal of administrative and financial barriers), while aiming to provide tools to combat energy poverty and recognize access to energy as a basic social right.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ The New Deal for Energy Consumers outlines the way forward making it easier for consumers to compare offers, switch suppliers and find their way around a digitalised energy market while protecting the most vulnerable. It supports people who generate and consume their own renewable energy, as well as enhancing the role of local and regional authorities in the energy transition. If the EU institutions are serious about putting citizens at the core of the Energy Union, there is a need to empower citizens and create solid rights and opportunities for them to participate in the energy transition. The Griffin report is definitely providing clear statements in that sense.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Mr President, colleagues, the creation of a new trade mechanism for energy consumers means the development of a consumer-oriented energy market in which the problem of energy poverty must find an adequate solution.  A variety of mechanisms are available that should be activated. In the first place, common and specific criteria for energy poverty, which may vary, for example for different climatic areas, should be clearly defined. The following are policies to reduce household bills.  This includes mandatory reduction of energy consumption in buildings by improving energy efficiency, which is a generally recognised effective policy across the EU and which should be prioritised for energy poor citizens. This also includes an active role for consumers in optimising consumption, for which they need to be better informed about the energy consumption profile, the possibilities to consume in cheap energy hours, and to have a competitive supply of such services by retailers. Without fair energy prices in a well-functioning competitive market, there are no good solutions to energy poverty.  Vulnerable consumers must also be included in social policies to combat energy poverty through various forms of support for the poor, taking into account best existing practices.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the Commission's intention to provide for the inclusion of specific energy-related legislation in the Annex to the Regulation on consumer protection cooperation.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on delivering a new deal for energy consumers. The report calls for the implementation of market liberalisation measures to tackle persistent high levels of market concentration, improve low levels of consumer switching and for retail prices to better reflect falling wholesale costs. Our energy market is going through a fundamental transition and we have to ensure that consumers are at the heart of these changes. Only a competitive and liberalised internal market will allow consumers to fully enjoy the benefits of this shift. Therefore, a new deal for energy consumers focused on empowering consumers and helping them to participate more actively in the market is urgently needed.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this report, together with my delegation. Consumers will be at the centre of the energy network in the energy union. When the market can play freely, it is up to the consumer to make the best choice that suits him or her best. Market incentives will ensure that consumers can use energy more efficiently and that the right price is paid without market distortions.  However, a market also poses certain risks for consumers who do not have the capacity to take account of this amount of information or for certain consumers who are unable to pay the energy bill. The report identifies the right pain points and calls on the Member States and regions, with respect for subsidiarity, to take this group of consumers into account. This report remains relatively balanced and provides a good basis for legislative work in the context of the Energy Union.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report, which calls for recommendations in the retail energy market to bring energy prices down, enhance transparency, empower consumers, democratise the energy system and protect the most vulnerable. Energy should be considered a social right: currently, over 50 million are living in energy poverty in the EU – around 2.3 million in the UK. We need to take action at the EU level so that people do not have to choose between heating, eating and cooling and do not pay more for energy because they are unable to insulate their homes.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. I voted in favour of this resolution in order to give consumers more power when it comes to energy purchases. These include price comparison methods and better information on energy efficiency, more EU resources to promote energy efficiency, self-generation of energy and other measures that can reduce energy bills for vulnerable households and citizens. This is already possible in Belgium, but not everywhere in the EU. In an era of available cutting-edge technology for each of us, citizens must also be able to generate their own renewable energy and, above all, become more energy efficient. They must be able to become a 'micro' energy producer themselves, which can only benefit the free market: we understand this among 'prosuments'.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is part of the Energy Union, making references throughout the document to profoundly negative aspects, including the dubious concept of 'producers-consumers', through a participatory process conducted by the European Commission and always under the motto of the competitiveness of an internal energy market. Once again in line with neoliberal dogma, it considers that the phasing out of regulated energy tariffs for consumers should take into account the real level of competition in the market under the Energy Union strategy, which should ensure that consumers benefit from stable energy prices. It is therefore a set of bosses designed to justify the mechanisms for the accumulation of profits by large economic groups at the expense of consumers and the productive apparatus.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. In principle, measures to strengthen consumer rights and consumer power should be supported. However, if, as in this case, the motives I have just mentioned are misused in order to pursue an inefficient and inflexible 'one fits all' social policy at European level, then I will not have any support for this.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I rejected the European Parliament's report on improved opportunities for energy consumers. The report calls for an economy based solely on renewable energy. The report also calls for the EU's climate targets to meet the 1.5-degree target set by the Paris Agreement. The climate changes as long as the earth exists. Climate change policy is based on unsuitable computer models of the IPCC ("Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change"). Carbon dioxide (CO2) is not a pollutant, but an indispensable component of all life.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Consumers should have a greater right to vote in the energy market. I believe that an appropriate deal should be put in place so that energy consumers can benefit from fair offers. It is appropriate to introduce better comparative tools for energy suppliers' offers on the market and to provide for a transparent agreement on the change of producer to another. It is necessary to prevent citizens from being forced to give up their energy use because of lower incomes. Energy poverty is the result of incorrect regulations that do not take into account the financial situation of households. Comprehensive information on the proposed energy offers should be provided to all consumers so that they may not incur additional charges in the event of withdrawal. I believe that the introduction of innovative business models will facilitate the use of energy in an efficient way by its consumers.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: In writing. I am convinced that the causes of the energy poverty that still exists in Europe must be eliminated. One way to do this is to provide that the EU's energy efficiency funds and self-production subsidies primarily benefit energy-insecure consumers, who are often low-income families. I also believe that new business models, such as collective purchasing systems and innovative financial instruments, should be introduced and encouraged to help consumers in everyday life.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I am in favour of this report because I believe that we must ensure reliable and stable sources of energy for European consumers and for the economy of all Member States. For this reason, I think it is very important to create an energy system in which decentralization, flexibility and renewables are great. On the other hand, I think it is also very important that, when raising this issue, the problem of the lack of physical integration of some EU members is addressed. In the meantime, I think it is very important that these countries, with a lack of interconnection with the rest of the European Union, can continue to implement national measures.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support this report and, together with Parliament, believe that the Energy Union should focus primarily on the interests of EU citizens. Personally, however, I am concerned that, five years after the date of the introduction of the third energy package, its objective of ensuring a truly competitive and consumer-friendly retail market has still not been realised. I believe that a key objective of the review of the structure of the electricity market should be to ensure sufficient investment in electricity markets and affordable prices and to give consumers more choice. However, there should also be no lack of strict control over energy providers operating on the European market.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Electricity is a strategic good that should not be traded outside the control of regulators. However, we must be aware that the current model of electricity production and distribution must evolve constantly in order to meet the growing consumer demand. Greater efficiency and flexibility in energy production and consumption is essential for Europe to be able to produce the amounts of energy needed to maintain a steady level of household supply. Of course, when designing the European energy market, we must bear in mind the differences that exist in the Member States, particularly in the area of the energy mix.  We cannot adopt any solution that discriminates against countries such as Poland, for which coal is a basic energy resource. The consumer's freedom to choose an energy supplier must entail real price differences and the possibility of making an informed choice, for which it is necessary to be able to compare offers from all operators. In particular, we must take care of the needs of the lowest income earners, who spend a significant part of their resources on the purchase of basic goods, including electricity. More attention and resources should be allocated to supporting individual forms of energy production, which significantly reduce costs and improve resource efficiency. Since the report makes account of the above-mentioned proposals, I voted in favour of it.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of the Griffin report because I understand that it is essential to strike a balance between economic gains in competitiveness, environmental gains in sustainability and social gains in equity. We know that today more than 50 million EU citizens live in energy poverty, but we do not know the data in each Member State. Knowing this data is crucial in order to be able to verify the conformity and quality of the answers to this problem. In particular, I would like to point out proposals to eliminate aggressive business practices for the most vulnerable, establish social benchmark tariffs, use incentive systems to foster efficiency practices and reduce costs. I would also stress the call to improve the frequency, transparency and clarity of energy bills in order to make it easier for consumers to read them while avoiding technical terms. I also highlight the obligation for suppliers to specify, on the invoice or annex, the contribution of each energy source to the supplier's total energy mix in the previous year in an understandable and easily comparable manner, including a remission to a source where information on the environmental impacts of CO2 emissions and radioactive waste is available.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. This own-initiative report, to which I gave my favourable opinion, aims to show the Commission how to consider the needs of consumers/citizens in the energy legislation coming in the autumn. Currently, 50 million European citizens live in energy poverty. Many citizens are tied to outdated contracts that often require them to pay a hen of a hen when switching to a cheaper supplier. At M5S, we want energy companies to provide consumers with clear information about the cheapest tariffs and eliminate the penalties for changing suppliers. We believe that energy poverty - cases where people are unable to have heating or use electricity in their affordable homes - needs to be tackled at its root. We have asked the Commission to think about EU funds to promote energy efficiency, self-generation and other measures aimed at vulnerable citizens in energy poverty. Together with my colleagues, we have tabled amendments, supported by the Intergroup on Commons and Public Services, which recognise that energy in the energy transition is to be considered a common good. In 2016, in Europe, no one should choose between heating or food.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the new agreement for energy consumers, which advocates, inter alia, that consumers should be given more rights in the common European energy market. Currently, around 50 million people live in energy poverty in Europe. I agree that the eradication of energy poverty requires the creation of a well-functioning competitive market and the introduction of new business models that will offer consumers a good price-to-service relationship.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: – We are talking about female poverty and in this report in terms of equality between women and men. I repeat 'women and men'. So why does the document highlight the alleged specific needs of groups profiled on the basis of sexual orientation and different gender identities? And some aren't even named yet! Unacceptable differences in the evaluation of women's and men's work, the resulting pension gaps and the unfair undervaluation of women who have cared for children and other dependants for years need to be addressed in order to improve the position of women at risk of poverty. It is here that the informal work of women must also be adequately assessed. These are also the specific needs of disadvantaged groups, such as single mothers, pre-retirement women or women at risk of unemployment. We must seek effective solutions in the fight against female poverty. And I do not consider unfounded demands to take women's individual needs into account, depending on whether they are heterosexual, lesbian, intersex, transsexual, queer and so on. Colleagues, doesn't that seem really absurd to you? It is very sad that the own-initiative reports from the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, instead of addressing the real and burning problems of women that we see on a daily basis, are pushing us over and over again with the agenda of gender ideology. They are subverting our fight against alleged stereotypes and the recognition of the super-rights of various self-proclaimed groups. I cannot agree with this and could not support this report.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur Of europe's population, 64.6 million women and 57.6 million men live in poverty. This means that poor women are not only more absolute in numbers. They are much more, I would say, predisposed to poverty and social exclusion than men. This applies to virtually any social groups, any age, family structures, etc. In this respect, it would be worth mentioning the deplorable fact that it is much more difficult for women, for various reasons, to do so at the same time in their personal and professional life. And I agree with the call on the Commission to develop as soon as possible a comprehensive, global legislative initiative aimed directly at meeting the needs of mothers and fathers for different types of leave. Stereotypical or not, but the role of the dominant survivor must coexist with a full-fledged mentor role.

name: Lars Adaktusson (PPE)
text: Written. Today, the European Parliament voted on an own-initiative report by the Committee on Gender Equality on female poverty in Europe. Highlighting gender poverty is important, as women are over-represented among Europeans who still live in material poverty, although it is important to underline that progress has been made in the right direction. Unfortunately, the report in question proposes wrong and destructive solutions, both in substance and from a subsidiarity perspective. The report includes, for example, demands for minimum wages, demands for enforcement of the now withdrawn maternity leave directive, and calls for an increase in the EU budget to directly subsidise various phenomena that are considered to promote gender equality. In addition, the report is characterised by generalising and generalising criticism of the market economy. I therefore chose to vote 'no'.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The increase in the proportion of women in poverty or conditions is undoubtedly linked to the work and social inclusion difficulties they face on a daily basis. Not only is the employment rate of women lower than that of men, but also the rates of pay and, consequently, pensions, are very different. That is why, in line with the family leave strategy, the EU should put in place legislation to ensure equal opportunities, in the areas of employment, education and pay, regardless of gender. For these reasons, I voted in favour.

name: Louis Aliot (ENF)
text: In writing. I opposed this 'European Parliament's motion for a resolution on poverty: a gender perspective'.  Indeed, based on the observation that poverty affects women more (64.6 million) than men (57.6 million), the rapporteur proposes a definition of women in poverty in which different situations are mixed: elderly women, single women, single mothers, lesbians, bisexuals, transgender, disabled, migrants... This mixture of situations which have nothing to do with each other shows from the outset a great lack of rigour in the rapporteur's approach. Moreover, the solutions envisaged are very little concrete and are based on the fight against discrimination (especially in favour of migrant women) without proposing solutions against the effects of austerity policies, especially in highly feminized jobs, the development of single-parent families, poverty in rural areas, part-time work... The text here merely asks the States and the Union to finance projects, and thus to increase spending, to strengthen already tangled anti-discrimination legislation or to put men at home. I therefore believe that this text is not likely to improve the situation of women.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it contained some very progressive and positive provisions. My colleague Lynn Boylan proposed the introduction of paid domestic violence leave in Europe through an opinion she recently authored in the European Parliament’s Employment and Social Affairs Committee, and key aspects of this opinion were incorporated in this vote.
