The report included a provision where paid leave for survivors of domestic violence would become a right. This is a valuable new idea that has been introduced in Australia and the US, and this week’s vote is the first time the European Parliament has called for its introduction in Europe. I am very pleased that my party Sinn Féin has successfully placed this proposal firmly on the agenda of the European Parliament, and Sinn Féin will call on Irish policymakers to take this on board immediately and act to introduce this leave in Ireland.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the poverty report: a gender-based perspective, because women are the first victims of austerity policies and the economic crisis, and this cycle of poverty passes on to future generations, as well as to their children.  In addition, this report calls on the EU institutions to invest in social infrastructure, better regulation of the working and living environment, to ensure that women stay or can enter the labour market and thereby break the vicious cycle of poverty.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. The effects of austerity policies, particularly in highly feminized jobs (human services), the development of single-parent families, poverty in rural areas, part-time work are envisaged in the report, but the solutions envisaged are limited to asking States and the Union to finance projects, and thus to increase expenditure, to strengthen already tangled legislation against discrimination or to put men at home. For all these reasons, this report is not likely to improve the situation of women. I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ This report is patronising and degrading towards woman. The UK already had laws defending women’s rights and gender equality before it joined the ECC in 1973. It is not for the EU to criticise National Parliament’s budgets and it certainly shouldn’t be allowed to interfere in UK Education policy.

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 The economic crisis, the effects of which the Union is gradually recovering from, has, according to the statistical reports, dramatically increased the number of people facing the threat of poverty and social exclusion, both men and women. According to the latest statistical surveys on the unequal distribution of income in the EU, 16.6% of the EU population of 28 Member States is considered at risk of poverty, even if social benefits are taken into account. The risk rate was 17.2% for women and 16.1% for men. The shift in wages between women and men doing the same work and the pension gap are the result of a career fragmented in an attempt to harmoniously reconcile private life and employment. It is important that women are paid the same wages for equal work, and the practical adoption and application of this principle is of paramount importance. Unfortunately, the report includes elements in which 'steps are called for in the policy of ensuring equality of rights in order to ensure social equality' (which may raise constitutional problems) or calls on the Commission to draw up proposals for a gender-dimensional transformation of tax policy under national competence. Similarly absurd is the need to create an institution of joint pension rights for divorced or separated persons and to provide additional rights and subsidies for LGBTI families. For all these reasons, despite its positive elements, I voted in abst.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course believes more should be done to fight poverty and protect people against discrimination and violence. However this report went on to call for many things that were completely unacceptable. Strong criticism of EU austerity policies which has devastated countries such as Greece was removed from the report. The report called for a reversal in the burden of proof, which would rip up UK law on innocent until proven guilty. There was a call for further EU steps and assessment of minimum income schemes in Member States - the EU has no right to interfere in the UK’s minimum wage or other tax policies. The report called for interference in education policy at EU level. It also called for interference with national procedures on the recognition of refugee status. Finally The EU Parliament voted to remove text which called for a reduced rate on essential goods for women such as tampons. For all these reasons UKIP had no choice but to oppose this report. The only people that should decide such matters are our own elected national governments, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. Eurostat figures show that the number of women living in poverty is consistently higher than that of men, with currently around 64.6 million women and 57.6 million men. It is also clear, as my colleague Marie Arena's resolution reminds us, that austerity policies have only exacerbated this gap in recent years. In particular, the resolution stresses the priority of setting working conditions conducive to family life. Similarly, MEPs call on the Commission, in close coordination with the Member States, to take comprehensive and comprehensive legislative action to meet the needs of mothers and fathers regarding different types of leave. The resolution also stresses the major importance of public care and quality services, in particular to promote the integration of socially marginalized groups of women. With regard to the fight against women's poverty in particular, the resolution calls in particular for the development of the social pricing and assistance mechanisms of the poorest, to empower girls in social, economic, cultural and political life, or to actively promote a positive image of the mothers employed and to combat the phenomenon of "penalization of motherhood" identified by several studies.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The most recent data provided by Eurostat confirm the presence of an alarming phenomenon: within the EU there are 64.6 million women and 57.6 million men living in poverty. This serious situation of deprivation, which affects more than one hundred million European citizens, affects women on a permanently higher level. The Arena report, which I supported, addresses the problem of poverty by adopting a gender perspective and highlighting the crucial role of high-quality public services in combating this phenomenon. It is precisely the lack of high-quality and affordable care services, such as nurseries, nurseries and long-term care facilities, that some of the factors contributing to social exclusion, the employment, pay and gender pension gap can be identified. The Commission and the Member States must commit themselves to implementing broad-spectrum policies aimed at strengthening education and ensuring lifelong learning. Access to credit must be promoted and, above all, women's employment and the integration into the labour market of socially marginalised categories of women must be promoted, not only through better use of the ESF and EFSI.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because it addresses a very relevant issue, heightened by austerity policies implemented in recent years, such as poverty and gender perspective. The report mentions the causes of women's poverty, precariousness and social exclusion. Women remain more affected than men by the economic crisis and are more exposed to the possibility of social exclusion, with poverty rates being significantly higher in women's cases. The pay and pension gap, the glass ceiling, the lack of conciliation policies, as well as the absence of equal and non-transferable parental leave are some of the reasons for this inequality. This report contains several aspects that make our vote decisive in favour, such as the need to ensure public services, education and social security to combat poverty, the need to promote conciliation to avoid precarious and "atypical" contracts, the defence of women's economic independence by fighting for equality in wages and pensions, strengthening maternity and paternity leave and combating gender-based violence.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. I strongly rejected this text, which is a new insult to women, who are reduced to the status of eternal victims unable to get by on their own. The rapporteur cannot even provide a concrete framework for what is defined by women in poverty: single mothers, migrants, lesbians, it is a succession of minority categorisations that is actually very reductive for women. Moreover, the text avoids mentioning the real problems - and thus proposing concrete and viable solutions - regarding the harms of austerity policies or globalisation, which has led to the desertification of rural areas and thus to the precariousness of the inhabitants of these areas. Finally, I will always be surprised at the hypocrisy of some well-meaning feminists, who condemn the so-called patriarchal model that persists in our societies, but never question mass immigration, which often involves people with the most patriarchal culture. I am not sure that, as the report proposes, the solution to women's precariousness lies in the over-regulation of "anti-discrimination" norms or the application of gender theory.

name: Mara Bizzotto (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Arena report is unbalanced and has elements that I consider to be highly demagogic and ends in themselves. For these reasons, I did not intend to support you with my vote.

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. The problem of poverty and women's social exclusion has been the subject of special attention from Parliament for years. In 2015, despite the efforts made, little progress has been made and much progress remains to be made to successfully address the causes and consequences of the many facets of this precariousness.  According to the latest available statistics, poverty affects women more than men, and it is they who still predominantly continue to occupy the most precarious jobs, which in many cases do not allow their professional life to be reconciled with their working lives. I have supported this report because it places particular emphasis on improving conciliation and child education and access to affordable care services for dependent children and family members. In addition, the Commission is urged to take further steps to further promote women's empowerment and combat gender stereotypes.

name: Vilija Blinkevičiūtė (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, in which the European Parliament pays close attention to the problems of poverty and social exclusion of women. Many of Parliament's resolutions call for the causes and consequences of this deprivation to be tackled in various aspects. However, it should be noted that, despite efforts, little progress has been made on this issue in 2015. The economic crisis, which has led to a gradual recovery in the EU, has led to an increase in the number of people (men and women) at risk of poverty and social exclusion. On average, however, more women than men experience poverty, all the more so if they are single mothers, pensioners, immigrants or people with disabilities. A very large number of women work precariously, end their careers, work in so-called women's areas (health care, chores, etc.) and work part-time more because they are obliged to take care of their loved ones rather than because of their choice. The difference in pay compared to the salary paid to men and the different pensions (which are part of a career that has sought to harmonise their private lives and work harmoniously) put a heavy burden on women in financial difficulties and the daily uncertainty about their economic independence. This report explains the persistent inequalities faced by women. It underlines the efforts that the EU and the Member States must make to give everyone equal opportunities in the fields of employment, social protection, pay, education, childcare and culture, regardless of gender.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 In voting on the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on poverty: I was abstentionly, because it contained certain solutions that I cannot support for moral reasons. In addition, statistics show that the exposure to poverty for both men and women is much the same. Statistics on the distribution of income poverty and income inequality in the EU show that 17.2% of women and 16.1% of men were at risk of poverty in 2015. The data is a clear indication that both women and men are exposed to poverty in roughly the same proportion, so in my opinion the gender aspect is not crucial in reducing poverty. It is our responsibility to provide the conditions for increasing employment, which is crucial in reducing poverty. For the most vulnerable groups, however, we have a duty to ensure such social policies that will preserve the dignity of every individual, whatever their reasons for the situation in which they find themselves.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the impact of the economic crisis on European citizens, it should be seen that while 122 million people in Europe are at risk of poverty, of these 65 million are women, with a particularly worrying situation with regard to single mothers. The situation in the various Member States still differs considerably. The resolution I supported lists a number of areas in which a more homogeneous European standard should be arrived at. Starting from the guarantee of access to medical care, in order to increase investment in social infrastructure such as kindergartens, up to a fairer division of the family burden between men and women.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ I am extremely sorry that some right-wing MPs did not support the report. The report calls for the use of EU funds (EFSI) to create care facilities, to enable women to enter and stay on the labour market, legislative initiatives to improve work/life, balance for men and women (motherhood, fatherhood, parental leave, carer). An EU guarantee for free access to healthcare, education is required.

name: Marie-Christine Boutonnet (ENF)
text: In writing. This report foresees an improvement in the situation of women by combating discrimination, particularly in favour of migrant women and ethnic, religious and sexual minorities. Also, even as migration is encouraged, this report blames "patriarchy". The solutions envisaged are aimed at asking states and the EU to finance the projects. This requires an increase in spending and a strengthening of already abundant anti-discrimination legislation. Therefore, I vote against it.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that women are in a more difficult position than their male counterparts and that this makes them more vulnerable than the risk of falling below the poverty line. I therefore believe that it is essential for the EU to work to make the extension of social rights as wide as possible, also taking into account the specific needs of women.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the important attention paid by the European Parliament in recent years to the issue of poverty and social exclusion of women, we are still today, in 2016, faced with an intolerable situation characterized, overall, by a preponderance of women in situations of economic difficulty and social exclusion. Precisely because of the important role that women play within the family context, women are in fact often forced to work part-time and precarious jobs, and are also suffering, helplessly, the unbearable injustice of recurrent and shameful unjustified wage differences. This is often underestimated, but appropriate responses must be given in good time. In this respect, the current austerity policies are playing a key negative role, which, by encouraging the privatisation of public assistance, contribute to increasing the burden on women in relation to the care of their families.  In order to respond to this problem, in addition to promoting new public investment in the welfare sector, I believe that we should give priority to directing existing European funds, including, for example, the European Social Fund, towards improving the training of European women in economic difficulties, while encouraging the poverty protection measures reserved for them.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. This report takes the pretext of poverty among women to call for stronger anti-discrimination legislation and to promote gender theory. Yet the real causes of women's poverty and/or social and physical insecurity reside elsewhere. They are first of all the result of austerity policies that hit fairly feminized categories of jobs, such as those of human services, austerity policies that are directly imposed by the European Commission. But what reflects a complete mismatch of the content of the motion for a resolution with the reality of the condition of women is the denunciation of a so-called "patriarchy" structuring our contemporary societies, while behaviours of another age, often caused by migrants, are not mentioned in the text. For all these reasons, I voted against the report.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis that has gripped the EU has increased the number of citizens threatened by poverty and social exclusion. According to the latest statistics, around 16.6% of the 28-year-old EU population is considered to be at risk of poverty after social transfers, and for women the risk is higher than men, with a difference of more than one percent, figures that hide many differences between Member States. I welcome the fact that the issue of poverty and social exclusion for women is in Parliament's attention and numerous resolutions have been adopted calling for tackling the causes and consequences of the multiple facets of this precariousness. Although I support the need for continued measures towards equality between women and men, I am considering Christian values which, in my view, must take precedence in decision-making at this level, which is why I have spoken out against this resolution.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 Instrumental, demagogic report on an equal footing with other reports already voted on. I am voting against.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The fight against poverty is a predominant objective of the European Union in the Europe 2020 strategy. It is clear that there is a gender dimension to this phenomenon. Worldwide, more than 65 million women live in poverty, compared to 57 million men. This difference can be explained by the continuing inequalities between men and women, particularly in terms of work and the role within the family structure. Too often, women are discriminated against in relation to men in order to enter a profession. This is just one example of discrimination against women. The report explains that gender inequalities can lead to a greater propensity for poverty among women than among men, and that these inequalities need to be addressed. That is the main message of this report. I therefore voted in favour of this report, even though some parts of the text did not suit me.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the poverty report: a gender perspective because poverty increasingly has a female face and the economic crisis and austerity policies only accentuate this gender gap. The number of women living in poverty is found to be permanently higher than that of men. In the light of the objectives we have set ourselves, see the Europe 2020 strategy, it is necessary and no longer procrastinating for the Commission and the Member States to implement policies that promote the employment of women and the integration into the labour market of socially marginalised categories of women. It should be reiterateed that gender equality, especially in the labour market, contributes to increasing social and economic well-being, not only for women, but also for the economy and society as a whole.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which deplores the impact of austerity policies on women and underlines the crucial role of public services in combating poverty. It calls on the Commission to introduce a comprehensive leave system comprising maternity, paternity, parental and carers’ leave to meet the needs of parents and ensure that women can continue to work after having children. The report incorporates proposals put forward by my Sinn Féin colleague Lynn Boylan in her parliamentary opinion on this report. The most significant Sinn Féin proposal which was approved by MEPs was our call for the introduction of paid leave for people experiencing domestic violence. We know that one in five women experience domestic abuse. British statistics show 20% of working women had to take a month off work in the previous year due to domestic violence, and 2% of working women actually lost their jobs as a result of it. Paid leave would ensure their employment – and their economic independence – is protected when dealing with the impact of domestic violence, for example, by allowing people the time to manage medical appointments, court appearances and other duties that must be addressed in such situations.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course believes more should be done to fight poverty and protect people against discrimination and violence. However this report went on to call for many things that were completely unacceptable. Strong criticism of EU austerity policies which has devastated countries such as Greece was removed from the report. The report called for a reversal in the burden of proof, which would rip up UK law on innocent until proven guilty. There was a call for further EU steps and assessment of minimum income schemes in Member States - the EU has no right to interfere in the UK’s minimum wage or other tax policies. The report called for interference in education policy at EU level. It also called for interference with national procedures on the recognition of refugee status. Finally The EU Parliament voted to remove text which called for a reduced rate on essential goods for women such as tampons. For all these reasons UKIP had no choice but to oppose this report. The only people that should decide such matters are our own elected national governments, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because it outlines very good, concrete measures that could really help us reduce poverty among women. It is appalling that in the 21st century women still face stereotyping, often significantly lower earnings when compared to men as well as gender discrimination, all of which contribute to female poverty which is significantly higher than male poverty. I especially welcome the proposals related to reconciliation of private and professional life.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report which addresses the problem of poverty with particular reference to the social exclusion of women. It is in fact noted that women are the most affected by situations of economic hardship. Furthermore, the report refers to the large pay and pension gap between women and men in Europe, calling on the Member States and the European Union to make new efforts to ensure the same opportunities in terms of employment, social protection, pay, education, children and culture.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ The report addresses a highly important issue, but includes some provisions which I was not able to support such as the linking of EU austerity measures needed at a time of economic and financial crisis and the increasing rate of poverty in the EU, including among women. Personally, I would have welcomed a more balanced approach and that is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament's report on the poverty conditions of women in the countries of the European Union highlights a problem that unfortunately still persists in European societies where, despite more than fifty years of gender equality policies, the differences in employment and poverty still remain very high.  Although women are a fundamental force for the economic and social development of European countries, they are more at risk of poverty than men. The causes are manifold and relate above all to the persistence of gender prejudices deeply rooted in the cultural fabric of the countries of the Union. This contributes to relegating women to a leading role in society and, consequently, to the feminisation of poverty.   Therefore, The Member States must give impetus to the development of policies aimed at increasing women's employment, promoting reconciliation between work and motherhood and ensuring support for the care and education of children in disadvantaged backgrounds. And the political and financial instruments already available must be used more to promote family support services so as to encourage women to enter, and remain, into the labour market. That is why I voted in favour.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. The Social Democrats in Denmark have always fought against poverty and to create equal opportunities for all, regardless of their background. Poverty is best combated by ensuring economic prosperity and high-quality jobs, as well as by creating a social safety net that takes care of those who cannot work. The EU has a shared responsibility to boost growth in Europe. However, it is not eu competence to determine the specific layout of social or fiscal policy. It is up to each Member State to decide how the national welfare system should be designed and financed. We can only call on the Member States to take an active part in the fight against poverty and for equality.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We abstain, as the report contains positive elements, but it also contains points of friction.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The vote on the report on gender-based poverty of citizens is an attempt to identify and address the problems faced by citizens related to their gender. As eliminating discrimination, combined with maintaining a healthy balance in our society, is a central objective of our policy, I have decided to vote in favour.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The period of crisis that we are going through, and which we are trying very hard to overcome, is, in my opinion, a subject for which the European Parliament must give effective and concrete answers. I felt it was equally right, however, to abstain from voting on this report because it was, for some political groups, a pretext for dealing with subjects which, in fact, contaminated its content. In fact, I found it a pretext to want to deal together with sensitive topics such as the economic crisis and gender differences especially trying to shift the focus to transgender and ILGBT categories. It is neither the venue nor the right way for me to play politics. Every subject, especially if it is sensitive, has its own area of argument to allow anyone to be properly informed and to be able to express their political opinion in complete freedom. It is for these reasons that I have chosen to abstain, because I believe that such important and socially relevant matters must be treated in the right way, with full respect for those in the European Union who invest hope, energy and resources.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report identifies the persistent inequalities that women suffer. It highlights the efforts that need to be made by the EU and the Member States to give to all, without distinction of gender, equal opportunities in the field of employment, social security, pay, education, child care and culture. It recalls the means, particularly financial, already available to Europe and the Member States to stem the trend towards the impoverishment of half the population.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course believes more should be done to fight poverty and protect people against discrimination and violence. However this report went on to call for many things that were completely unacceptable. Strong criticism of EU austerity policies which has devastated countries such as Greece was removed from the report. The report called for a reversal in the burden of proof, which would rip up UK law on innocent until proven guilty. There was a call for further EU steps and assessment of minimum income schemes in Member States - the EU has no right to interfere in the UK’s minimum wage or other tax policies. The report called for interference in education policy at EU level. It also called for interference with national procedures on the recognition of refugee status. Finally The EU Parliament voted to remove text which called for a reduced rate on essential goods for women such as tampons. For all these reasons UKIP had no choice but to oppose this report. The only people that should decide such matters are our own elected national governments, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on this report because it contains many points that fall within the competence of the Member States. I am well aware that the structural poverty of women is a problem and that much remains to be done in this area. The figures show that we still have a long way to go to tackle the disadvantage of women, with 65 million women living in poverty in Europe, but only 57 million men. However, this complex problem must be tackled together with the Member States and not against the Member States.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course believes more should be done to fight poverty and protect people against discrimination and violence. However this report went on to call for many things that were completely unacceptable. Strong criticism of EU austerity policies which has devastated countries such as Greece was removed from the report. The report called for a reversal in the burden of proof, which would rip up UK law on innocent until proven guilty. There was a call for further EU steps and assessment of minimum income schemes in Member States - the EU has no right to interfere in the UK’s minimum wage or other tax policies. The report called for interference in education policy at EU level. It also called for interference with national procedures on the recognition of refugee status. Finally The EU Parliament voted to remove text which called for a reduced rate on essential goods for women such as tampons. For all these reasons UKIP had no choice but to oppose this report. The only people that should decide such matters are our own elected national governments, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis from which Europe is gradually emerging has led to an increase in the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Among the most vulnerable groups are women, for whom the European Union is working to promote their role as a potential for growth and competitiveness of the labour market. Education plays a key role in the development of skills and abilities necessary for entry and permanence in the labour market, while also helping to counter gender attitudes and stereotypes.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Considering that women account for half the population, the fight against female poverty is not only a matter of social justice for equal opportunities, but a wise investment to resolve the problem of child poverty and global poverty as well. Even perceiving this from an economic perspective, fighting against female poverty will help liberate the workforce from the constraints of family obligations and sustain the domestic demand needed for the EU economy to recover from crisis. So I would like to support this report to urge more effort on gender equality issues. I believe that specific measures need to be taken in all Member States to improve work-life balance for women. Therefore, I urge the Commission to incorporate a more robust social dimension and workplace gender equality objectives which render tangible results. Finally, I underline the importance of wiping out inequalities in the digital economy as regards equal pay and career development. I would like to stresses that increasing labour-market participation of women and related investments in social inclusion policies will help to reduce the gender pay gap. We need a digital market economy which would be sufficiently equipped to safeguard quality and security of jobs in times of digitalisation.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because, despite the right's attempts, we have managed to make a clear denunciation of the devastating - and even more virulent - effects on women of austerity policies imposed by the European Commission on the Member States.  These "austericide" policies are the clear cause of the increase in the feminization of poverty in the European Union, where more than 64.6 million women are currently mired in poverty. The text we have adopted recalls the right to access to education for the daughters and sons of migrants and refugees and urges the European Commission and the Member States to increase funds for the fight against unemployment, poverty and social exclusion.  I therefore share the diagnosis of this Resolution, as well as its call for the promotion of free and quality public services in the areas of health, education and social security. I have therefore voted in favour of the text since the conviction that real and effective policies are needed to achieve the still far-reaching real equality between men and women.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 That women are affected by poverty more than men is evident in all Member States, as is the greater impact of poverty on women's and children's lives. The economic recession has further aggravated the existing inequalities between women and single-parent families, most of which (56.6% in 2014) are women. In addition, women are excluded from the labour market or stop working to care for children and the elderly to a greater extent than men. I voted in favour of this resolution, because I believe that ensuring gender equality at all levels is the only trump card for breaking the cycle of poverty, and above all for the feminisation of the phenomenon of poverty. I am convinced that it is not simply a question of achieving the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, but above all of becoming aware that economic and social development cannot exclude women as an active and integral part of all societies. Protecting gender equality has a positive impact on economic growth and the harmonious development of future generations. A first step in this direction is to focus on the role of education in the fight against gender stereotypes.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In 2015, European Commission reports pointed to the exacerbation of gender inequality as a result of austerity policies, resulting both in wage disparities with a subsequent impact on pensions and survivors, and by a high level of unemployment, thereby causing the phenomenon of feminisation of poverty.  As there is a close link between poverty, the balance in private and work life and the labour market, this report draws attention to discrimination, the risk of marginalisation and social exclusion of various categories of women. In order to combat these phenomena, reduce segregation, abuse of office and domestic violence, I would like to stress the importance of affordable and high-quality public services in the areas of health, education, social security and justice. Thus, the EU and the Member States must promote respect for the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment, democratic values, tolerance, societal responsibility and the achievement of social dialogue in the fight against precarious working conditions. I voted in favour of this report because I believe that inequality and poverty require a holistic approach involving national, European and private structures. Thus, I affirm the importance of the introduction by the European Commission of a robust social dimension and the prospect of gender equality in the objectives of the European Semester.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The problem of women's poverty and social exclusion has been the subject of parliament's particular attention for several years. The proportion of women remains abnormally high in precarious workplaces, career fractures, in 'female-friendly' professions (healthcare, households, etc.) and among part-time workers, which is less due to free choice but rather to them taking care of their relatives. The report identifies the instruments, including financial instruments, that Europe and the Member States already have to overcome trends threatening to impoverish half the population. The fight against women's poverty is also the way to a long-term solution to the problem of child poverty and, consequently, to eradicating poverty worldwide. It calls on the Member States and the Commission to take steps to combat all forms of gender-based multiple discrimination, to ensure the application of the principles of non-discrimination and equality in the labour market and access to employment, and to call on the Commission and the Member States to introduce policies aimed at promoting women's employment and integrating marginalised groups of women into the labour market in the light of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. Although the report contains a number of positive elements, it goes beyond its powers in several cases, so I abstained from voting on the report.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The problem of poverty and social marginalisation of women has been the subject of particular attention for many years. The issue of combating the causes and consequences of various aspects of women's precarious situation has been repeatedly raised in numerous resolutions. According to the latest statistics, 16.6% of citizens from the 28 EU Member States are at risk of poverty as a result of social transfers. The risk of poverty for women is 17.2%, in men it is 16.1%. One of the main reasons is the persistent gap in wages and pensions. The report contains many ideas that I fully support, such as closing the gender pay gap, adopting measures to promote work-life balance, introducing flexible working hours, etc. However, it raises a number of issues that I cannot agree with, namely: the Commission's call for work on the proposal on the minimum wage, the individual examination of household incomes in order to define social rights (on the assumption that women are always at a disadvantage), a new EU legislation on combating gender-based violence, the fight against stereotypes through educational programmes, etc. In view of the above, I was forced to abstain.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Women are victims of poverty, Eurostat data shows that the number of women remains permanently higher than that of men when it comes to poverty. It is unacceptable that females and children are victims of austerity policies which recently, due to the economic crisis, have widened inequalities. I voted in favour of this report as I support the recommendations outlined by the rapporteur in order to fight poverty amongst women. We need to allocate more funds and invest more in social infrastructures which eventually leads to more females accessing the labour market. Economic independence does not only address female poverty but also other aspects such as domestic violence. Further attention needs to be given also to the gender pay gap.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. This initiative report focuses on the root causes of women's poverty in the European Union. According to the rapporteur, women's poverty is caused by stereotypes in the professional world against women, by the gender pay gap and by the imbalance between private and professional life. Recognising the importance of the principle of fairness between men and women, however, I abstained on this report, together with my colleagues in the EPP Group, considering that a number of references on tax policies or minimum income were contrary to the principle of subsidiarity of the Member States.

name: Jean-Paul Denanot (S&D)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which stresses, beyond the fundamental struggle for gender equality, two important battles that I am waging within the "common good/public services" intergroup: - that for taking into account the difficulties and isolation in which many women find themselves in rural areas; - the one that goes through the defence and promotion of public services, a powerful vehicle for reducing inequalities between men and women. The economic crisis and austerity policies have exacerbated inequality and particularly affected women, exacerbating situations of poverty and exclusion from the labour market. In addition to the fact that there is a high probability of transmission of poverty over several generations, this report highlights the importance of education and social security systems and childcare (children and the elderly) to stem the relegation of women to the territory, in the specialization of tasks and in the world of work. It draws the Commission's attention to the urgent need to establish a definition of energy poverty that takes into account aspects of the phenomenon related to gender equality.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. This text is confusing and confusing between elderly women, single women, single mothers, lesbians, bisexuals, transgender women, disabled, migrants or women from ethnic minorities. Worse, the report does not propose concrete solutions to the negative effects of austerity policies on highly feminized service jobs, the development of single-parent families, poverty in rural areas or part-time work. The only solutions proposed are to incur incur non-coherent spending, to strengthen anti-discrimination legislation or to encourage parental leave for men. The report denounces the "patriarchy" without understanding that immigration, which Europe encourages, brings in itself a very strong patriarchal culture. For these reasons, I have not supported this report, as it is not likely to improve the situation of women.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I abstained from the report on poverty through the prism of gender equality, because although I agree with many of the proposals in the report, many of them are contradictory and involve supranational decision-making in areas of exclusive competence for individual Member States. The problem of women's poverty and their social exclusion has been widely discussed, and various resolutions have called before to address the causes and consequences of aspects of this social insecurity. In general, women are more at risk of poverty, which is why I fully support some of the report's proposals, such as closing the gender pay gap, measures to promote work and private life, flexible working hours (on a voluntary basis), the role of education in improving women's situation, and support for female entrepreneurship. On the other hand, me and my political group cannot agree on some of the elements of this motion for a resolution, such as the call to the European Commission for the establishment of a minimum wage, which is an exclusive right of individual Member States and must not be decided at supranational level.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as it promotes the promotion and support of transgender/homosexual people.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. This report deals with poor women in the EU. The subject is very important, and I have voted several times in favour of reports and legislative proposals aimed at strengthening the situation of vulnerable women. However, there were a few things i found very problematic in this report, and which were also voted through in plenary. This meant that, overall, I was not in a position to vote in favour of the report. This mainly concerned letters rejecting the EU's austerity policy and calling on the Commission to reopen the Maternity Leave Directive and legislate on European parental leave. Firstly, I do not agree and the second, I do not mean, are certainly issues to pursue at European level. I am in favour of a very generous parental leave and have pushed these issues hard in Sweden, but it is to open up a development I do not want to see to start legislating on these kinds of issues at EU level.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: the solutions envisaged are limited to asking states and the Union to finance projects, and thus to increase spending, to strengthen already tangled anti-discrimination legislation or to put men at home.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The issue of poverty and social exclusion of women is a reality that is linked to the gender pay gap, low wages and, consequently, low retirement pensions, precarious work. All in recent years, the policies imposed by the EU/ECB/IMF and implemented by the governments of EU countries. This report highlights the persistent inequalities affecting women. It points to the efforts to be made to provide everyone, without distinction of gender, including migrants, with equal opportunities in the fields of employment, social security, remuneration, education and childcare.  Underlines: the crucial role of high-quality public services and calls on Member States to implement policies that defend, value and encourage public, free and quality services; the importance of promoting reconciliation between personal and professional life; calls on the European Commission, in close liaison with the Member States, to present an initiative under maternity leave, paternity leave and parental leave. Without prejudice to some aspects from which we distance ourselves (reference to teleworking arrangements, among others), the report is overall positive, which is why we voted in favour.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 After years of austerity as an ineffective recipe for combating the economic crisis, we finally need to focus much more on the needs of the most vulnerable. In terms of the threat of poverty, such a group are demonstrably women. At the same time, combating their poverty is a question of social justice. At the same time, effective measures to improve the living standards of maternal women reduce child poverty-related threats. The persistent problem is the indefensiblely high pay gap compared to men, which on average are close to almost 20%. This, in turn, translates even more significantly into different levels of pensions. Women also have more than a third less. This is indeed a vicious circle that must finally be cut. In doing so, measures must be positively targeted towards women. At both European and national level, we must go down the path of fixed priorities with clear, enforceable penalties in the event of non-compliance. Otherwise, injustices about women's pay will persist for decades to come.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report because, despite some important and acceptable points, too much attention is paid to LGBT groups and calls for immigrant women to have free access to many services.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe it is about time we put a stop to female poverty. Women are the first victims of the austerity policies and the economic crisis, passing on the poverty cycle to the next generations and their children. I support the call for use of an EU instrument to invest in social infrastructures (namely childcare and care for dependents) and better work/life arrangements, and to ensure women stay in or join the labour market and break the vicious circle of poverty. It is fundamental to allow for a better reconciliation of private and professional life. Therefore, Member States should introduce family-friendly working arrangements. Access to high-quality early childhood education and affordable care is important to encourage women to enter and stay in the labour market and to make women more economically independent. Finally I support the call on the Commission to take action to increase women’s participation in the labour market, to promote the employment of women and the integration of marginalised women into the labour market.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. The economic crisis and austerity policies have led to an increase in the number of people exposed to poverty and social exclusion, affecting more women (64.6 million) than men (57.6 million). Women remain overrepresented in precarious work, are forced into career interruptions to care for their children and other dependents, in the absence of effective rules of work-life reconciliation, occupying worse-renumbered positions, often as a result of sexist stereotypes, and co-employment part-time , not by free choice, but rather forced by the need to have to care for their relatives. In addition, there is a wage gap that remains and is very difficult to eradicate. All this means that women receive lower pay than men, which also translate into lower pensions. I voted in favour of this report because it calls for urgent action to improve conciliation, combat stereotypes, reduce the pay gap and facilitate the integration and permanence of women in the labour market.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I would like to offer my support to the excellent work of my colleague Maria Arena, who in her report "on women's poverty: a gender perspective" which has so clearly highlighted the many fragilities and too many obstacles that women still encounter in their professional and social path, was an opportunity for me to reiterate my full support for the EU's commitment to new strategies that help women to gain equity , awards and possibilities both at the work level, and of participation and social inclusion. Eurostat figures show alarming numbers for people living in poverty: 64.6 million women and 57.6 million men. The hope is that with the constant pressure that we intend to continue to do with our work in the European Parliament, the Union will reconfirm itself as guarantor of the rights of the individual and of women and, with a broader look, also of the rights of children and the family. Growth and our future.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted with conviction in favour of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on poverty and its gender perspective, as I believe that women are most vulnerable and in need of support and attention from institutions at all levels. There is no doubt that in such an historic period, when the European economy is still struggling to recover, economic difficulties affect people at risk of poverty in particular and that women in particular are more exposed to the consequences, especially if they are single mothers, pensioners, immigrants or disabled people. The analysis of numerous studies on the relationship between gender and poverty has shown that austerity policies have a dramatic impact on the social and economic life of women, with strong repercussions on their children and subsequent generations. I share the rapporteur's concern about the persistent inequalities faced by women and I support the need for a greater commitment by the European Union and the Member States to invest in social infrastructure, guaranteeing everyone the same opportunities and conditions of access in terms of employment, social protection, education and pay.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. Poverty and social exclusion are issues to be tackled. However, I think it is wrong to take this important issue from a gender perspective. In addition, this report conceals measures to regulate labour market policy, which, however, falls within the competence of the Member States on the basis of the principle of subsidiarity. I cannot therefore support circumventing this basic rule from the EU Treaties.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As figures from Eurostat show, there are 7 million more women than men living in poverty in the EU. Sadly, what tends to happen is that poverty is cyclical, being ‘passed on’ to the next generations. I voted in favour of this report, and with colleagues in my Socialist group call for the use of EU funds to invest in social infrastructure such as childcare and better work/life arrangements, and to ensure that women can join or stay in the job market.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF)
text: In writing. Women in poverty outnumerd men in Europe: 64.6 million compared to 57.6 million. Based on this observation, this resolution looks at the fight against poverty from a gender perspective. However, it mixes very different situations: single older women, single mothers, lesbians, bisexuals, transgenders, disabled, migrants or from ethnic minorities.  This confusion does not really address the problems. For example, with regard to the effects of austerity policies on women, the resolution does not propose concrete solutions. The same goes for the development of single parenthood, poverty in rural areas or part-time work.  The only solutions envisaged are symbolic: proposing to incur expenditure in all directions or strengthening anti-discrimination legislation, while existing ones are not necessarily applied or even relevant. In fact, the fight against discrimination, particularly in favour of migrant women and ethnic, religious and sexual minorities, seems to be the only real aim of this resolution. This is why it is not likely to improve the material situation of women.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because it addresses a very relevant issue, heightened by austerity policies implemented in recent years, such as poverty and gender perspective. The report mentions the causes of women's poverty, precariousness and social exclusion. Women remain more affected than men by the economic crisis and are more exposed to the possibility of social exclusion, with poverty rates being significantly higher in women's cases. The pay and pension gap, the glass ceiling, the lack of conciliation policies, as well as the absence of equal and non-transferable parental leave are some of the reasons for this inequality. This report contains several aspects that make our vote decisive in favour, such as the need to ensure public services, education and social security to combat poverty, the need to promote conciliation to avoid precarious and "atypical" contracts, the defence of women's economic independence by fighting for equality in wages and pensions, strengthening maternity and paternity leave and combating gender-based violence.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Poverty in the EU affects 65 million women, compared to 57 million men. I voted in favour of this report as it is clear that women need more targeted support in the fight to end poverty.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. In Europe there are now more than 65 million women living in poverty compared to 57 million men. Poverty causes women’s social exclusion, in terms of access to public transport, healthcare, housing or culture and has a negative impact on their children. More efforts need to be made by the Member States to ensure equal opportunities in employment, social security, pay, education and childcare.

name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report because the report contains important elements. The report rightly points out that the economic crisis has affected women the most, particularly when it comes to pensioners, immigrants or people with disabilities. It is also noted that women still hold the most precarious and part-time jobs. This report also lists the continuing inequalities affecting women and encourages the Member States and the Commission to make efforts to provide everyone with the same opportunities and opportunities in the fields of work, social security, pay, education, and childcare and to stop the poverty of people.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that addresses persistent inequality issues such as the gender pay gap (16.3% in EU), the pension gap (39%) a lower employment rate of women vs men and the social exclusion of women. With more than 65 million women living in poverty compared to 57 million men, this report highlights the efforts that need to be made by the EU and the Member States to advance equal opportunities in the field of employment, social security, pay, education, childcare and culture. In particular I agree with its focus on targeted investments that would help to break the vicious cycle of poverty. Whether public or private, I fully support the need for investment with a view to better reconcile private and professional live, improving child elderly and disabled people’s care facilities, free public education and increasing women’s participation in the labour market.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this vote.

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel (ECR)
text: Writing. According to EU statistics, more than 120 million people in the EU are currently affected by poverty – more than 65 million of them are women. Accordingly, we share the basic position of the report that the fight against poverty must be a priority in all Member States, as the Europe 2020 strategy calls for. However, it is wrong to derive from this a European competence, as the report does. As little as we all want poverty, the EU is not responsible for it. The report therefore goes far beyond the target in many of its demands and clearly exceeds the competences of the EU. Although I warmly welcome the fight against poverty in Europe, I have therefore abstained from the final vote.  Incidentally, I believe that the single euro must be abolished. It leads to strife and discord in Europe.

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ This report highlights a number of important issues. In my own country, the Scottish Government has highlighted the pay gap between the genders and is committed to eliminating it. The government won last month’s general election with a pledge to increase childcare provision and this policy will further help to eradicate poverty in the country.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I support the report on poverty through the prism of gender equality. According to the latest Eurostat data, the number of women in a state of poverty remains consistently higher than that of men, with around 64 million women currently in poverty, compared to 57 million men. I believe that gender equality achieved in the labour market by increasing social and economic well-being benefits not only women, but also the economy and society as a whole. The austerity policies demanded by the Commission and implemented by the Member States, in addition to the economic crisis of the last few years, have increased inequalities and affected women in particular, exacerbating the problem of female poverty and leading to their increasing exclusion from the labour market, leading to social exclusion and a lack of participation in public life in terms of access to education , culture and information, justice and primary health services. I believe that gender equality provides a tool to combat female poverty, as it has a positive impact on productivity and economic growth and leads to greater participation of women in the labour market.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The economic crisis within the EU has, among other things, produced large gaps in the number of men and women at risk of poverty and social exclusion. I voted in favour of this report in support of joint efforts by all EU Member States on gender discrimination, opportunities and equal opportunities in areas such as employment, social security, wages, education, caring for dependent children, culture and combating poverty.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for a proposal for a European Parliament resolution on poverty: a gender perspective, with more than 65 million women living in poverty in Europe compared to 57 million men. Poverty promotes exclusion, lack of health care, major problems on the housing issue and negatively affects children of poor people. Therefore, it is necessary for Member States to take concrete and more serious measures to equalise opportunities between men and women in the fields of employment, social welfare, education and wages.  In this context, it is necessary to ensure the economic independence of women and allow them to advance professionally in all segments. It is important to stress that women's poverty is not only caused by the latest financial crisis, but is about various factors, such as stereotypes, gender pay gaps, discrimination, and others. Therefore, I support this report.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. The effects of austerity policies, particularly in highly feminized jobs (human services), the development of single-parent families, poverty in rural areas, part-time work are envisaged in the report, but the solutions envisaged are limited to asking States and the Union to finance projects, and thus to increase expenditure, to strengthen already tangled legislation against discrimination or to put men at home. All this justified my vote against this text.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Although I believe that the issue of gender poverty is undoubtedly an important issue and discrimination in the labour market and pay is a problem that should have been resolved long ago in today's European society, I think it is necessary to think about the principle of subsidiarity on this issue. I think that this issue should remain the responsibility of the EU Member States, which is why I could not vote in favour of the proposal put forward.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I abstained on this report, which deals with women's poverty in the Union, because this subject, to which I am particularly sensitive, falls within the strict competence of the Member States.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Maria Arena's report on the gender dimension on poverty. For many years , Parliament has been paying increased attention to the issue of poverty and the social exclusion of women.  Unfortunately, on the labour market women are affected on average more than men, much more so when it comes to single mothers, pensioners, immigrant women or when it comes to women with disabilities, while the pay and pension gap compared to men remains an important issue in many EU countries.  I agree with the report's approach because the fight against women's poverty is a matter of social justice.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. The report seeks to harmonise laws in the context of gender mainstreaming from different areas. I am voting against this report because I do not believe that harmonisation of these laws falls within the competence of the EU. It would be better to act here at national level, adapted to the specific situations in the respective Member States.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Poverty is a problem that needs to be addressed by improving the socio-economic situation in the Member States and in the European Union as a whole. However, in the vote on this particular report, I abstained because I believe that the report included requirements limiting the right of Member States to decide these important issues themselves. Every Member State of the European Union is facing the problem of poverty, but the situation in each Member State is specific, and I believe that this problem cannot be solved by a set of 'one size fits all'. This requirement contradicts my views and is too specific a matter to, in my opinion, be addressed in the same way throughout the European Union. I believe that each Member State should have the right to retain national competence to solve this problem.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Poverty hits women more than men: today, in the EU some 65 million women are concerned compared to 57 million men. I voted in favour of the report as it points out the causes that bring women into poverty and gives recommendations to the Commission and the Member States on how to tackle the effects of female poverty.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. The Social Democrats in Denmark have always fought against poverty and to create equal opportunities for all, regardless of their background. Poverty is best combated by ensuring economic prosperity and high-quality jobs, as well as by creating a social safety net that takes care of those who cannot work. The EU has a shared responsibility to boost growth in Europe. However, it is not eu competence to determine the specific layout of social or fiscal policy. It is up to each Member State to decide how the national welfare system should be designed and financed. We can only call on the Member States to take an active part in the fight against poverty and for equality. That is why I have abstained from voting on the overall report, which sets out a number of EU actions which, in my opinion, violate the limit of what is and should be the competence of the EUROPEAN Union and the Member States respectively.

name: Bernd Kölmel (ECR)
text: Writing. According to EU statistics, more than 120 million people in the EU are currently affected by poverty – more than 65 million of them are women. Accordingly, we share the basic position of the report that the fight against poverty must be a priority in all Member States, as the Europe 2020 strategy calls for. However, it is wrong to derive from this a European competence, as the report does. As little as we all want poverty, the EU is not responsible for it. The report therefore goes far beyond the target in many of its demands and clearly exceeds the competences of the EU. Although I warmly welcome the fight against poverty in Europe, I have therefore abstained from the final vote.

name: Agnieszka Kozłowska-Rajewicz (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 I abstained from voting on Maria Arena's S&D report on poverty seen from the perspective of gender equality, because it contains many articles that violate the principle of subsidiarity and the interests of Polish. These include proposals for a uniform DEFINITION of work of equal value in the EU and universal implementation of the minimum wage and pension; proposals for 'gender-fair' tax-making, a call not to apply spending cuts in public administration and not to develop flexible forms of work. I consider the latter in particular to be detrimental to women and to the overall good functioning of the labour market, with a particular focus on SMEs, including family businesses. That is why I voted against these proposals.  At the same time, I supported the article expressing satisfaction with the idea of leave for carers, which is present in the Commission's proposal on a policy of reconciling domestic and professional responsibilities. This proposal is due to the fact that caring responsibilities apply not only to parents of minor children, but also to adult children to aging parents, grandparents and other relatives. This perspective of thinking about barriers to women's inclusion in the labour market is more relevant to the reality that caring responsibilities apply not only to children, but also to senior family members. It is more appropriate to seek a more universal response to the work-home conflict caused by caring responsibilities than to impose inflexible solutions on Member States of the maternity directive withdrawn by the EC.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 There are almost 65 million women living in poverty in Europe, a number that is unfortunately increasing and far exceeds that of men living in the same condition.  With this resolution, we want to put this issue back at the heart of our political agenda, making a strong appeal to the Commission and the Member States to pursue strategies to eradicate gender poverty. But the fight against poverty must go hand in hand with the fight against social exclusion, of which women are increasingly the victims, especially if they are mothers, suns, pensioners, immigrants or disabled people. For these socially marginalised categories of women, we call for urgent measures in the field of education and lifelong learning, enabling women to acquire the skills necessary to access high-quality jobs, but also to retrain in an evolving labour market.  We call on the Member States to do more to reconcile women's private and professional lives by introducing flexible and adaptable working methods. It is unacceptable that jobs occupied by women should still be characterised by precariousness, low pay and atypical employment contracts.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because the number of women in poverty remains permanently higher than that of men. Unfortunately, the feminisation of poverty is a complex issue related above all to gender discrimination, gender stereotypes and the ever-changing nature of the labour market. Because of discrimination and stereotypes women often are employed in precarious and low-paid work and non-standard employment (outside the scope of national labour law). Often women’s wages are less than men’s, unequal pay for equal work. At work women are usually victims of labour exploitation and even sexual harassment. It is our moral duty to change this negative trend by empowering women in social, economic, cultural, scientific and political fields. Expressed in other words, women’s inclusion in sectors where they have been under-represented is the key to end the feminisation of poverty not only in Europe but in the whole world.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. One of the various fundamental principles of our Union is to promote equal rights for men and women. In this regard, the European Parliament proposes a series of resolution measures to combat poverty, of particular gender. The report focuses on the causes of this poverty and underlines the efforts that Member States must make to ensure that women receive the same opportunities for work, education, social, and pay, without distinction. This is a very sensitive subject for us and that is why a number of amendments have been discussed aimed at improving the text, given the importance of the issue of poverty, which is addressed from a gender perspective.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. We are faced with a sad reality: women are more prone and vulnerable to poverty than men. The Arena report on poverty: a gender perspective rightly highlights the difference in income between men and women while pointing to some discrimination in the labour market. It also stresses the situation of women in rural areas, which have an extremely high unemployment rate. It therefore calls on Member States to contribute to improving their quality of life. However, the report in its entirety cannot be supported in many respects. That is why I abstained on the final vote. Indeed, beyond its scope, it too often interferes with the competences specific to the Member States and therefore does not respect the principle of subsidiarity, in particular on parental leave, the European guarantee for children or the minimum pension.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the highly ideological report "Poverty: A Gender Perspective." Women in poverty outnumered men: 64.6 million women, compared to 57.6 million men. The definition of women in poverty mixes different situations: older women, single women, single mothers, lesbian, bisexual, transgender, disabled, migrant or from ethnic minorities. This mixture of situations which have nothing to do with each other shows from the outset a great lack of rigour in the rapporteur's approach. The report does not propose concrete solutions to the negative effects on women of austerity policies, the development of single-parent families, poverty in rural areas or part-time work. The only solutions proposed are to incur expenses in all directions, to strengthen anti-discrimination legislation or to put men in the home (parental leave). Moreover, the report criticizes "patriarchy", without questioning an immigration whose culture is very often very patriarchal. For all these reasons, this report is not likely to improve the situation of women.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. The aim of this report is to improve the situation of women, who suffer more from poverty than men: there are 64.6 million women in precarious situations, compared to 57.6 million men worldwide. However, the whole text is littered with ideological proposals, aimed more at imposing a certain vision of gender and relations between men and women. While indiscriminately mixing the different categories of women who are victims of poverty (elderly women, disabled women, migrants, transgender people, etc.), he calls on the State to finance all kinds of incoherent projects in this context, such as strengthening laws against discrimination or putting men at home (parental leave). This text is therefore not likely to improve women's poverty. On the strength of this, I voted against it.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because the fight against women's poverty is a matter of social justice. The public expenditure incurred by Member States to reduce this injustice, whether direct or indirect, should not be regarded as waste or mere cost, but a judicious, adequate and aimed at breaking the vicious cycle of poverty.  The report stresses the importance of enabling better reconciliation of private and professional life and access to affordable care services for dependent children and family members and high-quality early childhood education to encourage women to enter and remain in the labour market and for more economically independent women. The report reiterates the role of education in combating gender stereotypes, empowering women and girls in the social, economic, political and cultural spheres and in scientific careers, and in ending the cycle of poverty by including women in sectors where they are underrepresented.

name: Bernd Lucke (ECR)
text: Writing. According to EU statistics, more than 120 million people in the EU are currently affected by poverty – more than 65 million of them are women. Accordingly, we share the basic position of the report that the fight against poverty must be a priority in all Member States, as the Europe 2020 strategy calls for. However, it is wrong to derive from this a European competence, as the report does. As little as we all want poverty, the EU is not responsible for it. The report therefore goes far beyond the target in many of its demands and clearly exceeds the competences of the EU. Although I warmly welcome the fight against poverty in Europe, I have therefore abstained from the final vote.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against this proposal, which is a typical example of the Social Engineering of the European Union. I do not agree with the EU's definition of work of equal value (paragraph 20) or energy poverty (paragraph 53). I do not agree that the EU should determine the parameters of maternity leave and thus interfere with the competences of the Member States. I do not agree with the ideas for a Pan-European regulation of minimum income and, in particular, I do not agree with the denial of the basis of the rule of law in paragraph 18 'the transfer of the burden of proof when complaining of gender discrimination in the workplace'.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ This report highlights the inequalities women face and highlights the efforts the EU and Member States need to make to give everyone equal opportunities in terms of employment, social protection, wages, education and childcare. The problem of women's poverty and their social exclusion has been addressed through numerous resolutions and completely eliminated. By 2015, little progress had been made given the efforts made.  In times of economic crisis and recession, those most affected by the danger of living in poverty are mostly women. They are at risk, both in terms of social protection and their position on the labour market, and are subject to multiple discrimination. According to Eurostat data, the number of women who are at the poverty line and affected by poverty is steadily increasing. The figure stands at 64.6 million, while for men it is 7 million lower.   Women are generally more likely to take responsibility when it comes to caring for elderly or sick family members, which is most often reflected in the interruption of their careers. However, when I voted, I abstained, as this report in many areas goes outside the box and encroaches on areas that are explicitly the competence of the Member States.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Poverty is more and more about women than men. The reasons are different: family, social, maternity-related, both occupational and wage. In doing so, they are often also linked to the effects of the economic and financial crisis. There are currently 65 million women in the Union and 57 million men affected by poverty. It is the task of the Member States and the Union, in cooperation with the social partners as well as non-governmental organisations, to get to know the reasons for poverty thoroughly and, consequently, to create practical and real conditions for eradicating poverty at all, to eliminate discrimination and to ensure equalisation of the position of women and men in all areas, taking into account the specific situation of women in the field of maternity.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I abstained in the vote on the report on poverty: the gender dimension, because it is not sufficiently documented.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this text.  We welcome the desire to address poverty among women, but deplore the lack of concrete proposals, as well as the lack of clarity in the definition of women in poverty. This notion as understood in the text seems to intersect all kinds of categories (aimed at poverty, but also sexuality, religion, disability or illegal situation).
