This text seems to focus more on the fight against discrimination than on poverty. It proposes to spend more and more in areas that are not directly affected by poverty among women.  We also disapprove that the project is campaigning to develop parental leave for men and the development of single-parent families, rather than relaunching an ambitious family policy. Finally, it does not call into question the mass immigration of peoples whose cultures, particularly with regard to their relationship to women, are not compatible with ours.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we discussed a very important topic, such as poverty in terms of gender equality. According to the latest Eurostat data, the number of women living in poverty remains consistently higher than that of men , with around 64.6 million women compared to 57.6 million men. This shows that poverty has a different impact on women and men, with women remaining a more vulnerable group. At the same time, the report highlights the effects of the current austerity measures, which have particularly hit women, exacerbated inequalities and women's poverty, and further excluded them from the labour market. At the same time, we note in the report that there has been a reduction in the networks of public services and the infrastructure for the provision of care for children, the elderly and the sick, and the provision of these high-quality free public services. In the report, we therefore express our sharp opposition to austerity policies and call for greater equality between women and men. I supported the report.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Poverty and social exclusion are now serious social problems that need to be addressed pan-European. The EU must provide the regulatory framework and initiatives in order to move in the right direction. The increase in the percentages of people living below the poverty line is worrying and requires us to act immediately. It is also a fact that women bear the consequences of poverty to a greater extent than men, especially if they are single mothers or people with disabilities. This can also be seen from the professional sector, where there is, among other things, a wage gap, as women try to combine their family obligations with professional ones.  This resolution is an initiative against inequality against women in areas such as employment, social security and pay. I would like to vote in favour of this initiative to contribute to the effort to achieve social justice. I think it is also a broader way of reducing global poverty in a broader context.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is not about gender equality. This is about gender mainstreaming and LGBT. I cannot therefore support this report.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to various studies and reports, on average, more women than men experience poverty. This is due to a number of reasons– women are often paid less for the same job than men, receiving lower pensions and doing lower-paid jobs. I agree with the position taken in the European Parliament's report to give everyone equal opportunities, regardless of gender, in the areas of employment, social protection, pay, education, childcare and culture.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report poses a multitude of problems of rigour and reflection. First, it puts women in very different situations on the same level, between migrants, single mothers, single women etc... Many highly sized jobs for women are being addressed, but no concrete solution is being considered. The prospects are to increase legislation and put men at home. This text struggles with its unrealism and does not stick to a paradox. In particular, he lambasts patriarchy without questioning a population immigration very often of a patriarchal culture precisely. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. Equality in the labour market and the social and economic well-being achieved benefit not only women, but society at large. Because I have some doubts about the content of the resolution tabled, I decided to abstain from the vote.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report because of the necessity to recognise the unique issues of women in poverty and act in order to resolve these issues. This report includes suggestions for the relief of child and migrant poverty, and poverty affecting the LGBTI community. I voted in favour as it is essential to protect and demand equality for women and men in all aspects of society.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: Written. – Poverty has many causes and it can happen to anyone. Nearly 65 million women in Europe face poverty. As a result, their share is significantly and worryingly higher than the number of men facing poverty. Europe has set itself the goal of controlling poverty statistics. With this report, the European Parliament urges the Commission to take seriously the gender dimension of the poverty phenomenon and to implement a policy that tackles the causes of poverty among women. With equal access to the labour market, equal pay for equal work and positive measures that facilitate work-family balance, we are taking a significant step forward to make people financially independent and more resilient. The right to high-quality education for all children so that they can later take control of their own future, regardless of their origin, remains the key to avoiding generational poverty.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – We have been dealing with the issue of poverty and social exclusion of women in the European Parliament for several years, but despite many efforts, little progress has been made. The economic crisis has caused an increase in statistics on the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion. The fact remains that, on average, women continue to be more affected than men, all the more so when it comes to single mothers, pensioners, immigrants or women with disabilities. The pay gap with male colleagues and the old-age pension gap resulting from intermittent careers in an effort to harmoniously combine private and professional life place a heavy burden on women with financial difficulties and daily uncertainty about their economic independence. Member States have the funds to stem the trend of impoverishment. I believe that combating female poverty is a question of social justice. Public expenditure incurred by Member States to limit this injustice should not be seen as a waste or mere cost, but as a sensible investment designed to break this vicious circle. I support the proposal in question.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Poverty hits women more than men, who are usually the first victims of austerity policies and the economic crisis, passing on the poverty cycle to the next generations and their children. Today, in the EU 65 million women are concerned compared to 57 million men. Therefore, I voted in favour of this report which points out the causes that bring women into poverty and gives recommendations to the Commission and the Member States how to tackle the effects of female poverty.

name: Sorin Moisă (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I fully support this report which it would have been better not to have had reasons to adopt in Europe, in 2016. Poverty is particularly acute for women for reasons that should have no place in our society. Member States need to ensure social and economic security for women, to secure equal access to decent payment schemes, a fair inclusion in the labour market, and income and fiscal obligations in order to reduce the gender gap. We need to aim at measures that are based on the integration of the gender perspective, in general, as well as the implementation of fitting measures with adequate institutional and financial support at all levels.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Report of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality analyses the problem of poverty that affects women more than average. It points out that statistical surveys show that 16.6% of the EU population is considered to be at risk of poverty, with a risk ratio of 16.1% for men and 17.2% for women. Moreover, the exposure of certain groups of women, in particular single mothers, pensioners, immigrants or women with disabilities, is significantly higher than average. She points out that two-thirds of all working hours in the world are worked by women, who nevertheless earn only 10 per cent of the world's income and have less than one per cent of the world's wealth. The report identifies the efforts that the EU and the Member States should make to ensure that everyone, regardless of gender discrimination, has equal opportunities and opportunities in the field of employment, social security, income, education, childcare and culture. It also identifies the instruments that Europe and the Member States already have to overcome trends threatening to impoverish half the population. It emphasises that the fight against women's poverty is also, at least in part, the way to a long-term solution to the problem of child poverty. I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite Parliament's greater focus in recent years on the issue of poverty and social exclusion of women, the reality is that, at the time of today, the problem persists and we find that little has been achieved despite the efforts made. Given the latest available data on the distribution of monetary poverty and income inequality in the EU, 16.6% of the EU-28 population were considered at risk of poverty after social transfers. This risk increased to 17.2% for women, compared to 16.1% for men. These figures certainly hide numerous disparities between states. It is well known that women are, on average, more affected than men, especially when they are single mothers, pensioners, immigrants or disabled people.  I am voting in favour of this report because I support the need to strengthen the fight against domestic violence, in particular against women, of investment to improve education and training, with a view to improving access to the labour market and combating unemployment, poverty and social exclusion of women.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. You can't want to both defend women's rights and encourage immigration, it's a contradiciton in terms. Unfortunately, I will not vote for this report.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The number of women living in poverty in Europe (65 million) remains higher than that of men living in poverty (58 million). These figures show that poverty affects women differently than men. The report explores in detail the possible causes of this, such as stereotypes in society, discrimination and challenges in reconciling work and family life. However, I do not agree with the parts of the report which, contrary to the principle of subsidiarity, would regulate maternity, care and paternity leave and the development of relevant labour and state care services, in a way that goes beyond the provisions of EU law. That is why I abstained.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The gender perspective is about women in society, about the ways women and men interact and their ability to access resources and opportunities in their areas depending on whether they are a woman or a man. The matter of female poverty and the social exclusion of women has been of great importance to the European Parliament. I have voted for this report that identifies the ongoing inequalities that women suffer and highlights the efforts needed to be made by the European Union and its Member States to them all, without distinction of gender, equal opportunities in the files of social security, employment, education, childcare and culture.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Member States should give priority to reconciliation between private and professional life by introducing forms of work organisation that are favourable to the family. Unfortunately, the lack of quality and affordable care services for children, dependents or the elderly, and in particular nurseries, kindergartens and long-term care institutions contributes to the gender gap in employment, remuneration and pensions. We call for the optimisation of the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF), to give priority to the creation of public and private infrastructures for the care of children and other dependents, and to use the flexibility mechanism to finance the education and care of very young children. The Commission should allocate specific resources, through a co-financing mechanism, to promote incentives for specific areas that do not have child care and support services and for areas where the employment rate of women is extremely low. We call on the Commission to make an impact assessment on minimum income systems in the EU and to consider additional measures that take into account the economic and social conditions in each Member State, as well as to assess whether those systems allow households to cover their basic personal needs.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ In today’s Europe both men and women are at risk of living in poverty. Women still, however, suffer more than their male counterparts from gender structural disadvantages that affect their ability to create financially independent and stable existences for themselves and for their children. I support this resolution because it stresses that Member States have to take action in order to change the status quo and move more women out of a position of social marginalisation, for example through investing in education and training, improving child/elderly care options, creating quality jobs for women and by closing the gender pay and pension gap.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report as it contained some very progressive and positive provisions. My colleague Lynn Boylan proposed the introduction of paid domestic violence leave in Europe through an opinion she recently authored in the European Parliament’s Employment and Social Affairs Committee, and key aspects of this opinion were incorporated in this vote. The report included a provision where paid leave for survivors of domestic violence would become a right. This is a valuable new idea that has been introduced in Australia and the US, and this week’s vote is the first time the European Parliament has called for its introduction in Europe. I am very pleased that my party Sinn Féin has successfully placed this proposal firmly on the agenda of the European Parliament, and Sinn Féin will call on Irish policy-makers to take this on board immediately and act to introduce this leave in Ireland.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. Under the guise of a serious issue, issues such as gender mainstreaming and so-called LGBT interests (lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender) are hidden.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported.  Unfortunately, poverty affects women more than men, especially rural mothers, pensioners, immigrants or people with disabilities. They are over-represented in precarious jobs, many of them on career breaks, in so-called women-friendly positions or part-time jobs, because they have to look after loved ones, not because it is their conscious choice. To the detriment of women compared to men, the pay and pension gaps resulting from attempts to reconcile private and professional life are manifested in a patchy career, putting a heavy burden and daily insecurity on women in financial difficulties and limiting their economic independence. Member States must do more to eliminate this inequality.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 Measures need to be put in place to ensure a work-life balance in all Member States and to ease a certain burden on families. In particular, flexible working times and remote work opportunities should be used. Women and men must be given the same guarantees when raising children who encourage them not to leave the labour market, to learn and to improve their qualifications. The Commission must step up its efforts to introduce a European Children's Guarantee, and particular attention must be paid to the introduction of public and private care and support infrastructure for children and other dependants. In addition, pre-school education and care funding projects should allow the use of the Flexibility Instrument provided for in the Stability and Growth Pact.  I support the proposals to increase the minimum duration of fully paid maternity leave and to provide for compulsory entitlement to paid paternity leave and to the introduction of nursing leave.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 More and more popular families, especially women and children, are faced with poverty inherent in the exploitative capitalist system. By concealing this real cause of their problems, the EU and urban governments are hypocritically trying to "make up" the tragic consequences that barbaric politics is causing them to popular households.  The report proposes, for example, adaptable and flexible working hours, teleworking, which in this system not only do not meet modern needs and women's right to work permanently, stable with full rights, but instead undermine them. There is talk of 'affordable' and therefore paid 'childcare services', while at the same time the report calls for the use of 'financial instruments' for public and private 'social investment' 'in childcare and assistance infrastructures', i.e. parents putting their hands in their pockets to pay for businesses in the sector and, on the other hand, to be financed by EU funds derived from the tax collection of popular incomes.  This is the capitalist system that makes the poor poorer, men and women, to treasure monopolies. The people will only be able to meet their modern extended needs by overthrowing it and taking power into their own hands.

name: Δημήτρης Παπαδάκης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 Today, 122 million people in Europe are threatened by poverty. Women, like children, are one of the most vulnerable groups to find themselves on the poverty line. The number of women in poverty consistently exceeds that of men, with some 65 million women currently in poverty. The economic crisis and austerity policies have led to an increase in the gender gap in the labour market, resulting in women being most affected. In addition, gender discrimination found in the Labour Market in the Member States, covering various aspects such as recruitment, pay, social benefits and pensions, are some of the root causes where women are most at risk of poverty. I voted in favour of the report because it provides for a series of measures to combat social exclusion and gender inequality, leading to women's poverty. In particular, measures are needed to promote the combination of work and private life, high-quality public services to combat poverty, in particular female poverty, the introduction of a Children's Guarantee which ensures free healthcare, free education, decent housing and adequate nutrition for every child in Europe.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course believes more should be done to fight poverty and protect people against discrimination and violence. However this report went on to call for many things that were completely unacceptable. Strong criticism of EU austerity policies which has devastated countries such as Greece was removed from the report. The report called for a reversal in the burden of proof, which would rip up UK law on innocent until proven guilty. There was a call for further EU steps and assessment of minimum income schemes in Member States - the EU has no right to interfere in the UK’s minimum wage or other tax policies. The report called for interference in education policy at EU level. It also called for interference with national procedures on the recognition of refugee status. Finally The EU Parliament voted to remove text which called for a reduced rate on essential goods for women such as tampons. For all these reasons UKIP had no choice but to oppose this report. The only people that should decide such matters are our own elected national governments, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The impact of poverty on women was found to be greater than on men; In fact, it is estimated that some 64.6 million women as against 57.6 million men live in poverty. It is also worrying that poverty is being used to combat social exclusion, which affects the whole of the family. Given that the economic crisis has widened the gap and that the gender gap leads to serious economic loss, I believe that the European Union must change its guidelines as soon as possible in the direction that this draft would like. However, I do not give my full support to this proposal, so I prefer to abstain from voting.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – According to statistics there are now more than 65 million women living in poverty, compared to 57 million men. The draft INI report focuses amongst others on the root causes of female poverty, the scope of women’s poverty in the EU and the impact of social exclusion through poverty on the living and working conditions. It concludes, amongst others, that female poverty is caused by a variety of factors: stereotypes, pay gaps between men and women, lack of work—life balance, and all kind of gender— based discrimination which affects mainly women. I vote in favour of this issue to be able to enable a better and fairer handling of issues concerning gender equality.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. —The regrettable fact that we cannot escape is that women are more affected and susceptible to poverty than men. Women living in rural areas are in an even more difficult position – their unemployment rate is extremely high, they are often not recorded on the labour market, those who are employed have very low incomes, and they also face the problem of access to education and healthcare.  I am therefore pleased that this report adopts my amendments which warn precisely about the situation of women in the countryside and call on Member States to contribute to improving the quality of their lives and living in rural areas in general. I am also pleased that my appeal for the introduction of a minimum national pension that cannot be lower than the poverty risk threshold has also been recognised.  However, I could not fully support the report, as in many respects it goes beyond the scope and subject matter of the report itself, and the very scope of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality and the EU as a whole, and encroaches on areas that are explicitly the competence of the Member States.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The number of women living in poverty is consistently higher than that of men. In Europe, 64.6 million women are in poverty, as against 57.6 million men. The categories of single women, single mothers and migrants are particularly vulnerable. The main causes of female poverty are the lower wages and pensions received by female workers than their male counterparts, the persistence of sexist stereotypes and the lack of quality public services. Women are the first victims of austerity policies, which reproduce the cycle of poverty even in subsequent generations. Europe cannot remain indifferent to these problems, which seriously affect millions of European women and children. The Arena report calls on the European institutions to implement a whole series of initiatives to deal with this situation. The use of European funds to be invested in social childcare facilities; measures to ensure a better work-life balance; a 'European Child Guarantee' that ensures decent health care, education and housing for every European child. Finally, in order to break the vicious circle of poverty, it is essential to encourage the continued participation of women in the labour market.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The Report of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality focused on the fact that women are more likely to be victims of poverty than men. Figures show that 64.6 million women struggle with poverty against 57.6 million men. The cause of these differences are stereotypes that lead to unequal wages and pensions between the sexes. 38.9% of the population and 48.6% of single women are unable to cope with their costs. I agree with Parliament's decision to reduce gender disparities and I think we will achieve this if we increase childcare and dependent family members. We need to work to get women on business, making them more independent.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The impoverishment of peoples is just one of the faces of the implementation of austerity policies, memoranda, economic governance, the European Semester. It follows that today 25% of the POPULATION of the EU-28 is at risk of poverty before social benefits, more than 120 million citizens. Policies that aggravated inequalities and social exclusion with a particular impact on women, which were consummated in attacks on the social role of the State, destroying and privatizing public services, attacking workers' rights and collective hiring. Today, labour discrimination between men and women remains with a significant disparity between wages and pensions, discrimination in access to employment and a precarious labour relationship that affects women more than men. Combating social inequalities, poverty, discrimination against women and raising their economic and social status can only be overthe breakdown with exploitation policies, wage appreciation, labour regulation and security and collective bargaining, increasing the supply of free and quality public services in the areas of health, education, social security , among others. We follow many of the concerns of the report, which justified the vote in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The problem of poverty and social marginalisation of women has been the subject of particular attention for many years. On average, women are usually more at risk of poverty than men, especially for single women, pensioners and women with disabilities.  The report contains a number of ideas worthy of support, such as: closing the gender pay gap, adopting measures to promote work-life balance, introducing flexible working hours (voluntarily), the role of education in improving women's situations, supporting women's entrepreneurship, etc. However, it addresses a number of issues which cannot be agreed, i.e. the Commission's call to work on the proposal for a minimum wage (taking into account national circumstances; we believe, however, that this issue should not be regulated by the EU), individual consideration of household income to determine social rights (based on the assumption that women are always disadvantaged), a new EU legislation on combating gender-based violence (and supporting the Istanbul Convention) , fighting stereotypes through educational programmes, etc.  The report also contains points that are controversial, such as support for the Maternity Leave Directive or numerous references to the rights of people in the LGTBI community. I have hereby abstained.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. Poverty has no colour, origin or gender. Unfortunately, too many people, whether women, children or men, are in poverty in the European Union. I abstained on this text to point out that it is at the member level that strong measures in the fight against poverty must be adopted, in addition to the necessary European cooperation.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The European objective of ensuring gender equality - rectius, because it is a manifestly unfortunate expression, equal rights, duties and guarantees between the sexes - dates back to the Treaty of Rome of 1975. Since then, the issue of poverty and social exclusion has been the subject of several resolutions adopted in parliament, still complying today with regard to gender disparities with regard to the risk of poverty and income inequality. The report stresses that in this context women continue to be more affected than men, especially when they are immigrants, pensioners, disabled people or single mothers. The document also identifies the causes of this disparity, considering, in my view, that the Union and the Member States should do the aim of ensuring the same equal opportunities for all men and women in the fields of employment, social security, renumbering, education and childcare.  Considering the fight against poverty as a question of social justice, and with a view to reducing inequalities in rights, duties and guarantees between the sexes, I am voting in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non legislative, non-binding report. UKIP of course believes more should be done to fight poverty and protect people against discrimination and violence. However this report went on to call for many things that were completely unacceptable. Strong criticism of EU austerity policies which has devastated countries such as Greece was removed from the report. The report called for a reversal in the burden of proof, which would rip up UK law on innocent until proven guilty. There was a call for further EU steps and assessment of minimum income schemes in Member States - the EU has no right to interfere in the UK’s minimum wage or other tax policies. The report called for interference in education policy at EU level. It also called for interference with national procedures on the recognition of refugee status. Finally The EU Parliament voted to remove text which called for a reduced rate on essential goods for women such as tampons. For all these reasons UKIP had no choice but to oppose this report. The only people that should decide such matters are our own elected national governments, not unaccountable EU institutions.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported the resolution on poverty - a perspective of equality between men and women. The number of women in poverty in the European Union is higher than that of men. Single-parent families are more at risk.  The resolution therefore proposes a series of proposals to combat women's poverty, which I share: a better reconciliation of family and working life by establishing working conditions favourable to family life, better use of European Structural and Investment Funds, implementation of policies promoting women's employment and integration into the labour market of socially marginalized women's groups or even a more effective fight against unreported work or atypical forms of contracts. Finally, there is an urgent need to close the pay gap and to reduce the pension gap between men and women.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. The economic crisis from which the Union is gradually recovering has led to an increase in the number of men and women at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Some 64.6 million women live in poverty against 57.6 million men. Women work two-thirds of the world's total working hours, produce half the world's food, but earn only 10% of income and own only 1% of property. It was a difficult vote due to opposition from many right-wing MPs; neverthemore, we have managed to send important messages such as: the use of European funds to promote women's entry into the labour market; legislative initiatives towards work-life balance for women and men (motherhood, parenthood, parenthood); ensuring access to health care, education and housing for children; inclusion of social indicators in the European Semester; assessment by the Commission of the impact of minimum wage policy in the EU or the introduction of a national minimum pension never below the poverty threshold.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The problem of poverty and women's social exclusion has been the subject of special attention from Parliament for years. In 2015, despite the efforts made, little progress has been made and much progress remains to be made to successfully address the causes and consequences of the many facets of this precariousness.  According to the latest available statistics, poverty affects women more than men, and they are still predominantly the ones who continue to occupy the most precarious jobs, which in many cases do not allow their professional life to be reconciled with their working lives. I have supported this report because it places particular emphasis on improving conciliation and child education and access to affordable care services for dependent children and family members. In addition, the Commission is urged to take further steps to further promote women's empowerment and combat gender stereotypes.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I am convinced that it is important to consider the gender dimension when addressing poverty. That is why I supported the report entitled "Poverty: A Perspective of Gender Equality". In voting for this report, the European Parliament is making a clear appeal to the European Commission. In this report, I will take particular note of the European Parliament's request to the Commission to submit a new proposal for a directive on maternity leave but also a proposal for paid paternity leave. I regret, however, that some proposals have not received the necessary support from the European Parliament to be included in the text. I will mention in particular the idea of introducing a reduced VAT rate for goods that are essential for women, such as sanitary pads and tampons.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Poverty is, it can be said, a horizontal problem that affects people, regardless of their gender. The fact that Parliament has produced a report on gender aspects in anti-poverty policy is important and should contribute to better developing targeted measures to help people of each sex get out of poverty. At the same time, I would like to emphasise the importance of the semantic wording – it should not be so much about overcoming poverty, but about helping the poor themselves out of poverty – whether it is the supply of jobs or additional financial and material support.  I am not convinced that the EU or the Member States should take full responsibility for eradicating the poor from poverty who do not want to contribute to this themselves. I do not want to point fingers, but the experience of some Member States in trying to tackle poverty is being created for the fourth time by people living only from benefits. Let us change attitudes and give people a fishing rod, not turn them into fish, which perhaps they do not like very much!

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The issue of poverty and social exclusion of women has been the subject of particular attention from the European Parliament for several years. Despite the undeniable differences that continue to persist throughout the EU - such as the difference in women's pay compared to their male counterparts - unfortunately these are issues usually minimised or forgotten in the political debate. However, poverty and social exclusion are not frontiers and are not closely related to gender. That is why I believe that we should have strategies to combat poverty more focused on the most vulnerable age groups, such as childhood and old age, and on social groups or regions with prevailing poverty problems and where there is a need to break vicious cycles, which unfortunately insist on subsisting. It is for what I said in the last paragraph, and for agreeing with the absolute need to combat and prevent poverty in the EU, that I abstained in the final vote on this report.

name: Pirkko Ruohonen-Lerner (ECR)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Arena report because it raises important problems of equality, such as the poor position of retired women.  Too often in Finland and elsewhere in Europe, women receive a meagre pension that is barely enough to make a living. There are several reasons for this. Women have often stopped or stopped working to take care of their families. One solution would be to distribute childcare leave more evenly between women and men.  However, regardless of how this issue is resolved, the most important thing would be to ensure that having and caring for children does not significantly undermine the pension provision of parents on childcare leave.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because it addresses a very relevant issue, heightened by austerity policies implemented in recent years, such as poverty and gender perspective. The report mentions the causes of women's poverty, precariousness and social exclusion. Women remain more affected than men by the economic crisis and are more exposed to the possibility of social exclusion, with poverty rates being significantly higher in women's cases. The pay and pension gap, the glass ceiling, the lack of conciliation policies, as well as the absence of equal and non-transferable parental leave are some of the reasons for this inequality. This report contains several aspects that make our vote decisive in favour, such as the need to ensure public services, education and social security to combat poverty, the need to promote conciliation to avoid precarious and "atypical" contracts, the defence of women's economic independence by fighting for equality in wages and pensions, strengthening maternity and paternity leave and combating gender-based violence.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. According to the Commission, in 2015 women earned on average 16% less per hour than men for the same work. Implicitly these wage gaps lead to lower pensions for women and often make women poor. Another sad reality is that women's pensions in the EU are 39% lower than those of men. At the same time, women who have been housewives do not have pensions and depend on family members.  That is why I voted for the Arena report which calls for combating poverty among women, but also for equalising income between women and men, for the same type of work.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. The Social Democrats in Denmark have always fought against poverty and to create equal opportunities for all, regardless of their background. Poverty is best combated by ensuring economic prosperity and high-quality jobs, as well as by creating a social safety net that takes care of those who cannot work. The EU has a shared responsibility to boost growth in Europe. However, it is not eu competence to determine the specific layout of social or fiscal policy. It is up to each Member State to decide how the national welfare system should be designed and financed. We can only call on the Member States to take an active part in the fight against poverty and for equality.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Poverty and social exclusion affect more women than men, they also have a strong impact on their children and can persist for several generations. I therefore supported Mrs Arena's report, which highlights the tools for overcoming the inequalities that women suffer from. Their full use and application should be ensured by each Member State and by the European Commission, whether it is the introduction of family-friendly working conditions or the promotion of social care facilities. The available financial instruments of the European Union should also assist states in investing in social infrastructure, so it is important to optimise both the European Social Fund and the European Regional Development Fund in this context.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this resolution because, despite the right's attempts, we have managed to get it to make a clear denunciation of the devastating, even more virulent effects on women of austerity policies imposed by the European Commission on the Member States.  These "austericide" policies are the clear cause of the increase in the feminization of poverty in the European Union, where there are now more than 64.6 million women in poverty.  The text we have adopted recalls the right of access to education for the daughters and sons of migrants and refugees and refugees, and urges the European Commission and the Member States to increase funds for the fight against unemployment, poverty and social exclusion.   I therefore share the diagnosis of this Resolution, as well as its call for the promotion of free and quality public services in the fields of health, education and social security. I have therefore voted in favour of the text since the conviction that real and effective policies are needed to achieve the still far-reaching real equality between men and women.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this as I believe the UK has a good record in this area and I do not believe the EU should be making policy for the UK.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which addresses one of the most over-looked and crucial aspects to poverty prolongation. Women are the first victims of the austerity policies and the economic crises. This is passed on to their children and creates a poverty cycle to the next generation. The Socialists in this place call for the use of EU instruments to invest in social infrastructure and allow for better work/life arrangements, to ensure that women stay in or join the labour market, breaking down this vicious circle of poverty that we see all too often.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 One of the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy is to reduce the number of Europeans living below the national poverty line, thus out of poverty by 2020. It regrets that, according to the latest statistics available, women were particularly at risk of poverty in the EU in 2014, with a rate of 46.6% before social transfers and 17.7% after social transfers. However, in view of the subject under discussion, I find it particularly worrying that the number of women living in poverty is consistently higher than that of men – there are currently around 64.6 million women, compared with 57.6 million men. Although the EU has set clear targets for gender inequality by 2020 and has been paying close attention to this issue for several years now, I consider the results achieved in relation to the efforts made to be poorly satisfactory. I supported the resolution because I consider gender equality against poverty to be a very important instrument that can continue to play a very important role in productivity and economic growth, and can, of course, also lead to greater participation of women in the labour market. Nevertheless, I believe that if the Member States do not move towards a much more effective and strong introduction of family-friendly working conditions, it is difficult to expect improvements in the area of gender equality.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I abstained in the final vote on the report on poverty in terms of gender equality. I could not support a report that, in its recommendations, does not respect the competences of the Member States and proposes unrealistic solutions. It is true that there is still a situation in European society where more women than men are at risk of poverty. Income inequality, in particular, persists, which translates into a large pension gap (39% of the EU average). The report cites discrimination in the labour market and in remuneration. However, the report does not provide any new and better solutions to this situation and calls for actions that are clearly not within the Union's remit, e.g. on the European Child Guarantee, i.e. guaranteed care and services for all children at EU level, or on the recognition of the rights of same-sex couples in raising children. This sensitive issue is to be adapted at Member State level and the European Parliament should not interfere with their competence. On the other hand, the report does not address at all an issue that I consider to be absolutely crucial, which is discrimination against parents raising children. Families caring for children are at risk of poverty because they devote part of their professional careers to childcare instead of earning and depositing funds into pension funds. Unfortunately, the report makes no mention of this.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. Although gender equality is one of the EU's fundamental values and one of the objectives of the 2020 Strategy, it is still far from the desired achievement. What is more, since the beginning of the economic crisis, the situation in the area of gender equality has deteriorated further. Following the Recommendation of the European Commission, Member States have started implementing austerity measures and reducing public services, which has led to an increase in poverty among women in particular. The report is divided into three parts, addressing poverty and work-time balance, poverty and employment, as well as general recommendations, including, inter alia, a call for Member States to reduce energy poverty, a call to guarantee social rights for victims of violence against women, and a stressed role of education in combating gender stereotypes. Unfortunately, the report did not include a requirement for the establishment of a minimum wage and a minimum pension at European Union level, nor extended maternity leave from 14 to 20 weeks. The positive aspects of the report include the recognition of LGBTI rights and measures to reduce job insecurity. Although the report has certain shortcomings, I believe that it is nevertheless appropriate, which is why I voted in favour of its adoption.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR)
text: Written. – The N-VA delegation abstained on this report. The N-VA stands for an inclusive society with equal rights and obligations for all, as well as a policy on equal opportunities tailored to and with attention to all diverse target groups. This applies to all genders, especially women and girls, but also to people with disabilities, older people, LGBTIQ, etc. Violations of this equality, both at work and in private, are not acceptable to us. Poverty alleviation is an important theme for the N-VA. With our poverty policy, we want to guide people in poverty so that they become self-reliant people. As the report states, the N-VA sees work as an important means of getting out of poverty: after all, work is still the best guarantee against poverty. At the same time, respect for national powers for the N-VA is very important. It is not for the EU to adopt measures such as an EU minimum income or EU definitions of work.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Currently, 64.6 million women are affected by poverty and 57.6 million by men, and in 2014 women were particularly affected by the risk of poverty in all 28 Member States of the European Union. However, it should be noted that the rate of women affected by poverty varies significantly between Member States.  Also worrying is the fact that the number of women living in poverty has been steadily increasing and has increased by 50% since 1975. On the other hand, women work two-thirds of the world's working hours and produce half of the world's food, receiving a low 10% of the world's income and owning less than 1% of the world's ownership. In order to alleviate poverty among women, it is essential to highlight high-quality public services in the fight against women's poverty, which are more dependent on such services than men, and to encourage and engage men to promote gender equality in all areas and at all levels of the labour market.  It is important to bring macroeconomic and social and labour market-related policy reforms in line with equal gender rights policies to ensure economic and social rights for women.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The number of women affected by poverty remains consistently higher than the number of men. Currently, this number is 64.6 million women compared to 57.6 million men. Almost 40% of the population and almost 50% of single women in the Member States of the European Union are unable to cover unforeseen costs. The number of women living in poverty in rural areas has increased by 50% since 1975.  Gender equality in the labour market benefits not only women, but the economy and society as a whole. The gender pay gap is 16.3% and women are more likely than men to be employed under atypical and precarious employment contracts that further expose them to poverty. Parliament calls, inter alia, on Member States to monitor respect for the rights of working women who are increasingly doing low-cost jobs and becoming victims of discrimination. I would support if the report did not contain sensitive items that are incompatible with the values inherited by the EPP and which are inconsistent with our views, in particular with regard to subsidiarity, and items that have no direct or indirect link to the causes of poverty.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. I abstained from voting on the report on poverty: the gender perspective. The report on gender poverty provides important data showing that there are more women at risk of poverty in European society than men. The labour market is particularly exposed, where there is also significant gender discrimination. In 2016, there have already been several reports dealing with a similar theme. Unfortunately, we can see that, although this report highlights some important aspects, it does not bring new, better solutions, and I have therefore not been able to support it. The report also contains a number of sensitive issues which, in my opinion, should not be the subject of this report.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report rightly points out that the economic crisis has affected women the most, particularly when it comes to pensioners, immigrants or people with disabilities. It is also rightly pointed out that women still hold the most precarious and part-time jobs. Both the pay gap compared to men and the pension gap are borne by women in financial difficulties and cause daily uncertainty and lead to poverty.  It is a fact that neoliberal austerity policies in relation to workers, such as wage cuts and benefit cuts, are doubly affecting women, who statistically experience poverty to a greater extent than men. While women accept the dual exploitation of this system (as a worker and as a woman), the economic crisis leads to a further deepening of class differences and widening inequalities.  This report highlights the continuing inequalities affecting women and encourages the Member States and the Commission to make efforts to provide everyone with the same opportunities and opportunities in the fields of work, social security, pay, education, and childcare and to stop people being impoverished. That is why we voted in favour of the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 It is proposed to vote against the report as it promotes the promotion and support of transgender/homosexual people.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report, given that the compilation provides a thorough analysis and a list of remarkable facts showing that women are also the most vulnerable and discriminated against group in society from the point of view of social deprivation. I consider aspects referring to the situation and marginalisation of women in the labour market, which are often behind the state of poverty, to be particularly important. With regard to this report, I recalled that I have also made an initiative myself in the past to ensure that, from a law enforcement and judicial point of view, women are automatically given priority protection throughout the Union, in addition to other groups particularly vulnerable to crime, such as children and the elderly. In the spirit of the current debate and decision, I think it is appropriate to apply this type of preference with similar naturalness and automatism in the social and labour field, so in my further work in Parliament, I will try to help to further align our various political and legislative efforts on gender equality along the lines of similar facts and arguments in many respects.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 There are currently more than 122 million people in Europe at risk of poverty. More than half of them are women, especially single mothers, who struggle to make ends meet. It should be remembered that women's poverty is transmitted to children, which often prevents the whole generation from functioning normally in society. Parliament's report on women's poverty is a set of recommendations for the EU institutions and the Member States on how to combat this phenomenon. The document draws attention to the still existing gender pay gap or insufficient public assistance to mothers. It m.in eu funds to build social infrastructure or create a European guarantee for children, providing free education, decent housing and health assistance for every child. Despite the most legitimate objective of combating poverty between women and children, Parliament's document contains many unrealistic assumptions and demands, which are also incompatible with fundamental EU principles such as proportionality and subsidiarity. That is why I have chosen to abstain.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The report delves into improving the position of women away from poverty towards equality with men. It is important, but the report's arguments are not fully based on facts. In part, the report is e.e. pro-woman, rather than promoting equality. The report also contains mandatory paternity leave and changes to pension systems, as well as joint EU action, although these issues are competence of the Member States.

name: Dario Tamburrano (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 We voted in favour of the report addressing gender poverty. In fact, according to Eurostat, the number of women living in poverty is higher than that of men. The problem arises in particular for single mothers, pensioners, immigrants or disabled people. Austerity, the large pay gap between women and men and the economic crisis have increased inequalities, affecting women in particular, increasingly excluding them from the labour market, social life, justice, health care services, decent housing and nutrition, water, energy and education. While it has been shown that gender equality in the labour market, achieved by increasing social and economic well-being, benefits women, the economy and society as a whole. That is why the report calls on the European Union to make new efforts to ensure equal opportunities in employment, social protection, pay, education, children and culture. Proposals include the launch of a comprehensive and comprehensive legislative initiative to guarantee leave for mothers and fathers, improved access to credit, advice and financial services for women, the review of macroeconomic, social and labour market policies, and the call for ratification of the Istanbul Convention.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ In the EU 7 million more women live in poverty than men, bringing the total number up to 65 million women living in poverty (Eurostat). Worldwide, women earn only 10% of the world’s income and own less than 1% of the world’s property (UNHCR). However, these low figures are not reflected in the workforce, as women work two—thirds of the world’s working hours and produce half of the world’s food. Female poverty is caused by factors such as pay and pension gaps, which are at 16.3% and 39%, respectively, gender stereotypes and lack of work—life balance. This report highlights the importance of gender—balanced working environments and urges Member States to introduce family—friendly working arrangements. Furthermore, the Commission is asked to bring new proposals for maternity, parental care and paternity leaves and to increase women’s participation in the labour market. I support this report and I believe that women and girls have to be empowered in all economic and social sectors, in order to break the cycle of poverty for future generations.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I voted for the text of my colleague Arena. According to the latest Eurostat data, the number of women living in poverty is consistently higher than that of men, with around 64.6 million women currently compared to 57.6 million men. This shows that poverty affects women and men differently, that women were particularly affected by the risk of poverty in the 28 Member States of the Union in 2014, with a rate of 46.6% before social transfers and 17.7% after social transfers, and that women's poverty rates vary considerably from one Member State to another. Regardless of the specifics of the at-risk groups concerned (older women, single women, single mothers, lesbian women, bisexual women, transgender women and women with disabilities), the poverty rates of migrant and ethnic minority women are the same across the European Union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Poverty is a reality in Europe nowadays and the number of women in poverty remains permanently high. While this report proposes a number of good provisions to fight against poverty, I decided to abstain on the final vote because I believe that these elements should be decided at a national level in respect of different situations.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ Statistics suggest that women are more likely to be poorer than men and more at risk of starvation due to the systematic discrimination they face. Since the beginning of the economic crisis, poverty levels in Europe have increased, and according to Eurostat, the number of women affected by poverty remains higher than the number of men, currently at around 64.6 million women compared to 57.6 million men.  The reasons why women are more affected are numerous. While I support some of the proposals put forward in the report, such as flexible working hours, wage equality and the role of education in achieving equality, I believe that the European Parliament has no competence in regulating minimum wages. While it has been emphasised that the circumstances of each Member State would be taken into account, I consider that this should be entirely within the competence of the Member States. So I voted abstention.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. On the motion for a resolution of the European Parliament on poverty - the gender aspect, I abstained from voting. We have been dealing with poverty and social exclusion in the EU for many years. In the PPE Political Group, we are working against all forms of poverty, but the fact is that women face it more often than men. I could support certain parts of the report, but it is unacceptable that they should include ideological themes in resolutions that are necessary and have a good purpose. Labour market policies must be designed in such a way as to guarantee equal opportunities for all. Discrimination is not good in any way. The resolution also repeatedly neglected the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because it addresses a very relevant issue, heightened by austerity policies implemented in recent years, such as poverty and gender perspective. The report mentions the causes of women's poverty, precariousness and social exclusion. Women remain more affected than men by the economic crisis and are more exposed to the possibility of social exclusion, with poverty rates being significantly higher in women's cases. The pay and pension gap, the glass ceiling, the lack of conciliation policies, as well as the absence of equal and non-transferable parental leave are some of the reasons for this inequality. This report contains several aspects that make our vote decisive in favour, such as the need to ensure public services, education and social security to combat poverty, the need to promote conciliation to avoid precarious and "atypical" contracts, the defence of women's economic independence by fighting for equality in wages and pensions, strengthening maternity and paternity leave and combating gender-based violence.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. This report envisages improving the situation of women mainly from the point of view of combating discrimination, particularly in favour of migrant women and ethnic, religious and sexual minorities. He criticizes "patriarchy" in vain, even though the migration is encouraged. The effects of austerity policies, particularly in highly feminized jobs (human services), the development of single-parent families, poverty in rural areas, part-time work are envisaged in the report, but the solutions envisaged are limited to asking the States and the Union to finance projects, and thus to increase spending, to strengthen already tangled legislation against discrimination or to put men in the home. For all these reasons, this report is not likely to improve the situation of women. I'm voting against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 According to the latest Eurostat data, the number of women living in poverty (currently 64.6 million) remains consistently higher than that of men in poverty (currently 57.6 million). This shows that poverty affects women and men differently. For women, the risk of poverty in the EU-28 was particularly high in 2014, with women's poverty rates without social benefits at 46.6 percent and with these benefits at 17.7 percent. I voted in favour of the report on the agenda.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted in favour of this report because it addresses a very relevant issue, heightened by austerity policies implemented in recent years, such as poverty and gender perspective. The report mentions the causes of women's poverty, precariousness and social exclusion. Women remain more affected than men by the economic crisis and are more exposed to the possibility of social exclusion, with poverty rates being significantly higher in women's cases. The pay and pension gap, the glass ceiling, the lack of conciliation policies, as well as the absence of equal and non-transferable parental leave are some of the reasons for this inequality. This report contains several aspects that make our vote decisive in favour, such as the need to ensure public services, education and social security to combat poverty, the need to promote conciliation to avoid precarious and "atypical" contracts, the defence of women's economic independence by fighting for equality in wages and pensions, strengthening maternity and paternity leave and combating gender-based violence.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The report focuses on different dimensions to combat poverty from a gender perspective. It recognises the damaging effect that austerity measures, cuts in public services and privatisations have on women and asks for it to be redressed. Furthermore it also contains many good proposals to improve work-life balance, combat precarious work and gender discrimination, as well as other measures to combat poverty such as the development of support schemes to eradicate energy poverty and the introduction of a minimum income at EU level.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I support the contribution of voluntary organisations and services in this area, and I urge the Member States to support their activities; I recall the active participation of women in volunteering education and other activities, including support for and improvement of educational opportunities, such as education services for refugees and poor children.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on ‘Poverty: a gender perspective’. Eurostat data show that the number of women in poverty remains permanently higher than that of men and the more so if they are single mothers, pensioners, immigrants or disabled. The report stresses the importance of gender equality in the labour market which would benefit not only women but the economy and society as a whole. The report equally underlines the crucial role of high-quality public services in combating poverty, especially female poverty, since women are more dependent on such services. The report urges the encouragement and commitment of men in terms of promoting gender equality in all fields and at all levels of the labour market. In addition, the report considers that Member States should prioritise the issue of reconciling private and professional life by introducing family—friendly working arrangements.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it calls on the Member States and the Commission to develop and use the available policy and financial instruments, including the Social Investment Package, in order to meet the Barcelona objectives. In this context, it also calls for the European Social Fund (ESF) and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) to be optimised, for priority to be given, in the use of social investments and the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) regulation, to the establishment of public and private facilities for care of and assistance to children and other dependent persons. Finally, the report proposes that the Commission allocates specific resources, through a co-financing mechanism, to promote incentives for specific areas where there is a shortage of ECEC facilities and where the female employment rate is extremely low.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this report because women are still disadvantaged in labour market pay, i.e. 16.3% compared to men. Moreover, it is often women who work part-time to support family life.  This report also aims to develop measures to support men to take up an active father role, in order to allow a fairer distribution of family responsibilities and to enable women to participate equally in the labour market. Furthermore, this report also refers to the situation of refugee children and the need for the EU and the Member States to provide them with education.

name: Paavo Väyrynen (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 The report 'poverty: gender perspective' brings together the challenges of women's financial position and proposes ways of changing this situation towards a more equal position. The issue itself is very important and I have personally worked to promote equality in the past, for example, as Minister for Foreign Trade and Development and now vice-chairman of the Committee on Development.  However, the report is a collection of things - even those to be supported - that must be decided in the Member States. For example, parental leave and pension matters are the responsibility of the Member States. The report proposes, among other things, compulsory paternity leave, which is not suitable for Finland. We should emphasise volunteering. In line with my line, therefore, I voted against this report in the final vote, because these matters are largely up to the Member States themselves to decide.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. Women, particularly single mothers, elderly, migrant and disabled women, are the main victims of the worsening poverty and social exclusion resulting from austerity policies in Europe.  This is due in particular to the persistence of the gender pay and pension gaps, due in particular to career interruptions to care for children and the very large proportion of women in part-time jobs. It is high time that Member States promote real equality between women and men through the development of quality public services, particularly in the areas of education and health, and the strengthening of different types of leave.  In addition, it has now been ten years since the revision of the existing legislation to close the pay gap and reduce the pension gap between men and women, even though this issue has been enshrined in the treaties since the beginning of European integration. This report by the European Parliament's Women's Committee, as is often the case, makes good statements and makes good recommendations. I have therefore, of course, voted in favour, hoping that this document will have some impact on the policies of the Member States.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The issue of poverty and social exclusion of women is a reality that is linked to the gender pay gap, low wages and, consequently, low retirement pensions. This is added to the precarious work, aggravated in the last four years by the policies imposed by the Troika and which has particularly affected women. Despite the negative aspects contained in the report, such as the defence of the introduction of work regimes such as telework, individual and non-transferable parental leave rights or access to credit and financial advisory services to promote female entrepreneurship, we believe that, in the fundamental case, it characterises the situation well and calls for effective policies that dignify the work and social functions of the State.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. Contrary to the explanatory memorandum, this report is not a factual consideration of this issue. Rather, some of the issues are about promoting issues such as gender mainstreaming and so-called LGBT (lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender) interests in many areas.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I flatly rejected this resolution: this is not about poverty reduction, but about ideological education measures by the EU. Here, well-known unrealistic demands are repeated: a father-mother's protection directive for all 28 Member States, measures in the shadow boxing battle against the undocumented "gender pay gap", Europe-wide rules on domestic work (Brussels decides who irons at home and washes the laundry), the Introduction of minimum incomes and minimum pensions throughout Europe, the withdrawal of marriage through fiscal measures, fair distribution of wealth, combating gender stereotypes (girls should not become mothers and women). , boys not men and fathers) .... Relativism in a new dimension arises from the demand to "promote respect for differences caused by gender and belonging to minorities and ethnic and religious groups". Recognising the marriage statute for LGBTI families is becoming a challenge to the fight against poverty. It will also examine the impact of procedures for official recognition of a person's gender reassignment or the absence of such procedures on the position of transgender people on the labour market, in particular on their access to employment, remuneration levels, career development and pensions. I reject all this.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Studies have been carried out which have shown that women are a group that is discriminated against in terms of access to the labour market, capital market and public services. Inequalities in this situation create barriers that prevent countries from carrying out effective economic development due to the inability to exploit the potential of workers. As a result of discrimination, women's poverty is largely due to the already historically shaped structure of perception of their identity in terms of biology and society. The problems posed by common stereotypes about women will have a negative impact on the functioning of a sustainable economic process. Promoting gender equality will contribute to a smart development policy that will consequently have a positive impact on the future of the labour market and the private lives of its participants. I am in favour of measures that will improve women's working lives as a result and constitute new rules that will increase the well-being of society as a whole.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Women are more at risk of poverty than men since they become mothers. The present report also confirms this when it recalls that poverty threatens up to a third of single mothers. In the search for effective policies that reduce the risk of poverty related to motherhood, we must therefore talk about women and families. Not perceived gender identity, but specific obligations relating to motherhood and parenthood are a factor that disadvantages mothers and fathers in the labour market. And studies on the impact of the official recognition of transgender gender reassignment required by this report will make no contribution to addressing the poverty of mothers and families raising future citizens and taxpayers. I also find it very unfortunate to mention LGBTI families, as the legislation of most Member States does not know such families. The own-initiative report here ignores their exclusive competences, which is why, unfortunately, I had to vote against the adoption of the proposed resolution.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report we have adopted today addresses the problem of poverty, taking particular account of the social exclusion of women, who remain on average increasingly affected than men. This is mainly the case for single mothers, pensioners, immigrants or disabled people. Over-representation of women is present in precarious work, career breaks, women friendly professions (care for the sick, cleaning jobs, etc.) and part-time jobs. Another problem that emerges from the report is the fact that there is a large pay gap between women and men in Europe, which therefore also results in a pension gap, with a serious difficulty in being able to combine professional and private life. The European Union and the Member States are therefore called on to make new efforts to ensure equal opportunities in employment, social protection, pay, education, children and culture.

name: Σωτήριος Ζαριανόπουλος (
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 More and more popular families, especially women and children, are faced with poverty inherent in the exploitative capitalist system. By concealing this real cause of their problems, the EU and urban governments are hypocritically trying to "make up" the tragic consequences that barbaric politics is causing them to popular households.  The report proposes, for example, adaptable and flexible working hours, teleworking, which in this system not only do not meet modern needs and women's right to work permanently, stable with full rights, but instead undermine them. There is talk of 'affordable' and therefore paid 'childcare services', while at the same time the report calls for the use of 'financial instruments' for public and private 'social investment' 'in childcare and assistance infrastructures', i.e. parents putting their hands in their pockets to pay for businesses in the sector and, on the other hand, they should also be financed from EU funds derived from the tax bleeding of popular incomes.  This is the capitalist system that makes the poor poorer, men and women, to treasure monopolies. The people will only be able to meet their modern extended needs by overthrowing it and taking power into their own hands.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Combating women's economic exclusion and improving their situation on the labour market is an important objective in which the European Union should be actively involved. There is no doubt that women are much more likely to be at risk of poverty than men. The particular importance of women for the proper functioning of the family as a basic social cell is not to be underestimated, and they should therefore be given special protection and the creation of effective opportunities to combine work and family life.  Many of the proposals for action contained in this report deserve full support, including the call to close the gender pay gap, the call for further mechanisms to enable women to reconcile family and professional responsibilities, the call for women to benefit more from flexible forms of employment or access to training and tools to improve their professional qualifications. Unfortunately, I cannot agree with many of the solutions that have been advocated, which go beyond the need to improve the situation of women. In particular, it is an attempt to defer to the Member States and to transfer to the European level a mechanism for shaping the minimum wage, or an ideologically motivated perception of the problem of violence against women, as well as gender stereotypes. Understanding the importance of this issue and taking these arguments into account, I have decided to abstain in the vote on this report.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Arena report because I believe that it contains crucial elements in combating the phenomenon of 'feminisation of poverty'. I would like to call on the Member States and the Commission to take measures to combat all forms of gender-based multiple discrimination to ensure that the principle of non-discrimination and equality in the labour market and access to employment is applying, and in particular to adopt social protection measures to ensure that women's pay and social benefits are , in particular pensions, are the same as those of men with the same or similar experience who do the same work or work of equal value. These measures are key to promoting the principle of equal opportunities and equal treatment of men and women in the professional field.  I would also stress the proposal that makes it compulsory to submit equality plans for companies, including actions to eliminate segregation, the design of remuneration systems and measures to support women's careers.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. The report on poverty: The gender perspective looks at the latest Eurostat data showing that the number of women living in poverty is still higher than for men. I am in favour of full respect for the principle of gender equality in all areas and at all levels of the labour market, and for an effective support system for education, social protection systems and care services that will reduce the risk of poverty. However, as the report in some places interferes with the principle of subsidiarity, I abstained from voting.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, i would like to begin by congratulating the rapporteur It must be said that for more than 20 years, with the reform of the common market, the single market emerged, within which tariff barriers were successfully removed. Unfortunately, the barriers to non-phthis continue to have a significant impact on trade and the free movement of goods. While it is perfectly understandable that there will always be some bureaucratic burdens, cutting red tape, which is one of the main objectives, must also be achieved in the digital market. And the quality of cross-border provision of services should be noted separately, as there are often quite different systems in our Member States in this respect.
