Tell it, but, to entrepreneurs in the outermost regions such as the Canary Islands, where I come from, that every day they have to fight against the barriers not only physical imposed by insularity and remoteness, but also with less visible but very present barriers, which affect above all our SMEs. Not to mention the problems we continue to face with e-commerce, which creates discrimination for the people of these regions that cannot continue to be felt. So I join the Commission's call for deep work to be done in this regard and to definitively remove non-tariff barriers, which they do is hinder competition and reduce the possibilities for consumers.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 It is common ground that the Single Market has been achieved through effective cooperation between the Member States of the Union. The removal of tariff barriers to trade is an integral part of the Single Market. In contrast, non-tariff barriers have not yet been removed, which creates a disparity in state practices and thus lacks a common policy in this area. It is reasonable and understandable that there can be no complete abolition of non-tariff duties, since in accordance with the basic principle of subsidiarity, Member States have the first say on matters which are not European primary law. Thus, there will always be some degree of differentiation between Member States.  Nevertheless, the aim of removing many non-tariff barriers is to reduce protective measures by Member States in order to open up domestic markets even more and to benefit businesses across Europe, as well as consumers, from falling prices.  Having managed, as a political group, to protect the rights of consumers, workers and the environment through the resolution, I would like to vote in favour of this resolution.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. This is about non-tariff barriers. These will be determined centrally from Brussels. I reject this dictatorial economic policy.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Removing non-tariff barriers will help businesses in the EU, but consumers will benefit the most. This is confirmed by a study commissioned by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, which notes that the Single Market benefits some companies, namely the most competitive and innovative, but all consumers because of lower prices and greater choice. Therefore, in order to benefit our consumers in Europe, the aim of removing these non-tariff barriers is in the interests of all Member States and the European Parliament.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which acknowledges existing barriers to the proper functioning of the internal market and how these can be removed.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is of interest in that it proposes administrative relief for businesses and more economic freedoms. However, this text aims to install once and for all the single market and an unprecedented ultraliberalism. Measures to do this are the abolition of non-tariff instruments used by states to protect particular economic sectors (Made in, protected geographical designations, etc.). The argument has a considerable profit. It is also about pushing businesses towards the single market through aid. But we don't seem to see that SMEs are reluctant about this. As a result I voted against it.

name: Nuno Melo (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of the single market represents an important achievement, which has been made possible through cooperation and the sharing of a common objective, the removal of barriers to trade throughout the European Union. Tariff barriers have been successfully removed for almost fifty years, but it is the ongoing challenge of removing non-tariff barriers that currently motivates our single market initiatives. This reflects, in many ways, the latest innovations in international trade, where tariffs are more easily fought, but the removal of non-tariff barriers (BNP) is the ultimate goal. The deletion of BNP will help businesses across the EU, but the main beneficiaries will be consumers. Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I am in support of this report as the re-examination and removal of unjustifiable non-tariff barriers in hopes of moving towards a more consumer-friendly single market is essential to the Union’s economic development.

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: In writing. The Single Market is one of the EU's greatest achievements. However, even if tariff barriers have been eliminated, the non-tariff barriers encouraged by the protectionism of several bureaucracies are still present. These barriers, where they are not justified in terms of public order or the public good, must be removed, as they are obstacles to a functional market that serves all businesses, including SMEs and meets the needs of consumers.  We are not looking for harmonization of practices at all costs, but to boost mutual recognition. The Single Market could really be achieved through better cooperation between EMs and a faster and more uniform transposition of EU directives into internal law. As such, I further pinpoint the different VAT systems within the EU and the need to move towards concrete proposals to simplify VAT.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – Thanks to the common objective of the Member States of the European Union in removing barriers to trade, the single market has been created. Single market initiatives are currently motivated by the ongoing problem of removing non-tariff barriers. Few businesses or citizens seeking to engage in cross-border trade perceive the difference between the domestic single market and the environment outside the Union. Rather, it distinguishes between domestic and international trade, whether with a European country or a country outside the Union. This is because, although duties have been eliminated, the diversity of national regulations that a company seeking to trade cross-border or provide services in another Member State may encounter means that the situation cannot be too different from the different types of barriers that may be encountered in trade outside the Union. However, the principle of subsidiarity and respect for multi-level governance mean that there will always be some differences in national regulatory practice and public policy. This is really beneficial, as it allows countries to compete on the basis of different regulatory approaches. I believe that the Member States themselves can support a more competitive and open single market by working together and engaging in an intensified mutual assessment of how their national rules contribute to the single market. Removing non-tariff barriers to trade will not only help businesses across the Union, but, above all, consumers will benefit from it, and I therefore support the proposal.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which applies the external trade concept on non-tariff barriers inside the EU, looking at remaining obstacles to the completion of the single market as NTBs and calling for their removal. While insufficient or incorrect application of existing EU rules still hinders intra-EU trade and constitutes an obstacle to growth, a clear distinction has to be made between NTBs and other rules both at EU and Member States level that are lawfully in place and which serve a public policy objective.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The creation of the single market is a significant achievement. At the same time, although tariff barriers have been removed, undertakings wishing to enter into cross-border trade or service activities in another Member State may run into a number of national regulations. The persisting of non-tariff barriers therefore hinders the full exploitation of the potential of the single market. The report of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection points out that not all non-tariff barriers should be dismantled, but that there may be some which are contrary to the principles of proportionality and non-discrimination and which are not rooted in a public policy objective. Measures to improve the functioning of the single market should, according to the report, target these non-tariff barriers. The report emphasises the need for two main changes: better and consistent enforcement of existing rules and a change in member states' attitudes in order to move away from the application of increasingly protectionist measures and to fully open up their domestic markets. It underlines that removing non-tariff barriers will help businesses across the EU, but that consumers will be the main beneficiaries. It is therefore in the interest of all Member States and the European Parliament to continue to remove these non-tariff barriers across Europe in the interests of consumers.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. The creation of the single market has brought barriers to trade throughout the EU. Although tariff barriers have been removed for almost 50 years, today the challenge is to remove non-tariff barriers (BNP), which are due to the variety of national regulations that can be faced with a company seeking to trade across borders or provide services in another Member State, meaning that the situation on the ground can be the same as the types of barriers they may encounter when trading outside the EU. I endorse the rapporteur's position in recognition that not all BNP should be deleted. The principle of subsidiarity and respect for multi-level governance mean that there will always be a degree of national variation in regulatory practices and public policies. I am voting in favour of this report as, for the proper functioning of the single market, I advocate the elimination of NPBs which are contrary to the principles of proportionality or non-discrimination, or which are not based on a legitimate public policy objective. The deletion of BNP will help businesses across the EU, but mainly consumers, as they will benefit from lower prices and greater choice.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. This report is ridiculously and caricatured ultra-liberal. It is absolutely out of the question to endorse delusions that make this report, for example, say that the promotion of local products would be a hindrance to the single market. I'm voting against this report.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. This text on the removal of non-tariff barriers within the internal market stresses that the completion of the single market could bring Europe between EUR 650 and EUR 1100 billion in economic gains per year, while non-tariff barriers (e.g. technical standards or unjustified regulations) remain and hinder the free movement of goods and services between Member States.  The report believes that the time frames and methods of transposing directives from one Member To member States create legal uncertainty and distortions of competition for European companies. This is particularly true for France, which tends to self-legalise by overtransposing EU law.  It calls for a simplification of VAT at Community level, recognises the legitimacy of the regulation of public services that carry out missions of general interest, recognises the specificity of regulated professions and the need to guarantee them fair competition rules. I therefore voted in favour of this balanced report.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the persistence of unjustified non-tariff barriers in the single market, we are voting in favour of the Dalton report. A genuine completion of the single market, through structural reform which will ensure the elimination of the continuing fragmentation of individual economies and which, in particular, promotes regulatory harmonisation for trade in services, public procurement and the digital economy, would stimulate the European economy, including, in quantitative terms, between EUR 651 billion and EUR 1 100 billion, i.e. between EUR 5 billion and EUR 8 billion. ,36% of European GDP. The figures therefore point the way and the need for further integration of Community markets capable of stimulating economic recovery and, above all, employment levels, which are a source of great concern and represent a social scourge that cannot be underestimated. Small and medium-sized enterprises, the backbone of europe's socio-economic fabric, and industrial sectors aimed at the digital economy and innovation, the engine of technological development and an essential stimulus to research, are the sectors most exposed and weighed down by the persistence of non-tariff barriers. Without prejudice to the right of governments to legislate in the common interest, for example in the field of consumer protection or environmental protection, non-tariff barriers represent a serious discriminatory element.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the single market non-tariff barriers report. The report mentions the difficulties faced by businesses engaged in cross-border activities, who are still faced with obstacles due to differences and restrictions between Member States. These restrictions force undertakings to always change their products or services in such a way as to comply with multiple inspections and different standards. The report also highlights the problems faced by businesses providing services. It proposes an electronic registration system and better e-administration, which would make it possible, for example, to make authorisations and registrations more simple.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I have abstained in the vote on this report on non-tariff barriers in the single market.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Businesses and citizens face major obstacles to cross-border activities within the Single Market due to the lack of availability and quality of information, support services and online procedures, which lead to a considerable administrative burden and significant compliance costs. The monitoring of barriers and costs is fragmented and non-systematic and lacks clear quantification and identification of barriers and costs, making it difficult to prioritise measures. Member States should regard the Single Market as a common initiative, which must be maintained in a coordinated and collective manner and a condition for increasing the competitiveness of the EU economy.  Those who ultimately bear the consequences of unjustified non-tariff barriers are consumers, as new entities' access to domestic markets is denied and they face high costs, lower quality and a reduced choice.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this resolution because it stresses Member States protectionism regarding trade competition and lack of consistent enforcement of existing regulation as key obstacles, preventing the single market from becoming fully integrated. That is not to say that non-tariff barriers (NTBs) should be completely removed, as the resolution rightly states, however, it remains important to identify the cases in which NTBs are inflexible, discriminatory or work against the principles of proportionality. Indeed, removal of some NTBs would significantly benefit EU consumers who would have access to cheaper and greater variety of goods and services.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on non-tariff barriers in the single market, which highlights, inter alia, the complexity of VAT rules as one of the biggest non-tariff barriers. I believe that this obstacle could be removed by introducing a single VAT administration, which would also encourage SMEs to operate cross-border. It should be stressed that many national administrative procedures also lead to unjustified non-tariff barriers. I see the solution as a greater use of e-governance and in favour of interoperability and digital signatures, and in providing more extensive and accessible digital services to citizens and businesses, and facilitating cross-border cooperation and interoperability of public administrations. At the same time, however, the use of e-government should not exclude alternative ways of accessing information or disadvantage citizens who do not have access to digital services.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – This report raised concerns that the free movement of goods and services was being hampered by what are deemed as unjustified national technical rules and other regulatory and non-regulatory requirements. However, this is a mere masquerade as to what is a direct assault on a Member State’s autonomy. Each Member State should have the right to regulate their own economy and any further depletions of a national government’s economic competencies by the EU will be challenged by my party.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report highlights the main difficulties faced by companies or citizens involved in cross-border trade. The existence of too many different national provisions still presents a serious challenge for companies and individuals to participate in cross-border trade. Different countries introduce additional barriers to their market, which often discourage companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and they cease to expand.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. We are talking about non-tariff barriers. "Unjustified" national technical, legal or similar rules are intended to adversely affect the market. I believe that these restrictions are justified, but they should be abolished. Overall, the individual state is to lose its independence as a result.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. Member States should make greater efforts to promote a more competitive and open single market by cooperating and more peer reviews of how their national legislation supports the single market. Removing non-tariff barriers will help businesses across the EU and – thanks to lower prices and greater choice – consumers.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report. The effective functioning of the Single Market requires the removal of burdensome non-tariff barriers which run counter to the principles of proportionality and non-discrimination and are not in line with the country's public policy objectives. Removing customs duties and non-tariff barriers between EU Member States will enable businesses to make better use of their trade potential.  Particular attention must be paid to cross-border non-tariff barriers. In addition, in order to simplify procedures and reduce the administrative burden for service providers, further development of e-administration and electronic registration systems is needed.  It should be noted that not all non-tariff barriers need to be removed. The principles of subsidiarity and multi-level governance must be strictly respected. Member States must be empowered to apply measures which are proportionate and justified for legitimate public policy purposes.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. Whilst we agree that there are non-tariff barriers in the single market, we do not agree with the parliament approach to dealing with them. More specifically, we are against the further harmonisation of single market rules and we believe many future EU approaches to rectify could breach the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The removal of barriers to trade across the Eu ropean Union is the objective that Member States; Given that tariff barriers have been removed for a long time, some of the non-tariff barriers are a problem for the development of the single market. For example, the variety of national legislation in the Member States creates obstacles similar to those that would stand in the way if the legislation of a non-EU country were to be referred to. I believe that the economic loss resulting from the persistence of certain non-tariff barriers, with consequent repercussions for consumers, must be countered, so I support the rapporteur's proposal. I am voting in favour.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – I am a strong supporter of a free market economy, nevertheless I understand the importance of regulation in the European free market economy. I vote in favour of the regulation of non-tariff barriers in the single market to help improve our European Single Market. The report provides the definition, understanding the NTB as being a disproportionate or discriminatory regulatory action which results in a burden or cost to be borne by a firm which seeks to enter a market and which is not borne by firms already in the market, or a cost which accrues to non-national firms which is not borne by domestic firms. At the same time it recognises Member State’s right to regulate and to defend public policy objectives, while ensuring that regulatory measures are proportionate. This is vital for understanding the need for a better regulation of non-tariff barriers in the single market.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Unjustified non-tariff barriers continue to affect trade and the free movement of goods and services between Member States, although more than 20 years have already passed since the establishment of the single market. This needs to be changed and urgent action is needed at Union and Member State level to strengthen the single market and the competitiveness of the European market economy.  In my view, it is necessary to ensure easy access to information on differences in national regulatory conditions, while focusing on optimising and improving the current system. The Commission should establish a single access point through which businesses and consumers will be able to access all information related to the single market.  Cross-sectoral and sectoral non-tariff barriers are numerous, but solutions such as promoting a culture of compliance, paying greater attention to guidelines for the implementation of directives and improving the application of the principle of mutual recognition are outlined in the report and I support them. Non-tariff barriers need to be removed as soon as possible, and this report calls for this very thing, and therefore I supported its adoption.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The removal of the remaining obstacles to the completion of the single market is very important, given the stimulus to European economic growth that a fully achieved single market can bring about. The report extends the concept of 'non-tariff barriers', used for external trade, to the remaining obstacles restricting intra-European trade. Thanks to the work carried out by the S&D Group in the IMCO Committee, we have succeeded in achieving a balanced definition of 'non-tariff barriers' relating to the internal market. In fact, all the unjustified obstacles created by Member States to protect national companies from European competition fall into the category. However, the right of Member States to legislate in the name of the public interest and to adopt progressive legislation providing for greater protection in the case of minimum harmonisation directives is clearly recognised. Furthermore, the importance of public services and the fact that the relevant legislation does not constitute a non-tariff barrier are explicitly stated. If incorrect or incomplete application of existing European rules still restricts intra-European trade and constitutes an obstacle to growth, a clear distinction had to be made between non-tariff barriers and other rules, both European and Member States, which are entirely legitimate, because they serve the public interest.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒in 2012, the European Parliament considered that, despite the fact that tariff barriers were lifted on 1 July 1968, the free movement of goods and services continues to hamper non-tariff barriers such as unjustified national technical regulations and regulatory and non-regulatory requirements relating to products, service providers and conditions of service, or red tape.  He also pointed out that strengthening the single market requires urgent action at Union and Member State level to address such non-tariff barriers. He also stressed that differences in the speed of transposition and in the exact application of existing directives at national level lead to legal uncertainty for businesses and to an uneven playing field in the internal market. I agree with that report and underline the importance of the principle of mutual recognition in order to ensure that access to the single market is provided by goods that are not harmonised at Union level, as well as in cases where Member States have national rules on products that are very often different but which have the same basic objective.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. This is yet another report that continues to reflect on the Single Market and the absolute need to limit any restrictions that may still exist on the free movement of goods and services. It is not surprising, therefore, that it proposes: the end to non-tariff barriers; the openness and accessibility of Member States to their regulatory requirements, read deregulation, as a way of attracting foreign investment; deepening harmonisation, in particular in the digital single market, of existing regulations at national level of the Member States; deepening structural reforms in the context of the European semester, read the destruction of the social functions of the State, public services and privatisations;  In slight, the promotion of the attack on workers' rights, aggravating social inequalities, labor deregulation, wage devaluation and precarious work. From the foregoing, we voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ Non-tariff barriers are those "less visible" rules and regulations that in many respects hinder the trade of goods and services outside the national borders of one Member State. On the other hand, non-tariff barriers in the EU single market are assistance to economic operators, which appear in the form of lower prices and wider choice, which is a relevant achievement for Union citizens in domestic and foreign trade.  The complete removal of inappropriate non-tariff barriers remains a goal that still needs to be achieved because, although tariffs have been removed, they still remain a barrier in national legislation as the full potential of the market is not realised. Non-tariff barriers are contrary to the principles of proportionality, non-discrimination and are not based on legitimate public policy objectives.  However, respecting the rule of subsidiarity and multi-level management, such barriers should not be removed and preventive action is the most suboptimal. I supported Representative Dalton's report, as better and more consistent implementation of existing rules, a change in the attitude of Member States and the application of best practices can create better conditions in Member States' markets.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Despite the elimination of customs tariffs almost fifty years ago, the variety of national regulations faced by a company that intends to operate across borders poses obstacles that are not dissimilar to those that can be encountered when trading outside the EU. There are still non-tariff barriers preventing the full exploitation of the potential of the single market. For example, there are still non-tariff barriers that run counter to the principles of proportionality and non-discrimination or that are not based on a legitimate public policy objective. I therefore believe that better and more consistent application of existing rules and a change of mentality on the part of the Member States would serve to abandon protectionist measures and open up national markets more fully. For all this, I voted in favour.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report introduces an alternative trade-centred perspective on the development of the single market and its current status. encourages a look at the single market and national rules affecting cross-border trade through the lens of international trade. Its author sought to define cases where national rules can constitute a non-tariff barrier to internal trade within the EU. Member States may, for a number of reasons, want to introduce national rules in areas not covered by Union or international law or standards, but in order for those rules to comply with single market principles, they must be non-discriminatory and commensurate and be part of the pursuit of a legitimate public policy objective. The report identifies several sectors where this issue has been problematic in the past, including the application of the Services Directive and particularly poor experience in the retail sector. The conclusion of the report is that these non-tariff barriers constitute an obstacle to trade that cannot be justified and should therefore be prioritised by the Commission. The report calls for a report by the end of this year to address such existing barriers and calls on Member States and institutions to jointly commit to eliminating these obstacles to the smooth functioning of the single market. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. The single market, which is one of the strengths of the European Union, must evolve and not be subject to unjustified obstacles. I voted in favour of this report on non-tariff barriers to trade and trade, which include the often technical rules and requirements imposed at Member State level and which apply to suppliers of goods and services. Indeed, these obstacles are very clearly hampering the free movement of goods and services within the EU, which is a drag on growth. Where they are not justified, non-tariff barriers should simply no longer exist.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. The removal of barriers to trade and the creation of the European single market are an example of the success of EU action. Indeed, the single market has stimulated the competitiveness of European businesses, fostered joint demand and contributed to an increase in the consumer surplus through the general decline in prices. Despite the progressive suppression of tariff barriers, the elimination of non-tariff barriers is still an unfinished project today. The different national regulations and the technical requirements faced by an undertaking when it trades cross-border or services in another Member State constitute barriers to trade which, in practice, do not differ from the obstacles imposed outside the European economic area. Despite admitting a certain degree of discretion in regulatory practices and public policies carried out by Member States, the report rightly advocates a change of mentality towards a gradual departure from protectionist measures, often of a sectoral nature. The document also suggests the suppression of non-tariff barriers that contradict the principles of proportionality, non-discrimination and the pursuit of the public interest.  My vote is therefore in favour.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEP have voted against this non-legislative report. Whilst we agree that there are non-tariff barriers in the single market, we do not agree with the parliament approach to dealing with them. More specifically, we are against the further harmonisation of single market rules and we believe many future EU approaches to rectify could breach the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. I supported this resolution on non-tariff barriers in the single market. The single market is one of the pillars of European integration and is a source of growth and employment for the European economy. However, it still needs to be improved so that it has its full potential.  For example, in this case, the free movement of goods and services is still hampered by unjustified non-tariff barriers. They should therefore be lifted without undermining the ability of Member States to legislate and pursue legitimate public policy objectives.  To this end, it should be remembered, among other things, that Member States must effectively apply Eu legislation, that regulatory policies and practices must be consistent, or that information on the various regulatory requirements should be more accessible. In addition, we expect the Commission to present in 2016 a comprehensive overview of unjustified non-tariff barriers in the single market, as well as a proposal to remove them.  In the end, it is SMEs and micro-enterprises as well as consumers who are harmed by these unjustified non-tariff barriers.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 20 years after the creation of the single market, some non-tariff barriers (national technical rules and requirements for products and service providers) continue to hinder trade between Member States. This report analyses the barriers still face for companies operating cross-border and proposes measures to eliminate them, understanding that they can be an obstacle to the Single Market and growth. It is not advocated that all of them be removed, because the principle of subsidiarity and respect for the practice of multi-level governance must be safeguarded, as should the right to legislate in the public interest. However, there are such barriers that are contrary to the principles of proportionality and non-discrimination. These must be removed for the sake of the functioning of the single market, especially those with a more protectionist stance. Consumers will be the main beneficiaries of greater market opening.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. The creation of the single market is a significant achievement, made possible by cooperation and a common objective: the removal of barriers to trade across the EU. Tariff barriers were successfully removed nearly fifty years ago, but we faced the still-existing challenge of removing non-tariff barriers in our common market.  This initiative report, which I voted in favour of, calls for the removal of the remaining obstacles to the completion of the single market. While insufficient or incorrect application of existing EU rules still impedes trade within the EU and constitutes an obstacle to growth, a clear distinction must be made between non-tariff barriers and other rules, both at EU and national level, which are legitimately in place and serve public interest objectives. Moreover, thanks to the socialist group, a balanced reference to the so-called 'overregulation' has been introduced, which does not affect the right to legitimately adopt advanced legislation in the case of minimum harmonisation directives, and an explicit mention of the importance of public services whose regulation does not constitute a non-tariff barrier.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. The package of proposals for a digital single market, presented by the European Commission, was welcomed by the European Parliament. Overall, we welcomed the Commission's proposals. These measures will enable the construction of a Europe that is a pioneer in the digital revolution but also, for example, will require more transparency in the parcel delivery market so that EU nationals can truly deal with a European internal market. After presenting the Commission's initiatives to make it easier for consumers and businesses to buy and sell products and services online across the EU, Digital Single Market Commissioner Andrus Ansip said these "necessary" measures were truly paving the way for the digital single market. In response to our comments, he was aware that the final outcome of the legislative process would necessarily be a "compromise". Nevertheless, he said that cooperation with the EP would be "fruitful". To follow!

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Virtual currencies are still a new financial instrument and a technological phenomenon and already, in addition to their potential impact on the global economy, deserve separate attention.  They reduce the payment costs associated with the conclusion of transactions and transactions by a quarter or even a seventh and may result in payments of up to EUR 20 billion. The economic impact of the euro on a global scale, it increases the resilience and speed of payment systems and trade in goods and services, increases security while opening up space for a new type of abuse and illegal operations.  I am therefore convinced that the area of virtual currencies deserves careful supervision, but one that promotes the development of this highly competitive area, rather than hampering this opportunity to increase Europe's global competitiveness. In this respect, the technologies of the diffused book of operations, although developed by non-state actors, remain an area that must be carefully monitored by the responsible authorities, discussed in the political control bodies, such as the European Parliament, successfully integrated into everyday life and used to increase competitiveness.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Even though since 1968 we do not have any tariff barriers on the EU’s Single Market, the functioning of a truly single market is hampered by non-tariff barriers such as excessive national regulations, various additional requirements that are imposed on trade by Member States or bureaucracy. Non-tariff barriers strongly affect the free movement of goods, services and people, which is supposed to be the backbone of the European project. This report, for which I was a shadow rapporteur on behalf of the EPP Group, defines, identifies and addresses a variety of NTBs, while also emphasising that the EU should not hesitate anymore to eliminate disproportionate and discriminatory barriers, which are often motivated by protectionism. The EU single market bears a huge potential, which we should use to the highest level, especially in the situation when the economic growth is weak. Member States have to stop thinking in a protectionist manner and open their markets to products and services from other Member States, fulfilling the idea of a truly competitive single market. Therefore, I call on the Commission to draw on this report while preparing legislative proposals on eliminating non-tariff barriers in the single market.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The removal of tariff barriers, successfully removed in 1968, 18 months earlier than provided for in the Treaty of Rome, represents one of the main achievements of the European Union (then EEC). Currently, the main challenge in the single market is the removal of non-tariff barriers in intra-Community trade and their articulation with the protection of the internal market. This report rightly draws attention to some of the non-tariff barriers, particularly technical barriers, to trade in the internal market. I endorse the rapporteur's position on the need to improve some of the measures for non-use of non-tariff barriers, so that the single market can effectively function and realise its full potential- as mentioned in the recently adopted Single Market Strategy. What is wanted is an increasingly open and competitive single market and, to do so, member states need to avoid adopting protectionist measures and to remove some of the current non-tariff barriers in order to give greater benefits to businesses and, above all, to consumers, who will naturally benefit from a greater choice of goods and services at a lower price. For the reasons expressed above, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which points out that more than 20 years after the opening of the single market, unjustified non-tariff barriers continue to weigh on trade and on the free movement of goods and services between Member States. There is an urgent need for action at both Member States and EU level to permanently remove these non-tariff barriers, as long as they cannot be justified.  To do this, information on discrepancies in national regulatory requirements should be readily available, thanks to a simplification and improvement of the current system. As such, the initiative of a single digital portal should be underlined and also called for the establishment of a single point of access for businesses and consumers to all information relating to the single market.  I supported this text because it calls on the Commission to use guidelines and to further encourage a culture of compliance. To this end, the report calls on the Commission to identify non-tariff barriers in the single market in 2016 so that they can be permanently eliminated and the untapped potential of the single market is unleashed.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report presented deals with a particularly important point concerning the effective implementation of the single market, namely the so-called 'non-tariff barriers'. The compromise reached with the text of this report satisfies the PPE's intention to present the Commission with a strong and ambitious opinion on this issue. Of particular importance is the presentation of a clear definition of these non-tariff barriers: this term includes those rules which involve additional costs or disadvantages for companies entering the single market compared to those already operating there, and at the same time indicates the rules in force in the Member States which imply disadvantages for foreign players within the single market compared to national players. Together with the GROUP of the European People's Party, I voted in favour of the compromise reached in this own-initiative report, the aim of which is to call on the Commission to apply the rules that make up the single market clearly and uniformly so as to promote its full implementation.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted to abstain in this Report on Non-Tariff Barriers in the Internal Market, as it proposes balanced and protective elements, together with a number of other problematic elements that encourage the removal of barriers, to improve competition and enable companies to expand what, from their perspective, creates economic growth. It considers over-regulation problematic, and urges the Commission to ensure the full implementation of EU single market legislation and to ensure structural reforms in the Member States. The report also contains a number of balanced and rights-protection measures. This is why we propose to abstain in the final vote.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 Despite the fact that back in 1968 we removed the tariff barrier in the EU, we continue to see that trade in goods and services is hampered by non-tariff barriers such as unnecessary red tape or unjustified national technical requirements for products and/or delivery. If we want to strengthen the internal market, we need to remove these barriers. However, it is essential that we have a clear definition of what non-tariff barriers cover, so that it does not include, for example, labour rights, environmental protection and consumer rights. However, the proposal takes account of why I support the proposal.

name: Sven Schulze (PPE)
text: Writing. I voted in favour of the report as it is important to identify existing non-tariff barriers (NTH) across the EU. These include, for example, national technical rules and requirements for suppliers of products and services which, despite the removal of tariff barriers in 1986, still affect the genuine free movement of goods and services within the EU.

name: Olga Sehnalová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The purpose of this resolution is to identify non-tariff barriers that hinder the full development of the internal market. However, in the context of the ongoing debate on so-called better regulation, I consider it very important to make a consistent distinction between efforts to eliminate unfounded or discriminatory regulatory measures for society and between efforts to reduce the level of consumer or employment rights by watering down existing rules. I therefore welcome the fact that the contribution of the Social Democrats to the resolutions does not affect in any way the right of Member States to regulate and pursue legitimate public policy objectives that aim precisely at protecting consumers, workers or the environment. I am also very happy that I have managed to include in the resolution a provision that, although the general use of e-government, especially for businesses, is seen as an important tool, e-governance cannot exclude alternative ways of accessing information or disadvantage citizens who do not have access to digital services.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report makes a very strong commitment to the liberalization of services and trade to the Single Market, even suggesting that both sectors are 'overregulated'. Our view is that the European Single Market agenda, based on deregulation and sharpening of competition (with the promotion of forced mobility and double standards for digital services) favours commercial oligopolies and exacerbates social dumping in sectors such as transport. That's why I voted against it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 It is estimated that the completion of the single market for the free movement of goods, services, public procurement, the digital economy could bring economic benefits of between EUR 651 billion and EUR 1 100 billion per year, which is equivalent to between 5 and 8.63% of the European Union's GDP. I therefore voted in favour of removing non-tariff barriers (embargoes, import quotas, quantitative restrictions, licences) in the light of the important economic benefits not only for businesses but also for citizens themselves.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEP’s have voted against this non-legislative report. Whilst the fact of the matter is that there are non-tariff barriers in the Single Market, we do not agree with the parliament approach to dealing with them. In particular, we are against the further harmonisation of Single Market rules and we believe many future EU approaches to rectify issues will breach the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Czesław Adam Siekierski (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The persistence of non-tariff barriers to trade in goods in the EU single market is a situation that many economic operators still have to deal with. On the one hand, the EU is seeking to fully implement fundamental freedoms for the movement of people, goods, capital and services, and on the other hand, it is with concern that there are numerous cases of increasing non-tariff barriers in the internal market – including for food exporters – imposed by individual EU member states. Such practices are often discriminatory and undermine the import competitiveness of food in the EU internal market, with a negative impact on the EU economy. This situation could directly lead to a reduction in cross-border trade in foodstuffs in the EU internal market and have a negative impact on the functioning of SMEs in the internal market. In this situation, it is necessary for Member States to take action to control and guarantee fair trading conditions, which is in the interest of both producers and consumers. To this end, consideration should be given to different types of actions that could ensure the transparent and fair functioning of the internal market, particularly as regards food products produced by one of the EU's strategic sectors, agriculture.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I am very pleased with how this report developed in committee. We were able to achieve a clear recognition of the full respect of the right to regulate in the interest of the public and have the report contain explicit mentions of the importance of public services and the fact that related legislation does not constitute a non-tariff barrier. The main challenge of this report was to get a definition for non-tariff barriers that all sides could agree on, and I am happy that we have gone some way in achieving that.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union's greatest achievement is the single market. It is an area without internal borders which, in principle, ensures the free movement of goods, persons, services and capital. In order for this market to function, the persistent problem of removing those non-tariff barriers that are contrary to the principles of proportionality and non-discrimination or not based on one of the legitimate objectives of public policy still needs to be resolved. The completion of the single market benefits some businesses (most competitive and innovative) and the consumer in the form of lower prices and more choice. I voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Despite the fact that almost fifty years ago we removed tariff barriers (NPO) to help the free movement of goods and services, we continue to see persistent problems hampering trade in the single market across the EU. It regrets that, even after all these years, we are faced with unjustified national technical regulations, regulatory and non-regulatory requirements for products, and, many times, with unnecessary bureaucracy preventing access to new entrants in domestic markets. I supported the resolution because I believe that, thanks to the proposed measures, we will be able to strengthen the single market and eliminate THEO at both EU and Member State level. I also supported the report because the different application of the same rules in different Member States often leads to the creation of additional THAs, which I do not think is right. In the interests of the consumers most affected by the IPO, I expect the Report to make it much more consistent and effective in identifying and resolving problems that will require priority solutions not only from one member state but also from several Member States.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The creation of a single market is seen as an important achievement made possible by cooperation and the pursuit of a common objective, that is to eliminate trade barriers throughout the European Union. Tariff barriers were successfully removed almost 50 years ago, while our current single market initiatives are created by the persistent challenge of eliminating non-tariff barriers. The report addresses barriers to trade and the free movement of services and goods within the single market and any measures to remove them. Unfortunately, the report does not help to improve the definition of non-tariff barriers, but merely reflects the provisions of the Treaties and judgments of the Court of Justice of the European Union. Furthermore, the report does not prioritise harmonisation, but rather the mutual recognition of services and goods, which carries the risk of re-applying the country of origin principle to the services sector. What is more, the report remains focused on the exclusion of the requirements of the Member States, which it presents as divisive and unjustified restrictions. The report is in line with the deregulation approach of the Better Regulation Agenda, calling for an 'ex ante' of member states' arguments when introducing new regulatory measures.  On the basis of these reasons, the report does not reflect my requirements on non-tariff barriers, which is why I did not support it at the meeting and voted against it.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. \u2012 Completing the single market for the free movement of goods and services, public procurement, the digital economy and consumer legislation would bring significant economic gains to the European Union. Unjustified non-tariff barriers can greatly affect trade and the free movement of goods and services between Member States and may be the result of protectionism.  Unfortunately, there are a number of provisions in Union legislation that adversely affect the proper functioning of the single market, thereby reducing the potential profits from a functioning single market. Likewise, single market vulnerabilities, such as the incomplete implementation of European Union legislation and implementation contrary to the objectives of the single market, often lead to poorer choice of products or more expensive goods and services for consumers.  I support the report on non-tariff barriers in the single market, as I think it is essential that single market strategies for Europe include initiatives that need to be implemented swiftly, efficiently and ambitiously to reduce non-tariff barriers in the single market.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒Unjustified tariff barriers continue to affect trade and the free movement of goods and services between Member States. The controls imposed on foreign service providers lately are increasingly intense and numerous. Member States must ensure that such controls are proportionate, justified and non-discriminatory.  It is estimated that completing the Single European Market for the free movement of goods and services, public procurement and the digital economy would bring profits of up to a billion euros per year, amounting to around 8 % of the GDP of the European Union. Strengthening the single market requires urgent action at EU and Member State level, in particular in removing non-tariff barriers that cannot be justified. It is also necessary to establish a single access point through which businesses and consumers will be able to access all information related to the single market, as well as all the necessary data for cross-border operations in the European Union. I support the recommendations set out in this report, as I believe that by completing the European Single Market, everyone, the European Union, the Member States, but also the citizens themselves can benefit. The Single Market is a joint initiative that requires coordinated and joint maintenance, making a significant contribution to European economies.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on non-tariff barriers in the single market. We have been talking about the European single market for some time, and we have already adopted some important reports, and we all agree that it is much more necessary, because it contributes to the European economy. As the report notes, the completion of the single market in the area of free movement of goods, services, public procurement, the digital economy and most consumer protection legislation would bring economic benefits of up to EUR 1.1 billion per year, which is also 8.63% of the EUROPEAN Union's GDP. We need the removal of non-tariff barriers, which include unjustified national technical regulations and regulatory or non-regulatory conditions applicable to product suppliers.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report calls for the complete deletion of tariff barriers to strengthening and completing the single market. In addition to the concerns we have with the policies and objectives of the single market, we must also recognise that certain tariff barriers are particularly important. Typical examples are the barriers to consumer protection, which in some Member States are stricter.  Barriers to genetically modified products are also important. We have therefore voted against the report as we disagree with the general context in which tariff barriers are managed and with the objectives of deleting tariff barriers in the single market. We also voted against because we consider it important to respect the specificities of the Member States which lead to the formation of certain barriers.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We vote against, non-tariff barriers are the last obstacle and line of defence against a single market, which serves nothing but large capital and multinationals.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of this report because it has produced a sufficiently critical edge and may make European decision-makers realise that governments serving the interests of producers with great economic and political influence are in the way of removing non-tariff barriers that still restrict the single market too much. In my experience, some governments often see the arbitrary use of non-tariff barriers as a kind of political-tactical tool. Of course, as the report points out, practical aspects and the principle of subsidiarity require that the use of non-tariff instruments be possible in justified cases, timeframes and places in the future. However, in my opinion, the primary concern of this is the interests of local small and medium-sized enterprises and consumers throughout the EU, including promoting healthy quality and price competition. The decades-long backlog in the implementation of the single market in limiting non-tariff barriers can only be filled by a well-supported approach to trade policy from the social and political side, which the report can be a useful point in developing, both for Parliament and for national governments.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 There are still many non-tariff barriers in the EU single market, and instead of decreasing, the number of barriers continues to increase in many respects, hampering the free movement of goods and services between countries. Additional technical regulations, product or service requirements, lack of mutual recognition of qualifications or bureaucracy are just some of the protectionist methods used for producers and service providers outside the country concerned not applied to home-based enterprises.  Parliament's report defines and identifies various non-tariff barriers, stressing that the EU and the Member States have a duty to eliminate them. More important than the creation of new rules is the due implementation of existing ones and the faster response of the European Commission when new national restrictions are introduced. It must be borne in mind that the EU Single Market has great potential that needs to be fully exploited, especially in a context of unstable economic growth and a decline in Europe's importance in world trade. EU countries must stop thinking protectionistly as soon as possible and open up their markets to other players. Only then will we be able to exploit the full potential of the common market.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Non-tariff barriers are measures for free trade, consisting of instruments such as licences, quotas, standards and other administrative and bureaucratic measures designed to regulate flows in accordance with the interests of an economic actor. The achievement of the European Union's single market has led to the removal of tariff barriers between Member States, but non-tariff barriers continue to represent important obstacles to intra-Community trade flows. This state of affairs affects economic growth and the interests of European consumers. At the same time, however, it is true that a number of barriers of this kind derive from the very principle of subsidiarity, which allows regulation at various levels, including national and local, through public policies and in the public interest. Some of these regulations may form temporary non-tariff barriers in an attempt to protect the interests of citizens in certain Member States. Respect for employee rights cannot be included in the category of non-tariff barriers. However, they must not be transformed into protectionist measures that oppose the concept of the single market. Member States must work together to gradually harmonise their practices, as far as possible, in order to ensure the prosperity of citizens.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I followed our emissary on this text. I am aware that, despite the abolition of tariff barriers on 1 July 1968, the free movement of goods and services has continued to be hampered by non-tariff barriers, such as technical standards and regulatory or non-regulatory requirements which, at the national level, unjustifiably apply to products, service providers or service contracts. , or through bureaucracy. Strengthening the single market requires urgent action at both EU and Member State levels to remove these non-tariff barriers.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ More than 20 years after first launching the single market, trade and free movement of goods and services between states in Europe, there are still numerous non-tariff barriers (NTBs) that hamper both consumers and business, particularly SMEs and start-ups. NTBs include heavy compliance costs between Member States, unjustified national technical rules or unnecessary administrative requirements. I voted in favour of the resolution, which will look into ways to identify and remove the NTBs that are not justified, and make sure that, in cases where NTBs are justified, information on differing requirements is clear, accessible and user-friendly. I am confident that by ensuring a more uniform regulatory environment, making full use of digitisation, and guaranteeing mutual recognition where harmonisation is not possible, we can unleash the full potential of the single market and boost Europe’s competitiveness.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR)
text: Written. ‒ I supported the report on non-carine barriers in the single market, as I believe it will facilitate the movement of goods and public procurement within the European Union and thus contribute to the development of the European economy. Non-tariff barriers are discriminatory regulatory measures that result in more burdens and costs for companies looking to enter the market rather than burdening companies already present on the market.  As a result of such discriminatory rules, I believe that the Commission should remove non-tariff barriers as soon as possible. While it is necessary for Member States to create rules that are not subject to European or international standards, these rules must comply with the principles of the single market. This will create a clear and uniform regulatory environment that enables market development, protects workers and consumers and provides a favourable environment for existing and new companies on the European market.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the proposal on non-tariff barriers in the single market, as the creation of the single market is considered an important achievement made possible by the removal of trade barriers within the European Union. A Single Market Strategy has recently been adopted, highlighting a number of measures to strengthen and deepen the single market. The removal of non-tariff barriers will certainly help businesses across the EU, with consumers benefiting the most. The latter argument is based on studies prepared by the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection and states that the completion of the single market benefits the most competitive and innovative companies and, because of lower prices and greater choice, it benefits all consumers. It is therefore in the interest of the European Parliament and its Members to continue our efforts to remove non-tariff barriers, as this will benefit all consumers.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted to abstain in this Report on Non-Tariff Barriers in the Internal Market, as it proposes balanced and protective elements, together with a number of other problematic elements that encourage the removal of barriers, to improve competition and enable companies to expand what, from their perspective, creates economic growth. It considers over-regulation problematic, and urges the Commission to ensure the full implementation of EU single market legislation and to ensure structural reforms in the Member States. The report also contains a number of balanced and rights-protection measures. This is why we propose to abstain in the final vote.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. Report proposing some interesting points in terms of administrative relief for businesses and economic freedoms, but it remains parasitized by a highly offensive European zeal. It calls for full and definitive integration of the single market and maximum liberalisation of all sectors of activity by forcing the abolition of non-tariff, administrative (effective) administrative barriers used by Member States to protect particular economic sectors.  The report ignores national concerns and peculiarities and disregards the sovereignity of certain protective decisions. Intelligent protectionism is put to the fine here.  So I'm voting against it.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report points out that more than 20 years after the introduction of the single market, unjustified non-tariff barriers continue to create difficulties in trade and free movement of goods and services between Member States. The maintenance of these non-tariff barriers may result from protectionism and may result in bureaucratic burdens which are very often disproportionate to the objectives to be achieved. With my vote, I followed S&D's position.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted to abstain in this Report on Non-Tariff Barriers in the Internal Market, as it proposes balanced and protective elements, together with a number of other problematic elements that encourage the removal of barriers, to improve competition and enable companies to expand what, from their perspective, creates economic growth. It considers over-regulation problematic, and urges the Commission to ensure the full implementation of EU single market legislation and to ensure structural reforms in the Member States. The report also contains a number of balanced and rights-protection measures. This is why we propose to abstain in the final vote.

name: Ernest Urtasun (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which reflected a vision based on the a priori idea that Member States’ regulatory measures consist mainly of protectionist obstacles preventing cross-border trade, hence having to be urgently eliminated. The Greens tabled amendments to underline that regulations which pursue a legitimate public policy goal, such as consumer protection, should not be seen as non-tariff barriers. We also wanted to highlight that upwards harmonisation is preferable to mutual recognition, that public services should be protected from competition and internal market rules, that the rules of the country of destination should prevail as regards the exercise of free movement of services and that the lack of fiscal coordination also represents a non-tariff barrier because it prevents firms from competing on a level-playing field.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I welcome the peer review carried out over the last two years; believe that well-designed and open peer review processes that encourage discussions between Member States can be effective in promoting change; I encourage the Member States and the Commission to extend this practice, in particular to other areas of single market regulation.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on non-tariff barriers in the single market. The free movement of goods and services has continued to be hampered by NTBs (non-tariff barriers) such as unjustified national technical rules or bureaucracy. The report calls for the urgent action at both Union and Member State levels to address such NTBs and to strengthen the single market. The report equally underlines that the Digital Single Market Strategy and the Single Market Strategy for Europe comprise initiatives that should be implemented swiftly and ambitiously in order to reduce single market NTBs.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. We are talking about a report confirming the need to abolish non-tariff barriers in the European single market, which today prevent a more effective functioning in the movement of EU goods and services. Our great strength lies in our market, so it is always necessary and positive to take measures that help its best functioning. That is why I consider it necessary to vote in his favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. – My colleagues in the Labour Party and I voted in favour of this report because it realises that despite the removal of tariff barriers (NTBs) since 1 July 1968, the free movement of goods and services has continued to be hampered by NTBs such as unjustified national technical rules and regulatory and non-regulatory requirements governing products. It also highlights that the strengthening of the single market requires urgent action at both the EU and Member State levels to address such NTBs.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I voted in favour of this resolution because SMEs are still too often hampered by various national laws to be able to easily invest or work in another EU country. They cannot grow like this and the European single market is not perfect.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. It is a "funny" report that was presented to us regarding the so-called "non-tariff barriers" that would deprive the single market of some of its potential.  These so-called obstacles include all the norms and legislation protecting employees and consumers, the very ones that are at the heart of the TAFTA negotiations in particular. Even better, the rapporteur believes that this deregulation would not have an impact on the rights of employees if they were not "discriminatory and disproportionate". And of course it proposes to deregulate the digital single market a little more, which I have already strongly opposed.  It is also recommended that regulated professions and the banking sector be deregulated. We know the song and we see the negative effects of these policies every day, but nothing helps. The proponents of unbridled liberalism continue to flee forward.  So of course I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 We accept as valid the principle that prices cannot be compared without taking into account the specific conditions under which production takes place. What we do not accept is that this principle serves to level the playing point, often achieved through the harsh struggles of populations and workers. We also do not accept that this principle prevents national states from establishing standards to enhance local and regional production. Non-tariff barriers are the spearhead of those who want to impose free trade by force and without looking at the specificities of countries and regions and often without looking at their own history. In this sense, we see with many reservations any attempt to establish objectives of reducing these so-called non-tariff barriers, getting everything in the same bag and earthing the local and cultural specificities.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This report deals with non-tariff barriers. It is argued here that "unjustified" national technical, legal or similar provisions are particularly negatively affected. These should be abolished or thinned out, but without seriously considering that those rules are justified. This means nothing more than an attempt to pursue a centralised dictatorial economic policy in the future, beyond the interests of individual member states.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I abstained on the European Parliament's resolution on non-tariff barriers to trade in the internal market. The report includes light and shadow. It is good that it emphasises the importance of the principle of mutual recognition for access to the internal market for goods that are not harmonised at Union level. The report also draws attention to the tendency of the Commission and the Member States to burden directives transposed in the implementation of Union law with additional rules. Less regulation and more choice benefit consumers. However, the report's responses to the challenge posed by non-tariff barriers are partly dubious. In particular, the most obvious answer is missing: the Commission has only one way of removing barriers to trade by harmonising products through EU law. However, the EU must be asked to abandon this instrument. Regulatory egalitarianism is not an appropriate way to remove barriers to trade.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – The report on non-tariff barriers in the single market shows that, despite the removal of tariff barriers on 1 July 1968, the free movement of goods and services in the single market continued to be affected by non-tariff barriers, such as technical rules and regulatory and non-national regulatory requirements applicable to suppliers of products , service providers and conditions of service or bureaucracy. I voted for this report which considers non-tariff barriers to be a disproportionate or discriminatory regulatory action, especially for new firms that want to enter the single market. The rapporteur stresses that, in particular, the lack of implementation and divergent application of the Services Directive constitute obstacles to the Single Market and calls on the Commission to remove them.

name: Pablo Zalba Bidegain (PPE)
text: in writing. I am in favour of this report, as I believe that it is necessary to put an end to all the barriers and obstacles that prevent the creation of a true digital single market. The end of these will mean improving the EU economy as a whole and enhancing innovation, while companies will have no impediments in entering to compete in other Member States, where they will be able to expand their knowledge and acquire new intellectual capital. On the other hand, the supply of digital services will clearly improve for all Europeans, as it will not vary from one Member State to another. I am confident that with effort and coordinated work among all EU members we will achieve a prosperous and perfectly integrated Digital Single Market, which will help ensure that economic recovery is a reality in the European Union.

name: Marco Zanni (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report we have voted on today addresses the issue of non-tariff barriers within the Union. Non-tariff barriers are embargoes, import quotas, licences, quantitative restrictions, technical barriers and standards which make it difficult and particularly expensive for foreign producers to transpose or comply with national rules. But on the other hand they also represent rules and laws that protect employment, health and the environment within individual states. A set of safeguards that is being strongly discussed by the negotiations with the United States on the transatlantic partnership. I therefore found it difficult to support a report which aims to remove non-tariff barriers, despite the fact that the principles set out by the rapporteur are balanced and to a large extent acceptable. The draft report calls on the Commission to present a complete picture of non-tariff barriers in the single market, taking into account the difference between a non-tariff barrier and a legitimate public policy objective by a Member State. This is a welcome request, but there is still fundamental doubt as to who will assess the legitimacy of a Member State's public policy objective. Perhaps the same Commission which is negotiating the removal of non-tariff barriers with the United States under the TTIP.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I support the European Parliament's report, as the creation of the single market is a significant acquisition achieved only through cooperation to remove trade barriers throughout the European Union. I believe that, just as customs barriers have been removed, non-tariff barriers should also be removed. Removing non-tariff barriers will help EU businesses, but consumers will benefit most from removing these barriers. I believe that two main steps need to be taken. Better and more consistent enforcement of existing rules, as well as a change in the mindset of Member States, which would lead to a shift away from increasingly used protectionist measures and a more fully-fledged opening up of domestic markets.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 Trying to negate the fundamental principles on which the European Union is founded is a dangerous trend that we are increasingly facing. These fundamental principles are not, as the European Commission would like very often, abstract political values, but economic freedoms that make it possible for all Member States to benefit from the common market on an equal footing.  Unfortunately, we are now faced with a situation where these freedoms are restricted and limited by the internal legislation of the Member States, which is contrary to European law. Of course, in justified cases, such regulation of the free movement of goods and services is necessary and justified, but must then be proportionate to the objective set, non-discriminatory to entities from different countries with the same business profile and have a clear objective of protecting the public good. An example that illustrates this problem well is the minimum wage regulations introduced by the Government of the Federal Republic of Germany, which lead to unjustified discrimination against Polish transport companies. Despite a clear breach of the rules on the functioning of the single market, these rules are still in force and the European Commission is delaying the decision. Such cases should be investigated and clarified quickly in order not to encourage other Member States to do the same. I believe that the EC should do much more and enforce the economic freedoms of the EU more effectively.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Dalton report because I believe that the proposals put forward are crucial to tackling the remaining obstacles within the EU in the non-tariff field, i.e. disproportionate and discriminatory regulatory measures with negative consequences in the single market.  Within the various recommendations made to reduce the negative impact of non-tariff measures, I would like to point out the Single Digital Portal initiative and the call on the Commission to set up a one-stop shop for businesses and consumers that deal with aspects related to the single market, such as the provision of information and assistance, problem-solving and national and European procedures needed to carry out cross-border operations in the European Union.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The report addresses the issue of non-tariff barriers within the European Union. Non-tariff barriers are embargoes, import quotas, licences, quantitative restrictions, technical barriers and standards which make it difficult and particularly expensive for foreign producers to transpose or comply with national rules. On the other hand, they also represent rules and laws that protect employment, health and the environment within individual states. A set of safeguards which, among other things, is being strongly discussed by the negotiations with the United States on the transatlantic partnership.
