The draft report calls on the European Commission to present a complete picture of non-tariff barriers in the single market taking into account the difference between a non-tariff barrier and a legitimate public policy objective by a Member State. I agree with this request, but there is still a major doubt: who will assess whether a Member State's public policy objective is legitimate? The European Commission itself, which is negotiating the removal of non-tariff barriers with the United States under TTIP?  In view of the dangers of removing certain non-tariff barriers, I voted against the report.

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on non-tariff barriers in the single market. Non-tariff barriers continue to hamper the free functioning of the internal market. The completion of the single market, estimated in the report, would bring economic benefits of between EUR 651 billion and EUR 1.1 trillion per year.  I agree that the essential measures to strengthen and deepen the single market are more consistent enforcement of existing rules and a change in the thinking of the Member States, which must move away from increasingly protectionist measures and to open up domestic markets more to a greater extent.

name: Isabella Adinolfi (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 As part of the reforms for the European single market, we have reached a compromise with regard to the so-called sharing economy, which will ensure that the Commission coordinates the action of the various Member States on an issue that is essential for the future of our economies. In addition, to protect the geographical indications of the products, specific regulations have been inserted to protect Made in also for non-agri-food products. For these reasons, I voted in favour of the proposal.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which contained some very regressive and negative provisions. It is an alarming report which promotes austerity policies in addition to further transfers of sovereignty from National Parliaments to the European Union. The view of my party Sinn Féin is that the solution to the ongoing economic and financial crisis is not to continue with the same policies that have created this crisis, but a policy that puts the needs of people first and not those of the market. The Single Market Strategy promotes a neo liberal strategy, which endorses austerity policies. The austerity measures being applied by undemocratic means in the EU countries worst hit by the crisis reflect the failure of the EU’s neoliberal architecture. Sinn Féin are working in Europe to urgently reverse this policy and deliver solidarity and job creation within an economic system that serves people not profit. The single market and competitiveness have been used as arguments to justify attacks on workers’ rights, social inequalities, labour deregulation, wage devaluation and increasingly precarious employment, while fairer, more redistributive tax policies have been obstructed. Austerity is avoidable; it is a political choice that puts the interests of some above the interests of others.

name: Νίκος Ανδρουλάκης (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 This report is the response to the European Commission's Single Market Strategy implemented last year. The Group of the Party of Socialists and Democrats of the European Parliament is in favour of a more holistic vision for the single market based on the green, knowledge-based social market economy, which will improve the well-being of European citizens by proposing practical measures aimed at ensuring equal treatment and social inclusion, the creation of sustainable jobs and growth and high-quality consumer protection.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu (ENF)
text: In writing. This report provides interesting insights into the future, such as the collaborative economy or improving access to finance for SMEs and artisans. Unfortunately, no self-criticism; denial of the balance sheet.  The rapporteur manages to reconcile in a nice trick the intensification of the fight against all kinds of protectionism, the total implementation of the so-called "services" directive (catastrophic for businesses), that on the secondment of workers (destructive of jobs) and the protection of craftsmen and SMEs. Two irreconcilable goals. I obviously voted against this report.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report because I do not believe that further harmonisation of legislation is either necessary or desirable. I wish to highlight my abstention on the original text of paragraph 106, which praises the principle of equal pay for equal work. I support that principle, of course. I do not support the addition of the text ‘as advocated by Juncker’ (why single out the political views of any individual in a Parliamentary report?), nor is it an important tool with which to fight market distortions; it is, in fact, an important tool with which to fight discrimination. So whilst supporting the sentiment of that paragraph, I cannot vote for the text as written.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP fundamentally disagrees with the report, which criticises Member States for not transposing EU legislation. Moreover, we also strongly disagree with calls for further harmonisation and legislative proposals from the Commission. UKIP believes that the main problem with the single market is over-regulation, which damages SMEs causing higher prices and less choice for the consumer.

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. This report, which I approved, reminds us that the single market can be deepened with the aim of making gains in sustainable growth, job creation, research and the environment. This requires further harmonization of legislation. Reducing administrative and compliance costs for businesses, especially SMEs, must also contribute to this. A simplification of legislation as well, but while guaranteeing high standards in terms of consumer, employee, health and environmental protection.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE)
text: Written. The Single Market is a crucial driver of growth and job creation in Europe. We therefore support the European Commission's strategy to deepen that cornerstone of EU integration, but we are convinced that this cannot be separated from the pursuit of a fairer market.  Social dumping not only erodes our social achievements, but also makes it difficult for honest businesses to compete.  It is therefore essential that every worker is entitled to equal pay for equal work in the same workplace, and has access to the highest protection in terms of safety and health at work.  European Commissioner Marianne Thyssen has made a strong case for modernising this legislation, closing loopholes and equalising the working conditions for posted workers to local workers. We fully support this proposal in the European Parliament.

name: Brando Benifei (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market, a central element of European integration, is a constant economic challenge; a great opportunity especially in a global context strongly focused on the development of new technologies. My vote in favour of the Comi report is based on the common sharing of the opportunities and challenges associated with its implementation. The text presented supports the strategy proposed by the Commission, recognising its potential in terms of increasing competitiveness, increasing prosperity and employment. Particular attention is paid to SMEs and start-ups, the backbone of the continent's economy, which the Commission is asked to support without lowering the level of rules on the protection of workers and consumers. Reducing administrative burdens and adjustment costs, simplifying legislation and coordinating taxation within the Union, especially in the area of VAT, are the measures to be taken in order to move in the right direction.  Only with these measures will it be possible to achieve the single market and create a genuine, highly competitive social market economy based on sustainable growth and consumer protection.

name: Xabier Benito Ziluaga (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Report on the strategy for the single market, since our position on competitiveness in the context of an internal market economy is totally contrary to the ideas set out in the report. On the one hand, it points to some serious problems relating to SMEs and start-ups, but the focus is on improving the single market by increasing competition and eliminating the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this Report on the Strategy for the Single Market, which is in need of removing unjustified obstacles, as well as promoting social economy enterprises in internal market policies, as they account for approximately 10-12% of European enterprises. The Council needs to adopt the package of measures on product safety and market surveillance quickly and for this the Commission should play a facilitating role. It should be noted that the importance of providing adequate information on products intended for retail sale and in particular the indication of the country of origin should be highlighted. And it must be emphasized that the principle of equal pay for the same work in one place is an important tool for combating market distortions.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. In the European Parliament, bad faith does not know the crisis when it comes at all costs to saving Eurofederal utopia. This report on the "Digital Single Market Strategy" delivers the same incantation: the crisis, unemployment, is the fault of the Member States! Only a fully integrated Europe - a federal state - will allow the advent of the singing tomorrows and for this, we must first fully fulfil the single market! The report of Lara Comi therefore proposes to put these recalcitrant nations permanently in the process by putting an end to all non-tariff barriers such as regulated professions or protected geographical designations. A real death sentence for our food security and our industries, including the full implementation of the Services Directive and the Detachment directive on workers who have already murdered many of our companies. So I voted against this report. With the EPP group from which the rapporteur (Les Républicains) comes from, the clear message: the EU is always right, it is the reality that is wrong!

name: José Blanco López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it supports the overall objectives of the Commission's new strategy to achieve a fairer and more competitive single market in line with Title II TFEU, and appreciates its actions in key areas to exploit the full potential of the single market for the benefit of consumers, workers and businesses , especially emerging ones, in order to increase the number of quality sustainable jobs and promote the growth of SMEs. In addition, this report calls on the Commission to submit without resignation a legislative proposal for the establishment of a single European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products in the Union, which will have many positive effects for the whole European business and social fabric. It also reiterates its call for rapid adoption by the Council of the package of measures on product safety and market surveillance, stressing the importance of the indication of the country of origin in products intended for retail sale.

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the eu's new strategy on the internal market, because I believe that the proposals made in the reports will help to fulfil the potential of the single market and serve as a good starting point for Europe's success on the global economic scene. Today's ambitious and pragmatic strategy focuses on results. The next step is for the EU institutions, in cooperation with the Member States, to implement these specific measures as quickly as possible. In my view, every end must be made to ensure that consumers who wish to buy services or products in another Member State, whether online or in person, do not have to face different prices, changing sales conditions or different delivery methods unless objective and verifiable arguments can be substantiated. The European Commission and the European Consumer Centre often receive complaints that customers have been wrongly treated differently on the basis of nationality or place of residence. This practice should be discontinued in the future. Continue to reduce investment restrictions and create new opportunities for consumers, professionals and companies. The single market must always keep pace with change, so it must encourage and adopt innovative new business models. On the basis of the above, I voted in favour of the adoption of this report.

name: Franc Bogovič (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on a single market strategy. In the process of European integration, the completion of the single market has always been and is still one of the fundamental priorities of the European Union's policy. In recent years, the reality has changed dramatically. The challenges before us are growing and concern the internal market in particular: on the one hand, European citizens, especially young people, are facing increasing unemployment, which is linked to the weakening of entrepreneurship and competitiveness, and migration, on the other hand, is the problem here. The 'Refinement of the Single Market: more opportunities for the population and economy' complements and builds on these initiatives by proposing concrete measures that will certainly have a direct impact and an incentive effect for the market and strengthening consumer protection. I would also like to point out that that resolution contains an initiative for the Commission to prepare a legislative proposal that would also apply geographical indications to non-agricultural products and the mandatory labelling of the origin of products. I am very pleased about this, as we have consumers the right to know comprehensive information about where the products we buy come from.

name: Simona Bonafè (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is an indispensable source of opportunities for growth, employment and integration, both for businesses and for European citizens. In order for all its potential and benefits to be effectively deployed, however, greater joint efforts are needed, firstly, to continue the implementation of the single market in areas where it is still incomplete and, on the other hand, to remove the obstacles to its full and proper functioning in the remaining areas. I supported the resolution adopted today because it aims to strengthen the single market and, in particular, to strengthen an increasingly modern and competitive single market, capable of providing favourable conditions, especially for SMEs and start-ups investing in innovation, facilitating access to finance for these realities, enabling them to expand their activities and thus increase their competitiveness. In this area, as in other areas, it is therefore essential to develop more harmonised, transparent and quality legislation, without this creating additional administrative burdens. Greater harmonisation in terms of legislation does not, moreover, mean abandoning high standards or consumer protection instruments, such as the indication of the country of origin of products, the importance of which we have, on the contrary, stressed in the resolution.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D)
text: Written. I am extremely pleased that all my amendments have been adopted. I am particularly pleased that the amendment I had with my fellow Socialists and Democrats on the introduction of the mandatory designation of origin for products, the so-called "Made In", was adopted. According to the survey of the Consumer Society, as many as 72.8 percent of Croatian consumers have declared that data on the country of production/origin is the key information for them every time they buy. 18.7% think that leaving out the country of origin from the product notice is in the function of hiding the quality of the product. In addition, amendments to the introduction of the designation of origin and non-natural products were adopted. In this particular case, this means that the way is opened by which Slavonian gold embroidery, Pag lace and Brač stone would be given a geographical indication, which until now only original and autochthonous agricultural products such as Baranja kulen and Ličko potatoes had. An added value would also be that, according to the EC Green Paper of 2014, the system would create more than four million jobs in europe's poorest regions.

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this document because I believe that the single market is the greatest achievement of European integration and that its completion must be one of the main objectives of the Union and its institutions and that it is necessary to continue along the path taken by the Commission towards a modernisation of the market that will allow European businesses and economies to remain competitive at world level.

name: Renata Briano (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The future and gradual completion of the European single market is a key priority, which can significantly improve the lives of European consumers and businesses, which must be strongly supported.   Only in fact, with common and shared rules and regulations can we support balanced and environmentally friendly economic development, by tackling more calmly and effectively the major challenges we face, such as rising unemployment or the gradual weakening of our entrepreneurial fabric. It is precisely with a view to completing the single market that the Commission's new strategy is a further interesting mechanism capable of encouraging this process. In particular, of all the proposals contained in the package, I welcome and encourage the desire to promote the development and appropriate common regulatory framework of new economic models such as the collaborative economy, or the development of more appropriate rules for the benefit of greater protection for European consumers.  Among the latter, I would like to express my strong support for the amendment (paragraph 82) proposed by Mr Comi, which promotes the compulsory indication of the origin of products (the so-called 'made in'), a proposal that will provide consumers with more tools to protect the quality of their purchases and their safety.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF)
text: In writing. According to the report, the economic difficulties faced by EU Member States are largely due to the inadequacy of the single market integration process. Building on this premise, the rapporteur is trying to find solutions to remove all obstacles to the single market. It is within this framework that the whole tariff and non-tariff barriers must be removed, taxation between Member States to be harmonised in order to combat tax evasion and to increase the mobility of workers within the Union by implementing the 'detachment of workers' directive.  On the other hand, we believe that the sluggishness of current growth and mass unemployment are the result of widespread free trade that delivers our economies to all the winds of savage globalization. Only a return to intelligent protectionism protects us from the social and environmental dumping of emerging countries will allow us to return to the path of prosperity. That is why I voted against this text.

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 In the European integration process, the completion of the Single Market has been and always will remain a key political priority. The radical context has changed in recent years, and the challenges we face are increasingly pressing and have a significant impact on the internal market.  I welcome the provisions of this report that there must be mandatory labelling of non-agricultural products such as artisanal and industrial products, thus providing consumers with key information and ensuring equal quality of products in different Member States. This initiative is extremely beneficial for Romanian products, their quality-price ratio being an extremely advantageous one for buyers. In this way, products from Romania will make a difference on the European market, which is why I have expressed myself in favour of the Single Market Strategy report.

name: Gianluca Buonanno (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 If it were not for paragraph 82, the indication would simply and quickly be for a negative vote. There are too many highly critical references to Member States that are 'guilty' of not applying EU directives and regulations; in this respect, there are too many demands for the Commission to tighten up and make more effective sanctions against national and regional parliaments; there are too many calls for full implementation of the Services Directive. Too weak – if not absent – in the text are the references that objectively explain that supposed 'barriers to the internal market' introduced by the Member States are in fact caused by European law unsuitable for transposing into national and regional law. Of course, we are not convinced by the enthusiastic and ideological references to an EU internal market. This is, in fact, an important issue for Italian and Padanian interests. To be honest, it must be said that the rapporteur has managed to include in the text a reference to 'made in' which, although generic, is a significant element. Of course, it would be better to talk about "made in" of a mandatory type. For this reason, therefore, and for this reason alone, the indication is to limit ourselves to one abstention vote.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Single Market is one of Europe's greatest achievements, designed to enable the free movement of goods, services, capital and people. It offers opportunities for businesses and professionals as well as consumers.  The Digital Single Market Strategy adopted by the European Commission on 6 May 2015 aimed at stimulating economic growth and boosting job creation while removing obstacles faced by EU citizens and businesses every day, such as geo-blocking or inefficiency in cross-border parcel delivery, the impossibility of connecting to a range of services available online or limiting digital services at national borders , will primarily provide better regulation and improved enforcement.  I believe that the European Parliament can make an important contribution to making the Single Market strategy more appealing through concrete proposals in different areas, focusing efforts towards a more innovative and modern, strengthened and equitable single market.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it supports the overall objectives of the Commission's new strategy to achieve a fairer and more competitive single market in line with Title II TFEU, and appreciates its actions in key areas to exploit the full potential of the single market for the benefit of consumers, workers and businesses , especially emerging ones, in order to increase the number of quality sustainable jobs and promote the growth of SMEs. In addition, this report calls on the Commission to submit without resignation a legislative proposal for the establishment of a single European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products in the Union, which will have many positive effects for the whole European business and social fabric. It also reiterates its call for rapid adoption by the Council of the package of measures on product safety and market surveillance, stressing the importance of the indication of the country of origin in products intended for retail sale.

name: Alain Cadec (PPE)
text: In writing. The single market has significant potential for European citizens and businesses, particularly SMEs and start-ups. Yet it is far from complete. Many obstacles still remain, reducing the potential for innovation and growth as well as the benefits to citizens. A single market strategy that puts European citizens at the centre is needed.  Improving the business environment and adapting EU legislation to the specifics of SMEs will serve this purpose. Of course, for the single market to bear fruit, competition between the various players must be fair. I voted in favour of this report. It was also an opportunity for me to reiterate my positions on the need to combat tax and social dumping.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report today. The single market is the engine of sustainable growth and employment and is the cornerstone of the process of European integration. Strengthening its operation means creating new opportunities for both citizens and businesses. An effective strategy must focus on aspects aimed primarily at helping SMEs and start-ups. Tax coordination between EU countries must be facilitated and national VAT rules made uniform. In recent years the scenario has changed radically. The challenges to be faced are increasingly complex and have a major impact on the internal market (see, on the one hand, the persistent rate of unemployment, especially among young people, and, on the other hand, the sensitive and current problem of immigration). For the completion of the single market, its complementarity with the other horizontal strategic sectors, in particular the digital sector and the consumer protection sector, is essential. Paragraph 82 of the report is a step in the right direction. Compulsory indication of the origin of products protects consumer safety and breathes new life into the strenuous fight against counterfeiting.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which endorses the Commission’s proposal on the Single Market Strategy. Both the Commission proposal and this report focus on increasing competitiveness in the European Single Market, at the extent of secure jobs, workers’ rights and environmental protection. It calls for the repealing of ‘unnecessary legislation’ regulating businesses in Member States, and for deepened enforcement of the Strategy by the Commission of Member States. Not only does this report promote a thoroughly neoliberal attitude towards the economy, it also calls for further serious infringements on Member States’ sovereign rights. It states that Member States must refrain from implementing taxation and trade laws that may discriminate against businesses from other Member States (promoting harmonisation of trade and tax laws at EU level); endorses the Capital Markets Union, which Sinn Féin strongly opposes, and calls for a single European VAT rate.

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP fundamentally disagrees with the report, which criticises Member States for not transposing EU legislation. Moreover, we also strongly disagree with calls for further harmonisation and legislative proposals from the Commission. UKIP believes that the main problem with the single market is over-regulation, which damages SMEs causing higher prices and less choice for the consumer.

name: David Casa (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ This is an excellent report by Lara Comi and I congratulate her for the final outcome, which was preceded by long weeks of hard work. The overall aim is to improve the single market. The outlined measures are very promising and along with other EU strategies will help us further improve our economy and help it grow. The report is right in pointing out the single market should focus more on the needs of small and medium enterprises given their importance to our economy and that there are still possibilities within it to further improve the provision of goods and services.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report proposes a number of improvements aimed at achieving the objective of a better functioning of the single market. The text is balanced and there are many aspects that we can support, such as the Commission's call for legislative action to establish a system of protection based on geographical indications for non-agri-food products. The report also pays particular attention to the protection of the citizen as a consumer but also as a worker. Therefore, in view of the many positive aspects that emerge from the report, I voted in favour.

name: Dita Charanzová (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report as whole because the single market is the heart of the European Union. The Commission’s strategy is another step towards its completion and should be welcomed. But during the voting, I voted against the references to the ‘made in’ article of the Consumer Products Safety Regulation. This important piece of legislation has been blocked for too long over this one point, especially when the inclusion of such a requirement would have no benefits for product safety. It is time we as a parliament accept that it needs to be removed, at least from this regulation, so that we can move forward and finally enter trilogues with the Council.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market has been one of the main achievements of European integration, but it has yet to reach its full potential. Improvements are needed, particularly in the area of VAT, to facilitate companies' access to public procurement and to remove the obstacles posed by non-tariff barriers. The actions to be taken in the coming years must also be able to look at the new opportunities and challenges posed economically, socially and environmentally by the digital market and the rapidly growing collaborative economy, and which is changing the way goods and services are provided and used.  We all expect the Commission, together with the Member States, to be able to find legislative solutions to prevent the sharing economy from becoming a way of circumventing market rules to the detriment of consumers. A sine qua non for the single market to really be an opportunity for businesses and citizens is the transposition and consequent implementation by Member States of European single market rules. Furthermore, the report, on which I voted in favour, contains a request to the Commission to work to urge the Council to adopt the 'made in' regulation, a measure necessary to protect both businesses and consumers.

name: Ole Christensen (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The Danish Social Democrats want a well-functioning and fair internal market where workers and businesses compete on a level playing field and where consumers are properly protected. That is why we also support the report, which in many areas supports these principles. However, support for the report is not unlimited support for the concrete proposals in the report, but for the proper functioning of the internal market. We will take a position on proposals such as the sharing economy, service passports and VAT simplification when the concrete proposals are there and we can see the precise content.  Simplification of VAT may, for example, be a good idea, but it should not lead to Member States not being able to charge the desired rate.  Overall, an increased focus on the functioning of the internal market is a good thing. However, it is important that we consider not only how the market works for businesses, but also for consumers, workers and citizens.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report, stressing that the completion of the single market is a fundamental political priority in the process of European integration.

name: Κώστας Χρυσόγονος (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 The report on the Single Market Strategy is an attempt to improve the prevailing conditions and should aim to eliminate disparities between Member States, as well as to improve the growth prospects of all members of the Union.  Instead, the report focuses on specialising issues of free movement of products or barriers to the digital market for the benefit of companies, avoiding addressing problems affecting European citizens.  In spite of its positive elements, I have therefore decided to abstain.

name: Alberto Cirio (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The completion of the single market has always been a priority within the process of European integration. It is therefore important to focus our work on this issue in order to achieve a more modern, innovative and fair single market. I therefore voted in favour of this report also because I think it is essential to ensure the full and correct implementation of the rules relating to the internal market, an issue for which this report is very much fighting. In addition, the document pays particular attention to a subject of common interest with my specific competences, namely the indication of compulsory origin of products (made in), proposing to unblock the negotiations stopped in the Council. Therefore, as I agree with the report, also with regard to the content in support of SMEs and also with regard to the clear political message to protect the category of bathers so that their freedom to provide services is not compromised, I could only vote in favour of it. My intention is to build a real area in which the free movement of people, goods, services and capital is truly guaranteed.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Existing businesses should be made more competitive by modernising business models, cutting back on barriers created by administration and taxation, and facilitating entry to other Member Statesʼ markets. The EU single market also needs to attract new businesses from outside the EU, and private investment. There should be support for new kinds of businesses, in particular start-ups and micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, that promotes their ʽinnovativeʼ character and makes access to credit and EU funds easier and more efficient for them.

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP fundamentally disagrees with the report, which criticises Member States for not transposing EU legislation. Moreover, we also strongly disagree with calls for further harmonisation and legislative proposals from the Commission. UKIP believes that the main problem with the Single Market is over-regulation, which damages SMEs causing higher prices and less choice for the consumer.

name: Jane Collins and Mike Hookem (EFDD)
text: in writing. – UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP fundamentally disagrees with the report, which criticises Member States for not transposing EU legislation. Moreover, we also strongly disagree with calls for further harmonisation and legislative proposals from the Commission. UKIP believes that the main problem with the Single Market is over-regulation, which damages SMEs causing higher prices and less choice for the consumer.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Today, with the approval of the single market strategy, the EP has given a concrete response to the needs of our businesses, especially small businesses, and to our consumers. The internal market is the real means of growing the concept of Europe, not only as an economic power but also in unleashing all the potential for the benefit of all, so as to increase jobs, grow SMEs, achieve tangible and timely results in terms of competitiveness, sustainable growth, research, innovation and wide choice for consumers. But above all, the Members of the European Parliament have shown great unity with the approval of made in. We have shown that we can go beyond national self-interest by asking the Council to unblock once for all negotiations and to proceed, without delay, to the full approval of the origin mark. It is consumers who are asking us for more information on products, transparency and traceability to protect not only their health but also to protect products.

name: Therese Comodini Cachia (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support the call to strengthen efforts to ensure tax fairness in the European Union and combat aggressive tax planning and tax avoidance practices. Essentially the Commission would need to focus on working towards a country-by-country reporting obligation for transnational corporations. I agree that the Commission and the Member States would need to jointly come forward with proposals to prevent abuse in the employment and taxation areas in the sharing economy. The development of digital solutions for the payment of taxes, the provision of cross-border insurance schemes, and the modernisation of employment legislation are essential for the proper functioning of a single market strategy.

name: Javier Couso Permuy (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is a clear backlash to the European Commission's single market strategy, for which labour rights are a mere appendix to the freedom to provide services. Parliament should position itself clearly to ensure that collective bargaining and the right of States (and other public administrations) to regulate in accordance with the interests of the workers residing there are respected. That's why I voted against it.

name: Andrea Cozzolino (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Safeguarding and strengthening the single market is essential to ensure economic integration and growth, employment in the EU and the development of the digital economy. The single market will only achieve its full potential if The Member States adopt a common strategic vision that can exploit the benefits for European consumers in terms of the free movement of goods, persons, services and capital. My vote in favour is intended to support the proposed actions to improve and speed up the implementation of the single market. Among these, I consider it particularly important: harmonisation at legislative level, facilitation of SMEs and start-ups to enable them to grow in the single market, reducing the administrative burden on businesses, using single digital branches for the exchange of information, cooperation between the public and private sectors to break down barriers in the collaborative economy. This resolution brings attention to the responsibilities of the European institutions, on the one hand, and the Member States, on the other, with regard to the application of single market legislation. Specifically, I believe that we need to remove unjustified economic obstacles and develop a culture of compliance with standards and non-tolerance of breaches of single market regulations.

name: Andi Cristea (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The challenges of contemporary society demonstrate the need to constantly adjust and rethink the European strategy so that the social economy is a genuine factor in economic and social development in Europe. Balancing the market economy and social and environmental protection mechanisms could have the effect of combating unemployment, poverty, inequalities, social exclusion and wage dumping. At the same time, the European Single Market, by promoting respect for fundamental social rights, legal mobility and improved working and living conditions, will be an important element of solidarity and cooperation between Member States. Without aiming at the full liberalisation of the market, both unjustified and harmonised barriers must be removed, the information relating to them should be removed with a view to further achieving a fair single market, as a common good for all citizens, workers, economic operators and the Member States.  I voted in favour of this report, wanting me to reiterate the importance of achieving a balance between fundamental economic and social rights. Economic growth and stimulating the creation of quality jobs must aim at achieving the market economy rapidly, based on knowledge, and sustainable growth, while maintaining an effective system of social protection.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The proposals set out in the eu's internal market strategy reports can help to fulfil the potential of the single market and serve as a good starting point for Europe's success on the global economic scene. Today's ambitious and pragmatic strategy focuses on results. The next step is for the EU institutions, in cooperation with the Member States, to implement these specific measures as quickly as possible. The aim is to ensure that consumers who wish to buy services or products in another Member State, whether online or in person, do not have to face different prices, changing sales conditions or different delivery methods unless objective and verifiable arguments can be substantiated. The European Commission and the European Consumer Centre often receive complaints that customers have been wrongly treated differently on the basis of nationality or place of residence. This practice should be discontinued in the future. Continue to reduce investment restrictions and create new opportunities for consumers, professionals and companies. The single market must always keep pace with change, encourage and adopt innovative new business models.

name: Edward Czesak (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report sets out Parliament's position on the Commission's single market strategy. The report is supported by many of the main proposals made in the Commission Communication, although a number of additional requests have also been made consistent with the priorities previously set by Parliament's political groups. The report has a predominantly positive tone and recognises the need to improve the single market, especially in the services sector. The report contains several points of concern for the group, in particular support for the product safety and market surveillance package currently under consideration, which is blocked in the Council, instead of proposing an alternative approach that would allow the Commission to rationalise proposals and propose only those parts that are relevant. Nevertheless, overall, the report has a sufficiently positive tone with regard to the priorities for improving the Single Market. In view of the small number of points at issue in this report, I voted in favour of it.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The recent financial crisis has increased the number of unemployed citizens, this calls for further integration which can be achieved by a strategic approach. We need to ensure equal treatment and social inclusion which needs to be accompanied with the creation of sustainable jobs. Further assistance to SMEs is vital in order to have further economic growth and introduction of new jobs. The utilisation of all human capital is crucial in addressing unemployment, we need to improve skills and qualifications and continue to take actions against undeclared work. I am in favour of this report as we truly need a new holistic vision which focuses on green aspects and ensures the well-being of our citizens which calls for more equal treatment and social inclusion.

name: Michel Dantin (PPE)
text: In writing. The European Parliament voted on the European Commission's Single Market Strategy, presented in October 2015. In this report, MEPs propose to establish a modern, more innovative, deeper and fairer single market, with a particular emphasis on helping businesses, particularly SMEs, micro-enterprises and start-ups, in order to remove barriers to the development of their activities and the establishment in the single market. Considering that it is essential to reform, deepen and modernise the single market in order to promote growth and jobs, I supported this report.

name: Rachida Dati (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported the single market strategy report, which provides easy access for SMEs, start-ups and micro-enterprises to EU funds and highlights their innovative nature and measures to make it easier for them to access the patent system.

name: Marielle de Sarnez (ALDE)
text: In writing. A well-functioning single market is essential to achieving the EU 2020 strategy targets and to ensuring competitiveness and sustainable growth in Europe. It is therefore necessary to improve tax cooperation and ensure that companies compete with neighbours and partners who follow the same rules. In this regard, if we are to avoid protectionist temptation, it is crucial to bring to international trade negotiations compliance with our rules and standards in exchange for access to our already most open market in the world.

name: Angélique Delahaye (PPE)
text: In writing. The MAIN aim of the COMI report on the Single Market Strategy is to establish a modern, more innovative, deeper and fairer single market. I voted in favour of this text, which focuses on the aspects that tend to help businesses (especially SMEs, micro-enterprises and start-ups) to grow, grow and establish themselves in the single market. Thus, through this vote, we support a single European system for protecting geographical indications for non-agricultural products.  Similarly, we are in favour of a mandatory system for providing essential information on handmade and industrial products. Finally, I consider the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place, as advocated by European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, as an important tool to combat market distortions.

name: Andor Deli (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the eu's new strategy on the internal market, because I believe that the proposals made in the reports will help to fulfil the potential of the single market and serve as a good starting point for Europe's success on the global economic scene. Today's ambitious and pragmatic strategy focuses on results. The next step is for the EU institutions, in cooperation with the Member States, to implement these specific measures as quickly as possible. This practice should be discontinued in the future. Continue to reduce investment restrictions and create new opportunities for consumers, professionals and companies. The single market must always keep pace with change, so it must encourage and adopt innovative new business models.

name: Mireille D'Ornano (ENF)
text: In writing. Although this text evokes interesting avenues for thinking about the future, such as the collaborative economy or improving access to finance for SMEs and craftsmen, it remains in denial about the profound difficulties facing the European Union. These are said to be due only to the inadequacy of the single market integration process.  According to this report, unemployment, recession and the democratic crisis we are experiencing can only be solved by the completion of European federalism. It advocates sanctions against states that apply protectionism, administratively and technically regulate the mobility of workers, set non-tariff barriers, particularly in the retail market, or do not sufficiently align their regulations with those of the EU. For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the Single Market Strategy as it provides for ways to improve and harmonise the single market. The expected profit from the completion of the single market reform amounts to almost EUR 3 trillion, further leading to the creation of new jobs and a reduction in high levels of unemployment within the European Union. The report contains very concrete proposals that could, in a targeted manner, improve the functioning of the single market, such as a platform to combat undeclared work or the fully electronic procurement system proposed by Member States. I also fully support the ultimate objective of the single market reform initiated, namely the removal of unfair barriers for individual Member States within the single market.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against the report as the single market, apart from being non-functional in general, has caused a great loss of valuable human resources in our country, as in all the other economically weak countries of the Union.

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 A report responding to the Commission's strategy for the development of the internal market. A developed and better functioning internal market is a key factor in europe's economies gaining momentum, and the report contains many important points. I have chosen to vote in favour of the report as a whole. Parts of the report highlight a general demand for 'made in' for industrial products. I believe that this would disrupt the functioning of the internal market too much, and I have therefore chosen to vote against these points.

name: Edouard Ferrand (ENF)
text: In writing. Vote against: the report manages to reconcile the irreconcilable, such as the intensification of the fight against all kinds of protectionism, the full implementation of the so-called "services" directive (catastrophic for businesses), the one on the detachment of workers (destructive of jobs) and the protection of craftsmen and SMEs.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. Three decades of the single market have given gas to the concentration and centralisation of capitalist monopolistic groups, the dismantling of instruments for sovereign regulation of economies, privatisation and liberalisation of strategic sectors and public services.  But the great monopolistic capital wants more: deepening of the market, structural reforms (read settlement of the social functions of the State and social and labor rights). It proposes to link with the Juncker Plan, which is open to the interests of high finance and large companies, and which favours public-private partnerships, injecting public resources into the financial system. Or with TTIP, which would liquidate thousands of SMEs and deepen the attack on workers' labour and social rights. Risk capital and financial products that were at the root of the 2008 financial crisis are valued. The single market does not serve the interests of workers and peoples. It hindered the sovereign development of states. It has promoted levelling below living and working conditions in Europe, increasing inequalities, exclusion and poverty.  Obviously, we voted against it.

name: Santiago Fisas Ayxelà (PPE)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report, because I consider the Commission's objective of achieving a more modern and fair single market important. I also consider it appropriate to attach the importance given in the report to the aid to be granted to SMEs and start-ups, to ensure their market stay, as well as their access to EU funds. Strengthening European legislation is needed in the interest of innovation and competitiveness.

name: Raffaele Fitto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this resolution. We will fight for the European Commission to adopt rules as a matter of urgency in favour of better traceability of products, especially in the interests of consumer protection. An important step towards the right recognition of Made in Italy, which in preferences is at the top. And now the new challenge of the Conservatives and Reformists is the unreserved fight against counterfeiting.

name: Monika Flašíková Beňová (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The final completion of a functioning and efficient single market remains one of the European Union's top priorities for the coming years. In the recent past, there have been many changes that are actively affecting the internal market, such as the rise in unemployment, which affects young people in particular, but also the weakening of the business environment and the competitiveness of European businesses, and, last but not least, the migration crisis and the associated problem of immigration into the European Union. I therefore welcome the proposed plans and changes by the European Commission under Mr Juncker, such as the VAT Action Plan, the legislative proposal on corporate insolvency, the service passport and the legislative initiative aimed at preventing discrimination that harms the consumer and is based on nationality or place of residence.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF)
text: in writing. \u2012 I am abstaining from the report because, despite some positive passages, it is a report that places product traceability based on optional and non-compulsory schemes.

name: Ashley Fox (ECR)
text: in writing. ‒ My colleagues and I support much of the Single Market Strategy, which this report largely endorses. I am pleased that some of the more contentious issues in the report, such as VAT for e-commerce and non-agricultural GIs, were subject to separate votes. I am pleased that significant improvements came out of the negotiations on the final report and that these have been included. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome a new, holistic vision on the single market based on green, knowledge-based social market economy. The report will improve the well—being of European citizens by proposing practical measures that need to guarantee equal treatment and social inclusion, creation of sustainable jobs and growth and high level of consumer protection. I support the call for measures to help SMEs, micro-enterprises and start-ups, without providing opportunities for dishonest businesses to circumvent existing rules, lower workers’ and consumer standards; concerning REFIT, I support the introduction of measures which lower the administrative burdens and compliance costs on businesses, and which ensure high standards of consumer, employee, health and environmental protection; moreover, I welcome the inclusion of objective criteria and indicators for a definition of ‘innovative’ start-ups, SMEs. Finally, I support the call on the Commission to come up with a definition on social economy enterprises, which is currently non-existent.

name: Ildikó Gáll-Pelcz (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the eu's new strategy on the internal market, because I believe that the proposals made in the reports will help to fulfil the potential of the single market and serve as a good starting point for Europe's success on the global economic scene. The single market must always keep pace with change, so it must encourage and adopt innovative new business models.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it supports the overall objectives of the Commission's new strategy to achieve a fairer and more competitive single market in line with Title II TFEU. In addition, the report appreciates its actions in key areas to exploit the full potential of the single market for the benefit of consumers, workers and businesses, especially emerging ones, in order to increase the number of quality sustainable jobs and promote the growth of SMEs. On the other hand, this report calls on the Commission to submit without resignation a legislative proposal for the establishment of a single European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products in the Union, which will have many positive effects for the whole European business and social fabric. It also reiterates its call for rapid adoption by the Council of the package of measures on product safety and market surveillance, stressing the importance of the indication of the country of origin in products intended for retail sale.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it supports the overall objectives of the Commission's new strategy to achieve a fairer and more competitive single market in line with Title II TFEU, and appreciates its actions in key areas to exploit the full potential of the single market for the benefit of consumers, workers and businesses , especially emerging ones, in order to increase the number of quality sustainable jobs and promote the growth of SMEs. In addition, this report calls on the Commission to submit without resignation a legislative proposal for the establishment of a single European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products in the Union, which will have many positive effects for the whole European business and social fabric. It also reiterates its call for rapid adoption by the Council of the package of measures on product safety and market surveillance, stressing the importance of the indication of the country of origin in products intended for retail sale.

name: Enrico Gasbarra (S&D)
text: in writing. With today's vote, the European Parliament is once again taking a firm stand in support of Made in and the protection of products of excellence. I would like to thank my colleague, Mrs Comi, who, on behalf of the IMCO Committee, has presented a strategic report which will meet the many challenges and benefits that the internal market can bring to Europe: greater integration with digital technologies, improved quality of employment, the introduction of higher standards for consumers, support for the internationalisation of SMEs.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the non-legislative resolution on the Single Market Strategy, because I believe that only a fairer single market can really be of use to European citizens. I strongly supported the EP's demands on the European Commission in this important area with a view to future legislative proposals, because only a genuine single market can guarantee citizens, consumers and businesses real protection and benefits, in terms of better quality, greater variety, reasonable prices and security of goods and services. With regard to the future legislative proposal aimed at combating unjustified geoblocking and other unjustified forms of discrimination, I welcome the need to take account of the principle of proportionality, in particular for small and medium-sized enterprises, and to show the necessary attention, particularly for social economy enterprises that represent a variety of business models that are fundamental to a highly competitive and fairer single market. Finally, I agree with the call for the Commission to draw up a definition of start-ups, SMEs and social economy enterprises, to integrate the social economy into single market policies and to draw up a European action plan for social economy enterprises, in order to unlock all the potential for smart, sustainable and fair growth.

name: Jens Gieseke (PPE)
text: Writing. At present, many of the EU's challenges are weakening the single market. Increasing unemployment, especially among young people, the associated weakening of businesses and the migration problem call for a firm approach to the internal market strategy. We need concrete action from the common EU policy to meet these challenges. I support this approach.

name: Neena Gill (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which offers a new, comprehensive vision for the single market which is rooted in a green, knowledge-based social market economy. The report contains proposals for practical measures, such as the need to guarantee social inclusion and equal treatment; the provision of sustainable jobs and growth as well as ensuring that consumers are protected to a high degree.

name: Tania González Peñas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Report on the strategy for the single market, since our position on competitiveness in the context of an internal market economy is totally contrary to the ideas set out in the report. On the one hand, it points to some serious problems relating to SMEs and start-ups, but the focus is on improving the single market by increasing competition and eliminating the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Theresa Griffin (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this comprehensive strategy on the single market which seeks to improve the well-being of European citizens by proposing practical measures that need to guarantee equal treatment and social inclusion, creation of sustainable jobs and growth and high level consumer protection.

name: Antanas Guoga (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. The report highlights the key areas of EU Single Market Strategy, which aims to ensure the free movement of goods within the market, the freedom to provide services, especially for start-ups and SMEs, and to set high safety standards for consumers.

name: Jytte Guteland Anna Hedh Olle Ludvigsson Jens Nilsson och Marita Ulvskog (S&D)
text: Written. We Swedish Social Democrats voted today in favour of the own-initiative report "The Strategy for the Internal Market". It is important for the European Parliament to signal to the Commission about our priorities in the internal market, which are an essential part of our cooperation for job creation, among other things. Since the internal market must be accompanied by effective protection for consumers, workers and the environment, we chose to vote against a couple of points on which we believe that the wording is contrary to our values. We believe that, of course, Member States should continue to have the possibility of legislating on the protection of consumers, workers and the environment without being considered to be unjustified obstacles to the internal market. We also voted against wordings that go against municipal self-government in urban planning. The Swedish Social Democratic delegation voted in favour of several of the good wordings that highlighted the importance of strengthening consumer protection, workers' rights, environmental requirements. We also fully support those wordings that draw attention to the potential of the social economy to create sustainable and secure jobs within the EU's internal market. That is why we were able to support the report in the final vote, when sufficient good wording satin and balanced the text.

name: Sergio Gutiérrez Prieto (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it supports the overall objectives of the Commission's new strategy to achieve a fairer and more competitive single market in line with Title II TFEU, and appreciates its actions in key areas to exploit the full potential of the single market for the benefit of consumers, workers and businesses , especially emerging ones, in order to increase the number of quality sustainable jobs and promote the growth of SMEs. name: Τάκης Χατζηγεωργίου (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 We voted against the report on the ground that it makes no mention at all of solving the major challenges that EU citizens face on a daily basis. On the contrary, the approach to solving the problems being promoted is limited to strengthening markets, with the result that our group's shadow rapporteur submits a separate minority/minority report.

name: Marian Harkin (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that supports the overall objectives of the Commissions New Single Market Strategy that proposed actions for SMEs and start-ups such as simplification of VAT regulation and reduction in company registration, a European agenda for the collaborative economy a services passport to reduce barriers for the service providers, and a legislative initiative to stop consumer discrimination based on a nationality or country of residence. In particular, I was happy to support the report where it underlines the importance of the indication of country of origin on products and where the report promotes the principle of equal pay for equal work at the same place.

name: Brian Hayes (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of this report as it will help to clarify and strengthen the single market.

name: György Hölvényi (PPE)

name: Ian Hudghton (Verts/ALE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against paragraph 54 which states that the benefits of public-private partnerships have not been fully realised. Last month, 17 schools in Edinburgh were forced to close and thousands of pupils were affected. All of these schools were built under private finance initiatives signed off under the previous Labour government and they stand testimony to the real effects of PPP.

name: Филиз Хюсменова (ALDE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Dear Mr President, I support the proposals in the report on the Single Market Strategy, as I believe that they will have a positive impact on the internal market, especially on start-ups, small and medium-sized enterprises, as well as on consumer protection. I am confident that the measures envisaged, including simplifying VAT rules, reducing the cost of registering businesses and creating a digital single market, are important and forward-looking steps towards further integrating the single market. Fragmentation of the Single Market remains one of the main obstacles to achieving sustainable and structural economic growth. We must therefore step up our efforts to build a strategic approach to the single market that will become a driver of sustainable development and job creation and ensure a highly competitive social market economy at a time when unemployment rates remain high.  This report will significantly contribute to a more ambitious Single Market strategy by presenting concrete policy proposals and focusing our efforts on building a deeper and fairer internal market that is at the same time modern and advanced.

name: Cătălin Sorin Ivan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ We need a new holistic vision on the single market based on a green knowledge-based social market economy, which will improve the well-being of European citizens. We need practical measures which will guarantee growth, the creation of sustainable jobs, equal treatment and social inclusion, and a high level of consumer protection.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE)
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the Single Market Strategy Report (2015/2354(INI)) as the single market is the cornerstone of European integration and the profits of completing the single market are estimated at a million euros. The report supports the Commission's overall objectives contained in the document 'Improving the Single Market: More Opportunities for People and Businesses' and welcomes its actions in key areas enabling the full potential of the Single Market.  The report emphasises that in sectors employing a large number of labour, such as retail and hospitality, there is great potential for job creation, integration and tackling youth unemployment. In relation to the measures already adopted and procedures towards the single market, attention should be paid to their proper implementation and reduction of infringements in terms of the single market. The Commission and the Member States should carry out an analysis of unnecessary restrictions in the single market.  In addition to the economic aspects, attention should be paid to creating a fairer single market that will benefit and provide protection to citizens, consumers and businesses in terms of better quality, greater diversity, reasonable prices and the safety of goods and services. The Commission needs to include the social economy in its single market policies and develop a European action plan for social economy enterprises.

name: Jean-François Jalkh (ENF)
text: In writing. Although the report points to interesting avenues such as the development of the collaborative economy or improved access to finance for SMEs and craftsmen, it does not in any way formulate a self-criticism of the real obstacles to the single market. The rapporteur confines herself to pointing the finger at the protectionism of sovereign states and plans to overcome them regardless of the opinion of the peoples. I simply voted against it.

name: Petr Ježek (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 In its own-initiative report, the European Parliament presented a strategy to improve the single market. Although we have seen positive developments within the Single Market in recent years, there is still much to improve. For example, the EU should aim to reduce administrative burdens, get rid of unnecessary legislation, while ensuring a high level of standards in terms of consumers, workers, health and the environment. Similarly, the report supported the Commission's determination to address the lack of tax coordination within the EU, particularly with regard to VAT reform or cross-border crowdfunding. A functioning single market is, I think, one of the eu's greatest benefits and I was happy to support the report calling for numerous improvements.

name: Philippe Juvin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which aims to establish a modern, more innovative, deeper and fairer single market. It places particular emphasis on helping companies (particularly TPE/SMEs) to develop their activities within the internal market.  In addition, the text proposes to establish a single European system for protecting geographical indications for non-agricultural products, as well as a mandatory labelling system to provide key information on handmade and industrial products. These measures will therefore enhance transparency and consumer protection.

name: Εύα Καϊλή (
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of Mrs Lara Comi's report as I believe that the completion of the single market was and continues to be a fundamental political priority in the process of European integration. I would particularly like to stress that a very important step in this direction is also the single patent, which is an important step forward in the protection of intellectual property and the relationship with national patent systems and supplementary protection certificates must be improved.  The European single market needs more appropriate rules for market surveillance and a decision is therefore needed on the future of the legislative package pending in the Council, without overlooking the importance for consumer protection of the rules on the labelling of the origin of products.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF)
text: Writing. I am abstaining from this report. While it provides for some tax advantages for small and medium-sized enterprises, it also calls for measures that I am critical of, such as.B a single EU VAT system.

name: Krišjānis Kariņš (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The European Union is one of the largest and richest markets in the world, but there are nevertheless areas that, unfortunately, are not yet fully united, and Member States are taking very different practices on a number of issues. I support a single European Union market, but I abstained in the final vote on this report because I believe that it contains too many details and requirements that could be interpreted too broadly. This would in reality directly distort the single market. One of the most prominent examples is the report's 'equal pay for equal work in the same workplace'. In my view, such a principle is very dangerous and would effectively destroy any competition. It is very important to maintain competition in the Single Market of the European Union, because competition is one of the drivers of growth.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This report contains numerous relevant proposals how to reinforce and deepen the single market. Ideally the EU should be an open, innovative, welcoming single market. Unfortunately, even more than a decade after starting the process, we still face similar obstacles. The EU single market is still controlled by national borders to an extent that does not foster proper cross-border business making, cross-border services exchange, healthy labour mobility (that would in fact give European youth better starting point for finding proper jobs). Cumbersome procedures and complying with national standards and norms prevent many businesses, especially SMEs and microbusinesses to expand their activities across the borders. I call on the EC and the MS to take political leadership and rapidly eliminate remaining obstacles and minimize the impact of national borders on European Single Market. I call on developing and implementing innovative measures to reduce bureaucracy and compliance, enable access to seed and especially innovation financing. Common e-certificates, e-signatures, e-platforms accepted by all Member States are a must. Lastly, the report underlines mismatch of skills with rapidly developing digital sphere – action has to start now, from children to elderly, boosting digital literacy is key to provide sustainable and innovative European Single Market.

name: Afzal Khan (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report as it calls for a genuinely strategic approach for the further integration of the single market. New holistic vision on the single market based on green knowledge-based social market economy will improve the well—being of European citizens by proposing practical measures that need to guarantee equal treatment and social inclusion, creation of sustainable jobs and growth and high level of consumer protection.

name: Jeppe Kofod (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The Danish Social Democrats want a well-functioning and fair internal market where workers and businesses compete on a level playing field and where consumers are properly protected. That is why we also support the report, which in many areas supports these principles. However, support for the report is not unlimited support for the concrete proposals in the report, but for the proper functioning of the internal market. We will take a position on proposals such as the sharing economy, service passports and VAT simplification when the concrete proposals are there and we can see the precise content.  Simplification of VAT may, for example, be a good idea, but it should not lead to Member States not being able to charge the desired rate.  Overall, an increased focus on the functioning of the internal market is a good thing. However, it is important that we consider not only how the market works for businesses, but also for consumers, workers and citizens.

name: Ádám Kósa (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the eu's new strategy on the internal market, because I believe that the proposals made in the reports will help to fulfil the potential of the single market and serve as a good starting point for Europe's success on the global economic scene. Today's ambitious and pragmatic strategy focuses on results. The next step is for the EU institutions, in cooperation with the Member States, to implement these specific measures as quickly as possible. In my view, every end must be made to ensure that consumers who wish to buy services or products in another Member State, whether online or in person, do not have to face different prices, changing sales conditions or different delivery methods unless objective and verifiable arguments can be substantiated. The European Commission and the European Consumer Centre often receive complaints that customers have been wrongly treated differently on the basis of nationality or place of residence. This practice should be discontinued in the future. Continue to reduce investment restrictions and create new opportunities for consumers, professionals and companies. The single market must always keep pace with change, so it must encourage and adopt innovative new business models.

name: Stelios Kouloglou (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. ‒ The present report deals with the additional instruments offered by the new ‘Upgrading the Single Market: more opportunities for people and business’ strategy, in order to guarantee the effective functioning of the single market. The report adopts a liberal approach and seems to approve the majority of the measures proposed by the Commission, which are foreseen to further and deepen the single market. However, some serious issues that ensue from this fact, such as labour deregulation, worker’s rights protection, dismantling of national sovereign economic instruments are not addressed. In order to emphasize the necessity for these aspects to be taken into consideration, I decided to abstain.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I supported the resolution because the EU single market has brought tremendous benefits for both European citizens and European business. Yet the full potential of free movement of goods, services and capital has been unexploited because of ever changing environment of the market. Therefore, the EU should adapt new ideas and measures proposed by the new Single Market Strategy in order to stimulate competition, trade, efficiency and quality on the market. The new Single Market Strategy aims to improve mobility for services providers, ensure the growth of innovative businesses and enhance access to goods and services throughout the EU. Most importantly, the strategy focuses on helping business, and in particular SMEs, micro-enterprises and start-ups. These business are not only the backbone of EU economies but also are the main engine of growth and job creation within the EU. In this regard, we should support the Single Market Strategy because it aims to unlock the full potential of the EU Single Market by promoting entrepreneurship and development.

name: Giovanni La Via (PPE)
text: in writing. I am voting in favour of the own-initiative resolution on the single market strategy. As a goal of the Union, we have been working for many years towards the creation of a unified and integrated system that will advance our fundamental principles. In order to achieve this objective, the completion of the single market strategy is crucial. We need a more pragmatic and decisive system, which is also capable of combating the current problems of youth unemployment and immigration. The report highlights the possibility of ensuring greater opportunities for businesses and citizens, through ambitious and concrete proposals for the promotion of measures in individual areas that will allow the construction of a modern, innovative and fair single market. The text has an important principle, inserted by a large majority, thanks to the work of the rapporteur and the Italian delegation of the PPE, the so-called Made In. For us, the obligation to indicate the country of origin in products is an essential step and it is now up to the European Commission to respond to us on this point.

name: Constance Le Grip (PPE)
text: In writing. The Main Aim of the Comi Report on the Single Market Strategy is to establish a modern, more innovative, deeper and fairer single market. I voted in favour of this text, which focuses on the aspects that tend to help businesses (especially SMEs, micro-enterprises and start-ups) to grow, grow and establish themselves in the single market. Thus, through this vote, we support a single European system for protecting geographical indications for non-agricultural products.  Similarly, we are in favour of a mandatory system for providing essential information on handmade and industrial products. Finally, I consider the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place, as advocated by European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, as an important tool to combat market distortions.

name: Marine Le Pen (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against the single market strategy report. For Europeanists, the single market remains the alpha and omega of economic progress. Out of him point of salvation. The profound difficulties facing the European Union are due only to the inadequacy of the process of integration of the single market.
