The "intermediate" step towards federalism in which the Union finds itself blocked by the fault of the Member States alone is the only reason for unemployment, recession and disavowal of the peoples. The obstacles remain numerous and must therefore be overcome even in reverse of the will of the Member States and the people. Any questioning or criticism is prohibited. This text is an ideological litany.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF)
text: In writing. According to the rapporteur, the single market appears to be the only viable framework for the European economy. Although riddled with imperfections such as the protectionist barriers put in place by the Member States, the delay in the application and harmonisation of European rules, it remains the engine of European economic progress. In order to perfect federal Europe, the text proposes many strategies, starting with the destruction of protectionist and non-tariff barriers, the development of cross-border trade... Although some ideas should be emphasized, such as improving financing for SMEs and craftsmen, the whole text is a denial of reality, going against national economies. My vote is logically against it.

name: Javi López (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it supports the overall objectives of the Commission's new strategy to achieve a fairer and more competitive single market in line with Title II TFEU, and appreciates its actions in key areas to exploit the full potential of the single market for the benefit of consumers, workers and businesses , especially emerging ones, in order to increase the number of quality sustainable jobs and promote the growth of SMEs. In addition, this report calls on the Commission to submit without resignation a legislative proposal for the establishment of a single European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products in the Union, which will have many positive effects for the whole European business and social fabric. It also reiterates its call for rapid adoption by the Council of the package of measures on product safety and market surveillance, stressing the importance of the indication of the country of origin in products intended for retail sale.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it supports the overall objectives of the Commission's new strategy to achieve a fairer and more competitive single market in line with Title II TFEU, and appreciates its actions in key areas to exploit the full potential of the single market for the benefit of consumers, workers and businesses , especially emerging ones, in order to increase the number of quality sustainable jobs and promote the growth of SMEs. In addition, this report calls on the Commission to submit without resignation a legislative proposal for the establishment of a single European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products in the Union, which will have many positive effects for the whole European business and social fabric. It also reiterates its call for rapid adoption by the Council of the package of measures on product safety and market surveillance, stressing the importance of the indication of the country of origin in products intended for retail sale.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE)
text: in writing. One of our political priorities at European level has always been the creation of the single market with which to achieve full European integration.  In this context, this report is very ambitious, because it contributes concrete proposals for each area, a more innovative, modern and fair market. I believe that one of the key points for achieving the proposed objectives is the promotion of business competitiveness, through the modernization of business models and the reduction of barriers of a fiscal and administrative nature, among other measures. This report presents concrete tools that promote innovation, access to credit and European funding, such as the REFIT platform, to project the image of a Europe that is committed to the protection of SMEs and with which we improve the coordination of national policies for companies working at European level.  For the reasons set out above and because I believe that with the measures included we can continue to move towards an integration from which we will certainly benefit all, I welcome your approval.

name: Petr Mach (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted against. I do not agree with the establishment of the European Innovation Council, which I think is just another bureaucratic institution. I do not support either 'the Commission's intention to use COSME funding to finance information campaigns targeted at innovative young SMEs' or to subsidise companies from other programmes. I do not agree with the creation of a 'network of agents for SMEs'. In short, I am in a free market, not a uniformly overregulated and subsidised market.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Single Market is the cornerstone of European integration, a driver of sustainable growth and job creation, as it enables trade across the Union and guarantees a highly competitive social market economy. This report underlines the importance of further integrating the single market and harmonising union-wide rules and measures, such as trade and tax rules, which would contribute to the harmonisation of competition. Achieving the full potential of the single market and promoting sustainable growth require internal demand and strengthening purchasing power, adopting innovative measures and investing in the green economy. To this end, it is essential to reduce administrative and compliance costs for SMEs and support their technological improvement and modernisation of operations through the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and programmes such as Horizon 2020, COSME, the European Structural and Investment Funds. Given all of the above, I supported this report.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The resolution adopted today represents the European Parliament's response to the proposed strategy by the European Commission to modernise the single market. Europe went through the global financial crisis, paying a high price. Member States' economies continue to gasp because of youth unemployment, low growth rates and a lack of investment. The Single Market is at the heart of European integration, but there are still too many obstacles, especially for small and medium-sized businesses and start-ups. Few of them go beyond the scope of the local or regional market and operate at European level. The European Parliament's attention therefore focuses on their needs to simplify regulatory requirements, access to finance and promote innovation. With 423 votes in return, the European Parliament supported the objectives set out in the strategy and gave a clear signal that it expects its successful implementation soon.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The single market has been with a very high unemployment rate for a year, which last year amounted to 22 million Europeans of an economically active age. While much has been achieved in recent years, thanks in particular to the measures implemented to overcome the consequences of the financial crisis, the real potential of the single market has not yet been achieved. Therefore, the need to work more actively for their fuller implementation is quite logical and important. Reducing the bureaucratic burden is one of the main objectives to be achieved. The abolition or qualitative modernisation of genuinely unnecessary or outdated legislation must become the cornerstone of this task, which applies to both the supranational and national levels of government – for example, in regulating vat taxation policies. Increasing the role of small and medium-sized enterprises and further digitisation and innovation are some other fundamentally important objectives, as are combating counterfeiting of goods and the most active protection of consumer interests, which in the modern age is particularly relevant to the digital environment (e.g. online purchases). The need to improve the quality of cross-border provision of services should also be noted separately, as often quite different systems exist in our Member States in this respect. It is also necessary to make it easier to work remotely across borders and to deal with unjustified geo-blocking when, for example, a video on the same YouTube is available in one Member State and in another no longer. Within the real single market, this is neither acceptable nor logical.

name: Vladimír Maňka (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Single Market is an indisputable advantage for citizens and businesses. However, in order to make it work more efficiently and effectively, work is needed to close some of the differences in taxation, control, supervision, consumer protection and thorough and clear regulation. The aim should be to remove unnecessary barriers while building a transparent legal environment that provides legal certainty and guarantees to all operators moving in the internal market.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I am voting against the report on the Single Market Strategy, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the plenary of the European Parliament in Brussels on 26/5/2015, and because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique Martin (ENF)
text: In writing. I voted against this report. Despite some interesting proposals on the collaborative economy or improving access to finance for SMEs and craftsmen, we strongly oppose this report. Its sole aim is to develop the single market to its climax, in defiance of the will of the Member States to want to keep a share of sovereignty!  This text envisages removing barriers to the single market: we oppose the removal of non-tariff barriers, the questioning of administrative limits on the mobility of workers or the prohibition of state protectionism.  Finally, we oppose the full implementation of the Services Directive, which is particularly damaging to businesses, and the detached workers directive, which generates ever more unemployment!

name: Fulvio Martusciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the single market strategy. One of the primary objectives of the European Union is the creation of a single market, which guarantees the free movement of goods, services, people and capital and which ensures a highly competitive social economy, promotes European integration, growth and employment. It is therefore essential to make a commitment, both by the EU and by the Member States, to remove those unjustified obstacles, which lead to more limited choice and higher costs for consumers, in order to achieve the completion of this market. With greater cooperation from the Member States, we will be able to fully enjoy a single market that is more innovative, modern, intense and fair, a fundamental resource for all European citizens, workers, economic operators, and thus ensure economic prosperity, stimulate new jobs, improve the well-being of Europeans and the competitiveness of European businesses.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we voted on a report on the single market strategy. The report considers that the single market is the eu's most important cornerstone and de facto speaks only of its benefits. However, it must be remembered that single market policy does not only bring benefits. Especially for small countries with weaker economies, this means major challenges and the negative effects on these economies prevail. I stress that the single market is characterised by long-term high unemployment rates. Since the beginning of the financial crisis, the number of unemployed has increased by more than 6 million, which means that at the end of 2015 more than 22 million people in the Union were unemployed. I do not think that the creation of a single market is one of the EU's objectives. We should focus more on social, environmental policies, health, employment, etc. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE)
text: in writing. From this Parliament we support a strategy to create a more ambitious single market in Europe, with measures that really contribute to companies and citizens benefiting from joining the EU. We need to remove existing barriers, strengthen business competitiveness to create more jobs, and better protect consumers. And we must bet seamlessly on innovation and new technologies as a way to make it easier for that single market to become a more tangible reality every day. To this end, there must be clear rules and a simple and effective regulatory framework, which does not paralyze those projects that are good and which, on the contrary, stops any attempt to breach the current framework. And there must be a clear policy to support our products and producers by protecting, for example, protected appellations or indications of origin and ensuring maximum consumer confidence.

name: Georg Mayer (ENF)
text: Writing. The report has good approaches, especially in the area of SME support. On the other hand, however, the benefits for large corporations have been positively addressed. That is why I am abstaining from voting.

name: Valentinas Mazuronis (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 Strategy "Improving the Single Market: More opportunities for citizens and businesses" is seen as an additional and further instrument for achieving the objectives of the Single Market. The Communication presents a number of significant actions to remove obstacles to its development, such as the VAT Action Plan, the legislative initiative on business insolvency, the service provider's passport and legislative action to prevent discrimination against consumers on grounds of nationality or country of residence.  These specific measures will not only have a direct but also leverage effect on the market and the strengthening of consumer protection.

name: Mairead McGuinness (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I support this report which calls for measures to help smaller businesses and start-ups.

name: Joëlle Mélin (ENF)
text: In writing. The single market is the unsurpassable horizon of the Eurocracra. If it does not work well, it is because the Member States are holding back federalism. Europe, which was done without the peoples, has yet to get rid of the states. There is no questioning in this one-way relationship. That said, some of the talk about the collaborative economy is interesting. As a result I voted against it.

name: Roberta Metsola (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support the report as it focuses on a number of measures that will improve the functioning of the single market, namely increased transparency of product origins, SMEs more aware of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), and a more equal market for competitors are important steps towards increased employment and consumer rights in the single market.

name: Miroslav Mikolášik (PPE)
text: Writing. – In the process of European integration, the completion of the Single Market has been a top political priority from the 1990s. However, the current challenges have a significant impact on the internal market: on the one hand, there is rising unemployment, which affects EU citizens, especially young people, while undermining the business environment and competitiveness, and, on the other hand, the problem of immigration. Measures such as the VAT Action Plan, the legislative proposal on corporate insolvency, the service passport and the legislative initiative aimed at preventing discrimination that harms the consumer and is based on nationality or place of residence will undoubtedly have a direct impact, as well as leverage on the market and the strengthening of consumer protection. The political priorities to be pursued are, on the one hand, strengthening the competitiveness of businesses (resulting in an increase in employment), improving enforcement and regulation and strengthening consumer protection. I therefore support the proposal in question.

name: Marlene Mizzi (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ As a shadow rapporteur on the Single Market Strategy report, I fully support the overall objectives of MEP Comi’s Report. the Single Market Strategy report is a step in the right direction in achieving a new holistic vision on the single market based on a green knowledge-based social market economy that will improve the well—being of European citizens by proposing practical measures needed to guarantee equal treatment and social inclusion, creation of sustainable jobs and growth and high level of consumer protection.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The completement of the single market has always been and will continue to be a fundamental political priority in the European integration process. However, swift and effective action is needed to continue the work that has been started. The Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection therefore welcomes the proposals of the European Commission's strategy of 28 October 2015 entitled 'Further developing the single market: expanding opportunities for citizens and businesses', such as the legislative proposal on insolvency and early restructuring. It considers it unacceptable for undertakings to go bankrupt or experience difficulties because public authorities operating as creditors do not comply with the payment conditions laid down in the Directive. It also recommends examining the possibility of compensatory mechanisms.  It points out that a collaborative economy can play a role in growth and job creation, but that the same services should be subject to the same rules. It also praises the important role of the single patent in the protection of intellectual property, but also calls for measures to make it easier for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises to use a single patent for their own innovative products. It stresses that the EU single market needs new, more appropriate market surveillance standards. To this end, it urges a decision on the future of the legislative package blocked by the Council. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Cláudia Monteiro de Aguiar (PPE)
text: in writing. This report focuses its strategy on aspects aimed at helping businesses, in particular SMEs, micro-enterprises and start-ups, to step up their activities, expand and remain in the single market, thereby facilitating innovation and job creation. I am voting in favour of this report, which, in addition to supporting greater integration of businesses into the single market, is also in favour of the obligation to identify the origin of the products, thereby increasing information for consumers.  I also believe that it is essential for the European Union to analyse the future of the Digital Single Market, namely how best to create a European ecosystem to support startups, to analyse the better functioning of companies in the area of Sharing Economy and to increase European competitiveness also through trade agreements that will be established.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF)
text: In writing. Wanting against all kinds of protectionism, implementing the so-called "services" directive, the directive on the secondment of workers; and protecting craftsmen and SMEs is not possible. This report is absurd, I vote against it.

name: Nadine Morano (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report on the Single Market Strategy. The text includes supporting a single European system for protecting geographical indications for non-agricultural products, supporting country of origin indication and a mandatory system for providing essential information on handmade and industrial products.

name: Alessia Maria Mosca (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 Considering the importance of the single market as a source of economic integration and sustainable growth, we strongly support the Comi report on the Single Market Strategy. The removal of the remaining physical, legal and regulatory barriers will benefit the continent with higher levels of employment and will help to strengthen economic growth with particular effectiveness in the areas of innovation, which are particularly sensitive to the creation of a critical mass and more subject to non-tariff barriers. Economic growth cannot, in fact, be separated from a structural reform of the single market that can optimise costs for companies by reducing the fragmentation of markets. The single market is, first and foremost, a resource for European citizens and the key to all measures to support the Community economy. We particularly welcome the wish for the introduction of compulsory indication of origin of products. The measure, in fact, in addition to being in line with policies aimed at ensuring maximum transparency and protection for consumers, strengthens European products of excellence, protecting the high reputational level of made in from unfair competition practices. With equal conviction, we support the extension of geographical indications to non-agri-food products, sources of rural growth and ambassadors of the thousand-year-old traditions of our own.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the single market strategy. By adopting this report, we support not only companies and consumers, but also workers. An important aspect is to help micro-enterprises, small and medium-sized enterprises and start-ups, i.e. start-ups, develop. The report highlights the disadvantages of SMEs and start-ups, such as the fact that they find it more difficult to get credit than large companies and the differences in tax systems. The growth, development and long-term survival of such enterprises creates new job opportunities and contributes to innovation.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ Within the European integration process the achievement of the single market has always been a fundamental political priority. I have voted for this report that calls for a more pragmatic and incisive approach to a more ambitious single market strategy that will be more modern and innovative.

name: Dan Nica (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 In order to protect the objectives of the Single Market and generate growth and jobs, the EU must strengthen competitiveness. There is a need to remove unjustified barriers in the single market in order to achieve concrete and rapid results in competitiveness, sustainable economic growth, research, innovation, job creation, diversity for consumers and new economic models. Given that social enterprises account for 10-12% of all businesses in the EU, they should be promoted within the framework of internal market policies.  We call on the Commission, in further support from the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and programmes such as Horizon 2020, COSME and ESI Funds, to explore other ways of facilitating access to programmes and other instruments, especially for micro-enterprises, for example by reducing application periods to six months, simplifying applicable procedures, and improving the visibility of European funding.

name: Norica Nicolai (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Creating a truly integrated single market in the EU remains a top policy priority. As the resolution rightly highlights, unemployment – and in particular youth unemployment – makes the goal of a single market more important than ever, while it also represents a significant challenge. The resolution discusses the benefits of the Single Market Strategy and highlights the positive role that the European Parliament can play in suggesting even more specific policy initiatives under the umbrella of the Single Market Strategy, such as strengthening the competitiveness of businesses by reducing administrative burdens, supporting SMEs vital to the European economy and protecting and harmonising consumer rights in the single market. I endorse this resolution on the Single Market Strategy because these above—mentioned initiatives are all steps necessary to take if we want to create a deeper unified market and ensure economic prosperity across the EU.

name: Luděk Niedermayer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the report on the Single Market Strategy, which outlines new trends in the internal market in relation to identified gaps and shortcomings in its functioning. For example, the possibility of introducing a simplified VAT approach for the same category of e-commerce goods should be assessed. In practice, these would be new rules on the place of supply as regards VAT on digital services. I support the Commission in its intention to use COSME funding to finance information campaigns targeted at innovative young SMEs. SMEs would also certainly welcome the Commission's initiative to harmonise insolvency proceedings across the EU, from which they could promise to reduce the length of proceedings and reduce their costs.

name: Liadh Ní Riada (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – I voted against this report, which contained some very regressive and negative provisions. It is an alarming report which promotes austerity policies in addition to further transfers of sovereignty from national parliaments to the European Union. The view of my party Sinn Féin is that the solution to the ongoing economic and financial crisis is not to continue with the same policies that have created this crisis, but a policy that puts the needs of people first and not those of the market. The Single Market Strategy promotes a neo—liberal strategy which endorses austerity policies. The austerity measures being applied by undemocratic means in the EU countries worst hit by the crisis reflect the failure of the EU’s neo—liberal architecture. Sinn Féin are working in Europe to urgently reverse this policy and deliver solidarity and job creation within an economic system that serves people not profit. The single market and competitiveness have been used as arguments to justify attacks on workers’ rights, social inequalities, labour deregulation, wage devaluation and increasingly precarious employment, while fairer, more redistributive tax policies have been obstructed. Austerity is avoidable; it is a political choice that puts the interests of some above the interests of others.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 Completing the Single Market has always been and continues to be a top political priority in the european integration process.  The report calls for a fairer single market, stressing that a true single market should provide benefits and protection for citizens, consumers and businesses, consisting in better quality, greater diversity, reasonable prices and the safety of goods and services. For SMEs and start-ups, it is important that their innovation capacity is supported in every way possible, as they are the backbone of the European economy. The adopted strategy is expected to help Europe grow economically.

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Writing. It is hoped that the single market will be completed in the tradition of the Barroso and Junker Commission, which, contrary to the report, cannot only be viewed positively. In addition to good approaches in the report, particularly in the area of Support for SMEs, these positives are unfortunately partly offset by favours, especially by large groups.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported. The aim is to facilitate cross-border trade and create new opportunities for businesses. Estonia is a positive issue of the single digital market, which aims to create common rules and guarantee consumers greater rights in this rapidly evolving area.

name: Rolandas Paksas (EFDD)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Single Market offers opportunities to increase the competitiveness of the European economy. Decisive action is therefore needed to strengthen the integration of the Single Market.  The EU's single market must be stronger and fairer. The potential of the Single Market needs to be fully exploited by providing more opportunities for consumers and businesses and by promoting modernisation and innovation.  More effective enforcement and better regulation require a reduction in the administrative burden and compliance costs for businesses and the elimination of unnecessary legislation. SMEs and start-ups should be helped to address their problems. In view of the rapid growth of the social economy, social enterprises need to be supported. It should be noted that insolvency procedures should be harmonised across the EU and the Commission should therefore pay greater attention to the implementation of the legislative initiative on corporate insolvency. The framework standards for public-private partnerships between Member States should also be harmonised.

name: Margot Parker (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP fundamentally disagrees with the report which criticises Member States for not transposing EU legislation. Moreover, we also strongly disagree with calls for further harmonisation and legislative proposals from the Commission. UKIP believes that the main problem with the Single Market is over-regulation which damages SMEs causing higher prices and less choice for the consumer.

name: Aldo Patriciello (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The creation of the single market has developed considerably in recent years; both the Barroso Commission and the Juncker Commission have put in place a number of measures to this end. I regard the strategy 'Improving the single market: more opportunities for citizens and businesses' as necessary and complementary given the level of impact it would have on European economic operators, especially SMEs. I welcome the measures that have been put forward and therefore vote in favour of them.

name: Eva Paunova (PPE)
text: in writing. – The single market strategy is the Commission’s global roadmap to unleash the full potential of the single market with the objective of creating a modern, more innovative, deeper and fairer single market. Its focus lies in particular on aspects aimed at helping businesses (especially SMEs, micro-enterprises and start-ups) to scale up their activities, grow and stay in the single market. I support this initiative and report especially in creating call for a simplified VAT approach in the e-commerce sector; a call for facilitating SMEs access to EU funds.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The European market of 500 million consumers with great purchasing power to which they wish to access as quickly and easily as possible must be organised in such a way as to provide consumers with all the relevant information necessary for informed selection. This labelling of the origin of certain products contributes precisely to the recognition of Europe in its diversity and to highlighting the quality of the product.  'Made In' label introduced on the market for the first time in 1887 In the last century, it has contributed to the fact that national countries and economic operators have strongly cared about the quality of the products they produce and place on the market, and because of consumers' perception of the country of origin. In this way, the label has significantly contributed to the branding of products, as well as the recognition of individual brands and their products through an acceptable price, longevity of the product and guaranteed quality behind the country of origin.  Aren't these exactly the ideas that we want to implement today through a circular economy versus an unsustainable consumption system that we are witnessing nowadays? I believe that the responsibility of all stakeholders in the Single European Market, including consumers, precisely by introducing a mandatory country of origin label for certain non-agricultural products can, as an added value to products, help the European economy in the time ahead.

name: Pina Picierno (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The report adopted today presents a new holistic perspective of the single market, for a social market economy based on knowledge, attentive to the environment. By proposing a series of concrete measures to increase consumer protection and the creation of sustainable jobs, ensuring social inclusion and fair treatment for workers, it will lead to an improvement in the well-being of European citizens. The Commission must act in favour of SMEs, start-ups and the development of the sharing economy, while avoiding offering opportunities for dishonest entrepreneurs to circumvent workers' rights rules and consumer guarantee standards. The commission will have to develop an appropriate definition of a social economy enterprise and a regulatory framework that promotes its growth and pursue a strategy for fiscal equity, combating widespread tax evasion practices. Emphasis is placed on the importance of vocational education and training in creating more skilled jobs and on the need to ensure more social security and protection for workers. Finally, thanks to the efforts of our group and the Italian delegation in particular, it calls for the establishment of a European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products and 'Made in' labelling.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D)
text: Written. ‒ The European Parliament supports the Commission's overall objectives of the Single Market Strategy for Goods and Services, 'Improving the Single Market: More Opportunities for People and Businesses', and welcomes its actions in key areas enabling the full potential of the Single Market for the benefit of consumers, employees and businesses, in particular start-ups, with a view to increasing the number of sustainable jobs and the growth and development of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs). It encourages the Commission to develop cross-sectoral policies that deliver a fairer and more competitive single market in line with Title II of the TFEU on provisions that have a general application. However, it stresses that the Single Market Strategy must not ignore the potential of the industrial sector in terms of sustainable growth and quality jobs in Europe. I welcome Parliament's report and believe that the Single Market Strategy can provide new opportunities for SMEs, which are the basis of the European economy, and micro and innovative start-ups.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 More than 20 years of single market have meant accelerating the process of capitalist concentration and accumulation in favour of monopolistic groups, the dismantling of instruments at the service of Member States for sovereign regulation of economies, privatisations and the liberalisation of strategic sectors and public services, the harmonisation of legislation. But it's not enough. Large monopolistic capital wants more, and the objective of deepening the integration of the single market and contributing to structural reforms is explicit, read the liquidation of the state's social functions and labour rights. The single market has eclipsed propagated concepts such as convergence, cooperation and solidarity, deepening neoliberalism. In his name and in the name of the famous "competitiveness", the attack on workers' rights, social inequalities, labor deregulation, wage devaluation and the precariousness of work was promoted and more redistributive and fair fiscal policies were destroyed or contradicted. It serves capitalist objectives of further deepening the concentration of wealth in the major powers and economic groups, makes it standard for deregulation, liberalisation and exploitation in the economies of the Member States, imposing a single socio-economic model on peoples and workers contrary to their interests, rights and legitimate aspirations. We voted against it.

name: Andrej Plenković (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Single Market has been and remains the cornerstone of EU integration and a muster of sustainable development and job creation by enabling trade between Member States. It defines the EU as a single area without any internal borders and regulatory barriers to the free movement of services, goods, workers and capital.  For these reasons, the EU single market is arguably one of the Union's greatest achievements, as it encourages and facilitates the daily business life of European economic operators and consumers through the use of a variety of mechanisms. I supported MEP Comi's report, as I believe the single market needs to be strategically prospered, developed and strengthened through cross-cutting policies. The EU market needs to evolve towards new market technologies, in particular the digitisation of processes.  Removing all non-economic barriers - legal, political or economic - must be the focus of the EU, as well as achieving a greater degree of transparency in public procurement procedures and local market defragmentation. In addition, the Commission should oversee the implementation and implementation of legal aspects that must comply with EU law in order to prevent possible breaches of the provisions governing this area.

name: Salvatore Domenico Pogliese (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The text of the communication includes very interesting actions, such as the VAT Action Plan, the legislative proposal on business insolvency, the passport for services and a legislative initiative to prevent discrimination against consumers based on nationality or country of residence. But the most important aspect is undoubtedly that relating to "Made In". This is a battle of strategic importance for Italy. In the text, my colleague Lara Comi has included proposals on geographical indication for non-agricultural products and on compulsory labelling for craft and industrial products. I believe it is essential to provide relevant information on retail products. In particular, the indication of the country of origin remains essential in order to protect consumers and strengthen the fight against counterfeiting. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tomasz Piotr Poręba (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This report sets out Parliament's position on the Commission's single market strategy. The report is supported by many of the main proposals made in the Commission Communication, although a number of additional requests have also been made consistent with the priorities previously set by Parliament's political groups.  The report has a predominantly positive tone and recognises the need to improve the single market, especially in the services sector. It also echoes the call made in dalton's report for the necessary elimination of non-tariff barriers. The report has several points of concern, in particular support for the product safety and market surveillance package currently under consideration, which is blocked in the Council, rather than proposing an alternative approach that would allow the Commission to rationalise proposals and propose only those parts that are relevant. The report put forward proposals for VAT rates in e-commerce; mandatory labelling of certain types of products; geographical indications of non-agricultural products. Nevertheless, overall, the report has a sufficiently positive tone with regard to the priorities for improving the Single Market. I hereby supported the report.

name: Franck Proust (PPE)
text: In writing. I supported this report, which provides a response to the Single Market Strategy presented in October 2015 by the European Commission. Achieving the full potential of the single market must be the objective of every economic policy decided at European level. To achieve this, insisting on modernity and innovation to make this single market more integrated and fair are necessary guidelines. With this in mind, it is important to remember that it is SMEs but also small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and start-ups that will be the drivers of economic dynamism in the single market.

name: Paulo Rangel (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 The single market is one of the main foundations of European integration, constituting an engine of sustainable growth, stimulating job creation, facilitating trade between Member States and ensuring a highly competitive economy.  The report on the Single Market Strategy provides that the progress of recent years has opened up possibilities for improvement in different areas. To this end, the document is particularly focused on supporting the growth and proliferation of start-ups, micro-, small and medium-sized enterprises in a more open, innovative and deeper European single market, notably by targeting the digital sector and fostering global supply chains.  Without prejudice to the obligations of economic operators, in particular as regards labelling and geographical indication of products, the report underlines the importance of the European single market for the European project.  Therefore, considering that, in accordance with Article 3 TFEU, the Union must pursue a genuine single market and regard it as a common good of all European citizens, I am voting in favour of this report.

name: Julia Reid (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEPs have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP fundamentally disagrees with the report which criticises Member States for not transposing EU legislation. Moreover, we also strongly disagree with calls for further harmonisation and legislative proposals from the Commission. UKIP believes that the main problem with the single market is over-regulation which damages SMEs causing higher prices and less choice for the consumer.

name: Dominique Riquet (ALDE)
text: In writing. This report aims to provide guidance on one of the biggest well-known ills of the European single market: its fragmentation. Combined with the crisis that has pushed the number of unemployed people in the EU to 22 million in 2015, this represents a shortfall of almost 1000 billion euros.  Removing unnecessary barriers, non-tariff barriers, and promoting greater legislative and regulatory harmonisation could lead to rapid results in terms of competitiveness, sustainable growth, research, innovation, consumer protection, job creation and investment in infrastructure in particular, as well as the development of SMEs and the most innovative enterprises within the Union (including facilitating their access to finance).  While this report is not of a legislative nature at the moment, it remains a strong political message to the Commission and The Member States by MEPs to move towards more integration.  This is an initiative that can only be welcomed and encouraged, which is why I voted in favour of this text.

name: Robert Rochefort (ALDE)
text: In writing. The single market, beyond the symbol it represents for European integration, remains a vehicle for growth, competitiveness, innovation and employment, provided it adapts and responds to new developments. It is an asset that must be used in the best possible way to strengthen the European economy, consolidate its strengths and unleash its potential. Unwarranted barriers to it must therefore be removed.  Therefore, this House affirms its support for the overall objectives of the Commission's strategy for the single market for goods and services and calls for a more modern and innovative, deeper and fairer single market. Our resolution covers many aspects such as the adaptation of the single market to the digital revolution, the importance of adequate consumer information and country of origin indication, and the need to ensure a high level of consumer protection both online and offline. Overall satisfied with the final text, I gave it my support.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The European Parliament can make the single market strategy more ambitious by deepening it and making it more innovative. The Group of European Socialists has managed to negotiate the introduction of many measures related to sustainable growth, job creation, social inclusion, consumer protection, territorial cohesion, environmental concerns, protection and incentives for SMEs, cost relief from administrative positions; tax justice and the fight against tax avoidance and fraud, health and safety at work, qualification of workers, etc.

name: Inmaculada Rodríguez-Piñero Fernández (S&D)
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this report because it supports the overall objectives of the Commission's new strategy to achieve a fairer and more competitive single market in line with Title II TFEU, and appreciates its actions in key areas to exploit the full potential of the single market for the benefit of consumers, workers and businesses , especially emerging ones, in order to increase the number of quality sustainable jobs and promote the growth of SMEs. In addition, this report calls on the Commission to submit without resignation a legislative proposal for the establishment of a single European system for the protection of geographical indications for non-agricultural products in the Union, which will have many positive effects for the whole European business and social fabric. It also reiterates its call for rapid adoption by the Council of the package of measures on product safety and market surveillance, stressing the importance of the indication of the country of origin in products intended for retail sale.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the European Parliament's initiative report on the Single Market Strategy because this report highlights important elements, particularly for European consumers and workers. First of all, I am pleased to see that the European Parliament has been in favour of the introduction at European level of a mandatory system for communicating essential information on handmade and industrial products. This system would be a real added value for consumers and I hope that the Commission will hear our appeal.  I am also very pleased with Parliament's favourable vote, which considers the principle of equal pay for equal work in the same place as an important tool to combat market distortions. European citizens and workers expect Europe to fight social dumping more effectively, and respect for this principle in the context of the secondment of workers would be a first step forward. In view of all these elements, it seemed important to me that the European Parliament should support this text. I hope that the Commission will be ambitious on both issues.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. \u2012 The report on the single market strategy, drawn up on Parliament's initiative, is of particular relevance today to Europe, which is looking for a response to the economic downturn and the crisis of overproduction of agriculture. We support the general objectives set out by the Commission in the Single Market for Goods and Services strategy 'Improving the Single Market: Improving the Single Market: More Opportunities for Citizens and Businesses' and actions to unlock the potential of the Single Market for consumers, workers and businesses, especially start-ups, increase sustainable jobs and encourage small and medium-sized enterprises.  It should be noted that the forthcoming mid-term review of the Europe 2020 strategy should also set new targets, in particular to achieve a competitive social market economy by 2020, while ensuring sustainable economic growth. In this place, personally, I see insufficient attention to the problem of fair competition, abuse of dominant power. That is what is a significant trigger for the current crisis in the dairy sector in many EU countries.  Parliament's draft resolution rightly identifies other areas that are neglected , especially in labour-intensive sectors such as retail and accommodation businesses, to exploit the potential of creating new jobs, to integrate and address youth unemployment. We pay close attention to innovation, but we must not forget the less innovative sectors, but therefore not a smaller part of the economy.  In the draft resolution, we are making almost 100 recommendations to improve the work of the Commission and the Member States in this area, and I very much want to count on support.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE)
text: in writing. ‒ Last year the EC presented a Strategy on how to boost the performance of the European Single Market. The document, focusing on services and product markets, underlines some ways to enable a balanced development of the collaborative economy and to help SMEs and start—ups to grow. All of those initiatives are aimed at releasing the full potential of the EU Single Market. However, the European Parliament’s document addressing the Single Market Strategy, with all its positive aspects, includes points that could even further divide the internal market. I believe the principle ‘equal pay for equal work’ is not only against the idea of the single market, but fundamentally inconsistent with the mechanism of competition and basic principles of economics. Wages should reflect differences in productivity levels, and cannot be uniform. Likewise, companies across Europe differ in terms of quality and technological advancement of their products. Moreover, the report again speaks about ‘social dumping’, which has never been defined in economic or legal terms. I believe both slogans ‘equal pay for equal work’ and ‘social dumping’ encourage protectionist measures that would further hamper the functioning of the single market and harm competition. Hence, I abstained.

name: Fernando Ruas (PPE)
text: in writing. The completion of the single market is one of the key objectives of the European integration process. However, in recent years, the global economic, financial and business context has changed radically and the challenges to be addressed are increasingly significant, affecting the internal market considerably. In recent years, important progress has been made, but the current situation requires an even more pragmatic and incisive approach. This report proposes measures such as: a VAT action plan, a legislative proposal on business insolvency, the creation of a passport for services and a legislative initiative to prevent discrimination against consumers on grounds of nationality or country of residence. These are concrete measures that will certainly have a direct impact and a leverage effect on the market and on strengthening consumer protection. In order to achieve a more modern, innovative and fair single market, policy priorities should be to strengthen business competitiveness, improve budget implementation, better regulation and strengthen consumer protection. In fact, this work needs to be continued swiftly and effectively, which is why I voted in favour of this report.

name: Tokia Saïfi (PPE)
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this report, which sets out a strategy for the single market. While the single market has certainly seen many positive developments in recent years, the completion of the single market would be a source of significant gains. Indeed, the fragmentation of the single market is one of the main obstacles to greater economic growth. The aim here is to develop a strategy to deepen and modernise the integration of the single market, through further harmonisation of legislation.  This report calls for a reduction in administrative and compliance costs for businesses, particularly SMEs. It also calls for harnessing the full potential of the digital age with the creation, for example, of an all-electronic public procurement system or the recent establishment of an anti-unreported labour platform. I voted in favour of this text because it calls for greater consumer protection. Labelling, mentioning the product of origin or creating a single European system for protecting geographical indications for non-agricultural products would help to better protect consumers and better combat counterfeiting.

name: Massimiliano Salini (PPE)
text: in writing. \u2012 This text stands out not only for being an own-initiative report by Parliament on such an important subject as the Single Market, but also, and above all, for being focused in all its aspects on the point of view of small and medium-sized enterprises. The measures requested of the Commission are aimed at increasing the opportunities for business expansion within the Single Market by means of more harmonious and fair rules. Firstly, the report stresses the need to implement and strengthen existing rules in order to remove the obstacles that make it more difficult to offer cross-border services. Secondly, it takes up the initiative already taken by Parliament in favour of geographical indication of origin for non-agricultural products, making manufacturing excellence a strength of companies and a guarantee for consumers. This point, in particular, is very important for the Italian production system.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Report on the strategy for the single market, since our position on competitiveness in the context of an internal market economy is totally contrary to the ideas set out in the report. On the one hand, it points to some serious problems relating to SMEs and start-ups, but the focus is on improving the single market by increasing competition and eliminating the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ The Single Market Strategy must emphasise the social market economy, ensuring social inclusion, delivering high standards of environmental protection and upholding workers’ rights. Improved health and safety regulations in the workplace will contribute to better public health and harmonised standards across the EU will reduce persistent health inequalities. Integrating people with disabilities must also be a key aim. A single market strategy with these priorities will help create a fairer, more productive, and healthier society.

name: Christel Schaldemose (S&D)
text: Written. \u2012 The Danish Social Democrats want a well-functioning and fair internal market where workers and businesses compete on a level playing field and where consumers are properly protected. That is why we also support the report, which in many areas supports these principles. However, support for the report is not unlimited support for the concrete proposals in the report, but for the proper functioning of the internal market. We will take a position on proposals such as the sharing economy, service passports and VAT simplification when the concrete proposals are there and we can see the precise content.  Simplification of VAT may, for example, be a good idea, but it should not lead to Member States not being able to charge the desired rate.  Overall, an increased focus on the functioning of the internal market is a good thing. However, it is important that we consider not only how the market works for businesses, but also for consumers, workers and citizens.

name: Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. The report is a clear backlash to the European Commission's single market strategy, for which labour rights are a mere appendix to the freedom to provide services. Parliament should be clearly positioned to ensure that collective bargaining and the right of European nations and peoples to regulate in accordance with the interests of the workers residing there are respected. That's why I voted against it.

name: Remo Sernagiotto (ECR)
text: in writing. \u2012 I think it is essential to be able to give the final consumer an ever greater and more detailed overview of the origin of the products he buys. That was the reason why I voted in favour of compulsory indication of the origin of products with the aim of protecting the safety of citizens. In doing so, we will be able to strengthen, and at the same time step up, the fight against counterfeiting, the real scourge of our country. If "Made in Italy" were a brand it would be the third best known brand in the world after Coca Cola and Visa, so here is the need for greater traceability of products. Through this resolution, Parliament has also asked the European Commission to consider introducing at European level a definition of 'innovative start-up', a formula recently adopted in Italy and which has produced excellent results.

name: Jill Seymour (EFDD)
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP MEP’s have voted against this non-legislative report. UKIP fundamentally disagrees with the report which criticises Member States for not transposing EU legislation. Moreover, we also strongly disagree with calls for further harmonisation and legislative proposals from the Commission.

name: Siôn Simon (S&D)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this strategy which delivers a new holistic vision of the Single Market based on green, knowledge-based social market economy which seeks to improve the well-being of European citizens by proposing practical measures that need to guarantee equal treatment and social inclusion, creation of sustainable jobs and growth and high level consumer protection.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 The Single Market is one of the fundamental pillars on which the EU is built. For this reason, I voted in favour of adopting this resolution, in line with the ECR's position. I consider it essential that we focus on improving this single market strategy. The resolution therefore provides for the strategy to focus on creating a more modern and innovative single market in order to strengthen the competitiveness of businesses, improve regulation and increase consumer protection.

name: Monika Smolková (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 Completing the Single Market in the EU is a top political priority in the Process of European Integration. The Single Market requires ambitious measures such as the Investment Plan for Europe, the European Energy Union, the Digital Single Market Strategy in Europe and the Capital Markets Union. The VAT Action Plan, the legislative proposal on corporate insolvency, the service passport and the legislative initiative aimed at preventing discrimination that harms the consumer and is based on nationality or place of residence are also measures for the single market. All this should make it easier for existing businesses to become more competitive, reduce their tax and administrative barriers and facilitate their entry into the markets of other Member States. In addition, foreign businesses and private investment need to be attracted to the European single market and the creation of a new economic and business environment, in particular start-ups, micro, small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: Writing. The Single Market has been, and continues to be, a pillar of european Union integration and a driver for sustainable growth and jobs, by promoting trade in the European Union while ensuring a highly competitive social market economy. The report on the Single Market Strategy contains some good points, such as strengthening the development of SMEs and combating late payments. I am pleased that the report calls for a legislative proposal to address unfair geo-blocking and to address the lack of tax coordination. The report also calls for proposals to prevent employment and tax abuses through simple rules. A paragraph on standardisation, which places a strong emphasis on the role of innovation and calls for the development of high standards for quality and safety in the field of European industrial policy and the promotion of these standards at international level, is particularly welcome. The report on public procurement also emphasises the inclusion of rules to improve their service to public policy, Member States and local professional companies. For the reasons set out above, I voted in favour of the report at the meeting.

name: Davor Ivo Stier (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Single Market is a driver of sustainable growth and job creation, but also a cornerstone of European integration, as it enables trade across the Union. It also ensures a highly competitive social market economy. I support this report, as deepening the European internal market is one of the main economic issues, in particular as regards the development of new technologies.  If physical, legal and technical barriers are removed, even greater progress can be made in the field of the single market, where many positive changes have occurred in recent years. I believe that only with the full support of all Member States and their cooperation will the full potential of the single market be realised.  Also, in order to achieve concrete and rapid results in terms of competitiveness and job creation, it is necessary to remove unjustified barriers in the single market. In my view, one of the priorities is to reduce unnecessary regulatory administrative and practical barriers for SMEs, as SMEs need to be the engine of the business sector in Europe.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE)
text: Written. ‒ The Single Market has been and remains the cornerstone of European integration and a driver of sustainable growth and job creation, as it enables trade throughout the Territory of the Union and guarantees a highly competitive market economy. The deepening of the European internal market remains a major economic issue, especially in the context of the development of new technologies.  Positive changes have taken place in recent years, but unjustified barriers need to be removed in almost all areas to achieve even more, as barriers make consumers less choice and products and services more expensive. The economic consequences of the financial crisis continue to be felt and in several Member States GDP is still below 2008 levels, which requires a truly strategic approach to further integrate the single market. A genuine single market should benefit citizens, consumers and businesses in terms of better quality, greater diversity, reasonable prices and the security of goods and services. I support the recommendations set out in this report, as I believe that the establishment of an internal market that guarantees the full free movement of goods, persons, services and capital is a key objective of the European Union. I believe that the guidelines here lead to a more modern and innovative single market.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I voted in favour of the report on the Single Market Strategy. We need the completion of the single market, which will be a pillar of EU integration and a driver for sustainable growth and jobs. Despite developments in recent years, we still have many reserves, particularly in removing unjustified physical, legal and technical barriers. I agree with the report, which supports the overall objectives of the Commission's Single Market strategy for goods and services and measures in key areas that will exploit the full potential of the single market for the benefit of consumers and businesses, especially start-ups. This will increase the number of sustainable jobs and strengthen SMEs.

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported today's European Parliament resolution on the single market strategy. This document responds to the European Commission's single market plan and gives the European Parliament the opportunity to highlight some specific issues that it considers important. I believe that such a topic is, above all, a theme of supporting SMEs, the specificities of which must be taken into account in each of the future steps, starting with not burdening them with further unnecessary administration and ending with their active support through tailor-made provisions in the various areas of the single market. However, I also consider it equally important to reflect in other considerations the position of consumers, who should only be in the way of genuinely properly justified barriers to the principle of public interest for the use of services in the single market. With increased mobility of European citizens, there is also a legitimate requirement for cross-border use of services or the possibility to benefit from uniform consumer protection rules.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης (
text: GUE/NGL), in writing. \u2012 Policies promoted in the context of the single market exacerbate the dismantling of the real economy, divergences and asymmetries in growth, promote tax evasion, privatisation and deregulation of trade relations.  The single market and competitiveness are used as arguments to justify attacks on workers' rights, social inequalities, labour deregulation, wage devaluation and increasingly precarious employment, while fairer tax policies are falling apart or hindered.  Particularly negative is the reference in the report to the need in the single market to promote negotiations on the transatlantic TTIP agreement. That is why we voted against the report.

name: Ελευθέριος Συναδινός (NI)
text: Writing. \u2012 We are voting against, the single market, apart from being non-functional in general, has caused a great loss of valuable human resources in our country, as in all the other economically weak countries of the Union.

name: József Szájer (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the eu's new strategy on the internal market, because I believe that the proposals made in the reports will help to fulfil the potential of the single market and serve as a good starting point for Europe's success on the global economic scene. Today's ambitious and pragmatic strategy focuses on results. The next step is for the EU institutions, in cooperation with the Member States, to implement these specific measures as quickly as possible. In my view, every end must be made to ensure that consumers who wish to buy services or products in another Member State, whether online or in person, do not have to face different prices, changing sales conditions or different delivery methods unless objective and verifiable arguments can be substantiated. The European Commission and the European Consumer Centre often receive complaints that customers have been wrongly treated differently on the basis of nationality or place of residence. This practice should be discontinued in the future. Continue to reduce investment restrictions and create new opportunities for consumers, professionals and companies. The single market must always keep pace with change, so it must encourage and adopt innovative new business models.

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the single market strategy report, which supports the overall objectives of the Commission Communication on the Single Market Strategy for Goods and Services. I agree with the report that the single market should not be looked at in isolation from other horizontal policy areas, in particular the Digital Single Market, health, social and consumer protection, labour law and citizens' mobility, the environment, sustainable development, energy, transport and foreign policy. I share the view that, in order to achieve tangible and rapid results in terms of competitiveness, sustainable growth, research, innovation, job creation, consumer choice and new business models, unjustified barriers in the single market need to be removed as a matter of urgency. To this end, efforts should be made to better harmonise legislation, taking appropriate measures to overcome the unjustified obstacles that Member States have erected. I welcome the fact that the report addressed the importance of consumer protection, the protection of workers and environmental and health protection. Furthermore, I agree with the calls for the Commission to seek to introduce country-by-country reporting obligations for transnational companies and to coordinate member states' efforts to find legislative solutions for a sharing economy.

name: Adam Szejnfeld (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. –u2012 The Single Market creates an opportunity not only for businesses and workers, but also gives consumers the opportunity to choose more goods and services of higher quality and lower prices. This is one of the greatest achievements of a united Europe. However, these opportunities are not always fully exploited. That is why it is so important to strive to improve the functioning of the Single Market.  Parliament's report assessing the Single Market Strategy presented by the European Commission last year highlights a number of important issues that should be prioritised. These include m.in support for SMEs and innovative start-ups, the fight against so-called congestion, deregulation of professions, the promotion of the public-private partnership formula or, finally, the full exploitation of the potential of the digital revolution. Unfortunately, parliament's document also includes a provision on the implementation of the controversial principle of 'equal pay for equal work in the same place'. In my opinion, it is fundamentally contrary to the idea of the Single Market. Different companies bear completely different operating costs and those from another country have additional burdens which are not borne by local companies. In my opinion, therefore, this slogan conceals protectionism and the desire to restrict competition in the common market, rather than the protection of workers' rights.  I have therefore chosen to vote against this report.

name: Hannu Takkula (ALDE)
text: Written. \u2012 I voted in favour of origin marking on certain points in the report because it is important for consumers that they also know the origins of products within the EU.

name: Claudia Țapardel (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 The Single Market is the European Union's economic development engine and its main advantage compared to other international players. It is therefore a strategic objective of the Community institutions. The European Commission's Single Market Strategy, adopted last year, focuses on increasing opportunities for citizens and businesses through the VAT Action Plan, the business insolvency proposal, the service passport, the prevention of discrimination detrimental to consumers, the regulation of public procurement, intellectual property rights and market monitoring. In particular, the strategy includes provisions on strengthening the social market economy guaranteeing social inclusion, creating sustainable jobs, protecting consumers, measures to encourage SMEs and micro-enterprises, combating tax evasion, protecting the environment, developing social economy enterprises, combating the underground economy, facilitating access to the patent system, protecting agricultural products of certified geographical origin. All these provisions create the prerequisites for the development of a green, knowledge-based economy, focused on achieving the prosperity of European citizens and guaranteeing equal treatment for all. I therefore support the adoption of the current report.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D)
text: In writing. I have validated my colleague Comi's position, together with socialist amendments to defend workers' rights. The completion of the single market has always been and remains a major political priority in the European integration process.  In recent years, the situation has changed dramatically. The difficulties to overcome are becoming more and more pressing and weigh considerably on the internal market: on the one hand, the rising unemployment that afflicts European citizens, especially young people, while at the same time the fabric of businesses and the competitiveness of the latter are weakening and, on the other hand, the problem of immigration. Very important progress has been made in several areas under the Barroso Commission's mandate.  The current situation, however, requires even more pragmatic and effective action. In a short period of time, the Juncker Commission has already deployed important and ambitious initiatives, such as the Investment Plan for Europe, the Energy Union, the Digital Single Market Strategy and the Capital Markets Union.

name: Pavel Telička (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ Despite positive developments, the single market is still underperforming in most areas, and Europe’s competitiveness is suffering from it. This resolution proposes a new strategic approach to achieve a better integration of the single market, which is why I voted in favour of it. Europe should exploit the full potential of digitalisation and innovation, create a more start-up and risk friendly environment, but also ensure that legislation, namely in the area of taxation, is harmonised across Member States. Lowering administrative burdens and compliance costs on businesses, especially SMEs, and repealing unnecessary legislation, while continuing to ensure high standards of consumer, employee, health and environmental protection, is key to delivering the objectives of the strategy.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski (ECR)
text: Writing. \u2012 Mr President, I supported the report by Mrs Comi, a Member of the European Parliament, because the single market was and is the basis for EU integration and is the driving force behind sustainable growth and job creation, which facilitates trade throughout the EU. Therefore, laws and action at EU level should be part of a single strategic vision and should therefore be coherent and without contradiction. It is worth noting that the report presented to Parliament unequivocally underlines the need to develop a new strategy for the Single Market that complements actions in other areas. These should be cross-cutting actions to ensure, in particular, faster sustainable job creation and improve the material situation of European citizens through practical tools such as attracting investors to the European Union and developing the global competitiveness of European businesses. It is important that the proposals in question comply with the principles of better regulation.

name: Romana Tomc (PPE)
text: Writing. I supported the Single Market Strategy as completing the single market as one of the priorities of European integration. The current situation requires a pragmatic and harsh approach. The political priorities to be ed are: increased business competitiveness, better enforcement and law-making, and enhanced consumer protection. One of the priorities remains the Services Directive, under which the EC should ensure stricter control of transposition in the Member States. The announced legislative proposal on insolvency and the early stage of corporate restructuring is also important. Important and ambitious measures have been taken under the leadership of the current President of the EC, including the European Energy Union. These are concrete measures that will certainly have a direct impact and an incentive effect on the market and strengthen consumer protection.

name: Estefanía Torres Martínez (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Report on the strategy for the single market, since our position on competitiveness in the context of an internal market economy is totally contrary to the ideas set out in the report. On the one hand, it points to some serious problems relating to SMEs and start-ups, but the focus is on improving the single market by increasing competition and eliminating the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Mylène Troszczynski (ENF)
text: In writing. The single market remains the alpha and omega of economic progress. Out of him point of salvation. The profound difficulties facing the European Union are due only to the inadequacy of the process of integration of the single market. The "intermediate" step towards federalism in which the Union finds itself blocked by the fault of the Member States alone is presented as the sole reason for unemployment, recession and disavowal of the peoples. The obstacles remain numerous and must therefore be overcome even in reverse of the will of the Member States and the people. Any questioning or criticism is prohibited. This text is a litany.  I am voting against the adoption of this report.

name: István Ujhelyi (S&D)
text: Writing. \u2012 The completement of the single market has always been and will continue to be a fundamental political priority in the European integration process. In recent years, however, the environment has changed radically. The challenges to be solved are even more important and have a special impact on the internal market: on the one hand, rising unemployment affecting EU citizens and, in particular, young people, which is weakening businesses and competitiveness, and, on the other hand, the problem of immigration. I voted in favour.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. We voted against this Report on the strategy for the single market, since our position on competitiveness in the context of an internal market economy is totally contrary to the ideas set out in the report. On the one hand, it points to some serious problems relating to SMEs and start-ups, but the focus is on improving the single market by increasing competition and eliminating the sovereignty of the Member States.

name: Viktor Uspaskich (ALDE)
text: Writing. – I support the common objectives set out in the Commission's Single Market for Goods and Services strategy 'Improving the Single Market: Improving the Single Market: More Opportunities for Citizens and Businesses', and I welcome its actions in key areas to unlock the full potential of the Single Market for consumers, workers and businesses, especially start-ups, to increase sustainable jobs and to foster and develop SMEs.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of report on the Single Market Strategy. The report supports the overall objectives of the Commission’s Single Market Strategy for goods and services: ‘Upgrading the Single Market: more opportunities for people and business’. The report emphasises that the strategy has good potential to help ensure economic prosperity, increase the creation of sustainable jobs and growth, improve the well—being of Europeans by practical measures, make the European Union attractive for investments and develop the global competitiveness of European businesses. On the other hand, the report warns that the implementation of this strategy is needed to avoid inconsistencies and overlaps between the different initiatives. The report equally underlines that proposals should be evidence-based and in line with better regulation principles.

name: Ramón Luis Valcárcel Siso (PPE)
text: in writing. In this report, the European Parliament responds to the single market strategy launched by the European Commission in October 2015. It is necessary to move towards an ever fairer, more modern, more innovative and deeper single market, objectives contained in this text. That is why I think it is appropriate to vote in your favour.

name: Derek Vaughan (S&D)
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this report because it supports the overall objectives of the Commission’s Single Market Strategy for goods and services: ‘Upgrading the Single Market: more opportunities for people and business’, and appreciates its actions in key areas to unleash the full potential of the single market for the benefit of consumers, employees and businesses, in particular start-ups, to increase the number of sustainable jobs and to grow and develop SMEs; encourages the Commission to develop cross-cutting policies designed to achieve a fairer and more competitive single market in line with Title II of the TFEU on provisions having a general application.

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE)
text: Written. 'I support the objectives of the Commission's internal market strategy for goods and services: 'Improving the Single Market: more opportunities for people and businesses'.
