The internal market is in the interests of consumers, workers and businesses, especially start-ups, of more sustainable employment and for the growth and development of SMEs. I voted in favour of this report because it stresses that a genuine internal market must provide benefits and protection to citizens, consumers and businesses in the form of better quality, greater variety, reasonable prices and safe goods and services.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat (GUE/NGL)
text: In writing. One of the main objectives of European integration remains the strengthening of deregulation to enable the completion of a single market following neoliberal logic. While this report takes note of the rise in unemployment and in particular that of young people and the decline in the competitiveness of companies, it does not call into question their causes, that is to say first and foremost the austerity policies largely responsible for this situation. On the contrary, the report encourages us to keep the same course and to continue in the same neoliberal logic with the consequences we know of it. Unsurprisingly, it recommends reducing administrative and tax barriers in order to free up capital. Strengthening competition, removing The sovereignty of Member States in this area, encouraging public-private partnerships and finally not tolerating any breach of the rules of the single market are the way to go. It is always the same with the same negative consequences for the rights of workers and citizens.  Like all members of my group, I remain firmly opposed to the construction of this so-called single market and the widespread deregulation it entails, so I voted against it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. \u2012 These mechanisms, such as the Single Market, accentuate the dismantling of sovereign regulation instruments of economies, promote economic dominance and cause divergence and development asymmetries. They are also promoters of tax avoidance and evasion and the transfer of profits to tax havens, privatisations, deregulation of trade relations and capital concentration. The Single Market has eclipsed propagated concepts such as convergence, cooperation and solidarity, deepening neoliberalism. In his name and the famous competitiveness, the attack on workers' rights, social inequalities, labor deregulation, wage devaluation and wage devaluation of labor was promoted, and more redistributive and fair erredistributive fiscal policies were destroyed or contradicted.  Citing so-called concerns such as lack of growth, high levels of unemployment, the inability to finance SMEs and the very low levels of investment, the European Commission shuffles and re-launched the Single Market Strategy.  Unlike most, we firmly reject it. It serves capitalist objectives of further deepening the concentration of wealth in the major powers and economic groups, makes it standard for deregulation, liberalisation and exploitation in the economies of the Member States, imposing a single socio-economic model on peoples and workers, contrary to their interests, rights and legitimate aspirations.

name: Harald Vilimsky (ENF)
text: Writing. This report shows good approaches, particularly in the area of SME support, but unfortunately these positives are partly offset by favours, especially by large corporations.

name: Beatrix von Storch (EFDD)
text: Writing. I did not agree with the European Parliament's resolution on the strategy for the internal market. The report points out that the creation of the internal market, which ensures the free movement of goods, people, services and capital, is a fundamental objective of the Union. It stresses the need to remove the remaining barriers in the internal market in order to achieve tangible and rapid results in terms of competitiveness, sustainable growth, research, innovation, job creation, consumer choice and new business models. However, the report considers that, in order to achieve these objectives, efforts should be made, where necessary and appropriate, to strengthen the harmonisation of legislation. That is the wrong way to go. Rules should not be harmonised, nor is it necessary to create an internal market. The report itself is wordy and comprehensive and full of other points that, above all, have one effect: more legislative proposals, more regulation and, therefore, more EU.

name: Iuliu Winkler (PPE)
text: in writing. – I voted on the report on the Digital Single Market Strategy. I welcome the rapporteur's concern for removing unjustified barriers in the single market, achieving concrete and rapid results in competitiveness, sustainable economic growth, research, innovation, job creation, diversity for consumers and new economic models. The report also appreciates the focus of the Commission's strategy for the single market in goods and services on issues aimed at helping businesses, especially SMEs. In the rapporteur's view, the strategy can provide new opportunities for SMEs, which are the backbone of the EU's economies.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: Writing. \u2012 I decided to support the report presented, because the completion of the single market has always been a fundamental political priority in the process of European integration. I appreciate that in recent years, very important steps have been taken in various areas during the term of office of the Barroso Commission. On the other hand, the current situation forces us to take an even more pragmatic and decisive stance. I believe that the European Parliament can make a significant contribution to making the single market strategy more ambitious, through proposals in individual areas. Parliament should also concentrate its efforts on creating a more modern and innovative, stronger and fairer market. Personally, I believe that political priorities should be to strengthen the competitiveness of businesses (and, consequently, increase employment), as well as better enforcement, better regulation and the promotion of consumer protection.

name: Kosma Złotowski (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 The Single Market is one of the few indisputable achievements of European integration which, in the face of many of the crises affecting the EU today, is an example of the success of the cooperation model adopted by the Member States. Creating a level playing field and non-discriminatory rules for the functioning of economic operators in all Member States is a historic opportunity for the countries of Central and Eastern Europe to catch up economically with their Western European partners.  The world is constantly changing and the shape of the single market, designed in its current form in the early 1990s, must also change. The growing role of SMEs in the European economy or the digital revolution are issues that we need to better include in the definition of the Single Market. Strengthening the principle of the free movement of goods and services should be one of the priorities of the current European Commission. This is particularly important in the context of actions taken by countries such as Germany and France, which are hitting the freedom of transport companies to operate Polish. The Commission's proposed amendments to the Posted Workers Directive, which may restrict the freedoms of the Single Market, are also of concern. There should be no consent to such actions. I fully support all steps to ensure better enforcement of European law in the area of freedom to do business in the EU, and I hope that this report will contribute to strengthening the single market.

name: Carlos Zorrinho (S&D)
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the Comi report which presents a new holistic view of the European single market on the basis of the green market social economy and knowledge, seeking to unleash the full potential of the single market for the benefit of consumers, workers and businesses. I would remind you that the single market has been subject to many positive developments in recent years, but that it could improve in almost all areas, especially in the digital sector, improving mobility and social rights for workers and encouraging start-ups.  I would like to point out the proposals put forward by the European Socialist Group to strengthen the removal of unjustified obstacles to the single market in order to achieve tangible and rapid results in terms of sustainable growth, research, innovation, job creation, especially among young people, consumer freedom of choice and competitiveness. I would remind you that, in order to achieve these objectives, efforts should be made to further harmonise European legislation where necessary and appropriate, while ensuring the highest possible level of consumer protection.

name: Marco Zullo (EFDD)
text: in writing. The report, which I voted in favour of, comes within the framework of initiatives to propose improvements to consolidate the single market. The text shows that attention is paid to the protection of citizens as consumers but also as workers, who need adequate protection, but at the same time we have clearly stressed the importance of creating a fertile market for the growth of SMEs through simple and clear rules. On the subject of the sharing economy, which is already aware that it must safeguard the legitimate interests of those operating in the market, the Commission is asked to coordinate and manage the needs of this new market so as not to allow regulatory fragmentation to prevent society from reaping the full potential benefits.  I have fought for the Commission to establish a system of protection based on geographical indications for non-agri-food products. A system that will allow the excellence of our continent to see its peculiarities recognized and to be recognized as a competitive advantage over low-cost products from emerging economies. In addition, there is the request to provide for a regulatory framework for the indication of origin and production on labels, the so-called "Made In".

name: Milan Zver (PPE)
text: Writing. \ u2012 I supported the report on the Single Market Strategy. The Single Market Strategy is expected to bring new impetus for SMEs and start-ups, as well as increase the number of sustainable jobs. The EU must exploit the potential of the single market in order to maintain global competitiveness and improve the well-being of citizens.
